title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Economy Shrinks
description: Brazil's gross domestic product fell by 5 percent in the most recent quarter, as rising inflation and high interest rates offset a sharp increase in exports, according to a government report. The report, released by the statistics agency IBGE, said the country's gross domestic product totaled 344.3 billion reais ($120 billion) in the period, which was the first quarter of the 2003 fiscal year. The figure was down 5 percent from the fourth quarter, which traditionally has the fastest growth of the year. The economy grew 15 percent from the first quarter of 2002 and economists expect the country's economy to grow at an annual rate of 1.5 percent to 1.9 percent this year if inflation subsides and the government can reduce interest rates. Exports in the most recent quarter rose to 61.7 billion reais from 34.2 billion reais a year earlier. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: The Scramble for Hard Money
description: As President Bush's drive for re-election cash jangles across the land like a platinum-plated juggernaut, the Democrats can only envy the Republicans' longstanding edge in organizing donors. For years, the G.O.P. invested more heavily than the Democrats in the direct-mail, small-donor techniques of raising cash. The latest tallies from last year's Congressional elections show this Republican advantage paying off handsomely, perchance temporarily, now that the era of unlimited ''soft money'' donations from corporations, unions and individuals has been ended by the McCain-Feingold law. With its superior donor base, the G.O.P. attracted almost 50 percent more contributors than the Democrats and showed a commanding edge among lower-budget donors who gave less than $200 apiece. Sixty-four percent of them gave to the Republicans, versus 35 percent for the supposed party of the people, according to a detailed study by the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan watchdog group.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Plan To Renovate Ellis Island
description: The National Parks Service announced yesterday that it had entered into a public-private partnership to raise $300 million to renovate part of Ellis Island. Some 30 buildings that are part of an old public hospital complex on the island would be redeveloped as a center for the study of immigration, ethnicity and public health. The rehabilitation of the dilapidated structures on the two-thirds of the island that is within New Jersey's boundaries would be led by the nonprofit group Save Ellis Island, based in Gladstone, N.J., if it can raise much of the financing from private sources. The park service announced the plan as its ''preferred option'' and set a 60-day period during which interested parties could comment. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: National Briefing: South
description: VIRGINIA: JUDGE UPHOLDS SNIPER CHARGES A judge refused to dismiss one of the two capital murder charges against John A. Muhammad, one of the people accused in last fall's sniper killings, rejecting claims that prosecutors were overreaching in trying to apply Virginia's new terrorism law to the sniper crimes. Peter Greenspun, a lawyer for Mr. Muhammad, argued that the law was so vague that any crime that produces fear in a community could be prosecuted as terrorism. Mr. Muhammad's lawyers also dropped a request to allow a judge to decide the case alone. Mr. Greenspun said after the hearing that a retooled motion to dismiss would be refiled in a few days but declined to say whether the motion would seek a bench trial. (AP)

description: JAPAN: BANK STAKE SALE The Softbank Corporation said it had agreed to sell its 49 percent stake in Aozora Bank to the American investment bank Cerberus Partners, for 101.1 billion yen ($844 million). Cerberus, which already owns 12 percent of Aozora, the formerly nationalized Nippon Credit Bank, declared its intention to bid for the bank in April. title: AIR PRODUCTS TO PURCHASE ASHLAND UNIT FOR $300 MILLION
description: Air Products and Chemicals Inc., a producer of industrial gas, agreed to buy Ashland Inc.'s electronics-chemicals business for about $300 million to expand its semiconductor product line. The purchase will probably add 1 cent to 2 cents a share to earnings in the first year after completion, Air Products's chief executive, John P. Jones, told investors on a conference call. Ashland's electronics-chemicals unit will allow Air Products, based in Allentown, Pa. to provide more products used in building semiconductor chips and provide consulting and cleaning services. Ashland, based in Covington, Ky., said it would use the proceeds to reduce debt.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Builder Lowers Outlook
description: A building materials conglomerate, CRH, warned investors that profit for the first half of the year would fall at least 18 percent when it reported the results in September, from 196 million euros ($225 million) in 2002 to less than 160 million euros ($184 million). It said the weak United States dollar had diluted its American revenue and wet weather hampered construction activity, particularly in the United States. If the rain stops, full-year profits will recover to surpass last year's figure of 856 million euros ($984 million) before taxes, the company said. CRH, based in Dublin, said it spent 550 million euros ($632 million) in the past six months to buy competitors. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: LSI Logic Says Loss To Be Wider Than Forecast
description: The LSI Logic Corporation, which makes computer chips for DVD players and Sony's PlayStation video-game console, said yesterday that its second-quarter loss would be wider than forecast as the company sold a factory in Japan. Selling the factory would leave LSI with one manufacturing plant in Gresham, Ore. LSI has been forced to cut costs and production after nine consecutive quarterly losses. It shut two plants in 2001 and said in April that it would lay off 580 employees. The net loss will be 43 cents to 50 cents a share, wider than its April forecast, LSI said in a statement. Costs for severance pay, lease terminations and write-offs will be higher, at $140 million to $160 million, because of the additional expenses of trying to sell the Japanese plant, LSI said.

description: A court sentenced two European journalists and their American interpreter to 15-year prison terms after arresting them while they were reporting on Hmong insurgents. title: Technology Briefing | Software: International Game To Buy Acres Gaming
description: International Game Technology, the world's largest slot-machine maker, agreed yesterday to buy Acres Gaming for $130 million to gain software that tracks which games gamblers play. International Game, which will pay $11.50 a share, also makes casino games and equipment, the companies said in a statement. The purchase price is 2.7 percent more than Acres Gaming's closing share price on Friday. International Game, which sells about two-thirds of all slot machines, said the acquisition would allow it to supply casinos with systems that build customer loyalty. Acres Gaming shares rose 6 cents, to $11.26. International Game shares rose 80 cents, to $102.33. International Game said the acquisition would close in the fourth quarter.

Starting August 1, United said it would reinstate service between Chicago and Hong Kong with four flights a week. It plans to increase service between Chicago and Beijing from two flights a week in July to three flights a week and between San Francisco and Hong Kong from three flights a week in July to daily flights starting in August. The airline said it would fly between San Francisco and Shanghai every day, up from five flights a week in July. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: A Monotonic Cyborg Learns to Say 'Pantsuit'
description: In ''Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines,'' just as in ''T2'' a dozen years ago, the original T-1 killer cyborg from the future, played by Arnold Schwarzenegger, does battle on the streets of Los Angeles with an updated, sleeker, deadlier model. Last time, you may recall, it was the T-1000, played with metallic sangfroid by Robert Patrick. Now, in an apparent concession to the turbo-feminist lad-mag action-movie times, the state-of-the-art killer cyborg from the future is the T-X, who touches down on Rodeo Drive in the arresting and unclothed form of Kristanna Loken, and who goes about her subsequent business in a red leather pantsuit and a silver Lexus coupe.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Club Owner Resigns From TV
description: The co-owner of the West Warwick nightclub where 100 people died after a fire in February has resigned as a reporter for a Providence television station, the station said. The man, Jeffrey Derderian, who owned the club with his brother Michael, had been a television reporter in Boston before taking a job with WPRI-TV in Providence on Feb. 17, saying he wanted to shorten his drive to work. The fire occurred three days later as the band Great White took the stage in a burst of fireworks. Mr. Derderian had been on paid leave from the station since the fire. ''With the controversy and tragedy still fresh in everybody's mind, he felt it wasn't realistic that he would be a news reporter,'' his lawyer, Jeffrey Pine, said. ''He felt it was time for him to pursue other means of supporting his family, and it wasn't going to be in the media field.'' Kate Zernike (NYT)

title: DEAN FOODS TO ACQUIRE ORGANIC FOOD PRODUCER
description: The Dean Foods Company, the country's largest dairy distributor, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire all outstanding shares of the Horizon Organic Holding Corporation for $216 million. Horizon Organic, based in Longmont, Colo., makes a variety of products including organic milk, butter and cheese. Under the agreement, expected to close late this year, Dean Foods will pay $24 for each share of Horizon Organic. The offer is a 27 percent premium to Horizon Organic's closing stock price on Friday. The shares closed yesterday at $23.83, up 25 percent. Dean Foods will also assume $40 million in Horizon Organic debt. Dean Foods, based in Dallas, inherited a 13 percent stake in Horizon Organic in late 2001 with the acquisition of the Suiza Foods Corporation.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Boeing Jets Ordered
description: Asia's second-largest carrier, All Nippon Airways, formalized its purchase of 45 737-700 passenger jets from the Boeing Company. The new 142-seat planes are popular on short-haul domestic flights because of their fuel efficiency. By using the planes, ANA said, it expects to save 6 billion yen ($50 million) in annual operating costs by 2011. The first of the jets will be put into service in 2005. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Candidate Voted Twice
description: Daniel F. Mahony, who ran for the Conservative Party's nomination for lieutenant governor in 2002, pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to illegal voting and offering a false document for filing. Officials said Mr. Mahony, who was aligned with Tom Golisano for the conservative nomination, voted twice in two general elections under different spellings of his name and with two different addresses. Mr. Mahony also admitted filing false statements and photographs in a petition to have a fine for a parking ticket reduced. Mr. Mahony, 47, faces a $1,500 fine and 150 hours of community service when he is sentenced Sept. 9. Susan Saulny (NYT)

description: Diane Geppi-Aikens, who coached the Loyola of Maryland women's lacrosse team to a No. 1 ranking and the semifinals of the N.C.A.A. Division I tournament this season while in a motorized wheelchair with brain cancer, died Sunday at her home in Baltimore. She was 40.

title: Market Place; G.M. Profit Gets Lift From Pension Deal
description: You might think that a company selling $13.1 billion of bonds to raise cash for its needy pension fund would be losing money. But it turns out that a company can actually book millions of dollars of profit on such a deal, thanks to the peculiar rules that govern pension accounting.

description: The House of Commons voted overwhelmingly tonight to outlaw fox hunting with dogs, but it remained unclear when -- or if -- the ban would be enforced.

title: Oilers Get the Rights To Leetch, for Now
description: With Brian Leetch eligible to become an unrestricted free agent today, the Rangers, with Leetch's blessing, traded his rights to the Edmonton Oilers yesterday for goaltender Jussi Markkanen and a fourth-round pick in next summer's entry draft.

title: White House Weighs Direct Aid For the Palestinian Leadership
description: The Bush administration, seeking ways to encourage compromise in the Middle East, is considering increasing aid to the Palestinians and providing the first direct assistance to the Palestinian Authority, administration officials said today.

title: Johnson & Johnson to Sell Cancer Drug From Millennium Overseas
description: Johnson & Johnson won the right to sell the cancer drug Velcade, made by Millennium Pharmaceuticals, outside the United States under a deal announced yesterday. In May, Velcade was approved in the United States as a treatment for multiple myeloma, and Millennium expects European approval by next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEPBURN, , KATHARINE
description: HEPBURN--Katharine. With the death of Katharine Hepburn, the world has lost one of the most original actors of all time. It also has lost a woman who was as forceful off screen as she was on. Hepburn was a member of the PPFA Board of Advocates and Honorary Chair of the PPFA National Leadership Committee to Keep Abortion Safe and Legal. Her mother was an ardent suffragist who worked with Margaret Sanger. Speaking of Sanger in 1981, Hepburn said, ''it is imperative that I join Planned Parenthood because sadly even today there are those who would completely destroy all of her tireless work and deprive all of us of our right to plan our families''. Twenty years later, with the president and Congress waging a war on women's rights, we need voices like Katharine Hepburn's more than ever. We send our heartfelt sympathies to her family and friends. La Don Love, Chairperson Gloria Feldt, President Planned Parenthood Federation of America >>AD#

title: In a Momentous Term, Justices Remake the Law, and the Court
description: The Supreme Court term that ended last week will leave as big an imprint as any in recent memory -- not only on the country, but on the court itself in ways few could have expected when the term began.

title: A Message to Market Manipulators
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission rarely issues unambiguous decisions, and its latest rulings on the California energy crisis of 2000 and 2001 are no exception. On balance, though, the commission deserves modest applause. In all but one decision -- albeit an important one -- it ruled for the consumers and against the producers and traders whose cynical market manipulations in 2000 and 2001 greatly inconvenienced California residents, bankrupted one major utility and cost the state billions in excess energy costs. Equally important, the rulings reflect a willingness to punish wayward industries, something that would have been inconceivable two years ago, when both the commission and President Bush's senior advisers stupidly turned a deaf ear to pleas from California and other Western states for temporary price controls.

title: Crunching the Market's Numbers: Risk, Yes; Reward, Maybe
description: While no one has discovered a soothsaying method to guarantee wealth in the stock market, the whims of millions of investors do produce robust patterns in the seemingly random price swings.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Toy Store Bidding
description: Hamleys, the British toy retailer that is being pursued by two suitors, withdrew its support for a 52.2 million ($86 million) offer from management and the Baugur Group after a group including Tim Waterstone made a higher bid. Hamleys, which is 243 years old and known for its main store on London's Regent Street, plans to hold further talks with both suitors and advised investors to ''take no action'' regarding either offer, it said. Waterstone, the founder of Britain's Waterstone's book chain and owner of Daisy & Tom children's stores, created a contest for Hamleys on Friday with a bid of 230 pence a share in cash, beating a bid of 226 pence a share from Baugur, Iceland's largest retailer, and Hamleys managers.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- Moscow; Chaos and Contrasts On Crowded City Streets
description: St. Petersburg may be celebrating its 300th anniversary, but Moscow is the city of the future. As Russia's capital, its business and banking center and, with 10 million people, its largest city, Moscow is a chaos of honking horns and crowded streets. It is also a study in contrasts, with the ultrachic GUM (pronounced goom) shopping mall, itself once a dreary Soviet-era department store, looming over older people hawking red T-shirts and Kommunism-in-a-Kan gag gifts (there is nothing inside) and with hip young capitalists jostling past homeless people.

title: MGM to Sell Its Stake in Three Cable Channels

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Reform Vetoed
description: President Ahmet Necdet Sezer vetoed a measure that would have allowed greater freedom to advocate a separate state for the Kurdish minority. The legislation was part of a reform package aimed at bringing Turkey closer to the European Union. The vetoed measure would have lifted a ban on separatist propaganda, a provision critics charge has often been used to jail or silence writers and intellectuals. Dexter Filkins (NYT)

He also served as the Bush administration's liaison to the commission investigating the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. Mr. Ciongoli plans to leave the department next week to become general counsel and a senior vice president for AOL Time Warner's European operations, based in New York City. Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

title: Church's Chicken tried a new approach and disappointed franchise owners.
description: ABOUT a year ago, Church's Chicken made a daring decision: The chain moved to scrap the advertising slogan it had used for 50 years, ''Big Pieces, Little Prices,'' in favor of a less-direct, more thematic approach. But the new tagline, ''Full Flavor, Full Pockets, Full Life,'' and its accompanying cartoon characters, confounded consumers and left franchisees with falling sales.

title: Baylor Player Was Shot, Informant Says
description: An informant told the police that a missing Baylor basketball player was killed by his roommate and former teammate, according to a court document released here today.

title: Judge Releases Audit of Barnes Foundation
description: A county judge near Philadelphia ordered the release yesterday of a highly critical audit of the Barnes Foundation, which is seeking to move its art collection valued at $6 billion from suburban Merion to a downtown location.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Surveillance Ruling Deferred
description: The judge hearing the corruption case of a Brooklyn matrimonial judge declined yesterday to unseal the thousand-plus surveillance tapes that have been submitted to the grand jury. Justice Gerald P. Garson of State Supreme Court is accused of accepting gifts for fixing divorce cases. Several newspapers, including The New York Times, had asked Justice Steven W. Fisher to release the 1,009 audiotapes, 64 videotapes and 40 compact discs made during the investigation of Justice Garson, some with his cooperation and others without. Justice Fisher ruled yesterday that because Justice Garson and some co-defendants were challenging the legality of the surveillance tapes, some of which include sensitive discussions of divorce and child-custody cases, it would be inappropriate to release the tapes before the challenge is heard. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Court Rules On Pop-Up Ads
description: A federal court ruled last week that pop-up ads did not infringe the copyright or trademark rights of the Web sites on which they appear. Judge Gerald Bruce Lee, of the Federal District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, rejected U-Haul's claims that pop-up ads delivered by WhenU.com, an online advertising company, violated federal copyright and trademark laws. While Judge Lee's opinion has not yet been released, legal analysts said the decision was significant for all pop-up companies, including the Gator Corporation, which is facing several federal lawsuits on similar grounds. Bob Tedeschi (NYT)

title: A New Lens Restores Vision and Brings Relief
description: For 17 months, Joe Zienowicz lived in a world of darkness and pain, where every eye blink felt like barbed wire and even the dimmest light was an unbearable torment.

title: Sports of The Times; Miami Leaves, Opting For Sports Safety Net
description: DONNA E. SHALALA, the president of the University of Miami, announced yesterday that the Hurricanes were leaving the Big East and joining the Atlantic Coast Conference. The announcement ended a month of scurrilous accusations -- mostly from other conference members -- backroom maneuvers and intense negotiations between the Big East and Miami, a member since 1991.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hampton Bays: Ground-Breaking For Casino
description: The Shinnecock Indian Nation held a ground-breaking ceremony yesterday for a planned casino, despite a temporary restraining order from the state prohibiting the group from building it, state officials said. Darren Dopp, a spokesman for the New York State attorney general, said that his office had obtained the order because the Shinnecock tribe was not federally recognized and did not have a compact with the state to operate a casino. Two messages left for tribal officials were not immediately returned last night. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: TRENTON REACHES A TENTATIVE DEAL ON STATE BUDGET
description: With a shutdown of some state operations approaching, legislative leaders tentatively agreed Monday night on a spending plan that, for the second year in a row, would cut some services and property tax relief for most New Jerseyans but does not raise major taxes.

title: Few Habitats, Many Species And a Debate on Preservation
description: Conservationists call them hot spots -- habitats that cover just 1.4 percent of the earth's land surface but are so rich in biological diversity that preserving them could keep an astonishing number of plant and animal species off the endangered list.

title: Hiccup for United States On Road to World Cup
description: There is no reaction like an overreaction, or at least that is how it seems after the United States left the Confederations Cup in France without a victory and with a single point after three games. Before the eight-team tournament, United States Coach BRUCE ARENA said some of his players needed ''bloodying,'' in the sense of gaining experience in the cauldron of international soccer.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Sunday about the increased popularity of online dating misstated the Web address for Time Out New York, which offers such a service. It is Timeoutny.com, not TONY.com.

title: Hundreds of Thousands in Hong Kong Protest Security Laws
description: HONG KONG, July 1  Pouring through this city's tropical parks and its canyons of glittering skyscrapers, an immense crowd marched here today to protest the Hong Kong government's plans to impose stringent internal-security laws.

Richardson. Loving grandmother of Donald W. Richardson and Martha Janowski. Also survived by five great grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to attend a memorial service at Saint George's Episcopal Church, 550 Ridgewood Road, Maplewood, Thursday, July 3, 11AM. Interment at the convenience of the family. Inquiries to the Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, 2122 Millburn Avenue, Maplewood, N.J. >>AD#

title: New Kirov Home in Golden Glass
description: In St. Petersburg, a city of classical and neoclassical splendor, the Kirov Ballet is to get a starkly modern glass and marble new home designed by Dominique Perrault of France. His design, of black marble covered with golden-hued glass, won a competition to design the new Maryinsky Theater for the Kirov, and the results were announced on Saturday.

title: The Big East Moves On, To an Uncertain Future
description: The period of grief and commiseration passed quickly for the Big East Conference. Hours after hearing that Miami would join Virginia Tech in switching to the Atlantic Coast Conference for the 2004-5 season, the remaining members of the Big East already were talking about the future.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: IRELAND: BUILDER LOWERS OUTLOOK A building materials conglomerate, CRH, warned investors that profit for the first half of the year would fall at least 18 percent when it reported the results in September, from 196 million euros ($225 million) in 2002 to less than 160 million euros ($184 million). It said the weak United States dollar had diluted its American revenue and wet weather hampered construction activity, particularly in the United States. If the rain stops, full-year profits will recover to surpass last year's figure of 856 million euros ($984 million) before taxes, the company said. CRH, based in Dublin, said it spent 550 million euros ($632 million) in the past six months to buy competitors. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEINGLASS, , FLORENCE
description: STEINGLASS--Florence, widow of Samuel, passed away June 29th, 2003 at the age of 91. Beloved mother of Margaret and husband Al Wirtenberg, Ralph Steinglass and wife Joyce; loving grandmother of David Steinglass and wife Elizabeth, Katherine Steinglass and partner Dave Wine; and adoring greatgrandmother of Oliver and Naomi. Funeral on Thursday, July 3rd, at Bouton Funeral Home, Georgetown, CT. >>AD#

title: Smoking Foes Blame Lobbying For Delay in Fire-Safe Cigarettes
description: Three years after the Legislature required that cigarettes sold in New York be manufactured so they would cause fewer fires, the Pataki administration has yet to issue regulations to put the law into effect, partly because of heavy lobbying by the tobacco industry, opponents of smoking said today.

title: Education Dept. Test Chief Has Resigned, Regents Say
description: The director of the New York State Education Department's testing division was reassigned last week after widespread failures on the state's Math A Regents exam and has chosen to resign, according to members of the Board of Regents.

title: Muslims Recant, and Hindus Are Acquitted in Riot Trial
description: It seemed the moment of vindication had finally arrived for Zahira Sheikh.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about new international pressure on Myanmar's military junta for the release of the leader of the democratic opposition, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, misstated the action taken by Japan. It is suspending new economic assistance to Myanmar, not all economic assistance.

title: CORIXA AND GLAXO'S CANCER DRUG WINS F.D.A. APPROVAL
description: The Corixa Corporation and GlaxoSmithKline said the Food and Drug Administration had approved their Bexxar cancer medicine. Bexxar, a radioactive treatment for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, won approval for some patients whose illness is not controlled by Rituxan, one of the world's best-selling cancer drugs. The medicine will compete with Idec Pharmaceuticals Corporation's Zevalin, which won F.D.A. approval more than a year ago for a similar use. Stock in Corixa, which is based in Seattle, rose 54 cents, or 8 percent, to $7.74 a share. Glaxo is based in Brentford, England.

title: Better Presidential Campaigns for Only $2 More
description: Today many Democratic presidential candidates are expected to report how much money they have raised in the last three months. Meanwhile, President Bush's campaign has raised about $20 million in the last two weeks. The focus on these numbers and what they say about each candidate's prospects distracts attention from the much-needed reform of America's public financing system for presidential campaigns.

title: London Stage Enlists Old Rulers to Make Sport of the Current Crop
description: They are bonkers, these gentlemen who rule the world. Or if they're not crazy, they're sappy and passive, or corrupt and conniving, or just plain unsure. After all, as one of them puts it, a king ''is but a man.''

title: British Show Military Muscles In Town Where 6 Were Killed
description: British troops took a forceful step today toward re-establishing control of a village where six soldiers were killed a week ago, swooping in with tanks and helicopters and apparently questioning witnesses in the police station where the men were gunned down.

title: Ballet for Subway? Well, It Already Has Conductors
description: The sidewalks of New York have their own song. Broadway has several. Well-known plays and movies have been set in or inspired by, among many other New York locations, the Waldorf, the Plaza, Wall Street, Macy's, Yankee Stadium, Tiffany & Company, Katz's Delicatessen and the late Cammareri Brothers Bakery in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn.

Loving father of John Jr., Lisa and Chris Kunstadter and Elizabeth von Habsburg. Devoted grandfather of eight. Dear brother of Peter Kunstadter. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to Bargemusic, Fulton Ferry Landing, Brooklyn, NY 11201. >>AD#

title: Information Resources Sold for $98.4 Million
description: Information Resources in Chicago, which tracks consumer spending on packaged goods, has agreed to be acquired and taken private by a joint venture for $98.4 million, or $3.30 a share.

description: Buddy Hackett, the streetwise comedian from Brooklyn with a face like a plate of mashed potatoes, died yesterday at his beach house in Malibu, Calif. He was 78.

title: Monkey See, Monkey Speak: Facial Expressions as a Guide to Speech
description: Scientists have long known that there is more to speech perception than meets the ear. Humans, even infants who cannot yet speak, pick up visual cues from the movement of the lips and other parts of the face to help understand what it is they are hearing.

description: WEILGUS--Nettie. Heartfelt condolences are extended to: her children, generous supporter and member of the Stern College for Women Board of Directors, Eudice (and Irving) Rohinsky, Hindy (and Samuel) Ciner, Simmy (and Susan) Weilgus, and Naomi (and Daniel) Feuer; her brother Robert (and Miriam) Cohen; her thirteen grandchildren, and ten great grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Marjorie Diener Blenden, Chairman SCW Board of Directors >>AD#

title: ADIDAS SAYS NORTH AMERICAN SALES DOWN AT LEAST 10%
description: Adidas-Salomon , the sporting-goods maker, said its North American order backlog was down 10 percent to 15 percent in the second quarter as a sluggish economy hurt demand. Revenue from the region, which accounts for a third of total sales, will not grow this year, the chief executive, Herbert Hainer, said at a sports-equipment fair in Munich. Adidas, based in Herzogenaurach, Germany, maintained its sales and earnings forecasts for 2003.

Services Tuesday, 9:45AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave. >>AD#

description: Robert McCloskey, the writer and illustrator whose classic children's books -- among them ''Make Way for Ducklings'' and ''Blueberries for Sal'' -- captivated generations of young readers and their parents, died yesterday on Deer Isle, Maine. He was 88.

description: Shortly after the end of the Persian Gulf war in 1991, the newly semi-autonomous Kurdish region in northern Iraq held a rare democratic election. The region-wide election, however, provoked a civil war. There has not been another since.

title: Cleric Wants Iraqis to Write Constitution
description: Iraq's leading Shiite cleric has issued a ruling condemning the idea of a constitutional council put together by the American occupation authority, saying Iraqis should elect the drafters of their constitution.

description: The income tax increase on New York City's top earners that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed into law yesterday should start to be reflected in their paychecks within the next two or three weeks, city officials said.

description: Marriott International said yesterday that it had completed the installation of wireless high-speed Internet access systems in 400 hotels in the United States, Canada, Britain and Germany. Marriott said the wireless Internet service, commonly known as Wi-Fi, was available in hotel lobbies, meeting rooms and other public spaces. It said it was the largest such deployment in the hotel industry.

title: Public Health vs. Civil Liberties, Hawaiian Style: Rabies Quarantine Eased for Pets
description: For almost a century, people who brought their pets to Hawaii have had to quarantine them for as long as four months before they could take them home. Yesterday, that requirement, which was intended to ensure that Hawaii remains the only state without rabies, was eased considerably, and many pets will be able to skip quarantine.

Criticized by Vancouver Group, I.O.C. Official Denies Conflict of Interest

title: Rescuing Liberia
description: The United States cannot send troops to pacify every international conflict or relieve every humanitarian emergency. But the United Nations' secretary general, Kofi Annan, makes a compelling case for dispatching an American-led international force to Liberia. Washington is the appropriate leader for any international effort to rescue Liberia, a troubled West African nation that was founded by freed American slaves and has longstanding economic and political links to the United States. The Bush administration is divided over the issue, and a decision by President Bush is expected imminently. He should respond positively to Mr. Annan's plea.

title: A Judge in the Mold of Hoffman (Abbie, That Is)
description: GUSTIN L. REICHBACH, his flowing locks of curly hair shorn to a respectable length and tinged with gray, had a troubled relationship with authority before he became authority. And as much as he likes being a justice in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, and he does, he also does not want respectability to tarnish his credentials as a former student radical.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Hospital Demolition
description: Under pressure from preservationists, Cook County commissioners voted to delay razing the 88-year-old Cook County Hospital building to allow more public hearings. Commissioners said they would explore demolition and redevelopment possibilities with contractors. Ainsley O'Connell (NYT)

title: China Opens a Door to Trade
description: Corporate executives and lawyers poring over Sunday's free trade agreement between Hong Kong and mainland China say that Beijing has taken a fairly significant step toward opening the Chinese economy to international competition.

description: The private equity firms CVC Capital Partners and the Texas Pacific Group are joining together to bid for Debenhams, the British department store chain that traces its origin back to 1778, executives close to negotiations said today.

Bulger, the University of Massachusetts president, gave an incorrect surname from The Boston Globe for the president of the faculty union at UMass Amherst, whom the paper quoted on Mr. Bulger's role in university budget problems. He is Dan Clawson. (Dan Georgianna is president of the faculty union at UMass Dartmouth.)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Body Found In Suitcase
description: Two men walking in Chinatown about 2 a.m. yesterday found a suitcase on the corner of East Broadway and Forsythe Street that contained the headless, legless body of a man, the police said yesterday. The man could not be immediately identified. An autopsy yesterday was inconclusive and investigators were unsure of the race and age of the victim, as well as how he died, the police said. The police were fingerprinting the dead man's hands to see if he had a criminal record. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Accounts
description: ESPN, Bristol, Conn., expanded its relationship with the New York office of Wieden & Kennedy, naming the agency to handle the account of ESPN Videogames, a new joint venture with a unit of Sega of America. Billings were estimated at $10 million. Wieden & Kennedy handles the account of ESPN, which is owned by the Walt Disney Company and the Hearst Corporation. Sega of America is part of the Sega Corporation.

title: Across U.S., Redistricting as a Never-Ending Battle
description: For most of the past century, redistricting has been a fairly predictable though often contentious ritual. Every 10 years, state legislators would use the new census data to redraw Congressional district lines, and the party in power would usually manage to draw maps that gave it an advantage.

title: The Downside of Big Babies
description: Big babies -- nine-pounders and up -- are on the rise. And while it's better for babies to be large than small, newborns over nine pounds face some health concerns of their own, including complications in delivery and higher risk of adult obesity or diabetes.

description: California's charter schools typically perform as well as their traditional counterparts, despite facing persistent financial obstacles and relying on far more uncertified teachers, according to a state-sponsored study released yesterday.

description: It's the season of the whine -- the high-pitched note that signals a prowling mosquito near your ear, and the even more annoying complaints emitted by humans wondering whether mosquitoes really should have a place in the web of life.

description: ALMOST everything you read in travel columns about frequent-flier miles is focused on the availability (or more often unavailability) of point redemptions for free trips.

description: The Major League Baseball commissioner's office granted the Yankees' request today to put outfielder Bubba Trammell on the restricted list, freeing his roster spot and allowing the team not to pay him. But Trammell might not stay on that list for long.

title: Reports Detail Tests of Troops For Exposures
description: The Pentagon made public today a final set of reports on a cold war program that tested the vulnerability of American forces to unconventional attack, having identified 5,842 people who may have been exposed to chemical or biological agents.

title: Shuttle Controller Said Foam Strike Was 'Not Even Worth Mentioning,' Files Show
description: A flight director told the Columbia crew during their mission that the debris strike on liftoff was ''not even worth mentioning,'' except that reporters might ask about it at a news conference, according to e-mail messages released today.

title: Sharon and Abbas Meet and Stress Future
description: JERUSALEM, July 1  Appearing side by side before meeting here this evening, the Israeli and Palestinian prime ministers declared their mutual respect and hopes for peace, while Israeli forces prepared to withdraw Wednesday from the West Bank town of Bethlehem.

title: Afghanistan's Future, Lost in the Shuffle
description: Ten miles outside this dust-blown city, the historical capital of Afghanistan, gunmen belonging to the local warlord guard the airport, which American forces use as a base. The hefty fee the guards get from the United States has allowed them to build a marble-faced barracks nearby.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Sentence For Former State Aide
description: Moments after a tearful plea to the court, Scott Fawell, once a top assistant to former Gov. George Ryan, was sentenced to six and a half years in prison for racketeering. Mr. Fawell, 46, told Judge Rebecca R. Pallmeyer of Federal District Court that he was sorry for his role in a scheme to use state workers to campaign for Mr. Ryan, who was then secretary of state. Mr. Fawell's lawyer, Ed Gensen, tried to persuade the judge that Mr. Fawell's sentence should be reduced to about five years because he had not known he was committing a crime. Mr. Fawell, who plans to appeal the judge's ruling, is scheduled to begin his sentence in November. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: PLAN TO RENOVATE ELLIS ISLAND The National Parks Service announced yesterday that it had entered into a public-private partnership to raise $300 million to renovate part of Ellis Island. Some 30 buildings that are part of an old public hospital complex on the island would be redeveloped as a center for the study of immigration, ethnicity and public health. The rehabilitation of the dilapidated structures on the two-thirds of the island that is within New Jersey's boundaries would be led by the nonprofit group Save Ellis Island, based in Gladstone, N.J., if it can raise much of the financing from private sources. The park service announced the plan as its "preferred option" and set a 60-day period during which interested parties could comment. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Chicago Says Owner Lacked Building Permit for Porches
description: The owners of a building where 12 people were killed early Sunday in a porch collapse did not have permits to build the porches, city officials said late today.

title: Hepburn: An Inestimable Self
description: If you went searching the world for a perfectly selfless egotism, a person so ravished with self-confidence that she had the capacity to illuminate everyone around her, you might well end up settling upon Katharine Hepburn -- except that Miss Hepburn left this world on Sunday, from her home in Connecticut, at the age of 96. What the world would be like if we all had the inner confidence that Miss Hepburn projected is unknowable, but the odds are that it would be a much more interesting and probably a much happier place. Certainty made her look a little brittle when she was young -- that and a body that seemed as light as a kite. But the brittleness wore off, and she reminded us again and again that self is a gift not to be doubted or squandered or pawned for less than it's worth.

description: Listening while driving seems to be safe, even if the listening is absorbing much of the driver's attention. But talking while driving, it seems, is a different matter.

title: Two Shoot 69 to Lead Ike After First Round
description: Jay Blumenfeld of Mountain Ridge and Michael Mazzella of Orange County shot three-under-par 69's and led after the first round of the Ike, the Metropolitan Golf Association stroke-play championship.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Stake Sale
description: The Softbank Corporation said it had agreed to sell its 49 percent stake in Aozora Bank to the American investment bank Cerberus Partners, for 101.1 billion yen ($844 million). The sale will be completed by the end of August, pending approval by financial regulators. Cerberus, which already owns 12 percent of Aozora, the formerly nationalized Nippon Credit Bank, declared its intention to bid for the bank in April. Softbank, which needs cash to finance its high-speed Internet business, said it would book a 3.5 billion yen loss from the sale. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: THIS could have been the best day of the year in tennis, anywhere. The Round of 16 at Wimbledon, everybody playing, weather permitting. Hard to know where to go first.

title: Schrder's Economic Plan Is Aided by a Union and His Party
description: In Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's long uphill battle to resuscitate the Germany economy, he has been thwarted at every step by two seemingly immovable obstacles: Germany's deeply rooted labor unions and Europe's unforgiving laws on government budgets.

title: Court Halts a Bid by Intel to Stop E-Mail
description: The California Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a former employee of Intel was free to send e-mail messages to current company employees, overturning a lower court's injunction. The court rejected Intel's argument that the messages represented illegal trespassing to its computer systems.

title: A Bevy of Eccentrics In a Dreaming Frenzy
description: For four days last week Symphony Space was the site of a de facto mini-festival of experimental opera. But love them or hate them, the three short music-theater works by the composer John Eaton, presented by the Pocket Opera Players, and the 60-minute ''Vera of Las Vegas'' by the composer Daron Hagen and the librettist Paul Muldoon, presented by the Center for Contemporary Opera, were not operas in any remotely traditional sense.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Official Hired Killer
description: A court sentenced Karel Srba, a former Foreign Ministry official, to eight years in prison for plotting to kill a reporter. Mr. Srba, former chief of personnel at the ministry, was convicted of hiring Karel Rziepel, an ex-convict, to blow up the car of the reporter, Sabina Slonkova, last summer. Her articles in Mlada Fronta Dnes, the leading daily, had implicated Mr. Srba in a financial scam. The plot was foiled after Mr. Rziepel had second thoughts. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Giants Stadium Lands The Italian Super Cup
description: Italy's Serie A was the most glamorous soccer league in Europe more than five years ago because it attracted the best players in the world with high transfer fees and lucrative contracts. After falling behind in recent years, it is now looking to regain the prestige it lost to England's Premier League and Spain's La Liga.

title: Copenhagen Journal; Free Spirits in Their Fortress, the Law at the Gate
description: Ever since a group of squatters took over an abandoned military fortress in the heart of this intimate, orderly city 32 years ago, their ''Free Town,'' Christiania, has caused the government untold heartburn.

title: Sharon and Abbas Discuss Next Peace Steps
description: JERUSALEM, July 1  Appearing side by side before meeting here, the Israeli and Palestinian prime ministers declared their mutual respect and hopes for peace this evening, while Israeli forces prepared to withdraw from the West Bank town of Bethlehem on Wednesday.

title: Mets Trade Roberto Alomar to White Sox
description: The Mets, an expensive and colossal bust, began preparing for the future today by trading second baseman Roberto Alomar to the Chicago White Sox for three prospects. Alomar played only 222 games for the Mets over two frustrating seasons.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Economic Growth
description: India's gross domestic product grew 4.3 percent in the year ended March 2003 compared with 5.6 percent in the previous year. India's fiscal year runs from April through March. A statement by the government said growth in the farm sector diminished to 3.2 percent in the year, compared with 3.4 percent a year earlier. However, manufacturing appeared to be reviving. The sector showed a spike, growing 7.1 percent in the last quarter compared with 4.1 percent a year earlier. Saritha Rai (NYT)

The decline of $55.5 million is the first decrease since 1997. But the amount paid in settlements has more than doubled over the last decade. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been urging a number of changes in state law to limit the city's liability. Michael Cooper (NYT)

description: Exhausted from a weekend of budget negotiations and an all-night bargaining session that ended after sunup this morning, New Jersey legislators narrowly averted a government shutdown today by approving a $24.1 billion state budget that increases an assortment of taxes.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Rail Strike Ends
description: Railroad union members voted overwhelmingly to return to work after half the system's 22,000 workers refused to strike. The union, affiliated with the Korean Confederation of Trade Unions, recognized the unpopularity of the strike, which had forced cancellation of more than half the passenger trains and more than 90 percent of the freight trains for four days. Chun Hwan Kyu, the railway union's leader, announced the settlement on television and apologized for the inconvenience. Government officials promised to investigate union leaders for what the government said was an illegal strike. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: I.O.C. Will Vote Today On Host for 2010 Games
description: It is always preferable to have bid to play host to the Olympics and won than to be 24 hours from the International Olympic Committee's vote on which bid will win. Just ask Valentino Castellani, who was mayor of Turin, Italy, in 1999, when his city won the right to stage the 2006 Winter Games.

description: Five days before traveling to Africa, the epicenter of the AIDS epidemic, President Bush today named a former pharmaceutical company executive to coordinate the administration's global AIDS policy.

title: Henley Regatta Blend of Old and New
description: The Henley Royal Regatta, with its blue hydrangeas accenting the lawns of the Stewards Enclosure, prides itself on maintaining the traditions of this beautiful pageant of English life, as Winston Churchill described that oldest of all rowing events. This year's regatta, which begins today in Henley-on-Thames, England, will also accentuate some of the event's more recent trends.

title: Travel Industry Fears New Rules Could Deter Visits to U.S.
description: The Travel Industry Association of America warned today that several new security measures intended to prevent terrorists from entering the United States would also quite likely deter foreign tourists' visits.

title: U.S. Hostages in Iran Are Denied Damages
description: A federal appeals court ruled today that the Americans held in Iran for more than 400 days beginning in 1979 cannot receive damages from Tehran because the agreement that freed them barred such lawsuits.

title: China's Leader Gives No Sign of Changes to Come
description: President Hu Jintao said in a major address today that the ''foremost political duty'' of China's leaders was to carry out the ideological theories of his predecessor, Jiang Zemin, disappointing some reformists who hoped he would advocate at least a modest agenda for political change.

description: The New Jersey General Assembly approved a measure today to eliminate the post of state poet laureate. The legislation would effectively remove the poet, Amiri Baraka, who had caused a furor with his poem referring to the 9/11 attacks.

description: With Iran coming under mounting pressure to open up its nuclear program, the International Atomic Energy Agency and the Iranian authorities announced today that Dr. Mohamed ElBaradei, the Egyptian who heads the United Nations agency, would visit on July 9, his second trip to Iran this year.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Trade Surplus Slips
description: Brazil's trade surplus narrowed in June for the first month in four as a strengthening currency curbed exports. The surplus fell to $2.4 billion from a record $2.5 billion in May, the government said. Exports fell to $5.87 billion from $6.37 billion in May while imports fell to $3.52 billion from $3.87 billion.

description: THE BOOK AGAINST GOD

title: Finding That Today's Students Are Bright, Eager and Willing to Cheat
description: As a high school student working in a university professor's neurobiology laboratory, a 17-year-old Manhattan girl endorsed a strong code of scientific values. Honesty was essential, she said.

title: Wine for Appetizer, Entree and Dessert
description: THE tail wags the dog at Morrells, but what a tail. The restaurant is a greatly expanded version of the little wine bar and cafe next to the Morrells wine store in Rockefeller Center, and although the scale has changed, the concept remains the same: shock and awe. Diners face a nonstop bombardment of fine wines before, during and after the meal. The choices run into the thousands. The list of wines by the glass, normally a convenient way of narrowing the selection process, does not help. There can be as many as 150 ready to pour. If this sounds like a wine-lover's paradise, it is.

title: HOCKEY: Hockey Analysis; Lower Costs, Higher Hopes
description: Unless he gave himself a raise for taking on another role, Glen Sather probably saved the Rangers some money yesterday by assuming permanent coaching duties while continuing as president and general manager. Coaches can earn $1 million a year in the National Hockey League. A million here, a million there, and pretty soon you're talking real money.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Food-Stamp Fine
description: The Department of Agriculture on Monday fined the state $24.7 million for errors in its food stamp program. With an error rate of 14.1 percent, almost six percentage points above the national average of 8.26 percent, Michigan has the second-highest error rate in the nation, after California. Federal officials said that in 2002, Michigan issued $61.5 million in stamps to those who were ineligible for assistance and failed to issue $29.3 million in stamps to those who were eligible. Lawrence Rudmann, the agriculture department's director of public affairs for the Midwest, said the state could either pay the fine or work out a plan to reinvest the money in program improvement. Caitlin Nish (NYT)

title: Turnpike and Parkway Workers Avert Strikes Before the Holiday
description: Negotiators for two of New Jersey's busiest highways and their unionized toll collectors reached tentative agreements on new contracts yesterday afternoon, averting possible strikes or other job actions on the Fourth of July holiday.

title: Math Failures Are Raising Concerns About Curriculum
description: Everyone knows now that the June 17 Math A Regents exam was problematic, with almost two out of three test-takers failing.

title: Postpunk Power and Pugnacity, via Iceland
description: In the balmy sunshine on Saturday afternoon at Central Park Summerstage, Henrik Bjornsson of the band Singapore Sling stuck to his lyrics and sang, ''It's so cold outside.'' It's probably a more appropriate sentiment when the band is at home in Iceland. Singapore Sling was headlining a bill with three Icelandic bands that were trolling rock's past. Between sets Steindor Andersen sang the unaccompanied traditional songs called rimur.

description: PeopleSoft Inc. said today that it expected to beat analysts' estimates for its second-quarter earnings, despite having to fend off a hostile takeover attempt by Oracle Corp.

title: Thin Rays of Mideast Hope
description: One of the remarkable aspects of the Israeli-Palestinian struggle is that after so many failed attempts at peace, new initiatives can still rouse hopes. They may not be high for the success of the ''road map,'' and every politician on every side has taken care to raise the caution flags. Indeed, everything being witnessed these days -- the summit meetings, the cease-fires, the pullbacks -- has been done before. For Hamas and Islamic Jihad, a three-month cease-fire is a tactic, not a conversion. The Israelis are still working on their separation wall, and are a long way from actually uprooting a real settlement.

description: The Baltimore Orioles are a franchise stuck in neutral, without star power and annually buried in the standings. Mike Mussina bailed out after 10 years here following the 2000 season, lured by the Yankees' lucrative contract offer and their winning ways. When he returns to Camden Yards, Mussina usually reminds the Orioles of what they are missing.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Board Approves Same-Sex Registry
description: The Cook County Board of Commissioners approved a same-sex partnership registry, officially recognizing gay and lesbian relationships. While the registry would not give same-sex couples any new rights, it is intended to serve as an official government document to prove that they are domestic partners and are therefore entitled to benefits. Beginning in October, same-sex couples can go to the county office where marriage licenses are issued, sign an affidavit stating they are in a committed relationship, pay a $30 filing fee and receive a certificate confirming their registration. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Foreign Investment Falls
description: The Bank of Korea reported that foreign direct investment for the first five months of this year totaled only $412 million, about half the $812 million invested in the same period last year. Foreign direct investment for all of last year was $2 billion, down from $9.6 billion in 2000. President Roh Moo Hyun asked his cabinet to work out a program for bringing in foreign investment. The Korea-U.S. Business Council, in a recent white paper, cited labor problems as a major factor, along with government regulations, behind the reluctance of foreign companies to open offices and set up plants in Korea. The Bank of Korea also noted poor economic conditions abroad and declining profits. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Three Cheers for the Red, White and Blueberry
description: THIS Friday may not be the nation's greatest gastronomic moment. The Fourth of July tends to be a day when culinary ambition takes a sharp turn, when Americans home in on the relaxed, unpretentious fare they are known for, and that almost everyone, even a repressed cook, knows how to do. It takes no special skill to lay burgers on a grill and stand by drinking beer, and so what? It's fun.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: PROTESTERS SUE CITY A lawsuit claims the police brutally tried to rein in an antiwar rally in February by beating protesters with batons, allowing horses to trample others and holding detainees for hours without food or water. The federal civil rights suit was filed yesterday by 15 protesters who were among several hundred arrested at the Feb. 15 demonstration, which stretched more than 20 blocks on the East Side of Manhattan. Some of the plaintiffs have filed civilian complaints with the Police Department that are pending, said William Goodman, one of the lawyers who filed the suit. So far, 70 complaints connected to the Feb. 15 rally have been filed with the Police Department's civilian review board, said Ray Patterson, a spokesman for the board. The police said they had not seen the lawsuit and had no immediate comment. (AP)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: PeopleSoft Urges Rejection Of Oracle Bid
description: PeopleSoft, the business-software maker, said yesterday that the Oracle Corporation's $6.3 billion hostile offer to buy the company has ''massive downside risk,'' partly because clients were delaying purchases until the matter is resolved. Antitrust regulators might block Oracle's plan, customers would not be able to upgrade their PeopleSoft software, PeopleSoft's directors wrote to shareholders, adding that Oracle's offer was risky because it could be withdrawn at any time. PeopleSoft cited the damage to its business in a lawsuit filed last month. The company's $65 million project to install financial software for the government of Los Angeles County has been suspended over concern that Oracle would not support the programs, a county official said. Other clients have also said they were concerned about losing their investments in PeopleSoft products. Oracle's chief executive, Lawrence J. Ellison, has vowed to back PeopleSoft's products for at least a decade. But the company also said it would encourage customers to switch to its products. Oracle offered $19.50 a share for PeopleSoft last month to secure its No. 2 ranking behind SAP in sales of software for business tasks like payroll and accounting. Shares of Oracle rose 32 cents, or 2.6 percent, to $12.33. PeopleSoft shares rose 23 cents, or 1.1 percent, to $17.79.

title: Lehman Looks to Expand
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it was in talks to buy the asset manager Neuberger Berman Inc. as it sought to compete with bigger rivals in managing money for wealthy clients.

title: OIL AND GAS DRILLER BUYS RIVAL IN $190 MILLION DEAL
description: The Unit Corporation, a driller of land-based oil and natural-gas wells, said it had agreed to buy a rival, PetroCorp, for about $190 million in cash and stock to expand its holdings in Louisiana and Texas. The purchase price includes two million Unit shares, valued at $41.8 million based on Monday's closing price, Unit said. The offer is valued at $14.50 a share of PetroCorp. The acquisition will increase earnings and cash flow immediately, said Larry D. Pinkston, the chief financial officer. Both companies are based in Tulsa, Okla.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Venture
description: The Russian oil producer Lukoil set up a joint venture with the country's natural gas monopoly, Gazprom, to develop a large oil and gas field in the Caspian Sea. Each company will own half of the new concern, which will work together with Kazakhstan's natural gas company, Kazmunaigaz, to develop the field. The field, near the border between Russia and Kazakhstan in the waters of the Caspian, is estimated to contain about 3.8 billion barrels of oil equivalent, Lukoil said in a statement. description: Calling Joseph P. Ganim's crimes the ''stuff that cynicism is made of,'' a federal judge today sentenced Mr. Ganim, the former mayor of Bridgeport, to nine years in prison for systematically using his office to enrich himself.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: UNEMPLOYMENT STEADY Unemployment in the 12-member euro zone stayed at 8.8 percent in May, the third month in a row, the European statistics office, Eurostat, said. Germany and France, the two biggest economies, had rates of 9.4 percent and 9.1 percent respectively, while Spain had the highest jobless rate, 11.3 percent. Economists say unemployment is likely to rise as a result of economic weakness. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Balanchine's Abstract Vision of Love
description: George Balanchine first read Shakespeare in Russian. Perhaps that is why his ballet ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' for the New York City Ballet has less of an English literary tone than a musical sensibility derived from its Mendelssohn score. Yet Balanchine's knowledge of Shakespeare's play was deep.

title: The Ten Commandments Judge
description: Judges are often celebrated for their wisdom, compassion or legal acumen, but Roy Moore, the chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, has earned his fame in a different way. He is known as the Ten Commandments judge. As a trial court judge, he hung a wooden Ten Commandments plaque in his courtroom. When he became chief justice, he installed a two-and-a-half-ton Ten Commandments monument in the rotunda of the Alabama State Judicial Building. In an important First Amendment ruling yesterday, a federal appeals court ordered Chief Justice Moore to remove the monument. Once it is gone, Alabama voters must find a way to remove Mr. Moore.

title: How Not To Fix Medicare
description: Today we remember Medicare's establishment in July 1965 as a ringing affirmation of the ideal of social insurance. Less well remembered is how close Washington came to creating a very different system. Not long before Medicare's passage, the Kennedy administration seemed on the verge of a compromise with Senator Jacob Javits, the moderate Republican from New York. Senator Javits and his allies wanted to give private insurance a leading place in the new program so government could play a smaller role -- an idea opposed by liberal Democrats and organized labor. The opposition won out, and the private insurance idea seemed consigned to the dustbin of history.

title: A Teacher Who Helps the Many Become One
description: Suzanna McNamara has backpacked in Patagonia and worked at a Wyoming hunting camp and aboard a trawler in the Bering Sea. But she has found the ultimate challenge at a new alternative high school in the Bronx, where she is teaching English to teenage immigrants.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: AIRPORT GUARDS CHARGED A group of border guards from Sheremetyevo Airport in Moscow were arrested and charged with forging documents and selling them to Russian criminals who sought to leave the country, Russian news agencies reported. The police did not say how many guards were arrested or when the arrests took place. Political commentators explained the arrests as part of an anticorruption campaign being conducted by the government in advance of parliamentary elections in December.

title: Near Kips Bay, the Scent of a Vietnamese Summer
description: IN a city that has been long obsessed with Asian cuisines, Vietnamese food is often overlooked. It lacks the obvious fireworks of Chinese, and it seems quiet next to the sass and panache of Thai cuisine. But sweating through the first heat wave of the summer, I was drawn to the lively simplicity of good Vietnamese cooking.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Bomb Explodes At Mosque
description: A bomb exploded during evening prayers in a mosque in Kandahar, in the south, injuring 28 people, three of them seriously, local officials said. The bomb, left in a discarded jacket, narrowly missed the prominent anti-Taliban cleric, Maulavi Abdullah Fayaz, who was leading the evening prayers. He blamed the explosion on Taliban supporters and called them enemies of the state. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Japanese Winning Cleanup Battles

description: The Bush administration suspended all American military assistance to 35 countries today because they refused to pledge to give American citizens immunity before the International Criminal Court.

description: The woman answering the phone yesterday at the old Community School District 26 in Queens was a little confused. ''I'm really not sure what this office is called at this time,'' she said.

title: Modern German Duty: The Obligation to Play
description: This capital city, as leafy and uncongested a great world capital as you're likely to find, is like a vast continuous sidewalk cafe these days of summer, when darkness doesn't descend until 10 p.m. or so, and from staid Charlottenburg in the old West to trendy Prenzlauerberg in the East everybody seems to be breakfasting, lunching and dining outdoors.

title: Arnold Is Chosen For Amtrak Account
description: Amtrak has named the McLean, Va., office of Arnold Worldwide to handle creative duties on its account, which had been handled since 2001 by White & Baldacci in Herndon, Va. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $30 million.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: QWEST GETS MORE TIME TO FILE RESULTS With its accounting practices still under investigation, Qwest Communications International said yesterday that it had been given until Sept. 30 to release its audited 2002 annual report and first-quarter information for 2003. A company spokesman, Chris Hardman, said it was the second time that lenders had agreed to an extension. Qwest had been facing a July 15 deadline. Mr. Hardman said the waivers gave Qwest more time to restate earnings from 2000 and 2001. The waivers involve the company's Qwest Services Corporation credit center and a term loan to QwestDex, its phone directory unit. In February, Qwest released an unaudited 2002 statement that showed the company had lost $35.9 billion, or $21.35 a share, compared with a loss of $4.8 billion, or $2.88 a share, in 2001. The 2002 loss included a $30 billion goodwill reduction and $10.9 billion in asset impairments. Revenue in 2002 was $15.5 billion, down about 7 percent from $16.7 billion in 2001. Qwest shares rose 19 cents yesterday, to $4.97.    (AP)

title: Skepticism Lives on Scarred Jerusalem Street
description: Walk along Jaffa Road, the badly scarred commercial artery that runs through downtown Jerusalem, and you can scarcely travel a block without passing the scene of a previous Palestinian bombing.

title: Recipe: Blueberry Tart With Crme Frache and Honey Creme
description: Time: 1 1/2 hours plus 4 1/2 hours' chilling

title: Madrid Regional Legislature Is Split Over Corruption Charges
description: Rafael Simancas, the Socialist candidate to lead the Community of Madrid, one of the richest and most populous of Spain's 17 autonomous regions, should be enjoying the first of four years in office.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Reality Show Resumes
description: ''Cabin Fever,'' the Irish reality television show on a boat, went back on the air more than two weeks after its ship ran aground and sank on Friday, June 13. Coco Television, which is producing the show for Irish state broadcaster RTE, recruited two new contestants after some of the shipwrecked cast members refused to participate, and contracted a new 96-foot boat, the Johanna Lucretia, which originally sailed with the Belgian Navy in the 1940's. Viewers can force contestants to walk the plank by voting with a telephone call or text message, and the final contestant onboard after the ship circumnavigates Ireland will win a 100,000 euro ($115,000) prize. Coco Television and RTE jointly own the rights to the format and hope to sell it overseas. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: As California Borrows Time, Other States Scrape Together Some Budget Solutions
description: California began its new fiscal year today living on borrowed time and borrowed money as state officials remained locked in a seemingly unending dispute over how to resolve a record $38 billion deficit.

title: Cucumber by the Glass
description: You do not say ''cool as a . . .'' for nothing. Icy, pale cucumbers, a splendid antidote to summer heat in salads, tea sandwiches and cold soups, are now showing up in drinks that quench without cloying.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Second Argentine To Be Tried
description: A court has cleared the way for a war crimes trial of an Argentine ex-navy officer, Adolfo Scilingo, who has said that he helped throw drugged dissidents out of planes during Argentina's 1976-1983 military dictatorship. The court decision comes days after another Argentine, Ricardo Cavallo, also an ex-navy officer, was extradicted from Mexico to Spain to face charges of genocide and terrorism relating to the military dictatorship. Mr. Scilingo travelled to Spain voluntarily in 1998 and made his confession, but later recanted. No trial dates have been set. Emma Daly

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Contractors Agree To Back Wages
description: Two painting contractors agreed yesterday to pay more than $500,000 in back wages in a settlement reached with State Attorney General Eliot Spitzer and Rose Gill Hearn, commissioner of the New York City Department of Investigation. Their investigation found that the Sprucewood Painting Corporation of Massapequa, N.Y., underpaid 41 employees on eight New York City Housing Authority projects. The investigation also found that Aegean General Contracting of Flushing underpaid eight employees in contracts with the housing authority on two projects. Sprucewood is to pay $418,909 in back wages and interest, while Aegean is to pay more than $120,000 in back wages and interest. Sprucewood will be barred from being awarded any public work contracts in the state until February 2007, and Aegean until March 2008. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERRY, , VIRGINIA GREGORY
description: PERRY -- Virginia Gregory, wife of the late Albert L. Perry, died on Sunday, June 29th. Born in East Orange, NJ on October 12, 1911, she was active in civic affairs in Wilton. CT. She was a member of the Wilton Garden Club and the Wilton Congregational Church for over 50 years. A member of the Women's Board of the Norwalk Hospital, the Treasure House, the Minks to Sinks Sale and the Soup Kitchen. Mrs. Perry is survived by her sons Albert L. Perry III and Gregory M. Perry and her daughter Ginger Perry. She was predeceased by son Stephen T. Perry, who was killed in action in Vietnam in 1969. She is also survived by her five granddaughters and seven great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, July 3rd at noon at the Wilton Congregational Church. Memorial contributions may be made to the Wilton Congregational Church, 70 Ridgefield Rd., or the Wilton Historical Society, 249 Danbury Rd., Wilton, CT 06897 >>AD#

title: Mets' Clark Retrieves Lead Lost By Benitez
description: Armando Benitez had saved a game for the Mets 24 hours earlier, but the fans at Shea Stadium booed him anyway as he ran to the mound from the bullpen in the eighth inning last night. They seemed to know something that Benitez did not.

title: Iraqi Citizens Claim Victory With Ouster of U.S.-Chosen Mayor
description: A day after the interim mayor here was arrested for embezzling, intimidating officials and throwing citizens into jail without cause, many in this town claimed victory, saying they had pressed the Americans to remove him.

title: From a Psychoanalyst, Lessons in Independence
description: ONCE upon a time, more than three decades ago, when Dr. Ethel Spector Person's homosexual patients entered analysis, they hoped to emerge as heterosexuals.

title: Wal-Mart Sets a New Policy That Protects Gay Workers
description: Wal-Mart Stores, the nation's largest private employer, has expanded its antidiscrimination policy to protect gay and lesbian employees, company officials said today.

title: Remembering Hepburn, Floppy Pants and All
description: Katharine Hepburn, who died on Sunday at the age of 96, had an oddly subtle influence on women, one that has been felt, perhaps most keenly by moviegoers, well into the present day. It was widely known that she had a 27-year-long personal life with Spencer Tracy, outside of a formal marriage. Having grown up watching the films they made together, I -- along with scores of other women -- found them to be a romantic and appealing couple, on screen and off. The New York Times, in its obituary, quoted her as saying in her television biography: ''I have no fear of death. . . . It's how you live that really counts.''

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: RAIL STRIKE ENDS Railroad union members voted overwhelmingly to return to work after half the system's 22,000 workers refused to strike. The union, affiliated with the Korean Confederation of Trade Unions, recognized the unpopularity of the strike, which had forced cancellation of more than half the passenger trains and more than 90 percent of the freight trains for four days. Chun Hwan Kyu, the railway union's leader, announced the settlement on television and apologized for the inconvenience. Government officials promised to investigate union leaders for what the government said was an illegal strike. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: College Sophomore Wins M.G.A. Title
description: Brad Tilley, a 20-year-old sophomore at the University of Virginia with few notches on his golfing belt, refused to be intimidated yesterday at the Ike, the Metropolitan Golf Association stroke-play championship in Jericho, N.Y.

Palestinian Police Take Over Security for Bethlehem
description: BETHLEHEM, West Bank, July 2  Taking his 5-year-old son, Michael, by the hand, Elias Thaljieh led him up the hill today to Manger Square to watch solemnly as Palestinian police officers, in pressed new uniforms and dented old cars, reasserted their authority in Bethlehem after Israeli forces withdrew to the town's edges.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about British efforts to reestablish control in Majar al-Kabir, a town in southern Iraq where six British soldiers were killed last week, misspelled the surname of the commander of an incoming convoy of tanks and helicopters. title: Repression Thaws Under the Mediterranean Sun
description: In ''Swimming Pool'' Charlotte Rampling first appears in a belted tan raincoat, her hair cut short and her features a mask of no-nonsense Britishness. Her character, Sarah Morton, is a mystery novelist, whose Inspector Durwell books have a loyal, though aging readership. When Sarah encounters a young hotshot writer at her publisher's offices, he is sure to tell her how much his mother loves Inspector Durwell. This is meant as a compliment, but it only piques Sarah's frustration. To help her out of her midlife, midcareer rut, her oleaginous editor (Charles Dance) lends her his house in the Luberon region of southern France, a place swathed in greenery and bathed in soft sunshine.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COHEN, , ELIAS A.
description: COHEN--Elias A. Although 49 years have passed since our beloved founder, Elias A. Cohen, passed away on July 2, 1952, he is still remembered with love and reverence by the thousands of deserving boys and girls who were privileged to come to his Tranquillity Farm and Camp for a few, fun filled weeks each summer since July 1, 1919. In the spirit of ''Noblesse Oblige'', his devoted family, his many loyal friends and a grateful Alumni are all helping to perpetuate his Tranquillity Camp as a living monument to this great American humanitarian. We are proud to announce that Tranquillity is now celebrating its 85th year. Tranquillity Camp, Inc. Earlton, N.Y. Pearl C. Miller, Pres.

title: Trade Pact With Pakistan Reflects Politics, Not Economics, Critics Say
description: When he took office two years ago, Robert B. Zoellick, the nation's top trade official, envisioned a ladder of trade agreements for countries interested in doing business with the United States. As a country improved its trading rules and showed a willingness to open its markets, it would step up to reduced tariffs and more intense economic relations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HACKETT, , BUDDY
description: HACKETT--Buddy. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their beloved and esteemed member, and Honorary Officer, Buddy Hackett. Buddy was a consummate court jester who gave the gift of laughter. He was a master craftsman of humor who brought the Friar's Club to hilarious heights during his Roast & Dinner appearances. His humor and love of life will be sorely missed by all the Friars. We are honored and proud to have been touched by the comedy legend that will always be Buddy Hackett.
