title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; A Mistake Is Erased, But a Mystery Remains
description: Did the Cleveland Indians really know Roberto Alomar would be this awful with the Mets? There was no way they could have known he would plummet so swiftly and severely. Was there? Could Indians General Manager Mark Shapiro have been shrewd enough to dig beneath Alomar's gaudy statistics in 2001, detect a few deficiencies and decide he needed a stooge to scoop up his problem player?

title: Judge Orders New Venue for Malvo to Face Sniper Charges
description: The trial of Lee Boyd Malvo, the younger suspect in the sniper shootings that terrorized the Washington area last fall, will be moved 200 miles south, from Fairfax, Va., a Washington suburb, to Chesapeake, Va., near the North Carolina border.

title: There's Nothing Wrong in Washington That a Little Cream Rinse Can't Fix
description: ''Legally Blonde 2: Red White & Blonde,'' the sequel to 2001's ''Legally Blonde'' is a movie for people who somehow managed to miss the point of the first picture, itself the kind of material that put the ''b'' in subtle, as the old joke goes. And old jokes are really what ''Blonde 2'' is all about. Reese Witherspoon returns as Elle Woods, the indefatigable sprig of a girl whose disposition is as sunshiny as her hair. Previously she conquered Harvard Law School, a place in need of a new world order, and in the nominal sequel she takes on the moribund legislative branch.

title: Axis Capital Shares Rise on Public Offering
description: Shares of Axis Capital Holdings rose 16 percent after it raised $473 million in this year's biggest initial public offering by an insurance company.

title: Boeing Wins AirTran Deal Over Airbus For 56 Planes
description: AirTran Airways said yesterday that it had completed a deal with the Boeing Company to add six 717's to its fleet and take delivery of 50 737's by 2008. The order will allow AirTran to add more transcontinental routes and possibly start service to Mexico, Canada and the Caribbean, its executives said.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: NEW HAVEN: METRO-NORTH RAISES FARES Fare increases for Connecticut passengers of the Metro-North Railroad went into effect yesterday to help cover a $12 million operating deficit. Fares increased about 15 percent on trips from Connecticut into New York City. Fares increased about 7 percent for trips from Connecticut to other New York stops and about 5 percent for trips within Connecticut. The last fare increase was in 1998, said Harry Harris, bureau chief of public transportation for the Connecticut Department of Transportation. (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Brewer's Profit Falls
description: Scottish & Newcastle P.L.C., the British brewer, said its full-year profit fell 29 percent because of costs related to a reorganization in Britain and an acquisition. Net income for the fiscal year ended April 27 fell to 140.1 million ($232 million) from 196.5 million ($325 million) a year earlier, the company said. Scottish & Newcastle, which is based in Edinburgh, said operating profit at its British beer division fell 8.9 percent as sales stalled and it incurred costs related to the reorganization of Scottish Courage's supply chain. Tony Froggatt, above, who joined the company last month as chief executive, said business was recovering in France and Russia.

description: Bistro to Barbecue

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Racing Association Hires Security Firm
description: Responding to a scathing report by the state attorney general that accused the New York Racing Association of mismanagement, the association announced yesterday that it had hired a security firm to study and fix its security procedures. It said it also had formed a committee of its own trustees to ensure that it addresses the issues raised by the state attorney general. The association, a nonprofit corporation, owns and operates Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga racetracks and handles about $3 billion a year. The security firm, SafirRosetti, is a partnership of Howard Safir, the former city police commissioner, and Joseph R. Rosetti, the former head of security programs for I.B.M. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Democratic Field Tries to Add Punch to Environment Issue
description: Democratic presidential candidates are putting a new emphasis on making environmental issues more voter friendly. Instead of talking abstractly about ozone levels or the Superfund budget, they speak of the children whose asthma is aggravated by smog, or of how many more minority members than whites live near toxic waste dumps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPIER, , LARRY

Devoted father of Mark and Roberta, father-in-law of Lori and Wayne, loving grandfather of Matthew, Benjamin, Danielle, and Jeffrey. Cherished brother and brother-in-law. Owner and president of the Memory Lane Music Group encompassing the publishing firm of Larry Spier, Inc., and Memory Lane Music. Mr. Spier had been at the helm of the company since 1967, and was a pioneer in catalogue administration, entering into one of the first administrative deals in 1975. Relatives and friends are invited to services Thursday, July 3, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. The family shall return to the home of the deceased. At the families request, gifts in his memory may be made to ARPKD/ CHF Alliance, PO Box 70, Kirkwood, PA 17536. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bloomberg Extortionist Sentenced
description: A man convicted of trying to extort money from Michael R. Bloomberg before he became mayor was sentenced yesterday to 51 months in prison. In February, a federal jury found the man, Oleg Zezev, 29, of Almaty, Kazakhstan, the former Soviet republic, guilty of attempted extortion and computer intrusion, among other charges. Prosecutors had accused Mr. Zezev of hacking into the computers of Bloomberg L.P., Mr. Bloomberg's financial-information company, and threatening to reveal private information unless Mr. Bloomberg paid Mr. Zezev $200,000. Mr. Zezev had worked as the chief technology information officer for a securities company that used Bloomberg's database services. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: AFGHANISTAN: BOMB EXPLODES AT MOSQUE A bomb exploded during evening prayers in a mosque in Kandahar, in the south, injuring 28 people, three of them seriously, local officials said. The bomb, left in a discarded jacket, narrowly missed the prominent anti-Taliban cleric, Maulavi Abdullah Fayaz, who was leading the evening prayers. He blamed the explosion on Taliban supporters and called them enemies of the state.    Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Even at a Low-End High School, A Rich Menu for the Taking
description: WHEN Jorge Ballinas was in the eighth grade at Intermediate School in the Bronx, he had to select a high school. His father, Raymundo, a Mexican immigrant who works as a waiter and went only as far as sixth grade, could not advise his son.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MULLEN, , ARTHUR CLARENCE, JR.
description: MULLEN--Arthur Clarence, Jr., died Sunday, June 29, 2003. Beloved husband of Joan B. Mullen and father of Justin Bell, Sara Luke, Audrey, Victor and Joanne, and grandfather of Tatiana Bell and Emily and Evan Mullen. Born in Newark, NJ, he was educated in St. Nicholas and Dickinson HS in Jersey City where his father practiced law and was the head of the Board of Education. At age 18, he entered the US Navy and served on carriers in the Pacific theater during WW II. Retiring as an officer, he graduated from Seton Hall Univ. where he held a scholarship and was captain of the swimming team. Predeceased by older brother, George Sampson, and sister, Mary Lou, and survived by Betty Joan Cosgrove of Charlotte, NC, and Robert W. Mullen, Esq., of NYC. Sonny, a pioneer in mass marketing, spent his career in the stationery and toy business, retiring as VP of Empire Pencil Co. Lionhearted and extremely reliable, he leaves a grieving but grateful family. Mass will be celebrated at 10AM at Star of the Sea Church, Long Branch, NJ on July 3, 2003. >>AD#

title: Appeals Court Strikes Down City's Law on Lead Paint
description: The state's highest court today struck down New York City's four-year-old law to clean up lead paint, saying the City Council had failed to comply with New York's environmental standards in passing it.

title: ZALE BUYING BACK UP TO ONE-FIFTH OF ITS SHARES
description: The Zale Corporation, the largest North American jewelry retailer, was offering shareholders as much as 20 percent more than Monday's stock price yesterday as it began to buy back about a fifth of its shares. The shares closed up 14.8 percent. The company, which is based in Irving, Tex., said it would buy as many as 6.4 million common shares at $42 to $48 apiece, spending a maximum of $307.2 million, in a so-called Dutch auction. Zale shares closed at $40 on Monday and gained $5.90 yesterday, to close at $45.90.

title: Europe to Require Labels on Modified Foods
description: LONDON, July 22  The European Parliament approved legislation today to require strict labels for food and feed made with genetically altered ingredients, a move that was hailed by environmentalists but pilloried by American farmers.

title: Blossom Dearest: Quest for a Perfect Magnolia
description: Oaks may scrape the sky. Fruit trees may blossom. But what leafy creature in the wilting months of summer bursts open with 15-inch flowers and aromatizes the entire neighborhood with a fresh lemony scent?

description: Kraft Foods said today that it would rethink some product lines and introduce steps to help fight the worldwide problem of obesity.

description: Twinkies dressed like drum majors, and red, white and blue marshmallows on a stick are snacks fit for patriots of every stripe, but they are among the new treats for children from Ruby et Violette, a bakery at 457 West 50th Street. A gift bag of two Twinkies is $7; the marshmallow sticks are $2.50 each. Oreos and Moon Pies in parade dress are also available. The treats can be ordered from www.rubyetviolette.com or from (212) 582-6720. The company donates 5 percent of its net profits to Mount Sinai Hospital's traumatic brain injury unit.

title: Bush Team Says It's Weighing Intervention in Liberia's Torment
description: The Bush administration said today that it was considering whether to intervene to halt fierce fighting in Liberia between rebel groups and the government of President Charles Taylor. The White House also declared that it had not ruled out sending in American troops as part of an international peacekeeping force.

title: Fancy Finds That Stand Out From the Crowd

Javits Convention Center, the weird included a white Stilton cheese with bits of mango and ginger in it. But among the new goods offered by the 2,500 exhibitors were a few that come from a very old tradition: the preserves, almond-paste sweets and other confections made by Maria Grammatico.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTERCONTINENTAL HOTELS GROUP, London, said it would sell 16 Staybridge Suites hotels, part of a chain of 55 hotels in the United States, to Hospitality Properties Trust, Newton, Mass., for $185 million.

title: BANK OF AMERICA SELLS PROPERTY TO REALTY TRUST
description: American Financial Realty Trust, a real estate investment company that sold shares last week in an initial public offering, said yesterday that it had bought 158 properties from the Bank of America Corporation for about $770 million. The 8.1 million square feet will be leased back to Bank of America, American Financial said. The assets include the Bank of America Center in Chicago's financial district and other office buildings in 19 states. American Financial raised $699.4 million in its first stock sale. The offering was managed by Banc of America Securities and the Friedman, Billings, Ramsey Group.

description: Manufacturing contracted in June for a fourth consecutive month as factories kept inventories low until demand strengthens, an industry report showed yesterday. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCABE, , ROBERT P.
description: McCABE--Robert P. On June 29, 2003. A resident of College Point, Bob passed away at the age of 71. He is survived by three sons: Robert Jr., Timothy and Martin. title: Racial Differences Are Found in Use of Feeding Tubes
description: Senile residents of nursing homes are more likely to be put on feeding tubes instead of being hand fed if they are black or Asian and live in a big urban nursing home run for profit, a new study finds.

title: Wimbledon Semifinals: It's Williamses vs. Belgians
description: The familiar, hard-running American on the other side of the net was Jennifer Capriati, but Serena Williams was also playing against a Belgian opponent this afternoon on Center Court.

title: Royal Ahold's Inquiry Ends, Finding $1.1 Billion in Errors
description: The food retailer Royal Ahold disclosed today that it had discovered another 73 million euros ($84.4 million) in accounting irregularities, closing out a four-month investigation that found 970 million euros ($1.1 billion) in suspected fraud.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Unemployment Steady
description: Unemployment in the 12-member euro zone stayed at 8.8 percent in May, the third month in a row, the European statistics office, Eurostat, said. Germany and France, the two biggest economies, had rates of 9.4 percent and 9.1 percent respectively, while Spain had the highest jobless rate, 11.3 percent. Economists say unemployment is likely to rise as a result of economic weakness. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAYPOL, , CYNNIE
description: SAYPOL--Cynnie. Never to be forgotten. Funny as hell and loved by all. The Dalton Gang >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: Man Is Shot To Death
description: A 19-year-old man was shot to death and another man was critically injured yesterday afternoon in Hunts Point, the police said. Officers, responding to reports about a shooting just before 2 p.m., found the 19-year-old on the sidewalk outside 760 Bryant Avenue, dead from a gunshot wound in the back. A 20-year-old man who had also been shot was taken to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center in critical condition, the police said. A 19-year-old man was arrested at the scene, where a gun was recovered, the police said. He was not charged last night, Detective Thomas Kuchma said. The police did not release the names of anyone involved in the shooting. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Editors' Note
description: An illustration on June 23 with a front-page article about research on dietary supplements showed an advertisement for an ephedra-based weight-loss pill as well as two e-mail messages from its manufacturer, Muscletech Research and Development, to a researcher. The article looked at the way makers of ephedra and other dietary supplements use scientific research to market their products; it examined court cases that have raised questions about the rigor of those studies.

title: Barbecue? You Could Do It in Your Sleep
description: CHRIS SCHLESINGER was snoring softly on the couch. This was in the living room of his sprawling ranch house here in southeastern Massachusetts, nestled high above a pebbly beach. A Bill Murray movie was playing on the television in the corner, and the cool breeze sliding off Buzzards Bay had dampened the room, covering the warmth of the day. Outside on the sweeping deck, in a giant ovoid kettle grill, three pork butts sat in the smoky braise of a small oak fire, glistening, ruddy, plump. It was well after midnight. Seven hours' cooking done. Seven hours to go.

title: A.C.C. Greets New Members, And Sees More Room to Grow
description: The Atlantic Coast Conference might not be finished with expansion. After inviting Miami and Virginia Tech to join, the A.C.C. could look to add a 12th team, perhaps as early as next year, according to Dr. G. Wayne Clough, president of Georgia Tech and a strong proponent of a 12-team conference.

title: Mayor Extending Focus on Crime Hot Spots
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the New York Police Department would extend its Operation Impact crime-fighting program, which he credited with helping to bring down crime. The department will use overtime to continue the initiative, which posts officers in crime hot spots across the city.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Vivendi Snubs Bidder as It Moves to Keep Record Group
description: At a nine-hour board meeting in Paris yesterday, Vivendi Universal eliminated one of the six bidders for its entertainment businesses and decided to pull its giant record group, Universal Music, off the auction block, executives briefed on the meeting said.

title: Harry Potter's Magic
description: To the Editor:

title: Song of Nebraska, Land of Spacious Skies
description: To the Editor:

title: British Yellow Pages' Owner Revives Stock Offering Plan
description: The Yell Group, which publishes the British yellow pages, said today that it would try again to go public in a 850 million ($1.4 billion) stock offering that, if successful, would be the world's largest this year.

title: Collecting Despots, Assassins And Such
description: Where else could Romania's former first couple, Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu, mingle with the founder of the Soviet secret police, Feliks Dzerzhinsky, and Gavrilo Princip, the Serbian assassin who helped set in motion World War I? Only in Texas.

title: Terrorism and the Biology Lab
description: Were those two suspicious tractor-trailers found in Iraq really mobile weapons laboratories? The difficulty we are having answering that question shows just how tricky defending America against bioterrorism is going to be.

title: Judges Reject Suits Blaming Analysts For Losses
description: A federal judge said in a ruling announced yesterday that investors eager to take on risk were to blame for their own stock market losses and dismissed two class-action suits against Merrill Lynch that cited tainted research.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: XM Satellite Says It Has 692,000 Subscribers
description: XM Satellite Radio Holdings said yesterday that it ended the second quarter with more than 692,000 subscribers, comfortably ahead of Wall Street's projected growth for the new broadcasting service. Shares of XM, which had already more than tripled this year, rose another $1.41, or about 12.9 percent, to close at $12.40. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEIN, , MITCHELL
description: FEIN--Mitchell of Cliffside Park, NJ. Beloved husband of Helen, devoted father of Carol Fein Hoffeld, Janet Reichman, Beth Fein Hollander. Father-in-law of Jeffrey, Marc and Eric. Dear brother of Irene Brooks. Loving grandfather of Noah, Jeremy, Rosie, Daniel, Alexis, Juliet, Evan, Zachary and great grandfather of Elona and Nova. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'' 402 Park St, Hackensack, Wednesday 12:30PM. Contributions may be made to The Amy Fund, C/O the Marrow Foundation, 400 Seventh St, N.W., Suite 206, Washington, DC 20004 >>AD#

title: As a Reward, Claussen Gets Boston
description: When the Yankees' pitching coach, Mel Stottlemyre, told Brandon Claussen he would start on Saturday against the Boston Red Sox, Claussen responded like the grateful 24-year-old rookie he is. ''Thank you,'' he said.

title: I.R.S. Disallows A Shelter Intended To Delay the Tax On Stock Options
description: The Treasury Department and the Internal Revenue Service disallowed a tax shelter yesterday that executives bought to delay taxes on exercised stock options for 15 years. Public records show unusual transactions by L. Dennis Kozlowski, the indicted former chief executive of Tyco International, that fit the tax shelter's design.

title: Theater's Promise? Look Off Broadway
description: With all its grandeur and extravagance, ''La Bohme'' closed out its Broadway run on Sunday, making an early exit after all the hoopla attending its arrival last fall. Oh, well. Everybody knows what a crapshoot Broadway is. You can't make a living, but you can make a killing. So there won't be another opera staged as a big-budget musical for a while.

title: Washington's Muted Majority
description: Even the license plates of the District of Columbia now broadcast the sad state of hobbled democracy for residents of the nation's capital: ''Taxation Without Representation.'' Through most of the abstruse history of this hybrid city-state, the residents have not been allowed their own voting member of Congress. This deprivation has long been a civil rights issue for the Democrats. But control of the city's fate, from its budget to its ballot initiatives, has rested firmly with overseers in Congress, who are not given to surrendering much authority back to the 572,000 people who do not elect them. It wasn't until a century after the Civil War that Washingtonians were allowed to vote for president.

title: With Head Held High, Mondavi, at 90, Faces a Storm
description: HE uses a cane now, his hearing is poor and he tends to repeat himself when he's excited. But the high-pitched voice is as strong as it ever was, and the face, surely sketched from a Roman coin, still radiates the vigor and determination it must have shown half a century ago.

title: Subject of Anthrax Inquiry Tied to Anti-Germ Training
description: Three years ago, the United States began a secret project to train Special Operations units to detect and disarm mobile germ factories of the sort that Iraq and some other countries were suspected of building, according to administration officials and experts in germ weaponry.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Party To Recommend Judges
description: A small independent political party, responding to allegations of corruption by judges selected by the Democratic Party, announced yesterday that it was setting up a panel to evaluate potential judicial candidates. The liberal Working Families Party said Supreme Court candidates approved by its panel would also be eligible to appear on the party's ballot line in November, when eight justices will be elected (or re-elected). Approval by the panel will be ''the legal equivalent of the Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval,'' said Charlotte Hitchcock, a member of the new screening group and a senior staff attorney with the Legal Aid Society. The panel will also include at least one retired Supreme Court justice and several law-school professors. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: TROUBLESHOOTER IS NAMED TO LEAD BOSTON CATHOLICS
description: Bishop Sean P. O'Malley, a Franciscan friar, was appointed today by Pope John Paul II to lead the dispirited Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston, and he immediately set out to convey a new tone of episcopal humility and contrition. He met with victims of sexual abuse, visited hospital patients and emphasized in a news conference that his first task would be to listen.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about the Big East Conference's reaction to Miami's withdrawal misattributed a statement made during a telephone news conference. It was Jake Crouthamel, the athletic director at Syracuse -- not the Syracuse chancellor, Kenneth A. Shaw -- who said, ''Until we get our hands around this issue and get it resolved, we are all in a precarious position.''

title: Mets End One Sad Story With a Trade of Alomar
description: The Mets finally succeeded yesterday in shipping the underachieving second baseman Roberto Alomar out of New York, receiving three minor leaguers from the Chicago White Sox in return. Though Alomar hardly performed as expected during his season and a half with the Mets, many around the team expect that he will quickly become himself again.

title: Gay Marriage and Family Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROULET, , JEAN
description: ROULET--Jean. Still grateful for your presence, grieving for your loss. Your sister

title: Heat Teases Out the Other Side of the Lemon
description: AMONG the golden bits of fish, squid and shrimp in the fritto misto at Washington Park restaurant in Greenwich Village you will come upon something wonderfully different: thin slices of deep-fried lemon.

title: Buddy Hackett, Irrepressible, Streetwise Clown, Dies at 78
description: Buddy Hackett, the roly-poly streetwise comedian from Brooklyn whose puckish, irrepressible clowning was a fixture on America's home screens in the 1950's and 60's, died on Monday at his beach house in Malibu, Calif. He was 78.

title: Audit Sharply Criticizes Art Institution's Dealings
description: In a long-suppressed report made public today, auditors trying to determine how one of the world's richest art foundations fell prey to poverty found rampant mismanagement, conflicts of interest and questionable spending.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Murder Inquiry Faulted
description: Britain failed to provide an adaquate investigation into the death of Patrick Finucane, a prominent Catholic lawyer in Belfast, the European Court of Human Rights said in a unanimous ruling. Mr. Finucane, 38, was shot to death in 1989 by Protestant gunmen, allegedly in collusion with the Northern Ireland police, then called the Royal Ulster Constabulary. The court, in Strasbourg, France, found in favor of Mr. Finucane's widow, Geraldine, above, saying Britain ''failed to provide a prompt and effective investigation into the allegations of collusion by security personnel.'' It ordered Britain to pay legal costs and expenses of $46,000 to Mrs. Finucane. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES LAYS OFF 3,100 FLIGHT ATTENDANTS
description: American Airlines laid off 3,100 flight attendants yesterday in an effort to cut costs, the company said. More than 1,700 of the attendants used to work for Trans World Airlines, which AMR, the parent of American, bought two years ago. Since that buyout, American has been trying to reduce operations, leading many industry experts to say that the airline erred in buying T.W.A. Yesterday's layoffs were part of the concessions the company worked out with its unions in the spring. During those talks, American obtained $1.8 billion in annual cuts. Gerard R. Arpey, its chief executive, has said that the airline is struggling to avoid bankruptcy court. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: PROSECUTOR IS CONFIRMED The State Senate has confirmed the nomination of Joseph Bocchini Jr., a former state assemblyman, as Mercer County prosecutor. Mr. Bocchini, who was confirmed on Monday, will replace Acting Prosecutor Charles E. Waldron. Mr. Bocchini served as an assistant counsel for the State Senate majority from 1978 to 1982 and an assemblyman for the 14th Legislative District from 1984 to 1985. Mr. Bocchini, 59, is currently a municipal court judge in Hamilton Township, where he lives.

title: A Forager Shares Her Woodsy Secrets
description: AS her family has done for generations in the mountains of southern Virginia, Susan Bridges scours the countryside for wild greens, berries, chicory, dandelions, violets and other edible parts of nature. Since she was a child, she has picked weeds, roots and flowers from the fields, meadows and creek banks of a hamlet called the Meadows of Dan, not far from the North Carolina line. And for almost as long, she has cooked pokeweed, wild mustard and goosefoot, and ground the seeds of wild amaranth for porridge.

title: Transporter Of Immigrants Faces Charges
description: Ten years after the rusty steamer Golden Venture ran aground near Queens, exposing a bustling underworld of illegal immigrants being smuggled and held hostage, a woman who federal officials say was a vicious ringleader of the operation completed her own voyage from Asia to America. This time she was the captive, escorted by federal agents after being extradited to face criminal charges in New York yesterday, ending a worldwide pursuit.

title: Sports of The Times; Two Williamses Prove Plenty Tough
description: THIS was during the second Williams tennis quarterfinal yesterday. My friend Gianni Clerici, the tennis columnist for La Repubblica in Italy, was observing a large man with a cast on his left foot, sitting right below us, very involved in the match.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WATSON, , GEORGE S., MD
description: WATSON--George S., MD, of Arlington, formerly of Plympton, MA, June 24, age 86 years. Husband of the late Susanne (Turner) Watson. Loving father of Susanne Watson of Arlington; Charlotte B. Watson of Front Royal, VA; Jeannie Russell of the Bronx, NY; and Diane Russell of Nairobi, Kenya. He is also survived by four grandchildren and one great-grandchild. >>AD#

title: U.S. Urged to Educate Women About Foods Linked to Dioxin
description: The government should encourage women and girls to reduce the amount of meat, whole milk and other fatty foods they eat as a way of protecting themselves and their offspring from dioxins, harmful residues of natural and industrial combustion, an expert panel said today.

title: Tying Judges' Hands
description: To the Editor:

title: Salads That Declare Their Independence From the Same Old
description: MEAT is not only the centerpiece of most barbecues, but also the simplest part. Intensely flavorful to begin with, it is easily made more so with rubs, sauces and smoke.

title: Advocate for Parents Takes Job With the Schools
description: A parent advocate who in recent weeks has been a vocal supporter of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's efforts to overhaul the schools has found himself a new job: working for the school system.

title: South Korean railroad workers end strike, giving Roh a victory
description: SEOUL:  President Roh Moo Hyun appeared to have won a significant victory Tuesday in his drive to reconcile South Korea's labor unions to the reality of current economic conditions, persuading railroad workers to stop a walkout that had cut train service by more than half since Saturday.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; In various ways, the new tax law affects how companies handle their dividends.
description: MORE companies are raising dividends now that such payouts are getting better tax treatment. But at the same time, there has been an increase in the number of companies cutting or eliminating dividends.

title: Employers Seek To Shift Costs Of Drugs to U.S.
description: The bills to provide drug benefits through Medicare that were passed by the House and the Senate last week offer some of the country's largest employers a long-sought prize: shifting at least some of their burden of soaring drug costs to the federal government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RADUTZKY, , HARRY
description: RADUTZKY -- Harry. The Trustees, Administration and professional staff of Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center wish to express our sorrow and deepest regret on the passing of Harry Radutzky, Vice President of the Joyva Corporation, a major supporter of our institution, husband of Beatrice, father of Roslyn Wiener and Ellen Radutzky-Stockel, uncle of our esteemed fellow Trustee, Richard Radutzky and grandfather of four grandchildren. Harry Radutzky played a major role in the development of our Emergency Services. He will be remembered for his consistently sound advice, kindness and good humor. Alvin I. Kahn, M.D. Chairman of the Board David P. Rosen President and CEO Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center >>AD#

title: Hedge Fund Firm Diversifying Clientele
description: West End Capital Management, a hedge fund company in Bermuda that manages about $600 million for the billionaire Warren Buffett, plans to open its Value Capital LP fund to new investors in a bid to raise another $500 million.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Airport Guards Charged
description: A group of border guards from Sheremetyevo Airport in Moscow were arrested and charged with forging documents and selling them to Russian criminals who sought to leave the country, Russian news agencies reported. The police did not say how many guards were arrested or when the arrests took place. Political commentators explained the arrests as part of an anticorruption campaign being conducted by the government in advance of parliamentary elections in December. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Fear of Recession Fading In Japan Business Survey
description: Pessimism about the Japanese economy is slowly fading, a central bank survey of business executives showed today, as manufacturers prepare for an increase in orders from overseas for their cars, electronics and machinery.

title: Court Orders Removal of Monument to Ten Commandments
description: Afederal appeals court ordered the chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court yesterday to remove a monument engraved with the Ten Commandments from the rotunda of his courthouse.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about problems facing Lafayette High School in south Brooklyn misstated the school connection of State Senator Seymour P. Lachman, who discussed the resources and finances of neighborhood high schools. He is a former Lafayette teacher, not an alumnus. He graduated from Thomas Jefferson High, in East New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, , HERMAINE KURTZ
description: COHEN -- Hermaine Kurtz, age 82, of Edina, formerly of New York City, died June 28, 2003. Preceded in death by parents, Irwin and Josephine (Herzbrun) Kurtz; husband, New York State Supreme Court Justice, Charles H. Cohen; sisters, Babette Kurtz and Eve Kurtz Rackow. Survived by sons, Jonathan (Barbara) of Prior Lake, MN and Harlan (Patricia Salas) of Washington, DC; grand daughters Ilana, Aliza and Julia. ''Hummy'' was a loving and generous wife, mother and grandmother, a world traveler, a gourmet cook, an expert needlewoman and a loyal friend to many. She will be greatly missed. >>AD#

title: Stream of history / A search for urban charm : Seoul digs up a highway to expose its dynastic roots
description: SEOUL  In the midst of a frayed district of clothing shops and textile companies, beneath a stretch of elevated highway, Seoul metropolitan planners began Tuesday to expose a stream that disappeared from view and almost from memory a generation ago.

title: City Eases The Pain In Budget For Arts
description: Despite the worst New York City budget deficit since the 1970's fiscal crisis, the specter of closed museum galleries, canceled performances and staff cuts at the city's cultural institutions diminished with the budget agreed upon last week.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Airline's Credit Rating Cut
description: The credit rating of British Airways P.L.C., Europe's biggest airline, was cut to junk status by Standard & Poor's, which cited concerns about debt and demand for air travel because of the Iraq war and severe acute respiratory syndrome. The airline's long-term corporate credit rating and its senior unsecured debt were each reduced one level. The company's debt was already rated below investment grade by Moody's Investors Service.

title: Neglected Verdi Opera Is Heard Again in Paris
description: Nearly 150 years after its premiere, a long-neglected opera by Verdi, ''Les Vpres Siciliennes,'' has finally been revived in its original French version with nine performances by the Paris National Opera through July 15.

title: Review/Fashion; A Carnal Tom Ford, A Smoky Slimane
description: Tom Ford juiced up his Yves Saint Laurent men's collection with tangerine and livid green, while Hedi Slimane bathed Dior in silver and shadow. The question as the spring 2004 men's season ended here was, Who brings the light to Paris?

title: Guilty or Not, U.S. Is Blamed In Mosque Blast
description: At the graves, dust swirled and shovels scraped, but otherwise all was still. Men heaved dirt and rocks into five newly dug holes, occupied by five newly filled coffins. A flag proclaimed, ''There is no God but God,'' but almost no one spoke.

title: The Ten Commandments Judge
description: Judges are often celebrated for their wisdom, compassion or legal acumen, but Roy Moore, the chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, has earned his fame in a different way. He is known as the Ten Commandments judge. As a trial court judge, he hung a wooden Ten Commandments plaque in his courtroom. When he became chief justice, he installed a two-and-a-half-ton Ten Commandments monument in the rotunda of the Alabama State Judicial Building. In an important First Amendment ruling yesterday, a federal appeals court ordered Chief Justice Moore to remove the monument. Once it is gone, Alabama voters must find a way to remove Mr. Moore.

title: Oxford Investigates Scientist Who Denied Israeli Application
description: A geneticist at Oxford University, Andrew Wilkie, is under investigation for possible violations of the university's antidiscrimination rules after he rejected an Israeli student's application to work in his laboratory, citing disagreement with Israeli policies toward Palestinians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSTER, , GLADYCE
description: OSTER -- Gladyce. Beloved wife of Harry. Loving mother of Neill, Rhonda and Joel. Dear sister of Marvin and Leslie. Cherished grandmother of Scott & Faith. Services today, 9AM ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows, NY. >>AD#

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Migrants Saved From Locked Truck
description: The federal police said they had rescued 52 Central Americans near death in a locked and airless tractor-trailer in Oaxaca state, in the south. Highway patrolmen stopped the truck and freed 34 men, 16 women and 2 children at a checkpoint on a rural highway. The driver fled. The migrants had paid smugglers to transport them through Mexico to the United States border. The migrants -- 25 Salvadorans, 20 Guatemalans and 7 Hondurans -- are to be deported, the officials said. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDHIRSH, , BERNARD A.
description: GOLDHIRSH -- Bernard A. The employees of Gruner + Jahr USA Publishing mourn the passing of Bernard A. Goldhirsh, founder of Inc. magazine. Bernie's quintessential entrepreneurial spirit will be missed. We send our deepest condolences to his family and friends. >>AD#

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Only at Cindy's, Kids, Only at Cindy's

title: The Beer Sings Yankee Doodle But the Food Goes Oom-Pah-Pah
description: Guastavino's umbrella-shaded outdoor terrace, just steps from the East River at 409 East 59th Street, transforms itself into a beer garden from 5:30 to 11 p.m. On Wednesdays, an accordionist entertains, and an American beer, like Brooklyn Brewery's beautifully balanced golden summer wheat beer, is tapped from a keg.

title: God's Word, Echoing in English; Hispanic Pentecostal Churches Face Bilingual Problem
description: He wouldn't want his father to hear him say so, but Getulio A. Cruz prefers to listen to his dad, who is pastor of the Monte Sion Christian Church on the Lower East Side, preach in English on Friday nights rather than in Spanish on Sunday mornings.

title: I.O.C. Chooses Vancouver for 2010 Winter Games
description: PRAGUE, July 2  Vancouver was selected the host city of the 2010 Winter Olympics today in a vote by the International Olympic Committee, defeating Pyeongchang, South Korea, and Salzburg to bring the Winter Games to Canada for the second time.

title: Security Laws Target of Huge Hong Kong Protest
description: Pouring through this city's tropical parks and its canyons of glittering skyscrapers, an immense crowd marched here today to protest government plans to impose stringent internal-security laws.

title: Record Number of Homeless, But City Says It's Prepared
description: With every summer season comes a surge in family homelessness in New York City. Landlords are emboldened to evict people. School is out. The good will of relatives providing shelter wears thin.

title: Improving the Odds of Good Care
description: Americans may think they have the best medical system in the world, but the quality of the care they receive hardly reflects that. A disturbing study published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine found that participants whose medical records were analyzed had failed to get the recommended treatment for their illnesses almost half the time. This is a surprising and shocking failure of the medical profession to deliver the best known care to a broad swath of the American public.

title: A Brooklyn Seal's Trick: Surviving the Gowanus
description: Pretty soon, a 1-year-old harp seal that became the talk of Red Hook is expected to paddle onto Long Island Sound, leaving behind its celebrity in Brooklyn for a life of anonymity in open waters.

title: BLACK & DECKER TO BUY LOCK AND HARDWARE UNITS
description: The Black & Decker Corporation plans to buy the Baldwin Hardware and Weiser Lock businesses from the Masco Corporation. Financial terms were not disclosed. The Baldwin and Weiser units had 2002 sales of $250 million, Masco said. The transaction is expected to close later this year. Black & Decker, which makes DeWalt power tools and Kwikset security hardware, said the acquisition would help the company expand its lock-and-door hardware businesses. In April, Black & Decker said it intended to save about $100 million after cutting jobs and closing factories. Masco, based in Taylor, Mich., makes Delta faucets and Behr paints. Black & Decker is based in Towson, Md.

title: Britain Allows Suit by Kenyans Accusing Soldiers of Rape
description: LONDON, July 2  A group of 650 Kenyan women who say they were sexually assaulted and in many cases gang-raped by British soldiers on military assignment in their country won the right today to sue the Ministry of Defense for compensation.

title: PGA Plans Voluntary Club Tests
description: The PGA Tour took a stand today against high-tech drivers that enable players to hit balls great distances.

title: In a Christian-Muslim Dispute, Israel Blocks a New Mosque
description: Caught in a religious dispute that has pitted Christians against Muslims, Israel dispatched bulldozers and jackhammers today to tear down the foundation of a mosque being built next to a Roman Catholic basilica in Nazareth, the boyhood town of Jesus.

title: Court Orders Removal of Monument to Ten Commandments
description: A federal appeals court ordered the chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court yesterday to remove a monument engraved with the Ten Commandments from the rotunda of his courthouse.

title: 4% Rise in Auto Sales in June Fuels Optimism at the Big Three
description: Nationwide auto sales rose in June, but the domestic industry continued to lose ground to foreign competitors like Toyota despite spending heavily on consumer purchase incentives.

title: In Day of Violence in Iraq, Attacks From All Directions
description: Iraq's plague of violence showed no signs of abating today, as six American soldiers were wounded in two separate attacks, American soldiers killed four Iraqis at checkpoints in Baghdad, and a huge explosion killed at least five people at a mosque.

title: SHARON AND ABBAS STAND SIDE BY SIDE, THEN BEGIN TALKS
description: Appearing side by side before meeting here this evening, the Israeli and Palestinian prime ministers declared mutual respect and expressed hopes for peace, while Israeli forces prepared to withdraw Wednesday from the West Bank town of Bethlehem.

title: Herbie Mann, Jazz Musician, Dies at 73
description: Herbie Mann, who helped to popularize the flute as a jazz instrument and to introduce the music of other cultures into the mainstream of American jazz, died late Tuesday at his cabin in Pecos, N.M., near Santa Fe, where he lived. He was 73. .

title: One Leader Too Many as College Takes On SUNY
description: Will the real president of Rockland Community College please stand up?

It was Sega of America, not ESPN.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Jos Tras Monge, a former chief justice in Puerto Rico and major contributor to the Puerto Rican constitution, listed some survivors incorrectly. His surviving sons are Peter and Arturo; another son, Enrique, is dead, as is his foster daughter, Candida.

title: If the Budget Fits, Run With It
description: Take away the manufactured drama and election-year politics, and the largest pizza party in Trenton finally ended in yesterday's wee hours with a $24 billion budget agreement for New Jersey. To get there, lawmakers stopped the clock one minute before the fiscal year ended at midnight, and some of them pulled an all-nighter to avert a government shutdown that was never going to happen anyway.

title: I.O.C. Chooses Vancouver for 2010 Olympic Winter Games
description: PRAGUE, July 2 - Vancouver was selected as the site of the 2010 Winter Olympic Games today in a vote by the International Olympic Committee, defeating Pyeongchang, South Korea, and Salzburg, Austria, to bring the Games to Canada for the third time.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Burned Man Found Dead In Home
description: The partly burned body of a 39-year-old man was discovered on his kitchen floor in Bergen Beach last night, the police said. The man, Andrew Puccini of 2415 East 73rd Street, was pronounced dead after he was found just before 8 p.m., the police said. His wife found the body, Firefighter Paul Iannizzotto said. Neighbors said Mr. Puccini used to own a restaurant, Not Just Chicken, and lived with his parents and his wife. The police said the medical examiner's office would determine the cause of death. The house did not appear to have serious fire damage. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Judge Moves Sniper Trial To Tidewater Virginia
description: The trial of Lee Malvo, the younger man charged in the sniper shootings that terrorized the Washington metropolitan region in the fall, will be moved 160 miles southeast, from Fairfax, Va., a Washington suburb, to Chesapeake, Va., near the coast and the North Carolina border.

description: Losses resulting from the collapse of PipeVine Inc., a nonprofit organization that helped companies and fund-raisers like United Way collect and distribute charitable donations, now appear to be much higher than predicted.

title: Telecommuter Loses Case For Benefits
description: A woman who used a laptop computer and a phone line to work in Florida for a financial information company on Long Island is ineligible for New York's unemployment benefits, the state's highest court ruled today.

description: FEDERAL regulators are trying to curb the nation's backsliding drunken driving problem with an advertising and enforcement campaign that takes aim at the Fourth of July weekend, historically one of the worst periods for alcohol-related accidents.

title: The Quiet Shift in Overtime
description: The Bush administration is engineering bread-and-butter changes in the federal regulation of overtime pay, commendably making hundreds of thousands more low-wage earners eligible for time-and-a-half. At the same time, however, proposed Labor Department regulations have stirred justifiable concern that numerous white-collar, middle-income workers could lose income because employers will have more leeway to pronounce them managers and deny their current right to overtime.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MISSOURI: FACTORY WORKER KILLS THREE AND HIMSELF A factory worker fatally shot three co-workers and wounded five others in Jefferson City, then killed himself during a gun battle with the police, the authorities said. Two colleagues died along the manufacturing line at the Modine Manufacturing Company , where the gunman, Jonathon Russell, 25, had worked for two years. A supervisor, shot 50 feet away, died en route to the hospital. The police said Mr. Russell was close to being fired for absenteeism. They also said he was facing the possible breakup of a romantic relationship.    (AP)

title: Forget F-Stops: These Cameras Have Area Codes

description: Because Betsy Ross has the myth market cornered when it comes to making the American flag, hardly anyone has heard of Mary Pickersgill. But the immense flag that she and her daughter made nearly two centuries ago is one of the country's best-loved patriotic symbols.

title: Fortysomething Rock Star's Plight
description: Polly Draper is a very appealing actress with a significant stage rsum, but nothing she has ever done theatrically has usurped her identity as Ellyn, the single young professional from television's ''thirtysomething.'' It's easy to imagine that she's weary of hearing that, weary of waiting around for the next role that sticks in the mind and so decided to create it herself. But the play she has written, ''Getting Into Heaven'' will not, sad to say, rectify the situation.

title: Delay by U.N. On Rebuking North Korea Is Urged
description: China and Russia sought today to delay a Security Council condemnation of North Korea's nuclear arms program, a day after a top North Korean general said any sanctions or blockades initiated by the United States would be considered a ''complete breach'' of the truce that ended hostilities on the peninsula 50 years ago.

title: Canada law lifts Asian gays
description: HONG KONG:  While homosexual acts are illegal in many Asian jurisdictions, gay rights activists hope that Canada's new same-sex marriage law will open an avenue for pressuring legal change in the region.

description: It rained here most of this afternoon, causing the men's quarterfinals between Sbastien Grosjean and Tim Henman and between Alexander Popp and Mark Philippoussis to be suspended. The rain also forced the other two quarterfinals between Andy Roddick and Jonas Bjorkman and between Sjeng Schalken and Roger Federer to be postponed until Thursday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Art Gallery Admits Tax Violation
description: A company that owns an Upper East Side art gallery specializing in Dutch and Flemish masters pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to evading more than $200,000 in city and state taxes. The gallery company, Bob P. Haboldt and Company, which is on East 80th Street, admitted to two felony counts of violating the tax law and paid $400,000 in fines, officials said. An investigation found that the gallery failed to collect sales tax on more than 11 art works between March 1998 and November 2002. Officials in the Manhattan district attorney's office said customers of the gallery had remitted or were in the process of paying sales tax that had not been collected from them by the company. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Opinions to Spare? Click Here
description: A PENNY for your thoughts? These days your online opinion may be worth $1 or more as market researchers try to reach consumers who have grown increasingly reluctant to respond to surveys conducted by telephone, by mail or in person. In the process, they are changing the way research is done and raising questions about whose voice is being heard.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: NORTHERN IRELAND: HOSPITAL `SPY RING' The police in Belfast arrested five men in connection with a paramilitary spy ring that allegedly used medical records at Royal Victoria Hospital to single out politicians and police officers. Investigators suspect that the men are part of the Real I.R.A., a dissident group that opposes the mainstream Irish Republican Army's cease-fire. "It is a substantial operation, and it has been very professionally executed and carried out," said Hugh Orde, the chief constable.    Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: NASDAQ BROKER SEPARATES INTO TWO BUSINESSES
description: The Instinet Group, the electronic broker for Nasdaq stocks, reorganized into two businesses and laid off the sales clerks that sought trades from brokers and dealers for its electronic trade-matching systems. The company is looking to rebound from a loss of $627 million last year. Instinet, 63 percent owned by the Reuters Group, will run its brokerage and trading units as separate businesses, said Andrew Goldman, the executive vice president for marketing.

description: An explosion at a mosque here that killed at least six people on Monday night, including the mosque's imam, resulted from the presence of a bomb-making class inside, the United States Central Command said in a statement issued tonight.

title: Fabrics That Sneer At Stains
description: ''It's life-changing,'' said Randy Rubin of Crypton, a chemical treatment that makes cotton, wool, polyester or rayon resistant to water, stains and bacteria. Life- changing because you will never again have to flinch when a guest spills red wine or a child drops a hot dog. Ms. Rubin's husband, Craig, patented Crypton technology, which they sell through their company Hi-Tex, in West Bloomfield, Mich. Crypton-treated fabrics have been used at McDonald's franchises since the late 1990's. Now Crypton is available for the home in jacquards, twills, chenilles, top, and Smart Suedes, above, that resist even lipstick and ink; $25 to $50 a yard. Information: (800) 279-7866.

title: Bush's Record on Jobs: Risking Comparison To a Republican Ghost
description: For George W. Bush, the race has begun to escape comparisons to Herbert Hoover.

title: For Home Buyers, Fear of Commitment
description: LAST year, Jeff Holthaus, a 36-year-old engineer in Chicago, decided he was ready to settle down. But he had a commitment problem. Sure, he had his reasons. First, he had to figure out what he wanted. Then his company decided to move to Michigan, so he had to find a new job. And it wasn't always about him, either. In one case, he was the one who was rejected.

The fourth inning of last night's game against the Expos was unraveling, Seo was about to exit and Howe had a suggestion for him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SATTERTHWAITE
description: SATTERTHWAITE -- Franklin Bache, age 88, of Cranston, RI, died peacefully in his sleep June 30. Formerly of New York, NY and Short Hills, NJ, he was a market research executive who became an avid painter in his retirement. A direct descendant of Benjamin Franklin, he also served as President General of the Society for Descendants of Signers of the Declaration of Independence. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Emily Vaux Cresson Satterthwaite, of Cranston, RI; his son Franklin Satterthwaite, Jr., of Cranston, RI; his daughter, Sarah Gibson, of Toronto; and four grandchildren: Margaret Gibson, Katherine Gibson, Peter Satterthwaite, and Thomas Satterthwaite. A memorial service will be held in North Hatley, Quebec, Canada on July 5 at 4 o'clock in St. Barnabas Church. >>AD#

title: MetroStars Turn On Offense But Have to Settle for a Draw

They scored another goal in stoppage time that appeared to be the winner but settled for a 4-4 tie at Giants Stadium.

title: Market Place; PeopleSoft Sees Good Quarter, Lifted in Part By Oracle Foes
description: PeopleSoft defied fears on Wall Street that its software business would suffer from the uncertainty caused by a hostile takeover bid from Oracle, telling analysts yesterday that it expected to beat their second-quarter earnings projections by a comfortable margin.

title: Just a Leica (Pay No Attention To the Thing Behind the Curtain)
description: For some time, Nikon and Canon have offered digital cameras that accept many lenses originally designed for their 35-millimeter film cameras. Now Leica, a smaller German rival, says it will offer a way to allow some of its users to take digital pictures with their current cameras as well as their lenses.

title: A.I.G. to Stay in New Jersey
description: The American International Group, the world's largest insurer, said yesterday that it would reverse a plan to stop selling auto insurance in New Jersey after the state loosened some regulations.

title: Edison Stays Afloat By Altering Course
description: Confounding its critics in educational circles, Edison Schools, the nation's first and largest for-profit school management company, has made it to another graduation season. But in doing so, it has altered its course in ways that may mute Edison's future role in the national debate over educational reform.

title: Scouting Council Attacks Article Before It's Printed
description: In the spirit of the Boy Scout motto, ''Be prepared,'' the Boy Scouts national council sent a four-page internal memorandum last week to its local councils describing an anticipated article in The New York Times about scouting's ban on gays as inaccurate.

title: Trust Says Company Owes Rent on 24 Hotels
description: Hospitality Properties Trust, a hotel owner, said that the Prime Hospitality Corporation failed to pay rent due on Tuesday for 24 AmeriSuites hotels that Prime Hospitality manages for it.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Sweeping Party Changes
description: Prime Minister Costas Simitis, whose governing Socialist party has been trailing in opinion polls, appeared poised to overhaul his cabinet after ordering several party officials to resign, including the powerful secretary general, Costas Laliotis. Mr. Simitis told reporters the shake-up was necessary in order to chart a ''new period'' for his government and his Pasok party.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: SCHOOL MANAGEMENT PLAN IS CRITICIZED Assemblyman Steven Sanders yesterday criticized Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to reorganize the city's school districts. He told Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein that the new system, dividing the 32 existing community school districts into 10 regions, was shaping up to be more complicated than the old one. At a public hearing, Mr. Sanders, the chairman of the Assembly's education committee, told Mr. Klein, "It has become more complex, less easy for parents." Mr. Klein defended the plan, saying, "I exercised my judgment because I think that's the best thing for the system." Last month, Mr. Sanders and other lawmakers settled a lawsuit against the city aimed at blocking the plan. As part of the settlement, Mr. Klein agreed to keep small offices in each of the 32 districts. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: Herbie Mann, 73, Musician Who Gave Flute a Jazz Sound

title: Senators Back From Iraq See Lengthy U.S. Military Presence
description: WASHINGTON, July 3  A bipartisan group of senators, just back from a visit to Iraq, said today that American forces would have to remain there a long time to ensure the emergence of a democratic society, and that the United States needed the help of other nations.

title: That Immortal Scrawl, With a Digital Quill
description: ''HOW about that?'' Rob Fisher said. ''It's like a typo. Right in the Declaration of Independence.'' ''What's great about this document,'' he said, ''is that you know you are looking at something a human being has done, with real flaws and nuances.''

O'Farrell, chief executive of its parent company, CartCraft of Providence, R.I., which develops and sells products for the lawn and garden.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Spammer Agrees To Pay $221,000 To Fraud Victims
description: A spammer has agreed to repay more than $221,000 to consumers who were cheated by a fake work-at-home e-mail offer and may serve almost five years in prison for fraud, federal consumer protection officials said. Nelson Barrero, who operated the Stuffingforcash.com Corporation and related companies, has pleaded guilty to wire fraud and could be sentenced to 46 to 57 months in prison, the Federal Trade Commission in Washington said. Mr. Barrero is scheduled to be sentenced on Sept. 5 by a federal judge in East St. Louis, Ill., the agency said. Mr. Barrero and his companies also agreed, the agency said, to reimburse consumers who paid $40 each on the false promise that they would receive addressed envelopes that they could stuff with sales letters. Consumers were told they would earn $2 for each envelope they stuffed, the agency said. Mr. Barrero and his companies obtained customers through mass e-mailings, or spam.

title: Khieu Ponnary, 83, First Wife Of Pol Pot, Cambodian Despot
description: Khieu Ponnary, the quiet Cambodian intellectual who was the first wife of the Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot and a prominent member of the movement in its early days, died on Tuesday in Cambodia. She was 83.

title: PROVIDENT TO BUY NEW YORK BANK FOR $73.5 MILLION
description: Provident Bancorp Inc., which owns bank branches in Rockland and Orange counties in New York, agreed to buy the E.N.B. Holding Company for about $73.5 million to add banks in the state. Provident said it would pay $4,830 a share for each outstanding share of E.N.B. The purchase price represents the ''limited number'' of shares owned by E.N.B. Holding, said Stephen Dormer, a senior vice president at Provident. E.N.B., based in Ellenville, N.Y., is the parent of Ellenville National Bank, which said it had $324.6 million in assets and $292.2 million in deposits as of March 31. Stock in Provident, based in Montebello, N.Y., rose $2.20, or 6.7 percent, to $35.30 a share.
