The Pils, as they are popularly known, appear to believe that it is no sin to entertain. And the men, women and children of all ages who packed the Joyce Theater on Monday night were clearly having the time of their lives.

title: General Says 'We're Still at War' in Iraq as Attacks Continue
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 3 - Two months after President Bush declared the end of major combat, the commander of allied forces in Iraq acknowledged today that ``we're still at war,'' and the United States announced a reward of up to $25 million for the capture of Saddam Hussein or confirmation of his death.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Hospital 'Spy Ring'
description: The police in Belfast arrested five men in connection with a paramilitary spy ring that allegedly used medical records at Royal Victoria Hospital to single out politicians and police officers. Investigators suspect that the men are part of the Real I.R.A., a dissident group that opposes the mainstream Irish Republican Army's cease-fire. ''It is a substantial operation, and it has been very professionally executed and carried out,'' said Hugh Orde, the chief constable. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WASSERSTROM, , ROSLYN
description: WASSERSTROM -- Roslyn. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Helen Hollander and Carla Lamberson. Loving motherin-law of Martin Hollander. Cherished grandmother of Evan and Justin. Adored aunt and great-aunt. >>AD#

title: A Child of the 60's, and a Keeper of the Faith
description: MICHAEL A. REBELL, executive director of the Campaign for Fiscal Equity, does not seem the type to do the frug. (That's a dance, for the boogie-challenged among you.)

title: McCann Picks Director of G.M
description: Garry Neel, 48, managing director at the Troy, Mich., office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, was named yesterday to an added post, worldwide account director for the General Motors Corporation.

title: New Overtime Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Fielder Cook, director of many films and television dramas, misstated his wife's maiden name and gave the name of a daughter incompletely. His wife was Katherine Belk, not Belle; the daughter uses the name Lindsey Cook Roth.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: AOL SELLS TELEVISION STAKE Continuing a retreat from China, AOL Time Warner is selling a 64 percent stake in its Chinese television unit to a company backed by the Asian billionaire Li Ka-shing for $37 million. The Chinese company, Tom.com, said it would issue 53 million Hong Kong dollars ($6.8 million) in new shares to buy the stake in the unit, Chinese Entertainment Television. Tom.com also said it would provide all of the financing needs for CETV, up to $30 million, for the next 30 months. The deal values CETV at about $55 million. Tom.com's shares gained 4.3 percent yesterday. AOL, which put a Chinese Internet venture on hold earlier this year, will retain 36 percent of the unit and has an option to repurchase shares later. (Reuters)

title: FORMICA GETS $175 MILLION FOR RESTRUCTURING
description: The Formica Corporation, a maker of countertops, said it had received court approval for a $175 million investment from Cerberus Capital Management and Oaktree Capital Management to help it emerge from bankruptcy. Cerberus and Oaktree, the company's two largest unsecured creditors, will also assume about $427 million in debt, Formica said. The transaction cuts the company's bank debt to about $160 million. It said the United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan approved the deal on Tuesday. Formica sought bankruptcy protection in March 2002 to restructure more than $816 million in debt. The equity investment will form the basis of Formica's reorganization plan, and the company said it expects to emerge from bankruptcy early next year.

title: Paris Frees Head of Group Opposing Iran
description: In a setback to France's war against terrorism, a Paris appeals court today ordered the release on bail of a leader of a long-established armed Iranian opposition group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GITELSON, , PAUL, D.S.W.
description: GITELSON--Paul, D.S.W. The Trustees and Staff of Jewish Childcare Association mourn the loss of Paul Gitelson, who as Chief Executive Officer of JCCA from 1992 to the present, led the agency through a decade of vast changes in practice and attitudes towards children and families. Dr. Gitelson began at JCCA in 1982 as Training Director and during his eleven years at JCCA's helm, was responsible for the institution of familycentered practice, an agencywide approach to working with children in partnership with their families; an increased emphasis on independent living skills training; and accountability. He was active in the child welfare community, holding posts at C.W.L.A., C.O.F.C.C.A., H.S.C., A.A.C.R.C. and U.J.A.-Federation of New York. Paul was immensely devoted to his family and extraordinarily proud of their role in social welfare in New York City. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Aileen Gitelson, his children, Lisa and Michael and their families. Paul had a passion for social justice and a talent for connecting warmly with people; clients, trustees, colleagues and public officials benefited from his friendship and fine sense of humor. His contributions on behalf of children and families were significant. He will be missed. Barbara B. Mann, President Joyce L. Kramer, Board Chair Richard Altman, C.O.O.

title: Judge Says Closing of Queens Firehouse Is Illegal
description: A state judge yesterday upheld the closing of five of six firehouses by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in the city's budget crunch, but ruled that the administration illegally closed one in Queens when it failed to give some residents adequate notice.

title: Who Pulled the Pond's Plug? (A Hamptons Mystery)
description: The houses around and near Georgica Pond, an asymmetrical, mostly freshwater body right next to the Atlantic Ocean, are some of the most coveted in the Hamptons, owned by the likes of Steven Spielberg, Calvin Klein and, although she has decided to sell hers, Martha Stewart.

title: Boy Scouts Under Fire; Ban on Gays Is at Issue
description: After two years of meetings, civic leaders and Boy Scout executives here drafted a policy saying that the local scout council would not discriminate against gays. The goal was to forge a quiet compromise that would satisfy all parties: corporations and foundations that had withdrawn their support because of the national organization's ban on gays, gay rights advocates and the national scouting leadership.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Two Brothers Shot, One Fatally
description: Apparently without provocation, a gunman shot two young brothers, one fatally, in a sudden confrontation early yesterday morning at the entrance of their Co-Op City apartment, the police said. Malachi Wong, 20, died of a gunshot to his lower left back. His brother Timothy Wong, 18, survived a gunshot to his shoulder and was in fair condition after surgery at Jacobi Medical Center. The police said the brothers worked at Playland at Rye Beach. The gunman escaped and there have been no arrests, the police said last night. Shortly after 1:45 a.m., the police said, the gunman walked past the brothers outside their building, at 920 Co-Op City Boulevard, and gave the brothers a hard stare. The brothers, startled, headed to the entrance of their building. The gunman followed and opened fire. Another man had been seen with the gunman in the courtyard. The police said both men were about six feet two inches tall, weighing 150 pounds. One wore a white T-shirt and light jeans and the other had dreadlocks, the police said. Andrea Elliott (NYT)

title: New York Recycling
description: To the Editor:

title: They Leap From the Page In a Single Bound
description: Spider-Man, the Incredible Hulk and X-Men have fought a multitude of villains in a host of settings.

title: Mortgage Applications Up
description: Applications for mortgages rebounded last week, reflecting increases in refinancing and purchases, an industry report showed.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Bhopal Extradition Sought
description: Nearly two decades after the toxic gas leak at the Union Carbide factory in Bhopal in central India, India has asked the United States government to extradite Warren M. Anderson, then chairman of the company. A warrant has been pending against Mr. Anderson since April 1992 in a criminal case in which he is charged with culpable homicide, the equivalent of manslaughter. More than 3,000 people were killed when a deadly gas was released from a storage tank at the plant on Dec. 3, 1984. Thousands more died later from the aftereffects. The case was pressed by organizations representing survivors. Mr. Anderson resigned as chairman 15 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NATHAN, , CARL H.
description: NATHAN--Carl H. June 6, 2003 in Basel, Switzerland after a short illness, dearly beloved husband, brother and uncle. Born 1912, Carl touched many lives through his many business and social interests. We thank his many friends who also mourned his passing. >>AD#

title: New Details Are Disclosed On Missing Baylor Player
description: The Waco police continued to investigate the disappearance of the Baylor basketball player Patrick Dennehy today as new details emerged about his relationship with his former teammate Carlton Dotson.

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed Monday about Justice Clarence Thomas's dissent in last week's affirmative action case misquoted his opinion. Justice Thomas wrote that ''beneficial and burdensome racial classifications are equally invalid,'' not equally valid.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: LAPTOP SALES BEAT DESKTOPS FOR FIRST TIME Sales of laptop computers in stores in the United States outpaced those of desktop computers for the first time in May, according to a survey by the NPD Group, a market research firm. Laptops accounted for more than 54 percent of the nearly $500 million in retail computer sales in May, the company said on Tuesday. That contrasts with January 2000, when laptops represented less than 25 percent of sales volume, NPD said. Stephen Baker, director of industry analysis at the NPD Group, attributed the surge in sales of laptop computers to a greater interest in being able to transport a personal computer.    (AP)

title: AT HOME WITH: Justin Theroux; The Joy Of Junk
description: THE day the new ''Charlie's Angels'' movie opened, Justin Theroux was in his Greenwich Village apartment, rolling cigarettes and explaining his decorating secrets. Mr. Theroux, 31, the nephew of the writer Paul Theroux, plays the villain in the movie, which cost $120 million to make. His decorating tips required far earthier sums.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A Lawsuit Of One's Own

title: Theater That Uses The City As a Stage
description: From the top of One Times Square, where the ball drops on New Year's Eve, to the Chrysler Building to the Roosevelt Island tramway, Deborah Warner had scouted locations since October. The search was not for a film but for an environment in which to place a site-specific performance installation called ''The Angel Project.'' That project, which Ms. Warner regards, quite simply, as ''a walk,'' is the theatrical feature of Lincoln Center Festival 2003, which starts next week.

title: Justice Dept. Seeks Reconsideration of Ruling on 9/11 Suspect
description: The Justice Department has asked a federal appeals court to reconsider its decision declining to prevent Zacarias Moussaoui from interviewing captured people linked to Al Qaeda to support his defense that he was not involved in the Sept. 11 terrorist plot.

title: Hearst Ranch Seeks Public-Private Balance
description: As Stephen T. Hearst maneuvered his Chevrolet Suburban up the steep switchbacks of the Hearst Ranch, here in the shadow of his great-grandfather's storied castle, his elbow glanced off the console, which holds his books on tape.

title: Libraries Planning A Meeting on Filters
description: Officials of the American Library Assocation will call a meeting with the makers of Internet filtering software next month to voice concern over a federal law that requires libraries and schools to use Internet filters or risk losing federal money.

title: English Health Official Seeks a Broader Ban on Smoking
description: LONDON, July 3  Smoking should be banned in all public places to reduce the threat of illness caused by secondhand inhalation, England's chief medical officer, Sir Liam Donaldson, said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Biotech Food Labeling Rule Advances in European Union

title: Factory Orders and Computer Sector Lead Shares Higher
description: Stocks rose yesterday after Merrill Lynch told investors to buy shares of Microsoft, spurring a rally in computer-related companies.

title: Citing Low Threat Level, Officials Plan No Special Terror Alert for Holiday Weekend
description: Terrorist threats against the United States, domestically and abroad, have dipped to a surprisingly low level in recent days, senior government officials said today, in sharp contrast to intelligence reports of possible attacks that preceded last year's July Fourth holiday.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on June 5 about architectural moldings misstated the Internet address of a source, Decorators Supply of Chicago. It is www.decoratorssupply.com.

title: Searching For Novelty In a Palmtop
description: REMEMBER palmtops? Back in the golden age (circa 1996), they were thrilling and new. Every time Palm Computing sneezed, shockwaves went through the electronics community. There was one new model every year, and it vaulted straight onto the covers of techno-magazines. For the discerning gadget freak, life was a breathless adventure.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Jobless Rate Rises to 6.4 Percent; Highest in More Than 9 Years
description: Once again failing to live up to politicians' hopes and economists' expectations, the labor market got tougher for job seekers last month. The unemployment rate rose to 6.4 percent, the highest in nine years, and the economy lost 30,000 jobs.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AK STEEL HOLDING CORP., Middletown, Ohio, the U.S.'s largest supplier of steel for cars and trucks, said it would buy an exhaust tube factory in Columbus, Ind., from ArvinMeritor Inc., Troy, Mich., the world's largest maker of vehicle exhausts. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Williams Sisters to Meet Again in Wimbledon Final
description: LONDON, July 3  To polite applause, Serena Williams walked out to serve for this Grand Slam semifinal. When she missed her first serve of the game, silence engulfed Center Court as she composed herself to hit the next.

title: Corrections
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day last Thursday, about the connection between an increase in pay and the number of hours worked, misidentified the delivery service that participated in an experiment conducted by two economists at the University of Zurich. It was Veloblitz of Zurich; Flash Delivery Services provided some data.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Nuclear Chief Wants Clarification
description: Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, the head of Iran's nuclear power program who is on an official visit to Moscow, said his country would be willing to submit to tougher international inspections of its nuclear sites if the United Nations agency responsible for inspections, the International Atomic Energy Agency, clarified its demands. ''We want the demands of the I.A.E.A. to be concrete, transparent and backed by documents,'' Mr. Aghazadeh, above, said at a press conference on the last day of his three-day visit. The international community has said it suspects Iran of secretly developing nuclear weapons, possibly using fuel that Russia will supply for a nuclear power plant it is building there. Dr. Mohamed ElBaradei, the Egyptian who heads the United Nations agency, is to visit Iran on July 9. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on June 24 with an article about the auction of the entertainment assets of Vivendi Universal used an incorrect given name in some copies for the entrepreneur who led a group that made a bid. He is Marvin Davis, not Martin.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Monday about tension in the final days before the selection of a host city for the 2010 Olympics misidentified the home country of Ottavio Cinquanta, a member of the International Olympic Committee. It is Italy, not Spain.

title: Alstom to Issue $692 Million In New Shares
description: Shareholders of the power and transportation company Alstom approved today a sale of as much as 600 million euros ($692 million) in stock -- a move seen as vital for the struggling company.

title: Holiday Tomorrow -- Independence Day
description: NEW YORK

title: For Flexible Hosts
description: ALONG with summer nights come twilight barbecues, moonlit walks -- and weekend guests. As you size up your guest suite (a k a home office, pool house, screen porch), consider adding flexible pieces that can accommodate more than an overnight visitor or two.

title: Brazil Ponders Nestl's Acquisition of Competitor
description: When it finally comes to the crunch, a $230 million acquisition by Swiss multinational Nestl of Garoto, the maker of some of Brazil's favorite chocolates, promises to be the toughest test yet for the country's fledgling antitrust authorities.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: No Budging in California
description: In California, where Republicans hold no statewide offices and are minorities in both houses of the Legislature, the G.O.P. has found an arena to exercise some political muscle: the state budget debacle. Republicans are stalwartly committed to blocking the passage of tax increases, while Democrats insist that raising taxes is better than continuing to hack away at already drained public services. The result of this standoff is that California has entered a new fiscal year with no budget.

title: As Tour Nears, a Mellow Armstrong Says He's Ready to Roll
description: PARIS, July 3  Two days before the start of the Tour de France, the defending champion, Lance Armstrong, was mellow, thoughtful and cordial, even when asked dumb questions.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Interest Rate Unchanged
description: Australia's central bank left interest rates unchanged, signaling that the central bank governor, Ian Macfarlane, was more concerned about increasing housing prices than a slowing economy or the currency's biggest quarterly gain in 20 years. The Australian dollar rose to a five-year high after Mr. Macfarlane left the overnight cash rate at 4.75 percent, dashing the expectation of many economists that he would follow the lead of the Federal Reserve in the United States and cut borrowing costs a quarter percentage point.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about plans by Abbott Laboratories to settle an investigation into its sales practices misspelled the name of its partner in a joint venture, TAP Pharmaceutical Products, which earlier settled accusations related to the marketing of a cancer drug. It is Takeda Chemical Industries, not Tadeka.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Drug Trafficker Sentenced
description: A Yonkers man convicted of federal narcotics conspiracy and distribution charges was sentenced yesterday to life in prison without the possibility of parole, the United States attorney's office said. The man, Marzell Underwood, 24, was convicted in January of operating an interstate drug ring in Yonkers and Burlington, Vt., that sold large amounts of heroin, as well as powder and crack cocaine. The judge in the case, Jed S. Rakoff of United States District Court, also discovered an attempt by Mr. Underwood to testify falsely and encourage witnesses to perjure themselves. Thirteen other members of Mr. Underwood's organization have also been convicted and have received sentences ranging from time served to 87 months in prison. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Americans Show Strength At the Henley Regatta
description: The record number of entries from the United States at this year's 154th Henley Royal Regatta treated the English to some of the most closely contested rowing races of opening day. In Henley's knockout competitions, all six American eight-oared entries, racing in the Temple Challenge Cup advanced to Thursday's Round of 16. Princeton, with its United States national champion freshmen and its Eastern Sprint champion lightweight varsity in opposite halves of the draw, advanced both without being extended.

title: Odd Package. Edgy Riders. Trains Stop. Unclear Why.
description: So yesterday wasn't just another one of those days. It was a subway-stopping, bridge-closing, going-nowhere kind of day that had a nerve-rattling uneasiness. And all because of small things that had nothing to do with each other but set off a major reaction in Lower Manhattan, first on the subway at Canal Street, and later around a car near the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Russian Buys A Soccer Team In England
description: Months after raking in billions of dollars from the sale of an oil company, Roman Abramovich, one of Russia's richest men and perhaps its least predictable, made a purchase that surprised even the most jaded of businessmen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OROURKE, , ROBERT M.
description: OROURKE--Robert M. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Robert M. Orourke, associated with The Times from November 1967 until retiring in February 1992. >>AD#

title: U.S. IS CONSIDERING TROOPS IN LIBERIA TO MONITOR TRUCE
description: The Pentagon has ordered military planners to prepare detailed options for American troops to join an international peacekeeping force to oversee a cease-fire in the war-battered West African nation of Liberia, two senior military officials said today.

title: Face Recognition: Readers React
description: Last week in this newsletter, I described a fast, effective ID-card mechanism that a cruise line employs to speed up the boarding process. I wondered if it could be considered a tiny trial of the national security card that's been proposed.

title: Shift in Management For Shuttle Program
description: NASA announced sweeping changes in the management of the shuttle program yesterday, bringing people known largely for their engineering expertise to replace or supplement members of the management team that was in charge at the time of the fatal mission of the Columbia in February.

title: Bush Chooses U.S. Executive For AIDS Job
description: On the eve of a presidential visit to Africa, President Bush today nominated Randall Tobias, a former chairman and chief executive of Eli Lilly & Company, to run a $15 billion program to fight AIDS worldwide.

title: ALLIANCE GAMING TO SELL 3 SLOT UNITS FOR $120 MILLION
description: The Alliance Gaming Corporation, a maker of slot machines, agreed to sell three businesses that operate slot machines in supermarkets and racetracks for at least $119.5 million in cash to focus on supplying casinos. Alliance, based in Las Vegas, said the sales would enable it to concentrate on its Bally Gaming and Systems unit, which makes slot machines for casinos. The United Coin Machine Company was bought by Century Gaming Inc., for $126 million in cash and preferred stock. Video Services was sold to Gentilly Gaming. Terms were not disclosed. Bally Wulff, which operates gaming devices in Germany, was sold to an equity investment group for $16.5 million in cash.

title: Lewis Interested in Rematch
description: Twelve days ago in Los Angeles, Lennox Lewis stopped Vitali Klitschko after six rounds to retain his World Boxing Council heavyweight title. It was his first fight in a year. Yesterday, Lewis said he wanted to fight Klitschko again before taking on Roy Jones Jr., the World Boxing Association champion.

title: Good Debut for Stock Suggests Rebound for Initial Offerings
description: Molina Healthcare became the latest sign of a rebound for the initial public offering market, rising sharply in initial trading yesterday.

title: Kenyan Women Accuse British Troops of Rape
description: A group of 650 Kenyan women who say they were sexually assaulted and in many cases gang raped by British soldiers on military assignment in their country won the right today to sue the Ministry of Defense for compensation.

title: With a Nudge or Vibration, Game Reality Reverberates
description: A ONE-eyed zombie with bloodied teeth lumbers toward you through the South American mountains. Such beasts appear everywhere you look. Each swipe of their hideous arms reverberates through your body, or at least through your fingertips.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMON, , FRANCES
description: SIMON--Frances. The Board of Directors and members of Bocaire Country Club Inc. record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Frances Simon, on Wednesday, July 2, 2003. We extend condolences to all of her family. Services will be held Friday, July 4th, 2003 at 10 A.M. at Riverside Nassau North Funeral Home, Great Neck, New York. Kurt Merl, President >>AD#

title: No Remembrance Of the Things They Passed
description: When the Tour de France begins its centenary on Saturday, nearly 200 cyclists will embark on a most idiosyncratic race, one that hovers between tradition and transcendence, between solitude and community. But as the equipment and the training get better and better, one wonders if this will finally be the year when speed and solitude win, and riders, in the pursuit of velocity, completely seal themselves off from the world.

title: Don't Evict the Heart of a City
description: To the Editor:

title: Transit Projects For Downtown Get Under Way With Requests
description: Two major downtown transportation projects related to the rebuilding of the World Trade Center got under way this week as officials issued requests for proposals from companies seeking to work on the projects' early stages.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: SARS ALL-CLEAR The World Health Organization removed Toronto from its list of SARS-affected areas, 20 days after the last new infection was reported. The announcement should give a lift to Canada's tourism industry, which has been badly damaged since the disease was first reported in the country four months ago. Thirty-eight people have died of the respiratory illness in and around the city, making it the most affected place outside of Asia. Eleven people are still in critical or deteriorating condition. Only Taiwan remains on the health agency's SARS list. Toronto had been removed from the list in May but was put back when a new cluster of victims was reported.

title: Why Don't You and Your Friends Go Play on the Furniture, Dear?
description: Ikea has taken a stand against couch-potato kids. Ikea PS Children offers 32 pieces of furniture with built-in play possibilities. ''Children used to play outside, but now there's too much traffic, and too much danger,'' said Todd Steele, manager for North American children's furniture, Ikea Sweden. ''So we brought the play element inside.'' With some of the furniture, he said, ''it's impossible to sit still.''

title: PGA Golfers Question If New Test Is Sufficient
description: The PGA Tour's decision to have voluntary testing of golf clubs at tournaments next year is a positive step but does not go far enough, Tiger Woods said today after his pro-am round at the Western Open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERDY, , RUBE
description: BERDY--Rube. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Rube Berdy, associated with The Times from September 1958 until retiring in August 2000. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROZMARYN, , JACK
description: ROZMARYN--Jack. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and great grandfather. Astute entrepreneur and advisor, Rodomske Chasid, and walking encyclopedia of Chasidus. Survivor of Auschwitz and eyewitness to the horrors of the Holocaust. A true hero who saved scores of lives. We have lost the patriarch of our family. We will miss your warm smile, sage advice and sharp wit. Our world will never be the same. We hope to make you proud in all we do. Survived by his wife Lillian, his children Margie Hoffman, Annette and Avi Lebor, grandchildren Michael and Shelley Lebor, Karen and Donny Appel, Danny Lebor, Lauren and Jason Meyer, Josh Hoffman and great grandchildren Evan, Kerri, Abigail, Zachary, Hailey. >>AD#

title: Macho America Storms Europe's Runways
description: A remarkable reversal of sentiment and symbolism has occurred in the five months since designers here and in Milan and London, the site of fervent antiwar rallies, displayed peace flags and, in one instance, staged a love-in that featured a couple in a bed. At that time, European opposition to President Bush's position on Iraq ran so high that Tom Ford, the creative director of Gucci and a fellow Texan, told reporters after his women's show in February, ''I'm embarrassed to be an American.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARKE, , JULIUS J.
description: MARKE--Julius J. Your legions of friends of whom I am one are painfully bereaved. Herbert H. Hirschhorn >>AD#

title: French Rider at Home With Tour's First Leg
description: When the Tour de France rolls out for its first stage Sunday, it will pass through a microcosm of the country: from the gritty streets of St. Denis, a town of immigrants and unemployment just north of Paris, through the capital itself and its mythic squares, and into the country, through quiet villages like, say, Coulommiers in a gentle valley to the east.

title: It's Paris in 1871, and You Are There
description: At 67, Peter Watkins remains a restless radical, creating films that spectacularly defy narrative conventions, entrenched ideologies and, it must be said, the patience of his viewers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAYPOL, , CYNNIE
description: SAYPOL--Cynnie. Never to be forgotten. Funny as hell and loved by all. The Dalton Gang >>AD#

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: LAOS: ENVOY SAYS JOURNALISTS MAY BE FREED IN DAYS Two European journalists and their American interpreter, sentenced on Monday to 15 years in prison, could be freed within days, the Laotian ambassador to France told Radio France Internationale. The sentencing of Vincent Reynaud, a French cameraman, Thierry Falise, a Belgian photographer, and the Rev. Naw Karl Mua, an ethnic Hmong-American pastor in St. Paul, Minn., prompted an international outcry. The men had been reporting on Hmong insurgents when they were arrested last month.    (Reuters)

title: Finance Chief Is Resigning at Troubled Advertising Company
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies said yesterday that Sean F. Orr, the chief financial officer during its recent troubles, would step down, effective at the end of August.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEDEN, , SIDNEY
description: HEDEN--Sidney, on July 1, 2003. Beloved husband of Henrietta. Dear father of Judith and Ira Markowitz, Arlene and Joe Labenson, and Ann and Arnie Green. Adored grandfather of Mindy Gotleib, Holly Sando, Brian Labenson, Michele Melvin, D.G. Green and Wendy Green. Great grandfather of Michael, Ashley, Marissa and Hayden. Services today, 12 noon, at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, LI >>AD#

title: AURORA FOODS PLANS TO FILE FOR PROTECTION
description: Aurora Foods Inc., the maker of Duncan Hines and Lender's bagels, said yesterday that it would file for bankruptcy protection and replace its chief executive under a $200 million agreement with an investor, J.W. Childs Associates. Aurora plans to convert about $400 million in bond debt into stock and cash through a prenegotiated bankruptcy filing. J.W. Childs's investment would give it a 65.6 percent stake in the reorganized company. Lawrence K. Hathaway will succeed Dale Morrison as chief executive of Aurora, which is based in St. Louis. The company has more than $578 million in losses since 1999. Aurora suffered from an accounting scandal in which its former chairman, Ian Wilson, was sentenced last year to 33 months in prison.

title: Death Sought for Animals in Monkeypox Case
description: Moving to prevent monkeypox from reaching wild animals in the United States, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended yesterday that all 850 animals from a contaminated shipment of exotic pets from Africa in April be destroyed, along with all prairie dogs that might have been exposed to them.

title: People
description: * Ron Greene resigned as president and chief executive at Euro RSCG Devon Direct, Berwyn, Pa., after his contract expired. Mr. Greene, who founded the agency in 1983 and sold it to Havas in 1999, said he was considering opening a direct-marketing consulting company. Charlie Tarzian, chief executive at a sibling agency, Euro RSCG Circle, Wilton, Conn., will handle Mr. Greene's duties until a successor is named.

title: Next Thursday at 8? Just a Minute, Let Me Check My Watch
description: The makers of palmtop computers are always trying to shrink the size of their devices. Now one of the latest models is so small it's not even meant for a palm. A new hand-held organizer from Fossil that went on sale this week is worn on the wrist like a watch but has all the functions of a hand-held device.

title: Bethlehem Shrugs as Israelis Leave It to Its Police
description: Taking his 5-year-old son Michael by the hand, Elias Thaljieh led him up the hill today to Manger Square to watch solemnly as Palestinian police officers, in pressed new uniforms and dented old cars, reasserted their authority in Bethlehem after Israeli forces withdrew to the town's edges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WASSERMAN, , EDITH
description: WASSERMAN--Edith on July 2, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Devoted mother of Stephen and the late Phyllis Steinhardt. Loving sister of Eleanor Adelson. Cherished grandmother of Lori Scher and Geoffrey. Services Thursday, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. >>AD#

title: Study Sees a Longer Time For Evacuating Indian Pt.
description: A study commissioned by Entergy Nuclear Northeast, which owns and operates the Indian Point nuclear power complex, has concluded that it would take nine hours and 25 minutes to evacuate everyone in the 10-mile zone around the plants, almost twice as long as previously estimated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIES, , CYNTHIA M.
description: FRIES--Cynthia M. on July 1, 2003 at Franciscan Oaks, Denville, New Jersey. Longtime resident of Montclair, NJ. Daughter of Colonel and Mrs. Claude S. Fries. Col. Fries was a veteran of the Spanish American War and WW I. She is survived and missed by her sister-in-law and three nephews and several grand nephews and grand nieces and a friend of many years. For info Van Tassel Chickene Brown Funeral Home in Bloomfield, NJ. Private interment. >>AD#

title: Don't Evict the Heart of a City (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: SAS To Offer Connexion On Long-Haul Flights
description: Scandinavian Airlines System will install Connexion broadband Internet access on its long-haul planes starting in February. Passengers will be able to use the service for $30 to $35 a flight en route to North America and Asia using any wireless Wi-Fi network card in a laptop computer. Connexion, which is part of the Boeing Company, estimates that one-third of passengers will pay for access on a given flight based on a three-month trial run with Lufthansa. Lufthansa agreed in May to install Connexion on all of its long-haul routes in 2004.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Linden: Plane Crashes After Takeoff
description: A small plane crashed into a commercial area shortly after takeoff yesterday afternoon, but the pilot, who was alone, suffered only minor injuries, said a spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration. The single engine Cessna 172 crashed in a field about a mile from Linden Airport shortly after takeoff, and the pilot was treated for minor injuries at the scene, said Arlene Salac, an F.A.A. spokeswoman. She identified the pilot as Stanley Ferber, 62, of Brooklyn. A preliminary investigation indicated that the plane had lost power during departure, but the F.A.A. and National Transportation Safety Board were investigating, Ms. Salac said. The plane, built in 1977, is registered to the Richmond Pilots Association in Staten Island, but there is no telephone listing for the group. John Holl (NYT)

title: Papers That Boldly Depart From the Beribboned Tradition
description: Jean Orlebeke and her partner, Ellen Elfering, have created a collection of wrapping paper for their company, eiei-o, in Brooklyn, that does away with the need for a spool of fancy ribbon. Some designs have central patterns that radiate outward, said Ms. Orlebeke, a graphic designer who was inspired by the midcentury modernists' use of flat, bold graphic and biomorphic forms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KENNEY, , KATHERINE G.
description: KENNEY--Katherine G. on June 29. Beloved daughter of the late John E. Kenney and the late Carolina Kenney. She is survived by her aunt Virginia Ross Green and two cousins, Stephen Ross Green and Ann Pangels. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Wednesday, July 2, 2-5PM. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, July 3, 10AM, St. John The Evangelist Church, First Avenue at 55th Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to St. John the Evangelist Church. >>AD#

title: Judge Hints at Reinstatement For Men Who Wore Blackface
description: A federal judge in Manhattan indicated yesterday that he may have to order the reinstatement of a former New York City police officer and two former firefighters who were fired for wearing blackface on a 1998 Labor Day float in Broad Channel, Queens, if the city does not reach a financial settlement with the men.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It was a photo finish. That's what's great about sport, but winning is

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAPOLITO, , ANTHONY
description: DAPOLITO--Anthony, of Vesuvio Bakery, 160 Prince Street, New York City. Known by all as the Mayor of Greenwich Village. Beloved husband of Frances (nee Bianco). Devoted father of Jeannie Delaney. Loving brother of Joseph and the late Steven, Frank and Andrew. Cherished grandfather of Brian. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St, NYC, Thursday and Friday, 2-5 & 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Saturday 10AM, St. Anthony's RC Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Village Care of NY, 154 Christopher Street, NY, NY 10014, in his memory. >>AD#

title: Rainout Pushes Claussen Aside
description: At 4:30 this afternoon, when they had planned to be in the middle of a game at Camden Yards, the Yankees gathered on the platform at a Baltimore train station, ready for their ride home. Brandon Claussen was with them, but there is no work for him in New York.

title: Designers Dream on Paper of a City Park Called the High Line
description: Daisies, wild grasses and a crab apple tree grow on the High Line, one and a half miles of elevated railroad tracks running from West 34th Street to Gansevoort Street. (At right, a view from West 30th Street.) Built in the 1930's, the High Line was retired as a rail line in 1980. Now the Bloomberg administration and Friends of the High Line are suggesting it become an elevated promenade. A design competition, ''Designing the High Line,'' received 720 entries from 38 countries; next Thursday an exhibition of about 100 entries will open at Vanderbilt Hall in Grand Central Terminal and run through July 26. Admission is free.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OBERLANDER, , SAMUEL GUY, M.D.
description: OBERLANDER -- Samuel Guy, M.D., 63, died July 1, 2003 at home in Ardsley, NY of cancer. Born in Brooklyn, NY on June 22, 1940 to Harry and the late Belle Oberlander. A devoted father and husband, he is survived by his wife Monica, nee Hallacy; and their children, Matthew, Andrew, Laura Belle and Jennifer. Also survived by his children from his first marriage: Lynn (Gary Drevitch), Jill (Larry Penn) and Bert (Kristen) Oberlander; and grandchildren, Benjamin, Alexander, Jack and Natalie, all of Manhattan. Beloved brother of Martin ''Mickey,'' of Boca Raton, FL. A graduate of Hobart College, '61 and Harvard Medical School, '65, he was a dedicated physician. He was a Clinical Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, a partner in Associates for Women's Care, and practiced OB/GYN in the Bronx and Westchester for the past 30 years. Services will be held on Thursday, July 3 at 11AM at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave, White Plains, NY. Burial to follow at Ferncliff Cemetery. Donations may be made to the Samuel G. Oberlander, M.D. Foundation to advance ob/gyn and women's health, C/O Laurence Penn, Ellington Management Group, 53 Forest Ave, Old Greenwich, CT. 06870.

title: MEDICAL PRODUCTS MAKER ISSUES A WARNING ON PROFIT
description: Vital Signs Inc., which makes face masks and other disposable medical products, said third-quarter profit from continuing operations would be below its estimates because of legal and accounting costs. The company said profits would be 38 cents to 40 cents a share, which is down from its May forecast of 51 cents for the period, which ended Monday. Sales rose from $46.4 million in the quarter a year earlier, Vital Signs said declining to give a figure. The company, which is being sued by its former chief financial officer for ''fraudulent accounting,'' said costs related to a review of accounting practices and legal expenses contributed to the earnings shortfall.

title: Education Advocates Urge Quick Action by Albany on School Financing
description: Fresh from a victory in the state's highest court, education advocates fighting for equity in New York State's school financing system said today that the governor and lawmakers needed to tackle the issue as soon as possible.

title: Ernst & Young To Pay U.S. $15 Million In Tax Case
description: Ernst & Young, the big accounting firm, will pay the government $15 million because it did not properly register tax shelters and similar transactions or properly maintain lists of people who bought them. Details of the deals and customer names will now be turned over to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Expectations Are High, but Vast Problems Confront Boston's New Archbishop
description: After more than a year of mounting anger and disillusionment, Boston's Roman Catholics appear to be swept off their feet by their new archbishop, Sean P. O'Malley, who made his debut here on Tuesday at a news conference carried live on television and radio.

title: China? Or Here?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Gay Rights Milestone
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A music review last Thursday about a Norah Jones concert referred incorrectly to the singer Gillian Welch and her guitar accompanist, David Rawlings, who were the opening act. While they are a couple, they are not married.

title: Editorial Observer; In Colombia, Muckrakers Have Become Scarce
description: Colombia, a world leader in the production of tribulations, has also had a long tradition of journalists willing and able to investigate them. One of the best is Fabio Castillo, 47, until last month the chief of investigations for the Bogot newspaper El Espectador. Mr. Castillo was fired just after implicating Fernando Londoo Hoyos, who is both minister of interior and justice, in a corruption scandal. Mr. Castillo's dismissal shows the varied ways Colombia is silencing the independent voices that it so sorely needs.

title: Don't Evict the Heart of a City
description: To the Editor:

title: The Sidewalk Is His Pottery Barn
description: THE actor Justin Theroux is Mr. Downtown, the kind of guy who patronizes authentic Village spots like C. O. Bigelow Chemists and Garber Hardware. His prize acquisitions tend to be from the trash. The garbage is picked up on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday mornings on Mr. Theroux's favorite streets -- Perry, Charles and West Fourth -- so he recommends poking around the night before, especially when brownstones are being renovated.

title: Principal Is Accused of Having Sex With a Girl
description: The principal of a public elementary school in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday on charges that he repeatedly had sex with a girl from the time she was 11 until she was 14, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MANHEIMER, , LEONARD
description: MANHEIMER -- Leonard, September 28, 1934-July 3, 2002. You will be in my soul always. Thank you. Michael Nellenbac

title: DUANE READE REDUCES SECOND-QUARTER FORECAST
description: The drugstore chain Duane Reade Inc. lowered its second-quarter earnings forecast yesterday, citing the weather and the weak economy. Duane Reade, which is based in New York, said it expected operating income of 20 cents or 21 cents a share for the quarter, down from its previous forecast of 27 cents to 32 cents. Wall Street had expected earnings to be 24 cents a share. Duane Reade's lowered earnings forecast excludes an additional tax provision of about $1 million for the effect of New York's recent tax legislation. It lowered its second-quarter sales outlook by $5 million to $12 million. Duane Reade's stock fell 18 cents, to $14.46 a share.

title: New Hope for Shabby Modernist Heirlooms
description: AFTER 18 years of genteel ownership, followed by two years of my toddler's bouncing, my beloved Eames lounge chair looks, well, beyond classic. The black leather's rich patina is marred by countless cracks. The rosewood shell is chipped and streaked with white paint. And the seat cushion's guts spill out indecorously where the stitching has burst from the zipper.

title: Vancouver Wins 2010 Winter Olympics by 3-Vote Margin
description: Vancouver was selected as the site of the 2010 Winter Olympic Games today in a vote by the International Olympic Committee, defeating Pyeongchang, South Korea, and Salzburg, Austria, to bring the Games to Canada for the third time.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Disarmament Plan Delayed
description: An ambitious United Nations program to disarm 100,000 Afghan soldiers and armed militias around the country was postponed until the end of the month because the Defense Ministry has failed to enact necessary reforms in time, a presidential aide said. The disarmament and demobilization program is seen as essential in ending continuing violence and factional fighting before elections next year, but officials have said the program cannot go ahead until power in the Defense Ministry is more evenly distributed among Afghanistan's ethnic groups. The Tajiks, who are the strongest group militarily, dominate the Defense Ministry and have been reluctant to share power with other parties and ethnic groups. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: INVITROGEN TO BUY MOLECULE LABELER FOR $325 MILLION
description: The Invitrogen Corporation, which makes chemical kits used to analyze and clone genes, agreed to buy Molecular Probes Inc. for about $325 million to add drug-discovery products. The purchase, which will be completed by the end of September, will increase fourth-quarter revenue by $16 million and earnings by 5 cents a share, Invitrogen's new chief executive, Gregory T. Lucier, said. Molecular Probes, based in Eugene, Ore., had sales of $56 million last year from fluorescent markers used to label molecules in biology research. Invitrogen, based in Carlsbad, Calif., has announced almost half a billion dollars in acquisitions in seven months.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Ex-Minister Questioned In '71 Massacre
description: A former internal security minister was interrogated by special prosecutors about the government's role in the massacre of 30 left-wing protesters during a protest march in 1971. Mario Moya Palencia, who served as interior minister during the presidency of Luis Echeverra, from 1970 to 1976, refused to answer 96 questions from the prosecutors but said he would respond later, in writing. Paramilitary forces shot down the marchers on June 10, 1971. Historians now say the killings were part of a coordinated effort by the government to crush its left-wing opponents. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Korea's Golden Unwedding
description: On July 27, the free, prosperous people of South Korea and the oppressed, starving people of North Korea will celebrate the 50th anniversary of the armistice.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: EMC Buys Rights To BMC Data Storage Software
description: The EMC Corporation, one of the world's largest makers of computer data-storage systems, yesterday acquired the rights to discontinued storage software from BMC Software in exchange for access to BMC's customers. BMC, which makes programs for managing mainframe and server computers, left the storage software market this year, attributing its exit to a lack of return on its investment amid intense competition from rivals like I.B.M. and Veritas Software. EMC has bought nine software makers since 2000 and has spent billions of dollars on research to sell more software, which is more profitable than hardware. BMC, whose storage software runs on systems made by many companies, offers EMC access to about 50 BMC storage software customers, 5,000 other clients and 850 sales agents, Bill Nelson, senior vice president of EMC, said. Financial terms were not disclosed. Shares of EMC fell 33 cents, or 2.9 percent, to $10.89. BMC shares rose 45 cents, or 2.8 percent, to $16.40.

title: The Ghosts of Jamestown
description: I had a date the other night with a guy who has been dead for almost 400 years. His name was Richard Cornish, and the last time he got involved with another man, he was executed for his crime. That was at Jamestown, Va., in 1624, and his case was the first recorded sodomy prosecution in American history.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: SARS All-Clear
description: The World Health Organization removed Toronto from its list of SARS-affected areas, 20 days after the last new infection was reported. The announcement should give a lift to Canada's tourism industry, which has been badly damaged since the disease was first reported in the country four months ago. Thirty-eight people have died of the respiratory illness in and around the city, making it the most affected place outside of Asia. Eleven people are still in critical or deteriorating condition. Only Taiwan remains on the health agency's SARS list. Toronto had been removed from the list in May but was put back when a new cluster of victims was reported. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Italian's Sharp Tongue Punctures Image of United Europe
description: Stung by criticism, the Italian prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, suggested today to a German member of the European Parliament that he would make an excellent leader of a Nazi concentration camp.

title: For an Ailing Retina, Instant Diagnosis From Afar
description: AN eight-foot satellite dish stands outside the double-wide mobile home where Tyrone McElveen works, making it, as he observed, ''just like every other trailer in South Carolina.''

title: Where to Turn? A Plug-In Guide Points the Way
description: About as big as a pack of gum, the DeLorme Earthmate Global Positioning System receiver sits on a vehicle's dashboard and can turn a laptop into a portable navigation system.

title: Bernard Goldhirsh, 63, Magazine Innovator Who Started Inc.
description: Bernard A. Goldhirsh, who started a newsletter-publishing business in his basement that grew into Inc. magazine, one of the first publications to profit by aiming at owners of small businesses, died on Sunday in Boston. He was 63.

title: Another Choice; Wireless Rival Boasts Speed and a Roomy Keyboard
description: MICROSOFT isn't the only company in hot pursuit of corporate buyers. Palm's new wireless Tungsten C palmtop is a fast, powerful, worthy combatant, thanks to its brilliant, crisp screen, built-in antenna for Wi-Fi networks and a roomy thumb keyboard that's not yet available on any Pocket PC. (You know you're living in the 21st century when you hear the word ''roomy'' applied to a keyboard the size of a Pez dispenser.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOLSCHUH, , EDWARD B.
description: HOLSCHUH--Edward B., on June 30, 2003, of Westfield, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Constance Service Holschuh. Loving father of Edward B. Holschuh and Lina H. Coffey. Also survived by six grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren. A private funeral service was held at the August F. Schmidt Memorial Funeral Home, 139 Westfield Ave, Elizabeth, NJ on Wednesday. Interment Evergreen Cemetery. 1933 Graduate of Princeton University and retired Senior Vice President of Public Relations, EF Hutton, Corp, NYC. >>AD#

title: Economic Scene; Despite the recovery in stocks, some of the forces behind the Internet bust are still lurking.
description: THE stock market has come back from the dead, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index up 13 percent so far this year. Even the formerly moribund technology sector is reviving, with the Nasdaq showing a 26 percent return since January.

title: Miscellany
description: * The California Lottery Commission, Sacramento, extended on an interim basis its contract with Grey Worldwide, Los Angeles, part of the Grey Global Group, which expired May 31. The contract will remain in effect until an agency is selected to handle the lottery account, with billings estimated at $125 million over five years. The commission is in its third review for the assignment after the results of two previous reviews were canceled because of court challenges.

title: Van Gundy Names Ewing As Assistant
description: Jeff Van Gundy never underestimated the value of Patrick Ewing when he was coaching him in New York. Now, Van Gundy will be able to estimate Ewing's value as a coach.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: NEW TRIAL FOR CONVICTED KILLER A state appellate court yesterday ordered a new trial for a Bridgeport man who was serving a 90-year sentence in the fatal shooting of a Danbury liquor store manager. The court said the trial judge in the trial of Tommie L. Martin had tainted the verdict by taking "judicial notice," or pointing out that Mr. Martin's alleged accomplice had been convicted. Mr. Martin was sentenced in February 2001, two months after he was convicted of shooting Robert Gallo, 45, during a robbery. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about vaccines that are being prepared for teenagers misstated the name of an advisory committee to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. It is the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, not Policy.

title: Italian Leader Apologizes for Nazi Remark
description: BERLIN, July 3  After a barrage of criticism, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy apologized today for his statement in the European Parliament likening a German Socialist member to a Nazi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILDER, , JOSEPH R., MD.
description: WILDER--Joseph R., MD. On July 1, 2003. He is survived by his wife Madeline. Also survived by his former wife Ruth and their children Kathy W. Karlin, Tony and Piper; his former wife Cynthia and their children Alyssa and Nicholas; his grandchildren Margo and Natalie Karlin. Dr. Wilder was a Hall of Fame LaCrosse player at Dartmouth College, graduate of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, Director of Surgery at the Hospital of Joint Diseases, Professor of Surgery at Mt. Sinai Hospital, NYC. Dr. Wilder was a writer of numerous books and renowned painter. To his many children and grandchildren he was a devoted, caring and loving father and grandfather. He will be deeply missed. He embraced both the joy and pain of life to its fullest and has surely left his mark on all he touched. Services Thursday 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. >>AD#

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Adaptec Says Quarterly Sales Missed Forecast
description: Adaptec, which makes circuit cards that speed up the connections between computers, said yesterday that first-quarter sales missed its forecast as business failed to improve in June as expected. Sales in the quarter ended June 30 were about $107 million, according to preliminary results, less than the $115 million to $120 million the company had forecast, Adaptec said. The company also ''expects first-quarter bottom-line results in the middle of the range projected'' on April 28, which was 2 cents to 4 cents a share. Shares rose 35 cents, to $8.44.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, , HERMAINE KURTZ
description: COHEN -- Hermaine Kurtz, age 82, of Edina, formerly of New York City, died June 28, 2003. Preceded in death by parents, Irwin and Josephine (Herzbrun) Kurtz; husband, New York State Supreme Court Justice, Charles H. Cohen; sisters, Babette Kurtz and Eve Kurtz Rackow. Survived by sons, Jonathan (Barbara) of Prior Lake, MN and Harlan (Patricia Salas) of Washington, DC; grand daughters Ilana, Aliza and Julia. ''Hummy'' was a loving and generous wife, mother and grandmother, a world traveler, a gourmet cook, an expert needlewoman and a loyal friend to many. She will be greatly missed. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALTER, , DAVID
description: WALTER--David. The Juilliard community mourns the death of David Walter, a brilliant double bassist and teacher who had an extraordinary impact on the music profession of the 20th Century. His charm, wit, and integrity will be deeply missed. Our condolences to his entire family. Joseph W. Polisi, President >>AD#

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Summer Reading List

title: Picking Workers' Pockets
description: When I started in the newspaper business I made so little money I had to work part time in my father's upholstery shop to make ends meet. So I'd spend the days chasing stories and struggling with deadlines, and the nights wrestling with beat-up sofas and chairs.

title: Editor of Newsday Will Retire Aug. 15
description: The longtime editor of Newsday, Anthony Marro, will retire on Aug. 15 and Howard Schneider, one of its three managing editors, will succeed him, the newspaper announced yesterday.

title: Rooftop Sniper Wounds Officer in Brooklyn
description: A rooftop sniper wounded a police officer on Tuesday night outside a public housing complex in Brooklyn, the police said, and a task force of 30 investigators fanned out yesterday through the complex to search for information about the attacker.

title: Beach Budget Bingo: Surf's Up, Wallpaper's Down
description: THE most inspiring houses often start out less than ideal. Van Wifvat's was no exception. When he first saw it, the clapboard exterior of the two-story Victorian cottage in this historic Jersey Shore town was hidden beneath asphalt tiles masquerading as bricks. Lurid red and orange vinyl squares covered some interior walls in a desperate attempt to vanquish crumbling plaster. Other rooms had several layers of paint over wallpaper, a combination so unstable that some walls looked, Mr. Wifvat said, like ''sagging paper bags.'' A previous owner had painted the entrance hall navy blue with emerald green trim, and every French door and double-hung window was nailed and painted shut as a form of low-cost winter-proofing. The house was a mess, but it was cheap: $50,000. And Mr. Wifvat's vision of what it could be outweighed the drawbacks, an important lesson in an instant gratification world where the chance to create an idiosyncratic home is often passed up in favor of turnkey perfection.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Increase In Auto Output
description: The General Motors Corporation said it planned to expand production at a venture in Shanghai to meet increasing demand for vehicles in China. Shanghai GM, the company's venture with the Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation, China's biggest carmaker, has capacity to make 100,000 vehicles a year and is ''currently running at full capacity in two shifts,'' General Motors said. The expansion is subject to government approval.

title: At Glastonbury Fest, A Saner Free-for-All
description: Come summer, most bands that are popular in Europe don't bother scheduling tours. Instead they simply decide what European festivals they want to attend. A New York band like Interpol, which normally plays for one or two thousand people a night, for example, has suddenly found itself playing for tens of thousands a day as it makes a comparatively small circuit of 10 European festivals in two weeks.

title: Focus Is on the Big Four, and Wie
description: Despite an influx of young talent in professional women's golf, four players have dominated recent major championships.

title: Sports of The Times; Tranghese Has Big East At a Crossroads
description: Mike Tranghese, the Big East Conference commissioner, spent yesterday the way he'll spend the next 12 months: frantically lobbying, bargaining, attempting to devise a strategy to save the conference he has been involved with for the last 23 years.

title: Oil Executive Is Arrested, and Russians Look for Putin's Role
description: MOSCOW, July 3  In a political wrangle not seen in Russia since the early days of Vladimir V. Putin's presidency, Russian authorities have arrested a top executive at the financial group that controls Yukos Oil Company, Russia's largest oil company.

title: A Violin That Sings In an Informal Setting
description: The first season of Free for All, the series of free recitals at Town Hall, ended Sunday afternoon with a charmingly old-fashioned recital by the violinist Joshua Bell. Instead of the strait-laced recital style that is the current standard -- full-length sonatas and maybe a new work on the main program, with light pieces as encores -- Mr. Bell revived the less formal style favored by violinists (and their audiences) in the 1920's and 30's and even earlier. The encores, or most of them, were moved into the second part of the concert proper and were announced from the stage rather than being listed in the program.

title: UBS Analyst Forced Out for Remark
description: A top health care analyst for UBS resigned under pressure yesterday after bank officials discovered an e-mail message in which he disparaged HealthSouth just months after he had given the stock the highest possible rating.

title: No-Hitter Never Ends for Righetti
description: Twenty years later, Dave Righetti still hears the stories, other people's stories about his most famous day with the Yankees, his no-hitter against the Boston Red Sox at Yankee Stadium on July 4, 1983. Whether he is playing golf, buying milk or opening mail, Righetti is reminded of what it was like to be 24 years old and dominant.

title: Out of Turkey, Lanterns And Pots of an Antique Cast
description: Osman Cakir is Turkish, and his wife, Eugenie Lancereau, is French. Together, they operate Turks and Frogs, top, a New York shop that sells 18th- and 19th-century Turkish olive oil pots and reproductions of antique Ottoman copper and canvas lanterns. A former fashion executive in Istanbul, Mr. Cakir has a collection of 2,000 pots and lanterns. Ceramic pots range in size from 8 to 10 inches (above, $40 to $65) to 4 to 5 feet high ($500 to $2,500). Lanterns are 12 to 25 inches and sell for $45 to $450. The shop is at 323 West 11th Street; (212) 691-8875.

title: As Foes of Security Laws Vow New Protest, Hong Kong's Leaders Ponder Next Move
description: Opponents of the Hong Kong government's proposed internal security laws vowed today to surround the Legislative Council with protesters when it takes up the bill next week, as signs emerged of a possible split among pro-government political parties over how to proceed.

title: Metro Matters; What's Next? Lady Liberty, The Real Dirt?
description: TWO hundred and twenty-seven years ago tomorrow, the American colonists declared their independence, demanding the inalienable right to ''life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.'' Time to let a few more Americans in on the deal?

title: A Battle Against Pesky Geese Turns Lethal in North Jersey
description: His ponds overrun by goose feathers, his parks virtually abandoned because of goose droppings, George W. Devanney was a suburban politician with a problem.

title: Fiat Will Sell Aerospace Division for $1.7 Billion
description: The Italian conglomerate Fiat took another step today in its efforts to turn itself around and return to profitability when it agreed to sell its aerospace components business, FiatAvio, for about 1.5 billion euros, or $1.73 billion.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has confirmed the death of the following American in Iraq:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AVRECH, , AMIEL
description: AVRECH--Amiel. Yeshivat Sha'alvim extends deep sympathy and heartfelt condolences to our distinguished Executive Chairman, Rabbi Philip H. Singer and Cyril and their son Robert and wife Karen on the untimely passing of their dear grandson and son, whose young life was devoted to Torah while fighting illness valiantly. >>AD#

title: BOOTS & COOTS AGREES TO RESTRUCTURE LOANS
description: Boots & Coots International Well Control, a Houston company that fights oil-well fires, agreed to restructure loans from Prudential Insurance Company in a bid to avoid bankruptcy. Boots & Coots will issue $2.4 million in subordinated notes to Prudential, which agreed to waive the opportunity to call in loans, Boots said. Boots & Coots has lost money in five of the past six years, leaving it in violation of loan agreements.

title: Moving Up to a Grill With Extra Sizzle
description: THE latest domestic crisis began with the collapse of the flavorizer bars.

title: Britain Plans Law to Ban Age Bias in Workplace
description: Britain unveiled new proposals today to outlaw discrimination in the workplace on the basis of age by 2006.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STOVALL, , INGER BAGGER
description: STOVALL--Inger Bagger. On July 1, 2003, at 10:30 PM, in Memorial Sloan - Kettering Hospital, Inger Bagger Stovall died peacefully surrounded by family members. She had been suffering from lung cancer, first diagnosed on April 8, 2003, according to her adoring husband of some 52 years, Robert H. Stovall Sr. Born in Copenhagen, Denmark, in 1928, daughter of Dr. Sofus V. Bagger and Anna Nicoline Bagger, she graduated from the Royal Danish Technical School there as a print designer. Her work in silkscreening was exhibited throughout Scandinavia. She met her husband at the University of Copenhagen Graduate Study Program in 1948. She came to the U.S. in 1951, where they married. She became a U.S. citizen in 1996. Inger Stovall lived for 25 years in Mountain Lakes, NJ, with a seasonal home in Barnegat Light, NJ, for 19 years. Most recently she had resided in Sarasota, FL., with homes in Manhattan and Honesdale, PA, as well. Active in social work, she operated a Cheer Ring helpline service at Marble Collegiate Church for 20 years. Inger also helped establish student scholarship and ethics programs at NYU's Stern Business School, Seton Hall Prep, Penn, and four secondary schools in NJ, PA and FL. She is also survived by her four children, Sten T. Stovall of London, England, Sam Stovall of Jersey City, NJ, I. Benedikte Stovall of Bryn Mawr, PA, Robert H. Stovall Jr. of Fanwood, NJ, plus six beloved grandchildren. In addition, she raised Enrique Del Riego and Eduardo Del Riego now of Miami, FL., who joined her family via the ''Pedro Pan'' program from Cuba in 1962. A beautiful woman spiritually and in all other ways, Inger Stovall will be sorely missed by many people in many places. Interment will be private in Honesdale, PA, on July 5, with a memorial service planned for April 2004 in Sarasota. Memorial donations may be made to the Sarasota Hopewell Potters Field Fund. >>AD#

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Questions About SK
description: The Financial Supervisory Service said that it was investigating the statements made by some creditors of SK Global, the scandal-ridden trading firm, after discovering what it called irregularities. The investigation raised new doubts about the viability of the company, whose debts are $3.65 billion larger than its assets. The Financial Supervisory Service said some of SK Global's creditors had failed to confirm all of the figures that they had given to auditors. The creditors, led by Hana Bank, have agreed to settle more than $2 billion of SK Global's debt at 38 percent of its value. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Insurance Group Is Threatening Opposition to U.S. Asbestos Fund
description: An insurance industry trade group threatened yesterday to oppose legislation aimed at ending lawsuits over asbestos exposure unless lawmakers curb the cost of a proposed industry-financed compensation fund.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SELVERNE, , BETH B.
description: SELVERNE--Beth B. All who knew you learned of loyalty, goodness and love. Your Famil

title: Buckle A Swash, Me Video Hearties
description: BRAD PITT -- his sexy voice, at least -- has arrived in theaters as Sinbad the egotistical animated pirate in ''Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas,'' battling powerful gods and goddesses. Johnny Depp -- all of him -- arrives on Wednesday as Jack Sparrow, the swarthy buccaneer in ''Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl,'' up against a shipful of the undead. Casting Hollywood's handsomest leading men as daring pirate heroes is far from a new idea. At the video store, matinee idols from Errol Flynn to Kermit the Frog are at our fingertips in the original action spectaculars. Who says there aren't enough movies set in the Caribbean? ANITA GATES

title: Russian Oil Man Arrested; Allies Blame Politics
description: In a political wrangle of a kind not seen in Russia since the early days of Vladimir V. Putin's presidency, the authorities have arrested a top executive at the financial group that owns Russia's largest oil company.

title: Six Detainees Soon May Face Military Trials
description: President Bush today designated six captives suspected of involvement in terrorism as eligible to be tried before military tribunals, setting in motion the process that officials say will soon lead to the first use of such tribunals by the United States in more than 50 years.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Bush Insists Liberian President Go Before Troops Come In
description: President Bush, enmeshed in an internal struggle in his administration over whether and how to send American peacekeeping troops to Liberia, strongly implied today that no soldiers would be deployed until the Liberian president, Charles Taylor, steps down.

title: SOFTWARE GIANT MISSES PROFIT AND SALES FORECASTS
description: Siebel Systems Inc., a maker of customer-service software, said second-quarter profit and sales fell more than forecast. Sales in the quarter, which ended June 30, were $330 million to $334 million, and profit was about 2 cents a share, the company said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial expected profit of 3 cents. Siebel had expected sales as high as $360 million and profit of as much as 4 cents. Analysts have said that Siebel, based in San Mateo, Calif., has been losing market share to SAP, a German rival.

title: Welches Reach Divorce Settlement
description: Four days before a trial was scheduled to begin in their divorce case, John F. Welch Jr., the former chairman of General Electric, and his wife, Jane Beasley Welch, announced yesterday that they had reached a settlement.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Airline Cuts Salaries
description: Singapore Airlines Ltd., which had operating losses of more than $3 million a day in April and May, said it had reached an agreement with unions to cut the salaries of its administrative and general staff by as much as 11 percent. The airline said the 11 percent cut would apply to its administrative workers. Cabin crew and other general staff earning more than $1,500 Singapore dollars a month will take a 7.5 percent cut, and those making less money will take a 5 percent cut, the company said.

title: Plastic Is Back: Relearning Recycling's Dance
description: New York City may be recycling plastic again, but the ever-changing rules of disposal have left many residents befuddled.

title: On Auction: A Home To Chancellors Past
description: A seven-bedroom town house in Brooklyn Heights that is owned by the city and was once the official home of New York City's schools chancellors will be sold at auction on July 23.

title: Sports of The Times; Boston's Real Curse Is That of Sparky Lyle
description: ENOUGH already about the Curse of the Bambino. It is superstitious. It is silly. And it should also be clear by now to New England that the Red Sox did not turn eternally luckless until they traded Albert (Sparky) Lyle.

title: El Diario Is Sold to Los Angeles Equity Firm
description: El Diario/La Prensa, the 90-year-old Spanish-language newspaper in New York City, was bought by a private investment group for $19.9 million, the paper's publisher and chief executive announced yesterday.

title: French Exchange Students Get the Cold Shoulder
description: First it was French wines. Then French fries. Now it's French exchange students who are getting the cold shoulder from American families still smarting over France's opposition to the war in Iraq.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

description: HERSCHAFT--Jean. Concern for Helping Animals in Israel (CHAI) deeply mourns the passing of Jean Herschaft, longtime journalist for the Jewish Post and Opinion, dedicated activist for animals, locally and globally, and valued friend of CHAI. We extend condolences to her family. She will be greatly missed. Memorial donations can be sent to CHAI, PO Box 3341, Alexandria, VA 22302, www.chai-online.org. >>AD#

title: Man Found Burned Was Shot, Police Say
description: A man whose partly burned body was found on a kitchen floor in a home in Brooklyn on Wednesday night died from multiple gunshot wounds and was dead before his body was set on fire, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the possibility of American involvement in an international peacekeeping force in Liberia misstated the nature of the special court in neighboring Sierra Leone that is investigating war crimes there and has charged the leader of Liberia, Charles Taylor, with crimes against humanity. The court was created through an agreement between the government of Sierra Leone and the United Nations. But it is independent of both institutions, and staffed by both foreigners and citizens of Sierra Leone.

title: U.S. 'Still at War,' General Declares; G.I. Dies; 20 Hurt
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Friday, July 4  Two months after President Bush declared the end of major combat, the commander of allied forces in Iraq acknowledged on Thursday that "we're still at war," and the United States announced a reward of up to $25 million for the capture of Saddam Hussein or confirmation of his death.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LISKIN, , ELLIOT
description: LISKIN--Elliot. July 4th. Our anniversary day...''And the memories linger on.'' Joyce >>AD#

description: Harvard's Best Goes to London

title: Two Generations, Agreeing on a Single Ambience
description: Although one is a singer and the other a jazz pianist, the mother-and-son duo of Sandy Stewart and Bill Charlap share an artful simplicity that suggests that good taste, like other family traits, is a quality passed down through the generations. Ms. Stewart (whose late first husband, the Broadway composer Moose Charlap, was Bill's father) and her son make sophisticated, user-friendly music that is devoid of affectation. And in the show they have brought to the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel through Wednesday, their playful bond recalls the kind of spirited aesthetic conversations shared by the guitarists John Pizzarelli and his father, Bucky, in their duets at Feinstein's at the Regency.

title: Justice Dept. Takes Up a Little Church's Zoning Fight
description: On the lower slope of the Haleakala volcano here on the island of Maui, in red-dirt agricultural land famed for its sweet onions, worshipers hold church services in a low-slung concrete-block, metal-roofed building meant for storing farm equipment.

title: Fourth of July: What We Pursue
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraq Museum Reopens With Assyrian Treasures
description: Invited guests flocked to the Iraq Museum today to see the treasures of Nimrud, a collection of vessels, gold jewelry and a gold crown from the Assyrian Empire.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES WINS APPEAL IN FEDERAL LAWSUIT
description: A federal appeals court upheld a trial court's decision throwing out claims by the government that American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation, had illegally added flights to drive discount carriers from the Dallas-Fort Worth market. The United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit in Denver upheld a judge's decision that dismissed a suit first brought during the Clinton administration. The court announced its decision on its Web site but did not issue a written opinion. The Justice Department had accused American of engaging in predatory behavior against Vanguard Airlines, Western Pacific Airlines and Sun Jet, saying American's goal was to dominate routes linking Wichita, Kansas City, Phoenix and Cincinnati with Dallas-Fort Worth.

title: Psst! Naked Girls Arranged by a Gen-yoo-wine Ar-teest! Just 25 Cents!
description: In 1939 a gleaming city of the future rose on wasteland in the heart of Queens, lifting the spirits of a nation beaten down by a decade of economic deprivation. War loomed, but for the moment the New York World's Fair inspired millions with its vision of utopian promise, symbolized most pointedly by the Trylon and Perisphere at its center: one a soaring emblem of rationalist aspiration, the other a white globe of unity and wholeness.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Jury Acquits Teaneck Principal Of Sexually Assaulting Teenager
description: A high school principal accused of sexually assaulting a 17-year-old boy he had planned to adopt was found not guilty this afternoon by a jury that deliberated for less than five hours.

title: Judge Voids Cleanup Plan For Wastes At Bomb Plants
description: The Energy Department's plan for cutting billions of dollars and several years off the bomb-waste cleanup at three government nuclear reservations is illegal, a federal judge has ruled, because it would leave some of the wastes in shallow burial despite Congress's prescription that they can be safely disposed of only in a deep ''geologic'' repository.
