description: Comcast Sells QVC Stake

title: 36 Hours | Mystic, Conn.
description: IT'S not easy being a small seafaring town. Many up and down the Eastern Seaboard have been forced to abandon their heritage as fishing and other traditional maritime jobs have dried up. But Mystic, a picturesque town midway along the northern shore of Long Island Sound, refused to give up on its past. Instead, it reinvented itself as a living museum, preserving a sense of its maritime past and becoming a runaway tourist success. Near the Rhode Island line and within easy driving distance of both New York and Boston, and with a good selection of hotels, restaurants and things to do, Mystic offers landlubbers a chance to discover their nautical side. MATTHEW YEOMANS

title: Migraine Drug Maker Is Acquired In Britain
description: British Biotech said today that it would acquire the Vernalis Group, the maker of a marketed migraine drug, in a 48 million deal ($80 million) in an effort to become profitable.

title: Sleepless Nights Evoke Visions and Childhood Memories
description: Never one to let time waste her, the busy 92-year-old sculptor Louise Bourgeois decided a few years ago to put even her bouts of insomnia to productive use. From November 1994 to June 1995 she made the most of draggy hours in a state where sleep holds off by setting down thoughts, visions and memories that rose from the floor of her consciousness.

title: After Tour, Senators Warn U.S. Is Spread Thin in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, July 3  A bipartisan group of nine senators returned today from a three-day trip to Iraq, warning that American forces there are stretched thin and will face continuing attacks from disparate but increasingly organized Iraqi guerrillas.

title: Capturing Beauty In the Beast

title: FAMILY FARE

title: The Fine Art Of Slumming It
description: Two sweethearts of the American musical are looking anything but sweet at the moment, and oh, what a relief it is. The ever-lovely Melissa Errico (late of ''Amour'') and the ever-plucky Karen Ziemba (a Tony winner for ''Contact'') can be found standing back to back, murder in their eyes, singing a disharmonious little tune by Kurt Weill called ''Jealousy Duet'' at the Williamstown Theater Festival.

title: At Whistler, Skis and Snowboards Are in Season . . .
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia

title: Keeping Alive A Maritime Past
description: CENTURIES may be compressed into a themed shopping center and a recreated 1800's seaport village, but Mystic, Conn., on the northern shore of Long Island Sound, offers more than the maritime past it promotes so adeptly. There is a state-of-the-art aquarium with beluga whales, sharks and snapping turtles, along with a highly walkable downtown area. And did we mention the pizzeria that made Julia Roberts famous? Page 3.

title: Conservation Area to Expand In a $22 Million Hawaii Deal
description: A $22 million land sale was closed today that will will add more than 100,000 acres to Hawaii Volcanoes National Park and put under its care dozens of rare and endangered species. The buyers call it the largest land conservation deal in Hawaii history.

title: Suit Seeks Statewide Change In Formula for School Aid
description: The decision by the Court of Appeals last week ordering a change in how New York City schools are financed clears the way for a similar lawsuit in a lower court that could unleash a reorganization of the entire formula for state school financing.

title: New Affirmative Action
description: To the Editor:

title: 'In Honor of the Day'
description: On their first Fourth out, in what is now northeastern Kansas, Lewis and Clark honored the day by firing their swivel gun at morning and evening and by giving the men an extra gill -- a half-cup -- of whiskey. It was not a particularly busy day. The explorers came upon a lake full of nearly grown goslings, which they called Gosling Lake. They made some 15 miles by sail on the Missouri River. Capt. Meriwether Lewis poulticed Joseph Fields, who suffered a snakebite, and they named two creeks, one after the Fourth of July and the other, that evening, after Independence. ''We dined on corn,'' Capt. William Clark noted, with the terseness of someone who was hoping for meat.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: When Larry Forgione began writing the menu for his cafe in Lord & Taylor on Fifth Avenue, he knew he wanted panini. He also knew he wanted lots of ice cream. The two ideas come together in his reconfigured ice cream sandwiches, which are, unmistakably and brilliantly, real sandwiches, thick slices of toasted bread pressing against a generous slice of ice cream filling. The combination of cold ice cream and warm, chewy bread, with a gentle exterior crunch, more or less tosses the old Good Humor ice cream sandwich onto the dust heap of history.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I want my husband home. I am so on edge. When they first left, I thought yeah, this will be bad, but war is what they trained for. But they are not fighting a war. They are not doing what they trained for. They have become police, in a place they're not welcome.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 25 about the persistence of wars in Congo and Liberia, and an editorial on June 28 about the Bush administration's heightened level of interest in Africa, misstated part of President Bush's itinerary for his first trip to Africa, which begins on Monday. Besides South Africa, Botswana, Uganda and Senegal, he is to visit Nigeria, not Niger.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Killing In Apparent Love Triangle
description: A 60-year-old man, apparently in a jealous rage, shot and killed a rival for the affections of his Chinatown neighbor, the police said yesterday. The man, Charlie Lee, was charged with second-degree murder for shooting his rival, a 48-year-old man, several times with a .22-caliber pistol on Wednesday night, the police said. They did not release the name of the victim or the woman. The victim was shot in the apartment of the woman, who lived across the hall from Mr. Lee on the 40th floor of 20 Confucius Plaza, a high-rise apartment tower near 1 Police Plaza in Chinatown, the authorities said. Mr. Lee became enraged when he found his rival in the woman's apartment, the police said. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Passengers Lose Blood Clot Case
description: The Court of Appeal turned down claims by a group of airline passengers alleging damage to their health caused by deep vein thrombosis after long flights. The three-judge panel dismissed an appeal brought by 24 people against a High Court decision that the condition sometimes referred to as ''economy class syndrome'' was not an accident under the terms of the 1929 Warsaw Convention governing air travel. Deep vein thrombosis is a blood clot, usually in the leg, which develops when movement is restricted and can be fatal if it reaches the lungs or brain. Airlines argue that there is no link between the ailment and flying. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Russia: Oil Shipments Start
description: The Sakhalin Energy Investment Company, the consortium led by Royal Dutch/Shell that is producing oil in the waters off Russia's eastern coast, said that it had shipped its first cargo of crude oil to the west coast of the United States. The 700,000 barrels of oil is headed to ports in Washington and Alaska, the company said. Sakhalin Energy was the first consortium to begin producing oil in Russia's far east several years ago. It normally ships to buyers in Russia and Asia. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Opera and Concert Recordings Reveal Prokofiev's Variety
description: Here are some favorite Prokofiev recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Availability is hard to determine in the current state of the market. Most of the recordings here can be found on Amazon.com or in major record stores. CD's range in price from $17 for one CD to $34 for a two-CD set and $51 for three CD's. (An introduction appears on Page 1 of Weekend.)

title: Regulators May Be Clamping Down on Merger Accounting
description: TWO years ago, corporate America breathed a sigh of relief as a new merger accounting rule took effect. No longer would ''good will'' amortization lower corporate profits.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: ARIZONA: CHARGES IN FIGHT OVER WATER A rancher is facing a criminal charge for shooting at a helicopter that was scooping up water last month to pour on a nearby wildfire. The rancher, Clarence Conway, 59, was arrested on June 30. Mr. Conway told the authorities that the Forest Service did not reimburse him for water it took from his holding tank to fight a wildfire last year. He was indicted by a federal grand jury this week on a single count of interfering with the performance of federal officials or a contractor. The charges carries a maximum prison term of one year.

title: Prokofiev's Ingenuity Endures
description: IN the music world as elsewhere, every year presents several significant anniversaries, and it is illuminating to see who gets the biggest play and why. This year offered two prime possibilities: Hector Berlioz, who was born in 1803, and Sergei Prokofiev, who died in 1953 (on March 5, the same day as Stalin, his antagonist).

title: Red Sox Will Face a Yankee Ace Every Day
description: The Yankees will play host to the Boston Red Sox this weekend with their usual complement of aces. David Wells will start today, followed by Roger Clemens, Andy Pettitte and Mike Mussina. It is easily the most accomplished and battle-tested foursome in baseball, with 825 victories and 69 postseason starts combined.

title: Shares Slip After Disappointing Report on Unemployment
description: Stocks fell modestly yesterday after the government reported that the unemployment rate jumped in June and payroll jobs declined. But the three major gauges still finished the week higher, after closing out a very strong second quarter on Monday.

title: More Taxes, A Few Cuts, But Little Pain In New Budgets
description: Six months ago, political leaders around the New York City region were sounding alarms. They warned that state and local governments were facing the worst fiscal crisis since the 1930's and predicted dire budget cuts that in the eyes of many legislators would cripple services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALABY, , NAJEEB E.
description: HALABY--Najeeb E. The Board of Trustees of the American University of Beirut and members of the AUB community note with great sadness the passing of our friend Najeeb E. Halaby, Trustee Emeritus and former Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the University. We are deeply grateful to ''Jeeb'' for his inspired leadership of AUB during the gravest years of war in Lebanon. His abiding commitment to the humanitarian mission of the institution, and to its role as an international bridge of understanding between East and West, was instrumental in assuring its continuing place as a leading center of learning in service to the people of the Middle East. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Libby Cater Halaby and children, Queen Noor Al - Hussein, Christian Halaby and Alexa Halaby. Richard A. Debs, Chairman of the Board of Trustees American University of Beirut >>AD#

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: U.S. MIGHT HAVE BEEN MAD COW ORIGIN Canadian investigators say the one cow found in Canada to have mad cow disease so far may have come from the United States in a 1998 shipment of 25,000 pregnant cows across the border. The cows were born before a ban was imposed on cattle feed containing animal protein from cattle and other ruminants. Eating infected tissue is considered the most likely way that mad cow disease is spread among cattle. American officials discounted the report as conjecture. The United States, Japan and many other countries have banned the import of Canadian beef since May, crippling the Canadian cattle industry. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REYNOLDS, , WILLIAM GRAY JR.
description: REYNOLDS--William Gray Jr. 64, died July 2, 2003 at the home of his brother, Randolph N. Reynolds, after a courageous, extended battle with a brain tumor. Mr. Reynolds was Vice President, Government Relations and Public Affairs, of Reynolds Metals Company at the time of the company's merger with the Aluminum Company of America (Alcoa) in May 2000. Mr. Reynolds was a native of Kentucky and the grandson of the founder of Reynolds Metals, Richard S. Reynolds Sr. He was the son of William Gray Reynolds and Mary Nicklas Reynolds. He is survived by his brother, Randolph N. Reynolds and sister-in-law, Susan V.R. Reynolds; two sisters, Louise R. Belmont of Richmond and Mary Parham Simpson of Athens, Georgia; nieces, Dr. Mary Katherine Ross of Virginia Beach and Elizabeth Parham Simpson of Athens, Georgia; nephews, Randolph N. Reynolds Jr., Ralph S. Reynolds and Robert G. Reynolds, all of Richmond, Cornelius F. Florman, William R. Florman of Kentucky, Kelly G. Florman of Richmond and Kevin M. Brown of Athens, Georgia. Mr. Reynolds graduated from the St. George's School in Newport, R.I., where he was an outstanding athlete receiving All State Honors in three sports, and he was recently elected to the school's Sports Hall of Fame. After St. George's, he graduated from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School. At the University of Pennsylvania, Mr. Reynolds was the President of the student body and captain of the tennis and squash teams. After the University of Pennsylvania, he received his LL.D. from the University of Virginia Law School in 1965, where he also served as President of the student body. After law school, Mr. Reynolds joined the staff of Kentucky Governor Edward ''Ned'' Breathitt. From 1966 to 1968, he was Assistant U.S. Attorney in the United States Attorney's Office in Washington, D.C. In 1968, he joined the Law Department of Reynolds Metals Company and was named the Executive Assistant to the President and Chairman of the Board of Reynolds Metals Company in 1973. In 1975, he was elected Treasurer of the company, and he became Vice President of Government Relations and Public Affairs in 1980. Mr. Reynolds was a member of the bar in Virginia, Kentucky and the District of Columbia, and has been admitted to practice before the U.S. Supreme Court. He was also Vice President and Treasurer of both the Richard S. Reynolds and Missionary Emergency Foundations. In addition, Mr. Reynolds was a member of St. Paul's Episcopal Church and served on the board of directors of Central Fidelity Bank Inc., Richmond Renaissance and Keep America Beautiful, and also served as a member of Board of Trustees of the Medical College of Virginia Foundation. Mr. Reynolds was a member of the Board of Directors of the Greater Richmond Chapter of the American Red Cross, and served as the Chairman and Visionary of the American Red Cross Golf Classic. Funeral Services for Mr. Reynolds will be held at St. Paul's Episcopal Church on Monday July 7 at 2 p.m. Visitation will take place at Bliley's on Augusta Avenue on Sunday, July 6th from 4 p.m. until 8 p.m. Interment Hollywood Cemetery. Memorial contributions may be made to: Foundation for Cancer Research and Education, 1140 Buck Mountain Road, Earlysville, VA. 22936 or VCU Department of Neurosurgery, P. O. Box 631, MCV Station, Richmond, VA. 23298. >>AD#

title: A Smoke-Free England? A Medical Expert Says It's Essential
description: Smoking should be banned in all public places to reduce the threat of illness caused by secondhand inhalation, England's chief medical officer, Sir Liam Donaldson, said today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Schrder Denies Misleading Voters
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder told a special investigation committee of the Parliament that allegations that the government distorted economic data in last fall's elections were groundless. The committee, known as the election lies inquiry, was set up by the opposition to determine whether Mr. Schrder and his finance minister intentionally underestimated Germany's budget deficit by billions of dollars until after the election was won. ''I completely reject the insinuation that the government deceived the public,'' Mr. Schrder said. ''The forecasts we made were based on solid data.'' Hugh Eakin (NYT)

title: New Serial Criminal Spreads Fear With Fires Around Washington
description: They have barely had time to recover from last year's deadly sniper attacks. But now, residents of this city and one of its suburbs are being rattled by a new serial criminal whose weapons are flammable liquids and matches instead of rifles.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Toy Foam Is Recalled
description: More than one million cans of spray foam sold as toys, generally to children, are being recalled because some have exploded in use. The manufacturer, JAKKS Pacific Inc., in Malibu, Calif., announced the voluntary recall along with the Consumer Product Safety Commission. The cans of colored foam were sold for about $10 from February 2002 to last month; the foam, Spit Smatter, comes in a variety of themes: Original Smatter, Blueberry Smatter, Banana Cream Smatter, Lemon Meringue Smatter and Fatter Smatter. Consumers can get refunds from JAKKS Pacific by calling (800) 554-5516 or by e-mail at smatterrecall@jakks.net.

title: U.S. 'STILL AT WAR,' GENERAL DECLARES; G.I.  DIES; 20 HURT
description: Two months after President Bush declared the end of major combat, the commander of allied forces in Iraq acknowledged on Thursday that ''we're still at war,'' and the United States announced a reward of up to $25 million for the capture of Saddam Hussein or confirmation of his death.

title: Subject Is U.S., Object Is Art
description: SCENE: the day room of a nursing home as a television set burbles on. Captain America lies on a gurney, attached to an IV. Superman, long in the tooth, stands braced by a walker, its metal legs confining his flowing cape. A wizened Catwoman slumps in an armchair. And an elderly Mr. Fantastic sits glumly at a table, his played-out elastic limbs draped limply over and under it.

description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation, the largest cable operator in the New York area, said yesterday that federal regulators had opened a formal investigation into improper accounting at the company that led to the firing of 14 employees.

title: Roddick No Longer Just Watching the Semifinals
description: Not long ago, Andy Roddick was an early-morning Wimbledon viewer, not one of those providing the early-morning Wimbledon content.

title: When Collecting Tattoos Takes a Homicidal Turn
description: Robert Schwentke's grisly film ''Tattoo'' gives a sinister new meaning to the expression ''No skin off your back.'' That phrase, facetiously thrown out by a police officer during a murder investigation, accumulates several layers of horror as the body count escalates, and it's revealed that the mutilated, heavily tattooed victims have been skinned for their body art, to be auctioned at astronomical prices to a cult of collectors. The work of one Japanese tattoo artist is especially prized, and a fresh swatch of flesh he has illustrated can command a price in six or even seven figures. All 12 of the recipients of one of his most elaborate designs turn out to be dead or missing.

title: Corrections

title: The Day New York Declared Its Independence
description: Writing to his wife, Abigail, about the newly completed Declaration of Independence, John Adams observed that Independence Day ''ought to be solemnized with pomp and parade, with shows, games, sports, guns, bells, bonfires, and illuminations from one end of this continent to the other from this time forward forever more.''

description: The Department of Defense has confirmed the deaths of the following Americans in Iraq:

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE INCREASES TO 6.4%, HIGHEST IN 9 YEARS
description: Once again failing to live up to politicians' hopes and economists' expectations, the labor market got tougher for job seekers last month. The unemployment rate rose to 6.4 percent, the highest in nine years, and the economy lost 30,000 jobs.

title: What Home Buyers Whisper At a Look-See Open House
description: Finally, there's a home improvement show that I -- and other people who don't own staple guns -- can relate to.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

The company also sold the rights to 44 percent of the oil and gas that Apache extracts from those reserves over the next four years to Morgan Stanley, New York, for $300 million.

description: Three Jewish inmates at Rikers Island have filed a federal lawsuit saying their constitutional rights were violated by prison officials' refusal to provide them a vegan diet, which the inmates say is required by their religious beliefs.

title: A Scientist With a Song, or Two, in His Heart
description: TEN years ago, when David Botstein turned 50, his wife and brother conspired -- his word -- to buy him a cello. It was not a wasted investment. He began lessons at Stanford University, where he was then teaching, and will continue them at Princeton, where he has just arrived, boxes still lying about his new corner office.

title: With Camp Nearing, Roster Is Unsettled
description: The Knicks begin rookie camp on Wednesday, but as they headed into the weekend, they still did not know which players would be there.

title: Preston R. Washington, 54, Minister in Harlem, Is Dead
description: The Rev. Dr. Preston R. Washington, a prominent Harlem minister who led efforts to build housing and cope with the AIDS epidemic, among many other challenges, died on June 25 at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 54 and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y..

title: Liberty Media Buys QVC, Hedging Bets on Vivendi Auction
description: Liberty Media agreed yesterday to buy the Comcast Corporation's majority stake in the QVC home-shopping network for $7.9 billion, potentially complicating Liberty's role as a bidder in the zealously tracked auction for the entertainment assets of Vivendi Universal.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES

title: Mets Hope to Salvage Something From Trade
description: The question for the Mets is not whether ROYCE RING is the proper value for ROBERTO ALOMAR. It's whether Ring turns out to be worth giving up ALEX ESCOBAR and BILLY TRABER. Those were the two high-profile minor leaguers the Mets sent to Cleveland along with three other players in December 2001 to acquire Alomar, who was supposed to be a Hall of Fame second baseman.

description: The New York metropolitan region is celebrating Independence Day weekend with pomp and pyrotechnics. Events range from a fireworks spectacular on the East River (left) to three festive parades on Long Island -- in Patchogue, Southampton and Southold.

title: Big Litigation Firm Found To Have Acted Unethically
description: A federal jury in Chicago ordered a prominent South Carolina law firm yesterday to pay $36 million to a former client for what the jury found was unethical conduct in a class-action lawsuit.

description: The airlines' crucial summer season has arrived, but the industry's vital signs remain feeble. Like a comatose patient, the travel business is still struggling to lift an eyelid, despite endless rounds of medication and prayers.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Bid For Toy Retailer
description: The Baugur Group, Iceland's biggest retailer, raised its offer for the British toy retailer Hamleys to 58.7 million ($98 million), topping a bid from an entrepreneur, Tim Waterstone. Shares in Hamleys gained 8.8 percent. Soldier Ltd., Baugur's takeover company, increased its offer to 254 pence a share, 10 percent more than the 230 pence a share offered by Mr. Waterstone, the founder of Britain's Waterstone's book chain, who aims to combine Hamleys with his Daisy & Tom children's stores.

title: Chicagoans View Porches With New Wariness
description: Three stories above Halsted Street in Lincoln Park, Charles Thompson stepped slowly into the sunlight on his back porch today, making the floorboards sway with each turn of his heel. Reaching down, he raised a loose plank near the edge and shook his head.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: U.S. Might Have Been Mad Cow Origin
description: Canadian investigators say the one cow found in Canada to have mad cow disease so far may have come from the United States in a 1998 shipment of 25,000 pregnant cows across the border. The cows were born before a ban was imposed on cattle feed containing animal protein from cattle and other ruminants. Eating infected tissue is considered the most likely way that mad cow disease is spread among cattle. American officials discounted the report as conjecture. The United States, Japan and many other countries have banned the import of Canadian beef since May, crippling the Canadian cattle industry. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: R.P.G. Alley
description: ARIFJAN, Kuwait  American convoys delivering supplies to the troops in Iraq are being attacked more frequently than during the war. The insurgents have become more proficient in their weapon of choice  the rocket-propelled grenade  and are taking more care in setting up ambushes. An area just south of Baghdad has become so treacherous that G.I.'s have dubbed it "R.P.G. Alley."

title: With Future Uncertain, Mets' G.M. Stays Active
description: Jim Duquette, the Mets' interim general manager, has been barely visible since replacing Steve Phillips on June 12, but he has been busy.

title: Israelis Sense They've Won
description: Israeli officials are expressing growing confidence that after 33 months they have defeated the Palestinian uprising, or intifada.

title: Service Sector Showed Vigor In June Report
description: Activity by service companies grew in June at its best rate in more than two-and-a-half years, bolstered by a strong rise in new orders and an increase in optimism for the future, according to a report released yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: KILLING IN APPARENT LOVE TRIANGLE A 60-year-old man, apparently in a jealous rage, shot and killed a rival for the affections of his Chinatown neighbor, the police said yesterday. The man, Charlie Lee, was charged with second-degree murder for shooting his rival, a 48-year-old man, several times with a .22-caliber pistol on Wednesday night, the police said. They did not release the name of the victim or the woman. The victim was shot in the apartment of the woman, who lived across the hall from Mr. Lee on the 40th floor of 20 Confucius Plaza, a high-rise apartment tower near 1 Police Plaza in Chinatown, the authorities said. Mr. Lee became enraged when he found his rival in the woman's apartment, the police said. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Najeeb E. Halaby, the former airline executive and federal aviation official, misstated the name of the agency he was named to lead in 1961. It was the Federal Aviation Agency; it later adopted the name Federal Aviation Administration.

description: After a barrage of criticism, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi apologized today for likening a German member of the European Parliament to a concentration camp bully.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: WEAK BOND AUCTION The latest monthly auction of 10-year Japanese government bonds received a poor reception, a sign that investors are getting jittery about the recent sell-off that has sent yields more than doubling in the past three weeks. The 1.49 trillion yen ($12.4 billion) in 10-year bonds with a coupon of 0.9 percent received only half the interest from investors that they received last month. The weaker demand forced the government to raise the yield on the new bonds for the first time in 17 months. The yield on the benchmark 10-year bond trading in the secondary market was 1.115 percent, a nine-month high. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR RISES. The dollar gained after an index measuring the service industry rose for a third consecutive month. In New York, the euro settled at $1.1479, down from $1.1546 on Wednesday.

title: Harvard and Columbia Advance at Henley Regatta
description: Harvard and Columbia won their first-round heats in the four without coxswain Visitors' Challenge Cup today as the level of competition intensified on the second of the five days of the Henley Royal Regatta. Harvard's four paddled to victory by two and a quarter boat lengths over Aberdeen University.

title: Spanish Builder Bids for Larger Rival
description: The Spanish construction company ACS has offered 2.1 billion euros ($2.4 billion) worth of stock for its larger rival Grupo Dragados in a merger that will create one of Europe's largest construction and services companies.

title: Tribunals Move From Theory to Reality
description: Yesterday's announcement that President Bush has designated six prisoners as eligible for trials before military commissions is an incremental, but significant, step in turning a theoretical possibility into a practical reality.

title: E-Mail Hucksterism, Offensive but Effective
description: Every medium seems to have its signature hucksters, with advertising messages that are annoying, repetitive, improbable -- yet somehow successful.

title: Subway Cars' Last Stop: Under Sea, Not Ground
description: The hollowed hulks of 50 obsolete New York City subway cars were dumped into the Atlantic Ocean off South Jersey today to begin a watery new life as a haven for fish.

title: A DVD Club for Indie Films
description: This week you can find "Manito" on DVD, but not in stores. That acclaimed, heartbreaking 77-minute film by Eric Eason about the misfortune of a Latino family in Upper Manhattan is available only from Film Movement at its Web site, www.filmmovement.com. Here are some other things you might want to know about the DVD and the movie, which stars Franky G. as an overwhelmed, entirely human older brother trying to deal with the expectations and needs of four generations, from his son to his grandfather (Hector Gonzalez).

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article about the redevelopment of Front Street in Lower Manhattan misstated the location of Schermerhorn Row, a group of early-19th-century buildings. As the related diagram showed, it is on Fulton Street, just west of South Street, not on Front Street.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: OFFICIAL DISMISSED OVER A TAJ MAHAL MALL The government of the state of Uttar Pradesh, home to the Taj Mahal, suspended its environmental secretary, R. K. Sharma, for allegedly approving $7.7 million illegally to build a restaurant and shopping complex around the monument, a government spokesman said. India's minister for tourism and culture, Jagmohan (he uses only one name), had criticized the state government for allowing the project, and the suspension came a day before a meeting called by Mr. Jagmohan to review the case. Construction on the complex  workers sit idle, above  was halted last month. (AP)

title: . . . As Are Kayaks And Bungee Cords
description: MY first impression of summer at the Whistler-Blackcomb ski resort in British Columbia was the quiet. No predawn lift lines, no skiers chomping at the bit to hit fresh powder, no frenzy on the slopes. Just a tranquil stillness in the mountain air. In the middle of Whistler Valley's glacier-fed Alta Lake, my canoe paddle was the only disturbance in the glassy water for what seemed like miles around.

title: Advance U.S. Team to Go to Liberia, as Taylor Offers to Quit
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 - The White House said today that it was encouraged by Charles Taylor's offer to step down as president of Liberia, but that it was sending an advance military team to gauge whether an American peacekeeping force should be sent to that West African country.

title: For Hospitals Seeking Split, Debt Is Glue
description: After a troubled marriage and a long separation, two of New York's premier academic medical centers, New York University and Mount Sinai, are moving toward outright divorce.

title: A Liar's Garden, Weeded and Neat
description: YOUR weekend hostess's manicure is flawless, as are her flower beds. Yes, she insists proudly, she does her own work, the planting and the weeding and the pruning. But she has never been seen pulling a weed. Her shovels and hoes look unused. Does she or doesn't she? Only her (carefully hidden) gardener knows for sure. Page 5.

title: Graduates Hope They, and Liberia, Have a Future
description: It was a glorious Tuesday morning last week, said Winston C. Holt, who was in the soccer stadium in downtown Monrovia amid a sea of grinning would-be college graduates in shimmering black caps and gowns. Their proud parents clutched camcorders and flowers.

title: CARLYLE TO SELL MEDIA UNIT TO LEVERAGED BUYOUT FIRM
description: Willis Stein & Partners, a leveraged buyout firm that invests in consumer-products and media companies, agreed to buy a book, music and video supplier, Baker & Taylor Inc. from the Carlyle Group Inc. for $255 million. Baker & Taylor, based in Charlotte, N.C., distributes its products to retailers, libraries and schools. Willis Stein, based in Chicago, has more than $3 billion in capital under management. Richard Willis will become chief executive of Baker & Taylor when the transaction is completed later this month.

title: North Carolina Man Is Charged in Weapons Sting
description: A 32-year-old North Carolina man sold 11 guns to an undercover police detective in New York over a 13-month period, including two MAC-11 machine pistols, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Tranquillity Vs. Fireworks On the Fourth
description: WHEN in the course of human events, it becomes necessary to produce a Fourth of July column, one finds that a reasonable place to turn to is 101st Avenue in Ozone Park.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays (and most galleries and museums are closed today), but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Motion To Adjourn Legislature
description: Seeking to force a debate on an internal security bill as the government is struggling to respond to a protest against the bill that drew as many as 500,000 people on Tuesday, the Democracy Party submitted for floor debate a motion to adjourn the Legislative Council until autumn. Some pro-government lawmakers called for the government to delete controversial provisions but go ahead with a final vote on the bill next week. In Beijing, the Foreign Ministry warned governments abroad not to comment on the bill. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the possibility of American involvement in an international peacekeeping force in Liberia misstated the nature of the special court in neighboring Sierra Leone that is investigating war crimes there and has charged the leader of Liberia, Charles Taylor, with crimes against humanity. The court was created through an agreement between the government of Sierra Leone and the United Nations. But it is independent of both institutions, and staffed by both foreigners and citizens of Sierra Leone.

title: Stories of the Civil War, Carved on Headstones; Volunteers Unearth Names and History At Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn
description: The weathered, nearly identical marble gravestones of the Prentiss brothers stand side by side not far from the chapel of the Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn. Both evidenced a readiness to die so their causes might live.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 14 about an American strike on an encampment of about 60 young men near the Syrian border misstated the camp location given by an American military official on the day after the strike -- information that turned out to be in error. The official first said the camp was 150 kilometers from Baghdad (the equivalent of 90 miles); actually it was about 150 miles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REESE, , FRANCES STEVENS
description: REESE -- Frances Stevens. The Board and Staff of Scenic Hudson, Inc. mourn the loss of our indomitable Founder, Frances S. Reese. In founding Scenic Hudson 40 years ago to block construction of a power plant atop Storm King Mountain, Franny launched the modern environmental movement. In the decades since, she became a one-person protectress of the Hudson River and its Valley. Determined, full of insight, imaginative and indefatigable, she inspired her colleagues on Board and Staff, led by example and won friendship and admiration in all she did. Devastated by her loss, we will find the strength to honor her memory by continuing her work forever. We offer our condolences to her children, all of whom are valued members of the Scenic Hudson family. Marjorie L. Hart, Chair Ned Sullivan, President

title: No Major Taxes Will Rise, but Many Pockets Are Hit
description: As he promised, Gov. James E. McGreevey did not raise New Jersey's sales tax, income tax or any other broad-based tax in the budget fight that ended this week.

title: A Novelist's Mental Architecture
description: ONE of the exquisite pleasures of writing a novel is creating a home for the characters -- and therefore for yourself, too, as their invisible but bossy guest. A novelist can report daily to a hovel or a palace, just as she chooses. There are no worries about real estate values, no inspections required, and accessibility to transport is not a problem. On the downside, once a novel is set, it is very difficult to move. If your characters pack up and go, they'd better have a good reason.

title: Similar Solar System Found Only 90 Light Years Away
description: A team of British, Australian and American astronomers announced yesterday that they had found a hint of home 90 light years away in the constellation Puppis.

title: Ethnic Museums Abounding
description: New York City makes it possible to see much of the world without ever leaving the city.

title: A Desert's Unexpected Bloom
description: It was 3:30 on a cloudless afternoon and the members of the Tigers New Era Fan Club were already assembled in the far corner of the right-field bleachers. The ragtag group of two dozen or so factory workers, shopkeepers and hangers-on were there to cheer the Hanshin Tigers, working their way through the team's fight songs even though game time was more than two hours away.

description: The jump in the unemployment rate gave Democrats a new opening today to attack President Bush's management of the economy and question the effectiveness of his signature tax cuts.

title: McKay Thrives on a Course That Torments Others
description: After making five consecutive birdies today during a torrid back-nine stretch, Mhairi McKay deserved to be leading the United States Women's Open.

title: BIG FLORIDA CONCRETE MAKER BUYS A NEW UNIT
description: Florida Rock Industries Inc., a leading maker of concrete products in the Southeast, agreed to buy Lafarge Florida Inc., a unit of Lafarge SA, for about $122 million in stock to supplement its operations in Florida. Florida Rock, based in Jacksonville, Fla., will add two processing plants in Tampa and Port Manatee, Fla. The plants produced about 1.2 million tons of cement products last year and had sales of about $89 million in 2002, Florida Rock said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat's Sales Fall
description: Italy's largest manufacturer, Fiat, lost ground to its competitors in the Italian car market last month. Sales of Fiat, Lancia and Alfa Romeo brand cars dropped 4.6 percent, to 48,510 units from 50,833 in June 2002, the Transport Ministry said. Fiat's share of the market fell to 27 percent from 28.2 percent a year earlier. Fiat is introducing new models this year to try and win back customers. They include a new version of the Punto, a new Lancia Ypsilon, above, unveiled last month in Rome, a small car called the Gingo, a minivan and an Alfa Romeo GT Coupe.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Slovakia: Abortion Bill Roils Parliament
description: Efforts to extend abortion rights in line with European norms are threatening the center-right coalition government in the strongly Roman Catholic country after the Parliament passed a bill allowing pregnancies to be terminated up to the 24th week if the fetus might suffer from severe genetic defects. The governing Christian Democratic party said it would try to dismiss the sponsors of the bill from the cabinet if the draft law went into effect. ''The coalition is in crisis,'' the party's chairman, Pavol Hrusovsky, told reporters. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Allstate Is Cleared Of Bias
description: State regulators have cleared Allstate Insurance Co. of charges that it had sought to avoid selling automobile insurance in urban areas, a violation of a law intended to guarantee coverage for all but the highest-risk drivers. Sixteen Allstate agents had accused the company of developing marketing strategies that focused on suburban areas and excluded urban ones. Under the Fair Automobile Insurance Act, carriers must cover drivers with a certain point ranking on their driving record, typically fewer than nine. Holly C. Bakke, the state banking and insurance commissioner, found that the company's practices were meant to ensure ''financial stability.'' In a statement yesterday, she said, ''The requirement to sell auto insurance to all eligible drivers does not prevent a company from developing a statewide business plan.'' Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Big East Contracts May Be Renegotiated
description: ABC and ESPN may try to renegotiate their television contracts with the Big East Conference now that the football powers Miami and Virginia Tech are leaving to join the Atlantic Coast Conference, marketing and TV consultants said.

description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph Wilder, 82; New York Surgeon And Skilled Artist
description: Dr. Joseph R. Wilder, a New York surgeon who also became a well-known artist, died on July 1 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: Sports of The Times; Sisters Distinguish Themselves Again
description: Almost on a daily basis, the Williams sisters continue to amaze. Now they must play each other again on Saturday in the Wimbledon final, a disturbing prospect for the casual fan trying to root for someone, because these two sisters love each other so much.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: PASSENGERS LOSE BLOOD CLOT CASE The Court of Appeal turned down claims by a group of airline passengers alleging damage to their health caused by deep vein thrombosis after long flights. The three-judge panel dismissed an appeal brought by 24 people against a High Court decision that the condition sometimes referred to as "economy class syndrome" was not an accident under the terms of the 1929 Warsaw Convention governing air travel. Deep vein thrombosis is a blood clot, usually in the leg, which develops when movement is restricted and can be fatal if it reaches the lungs or brain. Airlines argue that there is no link between the ailment and flying. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Danish government efforts to crack down on Christiania, Copenhagen's ''Free Town,'' misstated the power of the Conservative Party. It is the majority party in the coalition making up the Danish government; it is not the ruling party.

title: Armstrong Rival Ullrich Lowers Expectations for Tour
description: PARIS, July 4  Jan Ullrich is telling anybody who will listen, and even some who will not, not to expect too much from him in this Tour de France.

title: The (Inflated) Price of Preservation
description: New York's landmarks have always been a source of pride for the city -- now they may become a source of income. The municipal budget that passed last week includes a new charge to be imposed on owners of our city's historic properties -- approximately 1,000 individual landmarks and 21,000 buildings in historic districts -- when they upgrade or repair them. These fees range from $50 to $600 for most residential projects and can reach tens of thousands of dollars for the construction of a new commercial building in a historic district. In all, they are expected to raise about $1 million annually.

title: Celebrating the Unity of Nature and Art, in This Case Dance
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in the Berkshires was for decades an odd but entrancing mix of the giddy and the visionary. In that, the festival took after its founder, Ted Shawn, a modern-dance pioneer whose choreography ranged from kitschy solos for himself to propulsive pure-energy group dances he made for his Men Dancers company. That double nature has changed, though the Pillow has retained the humane spirit with which Shawn welcomed early audiences.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Disbarments Nearly Double
description: A state agency reviewing the conduct of lawyers said a record number of them were disciplined last year for ethics violations and the number of those barred by the court from ever practicing law nearly doubled. The report, by the Office of Attorney Ethics, said that 267 lawyers were sanctioned in 2002, up from 204 the previous year. Disbarments that were ordered by the State Supreme Court totaled 20 in 2002, up 82 percent from 11 in 2001. The report, which was dated May 20 and sent to Chief Justice Deborah T. Poritz of the State Supreme Court, said that the reasons for disbarment included money laundering and swindling clients out of their funds.

title: After Tour, Senators Warn U.S. Is Spread Thin in Iraq

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey

The report, by the Office of Attorney Ethics, said that 267 lawyers were sanctioned in 2002, up from 204 the previous year. Disbarments that were ordered by the State Supreme Court totaled 20 in 2002, up 82 percent from 11 in 2001. The report, which was dated May 20 and sent to Chief Justice Deborah T. Poritz of the State Supreme Court, said that the reasons for disbarment included money laundering and swindling clients out of their funds.

In a brief hearing yesterday, Judge Shira A. Scheindlin of Federal District Court in Manhattan refused a request that she immediately order the city prison to provide vegan diets to the three prisoners, but the judge did agree to hold a full hearing on the matter on Wednesday.

title: Korean Telecom Board Rejects A.I.G. Offer

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: STATE TEACHERS AMONG BEST PAID Connecticut teachers have the third-highest average salary in the nation, according to a new survey by the American Federation of Teachers. Connecticut's average teacher salary for 2001-02 was $52,376, while the national average was $44,367. The top state was California, with an average of $54,348. Michigan had the second-highest average at $52,497. Connecticut had the highest average salary and starting salary among New England states, according to the survey. (AP)

title: A DVD Club For Indie Films
description: This week you can find ''Manito'' on DVD, but not in stores. That acclaimed, heartbreaking 77-minute film by Eric Eason about the misfortune of a Latino family in Upper Manhattan is available only from Film Movement at its Web site, www.filmmovement.com. Here are some other things you might want to know about the DVD and the movie, which stars Franky G. as an overwhelmed, entirely human older brother trying to deal with the expectations and needs of four generations, from his son to his grandfather (Hctor Gonzlez).

title: New Orleans's Hurricane Problem
description: As Louisiana continues to clean up from Tropical Storm Bill, which knocked out power in 200,000 homes and businesses across the state, New Orleans is bracing for the new hurricane season. Because of its unusual geography, the Big Easy is uniquely vulnerable -- if a powerful enough storm hits, experts warn, the city could be badly damaged and tens of thousands of people could be killed. New Orleans, and the nation, need a better plan for protecting the city.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Charges In Fight Over Water
description: A rancher is facing a criminal charge for shooting at a helicopter that was scooping up water last month to pour on a nearby wildfire. The rancher, Clarence Conway, 59, was arrested on June 30. Mr. Conway told the authorities that the Forest Service did not reimburse him for water it took from his holding tank to fight a wildfire last year. He was indicted by a federal grand jury this week on a single count of interfering with the performance of federal officials or a contractor. The charges carries a maximum prison term of one year. title: Pressure Grows on Hong Kong Chief Over Internal Security
description: HONG KONG, July 4  Pressure grew today on Hong Kong's chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, to delete controversial provisions of proposed internal security legislation or shelve it entirely following a massive rally against the bill on Tuesday.

title: BIG AIR FREIGHT CARRIER MIGHT SEEK BANKRUPTCY
description: Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings Inc., which carries freight for other airlines, said it might file for bankruptcy protection to complete a debt restructuring started in March. The company said it had reached agreement on delaying repayment of about half of $50 million owed to holders of bonds backed by some of its aircraft, and that a majority of the debt holders had agreed not to take actions on any defaults for 60 days. Atlas, based in Purchase, N.Y., said in March that it was halting payments on bank debt, senior notes and leases for 44 planes. Yesterday's agreement involves 12 of those planes. The company also said it would resume payments to its main banks.

title: Little Green Lies: Tales Told by Gardeners Who Do No Work

title: Families of British Terror Suspects Alarmed by Tribunals

title: Dozens Killed and Injured in Attack on Mosque in Pakistan

title: Editorial Observer; The Silence of the Past Gives Way, and Dead Writers Speak Once More
description: If we could hear Shakespeare's living voice -- the poet breathing syllables of his own verse into the air -- what would we know that we don't know now? A great deal about the pronunciation of Elizabethan English, certainly, and something about how Shakespeare imagined his words should sound, what stresses they should bear and what sonorities. It might disappoint us to discover that he spoke in a high, reedy trill or that he didn't give his own lines the drama they seem to carry to us. We would find ourselves listening not to the universal Shakespeare, the one timelessly represented in print, but to a particular Shakespeare, the flesh and blood and articulation of just one man. And yet who would pass up the chance to listen?

At the club's kickoff event -- a meal at a hand-picked, third-rate restaurant -- Mr. Pile made the mistake of catching a soup tureen midfall. description: There are days under the big sky of Montana when the human capacity for wonder is no match for the drama of a summer dusk. An eagle snatches trout from a gin-clear river, pronghorns dash over tan-colored hills, and the breeze out of the Rockies carries a sound for easy sleep -- yesterday's snowmelt, today's waterfall.

title: Briggs Cunningham, 96, Racecar Pioneer and Sailing Champ

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Presses Return Of Refugees
description: Chechen refugees living in the nearby region of Ingushetia will have to return to Chechnya by September, the head of the Moscow-appointed Chechen administration, Akhmad Kadyrov, said after a meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin. ''There will be no tents in Ingushetia in September,'' Mr. Kadyrov said, according to the news agency Interfax. Mr. Putin, after the meeting, said the date for presidential elections in Chechnya was set for Oct. 5. The Kremlin is looking for an exit to its war against Islamic separatists in Chechnya, now in its fourth year. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Quietly, Singapore lifts its ban on hiring gays
description: SINGAPORE:  With its export-driven economy winding down, Singapore's government has quietly lifted restrictions on hiring homosexuals as part of a broader effort to shake the city-state's repressive reputation and foster the kind of lifestyles common to cities whose entrepreneurial dynamism Singapore would like to emulate.

title: Internet Helps Make Candidate a Contender
description: Howard Dean's prominence among the nine Democrats running for president is largely attributable to his campaign's early embrace of the Internet for organizing supporters and raising money.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Election Set
description: Rwanda will hold a presidential election on Aug. 25, the first since the 1994 mass killings that left an estimated 800,000 Tutsis and moderate Hutus dead. President Paul Kagame, a Tutsi who heads the Rwandan Patriotic Front, seized power in the central African country in 1994 and he has led a transitional government ever since. Mr. Kagame's main rival will be Faustin Twagiramungu, a moderate Hutu who has served as prime minister. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Drop in Factory Orders Fuels Talk of Recession in Germany
description: German manufacturing orders fell for the third time in four months in May, government figures showed today, indicating that the nation's economy may contract again in the second quarter.

J. Wie.

Piazza emphasized today that he did not have a target date for a return, but he suggested that his comeback was in its latter stages.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: WOMAN RELEASED IN SPY CASE Katrina Leung, accused of taking classified information from her F.B.I. handler to pass on to China, has been freed from jail after posting $2 million bail. The federal government contends that Ms. Leung, 49, a naturalized citizen recruited to work for the F.B.I. 20 years ago, had an affair with her handler, James J. Smith. She had been jailed since her arrest on April 9. A federal judge granted her bail on June 19, but it took two weeks to complete the extensive paperwork needed to secure bond. (AP)

That was one of the pleasures of ''Wild Human Poetry,'' a program of two dances presented by Wil Swanson/Dance Works on Sunday night at the Danspace Project.

title: PENTAGON SEEKING NEW ACCESS PACTS FOR AFRICA BASES

title: Hong Kong's Message of Freedom
description: About a half-million of Hong Kong's seven million people turned out this week to protest a repressive internal security law that Beijing is trying to impose on the territory, a former British colony. The proposed legislation, which is scheduled to go before Hong Kong's Legislative Council next week, would permit the prosecution of political critics on charges similar to those used to crush dissent on the mainland. In the six years since China regained sovereignty over Hong Kong, most of the territory's civil liberties have remained intact. The passage of this bill would end that.

title: Gertrude Samuels, 93, Photojournalist and Writer in Many Genres

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: PUTIN PRESSES RETURN OF REFUGEES Chechen refugees living in the nearby region of Ingushetia will have to return to Chechnya by September, the head of the Moscow-appointed Chechen administration, Akhmad Kadyrov, said after a meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin. "There will be no tents in Ingushetia in September," Mr. Kadyrov said, according to the news agency Interfax. Mr. Putin, after the meeting, said the date for presidential elections in Chechnya was set for Oct. 5. The Kremlin is looking for an exit to its war against Islamic separatists in Chechnya, now in its fourth year. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Word for Word/Coup Control; The C.I.A.'s Cover Has Been Blown? Just Make Up Something About U.F.O.'s
description: THE State Department recently issued a collection of previously classified documents that shed new light on the Central Intelligence Agency's role in the June 1954 coup in Guatemala that ousted the president, Jacobo Arbenz Guzmn. Mr. Arbenz had clashed with the United Fruit Company, which for many years exercised decisive influence in Guatemala, and the Eisenhower administration feared that he was leading his country toward Communism. The coup brought Col. Carlos Castillo Armas to power and set off more than three decades of civil conflict and repression in which hundreds of thousands of Guatemalans were killed.

description: The Whore's Child: And Other Stories, by Richard Russo. (Vintage Contemporaries, $12.95.) In his first collection of short fiction, the author of ''Empire Falls'' bypasses the working-class settings and protagonists of his novels in favor of professors, writers and artists caught up in the drift of late middle age, worried about physical decline and deeply ambivalent about marriage. Last year our reviewer, Rand Richards Cooper, found these stories darker than Russo's friendlier, expansive novels, saying they ''insistently fish for failure beneath the surface of outwardly successful lives.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURCHELL, JONATHAN EDGAR
description: BURCHELL-Jonathan Edgar. 30, of New York City. Beloved son of Allison BurchellRobinson of New York City and Ashford, CT. and Richard C. Burchell of Longboat Key, Florida and Gilford, NH., was fatally injured in the crash of the bush plane he was piloting in the Kenya outback on Sunday, June 29th. He was on the staff of the Laikipia Predator Project, tracking, capturing, and collaring lions for research purposes. A graduate of Fieldston School in New York and the University of Rochester, Jonathan was an accomplished concert promoter, skier, fisherman, musician and pilot. He is survived by his parents, stepmother, Kris Burchell, stepfather Wallace Robinson, fiancee Kiki Harris of New York City and Lexington, NC. Aunts and uncles: George and Lynn Winner of Elmira, NY., Gary and Beverly Sanders of St. Louis, Henry Winner of Boca Raton, FL., Janet Norcross of Marblehead, MA., and nine cousins. A memorial service will be held at Marble Collegiate Church in Manhattan, Tuesday, July 8th, at 4:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to the Laikipia Predator Project, c/o Africa Program, International Programs, Wildlife Conservation Society, Bronx Zoo, 2300 Southern Blvd., Bronx, NY. 10460; or NORML, 1600 K Street NW, Suite 501, Washington, DC. 20006.

title: Road Trips For Sports Fans

''I turned 50 years old that year and I figured, why not go on an adventure?'' Ms. London said.

title: Editor in Chic
description: The Duke of York, William Gladstone, Lord Byron, Aldous Huxley, David Hicks, Terence Stamp -- all lived at Albany, Lord Melbourne's Georgian manse turned into gentlemen's apartments. From Albany's earliest days, the house rules were few and infrangible: no children, no dogs or cats, no noise after 11 and no women. To this day these nods to respectability endure, save for the last. Fleur Cowles (author, painter, ambassador, hostess, philanthropist, raconteur and most famously, editor of Flair magazine) was not the first woman to breach the club (that revolution occurred in 1919), but it's altogether in character that this woman of the world resides at a man's address.

title: Devoted to Mom and Pop

title: Sam Cooke: Cha-Cha-Cha Communicator
description: ERIC ALEXANDER -- It's good to see this tenor saxophonist, part of the bricks-and-mortar of New York's straight ahead jazz mainstream, at work in the clubs. He's absorbed not only the musical syntax of his heroes -- principally Sonny Stitt and John Coltrane -- but the sound: he positions the microphone nearly inside the bell of his horn and gets a deep, rich glow, centering around the low midrange of the horn's notes. His new album is ''Nightlife in Tokyo'' (Milestone), with Harold Mabern on piano, Ron Carter on bass and Joe Farnsworth on drums; it's an extremely able example of post-bop, from ballads (''I'll Be Around'') to fast tunes (''Nemesis'') to minor modes (''Cold Smoke''). But the key is that the band sounds beautiful.

Maynard, himself a former pirate, ordered Blackbeard's famously hairy head slashed off and hung from the ship's bowsprit. The rest of the corpse was thrown overboard and, according to legend, swam around the vessel several times before sinking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARPENTER, GILBERT F. ''BERT''
description: CARPENTER - Gilbert F. ''Bert'', artist and educator, died Friday, June 6, 2003 in Greensboro, NC. Born July 14, 1920 in Billings, Montana, Bert Carpenter was educated at Stanford University, Chouinard Art Institute and Columbia University, where he taught in the Columbia College humanities program in the 1950's. Carpenter was a founding member of the Art Barn School of Art (Utah) and the Honolulu Artist's League. He was Chairman of the Art Dept. of the University of Hawaii (Manoa) before moving to North Carolina to head the art department of UNCG (1964-1974), retiring as emeritus professor of art in 1989. He was director of the university's Weatherspoon Art Gallery from 1974-1989. He exhibited in New York at Zabriskie, A.M. Sachs, and Grunebaum galleries and at the Joy Tash Gallery, Scottsdale, AZ. In 1985 he received a grant from the Mark Rothko Foundation and was the subject of a solo exhibition at Artist's Space. A retrospective exhibition of his work was held in 1999 at the Weatherspoon Art Gallery that traveled to St. John's Museum of Art, the Ewing Gallery of Art and Architecture, and the Edwin A. Ulrich Museum of Art. Carpenter's work is represented in the collections of the Honolulu Academy of Art, the Herter Art Gallery, the Sheldon Memorial Art Gallery and Sculpture Garden, the Edwin A. Ulrich Museum of Art, the Iredell Arts Council, Leon's Inc., and Anderson-Hoagland Co. among others. Bert Carpenter is survived by his two brothers, Harry Carpenter of Peoria, AZ and Ted M. Carpenter of Napa, CA; by his wife, Editha; four children: Editha of Lyon, France; Matthew of Ashboro, NC; Franklin of Greensboro; and Naomi of Greensboro; and four grandchildren: Jonathan Carpenter, Jennifer Carpenter, Jeanne Le Floc'h, and Sydney Bennett.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSBERG, HERBERT R.
description: WEISSBERG-Herbert R. On July 3, 2003. Lived the classic American dream. One of five children born to his immigrant parents in New York's fabled Lower East Side, he slowly but relentlessly worked his way up to being a prominent New York hotelier. Along the way, he taught English to immigrants at night school and helped assemble B-29 engines during WWII. Like many businesspeople who came of age during the Great Depression, he learned his hotel trade handson, making beds, running the switchboard, showing rooms and learning from others over a nickel coffee at the Automat. At one time, he owned major hotels in Chicago, Palm Beach, New Orleans, Washington, D.C., Baltimore as well as Puerto Rico, Venezuela and Costa Rica. Since the late 1950s, his great pride and joy was the Gramercy Park Hotel, which he owned and ran with one brief interruption, for almost forty years. It was truly a family operation - countless hotel employees had worked for him long past normal retirement age and his deep affection for them went well beyond business relationships. He repeatedly refused to sell the property despite handsome offers, explaining ''I have to take care of my people...where else can they find a job?'' This affection was mutual. His commitment to his own family knew no bounds, especially when it came to education. Seeing his children and grandchildren graduate from prestigious schools on their way to their own versions of the American dream gave him immense joy. His wife of fifty years, Ruth Weissberg, was very much his business partner and a loving wife who, like her husband, dotted on her children and grandchildren. He is survived by Ruth, three children, seven grandchildren and one great grandchild. For his family, hundreds of former employees and all those who knew him, his death a few weeks shy of his 91st birthday is truly the passing of an era. Services Monday, July 7th, 12:45PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: 'Jonathan Edwards'
description: God accompanied his blessings with warnings of his judgments. Solomon Stoddard, pastor of the river town of Northampton, Massachusetts, knew that well and preached it often. Although he was the most renowned man in the promising valley of the Connecticut River, he knew that no mortal could guarantee the survival of the English on this beleaguered frontier. In 1703 the little towns stretched out along the river were not the peaceful New England villages of later postcards. Many of them looked more like armed garrisons, especially from Northampton north to Deerfield, the region most vulnerable to Indian attacks. Part of Northampton itself was surrounded by a stockade wall and the town was divided into "military divisions." Some families picketed their homes as well, creating an ominous effect almost the reverse of the next century's white picket fences.

He has been struggling to write a complicated new song this week -- also, depending on how you look at it, for three months or four years; four years is how long he's been working on ''The Light in the Piazza,'' a musical based on Elizabeth Spencer's 1960 novella. There's a dramatic hole at the heart of the story, and it needs to be filled soon because the show is about to open in previews. But difficult as the assignment may be, passionate as Guettel's writing process is, that's not what has done the damage to his hands. He's done the damage. With his teeth.

He is survived by his wife Megan, his children Kathleen, Chris, Barbara, Patty and Simon, his six grandchildren and countless friends. Bill was one of the country's leading experts on payments, clearance and settlement systems in both developed and developing countries. Bill retired from Manufacturer's Hanover Trust Company in 1993 as the Senior Vice President in charge of Global Banking Systems. After leaving Manufacturer's Hanover, Bill became the Senior Advisor on Payments, Clearance and Settlement at the Financial Services Volunteer Corps (FSVC) and over the past 10 years provided technical assistance to central banks, commercial banks and capital markets institutions in Central and Eastern Europe, Russia and the other republics of the former Soviet Union, the Middle East and Southeast Asia. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, DAVID S.
description: LOEB-David S., 79, died at his home in Wingfield Springs, Nevada on June 30, 2003 after a long illness. He graduated from the Maine Maritime Academy and served in the Merchat Marines during World War II. He served on the Board of Trustees of Maine Maritime, which awarded him an honorary doctorate degree, and was a benefactor of the Academy's Loeb - Sullivan School of International Business and Logistics. He was also a graduate, cum laude, of New YOrk University and subsequently served for thirteen years on the Board of Overseers of the NYU/Stern School of Business. He received the prestigious National Beta Gamma Sigma Award in 1992 and the Stern Distinguished Alumnus Award in 1998. Mr. Loeb endowed a Professorship in Finance at NYU/Stern. David Loeb was a brilliant visionary in the fields of mortgage banking and real estate development. He founded Lomas Realty Securities, which later became United Mortgages Servicing Corporation. He cofounded Countrywide Funding Corporation, which later became the largest independent mortgage banking company in the United States, and served as its President and Chairman from 1969 to 2000. He also cofounded Countrywide Mortgage Investments, which eventually became IndyMac Bancorp, Inc. and served as IndyMac's Chairman from its inception until his retirement this year. In addition to his prominent position in the mortgage banking industry. Mr. Loeb also maintained an active real estate business, and at the time of his death was co-owner of the Wingfield Nevada Group/ Loeb Enterprises, LLC and Coyote Springs investment. David Loeb is survived by his wife, Ingrid Heidi Loeb; his daughters, Tracey Loeb, Heidi Loeb and Wendy Lumsden; his stepson Nicholas Casini; and his grandchildren, Zane, Emily, Zoe, Jennifer, John and Molly. David Loeb's business acumen was surpassed only by his endless zest for life, his enduring passion for sports, music and history and his profound love and dedication to his family and friends. His unique wit and extraordinary wisdom will be greatly missed.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Poems Well Built
description: Give your debut collection of poems a title like HAMMER (Sarabande, paper, $12.95; cloth, $20.95) and you are all but promising a poetry of blunt, direct and forceful language. Mark Turpin's poems, most of which are set on the job sites of the home construction industry and peopled by the carpenters and backhoe operators who work there, deliver on that promise. Turpin has worked in the building trades for 25 years, according to the book's biographical note. In these exact and substantial poems, he deftly manages to do full justice to the too-often-overlooked world of work while wisely resisting the temptation to romanticize his craft. In ''Laborer's Code,'' a workman ''rips a bag of chips, / pops a Coke'' before returning to work ''for the pleasure of shoving the shovel in.'' In ''Sledgehammer's Song,'' Turpin deploys strings of monosyllables to achieve a staccato energy that evokes the music of demolition: ''The way a stance is spread, / The way the steel head pings / and thrums and thuds, / The way it undoes what was done.'' But readers of this collection need not worry about enduring giddy paeans to manual labor. Turpin sees with a clear eye the frustrated ambitions, complex human relationships and weary resignation that can be found at most any workplace. In ''Waiting for Lumber,'' Turpin asks: ''What was work in our lives anyway? / No one recalled a moment of saying yes / to hammer and saw, or anything else.'' Turpin's language is refreshingly plain, and his deadeye accuracy gets to the heart of our conflicted relationship with work. Andrew Santella

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERGAS, MARTIN
description: ERGAS-Martin. August 7, 1950-March 5, 2003. Martin Ergas, a visionary Miami philanthropist, real estate investor, entrepreneur and attorney has died of cancer at the age of 52. A passionate advocate and donor in the effort to make life better for people with spinal cord injuries, Mr. Ergas was a founding patron and member of the Board of Trustees of the Miami Project To Cure Paralysis. He supported the Martin Ergas Gym at Miami Children's Hospital, Mt. Sinai Hospital of Miami Beach, University of Miami and Shake-A-Leg. His dedication and contribution to the field of neuromuscular paralysis was initiated by his own spinal cord injury sustained at the age of eight as the result of a sign falling from a building in New York City. Mr. Ergas has served as a Trustee of the International Spinal Research Trust, London, and as a Director of the American Paralysis Association. In 1980 founded Therapeutic Technologies, which developed the Ergys electrical stimulation bicycle that allows paraplegics and quadraplegics to exercise aerobically. His interests also included real estate. In 1983 he began work on Deco Plaza, the first redevelopment project following the establishment of the Art Deco National Historic District. It received the Miami Beach Development Corporation Award as the Best Rehab of 1985. The son of Jack and Grace Ergas of Cedarhurst, NY, Mr. Ergas moved with his family to Bal Harbour in 1968 and entered the University of Miami. He received his BBA in 1972 and his JD from the U of M Law School in 1974. He remained a member of the Florida Bar and resident of Dade County throughout his life. Marty was admired most for his charm, his wit, his intellect, his love of the moment, and for his unfaltering sense of possibilities. He was loved by his family and friends as an extraordinary listener who offered straightforward advice with warmth and wisdom. He loved challenges: he learned to sail in the San Francisco Bay and fly fish in Colorado; he played tennis and completed the Orange Bowl Marathon in his wheelchair. Mr. Ergas maintained an active interest in the history of the Sephardic Jews and in that of his own family who had lived in the former Ottoman Empire for more than four centuries. He maintained relationships with family and friends in Western Europe, Greece, Turkey, Israel, Australia, Chile and Canada. He spoke Ladino (the old Spanish) and French, his conversations seasoned with Turkish phrases learned from his father. He is survived by his wife Shaari Ergas of Coconut Grove, stepchildren Jamie Hallman of Los Angeles and Justin Hallman of San Francisco, mother Grace Ergas of Bal Harbour, sister Betti Zucker of NYC, and a large extended family. Donations in his memory to the Fairchild Tropical Garden in Coral Gables will be directed to the development of wheelchair accessible transportation to tour the gardens. Service at the SF Columbarium, August 7, 2003, 1:30pm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNINGHAM, BRIGGS SWIFT II
description: CUNNINGHAM-Briggs Swift II. America's Cup Winner and motorsports legend dies at 96. Briggs Swift Cunningham II, who was born in Cincinnati, Ohio, and lived the majority of his life in Westport, Connecticut, died in Las Vegas, Nevada on July 2, 2003. Mr. Cunningham was the son of a Cincinnati financier and businessman who funded the start-up of Proctor & Gamble. While attending Yale University, in New Haven, Connecticut, Briggs developed a love of yacht-racing, which lead him to international recognition when he skippered the Columbia to victory in the 1958 America's Cup yacht race. In the 1930s Mr. Cunningham and two friends formed the Automobile Racing Club of America (ARCA) to promote racing in the New York area. In 1940 he began designing and building his own cars. After World War II, Briggs founded the Sports Car Club of America (SCCA) and competed in his first race at Watkins Glen, New York driving his ''BuMerc''-a hybrid Buick/Mercedes of his own creation. In 1950 Mr. Cunningham began his quest to win the 24 Hours of LeMans race in France. To legitimize the image of American racers, Briggs decided to build his own car; an Americanmade sports car that would be competitive with the best that Europe had to offer. He was the first American to drive an American car in the 24 Hours of LeMans. Teaming first with Cadillac and then with Chrysler and their new ''hemi'' engine, Briggs designed and built the Cunningham car. From the first C-1 to the most successful C4R, the Cunningham cars were marvels of American design and engineering. Briggs Cunningham gained the respect of racers worldwide and created a style of car which served as an inspiration for the Corvettes and Vipers of today. Over the next twenty years, Mr. Cunningham continued to design and build innovative race cars. Through strategic alliances with Jaguar, Maserati and Roger Penske, Briggs continued to enter cars in races worldwide including the 24 Hours of LeMans, the U.S. Grand Prix at Watkins Glen and the Presidents Cup at Virginia International Raceway. Mr. Cunningham was inducted into the Motorsports Hall of Fame of America in 1997 and into the International Motorsports Hall of Fame this past April. Mr. Cunningham is survived by his former wife, Lucie Bedford Warren, of Westport, Connecticut and their three children, Briggs Swift Cunningham III of Lancaster, Kentucky, Lucie Cunningham McKinney of Westport, Connecticut, and Cythlen Maddock of Palm Beach, Florida, and 16 grandchildren and 29 great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Norwalk Hospital, Norwalk, Connecticut.

title: The Challenge Ahead in Space
description: The board investigating the space shuttle Columbia accident will soon issue its final report, setting the stage for an important national debate over the future of the space program. By all accounts, the board will harshly criticize the performance and competence of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, and rightly so. The space agency's two catastrophic shuttle accidents -- the loss of the Challenger in 1986 and of the Columbia last February -- resulted from management failures, pure and simple. As Congress and the White House assess the future of the nation's space program, they must start with the need to refashion NASA, whose reputation for engineering excellence and dedication to safety is in tatters. Once that work is done, Washington will have to address the long-term issue of whether the space program should continue to focus on operations in low Earth orbit or reach for bolder, more adventurous missions deeper into our solar system.

title: From Cyborg to Governor?

No one knows whether the drive to recall the Democratic incumbent, Gray Davis, will succeed; no one knows whether the Republican star, Arnold Schwarzenegger, will actually run for the office; and no one has the faintest idea what sort of governor Mr. Schwarzenegger, who spent the first half of his life to date as a professional bodybuilder and the second half as the implacable hero (usually) of kick-butt action pictures, might be.

title: 'After Jihad'
description: Where is the Muslim Solidarnosc? Critics generally pose this question to impugn the democratic possibilities of the Muslim world. The ideal of pro-democracy activism arising spontaneously from the shipyards of Gdansk stands for the hope that in every society, no matter how totalitarian or repressive, there are freedom-loving people who see clearly that democracy is the solution to what ails their country. Yet such popular democracy movements are hard to come by in the contemporary Muslim world.

title: Looting or Saving?

I concede that the artist's intent was for the pieces to be on public display, not to be hung in my living room. But in the 1800's, Lord Elgin brought Greek statuary to London for safekeeping. So am I a preservationist or a looter? Anonymous, Chicago

title: Be the First to Hear A 'New' Donizetti
description: The title ''Eight Months in Two Hours'' (''Otto Mesi in Due Ore'') does not reveal much about the work's subject. One of Donizetti's first successes (from 1827), it is an opera about a young woman who journeys on foot from Siberia to Moscow, through flash floods and other hardships, to beg pardon from the czar for her exiled father. Her journey takes eight months but is presented in one evening.
