title: Page Two: June 29-July 5; UNEMPLOYMENT AND DIMMER HOPES
description: The Labor Department announced that jobs continued to bleed out of the economy in June. The unemployment rate rose to 6.4 percent, the highest in nine years. The report, whose figures were adjusted for seasonal variations, did not provide the launching pad economists were expecting for an economic rebound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATSCHA, ROBERT M.
description: BATSCHA-Robert M. On July 4, 2003. The Board of Trustees and the staff of The Museum of Television & Radio in both New York and Los Angeles mourn the untimely passing of our beloved President. His commitment and unwavering belief in the Museum and its mission were instrumental in securing the Museum's reputation as a leading cultural institution. His dedication, vision, determination, and unfaltering leadership guided and inspired us for more than 20 years. The loss to the Museum is immeasurable, and he will be sorely missed and long remembered by everyone who knew and admired him. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his son Eric and the rest of his family. Services are private. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Chairman of the Board of Trustees

Back when Jimi Hendrix opened Electric Lady Studios, he was on the phone all the time; we talked about how to mike a guitar amplifier and where he should place the mike in the studio.

Honors graduate of Princeton, Class of '42, member of the Ivy Club. He served his country in World War II in 4 of the toughest most successful campaigns in the Pacific. He had a long and distinguished career at Citibank in Manhattan providing principal financing for McDonald's, Holiday Inn and Pizza Hut. He was always generous to Johns Hopkins, Princeton, Episcopal High School and a myriad of individuals, hospitals and charities. Matt was a loyal friend, husband and father. Predeceased by his wife Rosemary Ford and daughter Harriet Freeman. Surviving are grandson Matthew Freeman, daughters Rosette Ford Gault of Seattle and Mary Virginia Gault of NYC. title: 'Bangkok 8'
description: The African American marine in the gray Mercedes will soon die of bites from Naja siamensis, but we dont know that yet, Pichai and I (the future is impenetrable, says the Buddha). We are one car behind him at the toll for the expressway from the airport to the city and this is the closest weve been for more than three hours. I watch and admire as a huge black hand with a heavy gold signet ring on the index finger extends from the window, a hundred-baht note clipped stylishly between the pinkie and what our fortune tellers call the finger of the sun. The masked woman in the booth takes the note, hands him the change and nods in recognition at something he says to her, probably in very bad Thai. I tell Pichai that only a certain kind of American farang attempts conversation with toll booth operators. Pichai grunts and slides down in his seat for a nap. Survey after survey has shown sleep to be my peoples favorite hobby.

title: A Final Push for the Bedeviled, Beloved Osprey

Buck Rogers himself couldn't have created a more dramatic sight: a hybrid craft, half helicopter and half airplane, that danced in the sky and appeared to defy the laws of aerodynamics.

title: Top Dog On the Hot Dog

Then, as The Washington Post reported, the cheers grew even louder.

title: In the Face of Death
description: At 2:40 a.m. on Aug. 26, 1998, along a main drag on the west side of Indianapolis, 18-year-old Jeremy Gross approached a convenience store with a friend. They intended to rob it. At 5-foot-8 and of slender build, Gross was not particularly physically imposing, and he had a distant look about him. He wore his blond hair in a bowl cut and often seemed nervous and fidgety. He knew the store well, since he worked there part time, and he also knew the young man, Christopher Beers, who was the lone clerk that morning. Beers, who was 24, had been raised by his father and had completed one year at Purdue University before running out of money for tuition. He was overweight and, according to his uncle, mild-mannered. He was working to earn money to return to school. An avid reader, he welcomed the graveyard shift; it gave him time with his books.

The arrangement, in other words, is perfect for a couple who love adventure and take pride in their stamina but like to finish the day with a shower, a good meal, and a comfortable bed.

title: Editorial Observer; What 'Capturing the Friedmans' Says About Getting Tough on Crime
description: Jesse Friedman took a break from a recent lunch to lift his leg in the air and show me his ankle bracelet. Electronic monitoring is hardly the worst of Mr. Friedman's current woes. He will have to register as a sex offender for the rest of his life -- his Manhattan apartment building, on getting word about that, evicted him and he spent two weeks in a homeless shelter. He is struggling to get his life on track after spending ages 19 to 32 behind bars. Mr. Friedman was upbeat at lunch, but I was getting depressed. Particularly since it seemed to me more than likely that he was innocent.

title: Fewer Jobs Were Cut in June
description: Employers cut 59,715 jobs last month, the lowest number since November 2000, according to a nationwide survey. The June number was down 13 percent from May and down 37 percent from June 2002. But the decline does not necessarily mean that companies are poised to hire more people anytime soon, said John A. Challenger, the chief executive of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, which published the survey last week. ''The fall in job cuts may mean that employers are simply staying with the workers they have, resulting in a stagnant job market,'' he said.

title: Rollicking Festivals of Traditional Irish Music
description: Every summer, Ireland celebrates its traditional music with dozens of festivals that mix virtuoso performances with weekend parties. Impromptu music sessions materialize in pubs and on street corners, and the lively sounds of a jig or reel are never far away. Public squares are the sites of concerts and dances, while students and fans attend workshops and master classes.

The apartment has always been in my mother's name, although she has never lived here and I am the one who has always paid the maintenance. If she should pass on, would I be allowed to keep living here indefinitely? Would it be advisable to put the apartment in both of our names now? . . . S. Alan, Manhattan

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: MEL GIBSON is a widowed priest who has lost his faith, so when he sees U.F.O.'s hovering over Mexico on television and someone or something has created crop circles in his cornfields, he does not turn to prayer. ''There is no one watching out for us, Merrill,'' he informs his brother (Joaquin Phoenix) in M. Night Shyamalan's SIGNS (2002). ''We are all on our own.'' Well, maybe not, and the oversentimental, overcontrived conclusion is the only thing that keeps this expertly creepy science-fiction film from being an unqualified winner. It turns out to be significant that little Morgan (Rory Culkin) has asthma and that littler Bo (Abigail Breslin) has a thing about the taste of water. But it's good to know that if an alien wanders into your house, you can just lock it in the pantry -- Saturday at 9 p.m. on Starz.

title: Virus as Metaphor: Microbiology and '28 Days Later'
description: DANNY BOYLE'S arresting and terrifying new movie, ''28 Days Later,'' seems to make it official: microbial plagues have displaced nuclear winter in the public's mind as the way the world will end. Although written and produced before we had anthrax spores in the Senate, national debates about smallpox vaccination, searches for weapons of mass destruction in Iraq and global anxiety about SARS, its release in this country at this time feeds on now routine fears of an unanticipated microbiological catastrophe.

All rates at these locations now include alcoholic and nonalcoholic beverages (Champagne and V.S.O.P. brandy excluded) and all-day access to light meals and snacks. Snack bars will be open between meals and until the bar or nightclub closes for the evening.

title: 'The Probable Future'
description: I. Anyone born and bred in Massachusetts learns early on to recognize the end of winter. Babies in their cribs point to the brightening of the sky before they can crawl. Level-headed men weep at the first call of the warblers. Upstanding women strip off their clothes and dive into inlets and ponds before the ice has fully melted, unconcerned if their fingers and toes turn blue. Spring fever affects young and old alike; it spares no one and makes no distinctions, striking when happiness is least expected, when joy is only a memory, when the skies are still cloudy and snow is still piled onto the cold, hard ground.

title: Two Airlines Increase Fees for Paper Tickets
description: In an attempt to move to an all-electronic ticketing system, American Airlines and Northwest Airlines have doubled their fees for issuing paper tickets to $50, and American has stopped issuing paper tickets entirely for some domestic itineraries. As of May 1, American no longer issues paper tickets for domestic itineraries eligible for e-tickets sold through its reservations agents, Web site, ticket offices and airport ticket counters. Paper tickets are still available through travel agencies, for a $50 surcharge. The same fee applies to international flights eligible for e-tickets, whether the ticket is purchased through a travel agent or American.

title: Making Oil Transparent

Some of the reasons, such as oil's distorting effects on exchange rates, trade balances and credit, are hard to combat. But around the world, governments and oil companies are beginning to embrace a simple change that can help: strip the secrecy from the deals.

title: New Museum Wing In Salem, Mass.
description: Two weeks ago, the public got its first glimpse of much that is new at a very old museum. In Salem, Mass., north of Boston, the Peabody Essex Museum, which says it is the oldest continuously operated museum in the country, reopened with a 110,000-square-foot wing designed by Moshe Safdie. The Peabody Essex showcases maritime memorabilia and art and artifacts from Asia and the Pacific. Late in the 18th century, Salem merchants made voyages to the East their specialty. In the process they amassed large fortunes and endowed the Peabody Essex as a repository for the wonders their voyages revealed, a collection that now includes more than 2.4 million items.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: CONNECTICUT-RHODE ISLAND BORDER DISPUTE Rhode Island is getting serious about deciding its boundary with its western neighbor, Connecticut. Last week, the Rhode Island General Assembly approved legislation to form a commission to determine the state line from the mouth of the Ashaway River between Hopkinton, R.I., and North Stonington, Conn., to the Massachusetts state line, a distance of about 65 miles. Rhode Island could lose about 22 acres. No deadline was given for the Rhode Island commission to complete its work. Connecticut is expected to form a similar commission, said the state's attorney general, Richard Blumenthal. He wants it done during the current special session. If not, he will push for its creation when lawmakers reconvene in February, he said. A spokesman for the Rhode Island attorney general, Patrick Lynch, said the states would then form a joint commission to fix a boundary. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about redistricting in Texas misstated the period during which congressional districts have routinely been redrawn and misidentified the districts of Representatives Martin Frost and Lloyd Doggett. Redistricting after each census was the norm for much of the last century, but not for most of it. (The process became the norm after the Supreme Court ruled in 1964 that large population imbalances between districts violated the principle of one person one vote.) Mr. Frost represents the Dallas-Fort Worth area (not Austin) and Mr. Doggett the Austin area (not Houston).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLARD, , ESTHER P.
description: MILLARD--Esther P., 81, of Greenwich, CT, died Wednesday, July 2, at her home. She died of complications arising from a recently diagnosed Myelo Dysplastic Syndrome condition according to her family. Born May 2, 1922 in Quebec City, Quebec, Canada, she was the daughter of Dr. Albert Paquet and Alice Amyot Paquet. Mrs. Millard was the wife of the late Dr. Donald H. Millard, an orthopedic surgeon and past vice president of Medical Services and Assistant Chief of Medical Staff at Greenwich Hospital. She met her husband during WWII in Washington while working at the Canadian Embassy. They were married in 1946 in Quebec City and lived briefly in Washington, post-war Germany, New Haven and Darien, CT. They moved to Greenwich in 1958 where she raised her children and was an active volunteer in various community organizations. She is survived by three sons and one daughter, Peter D. Millard of Greenwich, Michael N. Millard of Stamford, Brian P. Millard of Ipswich, MA and Anne M. Allen of Rowayton, nine grandchildren, two sisters, Madeline P. O'Sullivan of Vero Beach, FL, Monique P. LaBreque of Quebec City, and one brother, Nicolas Paquet of Quebec City. In addition to her husband, she was predeceased by two brothers, Michael and Jacques Paquet, and a sister, Louise Pettigrew, all of Quebec City. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10 AM, Wednesday, July 9th, at St. Michael's Church on North St. in Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, a memorial donation may be made to Greenwich Hospital, Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT. 06830. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEISKELL, , ANDREW
description: HEISKELL -- Andrew. The Board, Staff and Artists of Lincoln Center Theater grieve the death of the beloved Vice Chairman of the theater since its re-establishment in 1985, our treasured Andrew Heiskell. The theater was greatly blessed by Andrew's extraordinary spirit, his profound understanding of the way cultural institutions work in New York City. Andrew reveled in the artistic life of the theater. He was endlessly curious about the plays, their provenance and was eager to understand the process by which a script was converted to a production. He was given to saying that having read a play, he couldn't quite imagine it on stage, and was most often delighted by the realization of a production. Andrew's commitment, generosity, kindness and challenging intellect will be sorely missed along with his wise and gently commanding presence. We extend deeply felt condolences to Marian and all the family. John Beinecke, Chairman Linda L. Janklow, Chairman Emeritus John Chalsty, President Andre Bishop, Artistic Director Bernard Gersten, Executive Producer

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 25 about California's budget troubles and the effort to recall Gov. Gray Davis referred imprecisely to the timetable for holding a recall election. While signatures must indeed be submitted by Sept. 2, they must be certified by Sept. 4 to force an election in the fall. If the signatures are certified after Sept. 4, state officials have the option of holding a special election in the fall or the winter, or of putting the recall measure on the March 2 statewide primary ballot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLANAGAN, , THOMAS V.
description: FLANAGAN--Thomas V. 86, of Mineola, NY, on July 4, 2003. Former Officer - in Charge (Postmaster) of the General Post Office, 8th Avenue, NYC, and former Officer-in-Charge (Postmaster) of Brooklyn, NY. Tom retired form the Postal Service in 1980 after 45 years of dedicated service. He started as a clerk on the floor and with a tough work ethic moved up through various postal management levels. He became Postmaster of Brooklyn and then on to Officer-in-Charge (Postmaster) of the New York GPO, the largest single post office in the world. Tom was a professional basketball player during basketball's most difficult era, the golden years which featured such teams of the past as the original Celtics, Brooklyn Visitations, Philadelphia Sphas, Renaissance and the Cleveland Rosenblooms. Tom is survived by his wife of 56 years, Joan; sons Thomas, Terrence, Stephen, Kevin; 11 grandchildren; a brother, Eugene; and sister Joan Shea. Visiting Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, Cassidy Funeral Home, 156 Willis Ave., Mineola, NY. Funeral Mass 9:45 AM, Tuesday, Corpus Christi Church. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, , ALAN LEONARD
description: LEVY--Alan Leonard. 73, died at home on July 4, 2003, after a battle with cancer. Born in Brooklyn, NY, on October 8, 1929, son of David and Frances Levy. He graduated from Brooklyn College at 18 years of age and from Brooklyn Law School at 21 years of age. He was admitted to the Bar of the State of New York in 1951. Mr. Levy was a practicing attorney for 51 years at 160 Broadway, NY, NY, until shortly before his death, specializing in personal injury litigation for plaintiffs. His last major case was argued in the Appellate Division First Department on May 15, 2003, involving the right of a police officer who was killed in the line of duty by a fellow police officer's negligence and excessive use of force, to recover damages against the city. Mr. Levy is survived by his wife Judith Richter Levy, also an attorney who practiced with Mr. Levy for 42 years. He is also survived by a daughter Susan Joan Levy, a practicing attorney in New York City, and by a son Douglas Benjamin Levy, a practicing attorney in Tuscon, AZ, and two granddaughters Rachel Mariel Levy and Maya Grace Levy of Tucson, AZ. Funeral services will be held at The Village Temple, 33 E. 12th St, NY, NY, on July 8, 2003, at 11 AM.

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 7 -- In a sweeping attempt at overhauling the devastated postwar Iraqi economy, United States officials announced today that they would replace the Iraqi currency later this year and restructure the central bank to give it new autonomy.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: CAMDEN: BURGLARY SUSPECT KILLED An armed burglary suspect was shot and killed by a city police officer early yesterday morning, according to the Camden County prosecutor's office. The suspect, Corey Graham, 33, of Camden, was shot twice shortly after 5 a.m. near the Ivy Hill Apartments. The prosecutor's office said that about 30 minutes earlier, a homeowner reported two men breaking into the rear of his house. A short time later, Officer Kenyatta Kelly encountered Mr. Graham, who held a .44-caliber gun during a struggle with Officer Kelly. When Mr. Graham refused Officer Kelly's order to drop his weapon, Officer Kelly fired two shots that struck Mr. Graham in the torso, the prosecutor's office said. (AP)

His commitment to and compassion for family, friends, and The Museum of Television & Radio, were unwavering and will be sorely missed. He approached life with purpose and voracious energy, never wasting a second. His warmth, intelligence, and sense of humor touched everyone he came in contact with. His indomitable spirit will remain forever in our hearts. His grounding values, uncompromised and firm, will forever provide a guide for his son Eric. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Three Accused Of Sexual Abuse At Pool
description: Three young men were indicted yesterday, accused of surrounding and groping three girls at a public swimming pool in Marcus Garvey Park last month, officials said. The defendants -- Dellroy Jones, 18, Keith Short, 20, and Mitchell McPhee, 16 -- are charged with sexual abuse and unlawful imprisonment in the second degree and could face up to seven years in prison if convicted. Officials in the Manhattan district attorney's office said Mr. Jones encouraged other young men in the pool to chase the girls, who were swimming. The authorities said that he, Mr. Short and Mr. McPhee and as many as seven other men held and touched the girls as they tried to get away. A lawyer for Mr. McPhee and Mr. Jones did not return a call for comment yesterday. A lawyer for Mr. Short could not be reached. Susan Saulny (NYT)

description: Medtronic Inc. and Becton, Dickinson & Company won Food and Drug Administration approval to market a device for diabetics that combines a blood-sugar monitor with an insulin pump. The wireless product displays a recommended insulin dose so patients do not have to calculate the amount they need. It is the first device for diabetics that integrates a glucose meter, insulin-dose calculator and pager-size pump to deliver the medicine, the F.D.A. said. Medtronic is based in Minneapolis, and Becton is based in Franklin Lakes, N.J.

Travelers were once best known as wandering tinsmiths, which led to the disparaging term ''tinkers.'' They are still discriminated against, especially in rural areas. Mr. Ward, who was born in a Traveler camp but later moved into a settled house, has worked to integrate Travelers into mainstream Irish society. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: AIDS-Afflicted Villagers Say Chinese Police Attacked Them
description: Hundreds of policemen raided an AIDS-afflicted village in central China two weeks ago, rampaging through homes, beating residents and arresting 13 people, villagers said. The nighttime attack, which left more than a dozen injured, was apparently in retaliation for the villagers' previous protests calling for better medical care, residents said in telephone interviews today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Blood Test Settlement
description: The Chiron Corporation and Roche Holding settled complaints made to the European Commission by the German Red Cross and others that the two diagnostics companies fixed prices for blood-screening kits. Chiron, based in Emeryville, Calif., and Roche, based in Basel, Switzerland, agreed to modify terms of their agreements on hepatitis and H.I.V. tests, the companies said. Chiron will extend a licensing offer to blood banks allowing them to screen blood donations and to relieve them of liability for possible past infringements of licenses.

description: Congressional redistricting is about as interesting as someone else's genealogy. But occasionally the subject produces headlines, as it did two months ago when Democratic members of the Texas Legislature fled to Oklahoma to avoid creating a quorum to address the issue. Their desperate maneuver failed; Republican leaders have convened a special session on redistricting and the State Legislature will continue to debate the issue today.

title: More Perfect Union Of Function And Form

The question that faced its architect, Henry N. Cobb, of Pei Cobb Freed & Partners, was: What sort of building is a national schoolhouse?

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BRONX: $2.5 MILLION AWARD IN POLICE BRUTALITY CASE A state jury in the Bronx awarded a disabled Manhattan man $2.5 million yesterday in a case involving his accusations of police brutality nearly two decades ago. The verdict, before Justice Sallie Manzanet of State Supreme Court, came in the case of Pedro Minaya, who has a brain disorder and is mute. His lawyer, Steven Hoffner, argued that Mr. Minaya's disabilities came about because he was manhandled and choked by a police officer in 1985 in the Bronx after Mr. Minaya, then a livery-cab driver, was pulled over for running a red light. The $2.5 million award was designated for future medical expenses. Joseph E. Mohbat, representing the city, said the city would consider an appeal.

title: Is Home Care Really Working?
description: The idea sounds great in principle. Instead of confining elderly Medicaid patients in nursing homes when they become infirm, why not give them a broad array of options, everything from home care to adult day care centers and assisted living? That would please many of the elderly, who prefer to stay at home near friends and family as long as possible. It would also please state and federal Medicaid administrators, whose budgets are swamped with the high cost of nursing home care for elderly patients. No wonder the Bush administration has encouraged states to experiment with home- or community-based care under so-called Medicaid waivers, and no wonder many governors have responded enthusiastically. The trouble is, in many cases no one seems to be monitoring the quality of the care provided, or even whether it is provided at all.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hastings-On-Hudson: Federal Guards Urged At Nuclear Plants
description: A congresswoman called for the replacement of private security guards yesterday at the nation's commercial nuclear reactors with a federally trained and organized force. Representative Nita M. Lowey, a Democrat who represents parts of Westchester and Rockland Counties, described the training and payment of private security forces as inadequate and inconsistent. She said that her latest plan would differ from legislation she helped sponsor in 2001 by stationing the federal security forces permanently at every plant, instead of when needed. Mrs. Lowey said she did not have an estimate of the cost of the program.

title: Iranian Twins Die After Separation Surgery

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Muslim Reports Threats
description: A Muslim woman who recanted her testimony that Hindu neighbors burned members of her family said threats from Hindu nationalist politicians in Gujarat caused her and her family to change their testimony, an allegation denied by those accused. The woman, Zahira Sheikh, 20, was the key witness in a trial of 21 Hindus accused of burning 14 people alive in March 2002 during riots that killed 1,000 people, most of them Muslims. After the recantations, all 21 were acquitted. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Telecom Executive Named
description: Singapore's biggest phone company, Singapore Telecommunications Ltd., said Chumpol Na Lamlieng, left, president of Siam Cement, Thailand's biggest cement maker, will replace Ang Kong Hua, 59, as its chairman next month. SingTel said Mr. Ang, the president of Singapore's biggest steel maker, had indicated plans to retire in May. Mr. Chumpol will be the first non-Singaporean to be chairman of SingTel, and his appointment reflects the company's attempts to expand outside the home country. ''This appropriately reflects the changing nature of the group's business and operations and the fact that it has grown to become a multinational'' company, Mr. Ang said in a statement to the Singapore stock exchange.

title: Next Door to Bias Crime Scene, House Is Firebombed

Instead, the workers were taken to an abandoned warehouse and beaten nearly to death -- a crime that dramatized the growing tensions here over illegal immigrants.

title: Security Against Homeland Pork
description: The big boom in lobbying in Washington in the past 18 months has been in the lucrative world of homeland security, where the roll of new registrants intent on selling the government antiterror products and services has grown fivefold, to 799 and counting. That is a whole new level of competitive importuning, contact wooing and just plain salivating after this year's $30 billion budget at the new Department of Homeland Security. The more polished capital lobbyists usually work with some subtlety. Still, as The Times's Philip Shenon has reported, some of the pioneers in this burgeoning field talk candidly to potential clients of ''securing your piece of the homeland security pie,'' and of offering expertise ''to avoid the land mines and find the gold mines in homeland security.''

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Court Rejects Grand Jury Law
description: The State Supreme Court has declared unconstitutional an Orleans Parish law under which judges selected grand jurors in the parish, which includes the city of New Orleans, from 1883 to 2001. The ruling threw out the indictments of two people accused of being heroin dealers, but it is expected to affect only a few other cases, said Melanie Roussell, a spokeswoman for the district attorney's office. Sonny Armond, a defense lawyer, said other local laws regarding grand juries remained in place after 2001 and brought into question the indictments of several hundred people. The justices said local laws could not govern the criminal justice system. Ariel Hart (NYT)

A memorial service celebrating Mr. Woolworth's life will held on Wednesday, July 9th, 10 AM at Talmadge Hill Community Church, New Canaan, CT. The family will hold a private burial serivce. Contributions in memory of Mr. Woolworth may be made to the Harness Racing Museum and Hall of Fame, POB 590, 240 Main Street, Goshen, N.Y. 10924 or to the Special Olympics, 211 E. 43 Street, N.Y., N.Y. 10017. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: $2.5 Million Award In Police Brutality Case
description: A state jury in the Bronx awarded a disabled Manhattan man $2.5 million yesterday in a case involving his accusations of police brutality nearly two decades ago. The verdict, before Justice Sallie Manzanet of State Supreme Court, came in the case of Pedro Minaya, who has a brain disorder and is mute. His lawyer, Steven Hoffner, argued that Mr. Minaya's disabilities came about because he was manhandled and choked by a police officer in 1985 in the Bronx after Mr. Minaya, then a livery-cab driver, was pulled over for running a red light. The $2.5 million award was designated for future medical expenses. Joseph E. Mohbat, representing the city, said the city would consider an appeal.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: FileNet Reduces Earnings Forecast
description: The FileNet Corporation, a maker of data storage software, reduced its second-quarter earnings outlook yesterday, citing the deferral of several large sales. The company, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., now expects to earn 1 cent to 3 cents a diluted share, down from a previous forecast of 4 cents to 6 cents a share. FileNet also said it expected revenue in the quarter to be about $85 million, down from its earlier outlook of $90 million. Software revenue is estimated at $32 million. The company expects to report cash and investments at June 30 of about $205 million, with no long-term debt. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast, on average, second-quarter earnings of 5 cents a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEISKELL, , ANDREW
description: HEISKELL -- Andrew. The New York Public Library deeply mourns the passing of its Chairman Emeritus, great leader, champion, benefactor, and guardian, Andrew Heiskell. With great wisdom, and with selfless dedication and devotion for more than two decades, he was the guiding spirit in the Library's resurgence from financial difficulties in the 1970's and helped move the Library into a new century, embodying his vision as a university of the people without equal. Under Mr. Heiskell's leadership, the Library raised over $300 million in the 1980's, and he was directly and instrumentally responsible for securing financial support from diverse public and private sources, in addition to his own generous philanthropy. His great achievements included the restoration of the landmark Library building at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street to its original grandeur, the upgrading of many of the Branch Libraries in the Bronx, Manhattan, and Staten Island; improved access to the Library's great research collections; and the revival of the preservation program. He helped expand the Library's Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture and strengthen the endowment for The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts. His interest in the Library's immediate surroundings led him to form the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation, responsible for a comprehensive renovation of the Park, and he helped build 44 miles of new storage for the research collections in underground book stacks beneath the Park. The Andrew Heiskell Braille and Talking Book Library, a facility dedicated to serving the blind, visually impaired, and others unable to read standard print material, is named in his honor to recognize his great energy and commitment in making this facility a reality. New York is a better place because of Andrew Heiskell, for his creation of beautiful public spaces, his drive to provide democratic access to knowledge, and his unwavering support of cultural institutions and their role in bettering society. We owe him our deepest, most profound thanks, and we are grateful to have been touched by a man of such extraordinary vision and goodness. We extend our deepest sympathies to Marian Heiskell and to all members of Andrew's family. Mrs. Vincent Astor, Honorary Chairman Samuel C. Butler, Chairman Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti Paul LeClerc, President

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/New CD's; A Midsummer Night's Steam
description: The voices of summer pop don't set out to challenge anything. They croon and coo, accepting musical genres and standard personas, expecting to be half-heard from a boombox or a car radio as the background to sun-drenched flirtations. The songs in new albums by Ashanti, Monica and Thalia are one gauge of what young lovers expect from each other at this moment in the roughneck fantasy world of hip-hop and rhythm and blues: boys-will-be-thugs behavior from the men, availability and forgiveness (up to the breaking-up point) from the women. Not that they've planned for it to be taken so seriously. After all, it's only a summer fling.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Redback Holders To Exchange Debt
description: Redback Networks, a telecommunications-equipment maker that has lost money each year since it went public in 1999, said yesterday that a group of bondholders had agreed with a plan to convert their notes into shares. The chief financial officer, Tom Cronan, said holders of about 67 percent of the company's $467.5 million in convertible subordinated notes had agreed to exchange their debt for common shares. At least 98 percent of notes must be tendered for the transaction to be completed. Debt holders will then own 95 percent of the company's common stock. Shares of Redback fell 41 cents, to close at 50 cents. They have declined 76 percent in the last year.

title: CELLEGY SAYS F.D.A. REJECTS TESTOSTERONE MEDICINE
description: Cellegy Pharmaceuticals , which is developing drugs to treat sexual dysfunction, said yesterday that federal regulators rejected its Fortigel testosterone medicine. The Food and Drug Administration sent a letter to the company saying studies did not prove Fortigel is safe and effective at certain doses. Cellegy had expected the topical gel to receive federal approval by the end of the year, which would have given the company a $10 million payment from a marketing partner, PDI Inc., the chief financial officer, Richard Juelis, said. Now, the company will meet with the F.D.A. to discuss the agency's concerns. Stock in Cellegy, which is based in San Francisco, fell $1.99, or 38 percent, to $3.23 a share.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: THE NETHERLANDS: BABY FOOD CUTS The struggling Dutch owner of GNC vitamin stores, Royal Numico, said it would take an 88 million euro charge ($101.1 million) to compensate for closing seven baby nutrition plants in Europe and the loss of an estimated 525 jobs. The company said it would record 70 million euros of the 88-million- euro charge in the second quarter of this year and the remainder in 2004 and 2005. The restructuring should result in cost savings of about 35 million euros in 2006, the company said. Numico is a leader in infant nutrition with brands including Milupa, Nutrilon and Olvarit, but it is struggling to recover from poor investments that have left it heavily in debt. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Jobless but Not Hopeless
description: When the United States unemployment rate climbed to 6.4 percent last week, the highest point in almost a decade, analysts were generally glum about the prospects for job seekers. They were being far too pessimistic, however: a close look at four other economic indicators point to the end of what some have called the ''jobless'' recovery. These indicators show significant declines in the rate of job losses -- and positive signs of new hiring in growing industries.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Lawsuits Follow Porch Collapse
description: Two lawsuits, one against the City of Chicago, were filed in connection with a porch collapse in the Lincoln Park neighborhood that killed 13 people on June 29. Jean Ware filed a wrongful-death lawsuit on behalf of her daughter, Kelly McKinnell, 26, who was killed when the porch fell two stories to the ground level. Ms. Ware is suing the L. G. Properties Company; its president, Philip J. Pappas; and Restoration Specialists for an unspecified amount. David Dermejian, a financial analyst injured in the collapse, filed suit against Mr. Pappas; the property manager, Jack Emery; the porch contractor, George Koutroumbis, and the city. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MACE, , FRANK LAWRENCE
description: MACE--Frank Lawrence, 80, of Boca Raton, FL and Somers, NY. Died on July 6, 2003 at home in Somers. Beloved husband of Valerie, loving father of Frank Lawrence Mace, Jr., Sarah Mace, Christina Mace Turner and the late Kent Mace. Father-in-law of Alex Turner. Devoted grandfather of Oona Kent Mace Turner. He was born on December 31, 1922 in Norwalk, CT. He graduated from Dartmouth College in 1945 and from the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration in 1948. He served six years in the U.S. Marine Corps during World War II and the Korean War and retired with the rank of Major in 1952. He then spent an active career in the securities industry. Frank was a man of unique charm, humor and true kindness. He was a lifelong athlete, champion squash player, devoted family man and excellent friend. Memorial service at the Waccabuc Country Club, Mead Street, Waccabuc, NY, on July 10th, 2003 at 11 A.M. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Amnesty International USA, Inc., 322 8th Ave, New York, New York, 10001. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARSON, , PATRICIA GRIMES (BUNNY)
description: GARSON -- Patricia Grimes (Bunny), 80, of New York, NY and Deal, NJ, passed away peacefully at home in NY on July 6th. Born and raised in New York, she was married lovingly to Arthur Garson for 51 years. She was a beautiful, dignified and caring woman. Among her charitable activities were her service on the Boards of RSVPI (Retired Senior Volunteer Program International) which she cofounded with her adored husband; and Camp Oakhurst. She was an active supporter of the NYC Ballet and volunteered at Lenox Hill Hospital. She is survived by her children: Kathleen Frank, Susan Taylor, Thomas Garson and Dr. Arthur Garson, Jr.; her grandchildren: Holly Youngwood, Whitney and Devin Taylor, Michael and Thomas Garson, Jr., and Lauren and Kathleen Garson; and three great-grandchildren. The family will receive visitors from 5-8 PM on July 9th at Frank Campbell's, Madison Ave. and 81st St. Interment is private. Donations in her memory may be made to RSVPI (c/o University of Maryland Department of Aging); Camp Oakhurst (Oakhurst, NJ); Dystonia Medical Research Foundation (Chicago, IL).

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: SYMBOL TECHNOLOGIES CHAIRMAN RESIGNS Symbol Technologies, which makes bar-code scanners, mobile-computing devices and software, said that Jerome Swartz, its chairman, had resigned because of improper financial activities at the company that took place during his tenure. Richard Bravman, the chief executive, will become interim chairman until a new chairman is elected after the company's next annual meeting in October, the company said. The company expects to restate five years of results. Its former chief accounting officer pleaded guilty last month to criminal fraud and conspiracy to overstate earnings. The company's general counsel, Leonard Goldner, also resigned as of June 30. Shares of Symbol rose 51 cents, to $14.36. (Bloomberg News)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: State To Permit Super-Size Motor Homes
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has signed a waiver allowing larger recreational vehicles to travel on state highways without a special hauling permit. Previously, a permit was required for motor homes longer than 40 feet. Such ''super-size motor homes'' are often custom-built converted buses that can sleep up to 15 people and can cost as much as $1 million. The waiver, which takes effect immediately, allows recreational vehicles up to 45 feet long to ride state roads, including the New York State Thruway. It does not apply, however, to some parts of New York City. Stacy Albin (NYT)

But just off the main road, down a dusty alleyway and past the naked children and the few stray dogs at play, Melanie Pico sits in her tidy, modest home acting out one of the hottest trends in global finance and development theory. She is an entrepreneurial client of a microfinancing organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RABKIN, , JACOB (JACK)
description: RABKIN--Jacob (Jack). Formerly of Palm Beach and New York City, died July 1, at his home in Ashland, Oregon at the age of 98. He is survived by his wife of 75 years, Dorothy (Draper), his son Richard of New York, his daughter Amy Cipes of Ashland, six grandchildren and four great grandchildren. A graduate of New York University and its Law School, Mr. Rabkin co-authored with Mark H. Johnson the multivolume ''Federal Income, Gift and Estate Taxation'' and ''Current Legal Forms with Tax Analysis'', both published by the Matthew Bender Co. With his son Richard, he also wrote and illustrated three nature books. His wideranging interests included painting, sculpture, birding and Shakespearean studies. He was gifted with the ability to see to the heart of things; all who knew him will miss his example, his advice, his creative problem-solving, and his ability to enjoy life. >>AD#

title: FENWAY PARTNERS BUYS SPORTS APPAREL MANUFACTURER
description: Fenway Partners Inc., a New York buyout firm, said it bought the Riddell Sports Group, a maker of football helmets and athletic uniforms, for about $100 million. Fenway said the deal would help the company expand product offerings and acquire companies. Riddell, which had about $100 million in revenue last year, is the largest manufacturer of football helmets and the top helmet supplier to the National Football League, the company said. Fenway bought Riddell from Lincolnshire Management Inc., a private equity firm that acquired the company for $61 million in June 2001.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Venture In Picture Phones
description: Texas Instruments and the Sharp Company will jointly develop and sell components used in cellphones with cameras to cut down on design and production time. Sharp will contribute its imaging censors, flash memory chips and liquid crystal displays; Texas Instruments will add communication chips and processors that support multimedia functions like video. Sharp produced Japan's first camera phone three years ago, and now 80 percent of all new handsets sold in Japan include a camera. Japanese handset makers, though, have had a harder time breaking into markets overseas. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: 'Do Not Call' Lists Merged
description: Gov. George E. Pataki signed a bill yesterday making it easier for New York consumers to discourage telemarketers from calling them. Under the new law, the state's Do Not Call telemarketing program will be merged with the tougher and more extensive federal program. The state program's 2.4 million subscribers will now be included in the National Do Not Call Registry when it begins operation in October. Consumers can join the registry by logging on to donotcall.gov or calling 1-888-382-1222. The service, offered by the Federal Trade Commission, applies to most telemarketers but does not affect political organizations, charities, or pollsters. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Hong Kong Chief Executive Faces Calls to Step Down
description: The chief executive, after the defection of a key legislative ally, today faced calls for his resignation and for greater democracy as he was forced to defer a vote on the internal security legislation that has been his top priority.

title: Plans Improve Federal Workers' Drug Benefits
description: The House is expected this week to pass legislation ensuring that federal employees, including members of Congress, will have prescription drug benefits better than those available through Medicare when they retire.

title: The Guy Who Turned Jazz Into an Outdoor Sport
description: MYSELF AMONG OTHERS

title: Iranian Twins Die After Separation Surgery
description: SINGAPORE, July 8  They wanted to look each other in the eye, they said, then pursue independent lives. And so Ladan and Laleh Bijani, the 29-year-old Iranian twins who were born joined at the head, asked doctors here to go ahead with an unprecedented operation to separate them that ultimately neither would survive.

title: Itch? Don't Scratch
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeing Life In the Light Of Blindness
description: This recurring dream haunts me: I'm playing my violin in the youth orchestra, at the height of adolescent freedom, playing my heart out to Brahms or Mahler.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Joan Lowery Nixon, an author of mysteries for children and young adults, misstated the date of her death. It was June 28, not this past Saturday.

title: Microsoft to Give Its Employees Stock Instead of Options
description: Moving away from a pay system that showered riches on a generation of entrepreneurs and engineers in hundreds of technology companies, Microsoft said this afternoon that it would no longer grant stock options, relying instead on restricted awards of stock to help pay its almost 50,000 employees.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article in Weekend on Friday about recordings and events this year to mark 50 years after the death of Sergei Prokofiev misstated the number of his piano sonatas that Anne-Marie McDermott is to play over two performances on July 19 and 26 as part of Lincoln Center Festival's Prokofiev marathon. It is nine, as shown on a list of events with the article, not seven.

title: Steinbrenner's Tears of Rage and Joy
description: George Steinbrenner was clutching a metal railing with both hands in the auxiliary press box yesterday, waiting for the tension of another Yankee-Red Sox game to finally dissipate. He paced, he perspired, he clapped, he pontificated. The Yankees loaded the bases against the always welcome Byung Hyun Kim in the ninth inning, and Steinbrenner, like everyone else, waited.

title: People
description: Timothy Copacia was named executive vice president and managing director at the Dearborn, Mich., office of Wunderman, responsible for the Dearborn and Irvine, Calif., offices. He had been executive vice president and account director for new business development at Campbell-Ewald, Warren, Mich., part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Wunderman is the direct marketing unit of the Young & Rubicam division of the WPP Group.

title: A CONVERSATION WITH -- Shirley Tilghman; Career That Grew From an Embryo
description: Long before she became Princeton's 19th president, Dr. Shirley Tilghman was known among her peers as a distinguished molecular geneticist who had expanded the field of knowledge about embryo development in mammals.

title: A Five-Star Chain Hotel? Really
description: A Hyatt hotel opened last August in Paris on the august Place Vendme. Nearby, a statue of Napoleon Bonaparte, dressed in a Roman emperor's robes and perched atop a marble column, gazed down sternly.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: No Charges Against Protesters
description: A Circuit Court judge dismissed misdemeanor trespassing charges against 17 people in connection with a Jan. 27 antiwar protest outside the Kluczynski Federal Building in Chicago. If convicted, the protesters could have faced up to 364 days in jail and a $2,500 fine for criminal trespassing. They were accused of blocking entrance to the building and staging a ''die-in,'' in which they lay on the ground, holding pictures of Iraqi woman and children. Five other people facing similar charges will stand trail in September. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Dairy Farming an Industry in Conflict
description: Sagging milk prices have taken their toll on the Moss Oak dairy farm, which has been in Maurice Cooper's family since 1917.

title: Letters
description: Itch? Don't Scratch

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PLAINS ALL AMERICAN PIPELINE, Houston, which transports and stores oil in the U.S. and Canada, said it completed three pipeline and gas-storage acquisitions during the second quarter that had a combined cost of $29 million.

title: Workers in Argentina Take Over Abandoned Factories
description: The workers at the IMPA aluminum plant here all can remember when their company was privately owned, and a few veterans even recall when it was the property of the state. But these days, as a result of the worst economic crisis in the country's history, it is the workers themselves who are the factory's stockholders and managers.

title: Closer Kim Suffers Again At Hands of the Yankees
description: An important game was on the line and Byung Hyun Kim was on the mound facing the Yankees. The fatalists among the Red Sox faithful, which is to say virtually every Red Sox fan there is, glared into the future and knew exactly the heartache the next few minutes were sure to bring.

title: Europe Lists Its Objections To G.E. Deal
description: The European Commission has sent General Electric a formal statement outlining its concerns about the company's planned acquisition of the Finnish medical devices maker Instrumentarium. The companies said today that they remained confident the deal would go ahead.

title: At Least 6 Dead in Shooting at Lockheed Plant in Mississippi
description: An employee of the military contractor Lockheed Martin Corporation opened fire today at a company plant near Meridian, Miss., killing five people and wounding eight others before killing himself, the authorities said.

title: Hamilton Pedals On in Pain
description: Insisting that ''it's my decision, they left it up to me, there was no pressure,'' Tyler Hamilton, the leader of the CSC team, started and finished the second stage of the Tour de France today despite having a compound fracture of his right collarbone.

title: White House Seeks Revised Pension Rules
description: The Bush administration is preparing this week to introduce long-awaited pension legislation that could reduce corporate pension liabilities by billions of dollars over the next two years, but would require companies to handle plans more rigorously after that.

title: STARWOOD SELLS HOTELS FOR $300 MILLION TO PAY DEBT
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide, the owner of the Sheraton and Westin chains, said yesterday that it sold 12 hotels in the United States for $300 million to pay down debt. Olympus Real Estate Partners, Rockwood Capital, Prudential Real Estate Investors and HEI Hospitality bought the properties, Starwood said. Starwood, based in White Plains, has raised $955 million through hotel sales this year. The company said it expected to sell six more hotels in the United States this year to generate total proceeds of $1.1 billion. The chief executive, Barry Sternlicht, has said Starwood will pay down $1 billion in debt this year, which may help it make acquisitions.

title: All-Star Process Pleases Selig
description: One old, one young. One right-hander, one left-hander. One dominating, one exciting. If there were two pitchers who seemed destined to play in the All-Star Game next week after what they have accomplished this season, they were Roger Clemens and Dontrelle Willis. One is chasing history with the Yankees and the other has begun the long chase with flair for the Florida Marlins.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Alnylam And Ribopharma To Combine
description: Alnylam Pharmaceuticals and Ribopharma said yesterday that they would combine operations to develop a gene-deactivation technique that could lead to drugs for cancer and other diseases. The new company, the Alnylam Holding Company, will receive $24.6 million from five private equity firms, raising its financing to more than $43 million, Alnylam and Ribopharma said. Alnylam Holding will be based in Cambridge, Mass. The chief of Alnylam, John Maraganore, will become president and chief executive. Roland Kreutzer, the chief of Ribopharma, will become chief operating officer. The companies said Alnylam Holding planned to expand research on using RNA interference to develop treatments for viruses, cancer, metabolic disorders, autoimmune illnesses and diseases of the central nervous system.

title: When Choices Are Elusive
description: Almost a third of doctors surveyed said they had not told patients about useful treatments because they believed the patients' insurance would not cover them, a study reports today.

title: How to Make a Sonic Pure From Pop Snippets
description: Elvis Presley sounded all shook up. As his music streamed from a computer's speakers, he sang, ''You ain't nothin' but a hound dog/ don't be cruel.'' Then, after urging listeners to avoid contact with his blue suede shoes, he crooned, ''Hallelujah.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Baby Food Cuts
description: The struggling Dutch owner of GNC vitamin stores, Royal Numico, said it would take an 88 million euro charge ($101.1 million) to compensate for closing seven baby nutrition plants in Europe and the loss of an estimated 525 jobs. The company said it would record 70 million euros of the 88-million- euro charge in the second quarter of this year and the remainder in 2004 and 2005. The restructuring should result in cost savings of about 35 million euros in 2006, the company said. Numico is a leader in infant nutrition with brands including Milupa, Nutrilon and Olvarit, but it is struggling to recover from poor investments that have left it heavily in debt. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Setback For Fox
description: After midterm elections on Sunday, marred by a record 60 percent abstention, the Federal Electoral Institute announced that with 93 percent of the votes counted, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, would hold on to its relative majority in the Chamber of Deputies with 227 seats. Voters disappointed with President Vicente Fox delivered a sobering upset to his National Action Party, which lost 49 seats. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LYON, , LAURIE
description: LYON--Laurie. July 8, 1947 to March 17, 1972. Our darling sister and friend. We have never forgotten your beautiful smile. Happy Birthday

title: Finalists Chosen For Jergens Account
description: The Andrew Jergens Company has narrowed a review for the account of its personal care brands like Ban antiperspirant, Jergens lotion and John Frieda hair products. Although billings were not disclosed, Jergens and Frieda spent $90.1 million on advertising in major media last year, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, a unit of Taylor Nelson Sofres.

title: DRUGSTORE OPERATOR OFFERS BUYOUT TO ALL MANAGERS
description: Longs Drug Stores Corporation, which operates in the West and Hawaii, said it offered buyouts to all its store managers as the company seeks to trim its work force by about 2 percent to centralize operations. Employees have until July 21 to accept a buyout and will leave between Aug. 1 and Sept. 2. Longs, based in Walnut Creek, Calif., has about 22,000 workers. In May, the company lowered its forecast for the year, saying unemployment in California and customer worries about the economy were hurting sales. The managers will be replaced with executives the company currently employs, he said.

title: Bush Seeks Big Changes in Head Start, Drawing Criticism From Program's Supporters
description: President Bush called today for a major overhaul of Head Start, the popular Lyndon Johnson-era preschool program for poor children, that would add an academic focus to its traditional emphasis on health and nutrition and give some states the right to control its financing.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ILLINOIS: LAWSUITS FOLLOW PORCH COLLAPSE Two lawsuits, one against the City of Chicago, were filed in connection with a porch collapse in the Lincoln Park neighborhood that killed 13 people on June 29. Jean Ware filed a wrongful-death lawsuit on behalf of her daughter, Kelly McKinnell, 26, who was killed when the porch fell two stories to the ground level. Ms. Ware is suing the L. G. Properties Company; its president, Philip J. Pappas; and Restoration Specialists for an unspecified amount. David Dermejian, a financial analyst injured in the collapse, filed suit against Mr. Pappas; the property manager, Jack Emery; the porch contractor, George Koutroumbis, and the city. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVENTHAL, , HAROLD H.
description: LEVENTHAL--Harold H., a resident of North Miami Beach, FL, died on July 4, 2003 at the age of 79. Survived by his wife Therese of 43 years, children Gordon, Danny (Linda), Michele (Harry), Scott; brother David (Elizabeth); six grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Served as First Lieutenant and flew with the 8th Airborne, 447th Bomb Group in World War II. As a member of the Syracuse University chapter of Sigma Alpha Mu, he was known fondly as ''Monk''. He was happiest when surrounded by his large and growing family who will gather at his home to celebrate his life. >>AD#

title: A Portrait of Refugees That Transcends Words
description: During her four decades as an experimental theater director, Ariane Mnouchkine has never doubted the power of the stage to carry a message. She has also never lacked an audience eager to hear it, whether at festivals or at Thtre du Soleil's sprawling home on the outskirts of Paris. Yet for all her devotion to worthy causes, at age 64 her acute sense of theater continues to prevail.

title: Japanese Stay on Sidelines As Nikkei Stages a Big Rally
description: A funny thing happened on the way to Japan's stock market rally: the Japanese did not show up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JEDWABNIK, , LYDIA (NEE BARUCHSON)
description: JEDWABNIK--Lydia (nee Baruchson). Died July 6, 2003 at home in New York City at age 95. Widow of the late David Jedwabnik, M.D. She was born on September 8, 1907 in Odessa, Russia and lived first in Moscow and later in Vilna, Poland, where she was married. In September 1939, she came to America with her husband and daughter to visit the World's Fair, remaining here during WWII, after which she became a life-long resident of New York. Those of her family who remained in Vilna perished in the Holocaust. An accomplished artist she exhibited painting in Vilna and New York and continued painting into her 80s. She was a successful designer of toys and a formidable real estate owner and manager. She loved to travel and regularly summered in Venice. She spoke Russian, Polish, German, Italian, French and English with varying degrees of fluency, but was always able to make herself understood with her confidence, warmth and charm. She is survived by her daughter, Mira Jedwabnik Van Doren and son-in-law John Van Doren, grandsons Daniel and Adam, her daughters-in-law Susan and Charlotte, great grandchildren Benjamin, Ross, Henry, Abbott as well as nephews and nieces, the children of two sisters who predeceased her. She cherished her family and was a loving, devoted mother, mother-in-law, grandmother and great grandmother. She was an unwavering friend to many who passed through her doors. We loved her dearly. She is irreplaceable and will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, July 9th, 11:30AM at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. >>AD#

title: Lottery Numbers
description: July 7, 2003

title: Iranians Mourn for Twins They Had Watched Grow Up
description: TEHRAN, July 8  Most people remember Laleh and Ladan Bijani as the cute twins joined at the head who met Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini after the 1979 revolution. They were seen again in 1998 at a rally in support of President Mohammad Khatami.

title: Olympic Committee Changes Agencies
description: The International Olympic Committee said yesterday that it had selected Saatchi & Saatchi in New York, part of the Publicis Groupe, to handle global creative duties on its account, which has been handled since 1999 by offices of TBWA Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Still For Sale: Water Tower. Cheap
description: Officials in Sublimity thought they had finally rid themselves of their aging water tower when 20-year-old Michael Duhrkoop bought the tower, a 50,000-gallon eyesore, for $212.50 on the Internet auction site eBay. But now city officials say Mr. Duhrkoop has disappeared. City Councilor Bernie Miotke said that Mr. Duhrkoop had visited the central Oregon town of about 2,500 after the close of the May 24 sale to work out the details but that he had not returned phone calls or e-mail messages since then. Mr. Miotke said the city would contact the next highest bidder to see if he was interested in buying, and removing, the tower, which has not been used since 1999. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Genetic Meddling, for Good or Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about law enforcement investigations into a family of judges in Brooklyn referred incorrectly at one point to the relationship of Michael J. Garson and Gerald P. Garson. They are cousins, not brothers.

title: COOPER TIRE'S EARNINGS TO MISS ESTIMATES OF ANALYSTS
description: The Cooper Tire and Rubber Company said it earned 13 cents to 17 cents a share in the second quarter, falling short of analysts' estimates because of higher raw material costs, slower sales and reorganization-related expenses. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected the company to earn 24 cents a share. Cooper Tire is due to release earnings July 17. The tire maker, based in Findlay, Ohio, closed four plants in the United States for a week in May because of a buildup of unsold tires. That cut 4 cents from earnings per share, while charges related to restructuring cost 2 cents a share, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUINN, , MARCIA BORRUS
description: GUINN--Marcia Borrus, on Friday, July 4th, 2003; Mother of Susan Borrus, Dr. Scott Borrus and Debra McKean; grandmother of Rachel, Brandon, Daniel, Justin, Marshall and Matthew. Funeral from the Berheim-ApterKreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Rd., Livingston, NJ, Wednesday July 9, at 1 P.M. Interment Beth Israel Memorial Park. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Marlton: Nurses' Union Reaches Tentative Accord
description: Virtua Health, South Jersey's largest health care provider, reached a tentative agreement with the union that represents almost 1,100 of its nurses, avoiding a strike, said a union representative. The tentative three-year deal was reached last week but announced over the weekend, said Virginia Treacy, the union's executive director. Ms. Treacy would not release specifics of the deal but said the union, known as JNESO, formerly the Jersey Nurses Economic Security Organization, is expected to vote on the contract tomorrow. Ms. Treacy said the workers at three Virtua West hospitals in New Jersey had been working without a contract since June 8. John Holl (NYT)

title: Kissing and Telling (and More)
description: Women appear to be more likely than men to lie about their sexual history and practices, a new study reports.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Inquiry At Oxford
description: Oxford University referred the case of Prof. Andrew Wilkie, who rejected an Israeli graduate student for his laboratory on the grounds of his nationality, to a disciplinary committee. The committee could recommend responses from a formal warning to dismissal. Dr. Wilkie, a geneticist, cited his disapproval of Israeli policies toward Palestinians in a message turning down the application of Amit Duvshani. Diana Jean Schemo (NYT)

title: The Pop Life; Just Can't Get Enough of That Romantic R&B
description: ''It's like Mardi Gras,'' Alfred Moses Jr. said as he tried to edge his airport shuttle van through the crowded streets of the French Quarter here. ''This sure brings a lot of business down here.''

title: Banking Overhaul and New Currency Planned for Iraq
description: In a sweeping effort to revive the devastated Iraqi economy, United States officials announced today that they would replace the Iraqi currency later this year and restructure the central bank to give it new autonomy.

title: Persistence Pays Off for Surprise New Leader
description: ST. DIZIER, France, July 8  If the Jean Delatour team, long the laughingstock of the Tour de France, is looking for a motto to put on its jerseys, it might try "The last shall be first."

title: Spike Lee Is Expected To Settle Suit Over Spike TV
description: Viacom and Spike Lee could announce a settlement as early as today that would allow Viacom to rename its TNN cable network Spike TV, a move that Mr. Lee has been fighting in court, people close to the discussions said yesterday.

title: In Blair We Trust
description: One of the saddest results of our war in Iraq is that it may finish off Tony Blair before Saddam Hussein.

title: Inmate Sought Pen Pals Online After Plea in Internet Sex Case
description: A Greenwich man who used the Internet to lure a 13-year-old girl into a sexual tryst that led to her death has been seeking pen pals over the Net while in federal custody.

title: Turkish Soldiers Released by U.S.
description: Eleven Turkish soldiers returned to their base in northern Iraq today after their release by American soldiers, ending a bitter diplomatic quarrel that a senior Turkish military leader said had pushed relations to a historic low.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Accenture To Develop Voting System
description: Accenture, a large consulting service, has said that it will develop an Internet voting system for the Defense Department to allow thousands of citizens to vote from abroad in the 2004 elections. The company will provide secure electronic balloting and voter registration for military personnel and their dependents and for some other United States citizens who live overseas who have a Windows-based computer and Internet access. County election officials will use the system to receive voter registration applications, provide ballots to voters and accept completed ballots. ''We created our elections practice in response to the market need that emerged following the 2000 elections,'' said Steven J. Rohleder, who leads Accenture's government operating group, ''and we continue to see tremendous global business opportunities in the election industry.'' Officials in 10 states have said they will participate, including Florida, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Utah and Washington.

title: Blair Rebuffs Accusations That He Misled Parliament on Iraq
description: LONDON, July 8  Prime Minister Tony Blair firmly turned aside charges today that he had manipulated intelligence or misled Parliament to go to war, and declared he was convinced that Britain had taken military action at the right time for the right reasons.

title: Music in the Mind
description: Q. Why should I experience the constant repetition in my mind of melodies that I heard either long ago or recently?

title: Rangers' Lyashenko Found Dead In Turkey
description: Roman Lyashenko, a forward in the Rangers' organization, who spent most of last season at Hartford in the American Hockey League, was found dead in his hotel room Sunday while vacationing with his mother and sister in the Turkish resort town of Antalya. He was 24.

title: In Sound's New Economy, Fewer Old Salts; Lobstermen Are Giving Way to Leisure Fishing and Shellfish Hatcheries
description: The traditions and values of earning a living from the waters of Long Island Sound find their purest expression around dawn. That is the moment of departure, the fisherman's great daily leap of faith: one little boat with a little crew sailing out of a mist-cloaked harbor to catch what nature and luck might bestow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINE, , MARCY S.
description: LEVINE--Marcy S. Of Hackensack, New Jersey on July 7, 2003 after a lengthy illness. Dear sister of Peter. Adored niece of Binnie Blum. Services private. >>AD#

title: Rhode Island, Where 100 Died in Nightclub Fire, Adopts New Code
description: Five months after a blaze that was touched off by pyrotechnics killed 100 people at a a nightclub in West Warwick, R.I., the state yesterday adopted a new set of fire regulations that Rhode Island officials praised as the toughest in the nation.

title: Power Failures on Jersey Shore Dash Summer Hopes
description: After enduring the miseries of a rainy spring and a late-arriving summer, merchants and vacationers here and in neighboring towns on the Jersey Shore prayed for a hot and sunny Fourth of July weekend. They got their weather wish, and big crowds, too. But things still turned out miserably.

title: Royal Ahold Main Office Is Raided
description: The giant food retailer Royal Ahold said yesterday that its headquarters near Amsterdam were raided over the weekend by Dutch investigators seeking evidence in a criminal inquiry into the way the company has accounted for sales at partly owned foreign units.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about videos of pirate movies misstated the role of the actor Andr the Giant in ''The Princess Bride.'' He played Fezzik, not himself.

title: No Hits, But Pride Does Job
description: Newspaper headlines in New York yesterday read ''Pride of the Yankees,'' but Curtis Pride tried to focus on Pedro Martnez and the Boston Red Sox.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELKIN, , PAUL J.
description: ELKIN--Paul J. July 3, 2003. Age 91. Uncle of former Ambassador Robert Smith. Beloved great-uncle of Randy, Nick and Gary Smith. Devoted friend of many. Past President of Volunteers Metropolitan Hospital. Services Wednesday, 10 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. >>AD#

title: Thinking, or Thinking of Golf?
description: Is golf the thinking athlete's game? Perhaps, but don't think too hard if you want to do well, a new study suggests.

title: Persistence Pays Off for the Tour's Surprise New Leader
description: ST. DIZIER, France, July 8  If the Jean Delatour team, long the laughingstock of the Tour de France, is looking for a motto to put on its jerseys, it might try "The last shall be first."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REDDY, , ALICE, (NEE FIELDMCNALLY)
description: REDDY--Alice, (nee FieldMcNally) of Chappaqua, NY, died peacefully at home July 5, 2003. Survived by her beloved husband William H., children, Marcus F., Christian St. C., and Hillary M., her sisters Helen F. Richards and Mary F. Kirby and four grandchildren. Resting Wednesday 6-9 PM at Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10 AM, Church of St. John & St. Mary (Little Church), Chappaqua, NY. Interment Fair Ridge Cemetery, Chappaqua, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to AliceField-McNally Reddy Scholarship Fund at Fordham University would be appreciated. >>AD#

title: Opposites Attract? Not in Real Life
description: Suppose that dissenting Justice Antonin Scalia was right when he fulminated recently that, by overturning the Texas antisodomy law, the Supreme Court was paving the way for ''same-sex marriage.'' What's the big deal about gay nuptials, besides the fact that Canada got there first?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Offer Suspended After Prisoner Escapes
description: A police officer was suspended yesterday, accused of failing to safeguard a prisoner, after a man suspected of grand larceny escaped from North Central Bronx Hospital early yesterday morning, the police said. The man, Steven McNally, 47, of Tilbert Avenue in the Bronx, was being treated at the hospital for pneumonia when he fled down a stairwell around 4 a.m. He was caught at 10:30 a.m. at 233rd Street and Katonah Avenue in Woodlawn. Officer Felipe Tabales, who is assigned to the 52nd Precinct, was suspended without pay for 30 days in connection with the case, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Chill Therapy Is Endorsed for Some Heart Attacks
description: Hoping to save thousands of heart-attack victims a year, the American Heart Association has endorsed the cooling of comatose patients whose hearts have been restarted so that they can be brought back to life slowly, suffering less brain damage.

title: After Battling for Gay Rights, Time to Shift Energies
description: FIRST, the Supreme Court gives Texas a disapproving slap by striking down anti-sodomy legislation. Next, Wal-Mart clambers aboard the equal rights bandwagon to mollify its gay employees. Then there's the blessing recently bestowed on gay men and women by Canada, where non-heterosexual marriage is on the verge of legal codification.

title: When Wildlife Stay Wild
description: To the Editor:

title: Rift With France? Keep the Students Out of It
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rise, The Fall, And Now A New Day
description: Just Wonder, a 3-year-old purebred with a black mane and a guarded look, kicked vehemently at the straw in his cinder block stall at Hollywood Park as Bruce McNall measured the space by eye.

title: LIBERIAN SAYS U.S. BACKS HIS ENEMIES
description: President Charles Taylor, in an interview, accused the United States today of supporting his rebel enemies and pressed Washington to prove its commitment to Liberia by sending peacekeepers. He also added a surprising coda to his promise to step down, calling his exile a brief ''cooling-off period'' before a return to Liberian politics.

title: Tarbaek Journal; Fury, God and the Pastor's Disbelief
description: Thorkild Grosboll, a popular Lutheran pastor in this village by the sea, drags on his pipe and clarifies once and for all: ''I do not believe in a physical God, in the afterlife, in the resurrection, in the Virgin Mary.''

title: Placing Hope in a Hobo, Against Nazis
description: There is good news at the Bank Street Theater for undiscovered playwrights struggling to be produced: extensive competition from moldy, unmade film scripts is not something you need worry about.

title: Dissident Group Says Iranian Military Has Nuclear Site
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 — Iran has a nuclear complex northwest of Tehran that is apparently under military control, according to an Iranian opposition group that has provided reliable information about similar facilities in the past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAWKINS, , ROLAND J.
description: HAWKINS--Roland J. Of Manhattan and Remsenburg, NY. Died peacefully after a valiant struggle with brain cancer on July 6. Beloved husband of Dorinda. Loving father of Christine of Altamonte Springs, FL. Cherished son-in-law to Eleanor and Bud Cox of Malvern, PA and brother-in-law to Sandra and Robert DiRico of Kennett Square, PA. Retired General Manager, Vice President of Air France. Former President of Meridien Hotels, USA and A.C.R.C. Decorated Officer of the Legion of Honor, Officer of the National Merit and Officer of the Order of St. Charles. Friends may call at Follett & Werner, 60 Mill Road, West Hampton Beach, NY on Thursday, July 10, 79PM. Burial service on Friday, July 11 at 10AM at St Mark's Episcopal Church, Main Street and Potunk Lane, West Hampton Beach. Interment private. Memorial service planned for September in NYC. In lieu of flowers donations can be made in his honor to the American Society of the French Legion of Honor, 22 East 60th Street, NY, NY 10022. Greatly loved, he will be deeply missed. >>AD#

title: TEST SHOWS FOAM WAS LIKELY CAUSE OF SHUTTLE'S LOSS
description: A test intended to replicate the damage caused to the shuttle Columbia by foam debris during liftoff punched a gaping hole in a wing panel today, leading the investigator in charge of the experiment to declare, ''We have found the smoking gun.''

title: With Rivalry in Past, Mets Are No Match for Braves
description: The rivalry between the Mets and the Braves may be on ice these days, but Jae Weong Seo has experienced how contentious the diluted version can be. After he was forced to remove a Buddhist bracelet from his glove hand in a start in Atlanta in May, he implied that the Braves were to blame. Seo kept the bracelet hidden when he was on the mound for the Mets at Shea Stadium last night, but he could not hide his mistakes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DELLAL, , MOSHI
description: DELLAL--Moshi. Of New York, July 6, 2003. Beloved husband of Agnes, adored father of William, Wilma and Arlene. Devoted grandfather of Cyrus, Dara, Robert, David and Daniel. Loving brother of Khatoun, Naima, Violet, Naim, and Victoria. He was born in Iraq, moved to Iran and then to the United States. He dedicated his life to the service of his family. Funeral services will be held on July 8 at 11:15AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
