title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAIL, , PRISCILLA L.
description: VAIL--Priscilla L., an educator active in the fields of learning disabilities, dyslexia and the education of the gifted, died July 6, 2003 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital at the age of 71. Death was due to cancer. Priscilla Luke Vail was born in New York City to Mr. and Mrs. David L. Luke. She attended the Spence and Brearley Schools and graduated from the Mary C. Wheeler School in Providence, RI in the Class of 1949. Before her marriage, she attended Vassar College from 1949-1951. She earned her BA and MAT from Manhattanville College, Purchase, NY in 1973 and 1974, at which time she joined the faculty of the Rippowam-Cisqua School where she had been a parent and long-time trustee. While working full time at Rippowam-Cisqua, she wrote and published 9 books, and numerous articles for such professional journals as NAIS and the Orton Dyslexia Society. A frequent presenter at educational conferences both here and abroad, she spoke at individual schools and school systems, and at such institutions as the Principals' Center at Harvard, Cambridge University in England, the British Dyslexia Society and York University, York, England. She continued an active professional life, teaching, writing and consulting until the time of her death. She received the Outstanding Educator of the Year award from the NY branch of the Orton Dyslexia Society in 1987 and her book, ''Smart Kids with School Problems: Things to Know and Ways to Help,'' received the Margot Marek Book Award in 1990. She was a founding trustee of the Fisher Landau Foundation for Gifted Learning Disabled Students. In 1998 she received the Samuel T. Orton Award, the highest award given by the International Dyslexia Association. A 50 year resident of Bedford, NY and a 40 year summer resident of Stonington, CT, she was active in community affairs and was a lay reader and chalice bearer at St. Matthew's Church. Among other board assignments, she served on the Education Committee of the Mystic Seaport Museum, and was the non-resident education director of the Hallowell Clinic for Cognitive and Emotional Health in Concord, MA. She was married for 50 years to Donald Vail, who predeceased her. She is survived by four children, Melissa Vail Selby, Polly Vail Walsh, Lucia Vail & Donald Angus Vail and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, NY on Thursday at 4:30PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the International Dyslexia Assoc, 8600 LaSalle Road, Chester Bldg, Suite 382, Towson, MD. 21286. >>AD#

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Industry Use Gains
description: Brazil's industrial production increased in May compared with April but was lower than a year earlier as a result of high interest rates that are damaging economic output and retail sales. The government agency for statistics said output rose 0.1 percent in May, but fell 0.3 percent from May 2002. From January to May, industrial production increased 0.6 percent, while for the 12-month period ended in May, the figure rose 2.7 percent. Eager to combat inflation, the government raised rates to a four-year high of 26.5 percent earlier this year. Although the central bank has since cut its base rate by half a percentage point, the high cost of borrowing is contributing to slowing the economy. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: McDonald's Offers WI-FI
description: The McDonald's Corporation switched on wireless Internet access yesterday in 55 of its San Francisco area restaurants, with 20 additional outlets expected in the next few weeks. Customers who buy a Big Mac Extra Value Meal during a promotion spanning the next six weeks will receive free wireless fidelity, known as Wi-Fi, Internet service for two hours. McDonald's turned to Wayport for installation of its California network. Wayport operates Wi-Fi and broadband service in 565 hotels and airports in the United States, including La Guardia in New York. McDonald's began its Wi-Fi trial in New York in March. A McDonald's spokeswoman, Lisa Howard, said an expansion in New York and the beginning of service in Chicago were expected soon. Also yesterday, McDonald's Canadian unit said it would have a Wi-Fi trial by the end of the year. Glenn Fleishman (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Telecom Bonds Sold
description: The German government sold 4.5 billion euros ($5.1 billion) of bonds that can be exchanged into shares of Deutsche Telekom, in the world's largest convertible bond sale. The state-owned bank Kreditanstalt fr Wiederaufbau, which sold the bonds, can raise the offering by 500 million euros in the coming weeks. The sale cuts the combined stake the government and KfW hold in Deutsche Telekom to about 37 percent from 43 percent. The finance minister, Hans Eichel, who is trying to contain a growing budget deficit, has said he will consider selling shares in Deutsche Telekom and Deutsche Post next year.

description: A man who was found guilty of murder and robbery in June for his role in the fatal shooting of a sleeping passenger on a subway train was sentenced to 50 years to life in prison yesterday. The man, Ali Carrington, 27, of Queens, tried to steal a gold chain from the passenger, Louis Nixon, 28, with the aid of another man, Michael Amuso, on a No. 2 train on Nov. 7, 2000, the police said. Mr. Nixon, a United Parcel Service worker, was fatally wounded when one of the men, apparently frustrated in the robbery attempt, shot him once in the abdomen. Mr. Carrington was tried in State Supreme Court. The case against Mr. Amuso is pending. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: A City at the Melting Point
description: THE two little girls, sisters, weren't so much eating their peach ice cream cones as wearing them. There were bits of fruit on their T-shirts and rivulets of cream on their chins. Up in Brooklyn Heights the air was still and humid, but down on the banks of the East River there was a breeze running, and it ruffled the girls' hair. Still, stickiness radiated off them like heat.

title: Harry Potter's Magic, for Some
description: To the Editor:

title: So Long, School Bureaucrats: 110 Livingston Is Being Sold
description: Like the Kremlin, to which Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg compared it yesterday, 110 Livingston Street was more than a location or a shorthand name for the institution it housed, the city's Board of Education. It symbolized a state of mind, a failed system that was at once imperious and impervious.

title: A StairMaster? This Athlete Prefers Skyscrapers
description: JOHN KORFF has a curious way of choosing hotels. It is not the size of the bed, the view from the room, the pool, the restaurant or the service that sets him aglow. It is the stairways, especially the ones that zigzag 30 or 40 stories into the air.

title: Polish Player to Join Knicks
description: When the Knicks convene for their rookie camp in Greenburgh, N.Y., this morning, they will probably have an unexpected addition: the second-round draft pick Maciej Lampe.

title: Bishops and the Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush, in Africa, Promises Aid but Offers No Troops for Liberia
description: President Bush opened his tour of Africa today with a pledge to work more closely with African nations to help them build a prosperous and peaceful future. But he still would not commit to sending American troops as part of a peacekeeping operation in war-ravaged Liberia.

title: Hostile Bid, a Throwback Tactic
description: The recent rash of hostile bids -- Oracle's pursuit of PeopleSoft, Alcan's stalking of Pechiney and ArvinMeritor's unsolicited offer yesterday for Dana -- would certainly seem to indicate that a takeover tactic made popular in the 1980's is back.

title: INVENSYS SELLS SEMICONDUCTOR UNIT TO LITTELFUSE
description: Invensys, a British engineering concern, said it had sold a semiconductor business based in the United States to Littelfuse Inc. for $44 million. Proceeds from selling the company, Teccor Electronics, will be used to pay debt, Invensys said. Littelfuse is based in Des Plaines, Ill., and Teccor is based in Dallas. Invensys is shedding more than half its businesses to reduce debt and combat a drop in orders for products including factory software and meters. The unprofitable company plans to focus on railway signals and factory controls.

title: Frances Reese, 85, Defender of Hudson Valley
description: Frances Stevens Reese, a founder and chairwoman emeritus of the environmental group Scenic Hudson and a veteran of the fight to keep a power plant from being built on Storm King Mountain, died last Wednesday in Valhalla, N.Y. She was 85 and lived in Hughsonville, a village in Dutchess County, N.Y.

title: World Briefing: Europe
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Parks Department Bias Suit Advances
description: A federal court judge has ruled that employees of the city's Parks and Recreation Department who are accusing the department of bias qualify for class-action status, a decision that could widen the case's impact if the plaintiffs win. On Monday, Judge Denny Chin ruled the plaintiffs qualified for class-action certification because the allegations were common to all of them ''regardless of civil service rank, title, provisional status, or collective bargaining agreement.'' In 2001, 11 present and former employees, all Hispanic or black, filed a bias lawsuit. It accused the department of passing over qualified members of minority groups for promotions and also of maintaining a special program that, the plaintiffs charged, cultivated white people for management positions. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Arizona: Restricting Illegal Immigrants
description: In an effort to keep illegal immigrants from voting or receiving access to public services, a group is trying to collect enough signatures to get their initiative on the Arizona ballot in 2004. On its Web site, the group, Protect Arizona Now, cited increased crime, the ''destruction of our language and culture'' and higher costs for social services and law enforcement as reasons for the petition. The measure requires that people prove their immigration status before being approved for public services not mandated by the federal government. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Sniper Book And Film
description: Charles A. Moose, the former Montgomery County police chief, reached an agreement with the county ethics commission that allows him to go ahead with book and movie deals about his role in the sniper investigation last fall. As part of the deal, Mr. Moose agreed to pay the county $4,250, the amount he received in consulting fees for a possible movie. Mr. Moose, who resigned as chief last month, agreed to drop a federal lawsuit filed over what he called a violation of his First Amendment rights as well as a county Circuit Court lawsuit challenging the ethics commission's refusal to grant him a waiver to write the book. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: U.S. Pact Lifts South Africa Car Exports
description: This is a left-hand-drive country, where most cars have standard transmissions, and where even humble features, like the cup holder, have yet to be widely adopted. But such accessories, and others, like air bags, are standard in most of the more than 200 luxury 3 Series BMW sedans that roll off the production line in South Africa each weekday, in luminescent colors like Titanium Silver and Mystic Blue.

title: Tenet Discloses S.E.C. Is Investigating Its Medicare Billing
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation , which for months has been the subject of a Justice Department inquiry, is now being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission as well for its Medicare billing and financial disclosures dating back to 1997.

title: Alcoa Posts 4.2% Decrease In Earnings From Operations
description: Alcoa, the world's biggest maker of aluminum, said yesterday that second-quarter profit from continuing operations fell 4.2 percent on weak demand from aerospace and automotive customers as energy costs increased.

title: Hundreds of Afghans Attack Pakistan Embassy in Kabul
description: Hundreds of Afghans ransacked Pakistan's embassy in Kabul this morning, shattering windows, breaking down doors and setting the Pakistani flag on fire.

title: Abbas in Clash Over His Stance In Peace Talks
description: Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian prime minister, battled rival Palestinian leaders today to retain control of negotiations with Israel over a new American-backed peace plan, threatening to quit to face down a storm of criticism that he had gained little for renouncing violence.

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: MARYLAND: SNIPER BOOK AND FILM Charles A. Moose, the former Montgomery County police chief, reached an agreement with the county ethics commission that allows him to go ahead with book and movie deals about his role in the sniper investigation last fall. As part of the deal, Mr. Moose agreed to pay the county $4,250, the amount he received in consulting fees for a possible movie. Mr. Moose, who resigned as chief last month, agreed to drop a federal lawsuit filed over what he called a violation of his First Amendment rights as well as a county Circuit Court lawsuit challenging the ethics commission's refusal to grant him a waiver to write the book.

title: Underdog Sprinter Seizes The Lead
description: If the Jean Delatour team, long the laughingstock of the Tour de France, is looking for a motto to wear on its jerseys, it should try ''The last shall be first.''

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: College Admissions And Race
description: Gov. Bill Owens said he would support and sign legislation to bar race from being a factor in college admissions in the state. Governor Owens, left, a Republican, was answering a question on a radio show when he said he opposed quotas and ''regrets the Supreme Court decision'' last month. Though there had been no legislation drafted for the 2004 session, Senator Jim Dyer, also a Republican, rushed to draft the first bill to restrict the use of race in admission to Colorado universities. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Gold Miner Acquired
description: A Canadian gold mining company, Placer Dome Inc., agreed to buy East African Gold Mines Ltd., the owner of the North Mara mine in Tanzania, for about $255 million. The purchase is Placer's first in Tanzania. The bid is equivalent to $3.015 for each share of the closely held East African Gold Mines, Placer Dome said.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Extreme Networks' Executive Resigns
description: Shares of Extreme Networks slid 19 percent yesterday after an executive known for cutting costs, Hal Covert, the chief financial officer, resigned. Shares of Extreme Networks, which makes networking switches, closed at $5.01, down $1.16. Mr. Covert cited personal reasons when announcing the move. Analysts said his departure would slow the company's return to profitability. Extreme Networks executives were not immediately available for comment.

title: Bryant Accuser Works at Hotel
description: The woman who has accused Kobe Bryant of sexual assault is a 19-year-old employee of the resort where Bryant was staying last week, local authorities said today.

title: 4 Are Found Dead in South Jersey Home
description: Four people, including two children, were found dead yesterday afternoon in a small, well-kept ranch-style house in Magnolia, N.J., apparently the victims of a murder-suicide, the Camden County prosecutor said.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: From Trench Coat Mafia To Teen Heartthrob

title: Suit Says School Ordered Girls Tested for Diseases After Party
description: The ''hooky party'' attracted about a dozen students who cut classes at their intermediate school in Washington Heights on a Friday in mid-April, and it might have gone unnoticed, except for one thing: word of midday debauchery somehow got back to the school.

title: Man Held as 'Combatant' Petitions for Release
description: Lawyers for a Qatari student who was jailed by the military last month asked a federal court today to free him and challenged President Bush's authority to treat terrorism suspects as ''enemy combatants.''

title: Obesity on Rise in New York Public Schools
description: Nearly half the children in New York City's public elementary schools are overweight, and about one in four is obese, a city survey has found. Among Hispanic children, the rate of obesity is 31 percent.

title: INSIDE
description: Earlier Shuttle Damage

title: Bush Charge on Iraq Arms Had Doubters, House Told
description: The State Department told a Congressional committee today that seven days after President Bush gave his State of the Union address, in which he charged that Saddam Hussein was trying to purchase uranium in Africa, American diplomats warned the International Atomic Energy Agency that the United States could not confirm the reports.

title: Charles P. Kindleberger, 92, Global Economist, Is Dead
description: Charles P. Kindleberger, an economic historian who advanced the study of international finance and helped to devise the Marshall Plan for Europe's reconstruction after World War II, died on Monday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 92.

title: F.D.A. Requires Food Labels to Reveal a Lesser-Known Fat
description: After more than a decade of debate, the Food and Drug Administration said today that it would require food processors to include the amount of artery-clogging trans fatty acids on the nutrition label. That action could have implications far beyond the labeling of snack foods.

title: 9/11 COMMISSION SAYS U.S. AGENCIES SLOW ITS INQUIRY
description: The federal commission investigating the Sept. 11 terror attacks said today that its work was being hampered by the failure of executive branch agencies, especially the Pentagon and the Justice Department, to respond quickly to requests for documents and testimony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEISKELL, , ANDREW
description: HEISKELL -- Andrew. The New York Public Library deeply mourns the passing of its Chairman Emeritus, great leader, champion, benefactor, and guardian, Andrew Heiskell. With great wisdom, and with selfless dedication and devotion for more than two decades, he was the guiding spirit in the Library's resurgence from financial difficulties in the 1970's and helped move the Library into a new century, embodying his vision as a university of the people without equal. Under Mr. Heiskell's leadership, the Library raised over $300 million in the 1980's, and he was directly and instrumentally responsible for securing financial support from diverse public and private sources, in addition to his own generous philanthropy. His great achievements included the restoration of the landmark Library building at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street to its original grandeur, the upgrading of many of the Branch Libraries in the Bronx, Manhattan, and Staten Island; improved access to the Library's great research collections; and the revival of the preservation program. He helped expand the Library's Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture and strengthen the endowment for The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts. His interest in the Library's immediate surroundings led him to form the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation, responsible for a comprehensive renovation of the Park, and he helped build 44 miles of new storage for the research collections in underground book stacks beneath the Park. The Andrew Heiskell Braille and Talking Book Library, a facility dedicated to serving the blind, visually impaired, and others unable to read standard print material, is named in his honor to recognize his great energy and commitment in making this facility a reality. New York is a better place because of Andrew Heiskell, for his creation of beautiful public spaces, his drive to provide democratic access to knowledge, and his unwavering support of cultural institutions and their role in bettering society. We owe him our deepest, most profound thanks, and we are grateful to have been touched by a man of such extraordinary vision and goodness. We extend our deepest sympathies to Marian Heiskell and to all members of Andrew's family. Mrs. Vincent Astor, Honorary Chairman Samuel C. Butler, Chairman Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti Paul LeClerc, President

title: For Hard-Luck Chef, a Break: He Is Acquitted in Art Theft
description: After losing seven restaurants in the British Isles, a bar in Manhattan and part of his art collection -- as well as being jailed in Brooklyn -- the celebrity Irish chef Conrad Gallagher had a victory today.

title: A Rothschild's Chairman From France
description: The centuries-old Rothschild banking empire is aligning its global businesses and has appointed Baron David de Rothschild, head of the French operations, as its new chairman.

title: Campaign Memo; Tricky Question for Democrats: When Is Open Season on One Another?
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut came to the New Hampshire seacoast this morning armed with a speech that included what sounded like sharp criticism of his Democratic opponents. But the line was struck from his written remarks, and the attack went undelivered.

title: JLG INDUSTRIES TO BUY OUT TEXTRON'S OMNIQUIP UNIT
description: JLG Industries, a maker of industrial equipment, agreed to acquire the remaining business of Textron's OmniQuip unit for $100 million to expand its product line. OmniQuip, which sells backhoes and lifting equipment for construction, had $217 million in sales last year, JLG said. JLG is based in McConnellsburg, Pa. Textron, the maker of Cessna airplanes and Bell helicopters, is selling some businesses to focus more on its aircraft, finance and industrial-parts units. Textron is based in Providence, R.I.

title: Conferences Consider Merits of Realignment
description: Presidents of Conference USA universities will hold a conference call today to discuss a plan and timetable for future realignment. The call comes as universities prepare for a trickle-down impact of the Atlantic Coast Conference's decision last month to expand by adding Big East members Miami and Virginia Tech.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on June 28 erroneously stated that Iceland is currently hunting whales. Iceland suspended whaling in 1989.

title: Elaborating the Visceral in the Erudite, and Vice Versa
description: AS OF THIS WRITING

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Boldface Names column yesterday about the debut of ''Hamptons Report,'' Lizzie Grubman's radio show on WNEW, the station now known as 102.7 Blink, misidentified the actor who she said was looking for a girlfriend. He is Shane West (not Sean Connery, who is in a new movie with Mr. West).

title: It's Not Just About the Bikes
description: ST. DIZIER, France, July 9  Went to the Tour de France again today. What a wonderful event. People drive past in gaudy cars and toss ball caps and t-shirts and trinkets to people standing behind steel barricades. Nary a bicycle in sight.

title: From Your Own Rialto, the Refreshing Tastes of Venice
description: TELL anyone that you are going to Venice and you are likely to hear how bad the food is there. This is partly because people are keen to show how street-smart they are: to be loftily disdainful of the food is to show you are no mere tourist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PUGLISI, , REV. MSGR. GUY J., PH.D.
description: PUGLISI--Rev. Msgr. Guy J., Ph.D. On July 8, 2003. Devoted son of Catherine (nee Corcoran) and the late Salvatore J. Beloved brother of Sister Stephen Mary, CSJ. Monsignor was the Vicar for Education, the Superintendent of Schools for the Diocese of Brooklyn, a graduate from the School of Education at Fordham University and the Chaplain at Bishop Ford H.S. Funeral Mass Friday, 10:30AM. Mass of Transferral 7:30PM Thursday evening at Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church located at 73rd Street and 4th Avenue, Bay Ridge. Visitation 1 to 5PM Thursday, in Our Lady of Angels Church. Interment to follow Mass Friday to St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Rd, Bx, N.Y. 10461 in his memory would be greatly appreciated. For more information contact the Marine Park Funeral Home at 718-339-8900 >>AD#

title: Hasek to Return to Red Wings
description: Last year, Dominik Hasek retired after winning his first Stanley Cup. Yesterday, the 38-year-old goaltender said he had a change of heart and would return to the Detroit Red Wings next season.

title: Lopez Said to Be Near Settlement
description: Jennifer Lopez, the pop diva and actress, is close to reaching a settlement with her former manager, Benny Medina, whom she has accused of misappropriating money and inappropriately making deals on her behalf, two people close to the settlement talks said today.

title: McCann Executive to Become Consultant
description: Hank Wasiak, a vice chairman at the McCann-Erickson World Group in New York, said yesterday that he was leaving to become a consultant at the Concept Farm in New York, where his son is a partner and a co-owner.

title: Progress Against Outlaws Is Cited As U.S. Releases Aid to Colombia
description: The Bush administration certified today that Colombia was making progress in reining in paramilitary forces that terrorize the civilian population and often work in conjunction with the country's armed forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RENE, , ANDRE
description: RENE--Andre. Societe Culinarie Philanthropique deeply regrets the passing of Andre Rene, our former President and friend on July 7, 2003, in Wallkill, NY. The viewing is at The Copeland Funeral Home, 162 South Putt Corners Rd, New Paltz, NY, on Wednesday and Thursday July 9th and 10th from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Jean Pierre Stoehr, President >>AD#

title: Harry Potter's Magic, for Some
description: To the Editor:

title: James Era Begins Before 15,123
description: LeBron James, playing his first game in a Cleveland Cavaliers' uniform, drew close to a capacity crowd at the Orlando Magic's home court tonight and turned in a 14-point effort marked by several scintillating plays.

title: Indonesia Says Drive Against Separatists Will Not End Soon
description: The Indonesian military has now declared that its tough offensive against rebels in the northern province of Aceh, originally supposed to last six months, would last much longer, maybe even 10 years.

title: Harry Potter's Magic, for Some
description: To the Editor:

title: Dent Gets Bigger Role In Yankee Organization
description: If Bucky Dent succeeds Joe Torre as manager of the Yankees, their principal owner, George Steinbrenner, wants him to be ready. Steinbrenner has taken steps to give Dent, manager of the Class AAA Columbus Clippers, a more prominent role in the organization. But he has done it at the expense of Gordon Blakeley, its highest-ranking baseball operations official in Tampa, Fla.

title: EXXON MOBIL PIPELINE VENTURE GETS A CUSTOMER
description: Exxon Mobil and its partners in a proposed $3.5 billion pipeline from Papua New Guinea to Australia moved a step closer to turning their long-delayed project into reality yesterday when a government-owned power utility signed on as a future customer. The utility, Energex, which is owned by the Australian state of Queensland, agreed to buy gas for 20 years starting in 2007. Last year, the project had a major setback when Australian Gas and Light pulled out of a contract to buy gas. A project partner, ChevronTexaco, has since announced plans to sell its share of oil and gas fields in Papua New Guinea. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: CALPERS JOINS FOES OF BUFFETT'S OFFER FOR CLAYTON
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System said it would vote to reject Warren E. Buffett's $1.7 billion takeover offer for Clayton Homes Inc. The pension fund, which held 641,375 shares of the mobile-home manufacturer as of March, said that the bid from Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc. was too low and that Clayton's top management would benefit more than other shareholders by keeping their jobs. The $131 billion fund, known as Calpers, joins investors like Orbis Investment Management Inc. and First Pacific Advisors Inc. in opposing the takeover. Clayton shareholders will vote on the bid on July 16.

title: No. 2 in Trucking, Yellow, Will Buy No. 1, Roadway
description: The Yellow Corporation, the nation's second-largest trucking company, will acquire the industry leader, the Roadway Corporation, the two companies said yesterday. The deal will create the Yellow-Roadway Corporation, a behemoth with more than $6 billion in annual sales.

title: McCann Executive To Become Consultant
description: Hank Wasiak, a vice chairman at the McCann-Erickson World Group in New York, said yesterday that he was leaving to become a consultant at the Concept Farm in New York, where his son is a partner and a co-owner.

title: Frontier tries comedy even as many wonder whether flying has a humorous side anymore.
description: IS there really anything funny about flying these days? Especially flying cheap?

title: MetroStars Scrambling on Defense
description: Doubts on defense continue to dog the MetroStars as they prepare for Saturdays match against the New England Revolution in Foxboro, Mass. The team has yielded eight goals in its past three games, and a combined 10 in its other 11 matches.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Caci Expects Profit To Rise 36%
description: CACI International, which manages computer networks for the Defense Department, said that first-quarter earnings would increase as much as 36 percent because of spending on the military, intelligence and homeland security. Shares rose $4.13, to $38.30. Net income in the period ending in September is expected to rise to $12.3 million to $12.7 million, or 41 cents to 43 cents a share, from $9.4 million, or 32 cents, in the year-earlier period.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Real Estate Spinoff
description: Canada's largest auto parts maker, Magna International, said it would spin off its real estate assets as a publicly traded company to Magna shareholders. The company, MI Developments Inc., will hold almost all of Magna's auto-related factories and other property, as well as the company's interest in the publicly traded Magna Entertainment Corporation, North America's biggest owner of horse racetracks, Magna said. Belinda Stronach, the chief executive, said on a conference call that the real estate operations were not a core business for Magna.

title: Harry Potter's Magic, for Some
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENFIELD, , LAWRENCE
description: GREENFIELD -- Lawrence. Age 67. Of New York City and Roxbury, CT., died peacefully at his home in Manhattan on July 7, 2003 following a battle with brain cancer, during which he showed the utmost courage, dignity and spirit. Beloved husband of Roslyn. Loving father of Lauren, Lisa and Peter. Stepfather of James Greenberg. Grandfather of Onyx and Kaya. Brother of Leanne Shulman. Dear friend and associate of many. Larry will be remembered for his devotion to his family, his philanthropy, his many years of business leadership, and by friends and colleagues for his innumerable, quiet acts of compassion and support. Larry was a board member of The University of Wisconsin Foundation, where his unwavering commitment to The Center for Jewish Studies led to the creation of The Greenfield Summer Institute Program and The Center's annual newsletter. The Institute brings together people with an interest in Judaism for a week of study, discussion and other activities at the University campus in Madison. In addition to his support for Jewish education, Larry was keenly interested in the arts, both as an observer and a practicing writer and sculptor. In his forty years with the Kaye Group, of which he served as President and Chairman, he was instrumental in the firm's growth to one of the nation's largest insurance brokerage organizations. His astute insight and understanding of business and professional risks enabled him to devlop innovative and unique methods of risk management, many of which are widely practiced today. All who knew Larry will miss his dynamic energy, spirit, wit and kindness. Funeral service Thursday, July 10th, 12 Noon, at Congregation Rodeph Sholom 7 W. 83 St., N.Y. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Larry's memory may be made to The University of Wisconsin Foundation, c/o The Center for Jewish Studies, 1848 University Ave, Madison, WI 53708-1319.

title: Well-Ordered Lunchboxes, for the Home or Office
description: The term ''bento box'' is as redundant as ''pizza pie.'' In Japan a bento is a box, usually black lacquer and fitted with small compartments for assorted foods. Bentos have become familiar items at restaurants and take-out shops, and now you can have one delivered to your desk.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on June 17 about the use of natural light in building design misidentified one state in which researchers studied the effects of lighting on student performance. Besides California and Colorado, the study was carried out in Washington State, not Massachusetts.

title: Warning on Artery Stent Cites Some Cases of Clots
description: Johnson & Johnson sent a letter to doctors on Monday night advising them about rare cases of life-threatening blood clots linked to its new drug-coated stent, a fast-selling device used to keep blood flowing through the arteries.

title: Who Needs the Sommelier, Anyway? Just Try Wines From the Next Table
description: Walk into Montrachet, 239 West Broadway (White Street), on a Monday night and you might think a party is going on. A party for wine lovers. Some customers even offer tastes of their wines to fellow diners. The members of the restaurant's wine team, including Daniel Johnnes, above, the wine director, ease corks out of 40-year-old Burgundies and decant first-growth Bordeaux -- all of them brought in by the customers themselves.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Threatened Shellfish
description: The state, a leading oyster and clam producer, has a record number of counties with shellfish areas that may be closed because of pollution. Wayne Clifford, a State Department of Health adviser, said the survey of fecal bacteria in shellfish beds indicated that 44 of the state's 314 shellfish companies could have their harvesting areas closed if water quality keeps deteriorating. Farm animal waste runoff and sewer discharges are main sources of pollution, he said. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Consumer Debt Rises, Led by Credit Cards
description: Consumer debt rose in May as shoppers made more purchases on their credit cards, according to Federal Reserve statistics released in Washington yesterday.

title: An Outcast on Fire in Rio's Underworld
description: ''I'm a queen by choice,'' the defiant title character of ''Madame Sat'' furiously retorts to a gay-baiting drunk in the dingy Rio de Janiero bar where he has just driven a packed house into a euphoric frenzy with an extravagant drag performance. ''It doesn't make me less of a man.''

title: Rumsfeld Estimates U.S. Monthly Costs in Iraq at $3.9 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, July 9  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld estimated today that the cost of United States operations in Iraq were $3.9 billion a month  a figure considerably higher than previous estimates  as he testified today before senators who want other countries to absorb more of the coalition's human and financial costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DENTON, , JOHN WARD
description: DENTON--John Ward. Died July 5th, 2003 after a brief illness at the age of 42. He was a prominent member of the Ralph Lauren Design Department for over 10 years before starting Denton & Gardner Limited in 1995. After working as an interior designer in Paris and London, he opened his first store in Soho, NY in August 2001 and his second store in Bridgehampton, NY in April 2003. He is survived by his sister Nancy Poorman, his devoted partner of 15 years Christopher Gardner, and his beloved dog, Peter. To acknowledge all the joy Peter has brought him, it is suggested that memorial donations be sent to Peter's shelter, The Center for Animal Care and Control, 11 Park Place, Room 805, New York, NY 10007. His kindness, wit and passion for style and design inspired all who crossed his path. We all grieve the inconceivable loss of a true original. >>AD#

title: Too Hot to Cook? With Sancerre, Leave the Fluke Raw
description: BRING a glass of Sancerre to your lips and it won't be shy. Passion fruit and citrus might tickle your nose. Minerals and flint may strike. Sometimes a bit of mint leaps out of the glass, too, always to some surprise.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CORP., Portland, Ore., the biggest North American maker of paneling for floors and roofs, agreed to sell 465,000 acres of forest in Texas for $285 million to reduce debt.

title: Boston Church Leader Hires Lawyer Known for Settlements
description: Bishop Sean P. O'Malley, who will assume control of the Archdiocese of Boston this month, has hired a lawyer known for swiftly settling sexual abuse cases to advise him on the nearly 500 legal claims pending against the archdiocese. The move buoyed plaintiffs' lawyers, who have been working to resolve the cases for more than a year.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Researcher Joins Hewlett-Packard
description: David P. Reed, an early innovator of personal computing and the Internet, has joined Hewlett-Packard Laboratories as a researcher, the company said yesterday. Dr. Reed's arrival at Hewlett-Packard Labs comes as the company is trying to bolster its ranks of research scientists to give it an edge in a market increasingly dominated by low-cost PC makers like Dell Computer. Dr. Reed said he was drawn to the labs because of its span of interests and customers. Dr. Reed, who holds graduate degrees in computer science and engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will continue his work on wireless networking and collaborative computing. Most recently, he was a member of a Federal Communications Commission group looking at the radio frequency spectrum. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: OFF THE MENU
description: More Wild Edibles

title: Excerpts From Bush's News Conference in South Africa
description: Following are President Bush's statements on Iraq at a news conference on Wednesday in Pretoria, South Africa, as transcribed by the Federal News Service:

title: Watchdog Groups Push Anew For More Disclosure in Albany
description: With the latest effort to tighten the state's lobbying laws having failed in the last moments of the legislative session, government watchdog groups today began a new push for changes meant to shine light on Albany's inner workings.

title: South Korea Issues Report on North Korean Explosions
description: SEOUL, July 9  North Korea has conducted at least 70 "high-explosive tests" of devices used in nuclear warheads at a site about 25 miles northwest of its main nuclear complex in Yongbyon, South Korea said in an intelligence report released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARSON, , PATRICIA GRIMES (BUNNY)
description: GARSON -- Patricia Grimes (Bunny), 80, of New York, NY and Deal, NJ, passed away peacefully at home in NY on July 6th. Born and raised in New York, she was married lovingly to Arthur Garson for 51 years. She was a beautiful, dignified and caring woman. Among her charitable activities were her service on the Boards of RSVPI (Retired Senior Volunteer Program International) which she cofounded with her adored husband; and Camp Oakhurst. She was an active supporter of the NYC Ballet and volunteered at Lenox Hill Hospital. She is survived by her children: Kathleen Frank, Susan Taylor, Thomas Garson and Dr. Arthur Garson, Jr.; her grandchildren: Holly Youngwood, Whitney and Devin Taylor, Michael and Thomas Garson, Jr., and Lauren and Kathleen Garson; and three great-grandchildren. The family will receive visitors from 5-8 PM on July 9th at Frank Campbell's, Madison Ave. and 81st St. Interment is private. Donations in her memory may be made to RSVPI (c/o University of Maryland Department of Aging); Camp Oakhurst (Oakhurst, NJ); Dystonia Medical Research Foundation (Chicago, IL).

title: Sports of The Times; Pain Defines the Tour de France
description: LAST Saturday, Venus Williams evoked a few snickers from some sports fans after the Wimbledon final when she said that she had been taught by her parents not to play with pain. That is surely a worthy value for a young athlete, but it is not exactly observed in the hard-core world of professional sports.

title: Bush Defends War, Sidestepping Issue of Faulty Intelligence
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, July 9  President Bush brushed aside questions today about the accuracy of a piece of evidence he used to justify war with Iraq, saying he was "absolutely confident" he made the right decision to use military force to remove Saddam Hussein from power.

title: 2 Spending Bills For the Military Advance in Congress
description: The House approved another increase in military spending tonight while the Senate advanced a measure that provides the Pentagon with a nearly identical $369 billion next year for an array of new hardware, personnel needs and continued research into a missile defense system.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Auto Growth
description: The German automaker Volkswagen announced plans to nearly double manufacturing capacity in China within five years. Company officials said they would expand existing facilities and possibly add new factories at joint ventures in Shanghai and Changchun to reach a sales goal of more than a million cars annually by 2007. Volkswagen and its local partners account for 40 percent of China's fast-growing car market and the expansion is viewed as an attempt to defend its market share. But some analysts believe that the auto production is increasing too quickly for the market to absorb, with most major automakers simultaneously increasing production. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: Seeking Help With a Crisis, Zimbabweans Go to Pretoria
description: The attention of Zimbabweans is being diverted south this week as President Bush holds talks in Pretoria with the South African president, Thabo Mbeki, that will surely include discussion of the political crisis in Zimbabwe.

title: Democrats Lay Down Lines For Looming Medicare Fight
description: Senate Democrats set the stage today for a possible showdown with conservative House Republicans over legislation adding prescription drug benefits to Medicare.

title: Blair Denies Misleading M.P.'s, Saying 'We Did the Right Thing'
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair firmly denied today that he had manipulated intelligence or misled Parliament to go to war.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 27 about reactions to the Supreme Court decision legalizing private sex acts between gays referred incorrectly to comments by Michael Henderson, deputy attorney general in Idaho, about the effect on a state law that forbids ''crimes against nature.'' He said the law could still be applied to public acts of sodomy, and to bestiality; he did not suggest that it would be applied specifically to public sex acts involving gays.

title: Fresh Muffins and Rich Tortes, A Long Time Coming
description: For a while, it seemed as if Blue Sky Bakery was just pie in the sky. The little spot at 53 Fifth Avenue (Bergen Street) in Park Slope, Brooklyn, looked ready for months, yet it did not open until Monday, almost a year after the owner, Erik Goetze, far left, a graphic designer, began the project. Along the way he lost his pastry-maker partner and wound up doing most of the construction himself.

title: Worker Charged With Stealing $77,000 From Floral Park Library
description: A former library employee on Long Island was accused in court yesterday of stealing more than $77,000 in library funds from the rental and sale of videos.

title: New Casualty in War of Words: Schrder's Vacation in Italy
description: BERLIN, July 9  Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany canceled a planned vacation in Italy today after an Italian minister described German tourists as arrogant, nationalistic boors who "invade Italy's beaches" every summer.

title: Twins Die Trying to Live Two Lives
description: They wanted to see each other face to face, they said, and to pursue independent lives. And so Ladan and Laleh Bijani, 29-year-old Iranian twins who were born joined at the head, asked doctors to go ahead with a risky operation to separate them.

title: Mascara As Black As a Jolly Roger
description: The action comedy ''Pirates of the Caribbean: Curse of the Black Pearl'' raises one of the most overlooked and important cinematic questions of our time: Can a movie maintain the dramatic integrity of a theme park ride?

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Hanaro Approves Sale Of New Shares
description: The high-speed Internet service provider Hanaro Telecom approved the sale of newly issued shares valued at 500 billion won ($424 million) to the LG Investment and Securities Company, the financial arm of the LG Group. The deal will give LG, which already owns 13 percent of Hanaro, a controlling stake. LG is in a position to form a telecommunications company that would include LG Telecom and Hanaro, and two other LG affiliates, Dacom and Powercomm. Hanaro would also be able to pay off 450 billion won in debt due by the end of the year. Hanaro's board approved the LG proposal after rejecting a bid by an alliance led by the American International Group to pay $450 million for control of the company. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GERSTEN, , ANNA
description: GERSTEN--Anna, age 105. Beloved wife of the late Sam Gersten. Cherished, loving mother of Gerald (Roz) and the late Lila Greene. Adored, wonderful grandmother to five and loving great-grandmother to ten. Helped manyloved by all. She will be sadly missed. Services Wednesday, 12PM, Riverside Chapel, Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y. >>AD#

title: Bishops and the Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Good Boll Weevil News
description: Over a century ago, the mighty boll weevil left its home in Mexico and began devouring cotton fields across the American South and West. Now, after 25 years of spraying and more sophisticated antiweevil weaponry, the federal Department of Agriculture has finally forced this wily little beetle into submission. For many in the weevil's range -- and indeed for the struggling cotton industry -- this may be better news than another farm subsidy. It is certainly more satisfying emotionally. For years the farmers of the South and Southwest have struggled with a devastating natural plague that seemed to come straight out of the Book of Exodus.

title: Overtime Regulations
description: To the Editor:

title: McGreevey Tells Utility To Explain Blackouts
description: After three days of sporadic electricity failures that hampered businesses and angered residents on the central Jersey Shore, Gov. James E. McGreevey stepped into the fray yesterday, voicing his own impatience and asking the local power company to explain how it would end the blackouts.

title: Ex-Bonnies Coach Joins Maine Staff
description: Billy McCaffrey, a former coach in the troubled basketball program at St. Bonaventure, was named yesterday as an assistant coach at the University of Maine.

title: P.G.A. Championship Gets Early Welcome
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey yesterday welcomed to New Jersey the 2005 P.G.A. Championship at Baltusrol Golf Club.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SPINA, , MARY A.
description: SPINA--Mary A. Today is your birthday. In our hearts you remain forever. J.S.S. and Famil

title: New Jersey Panel Approves First Bear Hunt in 33 Years
description: The New Jersey Fish and Game Council brushed aside the objections of a lone dissenting member today to approve the state's first bear hunt in 33 years, to be held in December.

title: After Lyrical Serenade, Popping The Question
description: Forget tranquilizers. If you want to curb your anxiety on one of the biggest nights of your professional life, try scheduling something even bigger to take place immediately afterward.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Same-Sex Marriages In The West
description: The British Columbia Court of Appeal opened the way for gays to marry in the province by ending a one-year moratorium on same-sex marriages, making British Columbia the second province after Ontario to allow them. The court had ruled in favor of extending marriage rights but had imposed the moratorium to give the federal government time to change its laws. The federal government is preparing legislation to allow same-sex marriages nationwide; it is expected to pass in Parliament in the fall. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: COLORADO: COLLEGE ADMISSIONS AND RACE Gov. Bill Owens said he would support and sign legislation to bar race from being a factor in college admissions in the state. Governor Owens, left, a Republican, was answering a question on a radio show when he said he opposed quotas and "regrets the Supreme Court decision" last month. Though there had been no legislation drafted for the 2004 session, Senator Jim Dyer, also a Republican, rushed to draft the first bill to restrict the use of race in admission to Colorado universities. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: A Wine Award That Seems Easy To Come By
description: FOR wine drinkers around the country, finding a restaurant with a Wine Spectator award has become a reassuring sign. It has come to mean that the restaurant's wine list, wine service and wine storage have been held up to the discerning light of one of some of the nation's most well-respected wine critics, and that it has triumphed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOEB, , JIMMY
description: LOEB--Jimmy. His former colleagues at Gray, Seifert & Co., Inc. mourn the death of Jimmy Loeb, our longtime associate and friend, who enlivened all around him with his quick wit, impish charm and tireless and enduring friendship. We offer our affection and condolences to his wife Priscilla, his children and grandchildren, and we thank Jimmy for his example of life well and enthusiastically lived. He will be sorely missed. >>AD#

title: Reading, Writing and Special Attention in Queens
description: Finding the special education students in Marilyn Murphy's first-grade class is challenging.

title: What Iraq Needs Now
description: Some day, we Iraqis hope to celebrate an Independence Day like the one Americans have just observed. But for the near future we face the challenge of translating liberation into democracy -- a goal we Kurds will push for even more diligently now that we have agreed to join the interim Iraqi administration that will be formed this month. To that end, we will work closely with the United States to establish security, revive the economy and build a democratic culture.

title: General Urges Foreigners to Aid Afghans
description: The former top American general in Afghanistan warned today that the nation's recovery was imperiled unless the international community takes bolder steps in the rebuilding efforts there.

title: Court Blocks Effort to Protect Secret Cheney Files
description: A divided federal appeals court dealt a blow today to the Bush administration's efforts to keep information about Vice President Dick Cheney's energy task force secret.

title: Pechiney Dismisses $3.85 Billion Hostile Bid From Alcan, a Rival
description: The board of Pechiney of France dismissed a hostile 3.4 billion-euro ($3.85 billion) bid from its rival, Alcan, yesterday saying it was too low and would not win antitrust approval from the European Commission.

title: Democrats Counterattack on Malpractice Issue
description: About to be pushed by Republican leaders into an uncomfortable vote against capping medical malpractice awards, Senate Democrats joined today with a freshman Republican, Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, to strike back with a malpractice bill of their own.

title: Liberians Welcome U.S. Team Joyously, Down to Dancing in the Streets
description: American soldiers here to assess the extent of the nation's human crisis met cheering, dancing mobs everywhere they went today and listened to the cries of people declaring the demise of the embattled Liberian president, Charles Taylor. At one point, though, the Americans had to turn back because a government official was upset that protocol had not been followed.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: The Tobacco Lobby
description: The tobacco industry has spent nearly $1.7 million lobbying the Maryland legislature since 1997, Common Cause reported. Philip Morris paid the most for lobbying, $649,000, while the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company paid $334,972, and the Cigar Association of America, $217,933, the nonprofit group said in a report. The group said contributions to candidates for statewide office in the 1998 and 2002 elections from tobacco companies and what it called allies -- including restaurant, alcohol and retail organizations -- totaled more than $360,000. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Different Cities, Different Security for Buildings
description: The 50-story Trammell Crow Center in downtown Dallas, where the giant real estate company of the same name has its headquarters, is known for its glass pyramid top and its plaza with bronze works by Rodin and other French sculptors.

title: Well-Ordered Lunchboxes, for the Home or Office
description: The term "bento box" is as redundant as "pizza pie." In Japan a bento is a box, usually black lacquer and fitted with small compartments for assorted foods. Bentos have become familiar items at restaurants and take-out shops, and now you can have one delivered to your desk.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: PARKS DEPARTMENT BIAS SUIT ADVANCES A federal court judge has ruled that employees of the city's Parks and Recreation Department who are accusing the department of bias qualify for class-action status, a decision that could widen the case's impact if the plaintiffs win. On Monday, Judge Denny Chin ruled the plaintiffs qualified for class-action certification because the allegations were common to all of them "regardless of civil service rank, title, provisional status, or collective bargaining agreement." In 2001, 11 present and former employees, all Hispanic or black, filed a bias lawsuit. It accused the department of passing over qualified members of minority groups for promotions and also of maintaining a special program that, the plaintiffs charged, cultivated white people for management positions. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Terror in Chechnya, And in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Microsoft to Award Stock, Not Options, to Employees

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: West Nile Virus Victim
description: An elderly man from Oconee County is the first in the nation to test positive for the West Nile Virus this year, the Department of Health and Environmental Control said. Officials said he was infected when bitten by mosquitoes while fishing in June. Tests conducted by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention confirmed the presence of the virus. A department spokeswoman, Claire Boatman, said the man has recovered. The virus was first detected in New York four years ago. It had spread to California and reached Canada by 2002.

title: Intervening in Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Kills 5 Co-Workers at Plant and Himself
description: An assembly-line worker who had talked openly about shooting people walked out of an ethics and sensitivity training session at his factory this morning, returned moments later with a semiautomatic rifle and a shotgun, and opened fire, killing five co-workers before fatally shooting himself, the authorities and witnesses said.

title: The Best A Beet Can Hope For
description: BORSCHT is the highest and best use for a beet. Quick to cook (at least in my version), easy to vary, loved by almost everyone -- even children -- borscht is the archetypical midsummer soup, and belongs in everyone's repertory.

title: Why Mexico's Political Machine Keeps Chugging
description: Only three years after losing its authoritarian grip on the Mexican presidency, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, proved in elections this past weekend that it remains a force in Mexican politics, winning a slim majority in crucial elections for the lower Chamber of Deputies.

title: Manager Confirms Suicide Report
description: The manager of the Turkish hotel where Roman Lyashenko, a member of the Rangers' organization, was found dead on Sunday, today confirmed a report by a law-enforcement official that the hockey player had committed suicide.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Jackson's New Office
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson is to open a satellite office of his Rainbow/PUSH Coalition in Benton Harbor, Mich., the site of several nights of rioting after the death of a black motorcyclist who was being chased by the police when he crashed into a wall. The chapter, which is likely to be open by the end of summer, will serve as a liaison for the community, elected officials and clergymen. The Rainbow/PUSH Coalition is based in Chicago. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: CALENDAR
description: New West Side Greenmarket

title: U.S. Court Backs Ban on Beef Farmers' Fee
description: A federal appeals court ruled yesterday that cattle ranchers are deprived of their free-speech rights by a law that requires them to finance advertising campaigns.

title: Blood, Sweat and Tears. Lots of Tears.
description: In the 1992 film ''A League of Their Own,'' Tom Hanks portrayed the manager of a women's baseball team who told a weeping player, ''There's no crying in baseball!'' It's one of the great lines of a good movie. And if it was once true, it certainly is no longer.

title: A Lost Surgical Gamble
description: In the path of medical research there are complicated forks in the road that raise ethical questions. Patients, with the advice of their doctors, must decide whether to brave new medical procedures that may result in death, or continue living lives they do not want. Ladan and Laleh Bijani, 29-year-old Iranian sisters born joined at the head, chose the first route. Despite their courage and the exhaustive efforts of an international team of specialists, they died of blood loss yesterday after being surgically separated.

title: Kidd, Back in New Jersey, Is Drawing Closer to the Spurs
description: Jason Kidd and his wife, Joumana, returned to New Jersey from a lavish 26-hour recruiting visit to San Antonio late Monday, laden with a $94 million maximum offer and visions of winning a championship. The Spurs' presentation was so persuasive that Kidd was leaning toward signing with the N.B.A champions, according to three people with intimate knowledge of the Nets.

title: Terror in Chechnya, And in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Science and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Host in Germany Resigns Jewish Posts
description: FRANKFURT, July 8  One of Germany's most visible Jewish leaders, Michel Friedman, has resigned from his official posts and agreed to pay a fine after being found in possession of cocaine.

title: J.P. MORGAN UNIT TO RESUME LEASING CARS IN RHODE ISLAND
description: J. P. Morgan Chase & Company said it would lease cars again in Rhode Island because the governor was scheduled to sign a law limiting liability for auto-leasing companies. Leases will be offered to dealers and residents whose lease terms do not exceed 39 months through its Chase Manhattan Automotive Finance unit, the company said. The bank may have to stop leasing next July if the law is not permanent, it said. J.P. Morgan stopped writing leases in Rhode Island last October after a court awarded $28 million against the bank. The unit left the New York market July 1 because of a similar law that allows auto accident victims to sue leasing companies.

title: Shelter Operator Threatens Evictions in Contract Fight
description: A financial impasse between New York City and one of the companies that operates homeless shelters led yesterday to a threat to eject more than 300 families from shelters in Queens and the Bronx.

title: Whatanartist Draws No. 4 For the Meadowlands Pace
description: Whatanartist drew a decent post position today and was quickly made a favorite for the $1 million Meadowlands Pace on Saturday, but Jim Campbell, the horse's trainer, suggested that fans come to the track anyway.

title: Harry Potter's Magic, for Some (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 30 about the scarcity of American merchants at a French wine fair in Bordeaux misstated the surname of the co-owner of Smith Haut Lafitte, one of the region's premier vineyards. She is Florence Cathiard, not Chartrier.

title: Treasures at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAPERSTEIN, , LEAH
description: SAPERSTEIN--Leah. Temple Beth Am, Merrick, mourns the death of the wife of our beloved Rabbi Emeritus, Sanford E. Saperstein. Rebbitzin for 27 years. Burial from Temple Beth Israel, Longboat Key, FL. Tuesday PM She will be sorely missed. >>AD#

title: Phony Charities Tap Into AIDS Money for Africa
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 9  The Neema Children's Center has disappeared into thin air, authorities here say, and so have other groups that claim to be fighting AIDS in this African capital.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Hitachi Cuts Stake
description: The electronics maker Hitachi Ltd. sold a 17.6 percent stake in the Nitto Denko Corporation, a maker of components for liquid-crystal displays. The sale raised about 120 billion yen ($1 billion) based on Nitto Denko's closing price yesterday and leaves Hitachi with a 3.1 percent share. Hitachi joins rivals like Fujitsu and the NEC Corporation, which have also been unloading stakes in subsidiaries to raise cash for new investments and reduce debt levels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KINDLEBERGER, , CHARLES P.
description: KINDLEBERGER--Charles P. In loving memory of Charles P. Kindleberger, a scholar of rare ability and integrity. A great human being and a glorious friend for sixty years. Barbara and Peter Bernstein >>AD#

title: A Rich Nation, A Poor Continent
description: At a time when President Bush has lavished billions of dollars in tax cuts on the richest Americans, his trip to Africa presents him with the perfect opportunity to call on them to take some responsibility for the dire state of the world's poorest citizens. According to a recent report from the Internal Revenue Service, some 400 super-rich Americans had an average income of nearly $174 million each, or a combined income of $69 billion, in 2000. Incredibly, that's more than the combined incomes of the 166 million people living in four of the countries that the president is visiting this week: Nigeria, Senegal, Uganda and Botswana. America's richest individuals could actually change the course of Africa's history, and the president -- who has stressed the importance of personal responsibility -- should urge them to do so.

title: LIGHTSTONE TO BUY OPERATOR OF RETAIL OUTLET CENTERS
description: Lightstone Group, a closely held real estate company, agreed to buy Prime Retail Inc., which owns and operates outlet retail centers, for $115 million in cash and the assumption of $523 million in debt. Lightstone will pay 18 cents for each share of Prime Retail's common stock, Prime Retail, based in Baltimore, said. The offer values Prime Retail at 50 percent more than its closing price of 12 cents a share yesterday in over-the-counter trading. Lightstone, of Lakewood, N.J., will acquire retail centers in 9 states in addition to the 12 where it already operates, the chief executive, David Lichtenstein, said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Woman's Body Found In Apartment
description: City marshals carrying out an eviction order yesterday at an apartment in Queens found the decomposed body of a woman who had been dead for some time, the police said yesterday. It was not immediately clear whether the dead woman was the one set to be evicted. She had been dead for at least two months, so it was impossible to determine her race or other identifying characteristics, the police said. City marshals found the body in the bedroom of the apartment at 22-07 19th Street in Astoria about 12:20 p.m., the police said. There were no signs of forced entry and the apartment did not appear to be in disarray, investigators said. The medical examiner will perform an autopsy to determine the cause of death, the police said. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Baby, It's Cold Inside For These Lucky Few
description: It was 88 degrees in Central Park by quitting time, and even upstate New York was sweltering, but a handful of lucky people had to wear sweaters or even parkas to work yesterday. In fact, their warm clothing never goes to the back of the closet. Their jobs require a certain amount of chilling out, but it was not hard for them to warm up after work, as the heat index, a combined measure of heat and humidity, was 95 in New York City, according to the National Weather Service.

title: American Cars Show Gains In a Survey of Dependability
description: Mercedes-Benz has fallen behind its sister brand Chrysler in a closely watched report on vehicle dependability, while General Motors has surged. And Japanese vehicles continue, over all, to hold up the best.

title: Earlier Shuttle Flight Had Gas Enter Wing on Return
description: The space shuttle Columbia was not the first to have superheated gas invade its left wing on re-entering Earth's atmosphere, according to documents released yesterday by NASA.

title: STATE STREET CORP. SAYS 3,100 VOLUNTEER FOR SEVERANCE
description: The State Street Corporation said yesterday that 3,100 employees had taken voluntary severance, exceeding its goal of 1,800. The company, which provides administrative services like daily pricing of mutual funds to financial services companies, said it would take a charge of $296 million, or 58 cents a share, when it announces its second-quarter earnings next week. Excluding the charge, State Street said it expected to report improved operating results in the second quarter. The company, based in Boston, plans to add 800 to 1,000 employees over the next year after those taking the severance depart.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 26 about sewer sludge that is reprocessed as a fertilizer misstated the position of organic farmers on its use. They do not prefer it over chemical fertilizers, and in fact agree with Department of Agriculture regulations that prohibit its use for organic farming.

title: A German Union Takes Stock
description: The leaders of Germany's most formidable labor union, IG Metall, gathered today in Frankfurt to sift through the wreckage of an aborted strike last month in eastern Germany.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHEPPS, , HOWARD ZVI
description: SHEPPS--Howard Zvi 1 Sep 1953 - 9 July 1992 Dearly Loved Always Remembered >>AD#

title: 7 G.I.'s Wounded in 3 Violent Incidents in Iraq
description: Seven G.I.'s were wounded today in three violent episodes in northern and central Iraq, and Middle Eastern television stations broadcast a new audiotape in which a voice supposedly that of Saddam Hussein urged Iraqis to resist occupying forces.

title: Planning a Legacy in Venice for a 60's Art Movement
description: ''I don't feel like I'm supposed to die in three months,'' Emily Harvey, the art dealer, said recently by telephone from New York just after a chemotherapy treatment for pancreatic cancer.

title: Young Pitcher No Match For Braves
description: Jason Roach sat at the folding table in the middle of the Mets' clubhouse yesterday afternoon, peering into a laptop computer as he took mental notes on video of the Braves' hitters, his assignment that night. Behind him was an eager audience. The Brooklyn Cyclones were touring their parent club's locker room at Shea Stadium -- ''Wow,'' one player said -- and a handful were watching Roach use big-league technology.

title: Payton to Sign With Lakers
description: Aaron Goodwin, the agent for the All-Star guard Gary Payton, last night confirmed a report that Payton has agreed to sign with the Los Angeles Lakers as a free agent.

title: Japanese Traditions,  la Franaise
description: DOES Japan need truffle oil? Where you stand on the question will probably determine how much you like Yujin, a bold, fitfully successful experiment in modernizing traditional Japanese food by using French techniques and non-Asian ingredients.

title: Pork Rinds You Can Grind On
description: Street life and street food have melded in an exhibition opening Friday at the New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway (Houston Street) in SoHo. ''The Brotherhood,'' by Jos Antonio Hernndez-Diez, consists of skateboards made from fried pork rinds. The wheels come from actual skateboards. The boards come from, well, pigs.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: July 8, 2003

title: Imported Foods Become Costlier As Euro Dominates the Dollar
description: PRESERVES and biscuits from France are going up in price. So are cheeses from Spain and prosciutto and pasta from Italy. The increases may amount to only 50 cents a pound wholesale for now, but retailers predict that if the euro remains strong against the dollar, consumers may begin to register sticker shock in the fall, especially around the holidays.

title: Traber Shuts Down Yankees
description: The Mets were prepared to offer Billy Traber $1.3 million when they drafted him with the 16th overall pick in the 2000 draft. But a routine magnetic resonance imaging showed damage to Traber's pitching elbow, and the Mets slashed their bonus offer to about $400,000. Traber signed anyway, and the next winter, he was traded to Cleveland in the deal for Roberto Alomar.

title: Incredible Shrinking Y
description: Why, oh Y, are men so insecure?

title: A Friendly Showdown Between Former Enemies
description: Five years ago Jay-Z became New York City's favorite rapper by telling everyone he couldn't be touched. Every song was a clever way of reminding listeners of how invulnerable he was. This year 50 Cent became New York City's favorite rapper by taking the opposite approach: he brags about his bullet wounds while reminding listeners that he may not survive the next attack.

title: Laos Releases 2 European Journalists and Aide
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 9  Two European journalists and their American interpreter were released by Laos today after being sentenced to 15 years in prison during a two-hour trial that one of them called "a mockery of justice."

title: Bishops and the Scandal (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 3 Convicted Of Gang-Related Murder
description: A federal jury has convicted the leaders of a gang that terrorized East Tremont of ordering the killing of a renegade gang member. The gang, the Hughes Boys, was said to control most of the street sales of drugs in that area. The gang leaders, identified as Angel Cordero and Ricardo Delvi, along with the gunman, Edgar Marino Sanchez, were convicted Monday of killing Earl Edwards, 19. Prosecutors said Mr. Cordero and Mr. Delvi offered to pay $5,000 for the murder of any members who were part of a breakaway faction. Prosecutors said Mr. Sanchez shot Mr. Edwards seven times on a Bronx street corner. All three men face a mandatory sentence of life in prison. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Floods Force Evacuations
description: About 400,000 people were evacuated in Anhui Province, and engineers blasted a giant hole in a swelling dike as authorities worked to contain the worst flooding on the Huai River in more than a decade. Thirteen people have died in the flooding, the official New China News Agency said. While economic losses were estimated at nearly $1 billion, officials said new defenses had succeeded in greatly reducing deaths and damage. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: Red Sox Top Blue Jays On Varitek's Single in 12th
description: Jason Varitek hit a go-ahead single in the 12th inning last night, leading Boston over host Toronto, 2-1.

title: All Those Pretty Bodies, All That Fruitless Talk
description: ''Confusion of Genders'' was shown as part of the New Directors/New Films series in 2001. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 28, 2001; the full text is at nytimes.com/movies. The film, in French with English subtitles, opens today at the Quad Cinema, 34 West 13th Street, Greenwich Village.

title: Disabled Woman Dies While Trying to Escape Fire
description: A 42-year-old disabled Brooklyn woman died in a house fire early yesterday, trapped in her burning ground-floor apartment behind two layers of metal window bars, fire officials said.

title: On Horseback Along the Border, Hunting Ticks
description: Patrol the banks of the Rio Grande on horseback six hours a day. Speak Spanish and carry a pistol. Beware of smugglers. Spend 80 percent of your time alone, looking for ticks. Starting salary: $22,500 a year plus a horse.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Shipments To Start
description: A consortium headed by ChevronTexaco that owns a pipeline that ships oil from Kazakhstan to the Russian port of Novorossiisk, said it was preparing to take the first delivery of Russian crude. The group, called the Caspian Pipeline Consortium, signed an agreement with KalmTEK, a state-owned Russian company, to ship the Russian oil through its network. The group did not specify exactly when the shipment would be made. It said the agreement would bring the start of Russian oil flowing through the network, which currently carries only crude from Kazakhstan, even though it runs through Russian territory.

title: Counseling at Phillips, And Its Consequences
description: PHILLIPS ACADEMY is one of America's most prestigious boarding schools, known for educating the rich and mighty (both President Bushes are graduates) and sending a third of them to Ivy League colleges. Even on this fiercely competitive campus, Cathy Rampell -- an A student with perfect 1600 SAT's and a weekly column in the student paper -- stood out.

title: Conversing On the Arts By Clicking A Mouse

title: Vaccines for Adults
description: Most adults ensure that their children are vaccinated against childhood diseases, but many neglect to get their own immunizations. Even those who are well informed about health do not seem to know that adults, too, need vaccines. Nearly 50,000 adults die in America each year from vaccine-preventable diseases. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that these illnesses cost society $10 billion a year. Reaching adults with vaccines takes creative thinking, but it can be done, as has been shown by France and other countries with effective adult vaccination programs.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: OIL SHIPMENTS TO START A consortium headed by ChevronTexaco that owns a pipeline that ships oil from Kazakhstan to the Russian port of Novorossiisk, said it was preparing to take the first delivery of Russian crude. The group, called the Caspian Pipeline Consortium, signed an agreement with KalmTEK, a state-owned Russian company, to ship the Russian oil through its network. The group did not specify exactly when the shipment would be made. It said the agreement would bring the start of Russian oil flowing through the network, which currently carries only crude from Kazakhstan, even though it runs through Russian territory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAIL, , PRISCILLA L.
description: VAIL--Priscilla L., an educator active in the fields of learning disabilities, dyslexia and the education of the gifted, died July 6, 2003 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital at the age of 71. Death was due to cancer. Priscilla Luke Vail was born in New York City to Mr. and Mrs. David L. Luke. She attended the Spence and Brearley Schools and graduated from the Mary C. Wheeler School in Providence, RI in the Class of 1949. Before her marriage, she attended Vassar College from 1949-1951. She earned her BA and MAT from Manhattanville College, Purchase, NY in 1973 and 1974, at which time she joined the faculty of the Rippowam-Cisqua School where she had been a parent and long-time trustee. While working full time at Rippowam-Cisqua, she wrote and published 9 books, and numerous articles for such professional journals as NAIS and the Orton Dyslexia Society. A frequent presenter at educational conferences both here and abroad, she spoke at individual schools and school systems, and at such institutions as the Principals' Center at Harvard, Cambridge University in England, the British Dyslexia Society and York University, York, England. She continued an active professional life, teaching, writing and consulting until the time of her death. She received the Outstanding Educator of the Year award from the NY branch of the Orton Dyslexia Society in 1987 and her book, ''Smart Kids with School Problems: Things to Know and Ways to Help,'' received the Margot Marek Book Award in 1990. She was a founding trustee of the Fisher Landau Foundation for Gifted Learning Disabled Students. In 1998 she received the Samuel T. Orton Award, the highest award given by the International Dyslexia Association. A 50 year resident of Bedford, NY and a 40 year summer resident of Stonington, CT, she was active in community affairs and was a lay reader and chalice bearer at St. Matthew's Church. Among other board assignments, she served on the Education Committee of the Mystic Seaport Museum, and was the non-resident education director of the Hallowell Clinic for Cognitive and Emotional Health in Concord, MA. She was married for 50 years to Donald Vail, who predeceased her. She is survived by four children, Melissa Vail Selby, Polly Vail Walsh, Lucia Vail & Donald Angus Vail and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, NY on Thursday at 4:30PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the International Dyslexia Assoc, 8600 LaSalle Road, Chester Bldg, Suite 382, Towson, MD. 21286.

title: PRESIDENT OF KRAFT'S NORTH AMERICAN BUSINESS LEAVES
description: Kraft Foods said the president of its North American business, Irene B. Rosenfeld, has left after less than a year in the position. Ms. Rosenfeld, 50, left to pursue other opportunities, the company said. title: Man Sought in Killings Surrenders, but Is Freed

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
