Khodorkovsky, left, Russian authorities began investigating accusations of tax evasion at Mr. Khodorkovsky's flagship oil company, Yukos Oil. The general prosecutor's office began reviewing charges by a deputy in the Russian Parliament that Yukos, Russia's biggest oil company, did not pay all its taxes last year. The authorities have been investigating companies associated with Mr. Khodorkovsky, but this was the first time the inquiries touched Yukos, which is popular among foreign investors. title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Genentech Returns To Profit
description: Genentech, the biotechnology company, said it returned to a profit in the latest quarter after sales of its cancer drugs Herceptin and Rituxan climbed. Second-quarter net income was $132.3 million, or 25 cents a share, in contrast to a net loss of $213.6 million, or 41 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Genentech had additional costs in 2002 after losing a court case. Sales rose 29 percent, to $799.7 million, from $622.2 million, the company said. Shares of Genentech, whose majority owner is the Swiss drug maker Roche Holding, rose 89 cents, to $77.38.

title: DEPOSIT IN SMOKING CASE WEIGHS ON ALTRIA
description: Shares of the Altria Group fell 6 percent yesterday on concern an Illinois court might reinstate a $12 billion deposit the company was required to pay to appeal a legal judgment. The judgment found a unit of the company liable for misleading smokers with deceptive cigarette advertisements. Appeals court judges in Illinois yesterday questioned whether the judge who presided over the suit against the Philip Morris USA unit had the power to cut the bond to $6.8 billion. Philip Morris, which was required to post a bond to appeal a $10.1 billion verdict in the so-called light cigarette case, said the larger deposit could force it to seek bankruptcy protection. Shares of Altria, based in New York, dropped $2.77, to $44, in New York Stock Exchange composite trading.

title: Behind the Scenes, Via Movie Web Sites
description: SUMMER is blockbuster season, and with scores of new movies opening between Memorial Day and Labor Day, the Web is teeming with all things film. Of course there are reviews, showtimes and ticket purchases. But beyond the basics is a world of sites from movie studios, independent filmmakers, celebrities and the fans who keep the industry in business. These range from official sites with video trailers, carefully edited gossip and behind-the-scene photographs, to downloadable screensavers, to modest but impassioned fan sites devoted to talents large and small.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway Selling PC'S At Military Base Stores
description: Gateway, the personal computer maker, is selling discounted personal computers to United States military personnel through base stores under an agreement with the Army and Air Force Exchange Service. Stores on 52 bases in the United States are offering four Gateway models. ''It has already been a multimillion-dollar business for us in the last couple of months,'' said Steve McAllister, vice president and general manager for alternate channels at Gateway. Gateway is trying to increase sales and regain profitability after losses in 9 of the last 10 quarters.

description: Helen of Troy Ltd., which sells Vidal Sassoon and Dr. Scholl's brand personal-care products, said yesterday that quarterly profit more than doubled as sales increased to international and professional customers.

title: Tiny Rotating Microphone Records a Voice in a Crowd
description: Pocket-size digital recorders are great for preserving your thoughts, giving dictation and recording interviews, but these recordings can be hard to understand if you make them in noisy surroundings or record several people talking at once. If the recording is stereophonic, though, a listener can more easily focus on one sound among many. The ICD-ST10 from Sony, little larger than two matchbooks end to end, has a built-in stereo microphone that rotates 90 degrees to face the sound source, plus jacks for stereo earphones (which are supplied) and an external stereo microphone.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Computer Horizons Buys RGII Technologies
description: The Computer Horizons Corporation, a computer-network services company, acquired the closely held RGII Technologies for about $21 million, to add contracts with the government. Investors in RGII will receive another $10 million over the next three years if the company meets certain profit estimates, said William J. Murphy, Computer Horizons' chief executive. RGII had sales of more than $33 million last year, with about half of that from Defense Department contracts. Computer Horizons is itself the target of a hostile takeover offer made by Aquent, a closely held technology consulting company based in Boston.

The agency cited falling domestic consumption and investments in the first six months of the year. The country's economy grow 6.3 percent last year. The economy grew by 2.4 percent in the second quarter of this year, down from 3.7 percent in the first quarter, according to the institute. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Caterer's Revenue Falls
description: The catering company Sodexho Alliance said its revenue fell 7.8 percent, to 9.1 billion euros ($10.3 billion), in the first nine months of its fiscal year, raising concern that it would be unable to meet its financial target for the full year. The company said that the euro's appreciation against other currencies in the last nine months reduced revenue by 10.4 percent, but excluding currency factors, its sales rose by 2.9 percent. Sodexho also said its full-year profit, excluding one-time factors, was not likely to exceed the 200 million euros ($227 million) it previously forecast, and its stock fell 3.5 percent. description: PUGLISI--Rev. Msgr. Guy J., Ph.D. On July 8, 2003. Devoted son of Catherine (nee Corcoran) and the late Salvatore J. Beloved brother of Sister Stephen Mary, CSJ. Monsignor was the Vicar for Education, the Superintendent of Schools for the Diocese of Brooklyn, a graduate from the School of Education at Fordham University and the Chaplain at Bishop Ford H.S. title: Rangers Player Was Unhappy in U.S.
description: The Russian hockey player Roman Lyashenko was an ambitious young man, unhappy with his place in the United States and yearning to advance to the Rangers from their minor league team, Pyotr Vorobyov, his friend and former coach, said today in an interview.

title: BP SOLVAY POLYETHYLENE TO CLOSE TEXAS PLANT
description: BP Solvay Polyethylene North America, a plastics maker that is a joint venture of BP of Britain and Solvay of Belgium, said it was closing a Texas plant that makes polyethylene to replace it with cheaper production from a new factory. The company, based in Houston, will halt production at a factory in Deer Park, with the capacity to make 260 million pounds of polyethylene a year, as of the end of July, BP Solvay Polyethylene said. The output will be replaced by a new 700-million-pound plant in Cedar Bayou, also in Texas.

title: Power Failures Send Governor to the Beach
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey and his family planned a quiet Fourth of July weekend at the Jersey Shore, a tourist destination he and his wife have touted in television commercials that show them walking along the beach with their toddler daughter. But then the lights went off. And on, and off, from last Saturday through Monday.

title: Latest German Fad: Leasing Out the Subway
description: With smooth-running trains, bright, well-kept stations and a blissful lack of crowds, Frankfurt's subway is a pleasant surprise for people from more teeming cities.

title: Metro Matters; A Spat With Schools In the Middle
description: HE said she started it and she said he started it. She acted intemperately, and he is not forgiving. He said changes had to be made; she said attention had to be paid. They are barely talking.

title: Clash, Then Synthesis: Joys of a Laptop Jam
description: IN his native West Virginia, George Cicci arouses curiosity when he gets on stage at local open-mike events and turns out beats on his iBook laptop between sets of bluegrass guitarists and rockabilly bands. While the crowd is always receptive to the innovative sounds he mixes, he says, he is still the only laptop musician around.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MASSACHUSETTS: BOSTON U. WANTS EX-NASA CHIEF Bos- ton University has offered its presidency to Daniel S. Goldin, who was the NASA administrator from 1992 to 2001. Mr. Goldin, left, has a bachelor's degree from the City College of New York and is a senior fellow at the Neurosciences Institute in San Diego. John Silber, the chancellor, has been interim president since last July, when Jon Westling resigned. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: ATP Overturns Suspension After Tainted Pills Are Found
description: The ATP, the governing body of men's tennis, announced yesterday that its trainers might have inadvertently given players a tablet that included nandrolone, a banned anabolic steroid. As a result, the ATP overturned its suspension of Bohdan Ulihrach of the Czech Republic and told its trainers that they could no longer dispense electrolyte tablets or other vitamin or mineral products.

title: Democrats Design Agenda in Bid to Hold Hispanic Support
description: Moving to protect their political advantage with Hispanic voters against aggressive Republican encroachment, Congressional Democrats are preparing to showcase a policy agenda aimed directly at this increasingly sought-after bloc.

title: Rumsfeld Doubles Estimate For Cost of Troops in Iraq
description: Gen. Tommy R. Franks said today that violence and uncertainty in Iraq made it unlikely that troop levels would be reduced ''for the foreseeable future,'' and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld nearly doubled the estimated military costs there to $3.9 billion a month.

title: Jamboree for Cellos, Soprano And Steady Roar of Traffic
description: The violinist Alexander Schneider started the Washington Square Music Festival in 1953, and like several of his other projects -- a concert series at the New School University, and the annual New York String Orchestra Seminar, most notably -- it has become a part of the city's musical fabric. Offered on Tuesday evenings through July 29, these free concerts in Washington Square Park make the most of a tenuous budget, offering a mix of chamber music, orchestral works performed by a freelance festival orchestra, and jazz.

title: DELTA PILOTS' UNION FILES GRIEVANCE OVER FURLOUGHS
description: The pilots' union at Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it had filed a grievance against management for putting 250 pilots on furlough in the last three months. Mike Pinho, a spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association, said that while Delta had been forced to make cutbacks because of the traffic slump during the invasion of Iraq, the pilots should be called back because major fighting had ended. The union filed the grievance on June 26 and has had one meeting with management to discuss the issue. Delta laid off 1,060 pilots after the terrorist attacks of September 2001 by invoking a ''force majeure'' clause, Mr. Pinho said. The company used the same clause in the most recent round of layoffs. A Delta spokeswoman declined to comment. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Tavera Journal; On Trailblazing Corsica, Sausages With a Pedigree
description: It's not easy to find the hams and dried sausages of Julien Raffalli. The 60-year-old pig farmer and charcuterie maker refuses to sell to shops, avoids food fairs and will not advertise.

title: 3 Student Leaders Seized by Vigilantes in Iran
description: Armed vigilantes arrested three student leaders this morning after a news conference at which they announced the cancellation of protests to mark the anniversary of the 1999 student protests.

title: Metallica Thrashes Back to 80's Angst
description: Metallica brought along a fan club for its Summer Sanitarium tour: the other four hard-rock bands on the bill at Giants Stadium tonight. One by one they gave testimonials to Metallica's influence. Mudvayne's lead singer, Chad Gray, wore a Metallica T-shirt. Chino Moreno of the Deftones raised a drink to Metallica. Linkin Park's lead singer, Chester Bennington, called Metallica the greatest band on earth, and Fred Durst of Limp Bizkit seemed so cowed by the prospect of performing for Metallica fans that he sang ''Welcome Home (Sanitarium),'' which Metallica would play much better in its own set.

title: Muting That Squawk In a Modem Mating Call
description: Q.Is there a simple way to eliminate the unpleasant high-pitched sounds you hear while a modem connection is established?

title: China's Main Stock Market Opens to Foreigners
description: The Swiss investment bank UBS today became the first foreign investor to buy shares on China's dominant Class A share market, which trades in yuan. Previously, foreign investors had been allowed to buy shares only in China's much smaller, dollar-based market.

title: Political Memo; Recall Vote Promises to Add to California Chaos
description: One day this fall, Californians could wake up with a throbbing political hangover and a new governor.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Judge Rejects 'Choose Life' Plate
description: A federal judge in New Orleans ruled that the state could not distribute special license plates bearing the words ''Choose Life.'' The judge, Stanwood R. Duval Jr., said that by allowing that license plate design but not others, the state impermissibly favored some points of view. ''This case is not about abortion, the right to life or the right to choice,'' Judge Duval wrote. ''It is about the First Amendment.'' Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Publisher Accused of Abetting Iraqi Cause in U.S.
description: Federal authorities, using a document seized in Baghdad after the fall of Saddam Hussein, arrested a Chicago-area newspaper publisher today, saying he had worked for years as a secret Iraqi agent.

title: Disabled Girl Is Found Dead In Trash Truck
description: The foster mother of a severely disabled 8-year-old girl told the police yesterday that when the girl died she panicked and left her body in a garbage bag on an Upper East Side sidewalk, officials said. After hours of searching, the police found the girl's tiny body -- just 28 pounds -- inside a garbage truck.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Firearms In Europe
description: Europeans are more heavily armed than is commonly believed, according to a study released this week at a United Nations conference on small arms. There are an estimated 67 million privately owned firearms in the 15 countries of the European Union, or roughly 17 guns per 100 people, the survey said. In France and Germany, the figure jumps to about 30 guns per 100 people. In the United States there are 83 to 96 guns per 100 people, according to the study. The survey was conducted by researchers at the Geneva-based Graduate Institute of International Studies. The weeklong United Nations conference was convened to assess a 2001 plan to restrict small arms trafficking. Daniel B. Schneider (NYT)

Billings were estimated at $35 million.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Killer's Execution
description: Riley D. Noel, 31, was executed by lethal injection last night for the killings of three children in 1995. Unable to find the woman he suspected of helping kill his brother a week earlier, Mr. Noel entered her family's Little Rock home and shot to death her three younger siblings, ages 10 to 17. Defense lawyers had sought a stay of execution to argue for a reduced sentence, contending that Mr. Noel was mentally retarded, but the Arkansas Supreme Court refused. Steve Barnes (NYT)

description: The Bush administration, seeking to prop up the faltering administration of the Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, is planning a rapid infusion of funds to the Gaza Strip for public works projects, including rebuilding of roads and other job-creation efforts, administration officials said today.

description: Magazine advertising pages declined in June after rising in May and falling in April, maintaining the seesaw pattern that held for much of last year, according to data released yesterday by the Publishers Information Bureau.

description: Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, said yesterday that New York was committed to spending $15.75 million over the next four years to turn the High Line, an abandoned railroad viaduct that runs for 1.5 miles through the far West Side of Manhattan, into a park or public space. ''We hope this will serve as a catalyst,'' Mr. Miller said, attracting federal, state and private money needed for rehabilitation. His announcement was timed to coincide with the opening today at Grand Central Terminal of an exhibition displaying design ideas from a competition sponsored by the nonprofit Friends of the High Line. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEISKELL, , ANDREW
description: HEISKELL -- Andrew. The New York Public Library deeply mourns the passing of its Chairman Emeritus, great leader, champion, benefactor, and guardian, Andrew Heiskell. With great wisdom, and with selfless dedication and devotion for more than two decades, he was the guiding spirit in the Library's resurgence from financial difficulties in the 1970's and helped move the Library into a new century, embodying his vision as a university of the people without equal. Under Mr. Heiskell's leadership, the Library raised over $300 million in the 1980's, and he was directly and instrumentally responsible for securing financial support from diverse public and private sources, in addition to his own generous philanthropy. His great achievements included the restoration of the landmark Library building at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street to its original grandeur, the upgrading of many of the Branch Libraries in the Bronx, Manhattan, and Staten Island; improved access to the Library's great research collections; and the revival of the preservation program. He helped expand the Library's Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture and strengthen the endowment for The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts. His interest in the Library's immediate surroundings led him to form the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation, responsible for a comprehensive renovation of the Park, and he helped build 44 miles of new storage for the research collections in underground book stacks beneath the Park. The Andrew Heiskell Braille and Talking Book Library, a facility dedicated to serving the blind, visually impaired, and others unable to read standard print material, is named in his honor to recognize his great energy and commitment in making this facility a reality. New York is a better place because of Andrew Heiskell, for his creation of beautiful public spaces, his drive to provide democratic access to knowledge, and his unwavering support of cultural institutions and their role in bettering society. We owe him our deepest, most profound thanks, and we are grateful to have been touched by a man of such extraordinary vision and goodness. We extend our deepest sympathies to Marian Heiskell and to all members of Andrew's family. Mrs. Vincent Astor, Honorary Chairman Samuel C. Butler, Chairman Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti Paul LeClerc, President

title: Report on the Shuttle Has Been Delayed
description: The publication date for the report of the independent investigation into the shuttle Columbia disaster has been pushed back to the last week in August, officials involved in the investigation said yesterday.

title: Veterans, Vendors and Beaten Paths
description: Among the business left unfinished when the State Legislature decamped from Albany was the renewal of the law limiting city sidewalk vending by disabled war veterans. Big mistake. Recent history has shown that without these controls, a proliferation of vendors is guaranteed, and far from all of them will be veterans. Vendors have their place on New York City streets, but it is a limited one. When the number gets out of hand, the result is congested sidewalks and the flight of rent-paying storefront businesses.

description: HONG KONG, July 10  Beijing has sent a team of officials here from security and intelligence agencies, the foreign ministry and the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office to ask local leaders and residents why they are so upset and to collect ideas for what to do next, pro-Beijing politicians said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Equipment Sales Expected To Rise
description: Sales of equipment used in computer chip factories will rise 7.9 percent this year, after declining 37.9 percent in 2002, said Gartner Inc., a research company. Sales of gear by companies including Applied Materials, ASML Holding and Tokyo Electron will rise to $29.9 billion this year, from $27.7 billion in 2002, Gartner said. Worldwide factory capacity for chip makers is rising, semiconductor inventory levels are low and demand is growing, a combination that favors the equipment industry, Gartner said.

title: F.D.A. Announces Label Requirement For Artery Clogger
description: After more than a decade of debate, the Food and Drug Administration announced yesterday that it would require food processors to include the amount of artery-clogging trans fatty acids on nutrition labels.

title: Flash Point; Behind a Hacker's Book, a Primer on Copyright Law
description: ANDREW HUANG, an engineer and programmer in San Diego, has written a book called ''Hacking the Xbox: An Introduction to Reverse Engineering.'' It has also been an introduction to copyright law in the digital age.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Beverage Profits Rise
description: Diageo, the British beverage conglomerate, said that the growth in profit for its fiscal year was marginally better than the 6 percent growth in the first half of the year. Sales, however, did not improve from the first half of the year, partly because of a decline in demand for the company's premixed vodka drinks, Diageo said. The company said the war in Iraq and the SARS outbreak hurt its sales. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Law Replaces 32 School Boards
description: Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation yesterday that will replace the city's 32 local community school boards with parent councils. The bill is a follow-up to legislation last year that gave the mayor control of the city school system. The new councils will have nine parent members, two community members appointed by the borough president, and a nonvoting student member. The bill largely mirrored the proposals of a bipartisan task force. But critics say it ignored a key recommendation by the task force that all parents of school children in a district be eligible to vote for the council members. Instead, parent members on the councils will be elected by officers of parent-teacher associations. The law must still be approved by the federal Justice Department.

title: Prokofiev's Heroic Bolsheviks
description: After spending 15 restless years in the West, Prokofiev returned to Russia in 1933, frustrated and as intensely ambitious as ever. His timing was terrible, for Stalin had propounded the artistic doctrine of Socialist Realism. So Prokofiev tried to get with the program. A result was ''Semyon Kotko,'' his fifth opera, based on an obsequiously Stalinist novella by Valentin Katayev.

title: F.D.A. PANEL BACKS APPROVAL OF ASTRAZENECA DRUG
description: AstraZeneca, the European drug maker, won the backing of a Food and Drug Administration advisory committee yesterday for approval of its anticholesterol drug Crestor. The committee voted 9 to 0 to recommend that the agency approve Crestor in doses of 5 milligrams to 40 milligrams. Crestor already competes with Lipitor from Pfizer Inc. in Europe and Canada. The agency had delayed a decision on concerns about the medicine's risks to muscles and kidneys. With approval in the United States, annual sales might top $3 billion by 2007, making the drug AstraZeneca's most important new product, analysts said.

One, covered in nylon fishing line, above, looks furry. The other is covered in taut plastic. The space was designed by Emmanuelle Duplay, a well-known French set designer. title: Some Big Names Returning to Competition
description: Boris Becker and John McEnroe are well past their primes, but when they face each other tonight at the Tennis Club at Harbor Island Park in Mamaroneck in World Team Tennis competition, their match will provide star power, something this year's men's final at Wimbledon could not do.

title: Damage Control for Sun Worshipers
description: I'M no hysteric, but when I see my family sitting outside without sunblock, I get an irresistible urge to baste them like capons.

title: 'Big Food' Gets the Obesity Message
description: Almost everyone laughed when two Bronx teenagers sued McDonald's last year for making them obese. Legions of critics said it was ludicrous for the overweight girls to blame a fast-food company instead of their own nutritional ignorance, lack of willpower, genetic predispositions, failure to exercise or whatever else may play a role in the multifaceted problem of obesity. Commentators and late-night comedians had a field day deriding ''frivolous'' lawsuits, and a federal judge, in dismissing the case in January, explained that ''it is not the place of the law to protect them from their own excesses.'' Yet now the food industry is behaving as if the suit (now amended and refiled), or at least the fast-growing campaign to hold food companies responsible for adverse nutritional effects, may not have been so frivolous after all.

title: Yahoo's Earnings Double As Revenue Sets a Record
description: Profits more than doubled at Yahoo, the big Internet portal, in the second quarter as its revenue also grew briskly and even exceeded the record it set at the peak of the Internet boom.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Retail Prices Fall
description: Consumer prices in Brazil fell in June for the first month since 1998, a sign the government's unpopular tight monetary policy is succeeding in stifling months of high inflation and could be eased soon to encourage economic growth. The government statistics agency said the consumer price index, a barometer for government interest rate policy, fell 0.15 percent in June after a 0.61 percent rise in May. Although inflation in the 12 months ended in June was still high, at more than 16 percent, the rate was 6.6 percent in the first six months of the year, the agency said. With the central bank's benchmark interest rate on overnight loans at 26 percent, Brazil's economy has ground to a near halt, pushing up unemployment and paralyzing the retail sector. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Pop Bands Whose Beat Is Orthodox And Hip
description: It was just after midnight at the Makor nightclub on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, and the rock band Soulfarm was beginning to peak. Near the front of the stage, fans swayed and spun in time with the groove, their eyes closed as the band settled into a chugging Bo Diddley beat. Well-established on the jam band circuit, this New York-based quartet had drawn a young, slightly scruffy, neo-hippie crowd. But there was a twist: most of that crowd was made up of Orthodox Jews.

title: A 20-Year Talk With Hepburn Is Being Published
description: For years everything was in place for the publication of ''Kate Remembered,'' every thing save one.

title: The Forgotten Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Franks Details Raid Near Syrian Line
description: Disclosing new details of a mysterious Special Operations attack on a convoy crossing from Iraq into Syria, Gen. Tommy R. Franks said today that the mission had sought to kill suspected leaders of the ousted government and might also have closed a smugglers' route used by fugitive Iraqi officials.

title: The Reunion Upon a Hill
description: It was in July of 1951 that I made my first visit to Monticello, Thomas Jefferson's house in the hills of Virginia. My father was about to leave for duty in the Korean War, and our parents wanted some time to themselves, so they sent my brother, Frank, and me to Charlottesville to stay with our great-grandmother, Mary Walker Randolph, and our great aunts Aggie and Miss Moo, who lived with Gran in the woods in a cottage that had once been a speakeasy, and which they had grandly named Wild Acres.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ODENCE, , LOIS BECKER
description: ODENCE--Lois Becker. June 21, 1923-July 9, 2001. Your sparkling great-grandchildren have inherited your warmth, your sense of whimsy, your love of life, and your affection for others. Your six beloved grandchildren and their spouses continue to exemplify your values of compassion, graciousness and determination. What a legacy you have left us all. Little Sam says ''Grandma Lois will be in my heart forever,'' and, indeed, you will. Barbara and Ruth

title: Shares in ImClone Returning to Nasdaq
description: ImClone Systems, the biotechnology company at the center of an insider-trading scandal involving Martha Stewart, says it has returned to compliance with rules governing Nasdaq stock market listings.

title: Sports of The Times; First Advertisers, Then Cyclists
description: WENT to the Tour de France again yesterday. What a wonderful event. People drive past in gaudy cars and toss ball caps and T-shirts and trinkets to people standing behind steel barricades. Nary a bicycle in sight.

title: Nader, Whom Democrats Saw as 2000 Spoiler, Ponders '04 Run
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate whom Democrats blame for costing Al Gore the last presidential election, said today that he would decide later this year whether to seek the White House again, as a Green Party candidate or an independent.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: School Drug Testing Is Upheld
description: The State Supreme Court yesterday upheld Hunterdon Central Regional High School's random drug and alcohol testing as a condition of students' participating in after-school activities. Justice Peter G. Verniero, writing for the four-member majority, said the searches did not violate the State Constitution's ban on unreasonable searches. A three-justice minority argued that a student should not be tested without some evidence of drug or alcohol use. A trial-court ruling banning the testing was overturned by the Appellate Division. Iver Peterson (NYT)

title: Breaking Away
description: Caroline Jhingory had been warned but she was still surprised -- and hurt -- when some of her lifelong friends turned on her the way they did.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: COMPUTER EXPERTS SOUGHT The government will extend for about 18 months a "green card" program, inspired by the United States, entitling high-tech experts from outside the European Union to work in the country to fill a skills gap in computer technology. Since Aug. 1, 2000, a total of more than 14,500 work and residence permits have been allocated. Most applicants came from India and the former Soviet Union. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Nike Purchasing Converse, A Legend on the Blacktop
description: Nike, known for its shoes and its swoosh, has Michael Jordan and Tiger Woods on its corporate team. Now it is lining up yet another sports legend: for $305 million, Nike is buying Converse, a century-old footwear company and maker of the celebrated Chuck Taylor All Star shoe.

title: Corporate Logo, Or Smoke Screen?
description: MOST logos -- in kitchen cabinets, department stores and streets -- drive home their meanings instantly. Nike's swoosh says movement, McDonald's arches say ''drive in'' and Ralph Lauren's polo player conveys leisure class with clarity.

title: Braves Create More Misery for Glavine
description: Chipper Jones had just scored on a sacrifice fly by Javy Lopez, becoming the third Braves runner to cross home plate yesterday. Tom Glavine gripped the baseball tightly in his glove and glanced into the Braves' dugout, where high-fives were being handed out like victory cigars.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about efforts to revive the Salton Sea in Southern California misstated the drinkability of the water. The salt content is above Environmental Protection Agency limits for drinking; the water does not meet federal standards.

title: At Meal Time, Just Fold Up the Screen
description: A liquid crystal monitor that folds up for easy carrying sounds like something that would mainly interest business travelers. But NEC-Mitsubishi has introduced two new folding screens aimed at household users.

title: Law Firm Is Sued Over Conduct in Liability Case
description: A Texas law firm faked evidence and tried to bribe witnesses in a products liability case, according to a lawsuit filed on Monday in San Antonio by the DaimlerChrysler Corporation.

title: Europe's Central Bank Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged
description: FRANKFURT, July 10  The European Central Bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged today, raising the possibility that the bank will not tinker again with monetary policy until the man designated as its next president, Jean-Claude Trichet, takes the helm this fall.

title: Hong Kong Bombshell for Beijing
description: As it seeks to contain the fallout from a political fiasco in its cherished ''special administrative region'' of Hong Kong, the Chinese government has been uncharacteristically tongue-tied.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buffalo: More Prosecution For Doctor's Killer
description: The government will continue to press civil rights charges against James C. Kopp in the killing of a doctor who performed abortions, even though he has already been convicted and sentenced on a state murder charge, a federal prosecutor said yesterday. Mr. Kopp, 48, was sentenced in May to 25 years to life in prison for the 1998 shooting of the doctor, Barnett A. Slepian. Under his current sentence, Mr. Kopp will not be eligible for parole until he is 73. A conviction on the federal charges could keep him in prison for life without any chance of parole.

title: Corrections
description: An Editorial Observer published on Saturday gave incorrect titles for two CD's of writers' voices published by the British Library. The correct titles are ''The Spoken Word -- Poets'' and ''The Spoken Word -- Writers.''

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: AT&T Will Offer Wi-Fi
description: AT&T plans to offer wireless Internet access in more than 2,000 locations in the fourth quarter, using software from GRIC Communications. GRIC shares surged as much as 77 percent. The access points for wireless fidelity, or Wi-Fi, will allow travelers to connect laptop computers and other portable devices to company data networks at hotels, airports and convention centers in 20 countries, AT&T said. David W. Dorman, the AT&T chief executive, said the company was seeking to cater to business customers, who generated more than two-thirds of the company's $37.8 billion in revenue last year. GRIC shares rose $2.56, to $7. AT&T rose 12 cents, to $19.85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SELIGMANN, , OTTO
description: SELIGMANN--Otto. July 8, age 85, treasurer of Arnhold Ceramics until he retired at 80, to care for his beloved wife Esther. Admired for his integrity and generosity. Brother of Eva Vigart, brother-in-law of Henry Arnhold, father of Katherine, Michael, Peter and Monica, with nine grandchildren, 2 great-grandchildren. Service, July 13, 11:00AM, at Mountain Lakes House, Princeton, New Jersey (609-924-8720). Memorial contributions to Conservation International, Washington D.C., or International Rescue Committee, New York City. >>AD#

title: Factory Killer Had a Known History of Anger and Racial Taunts
description: When he overheard a black man complimenting a white woman a couple of years ago on the factory floor, Doug Williams stepped up to the man and, using a racial slur, angrily told him blacks had no business being with blond women, witnesses recalled today.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has confirmed the deaths of the following Americans while supporting military efforts in the Iraq theater of operations:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Landlord Accused Of Tax Evasion
description: A landlord who had previously been cited for numerous building code violations was indicted yesterday in federal court on charges of filing false tax returns and understating rental income from several of his buildings. The landlord, Pablo Llorente, did not return a call for comment yesterday. Mr. Llorente claimed to have collected slightly more than $2.1 million in rent from 1993 to 1996 from four Manhattan buildings. The indictment did not specify how much he actually collected, except to say it was ''substantially in excess'' of the reported amount. In 2001, Mr. Llorente's buildings drew attention after carbon monoxide sickened residents at 159 West 80th Street. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Panel Suggests Club Safety Rules
description: A National Fire Protection Committee panel has recommended strict safety measures for nightclubs, advising that all newly built clubs and existing clubs that can accommodate 150 patrons or more be outfitted with sprinklers. The committee, based in Quincy, advises local jurisdictions. It will formally vote onthe recommendations next week. The recommendations come in response to a Feb. 20 fire at a Rhode Island nightclub that killed 100 people. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JEFFORDS, , KATHLEEN
description: JEFFORDS -- Kathleen. On July 8, 2003, beloved wife of the late Walter Jeffords, devoted mother of George, John, and Sally. Cherished grandmother of Sam, Gabriella, Charlotte, Julian and Jofka. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wedneday and Thursday 7-9 P.M. Services Friday July 11, 2003, 11:30 A.M. at Saint James The Less, 3227 West Clearfield St, Phil, PA. >>AD#

title: Personal E-Mail at Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Tiff: What's Next? Food Fight?
description: No sooner did Italy and Germany extricate themselves from the diplomatic imbroglio of last week than they got into another one today, with Chancellor Gerhard Schrder reacting to an Italian official's insulting remarks about German tourists by imposing an unusual sanction: he canceled his vacation in Italy.

title: The Choice Factor in Home Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIRSTEN, , ROSE
description: KIRSTEN--Rose. Died on July 8, 2003 at age 95 in Florida. Beloved wife of the late George. Loving mother of Bob Kirsten (Helene) and Linda Spitzer (Jerry). Proud grandmother of Jeffrey Spitzer (Arlene), Rick Spitzer, David Kirsten (Janet), Bruce Kirsten and Michael Kirsten. Greatgrandmother of Jacob and Hannah Spitzer. Her sense of humor and wit helped her cope with many challenges in her life. Contributions to the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty, NY, Att: Willy Rapfogel.

title: Building Paris Was Just a Start
description: TWO weeks ago, Mariette Himes Gomez sat in her dining room on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, drinking iced tea from a ball-shaped English goblet with a hunting scene etched on it. She rested it on a mahogany breakfast table that once belonged to the Duke and Duchess of Windsor. The Devonshire-cream paint on the walls, with its hints of cinnamon and rose, was mixed exclusively for her by Donald Kaufman, a celebrated colorist.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: BANK STAKE ACQUIRED The Shinhan Financial Group signed the final agreement to buy the government's entire 80 percent stake in the Chohung Bank for 3.37 trillion won ($2.85 million). Shinhan said, however, that it would have to acquire money to pay for Chohung partly by selling shares worth 900 billion won on the Korea Stock Exchange. Standard & Poor's, citing Shinhan's weakened finances as a result of the purchase, cut its long-term rating on Shinhan but raised its rating on Chohung. Shinhan's president, Choi Young Hwi, said the acquisition of Chohung would enable Shinhan to reach customers through a wider network, but Shinhan, in a concession to union members who fought the deal, will operate Chohung as a separate bank for at least three years. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Wholesale Inventories Fell 0.3% In May, Commerce Dept. Reports
description: Wholesale inventories fell 0.3 percent in May, to $289.34 billion, according to a government report released yesterday.

title: Report Faults Big Companies On Climate
description: Many of the world's largest companies are doing a poor job of preparing for the business impact of global warming, a report issued yesterday by investor, environmental and public interest groups said.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column last Thursday about a design competition for a public promenade on the High Line, a disused elevated track in Manhattan, misidentified a rendering of a proposal with large translucent cubes along the pathway. It was a design by Ronald DeSouza of Specter DeSouza Architects in Manhattan, not ''50 Shafts,'' a similar proposal by Takuji Nakamura of Tokyo.

title: For Printing On the Run, Inkjets to Go
description: WHATEVER happened to portable printers? They were tiny battery-operated laptop companions that looked like black plastic Saran Wrap boxes. All right, they were a little slow; in the time it took one to crank out a page of text, you could have handwritten it. Even so, they were awfully cool. I gave serious thought to becoming a claims adjuster, just so I could carry one around with my laptop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANGLEY, , JOSEPH A.
description: LANGLEY--Joseph A. Of Cedar Grove, NJ. Longtime restaurant manager at The Merchants Club, NYC. Awarded the Cornell Hotel Society Hotelman of the Year Award in 1993. A proud WWII veteran. Reposing at Shook's Cedar Grove Funeral Home, (973-239-1489). >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOEB, , JAMES J.
description: LOEB--James J. Passed away peacefully on July 8, 2003 after a long illness. Known for his kindness and generosity he is survived by his loving wife Priscilla, daughter Marcie (Alan) Auerbach, grandsons Philip and Jason Auerbach and step children Mark and Annie Danielewski. The family will receive friends at the Harmonie Club on July 14th, 6-8 PM. >>AD#

title: Chief Confirms Viacom Wants Vivendi Cable Units
description: Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman of Viacom, confirmed today that his company was seeking to acquire Vivendi Universal's cable television networks but not its film or music studios, effectively relegating Viacom to the second tier of bidders in an auction of the Universal entertainment businesses.

title: California Will Wait Until 2006 to Require High School Graduates to Pass Exit Exam
description: Faced with failure rates that could bar tens of thousands of students from graduating, the California State Board of Education voted yesterday to postpone the consequences of its high school exit exam for two years.

title: In 'First Real Test' of the Tour, Armstrong Earns Himself an A
description: Lance Armstrong called it ''the first real test'' in this Tour de France, and today he and his United States Postal Service teammates responded to it with a show of strength that suggested that Armstrong may indeed be on his way to a fifth straight victory in cycling's most prestigious event.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Inmates Demand Segregation
description: Paramilitary inmates at Maghaberry Prison outside Belfast, Northern Ireland, intensified a week of protests by smearing excrement on the walls of their cells. Prisoners from dissident republican groups like the Real I.R.A., which are largely Roman Catholic and want Northern Ireland to join the Irish Republic, demand to be segregated from loyalist prisoners, who are Protestant and want to strengthen the province's ties with Britain. ''These men are sworn enemies on the outside, so how can they expect them to put up with a single regime inside?'' said Tommy Kirkham, a prominent loyalist spokesman. Republican representatives accused wardens of assaulting prisoners and forcibly washing them. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STAPLETON, , RIKKI
description: STAPLETON--Rikki. Died at her home in New York July 4. Memorial Mass for friends and family at St. John the Martyr Church, 250 E. 72 St at 1 PM, Thursday, July 17. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Angel's Gate Hospice, 18 Josephine Lane, Fort Salonga, N.Y. 11768.

title: COVENTRY HEALTH CARE TO BUY ALTIUS HEALTH PLANS
description: Coventry Health Care Inc., a managed health care insurer operating in 14 states, agreed to buy Altius Health Plans Inc. for as much as $41 million to gain customers in Utah. Altius, a private company based in South Jordan, Utah, has about 160,000 customers and annual sales of about $235 million, Coventry said. The purchase would be Coventry's third in 12 months as the company seeks to enter new markets. The transaction is expected to close late in the third quarter and will add 1 cent to Coventry's per-share earnings in 2003 and 6 cents in 2004, it said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This Schulz probably grew up taking part in noisy burping contests, after drinking gigantic amounts of beer and gorging himself on fried potatoes.''

title: Hong Kong Protesters Demand Free Elections
description: Tens of thousands of demonstrators gathered tonight before the legislature building here to call for free elections and the resignation of Hong Kong's leader.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Publisher Sells Stock
description: The publisher of the British Yellow Pages, the Yell Group, is expected to price its initial public offering today at about 285 pence ($4.65) a share, people close to the company said. The deal is said to be oversubscribed, and Yell increased the size of its offering by 30 percent, to 400 million shares. The company's total market capitalization will be about 2 billion ($3.3 billion). The price of 285 pence a share is at the upper end of the expected range of 250 to 300 pence. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: The Choice Factor in Home Care
description: To the Editor:

title: 2nd Deadly Bombing in Moscow Linked to Chechen Conflict
description: MOSCOW, July 10  A Russian security agent was killed early today during an effort to defuse a bomb that had been brought to a restaurant here by a woman officials characterized as a suicide bomber from Chechnya.

title: Knicks Open Summer Camp
description: Prospects were scattered around the court at the Knicks' practice facility, working through a four-hour session this morning, most of them wishful thinkers who have little or no chance of sticking with the team past the N.B.A. summer leagues.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: F+W PUBLICATIONS, Cincinnati, a magazine and book publisher, said it had acquired Adams Media Corp., Boston, a special-interest book publisher. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENFIELD, , LAWRENCE
description: GREENFIELD -- Lawrence. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Lawrence Greenfield, a cherished friend of the Jewish community who served as chair of UJAFederation's General Insurance Executive Committee and as a trustee of our beneficiary agency, The Educational Alliance. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Roslyn, and to his entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

title: A Troubled Occupation in Iraq
description: He may be deposed but he remains a haunting presence. From a hiding place, Saddam Hussein has issued defiant words and vowed resistance, saying that ''jihad cells and brigades have been formed.'' Earlier, President Bush, displaying misplaced bravado, issued his own challenge to Mr. Hussein's supporters: ''Bring them on.''

title: Three Released After Their Sentencing in Laos
description: Two European journalists and their American interpreter were released today in Laos after being sentenced to 15 years each in a two-hour trial.

title: Once, the Home of Chancellors; Now, a Place for Buyers to Tour
description: Laura Brightman stood in the fourth-floor hallway, outside a cedar-lined walk-in closet, and breathlessly offered her assessment: ''It's quite a house. The rooms are unbelievable -- the spaciousness.''

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on July 3 about problems facing Archbishop-designate Sean P. O'Malley of Boston misidentified the religious authority who appointed the auxiliary bishops now serving there and misstated the definition of their potential role as ordinaries. Auxiliary bishops are appointed by the pope; these were not named by Cardinal Bernard Law. Ordinaries are holders of certain church offices, like diocesan bishops or the heads of pontifical clerical institutes. The term does not denote a new bishop.

title: Passion, Wrongs and Reconciliation in a Racetrack Saloon
description: Toward the end of ''St. Louis Woman: A Blues Ballet'' -- the gorgeous entertainment that Michael Smuin choreographed for Arthur Mitchell's Dance Theater of Harlem at Lincoln Center Festival's opening on Tuesday night -- a horse race is in progress.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report last Thursday about design-oriented shopping in Asbury Park, N.J., misidentified the store where Van Wifvat, a Manhattan designer, bought a pair of Portuguese porcelain table lamps. It was From House to Home, not F.S. 20.

title: FUND TO OPPOSE BUFFETT TAKEOVER OF CLAYTON HOMES
description: Brandywine Asset Management said it would vote against Warren Buffett's $1.7 billion takeover bid for Clayton Homes Inc., joining more than a half-dozen investors seeking to block the sale of the mobile home manufacturer. Brandywine, which owns about 2.3 million Clayton shares, said in a statement that the price offered by Berkshire Hathaway, which is controlled by Mr. Buffett, is too low. About 13 percent of Clayton's shareholders have now said they will oppose the transaction out of concern that Mr. Buffett is getting too much of a bargain.

title: Closing Arguments Offered In Connecticut Bribery Case
description: In closing arguments today in the federal trial of a Boston investment firm and its lawyer accused of trading political donations for lucrative state contracts, both the defense and the prosecution asked jurors to determine what distinguishes a bribe from politics as usual.

title: High Official Quits Treasury And Woman Is Named No. 2
description: The Bush administration announced changes in its economic team yesterday, including the appointment of the first woman to be deputy Treasury secretary and the resignation of Peter R. Fisher as under secretary for domestic finance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MERRIMAN, , HANNE MAR GRETHE
description: MERRIMAN -- Hanne Mar grethe. On July 4, 2003 at Sibley Memorial Hospital. She is survived by her husband, Richard Mathus Merriman, her mother, a sister, two brothers and a step-daughter. A memorial service will be held at the Metropolitan Memorial United Methodist Church, 3401 Nebraska Avenue, NW, Washington, D.C. on Tuesday, July 15 at 11 a.m. Interment private at the Church Columbarium. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Sibley Memorial Hospital Cancer Center, 5255 Loughboro Road, NW, Washington, D.C. 20016 or Children's Hospital Foundation, Children's National Medical Center, 111 Michigan Ave., NW, Washington, D.C. 20010. >>AD#

title: City Trees Outgrow Rural Cousins, and Study Credits Urban Chemistry
description: Everyone knows that trees grow in Brooklyn. Now, scientists have discovered that they also flourish in the Bronx and Queens. In fact, cottonwood trees grow twice as fast in the chewy air of New York City as they do in the pastoral reaches of the Hudson Valley and eastern Long Island.

title: 180 Years of Practice in Patterns and Borders
description: Braqueni, founded in 1823, has opened shop in a tiny house at 3, rue Furstenberg in the heart of the St.-Germain section. Its remarkable archives of patterns and borders, left, is especially well known for its toiles de jouy and indiennes.

title: College Rating By U.S. News Drops Factor In Admissions
description: Perhaps the most influential survey of American higher education is changing the way it ranks the nation's top colleges and universities, dropping from its ratings a statistic that many institutions had sought to manipulate in hopes of raising their ranking in the survey.

title: Payton Takes Less To Join The Lakers
description: This is a tale of a player who passes up millions of dollars to pursue a championship. It is the story of an agent who insists that his client's happiness is more important than money. And in a league in which the cash register can spin like a slot machine, those ambitions may just decide the next N.B.A. championship.

title: Council Speaker Pressured on Lead Paint
description: Children's health advocates are increasing pressure on New York City Council Speaker Gifford Miller to pass a new law to clean up lead paint.

title: Personal E-Mail at Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Democrats Start Push To Revive Tax-Credit Bill
description: Struggling to revive a stalled bill to raise the child tax credit for low-income families, Senate Democrats began a series of parliamentary theatrics today intended to increase pressure on Republicans in both chambers to move the bill.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the decision by Microsoft to stop giving stock options to employees misstated the date and price of the peak in the company's shares. The stock, which closed on Tuesday at $27.70, peaked in December 1999, not March 1999. The value of the stock at its peak, adjusted to take account of splits, was $59.56, not $178.

title: Palestinians Say the Truce Is in Jeopardy
description: Palestinians expressed growing frustration today over the pace of talks with Israel, and what they see as Israel's unwillingness to grant concessions, and warned that the current truce could be in jeopardy if progress was not achieved soon on crucial issues like Palestinian prisoner releases and Israeli troop withdrawals.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Kathleen Raine, 95, Scholar And Poet With Mystical Bent
description: Kathleen Raine, a mystically inclined British poet and a scholar of Yeats and Blake, died on Sunday in London. She was 95.

title: Cool in the Midst of Battle
description: Playing video games does not normally generate as much sweat as a set of tennis or a five-mile run, yet gamers do have trouble with sweaty palms. Hands wrapped around the controller's grips will become clammy and players frequently find themselves wiping their hands on their pants legs or whatever else is handy during lulls in the game. Nyko's Air Flo controllers, which contain small fans in the grips that blow air into the player's palms, are one answer to sweaty palms. The newest windy controller from Nyko is the Air Flo EX for the PlayStation 2, which has been redesigned for better air flow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AVALONE, , ANTHONY I
description: AVALONE--Anthony I. Age 52. Died July 4, 2003. He is survived by his wife Nancy R.S. Kramer. HBO Editor for 15 years. Received 1999 International Monitors Award. Member of the Radio and TV Broadcast Engineers Union, Local 1212, IBEW. Previously married to Rebecca Koborie, who perished at the WTC on September 11. His memorial service to be held Monday, July 14, 2003, 6PM at the Cutting Room, 19 W. 24 St, N.Y.C. Donations in lieu of flowers to The Yankees Foundation, Yankee Stadium, Bronx, N.Y. 10451. Contact Michael Hegarty Funeral Home, Old Bridge, N.J. for information. >>AD#

title: Senator Clinton Offers a Cure For Foot-in-Mouth Disease
description: The other shoe dropped in the publishing and pontificating businesses yesterday. Not the one you talk about eating, but the one you eat.

title: Economic Scene; It's beginning to look as if the politicians in Washington need to take another look at economic policy.
description: IT is time for Washington, including Democrats, to start reconsidering economic policy once again. Just when economists began telling us the clouds were lifting, the June unemployment rate jumped to a nine-year high of 6.4 percent. Despite a modestly rising gross domestic product, some 236,000 jobs have been lost in 2003 and 2.6 million since early 2001.

title: Taking Gloves Off to Save a Gym; 3 Boxers Add Acting, Math and Computer Classes
description: ''Keep them hands up!'' George Washington admonished the two apprentice boxers prowling the ring. ''Jab him, Junior, jab him! Now throw him the right hand. Right hand, right hand, Junior.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about a decision by the Mazda Motor Corporation to stop producing some kinds of light trucks referred incorrectly to its relationship with the Ford Motor Company. Ford controls Mazda through a 33.4 percent stake; it does not own a majority of the stock.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Assemblyman Dies
description: State Assemblyman Jacob E. Gunther III, a Democrat from Sullivan County, died early yesterday in an Albany hospital where he was being treated for cancer, said Rita A. Simon, his chief of staff. He was 50 years old. Mr. Gunther, known as Jake, had been a town justice in Forestburgh, where he lived, and the owner of a glass business before he was first elected to the Assembly, in 1992. He was vice chairman of the State Legislative Commission on Rural Resources. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Kenya Starts Crackdown On Fake Charity Groups
description: The Neema Children's Center has disappeared into thin air, authorities here say, and so have other groups that claim to be fighting AIDS in this African capital.

title: Senate Refuses to Consider Cap On Medical Malpractice Awards
description: Voting mostly along party lines, the Senate refused today to take up a bill that would cap jury awards in medical malpractice cases, delivering a victory to trial lawyers who opposed the caps and a defeat to doctors, insurance companies and President Bush, who has made malpractice changes an important element of his domestic agenda.

title: France and Germany Tie Troops for Iraq to a U.N. Mandate

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARKWITZ, , ADELE
description: MARKWITZ--Adele, a prominent Audiologist/Speech Language Pathologist of great professional acclaim, died on July 7. A founding member of the New York City Speech-Language-Hearing Association, a charter member of the New York State Speech - Language Hearing Association and a member of the American Association of Audiology, Markwitz was a certified member of the American Speech-language-Hearing Association. When the New York State Department of Education established licensure status for her profession Markwitz was appointed as a member of the first licensure board. She was among the first of her profession in New York State to establish an independent practice. Early on in her career she directed her practice toward the development of verbal language among hearing - impaired children. With the strong belief that a universal ''inborn language mechanism'' operates normally only when children are given exposure to an adequate sample of language at an early age, Markwitz practiced what she described as a developmental psycho - lin guistic approach to language acquisition for hearing-impaired children. With this approach, her children have developed to live productive and often professional lives, fluent in verbal language. She shared this approach with colleagues in numerous presentations as well as with students at New York University, where she taught. She will be sorely missed. Ruth Turner Annette Zaner

RCN also reached an agreement to sell its cable system in Carmel, N.Y., for $120 million, to Susquehanna Communications, a cable provider that is closely held. RCN, based in Princeton, N.J., said $66 million of the sale proceeds would go to pay loans. It is under pressure to sell assets and restructure about $1.7 billion in debt. RCN will offer 32 cents to 37 cents on the dollar, plus accrued and unpaid interest, for its senior notes.

PDI, based in Upper Saddle River, N.J., will report second-quarter results on Aug. 5. The contract from Glaxo will add about $30 million in sales for 2003, starting this month, PDI said. The order, which ends in September 2004, will increase PDI's revenue by $55 million next year. PDI's stock rose $6.45, to $17.38 a share.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Suit Against Rambus Is Dismissed

The dismissal of the lawsuit follows a decision by an appeals court in January to throw out a jury's finding that Rambus committed fraud while pursuing patents for high-speed memory chips that became an industry standard. That appeals court also reinstated a patent-infringement lawsuit against Infineon Technologies, part of Rambus's efforts to collect as much as $840 million in patent royalties from semiconductor companies. Shares of Rambus rose 77 cents, or 4.2 percent, to $19.16.

title: The Changing South Finds Its Way on I-85
description: IT begins quietly enough in the piney woods of southern Virginia. At Petersburg, I-85 diverges from I-95, the main drag of the East Coast, and heads diagonally across Dixie for the next 600 or so miles, passing through North Carolina and Georgia, before petering out in Montgomery, Ala. Many call it the Main Street of the New South, and in its curves are written the broad stories of economic and social change, along with the attendant, if smaller, personal dramas.

title: World Briefing: Europe

"We will ask the government for damages for whomever has suffered losses because of these senseless remarks," said Gov. title: 36 Hours | Cape May, N.J.
description: AS soon as summer heralds its presence, tourists descend upon this Victorian resort at New Jersey's southern tip. The town, with a permanent population of 4,200, plays host to a half-million visitors annually -- most of them during the summer. An outdoorsy mentality has thrived on this 3.5-square-mile island (a canal makes it an island) for quite some time -- ever since the Kechemeche Indians hunted and fished here. In 1620, Cornelius Jacobsen Mey, a Dutch explorer, navigated the coastline and gave his name to the area, though the spelling was later changed to May. Breeze-seeking Philadelphians eventually made Cape May one of the nation's first seaside resorts. Today, entrance to Cape May's two miles of public beaches requires adults to pay as they go ($4 per day, $8 for three days), in the form of beach tags, which are sold around town. While the fee may be a nuisance, it helps to ensure immaculate beaches. And although Victoriana is a major attraction in Cape May, you can also stumble upon rolling farmland, thick woods and semideserted dunes, just as past explorers did generations ago. CHRISTINE EGAN

title: NEVERFAIL OF AUSTRALIA ACCEPTS BID OF COCA-COLA AMATIL
description: Neverfail Springwater Ltd., Australia's biggest supplier of water coolers, recommended yesterday that investors accept Coca-Cola Amatil's $148 million hostile bid, after Amatil secured 85 percent of the company's shares. The acceptance ends a 10-week standoff after Neverfail rejected Coca-Cola Amatil's initial bid of 2.35 Australian dollars a share ($1.55) as too low. The reversal comes amid concern that small shareholders would be bought out at a lower price when Amatil, based in Sydney, acquired the remaining shares. Buying Neverfail gives Coca-Cola Amatil a larger presence in the bottled water market, which is growing faster than demand for its Coke, Diet Coke and other soft drinks. The chief executive, Terry Davis, will now be able to focus on concluding the purchase of Berri Ltd., which sells fruit juices.

title: Greek Verities Endure as Times and Players Change
description: Greek drama is psychologically durable, but -- at least as important for theater -- it is politically and socially adaptable, too. Everything is there: the struggle between families, men and women, rulers and nations; the pull between what we control and what (hubris, fate, the will of the gods) controls us. About power and suffering they were never wrong, the old masters. They can be endlessly reworked to dramatize the here and now. And because they are old masters, they rarely offend audiences who have wildly different beliefs.

title: What If a Bumper Can't Take the Bump?
description: There wasn't a good bumper made after 1973," John Kearney said, and he should know. He has been welding sculptures from chrome auto bumpers since 1963. His work, often whimsical representations of animals, is in institutions like the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago and the Dallas Museum of Natural History and in private collections. The old bumpers "were about one-eighth-inch thick and about 50 pounds, with two coats each of nickel, copper and chrome," Mr. Kearney said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Charges Stand In Killing
description: A federal judge let murder charges stand yesterday against a Colombian man extradited to the United States in the 1999 killing of a retired New York police detective. The man, Carlos Gonzalez, is accused in the fatal shooting of Donald E. Pagani during a robbery at a Bronx meat company where Mr. Pagani worked as a security guard. Mr. Gonzalez's lawyer, Roger L. Stavis, argued for dismissing the charges, suggesting that the United States had misled the Colombian authorities when it sought the extradition. Colombia extradited Mr. Gonzalez on the condition that he not be subjected to a life sentence if convicted, Mr. Stavis argued, yet the charges carry a mandatory life term. But Judge Shira A. Scheindlin said, ''There is no doubt in my mind that Colombia acted knowingly.'' Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAIL, , PRISCILLA L.
description: VAIL--Priscilla L., an educator active in the fields of learning disabilities, dyslexia and the education of the gifted, died July 6, 2003 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital at the age of 71. Death was due to cancer. Priscilla Luke Vail was born in New York City to Mr. and Mrs. David L. Luke. She attended the Spence and Brearley Schools and graduated from the Mary C. Wheeler School in Providence, RI in the Class of 1949. Before her marriage, she attended Vassar College from 1949-1951. She earned her BA and MAT from Manhattanville College, Purchase, NY in 1973 and 1974, at which time she joined the faculty of the Rippowam-Cisqua School where she had been a parent and long-time trustee. While working full time at Rippowam-Cisqua, she wrote and published 9 books, and numerous articles for such professional journals as NAIS and the Orton Dyslexia Society. A frequent presenter at educational conferences both here and abroad, she spoke at individual schools and school systems, and at such institutions as the Principals' Center at Harvard, Cambridge University in England, the British Dyslexia Society and York University, York, England. She continued an active professional life, teaching, writing and consulting until the time of her death. She received the Outstanding Educator of the Year award from the NY branch of the Orton Dyslexia Society in 1987 and her book, ''Smart Kids with School Problems: Things to Know and Ways to Help,'' received the Margot Marek Book Award in 1990. She was a founding trustee of the Fisher Landau Foundation for Gifted Learning Disabled Students. In 1998 she received the Samuel T. Orton Award, the highest award given by the International Dyslexia Association. A 50 year resident of Bedford, NY and a 40 year summer resident of Stonington, CT, she was active in community affairs and was a lay reader and chalice bearer at St. Matthew's Church. Among other board assignments, she served on the Education Committee of the Mystic Seaport Museum, and was the non-resident education director of the Hallowell Clinic for Cognitive and Emotional Health in Concord, MA. She was married for 50 years to Donald Vail, who predeceased her. She is survived by four children, Melissa Vail Selby, Polly Vail Walsh, Lucia Vail & Donald Angus Vail and six grandchildren. A memorial service was held at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, NY on Thursday, July 10. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the International Dyslexia Assoc, 8600 LaSalle Road, Chester Bldg, Suite 382, Towson, MD. 21286. >>AD#

title: Oldest Planet Is Discovered, Challenging Theories
description: In new observations of a distant region of primitive stars, astronomers have found the oldest known planet, a huge gaseous object almost three times as old as Earth and nearly as old as the universe itself.

title: WAR'S COST BRINGS DEMOCRATIC ANGER
description: The Pentagon's new estimate that military costs for Iraq would average $3.9 billion monthly for the first nine months of this year produced surprise and anger today among Congressional Democrats, who said the amount was not only more than they had been told, but far too large given the budget deficit.

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Cooperation Agreement
description: The European Union and Japan agreed to cooperate more closely in the field of competition regulation. Under the agreement the European Commission and the Japan Fair Trade Commission will exchange general information about antitrust and merger investigations and will work closer to stem the rise in international cartels. The union has similar agreements with the United States and Canada.

title: A Welcome Tribute To a Lost Composer
description: THE German composer Hanns Eisler wrote music of terse expressiveness, sharp wit and often immaculate craftsmanship. If, more than 50 years after his death, his work is little remembered today, it is largely because he spent his career prostrate to the faltering God of socialism, seeking an elusive wedding of progressive music and progressive politics and ultimately lending his formidable gifts to history's losing side.

title: Buffett May Face A Competing Bid For Clayton Homes
description: Warren E. Buffett may have a new rival.

title: A Harsh Romance in a Land of Ruins and Revolution
description: ''I want to go to Cuba before things get better there,'' someone confided to me recently. Cuba, for many people, is a place suspended romantically in history. It has outgrown its socialist revolution, but has not yet become crass and capitalist. Its streets are full of old Buicks and Fords from the 1950's rather than new Toyotas. It is a country of ruins that doesn't have enough money to build lots of hideous high-rises. Every street musician plays the old songs of the Buena Vista Social Club. And that's the way some people want it to stay, forever.

title: A Shakespeare Tale, Down to the Essentials
description: The Italian composer Salvatore Sciarrino worked on his modernist operatic version of ''Macbeth'' in fits and starts for more than 25 years. That fact, when I learned of it, did not automatically command respect. Why would it take so long to complete a 110-minute musical drama?

title: ANTIQUES
description: An Unlikely Spot For Celebrating Swedish Style

title: Leave Subway Creativity for Off-Hours
description: To the Editor:

title: Questions on Data Cloud Luster of Houston Schools
description: When Jerroll Tyler, a sophomore at Sharpstown High School here, turned 18, he met the full force of Texas' no-nonsense approach to education. He received an attendance contract, warning that if he missed more than two days of school, he was out permanently. By week's end, Mr. Tyler had caroused his way past the limit.

title: Teaching Game Just One Part of a Manager's Job
description: The duties of a manager in the lower levels of the minor leagues go far beyond teaching the game.

title: Out in the Garden, a Reputation Blooms
description: ''I KNEW when he cited Dr. Seuss as one of his inspirations that he was the man,'' Melissa Meyer said. Perhaps not many people planning a glamorous second home on two acres near the ocean in Sagaponack, N.Y. -- smack in the middle of the socially anxious Hamptons -- would be overjoyed to hear the creator of ''Green Eggs and Ham'' mentioned as a muse by their prospective landscaper.

title: Don't Call Them Suicide Doors
description: IN the automobile industry, it's boom time at the Department of Euphemisms. Around the world, carmakers have been coming up with inoffensive phrases for describing a newly rediscovered old feature: the so-called suicide door.

title: Got Game? Got Old Game?
description: A TALL man in a black frock coat, a gray striped waistcoat and a top hat marched onto the field of mowed weeds and, in front of 200 fans arrayed on rough-hewn stadium benches, bellowed: ''Gentlemen, have you selected hurlers?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVENSON, , EDITH
description: LEVENSON--Edith. The AntiDefamation League mourns the passing of Edith Levenson, beloved mother of Judy Davis, a member of ADL's Women's Division. We extend our condolences to Judy and the entire family. Glen A. Tobias National Chairman Carol Ostrow Hochfelder Women's Division Chair >>AD#

title: Ex-Analyst's Second Note On HealthSouth Is Released
description: As part of its investigation of the HealthSouth Corporation, a Congressional committee released a second e-mail message yesterday by the Wall Street analyst who criticized the company just months after giving its stock the highest possible rating.

title: 'The Housekeeper'
description: Directed by Claude Berri

title: With Electricity Rate Rise, Price Controls End
description: The approval of a 15.1-percent rate increase for New Jersey's largest electricity company signals the end of price controls and discounts imposed by the state deregulation law in 1999, officials said yesterday. It is also the beginning of increases for other utilities in the state, they said.

title: Decision to Charge Bryant Delayed Until Next Week
description: The district attorney investigating accusations that Kobe Bryant sexually assaulted a 19-year-old woman said today that he would wait until next week to decide whether to file charges.

title: Mayor Pulls Back on Bridge Tolls, but Still Likes the Idea
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposal to put tolls on the city's free East River bridges is turning into something of a lose-lose proposition for him.

title: Angels Dare to Tread A Spooky Countryside
description: The annals of science record several cases of twins who communicate, as children, by means of special languages incomprehensible to anyone but them. I have no idea if Mark and Michael Polish -- twin brothers whose third film, ''Northfork,'' opens today in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles -- are literal examples of this phenomenon, but their movies, which they write together and which Michael Polish directs, seem to draw on a private lexicon of images and metaphors.

title: Accounts
description: * Air New Zealand, Auckland, to the Los Angeles office of BBDO West as agency of record on its United States account, which had been handled by Team One Advertising, El Segundo, part of the Saatchi & Saatchi division of the Publicis Groupe. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million. BBDO West is part of the BBDO Worldwide division of the Omnicom Group. A sibling, Colenso BBDO, Auckland, New Zealand, handles the airline's advertising in New Zealand.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on June 30 about Fielder Cook, a director of films and television dramas, misspelled the surname of his first wife. She was Sally Chamberlin, not Chamberlain.

title: Medicare to Pay Bonuses For Best of Hospital Care
description: Medicare officials announced a novel effort today to improve hospital care by paying a 2 percent bonus to hospitals that provide superior treatment for people with heart attacks, pneumonia and certain other illnesses.

title: Limited Options In Relief Hurt Yanks
description: If a Yankees starter works deep into a game, chances are Sterling Hitchcock will not work at all. Hitchcock, a former starter, is the Yankees' long reliever. He was also Manager Joe Torre's best option in the 10th inning of a tie game at Jacobs Field tonight.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Solid Debut Casts London In Spotlight
description: Shares of Yell Group, the publisher of the British Yellow Pages, made a strong debut today, putting a new shine on London as a market for initial public offerings.

title: China's Abuses on AIDS
description: By the end of the decade, China may have 20 million people infected with the AIDS virus -- a catastrophe driven in large part by totalitarian habits. Although China is slowly changing its attitude toward AIDS, it is doing so apparently only at the level of the central government. A recent attack on AIDS sufferers in Henan Province, the center of the country's epidemic, shows how far China has to go.

title: Goodby Is Selected by AT&T Wireless
description: AT&T Wireless said yesterday that it had added Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco to its roster of agencies, naming it to handle corporate brand advertising, which since 2001 has been one of the duties of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York. Billings were not disclosed; overall spending was estimated at $700 million.
