description: To the Editor:

title: Screenplay Swordplay
description: With "Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl" providing major swordplay on theater screens, video reaches back to 1952, when Stewart Granger crossed blades with Mel Ferrer in "Scaramouche" and Burt Lancaster scrambled around the rigging in "The Crimson Pirate." Both films were released on DVD last week by Warner, along with two other epics that live largely by the sword, "Knights of the Round Table," with Robert Taylor and Ava Gardner, and "The Master of Ballantrae," with Errol Flynn.

title: Corrections
description: The 36 Hours column last Friday, about Mystic, Conn., misspelled the name and misstated the address of a restaurant. It is Bartleby's Coffee Cafe, not Bartelby's -- on West Main Street, not Pearl Street.

title: Preaching to Both Sides of the Aisle on L.I.
description: THE air-conditioner inside the pastor's office is humming along halfheartedly, so the Rev. Allan B. Ramirez peels off his blue blazer, a nautical number with gold buttons and an R embroidered on the chest, family crest-style. Not that this immigrant from Guayaquil, Ecuador, who came to Hackensack, N.J., in 1964 with his parents and eight siblings, has a family crest. In his shirt sleeves, he extends his arms as wide apart as anatomy permits. His velvety choirboy's eyes glow, and a vein in his forehead pulses. His arms stiffen. Show time!

title: Their Home Is a Palace, but Life Is Far From a Fairy Tale
description: About 20 minutes into ''I Capture the Castle,'' which concerns an eccentric English family living in a dank, picturesque stone ruin sometime in the 1930's, I realized that I had devised a mental shorthand for two of the main characters. The narrator, Cassandra, a smart, sensitive 17-year-old with straight hair and soft features, was the Kate Winslet sister. The older Rose, with curlier hair, a sharper face and a spikier attitude, was the Helena Bonham Carter sister. To mention this is of course unfair to Romola Garai and Rose Byrne, who play the two young women, but it does shed light on one of the frustrating -- or as the case may be, satisfying -- aspects of this movie, which is the sense that you've seen it before.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Interest Rate Cut
description: The Bank of Korea cut its basic interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point as the country officially entered recession for the first time since the 1997-98 economic crisis. Park Seung, left, the bank's governor, said the decrease in the interest rate, to 3.75 percent from 4 percent, was needed to persuade both corporations and individual consumers to help the economy. Earlier, Kim Young Ju, assistant finance minister, pronounced the economy in recession, telling business leaders the gross domestic product had fallen from the previous quarter in each of the last two quarters, the traditional definition of recession.

title: Canada Pushes Hard to End Ban on Exports After Mad Cow Case
description: TORONTO, July 10  Nearly two months after the carcass of a single cow tested positive for bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease, Canada has started a desperate diplomatic campaign to reopen international markets to its cattle industry.

title: New Report on Students' Skills Reinforces Good News and Bad
description: A new report on American students' writing skills reinforces the findings the federal government released last month on reading scores: elementary and middle school students are improving, but high school seniors are not.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Millennium's Vice Chairman Gives Up Post
description: Millennium Pharmaceuticals, the maker of Velcade for blood cancer, said yesterday that Vaughn M. Kailian, the vice chairman, had decided to give up daily responsibilities for commercial operations and would leave his post by the end of the year. Kenneth Bate, the chief financial officer, will take over Mr. Kailian's duties immediately and was promoted to executive vice president, Millennium said. Mr. Kailian will remain a member of the board until his term expires in 2006, a spokeswoman, Adriana Jenkins, said.

title: 'Bauhaus/New Bauhaus'
description: Ubu Gallery

title: Metro Briefing | New York: City's New Voice Of Readiness
description: The city has enlisted an unusual celebrity ally in its quest to prepare its citizens for earthquakes, radiation exposure and terrorist attacks: Gilbert Gottfried, the comedian with the high-pitched voice. Mr. Gottfried, who provided the voice for the parrot in Disney's ''Aladdin,'' filmed a public service announcement urging people to keep emergency supplies at the ready and promoting the city's new 16-page book on preparedness. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL NAMES ITS PRESIDENT AS CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The Federal-Mogul Corporation, a maker of automotive engine bearings and seals, promoted its president, Charles McClure, to the post of chief executive. Mr. McClure, 49, succeeds Frank Macher, 62, who remains as chairman, the company said. Federal-Mogul, which is seeking final approval of its bankruptcy reorganization plan, hired both executives in January 2001. Federal-Mogul, based in Southfield, Mich., filed for bankruptcy protection in October 2001 because of asbestos lawsuits and declining revenue. The company last year postponed a plan to promote Mr. McClure to chief executive in July 2002 because it was preparing its reorganization. Federal-Mogul expects to emerge from bankruptcy by the end of this year or in the first quarter of 2004, a spokeswoman, Kim Welch, said.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: More Machines On the Rise

title: Senate Becomes O.K. Corral For a Surgeon and a Lawyer
description: Now that the Senate has blocked President Bush's plan to cap jury awards in medical malpractice cases, the battle will only intensify during next year's elections. At its essence, the fight comes down to doctors versus lawyers.

title: Along the Tour, a Free Lunch Recalls a Lost Tradition
description: LYON, France, July 11  People from Bernard Thevenet's native hamlet of Le Guidon in Burgundy, those from the surrounding village of St. Julien de Civry and everybody in the small world of bicycle racing who likes Thevenet, which is probably everybody who knows him, turned out today to honor him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERENBERG, , GUS, BAYSIDE
description: BERENBERG--Gus, Bayside, NY, June 17, 2003. Survived by loving son, Dr. Barry Baker; daughter-in-law, Joanne; grandsons, Jon and James. Dr. Barry's fight for you gave you three months more. We miss you. >>AD#

title: Mayorga Confident of Stopping Forrest
description: The only thing Ricardo Mayorga worries about, he says, is his brother, Jaime, who borrowed his car in Managua, Nicaragua, their hometown. He blew out the tires and now the car does not work.

title: Unions Finding That Employers Want More Concessions
description: For the 470 workers on strike at the Tyson Foods sausage and pepperoni plant here, the big question is why the company is so eager to cut starting salaries, freeze pensions and adopt a health plan with less coverage when the plant is so profitable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEEL, , DENISE M. (NEE BARNEY)
description: NEEL--Denise M. (nee Barney). Of Yonkers, NY and formerly of Greenwich Village, NYC, on July 9, 2003. Graduate of New York University and student at FIT. Beloved wife and best friend of Alex Neel; loving sister of Peter Barney and Joseph Bolduc; dear aunt of Amanda and Petey. Memorial Services Monday, July 14th from 12 noon to 1PM at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC. Memorial donations in her memory to Education Foundation for the Fashion Industries, 7th Ave at 27th St., NY, NY 10001, Room C204 attn Vicki Guranowski. >>AD#

title: A Truck With a Life of Its Own
description: IN 1989 I bought a shiny new little red pickup truck. I needed a commuting car and, because in our Boston suburb each household has to haul its own trash, the pickup could do double duty, getting me to the city on weekdays and our ragged newspapers and exhausted appliances to the municipal dump on Saturdays.

title: Baylor Coach Backs His Staff's Reaction
description: Baylor's basketball coach, Dave Bliss, publicly defended his staff today in response to accusations that the coaches did not act properly or quickly enough to protect or to help locate the missing basketball player Patrick Dennehy.

title: House Defeats Democrats' Bid To Thwart New Overtime Rules
description: The House cleared the way today for the Bush administration to impose new rules on overtime pay, narrowly rejecting Democratic arguments that the plan will cost millions of workers the opportunity to earn extra money.

title: The Tax Man Cometh To Dinner
description: IN this line of work, man-bites-dog moments are always welcome, and the newly increased sales tax in New York City may have provided one.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Corpse Is Identified
description: The police yesterday identified the young woman whose body was found burned in a Brooklyn parking lot as a 19-year-old from the Bronx who had been reported missing days earlier. The police also released photographs of the woman, Taisha Camacho. The police are trying to determine her whereabouts between May 4, when she was reported missing, and May 7, when her body was discovered beside an auto repair shop on 39th Street in Sunset Park near the Gowanus Expressway. Family members said Ms. Camacho, a graduate of Lehman High School, was to enroll in college when she disappeared. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: New Restaurant To Add Zing To Lever House
description: Is the city that breakfasted at Tiffany's ready for lunch at Lever House?

title: 7 Abuse Complaints Filed on Father in Murder-Suicide
description: The man who killed his two children and ex-girlfriend and then himself this week in a Camden suburb had been the subject of seven child-abuse complaints in recent years, according to state records released today.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: For years the food service at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was as dull as a turn-of-the-century Paris salon. The impressive setting, in McKim, Mead & White's Pompeiian Court, only accentuated the tired menu and indifferent service.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Bomb Kills 3 In South
description: Three people were killed and 25 wounded when a bomb hit a market in Koronadal, on Mindanao, the second bombing in two months. Military officials blamed the Moro Islamic Liberation Front; a spokesman for the front denied the accusation. The bombings of markets, bus stations and shopping malls have become common on Mindanao, where separatist, Communist and militant Islamic groups operate. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: Inmate Suicides Show a Spike At City Jails
description: Six inmates in the custody of the New York City Department of Correction killed themselves during the first half of this year, the highest number of inmate suicides for any six-month period since 1985, city officials said yesterday.

title: Looser Rules Proposed for Health Claims on Food Labels
description: The Food and Drug Administration plans to loosen its regulations for health claims on food, making it easier for companies to make them based on less scientific information. The agency said it wanted to provide more and better information about diet to consumers to help them lower their risks of chronic diseases.

title: After Iraqi Police Protests, U.S. Reduces Falluja Presence
description: FALLUJA, Iraq, July 11  In the first public display of independence by a new Iraqi police force, police officers in this restless town north of Baghdad yesterday threatened to quit if American forces did not leave them to do their jobs alone. The Americans agreed to reduce a presence of more than 20 at the Falluja central police station to one or two men.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Economy Slows
description: Weak electronics exports, a sluggish construction sector and the outbreak of SARS contributed to an 11.8 percent contraction of Singapore's economy in the second quarter, according to preliminary data. The data, which was worse than most economists had expected, prompted Singapore's de facto central bank to loosen the city-state's monetary policy.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: CURRENT ACCOUNT GROWS Japan's current account surplus expanded a greater-than-expected 28.5 percent in May from the month a year ago, as the country's exporters shrugged off the effects of the severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, virus and the Iraq war. The current account, the broadest gauge of goods and services coming in and out of the country, hit 1.35 trillion yen ($11.2 billion). Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: Ganim Witness Sentenced
description: The witness whose testimony helped lead to the conviction of the former Bridgeport mayor, Joseph P. Ganim, on corruption charges was sentenced yesterday to two years in prison. The witness, Paul J. Pinto, 32, was Mr. Ganim's former fund-raiser and shared more than $2 million in kickbacks from clients seeking city contracts. He was ordered to pay the government about $400,000 in fines and restitution. Had Mr. Pinto stood trial on charges of racketeering, mail and tax fraud, he would have faced a maximum of 28 years in prison and more than $1 million in fines. He will enter prison in September. Mr. Ganim was sentenced on July 1 to nine years.

title: Justice Department Seeking to Disallow Terrorist Interview
description: The Justice Department called on a federal appeals court today to reconsider an earlier ruling that would allow Zacarias Moussaoui to interview a captured member of Al Qaeda who had acknowledged that he was a crucial organizer of the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks.

title: Shopping List | Garden Ornaments
description: GARDEN ornaments can do more than brighten up the grounds. Permanent ornaments focus the eye and celebrate the elements around them. An added perk: as they age, they may get a burnished patina and become almost rooted, as if they had grown organically. SUZANNE HAMLIN

title: Daneyko Likely To Announce His Retirement
description: The Devils scheduled a news conference for this morning at which Ken Daneyko is expected to announce his retirement.

title: Bush and Rice Say C.I.A. Approved Uranium Comment
description: President Bush said today that intelligence agencies had approved the assertion he made in his State of the Union address that Iraq had tried to buy nuclear material from Africa.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: No Schrder? What A Calamity!
description: The Marche region in central Italy asked the government to declare it in a ''state of calamity'' after Chancellor Gerhard Schrder, angered when an Italian government official insulted German tourists, canceled his summer vacation there. ''We will ask the government for damages for whomever has suffered losses because of these senseless remarks,'' said Gov. Vito D'Ambrosio, referring to statements earlier this week by a tourism undersecretary, Stefano Stefani, who called Germans beer-chugging beach invaders. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: SARS Does Little to Slow China's Growth
description: Surging exports and industrial production last month showed that China's economy was still bounding ahead, apparently little damaged by the SARS epidemic.

title: Is Race Real?
description: I had my DNA examined by a prominent genetic specialist here, and what do you know! It turns out I'm African-American.

title: Weekender | Bristol, R.I.
description: WHAT does Newport have that Bristol doesn't? In a word, crowds. Like its famous cousin just to the south, Bristol is a quintessential New England waterfront town, heavily ballasted with three centuries of seafaring and by fine examples of Federal and Colonial architecture. But where Newport courts all manner of visitors, from high society to honky-tonkers, Bristol, on a tiny peninsula between the Narragansett and Mount Hope Bays, has traditionally kept a much lower profile.

title: Besotted by Nature's Grandeur
description: THIS show has traveled around the world for two years straight and, boy, is it tired. ''Ansel Adams at 100,'' an exhibition of 113 photographs that began at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in 2001 and is now on its last leg at the Museum of Modern Art, Queens, has a strangely random and homely feel. The photographs look insignificant and out of place on the warehouse walls. The spots and splotches on the gallery's concrete floors compete with Adams's famously nuanced scale of grays. What happened?

title: Girl Found in Trash Truck Lived in Filth, Officials Say
description: Prosecutors said yesterday that a severely disabled 8-year-old whose body was found in a garbage truck on Wednesday had lived in a foster home that was covered with feces and infested with maggots.

title: JOINT VENTURE HELPS ENTERGY TO TOP PROFIT EXPECTATIONS
description: The Entergy Corporation, a utility owner based in New Orleans, said second-quarter net income rose more than expected to at least $1.15 a share because of an energy-trading joint venture with Koch Industries. Energy trading made up for a decline at Entergy's utility unit, where mild weather eroded profit, the company said. Most of the revenue from the Entergy-Koch venture has gone to Entergy, which will share income with Koch evenly next year, a spokeswoman, Yolanda Pollard, said. Profit in the quarter fell at Entergy utilities in four Southeastern states and from nuclear-power plants outside the region because of cooler weather, which reduced demand for electricity to run air-conditioners, the company said.

title: The Next Green Revolution
description: The key to economic development in Africa is agriculture. As President Bush concludes his trip to the continent, and Americans ponder ways to help it emerge from decades of poverty and turmoil, we would do well to remember that crucial point. Fortunately, we have the economic and technological means to bring about an agricultural revolution.

title: Lord Shawcross, Prosecutor at Nuremberg, Is Dead at 101
description: Lord Shawcross of Friston, who was Britain's chief prosecutor of Nazi war criminals at Nuremberg in 1945 and who, as attorney general, also conducted treason trials against infamous British spies and turncoats, died yesterday at his home in Cowbeech, south of London. He was 101.

title: Top Down, Sound Up
description: Change the space where you listen to music and you change the sound. Putting down the convertible top drastically changes that space, taking it from intimate to infinite, not to mention bringing in road and traffic noise that the car's system has to overcome.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Plea In Arts Club Case
description: A man pleaded guilty to misusing the tax-free status of a historic Gramercy Park club to buy and sell millions of dollars worth of jewelry, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, John T. James, 55, of Manhattan, has agreed to pay $469,213 in restitution and $60,000 in criminal fines, according to officials in the Manhattan district attorney's office. Mr. James is the brother of O. Aldon James, the president of the National Arts Club. John James used the club's tax-exempt code number to buy jewelry and then sold the pieces, like Victorian necklaces, without charging sales tax. Mr. James also did not file taxes from 1997 to 2001. An investigation into the finances of the National Arts Club and its principals is continuing. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENFIELD, , LAWRENCE
description: GREENFIELD -- Lawrence. Former Trustee. The Officers, Trustees and staff of the Educational Alliance note with profound sadness the passing of Lawrence Greenfield, our former trustee. Lawrence joined the Alliance's Board of Trustees in 1975 and served as an officer and Chair of the Camp Committee during his 20 years of service. He was a wise, compassionate and caring human being. During his tenure, Lawrence was a major source of intelligence, integrity and vision. Our Camps flourished under his leadership. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his loving family.

title: Impact of A.C.C. Growth Rippling Through Other Conferences
description: The ripple effects of the Atlantic Coast Conference's expansion last month began to spread through college athletics yesterday.

title: Data in Conflict: Why Economists Tend to Weep
description: Is the economy pulling itself out of a slump, or is it sinking deeper?

title: Aided by Clifford and the Care Bears, companies go after the toddler market.
description: MARKETERS have long had the nation's schoolchildren in their sights. Now toddlers in preschools and day care centers are getting special attention from companies eager for new customers.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: INSIDE
description: Panel Cuts Wall St. Policing

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: New Debt Terms
description: The lead creditor to SK Global, Hana Bank, said it had improved the terms for foreign creditors to recoup some of their debts from the trading concern. Hana and other creditors are now suggesting that the foreign creditors, to whom SK Global owes 910 billion won ($774.5 million), accept 43 percent of the debt as a final settlement, up from 38 percent.

title: Judge Postpones New Housing Court Fees That Are Opposed by Landlords and Tenants Alike
description: Responding to concerns from an unusual alliance of landlords and tenants, the state's chief administrative judge yesterday postponed new fees in New York City Housing Court set to go into effect on Monday.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New Executives At E.P.A.
description: Senior officials at the Environmental Protection Agency will temporarily fill the top two positions of the agency, including the administrator's job vacated by Christie Whitman. Marianne Lamont Horinko, the assistant administrator for solid waste and emergency response, was named acting administrator to succeed Linda Fisher, the deputy administrator who has served in that position since late June. Ms. Fisher announced her resignation two weeks ago. Stephen L. Johnson, the assistant administrator who oversees pesticides and toxic substances, was named acting deputy administrator. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about summer skiing at Whistler-Blackcomb in British Columbia misstated the location. It is the Coast Mountains, not the Canadian Rockies.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: SENATE PASSES DIPLOMAT PENALTY The United States Senate unanimously approved legislation yesterday that would cut foreign aid to countries that have not paid property taxes owed to cities. The provision would reduce foreign aid to the countries by 110 percent of the amount owed to the city, which would receive the money instead. Foreign countries owe New York City $215 million in taxes and penalties on their consulates and United Nations missions, meaning the city might receive $236.5 million. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Showdown Looms in Europe Over Proposals on Accounting
description: A BATTLE ROYAL over accounting is breaking out in Europe. The leaders of the International Accounting Standards Board, which is trying to impose new rules on financial institutions, have been denounced by one of France's most prominent business leaders as ''ayatollah accountants'' who refuse to be reasonable.

title: In Africa, Money Won't Be Enough (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: CINTAS PROMOTES OPERATING OFFICER TO CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The Cintas Corporation, a supplier of uniforms, said its chief operating officer, Scott D. Farmer, was promoted to chief executive, succeeding Robert J. Kohlhepp. Mr. Kohlhepp, 59, was named vice chairman and will oversee strategic planning and investor relations, the company said. Mr. Farmer, 44, will retain the position of president and is the son of the chairman, Richard T. Farmer. The Farmer family owns about 20 percent of Cintas, the chief financial officer, William C. Gale, said. The company is based in Cincinnati.

title: 3 Power Plants Harming Life In the Hudson, a Study Says
description: A state environmental study has found that three power plants are causing the deaths of numerous fish and other life in the Hudson River each year by sucking in and spewing out river water to cool their condensers.

title: Wrong Remedy in California
description: The strategists behind California's recall effort sent their signature-gathering troops home this week, saying they now had the roughly 900,000 names needed to force a special election aimed at unseating the state's unpopular governor, Gray Davis. While county officials are verifying the signatures, Mr. Davis's associates are nervously digging for legal glitches to delay or stop an election that could happen as early as this fall.

title: A Tap, a Fall and Fury in Milwaukee
description: For three years, it has been a popular audience diversion at Miller Field in Milwaukee, a nightly race on the infield warning track between the sixth and seventh innings involving four sausage mascots: people dressed as a hot dog, a bratwurst, a Polish sausage and an Italian sausage.

title: A Better Mousetrap Is Built, Detecting Deadly Bacteria
description: Taking a biological approach toward detecting biological weapons, scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have genetically engineered white blood cells from mice to light up when they come into contact with deadly bacteria or viruses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COSER, , LEWIS
description: COSER--Lewis. The editors of Dissent Magazine mourn the passing of Lewis Coser, one of its founding editors and leading intellectuals and extend condolences to his entire family. Mitchell Cohen and Michael Walzer, Co-Editors >>AD#

title: Internet Candidates
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINKEL, , BEVERLY
description: FINKEL--Beverly. Wife of the late Arthur Finkel. Cherished mother of Barbara and Lynn. Loving grandmother of Maggie, Laura, and Lee. Her many friends remember her wit, style and humor. One of a kind. Contributions in her memory may be made to Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County, 4601 Community Dr., West Palm Beach, FL 33417. >>AD#

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Suspect In Killings Is Released
description: The police in Elizabeth City said they were forced to free Vincent E. Brothers, a Bakersfield, Calif., man suspected in five deaths, hours after he turned himself in for questioning. Capt. Neil Mahan of the Bakersfield police said investigators had found evidence that cast doubt on whether they could file charges. But the police said Mr. Brothers, 41, remained the sole suspect in the shooting death of his wife, her mother and the couple's three small children.

title: Chinese Underground
description: The dangers of the coal mines of Shandong Province are etched in the faces of its miners.

title: Bush's Africa Trip
description: President Bush visited five African nations to address issues from AIDS to democracy.

title: Pice de Rsistance
description: From the fall collections, get yer red-hot separates. . .

title: Garden Ornaments
description:
By SUZANNE HAMLIN
Garden ornaments can do more than brighten up the grounds; they celebrate the elements around them.

title: Wilderness Epiphanies of Ansel Adams
description: A selection of photographs from "Ansel Adams at 100," now on display at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Framing It
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Hot and Cool on Great Lawn
description: The roughly 50,000 listeners who filled the Great Lawn of Central Park to hear the New York Philharmonic on Thursday had an unusually cool, breezy evening. But the program, conducted by the Philharmonic's new associate conductor, Roberto Minczuk, was a few degrees hotter than usual. Works propelled by Latin dance rhythms and a Spanish score rich in gypsy inflections led up to Leonard Bernstein's jazzy dances from ''West Side Story.''

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA-PAKISTAN BUS SERVICE RESUMES India and Pakistan resumed Delhi-Lahore bus service, which was suspended after a terrorist attack on the Indian Parliament on Dec. 13, 2001. As a luxurious golden colored Delhi Transport Corporation bus was seen off from Delhi, about 20 nationalists protested, saying Indian troops and civilians continue to be attacked by Pakistanis. The bus from Lahore, left, entered India at Wagah. P. J. Anthony (NYT)

title: Man Continues Hostage Standoff in Queens, Police Say
description: A 48-year-old man who the police said had been holding his estranged wife hostage at gunpoint for more than 24 hours remained shut inside a Queens apartment last night. The man had held the same woman hostage twice before, threatening her with a machete, a box cutter and a live electrical cord, a state parole official said.

title: Lawmakers Attack Immigrants' Use of Antitorture Law to Block Deportation
description: Congressional Republicans sharply criticized a four-year-old law today that bars the deportation of immigrants, including those with criminal records, who are likely to be tortured when they return to their countries.

title: COMPUWARE SAYS PROFIT FELL SHORT OF FORECASTS
description: The Compuware Corporation, a maker of software for mainframe computers, said yesterday that profit and revenue in its most recent quarter were lower than analysts' forecasts. Earnings in the period, which ended June 30 and was the first quarter of the company's fiscal year, were about 1 cent a share on sales of $300 million to $305 million, Compuware said. Net income was 6 cents a share on sales of $346.6 million in the period a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected Compuware, which is based in Farmington Hills, Mich., to earn 6 cents a share on sales of $315.1 million.

title: G.E. Says Yearly Profit Rise To Be Smallest in a Decade
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that its annual profit would show its smallest increase in a decade because of slow economic growth and SARS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GIBSON, , JOHN PHILIP
description: GIBSON--John Philip. Age 66. On July 10, 2003, in New York City, of lung cancer. Formerly of U.N.D.P. Beloved husband of Maria Victoria. Dear brother of Michael and Barbara. Interment in Manila. >>AD#

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has confirmed the deaths of the following Americans in the Iraq theater of operations:

title: After 3 Stanley Cups, Devils' Daneyko Retires
description: Ken Daneyko said today that he would have considered coming back to play next season, if the Devils had not won the Stanley Cup last month.

title: Health Hazards Close Beaches
description: The discovery of medical waste and a break in a sewage pipe led the authorities to close beaches in Westchester County and New Jersey yesterday.

title: Plagiarism in Dylan, Or a Cultural Collage?
description: An alert Bob Dylan fan was reading Dr. Junichi Saga's ''Confessions of a Yakuza'' (Kodansha America, 1991) when some familiar phrases jumped out at him. There were a dozen sentences similar to lines from songs on Mr. Dylan's 2001 album, '' 'Love and Theft,' '' particularly one called ''Floater (Too Much to Ask).''

title: Blacks Lose Better Jobs Faster As Middle-Class Work Drops
description: Unemployment among blacks is rising at a faster pace than in any similar period since the mid-1970's, and the jobs lost have been mostly in manufacturing, where the pay for blacks has historically been higher than in many other fields.

title: Conserving Water: Everyone Can Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Here's Uncle Zeus, Aunt Hera, the Twins ...
description: It was about 20 years ago when Jon O. Newman, a federal appeals court judge in Manhattan, walked up to a staff member in the New York Public Library and asked, ''Do you have a book anywhere in this library that has a complete genealogical chart of Greek mythology?'' They didn't.

title: Wariness and Sadness in Town Changed by a Mine Rescue
description: In two weeks, this town in the coal-rich hills of Southwestern Pennsylvania will celebrate the first anniversary of what people here call ''the miracle'': the rescue of nine men trapped for 77 harrowing hours in a flooded mine 240 feet below the surface.

title: Bush Administration Says Title IX Should Stay as It Is
description: The Bush administration, which had been considering changes that might have eased standards for satisfying the law that expanded opportunities for girls and women in sports, instead reaffirmed yesterday how the law, known as Title IX, is enforced.

title: Lingering Questions About Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLINE, , HENRY CHAPMAN
description: KLINE--Henry Chapman, retired Vice President of Grumman Aerospace Corporation (Bethpage), formerly of Smithtown, NY and Stamford, CT, died Thursday, July 10, 2003 in his adopted city of Buffalo, NY. For 52 years Harry was the most devoted husband of Juliet Emma Gentile Kline, the proud father of four daughters, Elizabeth Mullan of Pacific Palisades, CA, Victoria Band of Chapel Hill, NC, Anne Amato of Harrison, NY and Mary Bacon of Buffalo, NY and one son Henry Kline, Jr. of NJ. Dear grandfather of seventeen adoring grandchildren who will miss him dearly. Family will receive friends on Monday July 14, 2003 from 24PM and 7-9PM at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Funeral service will be held at 10 AM on Tuesday, July 15, 2003 at St. Francis Episcopal Church, 503 Old Long Ridge Rd., Stamford, CT. Interment will follow Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the screenwriter and director George Axelrod on June 23 referred incorrectly to his 1971 book ''Where Am I Now When I Need Me?,'' which was cited as the source for a brief description of his childhood in New York. While its description of the main character as a stage-struck youth accurately reflected Mr. Axelrod's own experience, it is a novel, not a memoir.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: ANOTHER CHAPTER IN TOURIST WAR The daily Bild is organizing a free flight for Germans to the Italian resort at Rimini, continuing a campaign against an Italian tourism official who called Germans "hypernationalists" who "invaded the beaches of Italy." Bild also published Italian phrases that German tourists might need: "Do I disturb you if I spend my euros here?" or "I'm happy to introduce you to my blond girlfriend." Late Friday, the Italian official, Stefano Stefani, told Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi he had resigned, the Italian news agency Ansa reported. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NOBLE CORP., Sugar Land, Tex., which drills for oil and natural gas off the coasts of five continents, exercised an option to buy a rig in the Middle East from Schlumberger Ltd., New York, for $25.2 million.

title: Dorothy Miller Is Dead at 99; Discovered American Artists
description: Dorothy Miller, one of the first curators hired by the Museum of Modern Art, in 1934, and the woman responsible for pioneering exhibitions of new American artists that helped propel generations of painters like Pollock, Rothko, Frank Stella and Jasper Johns onto the international scene, died yesterday at her apartment in Greenwich Village. She was 99.

title: Verizon Is Told It Must Reinstate 2,300 Workers Let Go Last Year
description: An arbitrator has ruled that Verizon Communications improperly laid off 2,300 workers in December and must reinstate them, a decision that union officials hailed but that company executives said underlined Verizon's need to gain more flexibility in contract talks to cut costs.

title: A Web Site Causes Unease in Police
description: William Sheehan does not like the police. He expresses his views about what he calls police corruption in Washington State on his Web site, where he also posts lists of police officers' addresses, home phone numbers and Social Security numbers.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Privatization Advancing
description: The government will sell its remaining stakes in five already privatized companies. Arun Shourie, minister for disinvestment, information technology and communications, announced after a meeting of a government panel on privatization on Thursday that the government would sell its stakes in the software company CMC; an international phone and Internet service provider, Videsh Sanchar Nigam; the Indian Petrochemicals Corporation; an oil retailer, IBP; and the Bharat Aluminium Company. All of the companies were privatized in the last three years. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Bus Crash Kills 21
description: A double-decker bus collided with a truck on a mountain road in the New Territories on Wednesday, careened onto a guard rail, then fell nearly 100 feet down a cliff. The crash killed 21 and injured 20, of whom three were in critical condition. The truck driver was arrested on suspicion of dangerous driving. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An architecture review on Tuesday about the new National Constitution Center in Philadelphia misstated the number of squares in William Penn's original plan for the city. It was five, not four.

title: Court Upholds Ruling on T.W.A. Pensions
description: Pension plans for the employees of Trans World Airlines, which was acquired by the AMR Corporation in 2001, were terminated properly by the United States Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, a federal appeals court has ruled.

title: Russian Authorities Search Office of Powerful Oil Tycoon
description: Russian authorities today stepped up a criminal investigation of a powerful oil tycoon, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, as Russian police officers, some wearing black ski masks and carrying guns, searched the offices of Yukos Oil Company, the tycoon's flagship company.

title: About New York; With the Fish, And Feeling Quite Herself
description: AT first the lookdown fish, those silvery dinner plates of the sea, wanted nothing to do with her. The moment she dipped her tail fin into the water, they darted off to the coral-reef corners of the aquarium, as if to shun another creature that would dare to be as exotic.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Chaim Engel, who helped carry out an escape in 1943 from the Nazi death camp at Sobibor, misspelled the surname of the author of a 1982 book about the feat. He is Richard Rashke, not Raske.

title: Schumer Seeks Aid to Extend Witness Shield
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer is proposing a federal program that would allow state and local prosecutors around the country to better protect their witnesses in violent crime cases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   UNGAR, , MANYA
description: UNGAR--Manya, of Scotch Plains, NJ, former President of the National PTA. Wife of H.F. ''Skip'' Ungar. Mother of Paul and Michael. A memorial service will be held at Memorial Funeral Home, 155 South Ave, Fanwood, NJ, on Monday, July 14, at 2 PM. Contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society and the National PTA. To honor her memory, do as she did: volunteer and be active in your local schools, PTA and community. >>AD#

title: The Rich Get Richer, and O'Neal Stands a Little Taller
description: The giant, humbled no more, could not help gloating. Standing in the kitchen of his off-season home in Orlando, Fla., yesterday morning, Shaquille O'Neal issued a warning to the peasants, who today resemble the rest of the N.B.A.

title: CARMAX SAYS SALES MAY DOUBLE IN FOUR YEARS
description: CarMax Inc., the used-car retailer spun off from Circuit City Stores Inc., said it would ''roughly double'' sales to $8 billion by its 2007 fiscal year. It also plans to open as many as 44 new stores over four years, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. CarMax, which is based in Glen Allen, Va., has been capitalizing on demand for used vehicles and selling some of its new-car franchises. Used-cars accounted for 90 percent of the vehicles the company sold in the year that ended May 31. CarMax had $3.97 billion in sales in fiscal 2003, which ended in February.

title: Corrections
description: Credits in The Arts on Monday for three pictures by Li Zhensheng with an article about an exhibition of his long-hidden photographs of the Cultural Revolution in China misstated the supplier. The pictures -- of two party secretaries being denounced, of eight people being executed and of swimmers studying the words of Mao Zedong -- should have been attributed to Li Zhensheng/Contact Press Images.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Oracle Adding Jobs
description: The Oracle Corporation will almost double jobs in its Indian unit in the near term, the chief executive, Lawrence J. Ellison, said in a videoconference with partners, customers and reporters here. The unit will increase jobs to 6,000 from 3,200, Mr. Ellison said. Oracle is also building a new campus on seven acres in the southern city of Hyderabad and it is expected to open by early 2005, Keith Budge, the company's regional managing director for South Asia, said.

title: Liberian Faction Says It May Fight Peacekeepers
description: In an effort to increase the pressure on President Charles Taylor to step aside, the rebel group that calls itself Liberians United for Reconciliation and Democracy threatened today to fight West African peacekeepers if they arrived before Mr. Taylor's departure.

title: Josephine Jacobsen, 94, Former Poet Laureate
description: Josephine Jacobsen, a poet, short-story writer and critic who held the post that later became that of national poet laureate, died on Wednesday in Cockeysville, Md. She was 94 and had lived in Maryland most of her life.

title: Home of Dead Foster Child Was Called Clean by Agency
description: City officials said yesterday that the home of the severely disabled 8-year-old girl whose body was found in a garbage truck on Wednesday had been visited a total of four times by three different caseworkers since March and each time was reported to be clean.

title: Builder Rules Out Syracuse for Mega-Mall, Official Says
description: An official at an upstate development company said today that the company had decided not to build the nation's largest mall and tourist center in Syracuse.

title: Lewis Coser, 89, Sociologist Who Focused on Intellectuals
description: Lewis Alfred Coser, a politically active sociologist who grappled with the social role of intellectuals in influential books, articles and speeches, as well as in his personal politics, died on Tuesday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 89 and lived in Cambridge.

title: Sharon to Visit Britain and Meet Bush in U.S. to Press Peace Effort
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon will go to Britain on Sunday and visit President Bush in the United States later this month as part of an effort to build momentum for the current Middle East peace effort, Israeli officials said today.

title: PATRIOT GAMES -- Answer Key
Shore Community Sues Utility Over Costs of Power Failures
description: An Ocean County community filed a lawsuit yesterday against Jersey Central Power and Light to try to win back the costs of coping with power failures that crippled businesses, put traffic lights out of commission and scared tourists away during the Fourth of July weekend.

title: Denying Felons a Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: LIBERTY TO PAY FOR QVC WITH STOCK AND 3-YEAR NOTE
description: The Liberty Media Corporation will pay $2.6 billion in stock and a three-year note valued at $5.3 billion to buy the Comcast Corporation's 57 percent stake in the QVC home-shopping network, giving Liberty full ownership of the channel. Liberty agreed last week to buy QVC for $7.9 billion. The company, based in Englewood, Calif., had the option to pay a combination of stock, cash or a promissory note. Liberty will issue 280 million shares, the maximum allowed under the sale agreement, representing about 7.5 percent of its outstanding stock.

title: Monsanto Sues Dairy in Maine Over Label's Remarks on Hormones
description: In another sign of how contentious food labeling issues have become in recent years, the Monsanto Company has sued a small milk producer in Portland, Me., over the labeling of its dairy products.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about progress in prosecuting Balkan war crimes at the United Nations tribunal in The Hague referred incorrectly in some copies to the anniversary of the massacre of thousands of Bosnian Muslims at Srebrenica. When the article was written, on July 4, it had been almost eight years since the killings, not seven.

title: AMERICA ONLINE DROPS SOME LINKS TO AMAZON.COM
description: America Online has started a service to sell videos and compact discs online, ending part of its relationship with Amazon.com Inc. America Online is selling the products directly on its entertainment Web site and is removing some links to Amazon.com's online store, Bill Wilson, senior vice president of AOL Entertainment, said. America Online, a unit of AOL Time Warner, also expects to offer music downloads on its own site by year-end, he said. AOL, which has 26 million subscribers to its Internet access service, has been trying to build its entertainment site's audience by offering exclusive recordings, interviews and other unique material, Mr. Wilson said. America Online and Amazon.com have worked together on marketing since 1997.

title: In Tenet's Words: 'I Am Responsible' for Review
description: Following is the text of a statement yesterday by George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, as provided by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Sports of The Times; The Winners, but Not Yet Champions: The Nets
description: There is no known nirvana in professional sports, no perfect place or team or coaching staff. There are only situations, good, bad or what the Nets formerly were, unbearably ugly.

title: Viking and Packer Suspended by N.F.L.
description: Minnesota Vikings tight end Byron Chamberlain and Green Bay Packers linebacker Torrance Marshall were suspended for the first four regular-season games for violating the N.F.L.'s substance-abuse policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANDEL, , LENARD
description: MANDEL--Lenard. Elected to the Board five years ago, Lenard Mandell was a significant presence whose brilliance and measured reason brought clarity and understanding to each issue he met. His guidance always came with wisdom and a wry wit. We shall always remember his dedication to the organization's mission of bringing a finely tuned musical experience to the world. Heartfelt thoughts go to children Richard and Carol, brother Robert and five grandchildren. Board of Trustees New York Youth Symphony Leslie J. Garfield, Chair Barry Goldberg, Executive Director >>AD#

title: C.I.A. CHIEF TAKES BLAME IN ASSERTION ON IRAQI URANIUM
description: The director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet, accepted responsibility yesterday for letting President Bush use information that turned out to be unsubstantiated in his State of the Union address, accusing Iraq of trying to acquire uranium from Africa to make nuclear weapons.

title: Woman Killed and Man Is Shot in Home Invasion
description: A woman was dead and her husband was in surgery last night for gunshot wounds, a neighbor said, after what is believed to have been a home invasion in Rye Brook in Westchester County. The mayor said it was the first killing in the community in 15 years.

title: Czar Wars: Mussorgsky's Drama of 1690's Revolts
description: Don't be surprised if you find yourself baffled by the story of Mussorgsky's folk-music drama ''Khovanshchina,'' which opened at the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday night as part of the Lincoln Center Festival in a lavish yet reverent production by the Kirov Opera. The cluttered plot reflects the convulsive times the opera depicts.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: PRIVATIZATION ADVANCING The government will sell its remaining stakes in five already privatized companies. Arun Shourie, minister for disinvestment, information technology and communications, announced after a meeting of a government panel on privatization on Thursday that the government would sell its stakes in the software company CMC; an international phone and Internet service provider, Videsh Sanchar Nigam ; the Indian Petrochemicals Corporation; an oil retailer, IBP; and the Bharat Aluminium Company. All of the companies were privatized in the last three years. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Confessed Killer Kills Himself
description: A man who pleaded guilty to murdering a woman and her two children on April 28 hanged himself in his prison cell in St. Cloud. The man, Jonathan Carpenter, 21, was found dead on Thursday, hanging by his bed sheets. Mr. Carpenter left a suicide note, officials said. He was serving three life sentences without parole for slitting the throats of Holly Chromey, 49, of Long Prairie; her teenage son, Jerrod Zapzalka, and her daughter Katie Zapzalka. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about growing political opposition to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposed charter revision to establish a nonpartisan election system reversed the results for a question about the issue from a New York Times poll in June. Sixty-four percent of New York City residents said ballots should continue to list party affiliations; 22 percent supported a change.

title: Yanks in Trade Talks With Mets and Giants
description: With their top trade target, reliever Ugueth Urbina, traded to Florida from Texas tonight, the Yankees have moved into serious talks with the Mets about Armando Benitez and with the San Francisco Giants about Felix Rodriguez, two Yankees officials said.

title: Corrections
description: A question-and-answer interview in Science Times on Tuesday with Dr. Shirley Tilghman, the molecular geneticist who is president of Princeton, referred incorrectly to her children. She has a son and a daughter, not two daughters.

title: CIGNA SAYS PROFIT IN QUARTER WAS LESS THAN FORECAST
description: The Cigna Corporation said second-quarter profit was less than it had forecast because of rising costs in its health care business. The company said second-quarter earnings were $1 to $1.15 a share, and it projected full-year profit of $5 to $5.25 a share. Analysts had expected the company to earn $1.48 a share in the second quarter and $6.01 in 2003. Cigna is struggling with higher medical costs and fewer clients.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an opera review on Monday about productions of ''Tristan und Isolde'' and ''Idomeneo'' at the Glyndebourne Festival in Britain misspelled the current name of a theater in Munich where Wagner once considered staging ''Tristan.'' It is the Cuvillis-Theater, not Cuvilli.

title: A Regents Moratorium
description: To the Editor:

title: With Mountains Ahead, A Toast to Days Gone By
description: People from Bernard Thvenet's native hamlet of Le Guidon in Burgundy, those from the surrounding village of St.-Julien de Civry and everybody in the small world of bicycle racing who likes Thvenet, which is everybody who knows him, turned out today to honor him.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SCHMEELK, , GARRETT
description: SCHMEELK--Garrett. Your kindness, love and sparkle will live on in our hearts forever. You are missed and loved dearly. Betty, Marrie and Virgini

title: Canada Presses to Reopen Markets for Its Beef Exports
description: Nearly two months after the carcass of a single cow tested positive for mad cow disease, Canada has begun a desperate diplomatic campaign to reopen international markets to its beef exports. But no relief for the country's stricken cattle industry seems near.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Corsican Separatists Sentenced
description: France sentenced eight Corsican separatists to prison terms ranging from 15 years to life for the 1998 killing of Claude Erignac, the highest official on the French Mediterranean island. The suspected gunman in the case, Yvan Colonna, was captured a week ago and will be tried separately. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Patriot Games
description: And now, some fireworks for the brain. First solve eight puzzles. Each puzzle will give you a final answer that is a five-letter word. Once you've solved those puzzles, follow instructions for the star-shaped puzzle to get our vote for the best way to spend the Fourth of July holiday weekend.

title: Police Official Is Charged With Fraud
description: A top New York City police official was charged yesterday in federal court in Manhattan with diverting more than $110,000 from a nonprofit foundation to cover his personal bills for collect telephone calls involving prison inmates, according to court papers.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Stopping Bank Robbers
description: To the Editor:

title: MONACO COACH SAYS EARNINGS WERE WEAK LAST QUARTER
description: The Monaco Coach Corporation, the maker of Dynasty and Diplomat motor homes, warned that its second-quarter earnings were less than analysts' estimates as the company offered discounts to clear inventory. The company said the earnings were ''slightly above break-even,'' compared with net income of $11 million, or 37 cents a share, in the period a year ago. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast earnings of 15 cents a share. The company, based in Coburg, Ore., said sales were $266 million to $268 million, down from $313.7 million a year ago. Monaco's stock fell 65 cents, or 4 percent, to $14.95 a share.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India-Pakistan Bus Service Resumes
description: India and Pakistan resumed Delhi-Lahore bus service, which was suspended after a terrorist attack on the Indian Parliament on Dec. 13, 2001. As a luxurious golden colored Delhi Transport Corporation bus was seen off from Delhi, about 20 nationalists protested, saying Indian troops and civilians continue to be attacked by Pakistanis. The bus from Lahore, left, entered India at Wagah. P. J. Anthony (NYT)

title: In Scramble for Superstars, Nets Keep Their Own: Kidd
description: Jason Kidd, the All-Star point guard whose uncanny passing and exemplary leadership resurrected the New Jersey Nets out of the N.B.A. wasteland and into the league finals the past two seasons, announced yesterday that he would stay with the Nets for six more years instead of going to the league champion San Antonio Spurs.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Sale Of Violent Video Games
description: A federal judge approved a preliminary injunction against a law banning the sale of violent video games to minors, saying it might violate constitutional free-speech protections. The judge, Robert S. Lasnik of Federal District Court, sided with the video game industry in approving the injunction. The law, which was set to go into effect on July 27, concerns games depicting violence against the police. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: National Briefing: South
description: ARKANSAS: PROBLEMS IN HOME FOR MENTALLY ILL A state home for the mentally ill where five patients have died in the last eleven months is systemically flawed and in urgent need of additional staff and other resources, a consultant reported to the Department of Human Services. "There is not a system that is not broken" at the Arkansas Health Center at Benton, said the consultant, David French. The review was especially critical of the pharmacy at the 300-patient home, which officials said had made errors that led to two of the five deaths.

title: A Test of American Compassion
description: President Bush's successful trip to Africa this week is emblematic of a larger journey. As a presidential candidate, Mr. Bush was dismissive of Africa's importance to American interests. Now he has become only the third American president, and the first Republican, to make an extended visit to sub-Saharan Africa. Over five days in five countries, he addressed a variety of important themes: the cruel legacy of slavery, the current crises in Liberia and Zimbabwe, and most important, the challenge of AIDS and America's commitment to helping Africa fight it with treatment and prevention programs that can save millions of lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BONSAING, , EDWARD G. ''JERRY''
description: BONSAING--Edward G. ''Jerry'', died at his home at age 57 in Southampton, L.I. after a long battle with cancer. He is survived by his beloved sister, Barbara Feeney and his brother-in-law Patrick Feeney and was the loving uncle of Patrick Joseph Feeney, his wife Daisy and their daughters Isabella and Juliana. Barbara Ann Milmore and her husband John and their children Elizabeth, Kaitlyn, John and Christina. Jerry held several important posts at leading advertising agencies among them Wm. Esty and Bates USA and was one of the start up employees at the Backer & Spielvogel Agency. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Sunday, July 13, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial will be on Monday, July 14, 11AM at Blessed Sacrament R.C. Church on West 71st Street between Columbus and Broadway Avenues. Graveside services at Sacred Heart of Jesus and Mary Cemetery in Southampton, L.I. at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, NYC. >>AD#

title: Computers Battle in France, And the Dutch Win Again
description: Computer bridge programs are steadly improving. Most of them use simulations, which help plan ahead in the bidding and play. The seventh annual World Computer Championship was played in Menton, France, at the end of June, and the winner, for the third straight year, was the Dutch program Jack, now clearly established as the world's best. It is the brainchild of Hans Kuijf, with Wim Heemskerk and Martin Pattenier as collaborators.

title: How the Other Half Photographs: Looking Globally
description: The study of photography has been expanding its boundaries lately. Too long confined to the discourse of art history and the continents of Europe and North America, the discipline is at last yielding substantial books and exhibitions devoted to the photography of Japan, Africa, Latin America and India, and to the distinctive photographies that have grown out of medicine, the criminal justice system, the family, anthropology and so on.

title: Investigations Of Chemicals Will Continue
description: The Pentagon has assured Congress that it will not shut down its inquiry into a cold war program that tested the vulnerability of American forces to chemical or biological attack, officials said today.

title: Parental Guidance Required
description: Early Sunday morning, I got an emergency call on my portable radio from a sergeant asking for assistance at the Skate Key, a South Bronx roller rink that becomes a hip-hop music club at night, with crowds of up to 1,000 people, many of them teenagers. When I arrived at the scene, there was a great deal of confusion: people screaming, blood-soaked sidewalks, teenagers crying in pain. Four people had been stabbed (one of them a young security guard), and five police officers had been injured trying to stem the violence.

title: Fierce Fight for an Honorary Title; In Harlem, 2 Contenders Who Love to Be Called Mayor
description: In politics, as in many forms of war, the size of the prize can often have little bearing on the fierceness of the fight, and it is frequently the case that campaigns are waged with an intensity beyond all proportion to the office being sought.

title: Digging a Hole for the Future
description: The tourists packing Washington these days to see what really goes on in the Capitol have an irresistible metaphor at hand as the Republican-led Congress digs ever deeper deficits and debt into the nation's future. A gigantic hole has been excavated on the east side of the Capitol for what will be the new underground visitors center. And, just like the federal budget, the center is already running a deficit: $48 million above its initial price tag of $303 million, with more looming.

title: Palestinian Village Finds Itself Walled In, Not Out
description: Ishan Awad's well-tended garden, anchored by olive and palm trees and lined with pink roses, is a soothing place to spend a summer afternoon sipping thick black coffee.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Problems In Home For Mentally Ill
description: A state home for the mentally ill where five patients have died in the last eleven months is systemically flawed and in urgent need of additional staff and other resources, a consultant reported to the Department of Human Services. ''There is not a system that is not broken'' at the Arkansas Health Center at Benton, said the consultant, David French. The review was especially critical of the pharmacy at the 300-patient home, which officials said had made errors that led to two of the five deaths. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: In Judah-Corley Fight, Clothes Will Clash, Too
description: Don't kid yourself, Zab Judah says. His fight Saturday night with DeMarcus Corley is not just about bad blood, trash talk and money.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MINNESOTA: CONFESSED KILLER KILLS HIMSELF A man who pleaded guilty to murdering a woman and her two children on April 28 hanged himself in his prison cell in St. Cloud. The man, Jonathan Carpenter, 21, was found dead on Thursday, hanging by his bed sheets. Mr. Carpenter left a suicide note, officials said. He was serving three life sentences without parole for slitting the throats of Holly Chromey, 49, of Long Prairie; her teenage son, Jerrod Zapzalka, and her daughter Katie Zapzalka.    Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OBERLANDER, , HARRY L.
description: OBERLANDER -- Harry L. Died on July 10th at the age of 89. Beloved husband of the late Belle (nee Semel). Devoted father of Martin (Mickey) and Rose, and the late Dr. Samuel and Monica. Cherished grandfather of nine. Loving great-grandfather of seven. Dear brother of Abe and Melvyn. Services at Wellwood Cemetery, Wellwood Ave, Farmingdale, NY Sunday at 2 PM. >>AD#

description: BASEBALL

title: City Police and Fire Department Pledge Cooperation in Disasters
description: Reversing positions they took in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terror attack, New York City's police and fire commissioners said yesterday that they had agreed to adopt formal rules for how emergency agencies should work together in responding to major disasters.

title: INSIDE
description: Provisions of Title IX Upheld

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Luxury Goods Rebound
description: The chief executive of the Gucci Group, Domenico De Sole, said demand for luxury goods revived in the last two months as shoppers in Asia returned to stores. ''We see a dramatic improvement in retail operations in May and most importantly in the month of June,'' he said in a televised interview. ''There's been a dramatic bounce-back in Asia.''

title: Police Officer's Shooting Death Still Unclassified
description: Two days after a New York City police lieutenant was found fatally shot in her home on Long Island, investigators yesterday had yet to classify her case as an accident, a suicide or a murder.

title: Irate Customer Charged With Menacing
description: A customer at a fast-food restaurant in the Bronx who claimed to have found a mouse in his food was charged with menacing the manager with a chair yesterday, the police said.

title: Journalism in Colombia
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Warning On Denver Air
description: Denver may be returning to the federal government's list of cities with bad air less than a year after it was taken off and given a clean rating. Officials with the State Department of Public Health and Environment said that tougher standards were making compliance more difficult and that the ozone had not increased and the air was not dirtier. Public health officials said they hoped to correct the problems by possibly changing the auto emissions program and tightening rules on utilities and manufacturing. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Architecture's Irascible Reformer
description: Moss grows from the steep, pitched roof of the West Dean Gardens visitors' center. Carefully trained grape vines hug its walls. And the facade, approached by a curving gravel path, is a pleasing tapestry of flint, brick, concrete and Portland stone.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Insurer Acquired
description: Assicurazioni Generali agreed to buy a smaller French rival, Continent, which sells life, property and casualty insurance, for 290 million euros ($330.1 million). Assicurazioni Generali, based in Trieste, is buying Continent from Toro Assicurazioni, a former unit of Fiat.

title: Something to Hide?
description: To the Editor:

title: HealthSouth Looks Deeper Into Its Books
description: Internal investigators at HealthSouth have found evidence of dubious accounting that raises new questions about the role of the company's former auditor, Ernst & Young.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Airline Cuts Capacity
description: The national carrier Swiss International Air Lines said it was cutting capacity and the number of long-haul destination cities by a quarter because of the downturn in air travel. It also said it would cut its European destinations to 41 from 56. The airline's percentage of filled seats declined slightly in Europe and abroad for the first half of this year, compared with the period last year. The carrier said it would cut capacity by 27 percent and reduce its fleet to 79 planes. It said the decline in Europe reflected a ''weak first quarter, with demand picking up strongly in May and June.'' It also noted that fear of severe acute respiratory syndrome had a big effect on its international business, forcing it to suspend flights to Beijing and reduce service to Hong Kong. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: EL PASO TO SELL ASPHALT AND OIL UNITS FOR $102 MILLION
description: The El Paso Corporation, an owner of natural gas pipelines, said it would sell two businesses for $102 million. It also said it recorded second-quarter expenses of as much as $1.5 billion as it wrote down the value of assets. El Paso is selling an asphalt business to Trigeant EP Ltd. for about $90 million, including inventory valued at about $55 million, the company said. The Louisiana Lease Crude unit was sold to Plains All American Pipeline for about $12 million, including inventory valued at about $2 million, El Paso said. El Paso, which is based in Houston, recorded pretax expenses of $1.3 billion to $1.5 billion in the second quarter to account for a drop in the value of some assets, including an oil refinery in Aruba.

title: NASA Management Failings Are Linked to Shuttle Demise
description: Management failure at NASA was as important in the destruction of the shuttle Columbia and the loss of its crew as the chunk of foam that knocked a hole in its wing, the chairman of the Columbia Accident Investigation Board said today.

title: Charter to Sell Junk Bonds
description: Charter Communications Inc., the cable-television company controlled by the billionaire Paul Allen, will sell about $1.7 billion of junk bonds, gaining cash to buy back some convertible notes and more time to pay debt.

title: Yankees Squander a Lead but Rivera Saves Another
description: It is the baseball equivalent of a guitar string snapping or a pianist striking the wrong key. The inelegant, imperfect crack of a bat breaking has been the soundtrack to so many crucial Yankees victories. It means Mariano Rivera is on the mound, and on his game.

title: A Lawyer's Mind Channels Moses
description: The book jacket is enough to invite double takes -- ''Moses: A Memoir.'' When did Moses find time to jot down his thoughts? While fleeing Egypt with the Israelites? Between trips up Mount Sinai to receive God's commandments and law? Then again, he did wander in the desert for 40 years and live to be 120.

title: The Bright Stuff
description: The time has come for us brights to come out of the closet. What is a bright? A bright is a person with a naturalist as opposed to a supernaturalist world view. We brights don't believe in ghosts or elves or the Easter Bunny -- or God. We disagree about many things, and hold a variety of views about morality, politics and the meaning of life, but we share a disbelief in black magic -- and life after death.

title: Baseball Looks for Way To Give Clemens Star Turn
description: Major League Baseball rushed to add Florida Marlins pitcher Dontrelle Willis to the National League All-Star team yesterday after a roster spot became available, and there were indications that baseball officials might also try to add Yankees pitcher Roger Clemens.

title: Transforming Frogs and Teenagers
description: This weekend offers two life-affirming fables. Each of these television films telegraphs its trajectory within minutes. Each follows its course to a fortune-cookie-quality moral about the magical power of love (and the lovely power of magic). Taken together, however, they offer another kind of lesson: slick professionalism pales beside heartfelt storytelling.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Cameras For High-Crime Areas
description: The police will soon install several cameras throughout high-crime neighborhoods in Chicago in an effort to curb gang violence. Each camera will cost $15,000 and will have a control panel that officers can use in their squad cars to zoom in to a specific area, The control panels will cost $7,000 each. The police would not say how many cameras would be used, but they said the cameras would probably be on the South and West Sides. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Attack G.O.P. In TV Ads on Medicare Bill
description: Fearful of losing ground to Republicans on the potent issue of Medicare, House Democrats today began broadcasting television commercials attacking Republican lawmakers around the country for their support of the House-passed plan to create a new prescription drug benefit.

title: Machinists' Union Endorses Gephardt
description: The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers endorsed Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri for president yesterday, becoming the sixth union to do so and adding to his campaign momentum among organized labor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, , DOROTHY C.
description: MILLER--Dorothy C. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art and the Members of its International Council mourn the loss of their beloved and gentle colleague and friend, Dorothy Miller who, together with Alfred H. Barr, Jr., the Museum's founding Director, built the Museum's collection and exhibition program during its formative years. Throughout Dorothy's 35 years as a brilliant museum curator, she organized many landmark exhibitions, which recognized undiscovered talented American artists. These pioneering shows contributed greatly in building public awareness of the rich and diverse work by major artists who first emerged in the middle of the 20th Century. Although she retired from the Museum in 1969, as Curator of Museum Collections, her exuberant love of art and inspiring influence on the younger staff remain as part of her legacy. A longterm member of the Museum's International Council and Honorary Trustee of the Museum, Dorothy was first and foremost a passionate advocate for artists. We extend our deepest sympathy to her nephew, Reid White, her niece, Mrs. Edith White Danton, and her step-daughter, Jane Cahill Blumenfeld. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art Brian Urquhart, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President The Internation Council of the Museum of Modern Art >>AD#

description: INTERNATIONAL A2-4

title: STOCK IN SONUS NETWORKS RISES ON VERIZON DEAL
description: Shares of Sonus Networks Inc. surged 24 percent yesterday after the company announced a deal with Verizon Communications. An unexpectedly strong earnings report, released after the market's close on Thursday, also supported the price. Sonus, which is based in Westford, Mass., makes hardware and software for voice and data networks. Verizon is using Sonus's voice equipment in its central offices. Financial terms were not disclosed. On Thursday, Sonus reported a net loss of $3.2 million, or 1 cent a share, on revenue of $21.4 million for the quarter. The company reported a net loss of $17.8 million, or 9 cents a share in the quarter last year. Sonus's stock rose $1.38, to $7.10 a share.

description: In a league where centers tower over seven feet, Alonzo Mourning made his presence known with an inflated number that added two inches to his 6-8 height and with an intensity that measured off the charts.

description: A young woman says she was assaulted and raped by a group of men in a quiet park near Yale University on Thursday evening, the police said today.

title: Poor in Money, but Even Poorer in Democracy
description: African chiefs, whether the old variety in feathered hats or the modern kind in military fatigues with Kalashnikovs, always travel with gifts and rewards. President Bush has followed that time-honored tradition in his trip to Africa this week by showcasing his $15 billion pledge to fight AIDS in Africa and the Caribbean and his $100 million fund to help combat terrorism and promote development.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on June 29 about Europe's aging population and its consequences for pensions misstated the percentage of older European men who are employed. According to a report by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the figure is 49 percent of men in the organization's European countries, aged 55 to 64, not 39 percent.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Minimum Wages Rising
description: The government is raising minimum wages and pensions to spur consumer spending and bolster the country's timid economic recovery. The economy minister, Roberto Lavagna, announced the plan on Thursday to raise monthly minimum wages to 250 pesos ($90) from 200 pesos ($72) this month and then gradually to 300 pesos ($108) by December. Pensioners' allowances will rise to 220 pesos ($80) from 200 pesos. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: A Sunken Link To Oliver Cromwell
description: After two weeks' exploring a shipwreck in Waterford harbor, divers for the Irish state heritage service said they believed it to be the remains of the Great Louis, part of Oliver Cromwell's fleet that attacked a nearby fort in 1645. The boat was discovered during a dredging operation in the harbor, a busy shipping area, the state radio broadcaster RTE reported. Brian Lavery (NYT)
