title: Solutions for the Salton Sea
description: Southern California's Salton Sea has lost much of the appeal it once enjoyed with tourists. A lot of the fish died off, and people began worrying about pollution. To the fish that still call it home, however, as well the millions of birds that use it as a migratory stopover, the Salton Sea is still crucial. At the moment it is caught in the middle of an interstate dispute that threatens to reduce, if not entirely cut off, its chief source of water: irrigation runoff from Imperial Valley farms.

title: Diana Charity Halts Grants, Citing Lawsuit
description: The charity set up in honor of Diana, the Princess of Wales, said today that it was cutting off all grants because of a financial crisis brought on by a lawsuit filed by the Franklin Mint, the company that specializes in commemorative dolls, dishes and baubles featuring celebrities, living and dead.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Banks Consider Acquisition
description: The British bank Lloyds is preparing to exit Brazil, and at least five banks -- including Citigroup, ABN Amro, and the top two local private banks, Bradesco and Ita -- are interested in picking up its consumer finance business. Market analysts said the British bank's most attractive asset is Losango, its consumer finance arm, with a credit portfolio of nearly $700 million and 14 million clients. Analysts expect the sale might fetch more than $350 million; Lloyds officials were not immediately available for comment. ''This is a very attractive niche of a bank with well-segmented business,'' said Tomas Awad, bank analyst at Itau-BBA Corretora, a So Paulo brokerage house. ''The economy may be stalled at the moment, but the consumer credit market has great potential in the future.'' Tony Smith (NYT)

title: U.S. FORCES GIRDING FOR RAIDS BY IRAQIS
description: American intelligence agencies are warning of a possible new wave of attacks against United States forces in Iraq during the next week to coincide with anniversaries tied to Saddam Hussein and the Baath Party, military officials said today.

title: Ex-Superintendent of Air Force Academy Is Demoted in Wake of Rape Scandal
description: The former superintendent of the Air Force Academy, Lt. Gen. John Dallager, has been demoted by one star, in the clearest move yet to punish a commanding officer after the sexual assault scandal at the school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CORNELL, , PHYLLIS LEVINE
description: CORNELL--Phyllis Levine, a beautiful, courageous lady, July 10, 2003. Devoted, beloved wife of the late Dr. Albert Cornell; dear mother of Leslie, Jan and Wendy; cherished mother-in-law of Matt Neuman and Mikhail Levin; adoring, loving grandmother of Aurora, Theo and Gleb; great-grandmother of Misha; aunt and great aunt. For fifty years she worked tirelessly by her husband's side in his medical practice; former President of Park Avenue Synagogue's Sisterhood; former member of Manhattan Community Board #

title: Recycling Comes Back
description: New Yorkers are an adaptable bunch. Just since last year, they have adjusted to traffic-flow changes in Midtown, noise crackdowns in neighborhoods and smoking bans in restaurants and bars. Keeping up with the rules on recycling, however, may prove a singular challenge. Recycling is back, but in a way that will require some real sorting out.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Another Chapter In Tourist War
description: The daily Bild is organizing a free flight for Germans to the Italian resort at Rimini, continuing a campaign against an Italian tourism official who called Germans ''hypernationalists'' who ''invaded the beaches of Italy.'' Bild also published Italian phrases that German tourists might need: ''Do I disturb you if I spend my euros here?'' or ''I'm happy to introduce you to my blond girlfriend.'' Late Friday, the Italian official, Stefano Stefani, told Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi he had resigned, the Italian news agency Ansa reported. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Bush Has Praise for Uganda In Its Fight Against AIDS
description: President Bush praised Uganda today as a model for how African nations can succeed in combating AIDS and pledged that the United States would help underwrite efforts to fight an epidemic that has cost millions of lives and disrupted efforts by many countries to lift themselves from poverty.

description: To the Editor:

description: ROTHSTEIN -- Edward H. Died July 9, 2003. Survived by his brother, Robert Z. Rothstein, his children, Patty Dashefsky, James Rothstein, Peggy Wollins, Ellen Slater and Linda Gruen, his grandchildren David and Keith Dashefsky, Andrew and Michael Rothstein, DJ and Evan Wollins. title: His Headlines Pack Punch. Indonesia Hits Back.
description: IN the boldest traditions of tabloid newspapers, Mr. Supratman, the editor of one of this nation's raciest papers, is not afraid of outrageous headlines sprawled across the front page in mile-high type. He has been writing them for three years with a punch that makes the poor of this frenetic city smile, and politicians shudder.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Marriage For Transsexuals
description: The government published a bill that would allow transsexuals to marry under their adopted sex, ending a 30-year-struggle for a change in the law, which involves an estimated 5,000 people. Legal status and new birth certificates, if necessary, would be given to Britons who can demonstrate to a panel of doctors and lawyers that they have taken ''decisive steps'' to live permanently in their acquired sex. In Europe, only Britain, Ireland, Albania and Andorra do not legally recognize sex changes. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: G.I.'s Turn Over Policing of Iraqi Town to Local Force
description: The new Iraqi police force in this restless town west of Baghdad threatened to quit on Thursday unless American forces allowed them to do their jobs alone.

description: GERSTEN--Frieda. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Devoted mother of William & the late Barbara. Cherished grandmother of Monica & the late Tara. Dear aunt and great-aunt. A good friend to many. ''Sinai Chapels,'' phone 1-800-446-0406. >>AD#

title: The Uranium Fiction
description: We're glad that someone in Washington has finally taken responsibility for letting President Bush make a false accusation about Saddam Hussein's nuclear weapons program in the State of the Union address last January, but the matter will not end there. George Tenet, the director of central intelligence, stepped up to the issue yesterday when he said the C.I.A. had approved Mr. Bush's speech and failed to advise him to drop the mistaken charge that Iraq had recently tried to import significant quantities of uranium from an African nation, later identified as Niger. Now the American people need to know how the accusation got into the speech in the first place, and whether it was put there with an intent to deceive the nation. The White House has a lot of explaining to do.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The president had every reason to believe that the text presented to him was sound. These 16 words should never have been included in the text written for the president.''

title: East Seems to Be Serious About All-Star Chances
description: The Western Conference All-Stars of the Women's National Basketball Association had just finished a 45-minute practice yesterday, delighting thousands of young fans at Madison Square Garden.

title: Religion Journal; Summertime and Outdoor Services
description: In Fairbanks, Alaska, the Rev. J. Douglas Leggett, minister of Midnight Sun United Church, seizes summer while he can and moves worship services outdoors to a garden. At Easter services, with the garden still frozen under snow, his congregation has in recent years planted onions after thawing the soil with hot coals from a bonfire. The open-air sanctuary has drawn church members, local residents, tourists and an occasional moose.

title: W.T.O. Formally Designates U.S. Steel Tariffs as Illegal
description: The World Trade Organization issued its formal finding today that steel tariffs imposed by the United States last year were illegal. The ruling could lead the European Union and other nations to retaliate later this year with sanctions on American exports.

title: Queens Man Is Shot Dead While Home With Family
description: A Queens man was fatally shot yesterday by gunmen at his home while his wife and three children were in the house, police officials said.

title: Spaniards on Way To Back U.S. in Iraq
description: Spain will begin sending soldiers to Iraq on Saturday, after cabinet approval of a peacekeeping force of 1,300 troops, a move that quickly drew political fire here.

title: Mets Lose Again and Howe Loses Patience
description: In an effort to tune out the rest of the world yesterday, the Mets rookie pitcher Aaron Heilman pulled on headphones two hours before the game and began to spit tobacco juice into a paper cup.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Federal Meat Inspection
description: Elsa Murano, undersecretary for food safety at the Agriculture Department, said the department would not ask Congress for greater authority to shut down meat plants that produce contaminated food. After record recalls of 66 million pounds of potentially contaminated meat last year, the secretary of agriculture, Ann M. Veneman, said federal meat inspectors had to have greater authority to punish meat plants. The meat industry has opposed the idea, and Dr. Murano said the department needed to study it further. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: Rangers Close to Signing a Defender
description: The Rangers are expected to announce their first free-agent signing of the off-season early next week, defenseman Greg de Vries, an official in the National Hockey League said yesterday.

title: Stowaway on Bush Press Plane Is Arrested in Uganda
description: The Ugandan authorities arrested an unidentified man who stowed away on the press plane accompanying President Bush from South Africa to Uganda today and then entered the hotel complex where Mr. Bush was speaking.

title: In Scramble for Superstars, Nets Keep Their Own: Kidd
description: Jason Kidd, the All-Star point guard whose uncanny passing and exemplary leadership resurrected the New Jersey Nets out of the N.B.A. wasteland and into the league finals the past two seasons, announced yesterday that he would stay with the Nets for six more years instead of going to the league champion San Antonio Spurs.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about progress in prosecuting Balkan war crimes at the United Nations tribunal in The Hague referred incorrectly in some copies to the anniversary of the massacre of thousands of Bosnian Muslims at Srebrenica. When the article was written, on July 4, it had been almost eight years since the killings, not seven.

title: 2nd Woman in Crash Dies
description: A second pedestrian has died as the result of an accident Thursday on Queens Boulevard, the police said. The pedestrian, Sharon Rivers, 34, died yesterday morning at Jamaica Hospital, said Sgt. Mike Accurso. The other victim, Caprice Bush, 23, was pronounced dead at the scene of the accident, on the corner of 78th Avenue in Forest Hills. The women were friends and co-workers.

title: There Is Life After Enron; New Money Flows Into the Energy Trading Business
description: On the surface, few businesses would seem more left for dead than energy trading. Yet some of the world's biggest investment banks, including Goldman Sachs, Merrill Lynch, Bank of America and Deutsche Bank, have recently taken steps to strengthen their electricity and natural gas trading operations, injecting new life into an area that had been pummeled by the 2001 collapse of Enron and California's electricity crisis.

title: Striking Similarities
description: Cars have all sorts of devices to protect them from being stolen. Car designs are just there for the taking.

title: Why People Still Starve
description: Late one afternoon, during the long melancholia of the hungry months, there was a burst of joyous delirium in Mkulumimba. Children began shouting the word ngumbi, announcing that winged termites were fluttering through the fields. These were not the bigger species of the insect, which can be fried in oil and sold as a delicacy for a good price. Instead, these were the smaller ones, far more wing than torso, which are eaten right away. Suddenly, most everyone was giddily chasing about; villagers were catching ngumbi with their fingers and tossing them onto their tongues, grateful for the unexpected gift of food afloat in the air.

The Caledoni a slips through the grey water and sea-mists of the English channel, skirts the Iberian peninsula, then rounds the rock of Gibraltar into the Mediterranean. They thread the needle of the Suez Canal at night: the water so still and dark it seems more like a geological feature, a seam of graphite clamped between the layers of the desert. Then out into the hot air of the Red Sea, where the ocean is as calm as a reservoir and the ship moves across it leaving barely a wake on the water.

title: The Lord Collection
description: In more than a half-century of writing about and mingling with Europe's artistic and intellectual elite, the art critic James Lord has amassed a rare collection of portraits, rendered by the likes of Picasso and Balthus. In Plausible Portraits OF JAMES LORD: With Commentary by the Model (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25), he pairs these pictures with short, reflective essays in which he explores the dynamic between himself and each artist and offers his perspectives on portraiture and aesthetic truth. Sentimental, humorous, occasionally sardonic, the narratives give an intimate and refreshing glimpse of figures like the poet (and draftsman) Jean Cocteau and the bristly photographer Henri Cartier-Bresson. Lord uses anecdotes to sustain his interpretations of the artworks, examining with meticulous grace how each portrait's vitality hinges on the relation between artist and model. He imbues this dynamic with metaphysical and redemptive qualities, claiming portraiture offers humans a ''gamble against death.'' Through their flexibility and creative license, the 37 likenesses reveal with stunning clarity how the variables of mimesis diverge with each artist's interpretation of a constant model. Some are roughly executed and others tender; some appear vital and others inert. Giacometti's determined, sculptural vision emerges as a clear contrast to Picasso's swift genius. As Lord writes, ''In the image he creates the artist dwells.'' Roxana M. Popescu

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GANNES, , ABRAHAM
description: GANNES--Abraham, a renowned pioneer in Jewish education, teacher, scholar and dear father, grandfather, great-grandfather and friend, died on July 8 (8 Tammuz). Dr. Gannes was the last in the galaxy of Jewish luminaries who established the foundation and built the structure for modern Jewish education, including a network of Jewish schools and cultural institutions, in the United States and Canada. Dr. Gannes was the former Executive Director of the Department of Education and Culture-American Section of the WZO, Executive Director of Cejwin Camps, Executive Director of the Council of Jewish Education (Philadelphia), and founder and Executive Director of the Bureau of Jewish Education (Miami). His passion for Jewish learning influenced thousands during his 75 years as a Jewish educator. The Jewish world will greatly miss Dr. Gannes' ongoing contribution to strengthening Jewish education, values and life. His loving children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren deeply mourn their personal loss. Memorial contributions are suggested to the Miriam Gannes Memorial Reading Program, Congregation Beth David, 19700 Prospect Rd., Saratoga, CA 95070. The Gannes Family >>AD#

title: Chinese Underground
description: According to the Chinese government's official statistics (which, critics say, are conservative estimates), 6,121 people died last year in coal mines in China. With numbing regularity, year after year, Chinese miners are killed by floods, fires, gas explosions, collapsing tunnels and carbon-monoxide poisoning. Most miners are migrants who hail from the country's poorer regions, endangering their lives to make more money than they would by farming the land. They are 117 times more likely to be killed at work than their American counterparts.Putting human faces on this statistical horror is Song Chao, a 24-year-old amateur photographer who also happens to be a miner in Shandong Province. About two years ago, Song met Hei Ming, a professional photographer from Beijing who helped him develop a hobby of taking pictures of his co-workers. Song began with a 35-millimeter camera, but when Hei showed him the work of the American photographer Richard Avedon, he became determined to switch to a 4-by-5-inch camera of the sort that Avedon uses. Though the camera was prohibitively expensive, with financial support from friends and family he was ultimately able to acquire one. His portraits, which are being featured this month at the International Photography Encounter in Arles, France, and in September at the Pingyao International Photography Festival in China, are uncannily reminiscent of Avedon's, yet unique in their intimate acquaintance with their subjects.

title: Why People Still Starve

These were not the bigger species of the insect, which can be fried in oil and sold as a delicacy for a good price. Instead, these were the smaller ones, far more wing than torso, which are eaten right away. Suddenly, most everyone was giddily chasing about; villagers were catching ngumbi with their fingers and tossing them onto their tongues, grateful for the unexpected gift of food afloat in the air.

title: 'Merchants of Immortality'
description: Several years ago, while spending a weekend in the country with my family, I stepped out onto the porch of the cabin where we were staying one night and looked up into the sky. It was unusually clear for a summer night in the Catskills, and every familiar jot and scrawl of the firmament was writ large-the Polestar, Little Bear, filaments of the Milky Way strewn like pulled cotton right down the middle of the dome, the entire landscape "apparelled in celestial light," as Wordsworth put it in his "Ode: Intimations of Immortality." A field of tall grass and wildflowers sloped down from the porch, and hundreds of fireflies blinked on and off in the middle distance, so that the line where our earthly, mortal light yielded to the celestial became beautifully blurred in the darkness. As I stood at the rail, I could hear the uniquely peaceful sound of untroubled sleep behind me in the cabin- my wife and two children. I scanned the dark sky for a shooting star. I even had a wish ready.

title: 2 Fast? 4 Safety?
description: Out on the long, lonely highways of the West, the mythical backdrops for countless car commercials and millions of summer family vacations, the speed limits make criminals of everyone -- minor revolutionaries, even. Up ahead, nothing but sky and flattened jack rabbits. In the rearview mirror, ditto. How many more hours to Yellowstone National Park? With only the road signs themselves for landmarks, there's often no way to judge. And so, to convince himself that he's making progress, Dad kicks it up to 80, 85, and then -- as the kids start whining for a bathroom break -- to a solid 90; 90 feels right. Sure, it's against the law, but what's the law, particularly to an American with a V-8, an empty cooler and a full bladder? The law is a nag. The law is petty, irrelevant. Speed kills -- of course it does. But slowness tortures, particularly when the next town on the map (which may or may not turn out to be a town, in the sense of having a gas station or a store) is exactly 216 miles away.

title: The Executioner's I.Q. Test

Talbot's article is a window into other problems that plague our capital-punishment process -- unreliable eyewitness testimony, jailhouse snitches and overworked and underqualified defense counsel. While these flaws fall most often on the most at risk, they pervade the process.

title: Keep Moving On
description: Your Lives feature about Terri Noone (June 29) illustrates some seldom-appreciated facts about living with a severe disability. I am a paraplegic who has worked for years with a state agency developing accessible housing for disabled people. Before that, I myself had to devise strategies for finding and modifying usable apartments. I also had to deal with discrimination, with more than one landlord telling me, ''I'm not running a nursing home here!'' But it's also a matter of finances. Affluent people with disabilities have a far greater choice in housing than those of low income.

title: The Real Dave Grohl: Rock's Andy Kaufman
description: DAVE GROHL -- Some say Mr. Grohl, the former drummer in Nirvana, became one of rock's most surprisingly successful frontmen with his band the Foo Fighters. Others say that after his recent stint as a drummer in Queens of the Stone Age, his true talent is and always has been behind the trap set. But perhaps they are all wrong. Mr. Grohl's calling may be Vegas or the Catskills or at least his own HBO comedy special. He's no Phil Collins or John Bonham, but rather he's rock's Andy Kaufman. His personality, his videos, his guest appearances and his forthcoming mock-heavy-metal side project, Probot, all bear this out, but nothing does so more than the new Foo Fighters ''DVD/EP'' (RCA), which contains several videos by the band, including one for ''Low.'' Shot like a home movie, it features Mr. Grohl and the actor, comedian and singer Jack Black checking into a motel room. Inside, they goof off, destroy the room and maul each other to comic effect before dressing up as women and passing out together. In a Kaufman-esque stunt, before the release of the video, the band leaked excerpts to Web sites, claiming that it was unauthorized party footage of Mr. Grohl and Mr. Black.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, , DOROTHY C.
description: MILLER--Dorothy C. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art and the Members of its International Council mourn the loss of their beloved and gentle colleague and friend, Dorothy Miller who, together with Alfred H. Barr, Jr., the Museum's founding Director, built the Museum's collection and exhibition program during its formative years. Throughout Dorothy's 35 years as a brilliant museum curator, she organized many landmark exhibitions, which recognized undiscovered talented American artists. These pioneering shows contributed greatly in building public awareness of the rich and diverse work by major artists who first emerged in the middle of the 20th Century. Although she retired from the Museum in 1969, as Curator of Museum Collections, her exuberant love of art and inspiring influence on the younger staff remain as part of her legacy. A longterm member of the Museum's International Council and Honorary Trustee of the Museum, Dorothy was first and foremost a passionate advocate for artists. We extend our deepest sympathy to her nephew, Reid White, her niece, Mrs. Edith White Danton, and her step-daughter, Jane Cahill Blumenfeld. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art Brian Urquhart, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President The Internation Council of the Museum of Modern Art >>AD#

title: The World; Slavery's Past, Paved Over Or Forgotten
description: IN what seems to be a recurring political ritual, President Bush last week -- like President Clinton in 1998 -- traveled to an island off the coast of Africa to give a speech on slavery in America. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUGHES, , JAMES A.
description: HUGHES--James A., at age 95, July 11, 2003, died peacefully at home. Cherished son of the late Joseph and Mary (nee Conway), of Dunaganon Co, Tyrone, Ireland. Brother to the late Henry, Mary Brady, Margaret, Patrick, Alice McGovern and his late first wife Laurette Riordan Hughes. James was born and lived in Greenwich Village, attended St. Joseph's Parochial School. In 1921 at age 13, he attended the St. Joseph's High School at Pocantico Hills and entered the Novitate of the De La Salle Christian Brothers. Known as Brother Albert Andrew, FSC. A teacher for 31 years at all levels, elementary at Ascension School in Manhattan for three years, LaSalle Military Academy, Oakdale, NY for 18 years and at Manhattan College for 10 years. He left the Order in 1956. Full time Staff Editor at William H. Sadlier Inc. for 15 years. A retired Consultant. Survived by his wife, Mary O'Kelly Hughes, of 20 years. Also survived by nine step-children, Mary Ellen, Jim, John, Michael, Morna, Katie, Brian, Tricia, Laura & their spouses and 18 grandchildren. Also survived by his sister, Susan D. Brown, of Sag Harbor; nieces, nephews, grand-nieces and grand-nephews. We will greatly miss our dear James, for his gifts of wisdom, a scholarly mind, sense of humor, generous and caring heart, combined with his great faith which have forever influenced our lives. Reposing Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9, Hillebrand Funeral Homes, Inc, 6317 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10:45am, Resurrection Ascension RC Church. title: 'Absolutely American'
description: Icame to love, really love, road marching. It's called a suck or a haze at West Point, but I think the cadets aren't being fair to it. There's something wonderful about being in a column of marching people: the gravel popping under soles, the leather flexing in boots, the kind of saddle-top sounds as the ruck (what a backpack gets called in the Army) frames settle. Occasionally someone, out of sheer misery, sighing Oooh, or just blowing out air, which in the general silence is like a whale breaching and then slipping back under the surface. You can watch a leaf float down from a tree or stare at the guy's rifle in front of you. The boiling down of life to its basic questions: Can you do this? What kind of person are you, and what can you make yourself finish? Can you hang with the rest of us? Those questions don't get asked much, in the civilian world.

title: The Executioner's I.Q. Test
description: Why, as a nation, do we feel the need to execute criminals? The primary reason given is that the death penalty acts as a deterrent to others who might commit similar crimes. The mentally retarded are, because of a lack of cognitive ability, unable or very unlikely to be deterred. What the Atkins decision forces us to explore is whether we want to have a death penalty to deter others or simply to exact vengeance on certain criminals. It should prove very useful in touching off a philosophical debate as to what exactly our motives are for executing someone.

title: Advice From Ex-Cons To a Jet-Set Jailbird: Best Walk on Eggs

After two years at the Wyoming Correctional Facility in upstate New York for sale of a controlled substance, he was granted his freedom on June 23, and given back his personal belongings -- a Social Security card and some medication -- then handed 40 bucks and a one-way bus ticket to the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan. He had a little time, so he savored a quiet meal at McDonald's. A few hours later he was jostling through the bustle of New York City and the crowds of Midtown. Though uncertain about his job prospects and his future, he was elated. ''You wanted to scream, 'I'm free!' '' he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANDEL, , LENARD HAROLD
description: MANDEL -- Lenard Harold. (1917-2003). It is with profound sorrow that the family of Lenard H. Mandel announces his passing on July 11, 2003. Mr. Mandel, a resident of New York City, served as Partner Emeritus at the Manhattan law firm of White & Case until the time of his death. Mr. Mandel was born on July 23, 1917 in Plainfield, New Jersey to Herman and Rose Mandel. He was married to Ruth Garfield from 1948 until the time of her death in 1998. After earning his B.A. from New York University in 1937, Mr. Mandel went on to receive his J.D. from Harvard Law School in 1940. Mr. Mandel served in the United States Military from 1942-1945. He rose to the rank of Major and earned three Battle Stars as well as a Gold and Crimson Bar awarded him by the Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Forces to Planning Staff of Operation Overlord -the Invasion of Normandy. Before joining his present firm, White & Case, Mr. Mandel served as Senior Partner of New York City law firm, Paskus, Gordon & Mandel. He joined White & Case in 1987 as a Partner. He represented several local and international large real estate clients including The Durst Organization. He was a member of the Board of the New York Youth Symphony Orchestra and Secretary to the Board of The Durst Organization. Mr. Mandel was a member of the State Bars of New York, New Jersey and Colorado, as well as the District of Columbia Bar. Friends and family describe Mr. Mandel as a ''true original'' who brought unique insight to all of his endeavors. Family was his primary love, followed closely by the legal profession. He was passionate about his practice, working until the day of his death. Mr. Mandel also enjoyed fine art and the symphony. Mr. Mandel is precedeased by his wife Ruth and sister, Myra. His brother, Robert (Beverly) Mandel, son Richard Garfield Mandel, and daughter Carol Diane Milstein survive him. Mr. Mandel is also survived by grandchildren Aaron, Amanda, Ethan, Daniel, and Maria. Services to be held Sunday, July 13, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: 'The Dogs of Babel'

Robert Hanley

title: The Cult of Rajavi
description: For more than 30 years, the Mujahedeen Khalq, or People's Mujahedeen, has survived and operated on the margins of history and the slivers of land that Saddam Hussein and French governments have proffered it. During the 1970's, while it was still an underground Iranian political movement, you could encounter some of its members on the streets of New York, waving pictures of torture victims of the shah's regime. In the 80's and 90's, after its leaders fled Iran, you could see them raising money and petitioning on university campuses around the United States, pumping photographs in the air of women mangled and tortured by the Islamic regime in Tehran. By then, they were also showing off other photographs, photographs that were in some ways more attention-grabbing: Iranian women in military uniforms who brandished guns, drove tanks and were ready to overthrow the Iranian government. Led by a charismatic husband-and-wife duo, Maryam and Massoud Rajavi, the Mujahedeen had transformed itself into the only army in the world with a commander corps composed mostly of women.

title: Erica Dancyger, Eli Halliwell
description: Erica Flint Dancyger, a daughter of Dr. Ida Dancyger and Ken Dancyger of New York, was married yesterday to Eli Ben Anson Halliwell, the son of Anne and Steve Halliwell of Irvington, N.Y. Cantor Robin Joseph officiated at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: On the Yangtze With The Hatfields and McCoys
description: THE songwriter Stephin Merritt, a diminutive baritone with sad eyes, is not the sort of person who does much spontaneous laughing. His best-known work, the Magnetic Fields' ''69 Love Songs,'' is a sprawling, three-CD survey of pop music, full of bittersweet lyrics. But on a recent afternoon, as he was describing his schedule, he broke into a long, quiet laugh. ''My life is seeming a little weird at the moment,'' he said. ''I'm sitting in a high school, rehearsing an opera.''

title: Habitats/West 33rd Street; For Minister, His Church Is Home, in Many Ways
description: ON a recent drizzly Thursday, the nave of the Glad Tidings Tabernacle Church on West 33rd Street was a tangle of chairs and extension cords. At the apse end (there really isn't an apse) was the stage, which held an enormous, vaguely Celtic-looking metal cross, a huge drum set and a poster of the Incredible Hulk. There wasn't a pulpit either; the church's pastor, the Rev. Carl Keyes, sits on a little wooden stool that's mostly dwarfed by all the props behind it.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: ICE-CREAM CONES FOR SALE! Written and illustrated by Elaine Greenstein. Arthur Levine/Scholastic. $15.95. (Ages 4 to 8) America is the melting pot, right? So what better demonstration of diversity in action than this account of ethnic rivalry surrounding the appearance at the St. Louis World's Fair in 1904 of that summer essential, the ice cream cone. The pressed cone came first.

description: CHRISTOPHER SHINN'S ''Four,'' at TheaterWorks in Hartford, has a back story that may resonate for local audiences.

description: Terry Pristin and Ronald H. Silverman were married on Friday at the chapel of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations in New York. Rabbi Lennard R. Thal officiated at the service, which was led by Rabbi Suzanne Singer.

title: The Pretentious Summer Superhero
description: WHERE do a movie critic's thoughts turn during the long, hectic months of summer? Why, to Shakespeare and Sophocles, of course, and also to Hegel, Jung, Freud, Plato, Baudrillard, Dostoyevsky and Homer. We are professionals, after all, grimly aware of our responsibilities as interpreters of culture. And how, without reference to these and other giants of Western thought, could we ever hope to make sense of ''The Hulk'' or ''The Matrix Reloaded''? The Hulk, you see, is Oedipus, and his dad is, um, Prometheus, but in any case it's obvious that the green monster's anger-management issues represent a parable of the id. As for ''The Matrix,'' well, that's a whole different syllabus, since Neo, in his fetching leather trench coat, must karate-kick his way through a series of ancient philosophical conundrums about the nature of free will, the ontological status of reality and the metaphysical endowments of Italian actresses.

title: Everyone Loved Lucy. Except Me.
description: In her heyday, Lucille Ball was ''not only funnier than anyone else on television; she was also more beautiful -- a matchless combination,'' writes Stefan Kanfer in his new biography ''Ball of Fire: The Tumultuous Life and Comic Art of Lucille Ball'' (Knopf). When Ball died in 1989, her alter ego Lucy Ricardo had already become the face of television nostalgia: that lipstick pout, those puddle eyes, the brows rising like twin rainbows. But for this viewer, actually watching the famous ''I Love Lucy'' -- as opposed to recognizing its historical importance -- has always been perversely uncomfortable. It's not just the dated rhythms, the sense of the sitcom inventing itself. It's Lucy, radiating anxiety.

title: A Versatile Master

His pure-toned, impeccably phrased performances made him one of the two pre-eminent alto saxophonists in jazz, with Johnny Hodges, from the late 1920's until the arrival of Charlie Parker in the mid-1940's. He was also an accomplished soloist on trumpet and clarinet, and on occasion he played piano, trombone and both tenor and baritone saxophones.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Saddle Brook: Catholic School To Close
description: A 50-year-old Roman Catholic elementary school will not reopen this fall because of scant enrollment, the school's administrators said. Officials at St. Philip the Apostle Roman Catholic Church sent letters last week to the parents of students at the church school, said the Rev. Robert McBride, the pastor. In past years, the school's typical enrollment was about 220 students, and it cannot afford to operate with fewer than 125, Father McBride said. Only 85 children enrolled for the next year. The low enrollment would have meant a $400 tuition increase -- to $2,800 annually for parishioners and $3,200 for nonparishioners. Hope Reeves (NYT)

As the university's chief academic and budget officer, he will be responsible for undergraduate and graduate education, research and university budgeting. A researcher in cancer-cell biology, Dr. Furmanski, 56, was an undergraduate at Temple University and earned his doctorate there in microbiology. Rutgers said his salary would be $350,000, which it said was $25,000 more than what he earned at N.Y.U. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Angst Aplenty, but Flavored by Dark Humor
description: Dairakudakan developed from the Japanese dance and theater art of Butoh, which plunges unhesitatingly into primal postwar angst. Tatsumi Hijikata, a founder of Butoh, was an early influence. But the playful spirit of Kazuo Ohno, another founder, is more to be seen in the work of Dairakudakan today. The two pieces these Tokyo-based performers presented at the American Dance Festival on Thursday night at Page Auditorium here were theatrically big and bold and filled not only with the requisite angst but with dark, teasing humor. There was not an ounce of redeeming social value to the evening, bless their hearts.

title: U.S. Rolls to Victory in Gold Cup

title: Benny Carter, 95, Musician and Arranger Who Shaped 8 Decades of Jazz, Dies

title: No country more beautiful

As an expression of its gratitude, the Stasi (the former East German secret police) granted citizenship to the defector. Now the former top spy wants to return. But the German authorities are balking and the homeland he is seeking has long since ceased to exist.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: NEW BRUNSWICK: N.Y.U. OFFICIAL TO TAKE RUTGERS POST Rutgers University named Philip Furmanski, chairman of New York University's biology department and former dean of its Faculty of Arts and Science, as executive vice president for academic affairs, effective Sept. 1. As the university's chief academic and budget officer, he will be responsible for undergraduate and graduate education, research and university budgeting. A researcher in cancer-cell biology, Dr. Furmanski, 56, was an undergraduate at Temple University and earned his doctorate there in microbiology. Rutgers said his salary would be $350,000, which it said was $25,000 more than what he earned at N.Y.U.    Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: CHIP MAKER SELLS SHARES NEC Electronics, the chip making division of the NEC Corporation, said yesterday that it had sold 34 million shares at 4,200 yen ($35.66) each, the upper end of expectations. The sale raised 143 billion yen ($1.2 billion), making it the largest public offering this year in Tokyo. The strong demand for the shares, which begin trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on July 24, comes a few weeks after Seiko Epson, which makes printers for computers, completed a successful initial public offering. In yesterday's sale, NEC Electronics sold 23.5 million shares and its parent, NEC, sold 10.5 million shares that it holds in its subsidiary. NEC may sell an additional 3 million shares to meet demand. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPEARS, , JACKSON E.

Spears, and by nine grandchildren, twelve great-grandchildren and two nephews. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Wednesday, July 16, 2003 at St. Thomas More Church in Darien, CT at 10:30 AM. Interment will follow at St. John's Cemetery, Stamford, CT.

title: Population-Control Politics
description: The House of Representatives faces a crucial vote today affecting the health of women in 140 poor countries. Through the authorization of the State Department budget, the House can restore tens of millions of dollars in vital American aid for the United Nations Population Fund or, for a second year in a row, cut it off in the mistaken belief that the fund colludes with coerced abortions in China.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Sheriff Cited For Overcrowded Jail
description: A federal judge has declared Sheriff Frank Anderson in contempt for not solving the chronic overcrowding problem at the Marion County Jail. The judge, Sarah Evans Barker of Federal District Court, ruled that the jail, which serves Indianapolis, must reduce its population to no more than 1,135 inmates by April; it had more than 1,600 inmates in January. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Bloomberg Defends His Stance On Nonpartisan City Elections
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg strongly defended his support of nonpartisan elections yesterday, insisting that removing party labels from the ballot broadens political opportunity.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: KUWAIT: LEADERSHIP SHIFT The emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber Ahmed al-Sabah, has met a demand of political activists by separating the office of crown prince from that of prime minister. Sheik Sabah al-Ahmed al-Sabah, foreign minister for some 40 years and the emir's brother, was appointed prime minister on Sunday. Analysts were divided over whether the move represented a real shift toward greater democracy or was merely royal family housekeeping. Sheik Sabah has been effectively running the government because Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, the crown prince, has been seriously ill. The change, however, means the prime minister can be subject to questioning by Parliament. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: TV Bond Deal
description: The controlling shareholder of one of Mexico's biggest television networks, Azteca Holdings, said it had reached an exchange agreement with bondholders that will allow the company to pay off a $150 million bond that falls due today. Investors holding $96.2 million of the bonds agreed to swap their bonds for new bonds paying 12.25 percent and maturing in 2008. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: Nets Risked Much More If Mourning Got Away
description: The Nets' owners made a bold financial commitment to sign center Alonzo Mourning, taking a risk on a player who has a rare kidney disease because they knew it would persuade Jason Kidd to stay in New Jersey.

title: Rebuilding Mets Ship Burnitz to Dodgers for Prospects
description: The Mets used to think nothing of dealing prospects if the trades improved their chances of contending immediately. But that tactic seemed to bring more losing and even more frustration. Now the Mets cannot seem to scoop up prospects quickly enough.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: DROUGHT AID SOUGHT A severe drought in northern Italy has caused so much damage and concern that several regions have asked for special aid from the national government, which is considering declaring a state of emergency. Months of dry weather coupled with intense heat have devastated the Po, Italy's longest river and one of its most crucial for agriculture. Its water levels have dropped to nearly 25 feet below average, one of its lowest marks in almost a century. The Piedmont and Emilia-Romagna regions have asked for aid, and Lombardy and Venice were expected to do the same. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Theater In Village Is Granted A New Life
description: The Waverly Theater in Greenwich Village closed its doors a couple of weeks after Sept. 11, 2001, and has been boarded up since. It's a sad hulk in a depressing block. There's an X-rated video store a couple of doors away; the Gap just up Avenue of the Americas recently closed. But the Waverly is far more than just another vacant storefront.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/New CD's; Three Helpings of Soulful Jazz
description: So much jazz has been a matter of virtuosity; quality always pays off in the short game. But when the tempos slow down, or the person in charge of choosing songs leans toward the sturdiest stuff, or the rhythm section starts positing solid groove over fractured patterns, then the better musicians steer into an area which, for lack of a better term, we can call soul. These three recordings are soulful: not destined to create any new categories or shake up any Paganinis, but beautifully played.

description: No branch of medicine intersects with politics more than public health. Not surprisingly, the two areas often clash, particularly when health issues bear on economics, like SARS and tobacco use.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Catching A Fast Train
description: China appeared set to choose Japan's bullet-train technology for its new multibillion-dollar high-speed rail service linking Beijing and Shanghai, the state news media reported. The Economic Observer said authorities had nearly settled on Japan's Shinkansen, or bullet train, for the 815-mile route, estimated to cost $12 billion. Germany has been heavily promoting its high-tech magnetic levitation train, known as the Maglev. But Chinese officials have hinted recently that they favor traditional high-speed trains as more cost effective. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR FIRMS. The euro fell moderately against the dollar ahead of Congressional testimony from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. In New York, the euro settled at $1.1278, down from $1.1306.

title: Early Voices: The Leap to Language
description: Bower birds are artists, leaf-cutting ants practice agriculture, crows use tools, chimpanzees form coalitions against rivals. The only major talent unique to humans is language, the ability to transmit encoded thoughts from the mind of one individual to another.

title: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES TO DELAY DELIVERY OF NEW JETS
description: Continental Airlines said yesterday that it was deferring deliveries of 36 Boeing 737 jets that it had been scheduled to accept in 2005, 2006 and 2007. The airline will not take the deliveries until 2008 and beyond, it said. ''We are not going to invest in aircraft that we cannot profitably fly in the current marketplace,'' Gordon Bethune, Continental's chief executive, said. The announcement is a blow to Boeing, which is trailing Airbus in orders. Continental said it would take delivery of four 737-800's at the end of this year and 12 737-800's next year. It also is in discussions with Boeing about the delivery of 11 757-300's that it had ordered, the company said. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Fallout From Failed Strike
description: Leaders of IG Metall, Germany's most powerful union, have proposed a special convention at the end of August to settle a leadership battle that erupted after a failed strike in eastern Germany. The meeting, which must be approved by the union's 41-member board, could derail the candidacy of Jrgen Peters to replace the longtime chairman, Klaus Zwickel, left, who is departing. Mr. Peters, now the union's vice chairman, has been blamed for the collapse of the strike, which had been called to demand a shorter workweek. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Journalist Arrested
description: Iran's hard-line judiciary arrested another journalist, Iradj Rastegara, bringing the total number of journalists arrested since Saturday to four. Scores of pro-democracy students and activists have been arrested in the past month since antigovernment protests became widespread. President Mohammad Khatami, however, ordered an investigation into the suspicious death of an Iranian-Canadian photojournalist who died on Friday. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: ILLINOIS COURT ORDERS TOBACCO DECISION REVIEW
description: An Illinois state appeals court has ordered a trial judge to reconsider his decision reducing how much Philip Morris USA must deposit to appeal a $10.1 billion verdict for misleading Illinois smokers about the dangers of ''light'' cigarettes. The judge had cut the bond for Philip Morris, a unit of Altria Group Inc., to $6.8 billion from $12 billion, an amount that Philip Morris has said would force it to file for bankruptcy protection and might jeopardize its payments to states under a 1998 nationwide settlement. The case was sent back to the trial court ''for the purpose of reconsidering the amount, terms, conditions, and security of the appeals bond,'' the appeals court wrote.

title: After 25 Years, New Ideas in the Prenatal Test Tube
description: Twenty-five years ago this month, Louise Brown became famous just by being born -- the first human conceived outside the body. Doctors removed a single egg from her mother's ovary, combined it with her father's sperm in a laboratory dish and, two and a half days later, placed the resulting eight-cell embryo into her mother's womb.

title: TOYOTA TO EXPAND ITS NEW ALABAMA FACTORY
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, the automaker, said yesterday that it would spend $20 million more at a new Alabama factory to make V-6 engines to match increased pickup truck production in North America. Toyota is adding 150 jobs, for a total of 500 at the plant, a spokesman, Dan Sieger, said. The plant, in Huntsville, Ala., opened in May with an annual capacity to build 120,000 V-8 engines. The plant will more than double its capacity to 250,000 engines, including 130,000 V-6 engines. The company built 1.21 million vehicles and more than a million engines at plants in the United States and Canada in 2002. Engines from the Alabama plant are for Tundra pickups built in Indiana and Tacoma pickups built in California.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Berlin Township: Man Sought For Questioning
description: The police are seeking a man for questioning in the disappearance of a woman over the weekend. The police described the man, Wayne Morris, 65, of Morrestown, N.J., as a friend of the woman's family. The woman, Barbara M. Staudt, 37, a mother of four, was last seen leaving her home in Marlton around 11 p.m. on Saturday for a Taco Bell in nearby Berlin Township, the police said. Her husband said he found her abandoned minivan near the restaurant and called the police, investigators said. Ms. Staudt's purse and keys were inside the minivan, they said. Mr. Morris drives a 2001 white Dodge Ram pickup truck with New Jersey license plates that read 'litmoe,' Chief Hayden said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Brooklyn: 2 Accused Of Kidnapping Teens
description: Two teenagers were forced into a livery cab as they were leaving Coney Island after midnight and held hostage for five hours on Sunday until two police officers spotted the cab in Brooklyn and arrested two men in the abduction, the police said yesterday. The police said the two men forced the teenagers, a 14-year-old boy and a 15-year-old girl, into a livery cab at West 17th Street and Surf Avenue about 2:30 a.m. on Sunday, and ordered the driver into Queens before robbing him and forcing him out of the cab. The men took the cab back to Brooklyn, where, the police said, one of them, Brendon Elbourne, 19, of South Jamaica, Queens, raped the girl. The second man, Gregory Gill, 21, also of South Jamaica, was about to sexually assault the girl when two patrol officers noticed the cab, a 1997 Lincoln sedan, about 8 a.m., the police said. Mr. Gill ran and was caught, officers said. Both men were arrested and charged with kidnapping, rape, sodomy, robbery, possessing stolen property, possessing a weapon and endangering the welfare of a child, the Brooklyn district attorney's office said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Storm Grinds Across Texas; No Casualties Reported
description: The first hurricane of the Atlantic season struck the Gulf Coast of Texas today, its wind and rain driving many residents from seaside communities but causing only scattered damage, with no reports of injuries.

description: This city is immersed in photography exhibitions, a coincidence of scheduling, perhaps, that the museums here decided made a catchy marketing scheme. Posters and flyers advertise the ''Summer of Photography.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Poland: Talks On Control Of Steel
description: The Polish government said it would hold exclusive talks for control of about 70 percent of Poland's steel industry with LNM Holdings, a British-Dutch steelmaker, largely owned by the Indian-born billionaire Lakshmi N. Mittal. It rejected a rival bid from U.S. Steel of Pittsburgh. The government canceled the expected $600 million sale of the oil refiner Lotos to Poland's largest energy company, PKN Orlen and the British-based investment group, Rotch Energy. Instead, the Treasury ministry announced that it would merge Lotos, previously known as Rafineria Gdanska, with three ailing, government-owned refineries in Southern Poland. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: GOLDMAN SACHS REALTY UNIT EXPANDS IN SWEDEN
description: The Whitehall Street Real Estate unit of Goldman Sachs Group Inc. agreed yesterday to buy 31 properties from Drott AB for 5.2 billion kronor ($641.6 million) to increase its holdings in Sweden. The Stockholm properties have 280,000 square meters of rentable space and include a part of the Globen concert and sports arena complex, Drott said. Whitehall is among several United States funds that have increased investment in foreign markets in recent years. The fund last year bought 40 Swedish properties for 3.95 billion kronor.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Use Of File-Sharing Services Drops, Survey Says
description: Use of file-sharing services like KaZaA dipped after the recording industry threatened to sue users who violate copyrights, a new survey of Internet use has found. According to the Internet measurement firm Nielsen/NetRatings, traffic to KaZaA declined by one million unique visitors the week ended July 6, after the announcement by the Recording Industry Association of America. That was a 15 percent drop, and the firm measured similar declines at Morpheus and iMesh. ''We observed a noteworthy week over week decline for KaZaA,'' said Greg Bloom, a senior Internet analyst for Nielsen/NetRatings. He acknowledged that some of the drop could be attributed to the fact that use might also have been depressed somewhat by summertime distractions from the Internet and the Independence Day weekend, but said, ''it's certainly bigger than holiday or just summer'' declines. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Expanding Conservation Program
description: The Department of the Interior said it would provide $70.4 million to 29 states for endangered species conservation projects. Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton said financing for such projects had increased by about 400 percent over the last two and a half years. A spokesman for the department said that in recent years the conservation programs had been intended for Southeastern states and California, which will receive almost a quarter of the money involved. Arkansas, North Carolina, Tennessee and Texas are among other states that will get money.
