description: ROTHKOPF--Carol. You will always be in our hearts. Ira >>AD#

title: Greenspan Says Fed Could Cut Rates Again
description: WASHINGTON, July 15  Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, took a generally upbeat economic forecast to Capitol Hill today, citing in particular improved household income, but he said the Fed was prepared to hold interest rates low "for as long as needed" to stimulate further growth.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Suspect In Bomb Plot Escapes
description: A Muslim militant accused of taking part in a plot to bomb the American Embassy in Singapore in 2001 escaped from his cell inside Camp Crame, the national police headquarters in Manila. Fathur Rohman al-Ghozi, a 31-year-old Indonesian, was a member of Jemaah Islamiyah, the Islamic fundamentalist group based in Indonesia that has been accused by authorities of carrying out the deadly bomb attacks in Bali last October. He was jailed in the Philippines last year for illegal possession of explosives. Mr. Ghozi escaped with two suspected members of Abu Sayyaf, an extremist group. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Leisure on Sunday about the series ''Queer Eye for the Straight Guy,'' on Bravo, misstated the time of the debut episode tonight. It is at 10, Eastern time, and 9 Central, not 9 Eastern.

title: Calling Fire an Accident, Leaders of Mosque Say They Will Rebuild
description: After a fire Sunday night badly damaged the Dar-Ul-Islam Mosque in Elizabeth, N.J., one of the largest in Union County, its directors vowed yesterday to rebuild and said they would set up tents to continue holding prayer services.

title: Israelis Question Palestinian Security After Fatal Stabbing
description: JERUSALEM, July 15  A Palestinian assailant with a dagger fatally stabbed a young Israeli man walking with his girlfriend along the Tel Aviv beachfront early today, and Israeli officials said the attack demonstrated a lack of action by the Palestinians to halt violence.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: CAMERAS FOR HIGH-CRIME AREAS The police will soon install several cameras in high-crime neighborhoods in Chicago in an effort to curb gang violence. Each camera will cost $15,000 and will have a control panel that officers can use in their squad cars to zoom in on a specific area. The control panels will cost $7,000 each. The police would not say how many cameras would be used, but they said the cameras would probably be on the South and West Sides. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Commuter Train Bound for Manhattan Derails, Injuring 13
description: Two cars on a Manhattan-bound New Jersey Transit train carrying about 1,200 commuters derailed here this morning when a wheel fell off one of the cars, leaving passengers in a desolate marsh for about two hours and snarling train service throughout the day.

title: Edison Schools' Founder to Take It Private
description: After four roller-coaster years as a publicly traded company, Edison Schools, the nation's largest for-profit manager of public schools, announced yesterday that its board had accepted a bid of about $174 million by its founder and chief executive, H. Christopher Whittle, to take the company private.

title: Study Calls for Better-Kept Subway Phones
description: It is the sort of news that never exactly comes as news to any regular subway rider: the state of pay phones on the platforms leaves a lot to be desired. Some appear to have been dismembered. Others have been befouled. Many others simply seem as if they have been unplugged.

title: Italian Output Fell in May, Raising Fears Of Recession
description: Italian industrial production plunged 1.6 percent in May, its steepest monthly fall in more than four years and the newest sign that the country, Europe's fourth-biggest economy, could slip into recession.

title: M.S.: Beyond the Diagnosis
description: Of the many mysteries surrounding multiple sclerosis, one of the most painful is what to expect after a diagnosis. Some people with similar brain scan findings will go years before having new bouts, while in others the disease progresses with daunting swiftness.

title: Only a Game
description: Not everything in life has to mean something. Some things are just for the fun of it. The people who run baseball, including Commissioner Bud Selig, have yet to learn that little lesson. They keep trying to give the annual midseason festival known as the All-Star Game ''significance,'' with a capital S. It can't be done. Tonight's game is an exhibition, no more, no less, and baseball ought to live with it.

title: Court Sides With M.T.A. Dispute Over Toll Increase
description: Astate appeals court unanimously ruled today that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had abided by the law when it raised transit fares and tolls in May  meaning that millions of riders and drivers will continue to pay the higher prices.

title: Diagnosis: Depression
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Criticizes NASA's Shuttle Maintenance and Predicts Further Fatal Accidents
description: Even if NASA corrects the problem that doomed the Columbia, the agency is likely to lose more shuttles before the fleet reaches its planned retirement date of 2020, according to the draft of a study done for the Columbia Accident Investigation Board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NOVAK, , MARGUERITE THEURER
description: NOVAK--Marguerite Theurer. Of West Caldwell, NJ, on Saturday, July 12, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Max Novak. Devoted mother of Darryl L. and Wayne A. Novak. Loving grandmother of Lars T., Margo S., S. Yvonne, Todd A. and Emily E. Novak, great-grandmother of Woods W., Alexander T. and Emily K. Novak. Dear sister of Lydia Pfund and the late John Theurer. Relatives and friends are invited to attend a memorial service at St. Luke's Lutheran Church, 306 W. 46th Street, NY, NY, on Thursday, July 17, at 10:30 a.m. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers Memorial gifts may be made to St. Luke's Lutheran Church (Memorial Fund) or Foundation for Diabetes Research, 513 West Mount Pleasant Avenue, Livingston, NJ 07039. For more information contact The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, 2122 Millburn Ave., Maplewood, NJ 07040, 973-762-2200. >>AD#

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has confirmed the deaths of the following Americans in the Iraq theater of operation:

title: MEMO PAD
description: More news about shoes: The Transportation Security Administration issued a statement seeking to clarify its policy on screening shoes at airport checkpoints. The agency said it wanted to ensure that its policy on shoes was consistently interpreted.

title: A Sliding Mickelson Has Been Working on His Driving Skills
description: Phil Mickelson has come to the British Open to make amends, not excuses.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: An Official Yes To The E.U.
description: Parliament unanimously endorsed the island's entry to the European Union, paving the way for its official accession to the 15-nation club next May. The move comes three months after the European Union agreed to accept Cyprus as a member along with nine other nations. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Blackstone Names Adviser
description: The Blackstone Group, the manager of the world's biggest buyout fund, said yesterday that it had named Charles H. Noski, a former vice chairman of AT&T, as a senior adviser to the company.

title: You May Be Hercules; You Just Don't Know It
description: It is not just that some people don't know their own strength. It may be that nobody does.

title: House Retreats From Bush's Nuclear Plan
description: A spending measure emerging in the Republican-led House eliminates much of the money sought by the Bush administration for research into a new generation of nuclear weapons that it says are needed to combat 21st-century threats.

title: Times Company Posts 7.5% Decline in Quarterly Earnings
description: The New York Times Company reported today that its earnings in the second quarter fell 7.5 percent, weighed down in part by declines in travel-related advertising in the early spring that resulted from the war in Iraq and the spread of the disease SARS.

title: Cholesterol: When It's Good, It's Very, Very Good
description: ''H'' stands for ''high'' -- that's how to remember which of your cholesterol readings should be as high as you can get it: H.D.L.-C. Known as the good cholesterol, it is the common designation for high-density lipoprotein cholesterol.

title: A Question of Opposites
description: To the Editor:

title: BURBERRY SALES REBOUND AS PANIC ABOUT SARS SUBSIDES
description: The British luxury-goods retailer Burberry Group said sales revived toward the end of the first quarter as price cuts and the end of the SARS epidemic encouraged shoppers to return to stores. Sales at outlets open at least a year gained 1 percent to 2 percent in the three months ended June 30, the chief operating officer, Mike Metcalf, said on a conference call. The company's sales dropped 5 percent in the first seven weeks of the period because of concerns about SARS and the war in Iraq, he said.

title: State Used False Testimony In Shooting Case, Court Says
description: A federal appeals court has granted a new trial to a man convicted of attempted murder, ruling that a prosecutor for Queens District Attorney Richard A. Brown elicited false testimony and misled the jury during the man's trial in 1992.

title: Mixed Results In Mayor's Plan To Use Offices As Classrooms
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg visited a new charter school in Harlem yesterday to offer it as proof that his slashing of the education bureaucracy will create 5,000 much-needed student seats by the start of school in September.

title: Sound, Fury and Cellphone Users and Abusers
description: A woman sought out Amtrak conductor Walter Garrett recently on the Metroliner's Washington-New York run to complain that a fellow commuter had grabbed her cellphone and thrown it against the wall, smashing it into pieces. The incident took place in one of the ''quiet cars'' that Amtrak has designated on certain trains as cellphone-free for riders who treasure tranquillity. The company started the experiment in January 2001 and says it has been a great success.

title: Uranium Quicksand
description: In trying to defend the indefensible in its depiction of Iraq's nuclear weapons program, the Bush administration is now making a legalistic argument that would be laughable if the matter were not so serious. Because the British government believed in January that Iraq had been trying to import large quantities of uranium from Africa, top administration officials are saying, Mr. Bush was technically correct when he cited the British concerns in the State of the Union address. The explanation conveniently glosses over the fact that long before Mr. Bush delivered the speech on Jan. 28, American intelligence officials had concluded that the British charge was probably unreliable.

title: Owners of sport utility vehicles strike back at environmental critics with an ad of their own.
description: A FLEDGLING association of owners of sport utility vehicles is taking aim at their critics with a swipe at anti-S.U.V. advertising campaigns.

title: China Sentences Flower Tycoon to 18 Years for Fraud and Bribery
description: A flower tycoon considered one of China's most dynamic private businessmen was convicted of fraud and bribery today and sentenced to 18 years in prison, his lawyers and relatives said after a closed-door sentencing hearing.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: SUSPECT IN BOMB PLOT ESCAPES A Muslim militant accused of taking part in a plot to bomb the American Embassy in Singapore in 2001 escaped from his cell inside Camp Crame, the national police headquarters in Manila. Fathur Rohman al-Ghozi, a 31-year-old Indonesian, was a member of Jemaah Islamiyah, the Islamic fundamentalist group based in Indonesia that has been accused by authorities of carrying out the deadly bomb attacks in Bali last October. He was jailed in the Philippines last year for illegal possession of explosives. Mr. Ghozi escaped with two suspected members of Abu Sayyaf, an extremist group. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: MGM Sets Conditions On Bid for Vivendi Units
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer offered to raise its bid for the entertainment assets of Vivendi Universal yesterday by $300 million, to $11.5 billion, on the condition that Vivendi allow MGM to review certain confidential documents that have so far been withheld, according to executives close to the auction.

title: It's Your Big Day, but There's a Catch . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGEL, , EDITH DAVIS
description: SIEGEL--Edith Davis. Died July 13, 2003 at 86. Her children, grandchildren, brother and friends mourn her passing. Service at Temple Israel, 112 East 75 St, NY NY on Thursday July 17 at 10AM. Interment to follow in Kingston NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to Crystal Run Village, 601 Stony Ford Rd, Middletown NY 10941 or Scan-NY, 207 East 27 St, NY NY 10016.

title: Lottery Numbers
Pope Names New Philadelphia Archbishop
description: Archbishop Justin F. Rigali of St. Louis, a theological conservative who spent three decades working in the Vatican, was appointed by Pope John Paul II today to succeed Cardinal Anthony J. Bevilacqua of Philadelphia, who is retiring at age 80.

title: Developing the Profile Of a Yorkshire Copper
description: Alan Banks, the Yorkshire police detective in Peter Robinson's series of crime novels -- the latest is ''Close to Home'' -- is a tough-minded cop with an intellectual bent, a man who quotes Philip Larkin and listens to Rostropovich and the Rolling Stones. Though younger by a decade and not as apt to rankle his colleagues, he has much in common with John Rebus, the Edinburgh detective in Ian Rankin's books. Each is something of a maverick and a complex character who grows from book to book.

title: Seabiscuit Slept (With Lots of Mares) Here
description: Few people in this scrappy former timber town nestled in the redwoods would disagree that the most famous citizen ever to hail from here was short-legged, knobby-kneed, somewhat scrawny and ill-tempered -- a mud-colored underdog, not unlike Willits itself.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: EXPANDING CONSERVATION PROGRAM The Department of the Interior said it would provide $70.4 million to 29 states for endangered species conservation projects. Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton said financing for such projects had increased by about 400 percent over the last two and a half years. A spokesman for the department said that in recent years the conservation programs had been intended for Southeastern states and California, which will receive almost a quarter of the money involved. Arkansas, North Carolina, Tennessee and Texas are among other states that will get money. (NYT)

title: Wider Budget Gap Is Seen
description: The White House plans to release its latest projections on Tuesday for the federal budget deficit in this fiscal year, and Congressional budget authorities said today that the figure would be well over $400 billion.

title: Ballgame, Then Concert: Williams Hits Perfect Chord
description: Bernie Williams was so nervous performing at the House of Blues on Sunday night that he had to close his eyes. Many musicians do it, but Williams, the Yankees' center fielder, was doing more than drifting into a musical trance. He was protecting himself from an eager crowd probably wondering what kind of guitarist this baseball player really was.

title: Ralph Emerson Cross, 93; Helped Retool Car Industry
description: Ralph Emerson Cross, an engineer and manufacturer who helped bring modern automation to the postwar auto industry, died at his home in Grosse Pointe, Mich., on June 26. He was 93.

title: Bill Keller, Columnist, Is Selected As The Times's Executive Editor
description: Bill Keller, a columnist for The New York Times who previously served as its managing editor and foreign editor and as a foreign correspondent, has been chosen as its executive editor.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Kuwait: Leadership Shift
description: The emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber Ahmed al-Sabah, has met a demand of political activists by separating the office of crown prince from that of prime minister. Sheik Sabah al-Ahmed al-Sabah, foreign minister for some 40 years and the emir's brother, was appointed prime minister on Sunday. Analysts were divided over whether the move represented a real shift toward greater democracy or was merely royal family housekeeping. Sheik Sabah has been effectively running the government because Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, the crown prince, has been seriously ill. The change, however, means the prime minister can be subject to questioning by Parliament. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: When the All-Stars Played to Win
description: The outcome of Major League Baseball's All-Star Game has never mattered in the standings. Nevertheless, for decades after the game was first played in 1933, the All-Stars played to win -- it was a matter of league pride. Today's players, of course, have come to treat the Midsummer Classic like a cross between a jovial exhibition and a family reunion. The nadir was reached last year, when a lackluster contest was abruptly ended with a tie score in the 11th inning.

title: The Dirt On the David
description: It's not easy being the world's most famous statue. Michelangelo's ''David'' has managed to rouse passions and provoke controversy ever since 1504, when unruly Florentines greeted its unveiling with a hail of stones. Since then it has been the target of rioters who hurled a bench at it in 1527, breaking the left arm in three pieces, and of an envious artist named Piero Cannata who took a hammer to it in 1991, demolishing one of its toes. Few masterpieces of Western art have been on the receiving end of so many projectiles.

title: AMERICAN HOME MORTGAGE TO BUY REAL ESTATE COMPANY
description: American Home Mortgage Holdings, which lends money through 206 branches and the Internet, agreed yesterday to buy Apex Mortgage Capital Inc., a real estate investment trust based in Los Angeles, for about $186 million to diversify its lending. American Home Mortgage, based in Melville, N.Y., will pay $6.21 a share for Apex Mortgage, or 11 percent more than the stock's closing price on Friday, the companies said. The sale has been approved by the boards of both companies. American Home Mortgage, which last month agreed to buy the assets of American Mortgage, plans to become a real estate investment trust to reduce its tax payments.

title: Architect and Developer Clash Over Plans for Trade Center Site
description: With pressure increasing to begin the rebuilding at ground zero, the architect with the winning design for the World Trade Center site plans to meet today with representatives of the developer to try to resolve clashing visions of what will be built.

title: Child Welfare Disgrace
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Seems to Favor Sending a Modest Force to Liberia
description: President Bush today gave his strongest indication yet that he would send a small force of American troops into Liberia to help enforce the cease-fire there. But he said that he was waiting for further information from military teams in the region before deciding, and that the peacekeeping operation would ultimately be taken over by the United Nations.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: FALLOUT FROM FAILED STRIKE Leaders of IG Metall, Germany's most powerful union, have proposed a special convention at the end of August to settle a leadership battle that erupted after a failed strike in eastern Germany. The meeting, which must be approved by the union's 41-member board, could derail the candidacy of Jurgen Peters to replace the longtime chairman, Klaus Zwickel, left, who is departing. Mr. Peters, now the union's vice chairman, has been blamed for the collapse of the strike, which had been called to demand a shorter workweek. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NOVACK, , RABBI JULIUS
description: NOVACK--Rabbi Julius. Congregation Hope of Israel and its Sisterhood sadly note the passing of our esteemed Rabbi, spiritual leader and mentor. For over 30 years, Rabbi Novack, a brilliant student of the learned Rabbi David Leibowitz, labored tirelessly to maintain the vitality of our daily minyons, festivals and sabbath services. He devoted his life to enriching congregations, yeshivas and nursing homes in Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx. He will be dearly missed by our congregation, his family, and his loving wife Judith. >>AD#

title: Their Health Costs Soaring, Automakers Are to Begin Labor Talks
description: The Big Three automakers, which open contract talks with the United Auto Workers union on Wednesday, are making a bigger issue out of reducing medical costs than they have in years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MUELLER, , MARTHA
description: MUELLER -- Martha. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of the beloved sister of our esteemed benefactor, Werner Brodman. To Werner, Judy, and to the entire family, our heartfelt sympathy. Rabbi Marc Schneier Michael B. Weisbrod, Pres. Seymour G. Siegel, Treasurer >>AD#

title: A Question of Opposites
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Thursday, about Microsoft's new employee compensation plan, misstated the type of grants involved and their tax treatment in some circumstances. The company describes the grants as restricted stock ''units,'' not restricted stock. The company says that device has tax consequences different from those of restricted stock.

title: Lining Up for Healthy Colons
description: When Katie Couric had an on-air colonoscopy, America followed her example: a study released yesterday found that rates of the screening for colon cancer jumped by more than 20 percent.

title: Rock 'n' Roll Dissidents, Fearless for 4 Decades
description: Four decades ago Ed Sanders and Tuli Kupferberg founded the Fugs in an East Village bookstore on a bedrock of sex, drugs, rock 'n' roll and poetry.

title: White House Foresees Deficit Reaching $455 Billion This Year
description: WASHINGTON, July 15  The White House today projected a $455 billion budget deficit in the current fiscal year, by far the government's biggest deficit ever and $150 billion higher than what the administration predicted just five months ago.

title: Court Sides With M.T.A. Dispute Over Toll Increase
description: NEW YORK (AP) -- The MTA had the legal right to raise the city's transit fares and tolls, a state appeals court ruled Tuesday.

title: Officials Favor Larger Site For Trade Center Complex
description: Struggling to solve an urban-planning Rubik's Cube, the Port Authority is now inclined to expand the World Trade Center redevelopment site to the south by acquiring the property on which the doomed Deutsche Bank tower stands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOCTOR, , DANNY
description: HOCTOR--Danny. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed Member, Friar Danny Hoctor, on July 14, 2003. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Services will be held on Thursday, July 17, at 10 AM, at St. Luke's Church, Franklin Turnpike, Waldwick, NJ. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director >>AD#

title: Two Executives Switch Agencies
description: Two creative executives have changed agencies.

title: Justice Department Ends Its Review of PeopleSoft's Bid to Acquire J.D. Edwards
description: The Justice Department today cleared a bid by PeopleSoft to acquire J. D. Edwards, saying it would not prolong its inquiry of the merger's antitrust impact.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINDEMANN, , STEPHEN
description: LINDEMANN--Stephen. Devoted father of Patricia and Eric. Dear brother of Donna. Loving grandfather of Rebecca, Jordan, Casey and Tyler. Services Wednesday, 11:30am, ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel,'' 91st Street & Amsterdam Avenue. >>AD#

title: Broad Study Finds Significant Resistance to AIDS Drugs
description: The biggest study so far of resistance to AIDS drugs, to be released on Wednesday at an international AIDS conference in Paris, finds that about 10 percent of all newly infected patients in Europe are infected with drug-resistant strains.

title: Webber Avoids Jail, Pleading Guilty on a Contempt Charge
description: Chris Webber, the Sacramento Kings' All-Star forward, pleaded guilty to criminal contempt in federal court today, one day before jury selection was scheduled to begin in the federal perjury case against him. Webber pleaded to a lesser charge, striking a deal with prosecutors that allows him to avoid jail time.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Gilead Sales Surge On Aids Drug
description: Gilead Sciences said yesterday that second-quarter sales soared as doctors wrote more prescriptions for its Viread AIDS drug. Shares rose as much as 15 percent. Revenue was $236 million to $239 million in the quarter, the company said in a statement. Analysts had expected $179 million, according to the average estimate from those surveyed by Thomson Financial. Sales of Viread were as much as $165 million, about $45 million higher than some analysts expected, and may mean that second-quarter earnings were also above forecasts, said Eric Schmidt, an analyst at SG Cowen Securities. Gilead already raised its forecast for 2003 sales of the drug by 18 percent to as much as $500 million in April. Before yesterday's announcement, analysts had expected the company, which reported a loss of $438.1 million, or $2.21 a share, in the first quarter, to earn 20 cents a share in the three months through June, according to a Thomson Financial survey. Shares rose $7.97, or 13.4 percent, to $67.25. after reaching $68.15, its highest price since it began trading in 1992.

title: Earnings Reports
Sports of The Times; Pitcher Is Taken Out Without Being Told
description: SO here's Barry Zito, sitting in a hotel ballroom, talking with reporters about how it's great to be on the American League All-Star team and saying, yes, he pitched Sunday for the Oakland Athletics, but he could certainly throw to one batter in this game, even on one day's rest. He threw to one batter in last year's All-Star Game, and that also came on one day's rest. Besides, this is the dream game, this maybe-never-again-in-a-lifetime opportunity (you never know when a sore arm or a flat fastball will terminate one's career). He said he was honored to be on the team, and was excited when a week ago Sunday he heard that he had been selected for this Midsummer Classic, as the publicists term it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLARK, , ROBERT J.
description: CLARK--Robert J., of Holtsville, NY, age 60, on July 12, 2003. Most beloved husband of Georgene for 36 years. Devoted and loving father of Darby Ann Clark and Tracy Lynn Pearl. Loving father-inlaw of Raphael Pearl. Cherished grandfather of Kyle Robert Pearl. Retired from Pfizer Inc., NYC headquarters, after 30 years. Truly loved by all who had the privilege to know him. Reposing Joseph A. Weber Funeral Home, Hawkins Avenue, Lake Ronkonkoma, Tuesday 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM. Services Wednesday 10:30 AM, Lake Ronkonkoma United Methodist Church. Burial, Lake Ronkonkoma Cemetery. Eastern Star services Tuesday 7:30 PM, Masonic services, Tuesday 8 PM. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | White Plains: Indictment In Tossing Of Baby
description: A man accused of throwing his 10-month-old daughter out a seventh-floor window was indicted yesterday on a charge of attempted murder. The infant survived the fall, suffering bruises and a broken rib. Prosecutors said the man, Willie Williams, 29, of Ossining, had threatened to kill his former girlfriend, the child's mother, then attacked her on June 21. He hurled the baby from the window after learning that the police had been called. Mr. Williams could face 25 years in prison if convicted. His court-appointed legal adviser, Kevin Griffin, said he had not seen the indictment. Mr. Williams, who is in custody, plans to represent himself. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: United Airlines May Face Deeper Challenges on Two Fronts
description: United Airlines mechanics have voted to oust the powerful machinists' union in favor of being represented by a union that is smaller but more militant.

title: Eliot Wald; Comedy Writer, 57
description: Eliot Wald, a comedy writer for television and films, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 57 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Art Technology Shares Rise On I.B.M. Pact
description: Shares of the Art Technology Group rose yesterday after the company, an Internet software provider, said it had signed a marketing agreement with I.B.M. Art Technology rose 24 cents, or about 13.5 percent, to $2.02. The company's shares have risen 43 percent this year. By including I.B.M.'s WebSphere software with its server programs, Art Technology will be able to shift attention to technology used to interact with consumers, allowing the company to compete with companies similar to its size, a spokesman, John Dragoon, said. Art Technology will focus on programs that allow people to check the number of minutes left on their plans at companies like AT&T Wireless Services, or to buy pants from the J. Crew unit of the Texas Pacific Group.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: A High-Speed Rail
description: China appeared set to select Japan's bullet train technology for its new multibillion-dollar high-speed rail link between Beijing and Shanghai, the state news media reported. The Economic Observer said that the authorities had nearly settled on Japan's shinkansen, or bullet train, for the 815-mile route, estimated to cost $12 billion. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Poland: New Wrapping For Stalin's Gift
description: It is almost universally regarded as the greatest eyesore in a capital city known for its brutally unattractive architecture, but now Warsaw's tourist authority says it will dress up the city's Palace of Culture to celebrate Poland's entry to the European Union next May. According to the newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza, the soot-stained, 42-story, stone-clad tower will be wrapped in gold fabric at a cost of about $1.9 million. The tower was a gift of the Soviet dictator Josef Stalin and dominates the center of the city. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: BBC Defends Itself Against Accusations of Bias on War
description: LONDON, July 15  The British Broadcasting Corporation, the public-financed network that sees itself as the world leader in balanced broadcast reporting and analysis, defended itself in Parliament today against government charges of bias in its war coverage.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Clownfish Social Register

title: Limbaugh Added to ESPN's Grand Old Party
description: Rush Limbaugh's sportscasting career, stunted when Dennis Miller, and not he, was hired for ABC's ''Monday Night Football'' three years ago, was reborn yesterday when ESPN enlisted him to join Chris Berman, Tom Jackson, Steve Young, Michael Irvin and Chris Mortensen on ''Sunday NFL Countdown.''

title: But is it O.K. to chew gum while bar dancing?: Singapore lets its hair down
description: SINGAPORE:  It was midnight at Carnegie's, an Irish-theme pub in the heart of Singapore's Chinatown, when a young woman clambered onto the bar, stood up amid the ashtrays and cocktails, and started shaking her suede miniskirt to 2 Live Crew's hip-hop sexual anthem, "Me So Horny."

title: AOL Defense: It Was Doing What It Said It Would Do
description: AOL Time Warner fired the first salvo in its defense against a lawsuit from angry shareholders yesterday, contending that it had disclosed for years the business practices some are now calling fraud.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER SOARS. Copper prices rose as inventories fell to a two-year low, partly because of increased demand from China. The September contract increased 1.8 cents, or 2.3 percent, to 79.8 cents a pound.

title: San Miguel Chief's Bank Purchase Is Nullified
description: A Philippine antigraft court has dealt a blow to efforts by the chairman of the Philippine beer and food conglomerate San Miguel to regain control of the shares that put him at the company's helm nearly 30 years ago.

title: Front Row
description: The Mayor's New Fashion Plate

title: The Road to War Was Slippery
description: To the Editor:

title: KONICA GETS U.S. ANTITRUST APPROVAL TO ACQUIRE MINOLTA
description: The Konica Corporation has been cleared by the Justice Department to buy the Minolta Company and become one of Japan's largest makers of cameras and imaging equipment. The combined company, to be called Konica Minolta Holdings Inc., will be formed in August and have more than $8 billion in annual sales. Last week the European Commission approved the 234 billion yen ($2 billion) buyout after Konica agreed to sell its stake in the Sekonic Corporation in Japan, which makes copiers and optical meters. Konica shares were unchanged yesterday.

title: States, Intent on Regulating, Look at Morgan
description: State securities regulators announced a new investigation into Morgan Stanley's mutual fund sales practices yesterday and warned that pending legislation could stop the states from pursuing this and other securities initiatives in the future.

title: Conflict on Iraq-Syria Border Feeds Rage Against the U.S.
description: On this desolate stretch of desert along the Iraqi frontier, tensions with the American soldiers just across the border are running so high, Syrian soldiers say, that four villagers have been shot by American soldiers in the past month.

title: Yahoo in Deal For Overture, An Internet Listing Service
description: Yahoo, the big Internet portal, announced yesterday that it would buy Overture Services, an Internet search listings service, for $1.63 billion in cash and stock.

title: Documents Disclose Wider Pension Deficit
description: United Airlines' pension difficulties may be significantly greater than the airline has disclosed to its investors and employees, according to documents filed in federal bankuptcy court.

title: St.-Pierre Journal; On Bastille Day, Far Away but Fervently French
description: Only Maurice Chevalier seemed to be missing on Bastille Day in this last speck of a French imperial holding that once stretched from this tiny archipelago just south of Newfoundland to New Orleans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUCKINGHAM, , RAYMOND J.D.
description: BUCKINGHAM -- Raymond J.D. Well known singer and vocal pedagogue died at the age of 75 in Holbrook, MD. He is survived by his loving wife Nancy and four children Christopher, Georgia Yambanis, Elizabeth and Peter. Raymond began his career in musical comedy in England, followed by a successful classical singing career in the US. He was also known as a prominent voice teacher who developed a highly effective technique for developing and building voices. A memorial service will be held at 1PM on Thursday, July 17 at Temple Sharey Tefilo-Israel, 432 Scotland Rd, South Orange NJ. >>AD#

title: Selig Defends Reward System
description: Commissioner Bud Selig has heard the widespread criticism of his decision to let the winner of the All-Star Game have the home-field advantage in the World Series. But Selig strongly defended the choice tonight.

title: Powell Affirms That Red Cross Is Allowing Israel to Take Part
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell has certified that the Israeli relief agency, the Red Shield of David, is fully taking part in the activities of the International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement, despite a standoff over the agency's emblem.

title: At British Open, the Way the Ball Bounces May Tell the Tale
description: SANDWICH, England, July 15  Tiger Woods won the British Open in 2000 at St. Andrews, never once hitting into a bunker.

title: Mexican Film: High Art, Low Budget
description: A boomlet of celebrated movies in the last three years has prompted predictions of a renaissance in the long-dormant Mexican film industry. Not since the golden age of the 1940's and 50's, when the industry cranked out melodramas and comedies for all of Latin America and counted the Spanish exile Luis Buuel among its stars, have Mexican movies created such a stir abroad.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Reno; City Known for Gambling Works to Reinvent Itself
description: Reno, Nev., the self-proclaimed ''biggest little city in the world,'' is trying to reinvent itself as a mecca for business travelers to make up for the gambling revenues it has lost to the Indian casinos that have sprung up in California near Sacramento. Last August, it doubled the size of its convention center and renovated the business district on the banks of the Truckee River. It is also advertising special promotions, like dinner and show packages at the local casinos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWAB, , ANNE L. (NEE MICHAELIS)
description: SCHWAB--Anne L. (nee Michaelis). Beloved wife of Edgar, mother of John, motherin-law of Cheryl, many other family members and friends, at age 91. Services private. >>AD#

title: Sports of The Times; Knicks Begin A Summer Of Tall Tales
description: THERE is something junior-varsity-like about the Knicks, even in the summer league. They drafted big but they still seem small and, at this site, they are dwarfed by the mere presence of LeBron James.

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend on Friday about ''I Capture the Castle'' misidentified the actor who plays the young man in love with Cassandra, the narrator. He is Henry Cavill. (Joe Sowerbutts plays Thomas, her younger brother.)

title: Iraqis Celebrate, Defying a Holiday Ban
description: In its first official act on Sunday, the new Iraqi Governing Council abolished all old state holidays.

title: Japan Phone Case to Pit Business Against Bureaucrats
description: Few things are more absolute in Japan than the will of its bureaucrats. For decades, they have written almost every major piece of legislation, drafted each year's budget and doled out informal administrative guidance that has amounted to the rule of law.

title: Why We Die, Why We Live: A New Theory on Aging
description: As you write yet another check to cover your children's ruinous college bills, there is definitely a bright side to consider: if you weren't doing this, you'd long since be dead.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Lord Shawcross, Britain's chief prosecutor at the Nuremberg trials of Nazi war crimes, misidentified the mother of a surviving son, Hume. She was Lord Shawcross's second wife, Joan Winifred Mather -- not his third, Monique. The article also misspelled the surname of the Labor prime minister whose landslide victory in 1945 helped carry Lord Shawcross into the House of Commons. He was Clement Attlee, not Atlee.

title: London Seeks Custody of 2 British Terror Suspects Held by U.S.
description: The British government is discussing with the United States the possibility of taking custody of two British terror suspects destined for military tribunals at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, and of putting them on trial here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, , DONALD B.
description: MILLER--Donald B. Former ad executive with RumrillHoyt, Satchi-Satchi, and Horizon Media died July 13, 2003. Survived by wife Jean, son James, daughter Patricia. >>AD#

title: Police Lieutenant and Friend Found Dead
description: A New York City police lieutenant and his companion were found dead yesterday afternoon at the home they shared in Roslyn Heights, in Nassau County, the Nassau County police said. They called the killings a double homicide. Earlier in the day, a New York City police official, who spoke on condition that his name not be printed, said a ''very preliminary'' investigation had found ''it appears to be a suicide/homicide.''

title: Increasing the Odds of Trouble
description: Heart experts would like doctors and patients to stop focusing just on bad cholesterol and start thinking about ''metabolic syndrome,'' a cluster of warning signs that new research shows is far more accurate in predicting the risk of diabetes and heart disease.

title: G.I. Killed and 6 Are Wounded in Ambush
description: An American soldier was killed and six others were wounded in a bold guerrilla attack at dawn today in the heart of the city's affluent Mansour district.

title: Tex Schramm, Innovator for Cowboys and N.F.L., Dies at 83
description: Tex Schramm, an ebullient, innovative football man who directed the rise of the Dallas Cowboys and played a major role in the merger of the rival American and National Football Leagues in 1970, died today, the Cowboys said.

title: Teaching Computers To Work In Unison
description: Computers do wondrous things, but computer science itself is largely a discipline of step-by-step progress as a steady stream of innovations in hardware, software and networking pile up. It is an engineering science whose frontiers are pushed ahead by people building new tools rendered in silicon and programming code rather than the breathtaking epiphanies and grand unifying theories of mathematics or physics.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Chip Maker Sells Shares
description: NEC Electronics, the chip making division of the NEC Corporation, said yesterday that it had sold 34 million shares at 4,200 yen ($35.66) each, the upper end of expectations. The sale raised 143 billion yen ($1.2 billion), making it the largest public offering this year in Tokyo. The strong demand for the shares, which begin trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on July 24, comes a few weeks after Seiko Epson, which makes printers for computers, completed a successful initial public offering. In yesterday's sale, NEC Electronics sold 23.5 million shares and its parent, NEC, sold 10.5 million shares that it holds in its subsidiary. NEC may sell an additional 3 million shares to meet demand. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the opposing roles played by Senators Bill Frist and John Edwards in the debate over capping jury awards in medical malpractice cases misstated the name of a group that supports limits. It is the American Tort Reform Association, not American Tort Law.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   URBANO, , JEANETTE (NEE DIGRANDI)
description: URBANO--Jeanette (nee DiGrandi), age 87, July 14, 2003, peacefully after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Armand, most loving and wise mother of Georgia, Paula and Natalie, loving mother-in-law of Richard Raysman and David Dong, and beloved grandmother of Julia and Peter. Visiting at Nolan and TaylorHowe Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Ave. at Main St, Northport, NY Wednesday 2-5 & 7-9 pm. Mass of Christian Burial 10am Thursday at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs R.C. Church, Centerport, NY. Interment at Northport Rural Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home, 1339 York Ave, NY NY 10021. >>AD#

title: To Go Where Few Have Gone Before
description: Triple Crown. When those two words are linked with a player, they should make him excited, make him smile or at least make him act a little excited or fake a smile. No player has won a Triple Crown since Carl Yastrzemski for the Boston Red Sox in 1967. It is one of the rarest of feats in baseball, it has been accomplished 14 times by 12 different players, and the pursuit of it should be celebrated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACOBSEN, , JOSEPHINE
description: JACOBSEN--Josephine. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be mourned by the world of literature. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Fouled Beaches Reopen
description: After the authorities closed four miles of public beach on the Jersey Shore last Friday because of spreading medical waste, New Jersey officials said yesterday that the waste was not as threatening as originally feared. Elaine Makatura, a spokeswoman for the State Department of Environmental Protection, said that an investigation found syringes used for home insulin injections among plastic waste on the beaches, but that all the waste had been flushed through sewer systems after recent heavy rains. The beaches, in Lavallette and Dover Township, reopened on Saturday. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FURTH, , ENRIQUE
description: FURTH--Enrique. Born August 4, 1928 in Buenos Aires, Argentina, died suddenly July 11, 2003 at his home in Brooklyn, NY. Survived by his three children, Susan of Bedford, NY, Hugo (Lori) of Manhattan Beach, CA, and Elizabeth of Brooklyn, NY; brother, Tomas, of Buenos Aires, former wife, Ada of Playa Del Rey, CA, and long-time friend Randi Baker of Brooklyn, NY. Preceded in death by his sister, Dorotea Furth-Cerych, of Paris, France. He was retired from a long and distinguished career as professor of computer science and data processing at New York University. He will be remembered for his quick wit, clever humor, deep knowledge of many subjects, love of books, and interesting conversation. His children remember him as a loving and proud father, extremely generous with his time, who was never too busy to talk to or spend time with his children. His family was always his highest priority. His daughter, Elizabeth, who was born to him later in life brought him great joy to the end of his days. He was also very proud of his grandchildren, Eric, Joel, and Daniel. He will be missed tremendously, as he left far too soon, by his loving family and his many many friends both in the U.S. as well as Argentina, where he visited frequently. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about new fees for New York City Housing Court, postponed after opposition from an alliance of landlords and tenants, referred imprecisely to the practice of Sokolski & Zekaria, a law firm threatening to sue over the issue. While the firm is representing both landlords and tenants in this matter, it ordinarly represents only tenants in Housing Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOULDEN, , REGINA A.
description: GOULDEN--Regina A. on July 13, 2003. Graduate of the College of Mount Saint Vincent, class of 1951. Retired NYC Office of Comptroller. Beloved sister of Joseph A. Loving aunt of Estelle Menon, Alice Jamba, Laura and Joseph. Funeral from Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 E. Tremont Av, Bronx, Wednesday, 9:30AM, Mass of Christian Burial St. Frances de Chantal at 10:00AM. Interment St Raymond Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday 2-5 & 7-9PM. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about two early-college high schools opening in New York City misstated the percentage of graduates who moved on to four-year colleges from an existing one, Bard High School Early College. It was more than 90 percent, not 75.

title: Attention Holiday Inn Towel Snatchers: All Is Forgiven
description: ''EVERYBODY'S got a Holiday Inn story,'' said Mark Snyder, who took over in late February as the executive vice president in charge of brand management for the chain.

title: Deadlines in Cordiant Deal May Force Opponents to Act
description: The Cordiant Communications Group, the British advertiser that has agreed to be bought by the WPP Group, is facing deadlines this week that may accelerate last-minute moves by shareholders opposed to the deal.

title: Pataki Has New Proposal To Revise Drug Laws
description: Officials in Gov. George E. Pataki's administration started circulating a proposal tonight that they said they hoped would lead to a new state drug-sentencing law within months.

title: White House Tries to Dismiss Iraq Claim as Campaign Issue
description: The White House mounted an aggressive campaign today to contain what several Republicans said was a potentially worrisome dispute over President Bush's use of suspect information in pressing for a war on Iraq.

title: Metro Briefing | Manhattan: City Seeks Tax Refunds
description: New York City has sued the federal government in an effort to collect $100 million in taxes that the city says it should not have paid. The suit, filed last week in Federal District Court in Manhattan, seeks a refund of Social Security taxes paid from 1989 to 1998 for members of the Police, Fire, Sanitation and Correction Departments who were injured in the line of duty and were out of work for less than six months. Workers' compensation payments are exempt from the Social Security tax, and the city contends its payments under a city statute similar to workers' compensation should also be exempt. An I.R.S. spokesman declined comment. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

description: VITIELLO--Christopher. July 15, 1993. Loving son and brother, dear nephew and cousin, loyal friend. You live forever in our hearts

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Murdoch Seeks Software Stake
description: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation will offer to buy up to 20 percent of Hughes Software Systems, an Indian communications software subsidiary of the Hughes Electronics Corporation, the Bombay Stock Exchange announced. The offer is related to plans by the News Corporation to buy a controlling stake in Hughes Electronics from General Motors. Hughes Electronics owns DirecTV, the broadcast satellite service. Securities regulations in India require that stockholders be given the opportunity to sell their shares when there is a change in control of a company. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: A Governing Council for Iraq
description: Washington was wise to speed the formation of a broadly representative 25-member Governing Council for Iraq, which met for the first time this past weekend. In a careful balancing act, the Council consists of 13 Arab Shiites, 5 Arab Sunnis, 5 Kurds, a Christian and a Turkmen. There are 22 men and 3 women. Many were exiles, but at least some are people who suffered through Saddam Hussein's tyranny inside Iraq. How coherently this highly disparate body can act and how much power it will wield remain to be seen. Yet at least the appearance of limited self-government has been restored, and appearances do count.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: NEWARK: 1 DEAD, 3 HURT IN SHOOTING One person was killed and three were injured last night when shots broke out in the Vailsburg section, the police said. The shootings occurred about 11:30 p.m. in front of a home on Valley Street near Stuyvesant Avenue, said Robert Rankin, the police director. The injured were taken to University Hospital, where one was in critical condition.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Cameras For High-Crime Areas
description: The police will soon install several cameras in high-crime neighborhoods in Chicago in an effort to curb gang violence. Each camera will cost $15,000 and will have a control panel that officers can use in their squad cars to zoom in on a specific area. The control panels will cost $7,000 each. The police would not say how many cameras would be used, but they said the cameras would probably be on the South and West Sides. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

description: PARIS, July 15  President Jacques Chirac said today that France would not send troops to Iraq to help the American peacekeeping effort there.

description: ROSEN--Fred W. Age 85 died at his home in Dalton, GA on July 14, 2003. Retired LCDR US Navy, served as Captain of PT 207 in Motor Torpedo Squadron Ron 15 in the Mediterranean theatre during WW II and was awarded the Purple Heart. Former CEO of Enduro Mills. Son of the late Jennie and Louis Rosen and brother of the late Ira and Eli Rosen. He is survived by his sister, Helene Alisberg and seven devoted nieces and nephews: Barrett Rosen, Robert Rosen, Gary Rosen, Arthur Rosen, Cathy Chambers, Nancy Alisberg and Andrew Alisberg and 14 great nieces and nephews. As the endeared and respected President of Florida Pneumatic Manufacturing. Mr. Swank was a fine leader, a dear colleague and friend to all. His twenty years of dedicated service ended too soon on July 12th, 2003. He will be truly missed by all. Rest well, Charlie. >>AD#

title: No-Show Equals No Vote, Irate N.A.A.C.P. Hosts Say
description: Leaders of the nation's most prominent black civil rights organization attacked three Democratic presidential candidates today for failing to show up for a forum that the group held here at its annual convention.

title: First Stop, Straphanging; Next Stop, Hanging Ten
description: As popular surfing destinations go, Beach 90th Street in Queens does not have quite the charm of, say, Huntington Beach in California. Instead of sprawling piers in the Spanish Mission style, there is a shopping strip in the mid-70's style, facing a sad-looking Super Wok take-out place and a defunct center for the elderly.

description: To the Editor:

title: Pattern Of Corruption
description: More than half of the U.S. Army's combat strength is now bogged down in Iraq, which didn't have significant weapons of mass destruction and wasn't supporting Al Qaeda. We have lost all credibility with allies who might have provided meaningful support; Tony Blair is still with us, but has lost the trust of his public. All this puts us in a very weak position for dealing with real threats. Did I mention that North Korea has been extracting fissionable material from its fuel rods?

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: 3 Hurt In Gun Plant Blast
description: An explosion at a Glock firearms plant in Smyrna injured three people, one critically, the authorities said. The cause of the explosion was uncertain, but it may have been the result of residue from spent ammunition in the area, a firing range, said Tracy Mansfield of the Smyrna Fire Department. It caused no fire and did not damage the building, but three burn victims were taken to a hospital, one with ''significant burns over most of his body,'' Ms. Mansfield said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Loral Files for Bankruptcy; Boeing to Take $1.1 Billion Charge
description: Two leading satellite manufacturers weakened by a long slump in new orders swallowed bitter financial medicine today, as Loral Space and Communications sought protection in federal bankruptcy court and Boeing said it would take a $1.1 billion charge against its second-quarter earnings.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Profit Grows At Steel Maker
description: Pohang Iron and Steel, known as Posco, posted a profit of 550 billion won ($471 million) in the second quarter, more than three times the 169 billion won that it earned in the period a year earlier. The earnings, the best quarterly profit since the company netted 1.3 trillion won in the first quarter of 2000, resulted largely from increased exports of steel products to China, notably for automakers. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: More Itsy-Bitsy Teeny-Weeny Than Ever
description: In the poster for ''The Swimming Pool,'' a new film by the French director Franois Ozon, Ludivine Sagnier lies soporifically on a granite patio in a chevron-patterned bikini whose construction clearly did not tax the world's fabric supply. To an American eye, the image seems almost anachronistic for the very reason that Ms. Sagnier isn't spear-fishing in her bare bikini, wrestling felons or competing in an Australian surfing competition.

title: A First: Fraternal Twins, One Placenta
description: Doctors have reported the first known case of fraternal twins who shared a single placenta in the womb. The researchers have suggested that this unique form of twinning may have come about as a result of in vitro fertilization.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Plans To Encourage Investment
description: The government announced measures to encourage direct corporate investment by South Korean as well as foreign interests. The tax deduction for investors in factories was raised to 15 percent from 10 percent after the finance minister, Kim Jin Pyo, expressed concern about the slumping growth rate and falling direct investment. The government also said foreigners working for companies in South Korea would have the choice between a flat 18 percent tax and a graduated tax tied to their income. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Car Plows Through Crowd in Santa Monica, Killing 8
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 16 - An elderly motorist plowed through a crowded farmer's market in downtown Santa Monica at an estimated 60 miles an hour this afternoon, killing eight people and injuring dozens more, witnesses and the police said.

title: An Evening in the Park With a Playboy Prince
description: Where is that old muse of fire when you need her? That goddess of inspiration, beseechingly evoked in the prologue of ''Henry V,'' appears to be on vacation this summer. Maybe she's been co-opted as a houseguest by some movie producer in the Hamptons. In any case she is definitely keeping her distance from the flashy, flabby production of Shakespeare's gung-ho military history play that opened last night at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about the book ''Moses: A Memoir,'' by Joel Cohen, misspelled the name of the law firm in which the author is a partner. It is Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, not Levan.

title: Gephardt Lagging Behind In Democrats' Fund-Raising
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, a Washington power whom leaders in both parties had viewed as a formidable challenger to President Bush, is struggling to raise campaign money this year, lagging behind some less-established Democratic competitors, according to official reports filed today.
