description: Diamonds Are A Bad Boy's Best Friend

title: Business Tax Shelters a Drain on States' Finances, Study Says
description: Tax sheltering has cost states more than a third of their revenue from taxes on corporate profits, a new study showed yesterday, adding to the severe strain on state finances across the country.

title: Bond Rally Over, but Fed Still Wants Rates to Remain Low
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, has helped convince investors that the bond market rally is over.

title: Pentagon Sees Possible Delay In Return of the Third Division
description: Military officials said today that they were committed to bringing home the Third Infantry Division's troops, who led the capture of Baghdad, by autumn, but that their return might slip beyond the September date given to the Senate last week by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld.

title: Dr. O. Currier McEwen, 101, Former N.Y.U. Dean of Medicine
description: Dr. O. Currier McEwen, a former dean of the New York University School of Medicine who was instrumental in the creation of the N.Y.U. Medical Center, died on June 23 in Harpswell, Me. He was 101 and lived in Harpswell.

title: More Fun Than a Barrelful of Monkeys
description: A shiny sliver of a pickle boutique, Pickles, Olives, etc., has opened at 1647 First Avenue (86th Street). More than 20 kinds of pickled cucumbers and other vegetables and two dozen olives -- including green ones stuffed with anchovies, garlic, sun-dried tomatoes or celery -- are ready to be fished from their barrels. The owners, who include Yonca Sozer and her father-in-law, Tevfik Karabenli, are Turkish, and so is the manager, Emre Sen, at right, offering a sample to a customer. The shop sells some Turkish olives, like black Gemliks cured in their own oil, and a few other Turkish savories like stuffed vine leaves and peppers. Almost everything is $6 to $15 a quart.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We just call him 'Bruce' around the house. I've got more pictures of Bruce than I have of my family.''

title: Hopes Brighten as Concern Persists in Japan
description: After a dozen years of start-and-stop recoveries, economists in Japan might be forgiven for urging caution when looking at the latest growth figures. The revival of Japan's stock market in the last three months has begged the question, though, with many investors asking whether optimism, not wariness, is in order.

title: Pataki Raises $2 Million Just in Case Of Bid in '06
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has raised more than $2 million in campaign funds so far this year, even though he has not indicated whether he will seek a fourth term in 2006.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Some Concealed Weapons Allowed
description: The State Supreme Court ruled 6 to 1 that homeowners and store owners have the right to carry concealed weapons on their property. The ruling overturned the conviction of a grocery store owner who had a loaded gun in his pocket. The court based its ruling on a five-year-old amendment to the state's Constitution that guarantees the right to bear arms, but stopped short of undoing the state's longstanding ban on concealed weapons. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Getting to Know Henry VIII's Women
description: Henry the Eighth

title: The Bowls of Summer, for Picnics in the Pool or Out
description: Jelli Bowls, 12-inch bowls in four vibrant colors, are molded from plastic cutting-board material, making them virtually indestructible and perfect for holding summer salads, chips or fruit, indoors or out. They are light enough to take on a picnic, will even float in a pool and can go in the dishwasher. They come in red, lime, cobalt and orange, and are $11 each. Flower-shape salad servers are $7.50. All at the Art of Cooking, 555 Hudson Street (Perry Street).

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Virage Logic Shares Soar
description: Shares of the Virage Logic Corporation, a maker of memory products for semiconductors, rose as much as 48 percent yesterday after an analyst said the company might raise its earnings forecast. Shares of Virage rose $2.25, or 26.7 percent, to $10.69. Shares in the company, based in Fremont, Calif., had fallen 16 percent this year. Richard Faust, an analyst at Adams, Harkness & Hill, upgraded Virage to ''strong buy'' from ''market perform.'' He said in a note to clients that the company would probably raise its estimates for future periods after reporting third-quarter results on July 24. Mr. Faust estimated Virage would have a loss of 6 cents in the third quarter, which ended in June. Virage has ''turned the corner'' because it may have completed some major licensing agreements that had been delayed, Mr. Faust said in the note.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Delay Of E.P.A. Regulations
description: A series of orders issued on Friday by the Environmental Protection Agency effectively put off regulation of certain chemicals and other substances that can appear in drinking water, including perchlorate, a component of rocket fuel, and M.T.B.E., a gasoline additive. Environmental groups protested the action, saying it would delay any new regulation for five to eight years, a time frame that agency officials dispute. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Dessert Wines Before and During Dinner
description: AMERICANS don't cotton to elegant dry wines, we are told, because we are raised on Coca-Cola and sugar-coated everything else. In fact, we have taken enthusiastically to dry wines -- so much so that, except for Sauternes and port, we tend to look down on sweet wines as gauche, embarrassing, the excesses of misspent youth. But the truth is, in a guilty sort of way, we still love our sweet wines. Only now we call them dessert wines.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Volkswagen To Increase Output
description: Volkswagen A.G., which sells two out of every five cars in China, said yesterday that it planned to invest 6 billion euros ($6.8 billion) in the country over the next five years to double production capacity in China, the world's fastest growing auto market. The company aims to expand annual production capacity to 1.6 million units from 800,000. Volkswagen, based in Wolfsburg, Germany, plans to add one factory in Changchun with its partner, First Automotive Works, and another with its local partner in Shanghai.

title: About New York; Blessed Are The Pack Rats
description: AMONG the unwritten bylaws of the Our Lady of Mount Carmel Society on Staten Island is this: Throw nothing away, for there is beauty in these pebbles, in those shells, in this here piece of glass. Open your eyes, pal, and see the glory in the everyday.

title: Fed Chief Gives Bright Outlook; Cuts an Option
description: The Federal Reserve is prepared to hold interest rates low ''for as long as needed'' to stimulate further growth, the chairman, Alan Greenspan, said today, even as he presented an unexpectedly upbeat economic forecast to a House committee.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Death Toll Rises In Plant Shooting
description: A victim of a July 8 shooting at a factory in Meridian, DeLois Bailey, 53, died of her wounds, bringing to six the number killed by Doug Williams, an employee who also wounded eight others before fatally shooting himself. Mr. Williams had frequently made violent threats against blacks, co-workers said. Five of those killed were black, including Ms. Bailey. The Lockheed Martin plant has reopened a week after the shooting. David M. Halbfinger (NYT)

title: Dispute on Iraq Weapons Clouds Blair's Trip to U.S.
description: LONDON, July 16  Prime Minister Tony Blair travels to Washington on Thursday on a mission to underline Britain's close and dependable relationship with the United States without reinforcing his domestic critics' portrayal of him as an unquestioning follower of President Bush.

title: Europe Weighs Helping Out in Iraq, but Under Its Own Terms
description: Despite bruising disagreements with the United States over the war in Iraq, Europe is tentatively offering to help pay for reconstruction, provided that the money is administered by an international agency like the World Bank or the United Nations, a top European Union official said today.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: GUATEMALA: FUROR OVER EX-DICTATOR Rights groups, including Amnesty International, condemned the decision by the Constitutional Court to let a former dictator run for president in November. The court ruled Monday that the former dictator, Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, could be a candidate despite a constitutional ban on ex-dictators running for president. General Rios Montt had argued that the article in the 1985 Constitution did not apply because it was included after his 1982-83 presidency. Rights groups fear that a Rios Montt presidency would dash hopes of putting him and other military leaders on trial for massacres in the early 1980's. (Reuters)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOOM, , SYLVIA
description: BLOOM--Sylvia. We mourn the passing of the Honorable Sylvia Bloom, former CUNY trustee (1981 to 1994) and member of the CUNY Construction Fund. Her enduring dedication to and love for the City University's student body will be long remembered. Our deepest sympathies are extended to her beloved family. Benno C. Schmidt, Jr., Chairman Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor >>AD#

title: Council Speaker Is Accused Of Stalling Lead Paint Bill
description: With three potential mayoral candidates standing by, a city councilwoman implied yesterday that Council Speaker Gifford Miller was condoning environmental racism by failing to move quickly on a proposed law to reduce childhood lead paint poisoning.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has confirmed the deaths of the following Americans while supporting military efforts in the Iraq theater of operations:

title: Tex Schramm Is Dead at 83; Builder of 'America's Team'
description: Tex Schramm, an innovative force in pro football who directed the rise of the Dallas Cowboys and was a major figure in bringing about the merger between the rival American and National Football Leagues, died yesterday at his home in Dallas. He was 83.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Judges Reject Sect's Suit
description: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, has unanimously rejected a lawsuit by families of Branch Davidian members who died in a fire during a standoff with federal law enforcement officials near Waco in 1993. The suit for damages against the government was rejected in 2000 by Judge Walter S. Smith Jr. of Federal District Court in Waco. In their appeal, the families said that Judge Smith, who had presided over the criminal trial of Branch Davidians in the deaths of four federal agents, should have recused himself. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: In This Corner, the Nonbelievers
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Party Crasher Avoids Charges
description: The intruder dressed like Osama bin Laden who crashed Prince William's 21st birthday party at Windsor Castle last month will face no charges, Scotland Yard said. Aaron Barschak, left, a self-styled ''comedy terrorist,'' managed to elude officers of the Royal Protection Service and jump onto a stage, where he kissed the prince on both cheeks before being arrested. The commander of palace security has been removed, and nine members of his detail have been told they are under investigation. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Smithfield Makes $364 Million Bid for a Rival Pork Processor
description: Smithfield Foods, the nation's biggest pork producer and processor, said today that it had offered to buy Farmland Foods, another big pork processor, for $363.5 million in cash.

title: Moyer Gets Job Done At His Own Speed
description: ''What's it like to bat against Jamie Moyer?'' Dmitri Young, the slugging outfielder for the Detroit Tigers, said Monday. ''Oh, man! You never think the pitch is going to reach the plate, and by the time it does, you've already swung. You can drive a car faster than he throws -- in third gear.''

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Motorola Posts 2nd-Quarter Net Income
description: Motorola Inc., the mobile-telephone maker, yesterday reported second-quarter net income of $119 million. Sales fell 10 percent as demand slumped in Asia, and the company said sales in the current quarter might also drop. Net income in the quarter was 5 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $2.32 billion, or $1.02 a share, in the year-earlier period, when the company wrote down the value of some assets, Motorola said in a statement. Sales fell to $6.16 billion. The company exceeded the lowered earnings-per-share forecasts it gave last month of 2 cents a share. It reported a profit before some gains of 1 cent a share, above a break-even forecast. Motorola made no forecast for 2003 results. In April, the company forecast sales of as much as $28 billion and net income in a range of 35 cents to 40 cents. In 2002, Motorola had a net loss of $1.09 a share on sales of $26.7 billion. Motorola shares rose 28 cents, or 3 percent, to $9.78. They have risen 29 percent this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WANG, , C.C.
description: WANG--C.C. The Trustees and staff of China Institute mourn the loss of Trustee Emeritus, longtime friend and benefactor C.C. Wang. C.C. Wang was curator of China Institute's 1970 exhibition, Album Leaves from the Sung and Yuan Dynasties, and his works graced the walls of our Gallery in 1989 with the exhibition, The Paintings of C.C. Wang. He will be greatly missed. We extend our condolences to the entire family. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Landlord Faces Tax Charges
description: A Manhattan landlord who has been cited for numerous building-code violations and was recently accused of filing false income tax statements turned himself in yesterday to federal authorities. The landlord, Pablo Llorente, had said he earned slightly more than $2.1 million in rent between 1993 and 1996 for four Manhattan buildings. Yesterday, Mr. Llorente pleaded not guilty to filing false statements and was released on $10,000 bond. In 2001, tenants reported becoming ill after carbon monoxide flooded 159 West 80th Street, one of Mr. Llorente's buildings. Twenty-one people were hospitalized. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Administration to Exempt Forest From Road Act
description: The Bush administration set out a proposal yesterday to exempt the Tongass National Forest in Alaska from the Roadless Area Conservation Rule, potentially helping to clear the way for 50 pending land sales in the forest.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: HAUPPAUGE: 8 ACCUSED OF RUNNING GAMBLING RING Eight people described by the authorities as members of the Bonanno crime family have been arrested in a raid that shut down a gambling ring that took in $20 million a year in bets on football and other sports, the Suffolk County district attorney, Thomas J. Spota, announced yesterday. Investigators said that the ring had been operating for up to two decades, taking bets in the Bronx and Manhattan. The suspects, arrested in a Monday raid, are Patrick Nestico of Manhattan; Anthony Frascone of East Meadow; Michael Casale, John Spirito Jr., Nicholas Terrigno and Louis J. Aresu, all of the Bronx, and Vincent Falci and Patrick Marone, both of West Babylon. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GLAZER, , SIMON
description: GLAZER--Simon. Tim Dear, It's been a very long eighteen years without you. Love, Val >>AD#

title: INSIDE
description: C.I.A. Chief to Face Panel

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: BRITAIN: PARTY CRASHER AVOIDS CHARGES The intruder dressed like Osama bin Laden who crashed Prince William's 21st birthday party at Windsor Castle last month will face no charges, Scotland Yard said. Aaron Barschak, left, a self-styled "comedy terrorist," managed to elude officers of the Royal Protection Service and jump onto a stage, where he kissed the prince on both cheeks before being arrested. The commander of palace security has been removed, and nine members of his detail have been told they are under investigation. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Data Sought From Lehman
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. disclosed in a quarterly regulatory filing that it has received requests from the New York Stock Exchange, acting in coordination with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the National Association of Securities Dealers, for information, documents and testimony relating to spinning in initial public offerings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAGARIN, , GERTRUDE ESTHER
description: SAGARIN--Gertrude Esther, 88, died June 28, 2003. Loving mother of Fred, grandmother of Brad, Johanna and Eric, great-grandmother of Maya. Wonderful, loving and loyal friend to so many people. A memorial service will be held Aug. 2, at 10 A.M. at Memorial House, 71 Bedford Road, Katonah, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to either UNICEF or Deborah Heart and Lung Center, Browns Mills, NJ, would be appreciated. >>AD#

title: Merrill Lynch's Earnings Surge After Cost-Cutting
description: Merrill Lynch reported a 61 percent gain in its second-quarter earnings yesterday, driven by a powerful combination of robust bond trading profits and vigilant cost-cutting.

title: Music channels hit wry notes in their latest campaigns.
description: THE all-music spinoff of MTV this week began its first ad campaign to appear outside the family of MTV channels. Trying to take advantage of its growing availability, the channel, MTV2, which is now in almost 50 million homes, is seeking viewers, buzz and an identity distinct from its more popular older sibling.

title: Bit by Bit, Putting It Together
description: Starting in 1986 with a finance company cast off by a computer maker, Sanford I. Weill built the world's largest financial services empire by repeatedly swallowing institutions bigger and more famous than his own and donning their identities. Here is a timeline of major events along the way, the growth of Mr. Weills empire measured by total assets and some notable heirs apparent who came and went before Mr. Weill finally named Charles Prince to succeed him as chief executive.

title: Leis and Sea Breezes, Up on the Roof
description: THE tropical swelter that finally settled over Manhattan had us longing for the swaying palms and shoelessness of the islands. Rainbows may appear in the shower of a fire hydrant, but summer in the city is no Waikiki. So we decided to conjure up the flavor of Hawaii by holding an urban luau, a rooftop dinner party where the drinks were rummy, the music was slack key and the Hawaiian dishes nearly outnumbered the guests.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent Pushes Back Goal Of Profitability
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said yesterday that fiscal third-quarter revenue declined to about $1.97 billion because of lower sales of wireless equipment and pushed back its target for a return to profitability. The company said it had a narrower third-quarter net loss of 6 cents to 8 cents a share in a statement on preliminary results. It said third-quarter sales fell 18 percent from $2.4 billion in the second quarter. Lucent had incurred losses of $29 billion in the last three years amid falling demand for phone-networking equipment. The chief executive officer, Patricia Russo, is trying to sell customers a wider range of products, like network services, to combat a fourth consecutive year of slumping sales. The company also said it would not reach profitability until the 2004 fiscal year. Previously, Lucent aimed at a return to profitability by this fiscal year, which ends in September. Shares of Lucent fell to $1.80 in after-hours trading, after the statement was distributed. The stock had fallen 6 cents, to $1.92, in regular trading.

title: Is Organic Food Provably Better?
description: IN the debate over whether organic food is better than conventionally raised food, advocates for organic produce say it contains fewer harmful chemicals and is better for the earth, and some claim that it is more nutritious.

title: Liberty Is Outplayed By Sharp 2-14 Team
description: In an open letter posted on the Washington Mystics' Web site Monday, team officials begged the indulgence of fans for the rest of the season.

title: Death Penalty: Worth the Risk?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Concentration on Seafood. After That, It's Diner's Choice.
description: SNACKBAR is the sort of restaurant that on paper I would be inclined to hate: loud and cynically fashionable, with distracted waiters and fake martinis by the pitcher. The restaurant even charges for bread.

title: Market Place; Intel Gives Credit For Strong Results To the Calendar, Not a Tech Surge
description: Intel, the world's largest maker of semiconductors, reported second-quarter earnings today that surpassed expectations from strong sales of its more profitable chips for personal computers and notebook computers. But company executives said the positive results did not necessarily indicate a general upswing in technology spending.

title: A Lesson Not Learned in School: Using What's at Hand
description: IN some families you can drop out of college and no one blinks an eye. Chris Schlesinger's family is made of sterner stuff. When the young Mr. Schlesinger, the nephew of the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., walked away from Northeastern in 1975 to spend the fall surfing in Virginia Beach, his grandmother took a dim view of the situation. ''You better get yourself a job,'' she told him.

title: In This Corner, the Nonbelievers
description: To the Editor:

title: Profit in 2nd Quarter Was Off 7.5% at the Times Company
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the second quarter fell 7.5 percent, weighed down in part by declines in travel-related advertising that resulted from the war in Iraq and the spread of SARS.

title: France Declines U.S. Call for Iraq Force
description: President Jacques Chirac said today that France would not send troops to Iraq to help the American peacekeeping effort there.

title: Corrections
description: The Wines of The Times column last Wednesday, about Loire Valley whites, reversed two locations on the banks of the Loire. Sancerre is on the west bank and Pouilly on the east. The column also misstated the location of Quincy and Reuilly. The towns are west of Sancerre, not east.

title: When Data Don't Mean That One Way Is Best
description: TOO often in education, there is a rush to compare programs, schools or even entire reform movements that simply are not comparable.

title: California Takes Aim At Dealer Bias In Car Loans
description: Gov. Gray Davis of California has signed into law a bill to curb outsize interest rates that car dealers sometimes charge minority customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUBOVICK, , PETER
description: DUBOVICK--Peter. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Peter Dubovick, associated with The Times from December 1, 1970 until retiring in December 1, 1982. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Study Of New Jersey Park Advances
description: A Congressional committee has approved $1 million for a study that would determine how to turn a degraded wetland area into an 8,400-acre environmental park. The money, approved yesterday by the House Appropriations Committee, would help finance a three-year study by the Army Corps of Engineers that would, among other things, look at ways to reverse nearly a century of dumping and dredging. Supporters of a Meadowlands Park, which would include parts of 14 surrounding towns, have already secured $8.4 million in state and federal money for land acquisition. Representative Steve Rothman, a New Jersey Democrat on the appropriations committee, said he expected the full House to approve the financing. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: In Wake of Protests, Two Officials Resign in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, July 16  Two weeks of street protests here produced a government crisis tonight as two top officials announced their resignations and the territory's chief executive said he would fly to Beijing on Saturday to consult China's rulers about what to do next.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Litter Levy
description: A tax on chewing gum, A.T.M. receipts and polystyrene fast-food packaging would help curb littering, said Environment Minister Martin Cullen, who will introduce legislation for the tax after Parliament's summer recess. The move is modeled on a 17-cent tax last year on disposable plastic shopping bags, which is credited with cutting their use by 90 percent. Irish people spit 500 tons of gum onto the street each year, Mr. Cullen said. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LOBENFELD, , RUTH
description: LOBENFELD--Ruth. It's 17 years babe and you're still the one and only. Your Love, Your Honey >>AD#

title: New Tarantino Film to Be Released in 2 Parts
description: Miramax Films will take the unusual and potentially risky move of releasing ''Kill Bill,'' the much-anticipated Quentin Tarantino martial arts action-adventure film, as two movies, the first to open in the fall. Miramax will in effect be taking a three-hour film with a 200-page script and turning it into a serial.

title: Philharmonic Is Rethinking Carnegie Plan
description: The New York Philharmonic is questioning whether to go ahead with its planned merger with Carnegie Hall, throwing into doubt a powerful classical music combination that was initially portrayed as definite.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Monday about the championship game for the Independent Women's Football League misstated the record of the New York Sharks. It is 8-1, not 7-1.

title: Before the Answer, the Question Must Be Correct
description: Looking for work? Try writing questions for standardized exams, a profession exploding with new jobs. But be aware of the frustrations.

title: U.S. Suffers Rash of Attacks on Anniversary of Hussein's Rule
description: In a rash of attacks on the anniversary of Saddam Hussein's seizure of power in 1979, a pro-American mayor and an American soldier were killed today and a surface-to-air missile was fired at an American military aircraft, although it was not hit, the military said.

title: After His Loss in Rematch, Forrest Is Sounding Beaten
description: After the fight on Saturday night, Vernon Forrest fled the ring, raced to his hotel suite, then slammed the door shut. He could not speak to family, friends or trainers. Nobody. He simply sat on the edge of the bed in silence, buried his face in his large, soft hands and cried.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TOOMB, , MARY C., ''MAE''
description: TOOMB--Mary C., ''Mae'', of Centerville, OH, passed away Sunday, July 13, 2003, at Heartland of Centerville. She is survived by her children, Kevin Toomb of Charlotte, NC, Kathleen Oakes (Ray) of Kettering, OH, Martin Toomb (Peggy) of Rockaway, NJ, Robert Toomb (Laura) of Mason, OH, a sister, Elizabeth Tinnelly of Centerville. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated 11AM Thursday, July 17, 2003, at St. Cecilia Church, 70 Church St, Rockaway, NJ. Interment Ascension Cemetery, Monsey, NY. Friends may call 7-9PM Wednesday at the WhithamKanapaux Funeral Home, 20 Keller Ave, Rockaway, NJ. >>AD#

title: Perfect Complement to a Grand Design
description: Daniel Libeskind has already secured what has been called ''the commission of the century.'' He has the plans, the contracts to carry them out and the backing of important patrons, from Gov. George E. Pataki on down.

title: Bush Pension Proposals Get a Cold Reception From Congress
description: Bush administration officials offered detailed plans yesterday for how America's pension system might be strengthened but received a cold reception from members of Congress, who said they feared the measures would hurt the companies that offer the pensions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRONIN, , JAMES P.
description: CRONIN--James P. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of James P. Cronin, associated with The Times from January 27, 1977 until retiring in March 31, 2002. >>AD#

title: No Plumbing. No People. But No Light?; Though Beacon Is Dark, Keeper Savors the Life
description: To ferryboat passengers disembarking onto this forested 53-acre hump of earth two miles off the Connecticut coast, David Graaf is the sun-seared, scruffy-faced dock hand in black Chuck Taylor high-tops waving hello.

title: Cocktails on the Patio and e-Snacks at Hand
description: It's prime time for summer entertaining, and terraces and patios beckon. This year, there are new sources for tidbits that demand little work and a minimum of planning.

title: Jets Sign McGlockton, Bulking Up the Defense
description: The Jets signed the veteran defensive tackle Chester McGlockton to a one-year contract yesterday, ensuring that, no matter what else happens off the field, the team will have enough starting-caliber tackles when the season begins.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: New Search For Missing G.I.'s
description: American and North Korean officials have agreed to join in a new search for the remains of more than 8,000 United States servicemen who have been missing since the 1950-53 Korean War, the Pentagon said. At a meeting in Bangkok, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Jerry D. Jennings made plans with North Korean officials for an operation later this year north of the capital, Pyongyang, and in the northeast near the Chosin Reservoir. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Mets and Yanks Close To a Deal for Benitez
description: The Mets and the Yankees were closing in on a startling deal last night that would send closer Armando Benitez, famous for his big-moment meltdowns, to the Yankees for a package of prospects, an executive with one of the teams said.

title: Officials Reach An Agreement On Rebuilding Downtown Site
description: The architect with the winning design for the World Trade Center site and the developer who will rebuild the office space there agreed early this morning to collaborate on the design and construction of the 1,776-foot tower that will anchor the redeveloped site both on the ground and in the Lower Manhattan skyline.

title: Searching for Fun and Grace To Strains of Familiar Music
description: ''Celebrating Summer, Celebrating Dance!'' was the appropriate title Earl Mosley's Diversity of Dance Inc. gave to a genial program on Friday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: In This Corner, the Nonbelievers
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about ice cream in New York City misstated part of the name of a franchise vendor and misidentified its home state. The company is Cold Stone Creamery, not Coldstone -- of Arizona, not Colorado.

title: Mortgage Loans Lift Profit at Wells Fargo
description: Wells Fargo & Company said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose more than 7 percent as the lowest mortgage rates on record extended a refinancing boom that began in April 2002.

title: Where Are Democrats?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Peace Talks Planned
description: The government of President lvaro Uribe of Colombia and a right-wing paramilitary group that has killed thousands in the last decade agreed to embark on formal peace talks that could lead to the demobilization of more than 10,000 fighters, potentially eliminating a major combatant from Colombia's 39-year-old conflict. The paramilitary group, the United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia, has besieged the country in its war against left-wing rebels and is heavily involved in the trafficking of cocaine. Under an agreement announced by Mr. Uribe's office, the paramilitaries have agreed to negotiations that call for a gradual demobilization that will begin before the end of this year and be completed by Dec. 31, 2005. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: U.S. Deports Charity Leader In Visa Dispute
description: The founder of a Muslim charity accused of funneling money to Al Qaeda has been deported, Justice Department officials said today. His lawyer said he was returned to Lebanon late last night.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on June 18 about Dr. Robert Alan Good, a founder of modern immunology, misstated the hometown of a surviving daughter, Mary E. Good. It is Smithfield, Me., not Smithville.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about fees paid to trustees of private foundations misstated the asset value of the Duke Endowment, whose trustees divide 3 percent of its investment income. It is $2.5 billion, not $6 billion.

title: Fake Goods Support Terrorism, Interpol Official Is to Testify
description: Groups like Al Qaeda and Hezbollah have turned to trafficking in counterfeit consumer goods, like fake Nike shoes, Sony stereo equipment and Calvin Klein jeans, says the top official at Interpol, who is scheduled to testify about the issue on Wednesday at a Congressional hearing.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PARK PLACE ENTERTAINMENT CORP., Las Vegas, the world's largest casino operator, said it would change its name, effective in January, to Caesars Entertainment Inc. to attract more gamblers and investors with its most recognized brand, Caesars Palace casino.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about efforts in Willits, Calif., and by the nearby Ridgewood Ranch to promote interest in the racehorse Seabiscuit, who retired there, misspelled the surname of a man who recalled having heard about the horse's intelligence from his father-in-law, the jockey's doctor. He is George C. Akins, not Atkins.

title: Governor Offers Legislation To Soften Harsh Drug Laws
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today released the details of his latest plan to soften New York's mandatory sentences for drug crimes, putting forward a bill he urged the State Legislature to pass.

title: Editorial Observer; Interracialism Among the Jeffersons Went Well Beyond the Bedroom
description: Walk the grounds of Thomas Jefferson's Monticello around dawn (before the tourists come) and you enter a 19th-century landscape where you half expect to meet The Founder himself, out on one of those brisk constitutionals for which he was known. These paths and gardens were alive with Jefferson descendants last weekend, for a new version of a family reunion. There were white Jeffersons, descended from Thomas and his wife, Martha. Alongside them -- and in some cases looking just like them -- were white, brown and black Jeffersons, descended from the children that the nation's third president is now presumed to have fathered with his slave mistress, Sally Hemings.

title: HCA LOWERS EARNINGS FORECAST AS ADMISSIONS SLOW
description: HCA Inc., the largest American hospital chain, said its second-quarter profit was hurt by slow admissions and its underestimation of the amount of bills it might not be able to collect. The company said it expected to report net income of 46 cents to 48 cents a share for the quarter, compared with 66 cents a year earlier. Profit excluding some costs will be 74 cents to 76 cents, HCA said, less than the average estimate of 77 cents from analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose about 12 percent to $5.5 billion, HCA said, higher than the $5.47 billion estimate from Thomson First Call. HCA is based in Nashville.

title: In This Corner, the Nonbelievers
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: VOLKSWAGEN TO INCREASE OUTPUT Volkswagen A.G., which sells two out of every five cars in China, said yesterday that it planned to invest 6 billion euros ($6.8 billion) in the country over the next five years to double production capacity in China, the world's fastest growing auto market. The company aims to expand annual production capacity to 1.6 million units from 800,000. Volkswagen, based in Wolfsburg, Germany, plans to add one factory in Changchun with its partner, First Automotive Works, and another with its local partner in Shanghai. (Bloomberg News)

title: Nets Place Priority on Players, Not Coach
description: Coach Byron Scott was in his office at the Nets' practice center late yesterday afternoon, not dwelling on his job status but concentrating only on his job.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Antiterror Bill Rejected
description: A crucial committee of Parliament rejected a stringent antiterrorism bill that had been praised by American diplomats but that critics said trampled individual rights. ''The Suppression of Terrorism Bill 2003 threatens to tear apart the very fabric of one nation and could offer fertile ground for interreligious animosity and suspicion,'' the Administration of Justice and Legal Affairs Committee said in a statement. The bill would have allowed officers to question terrorism suspects without their lawyers present. Kenyan Muslims have led the opposition to the bill. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: West Nile Cases Hold Steady
description: Four people in the United States have contracted West Nile virus infections this year, the same number reported at this time last year, but the virus itself is spreading faster this year, federal health officials reported. In 2002, there were 4,156 cases of West Nile fever and 284 deaths. This year, three cases have been diagnosed in Texas and one in South Carolina. Tests in birds, animals and mosquitoes have found the virus in 32 states, compared with 20 a year ago. Denise Grady (NYT)

title: BURLINGTON SHAREHOLDER ASKS COURT TO ALLOW INQUIRY
description: A shareholder has asked the court overseeing the bankruptcy case of the fabric maker Burlington Industries to allow an investigation into the company and its chief executive, George Henderson. Walker Rucker, who was turned back in his effort to establish an official committee of stockholders in the bankruptcy case, asked the United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., to direct Burlington to produce documents and make people, including Mr. Henderson, available for examination. A hearing on the matter is scheduled for July 31. Burlington plans to auction its assets July 28 and has said it does not expect any recovery for shareholders.

title: In This Corner, the Nonbelievers (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A.L. Snatches a Victory, and the Home-Field Advantage
description: Hank Blalock plays for the Texas Rangers, one of the worst teams in the American League and a team that has no chance of playing in the World Series. But Blalock helped decide where a potential Game 7 would be played this season when he hammered a pinch-hit two-run homer off Eric Gagne to catapult the American League to an exciting 7-6 victory over the National League at U.S. Cellular Field.

title: In This Corner, the Nonbelievers
description: To the Editor:

title: Top U.S. General in Iraq Sees 'Classical Guerrilla-Type' War
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  A top United States general said today that American troops in Iraq were now facing a "classical guerrilla-type campaign"  the sort of phrase Bush administration officials have so far avoided  and he added that American troops should be prepared for duty tours of perhaps a year.

title: New York Is Holding World Championships
description: It is a scene straight out of a Norman Rockwell painting: 5-year-old Vic Wunderle running around his backyard in rural Illinois with a bow made from a branch of a willow tree and an arrow with a rag for a tip.

title: St. Louis Archbishop to Take Over Philadelphia Archdiocese
description: Archbishop Justin F. Rigali of St. Louis a theological conservative who spent three decades at the Vatican, was appointed yesterday by Pope John Paul II to succeed Cardinal Anthony J. Bevilacqua of Philadelphia, who is retiring at the age of 80.

title: The Country That a President Never Gets to See
description: President Bush has come and gone, but in the opinion of many Nigerians he was never really here.

title: Israelis Rescue Cabdriver After Kidnapping
description: Israeli security forces rescued an Israeli cabdriver near the West Bank city of Ramallah five days after he was kidnapped in a case that strained the fragile Middle East peace efforts, the military announced early today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Union: Support For Budget Limits
description: European Union finance ministers yesterday defended a set of rules intended to ensure sound bookkeeping by governments in the euro zone, after President Jacques Chirac of France called for them to be temporarily eased. The prevailing view among European finance ministers is that the Stability and Growth Pact signed before use of the euro began in 1999 is flexible enough to manage the current economic downturn, Gerrit Zalm, the Dutch finance minister, said after yesterday's meeting. The pact calls on governments to keep their budget deficits below 3 percent of gross domestic product. The French finance minister, Francis Mer, above, however, announced that France would exceed that limit again next year, the third consecutive year. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: ROCHE BARRED FROM SELLING SOME INSULIN PUMPS IN U.S.
description: Roche Holding has been prohibited from selling insulin pumps made by a company it recently acquired, Disetronic Holding, in the United States until manufacturing violations are resolved. The Food and Drug Administration discovered the quality flaws while inspecting Disetronic's plant in Burgdorf, Switzerland, according to a June 11 letter to Roche posted on the F.D.A. Web site yesterday. Roche has not been able to sell the products in the United States since early June, said a Roche spokesman, Joel Reuter. The pumps had sales in the United States of $16 million in 2002.

title: Frederic Bradlee -- Actor and Writer, 84
description: Frederic Bradlee, a New York actor and writer, died on Saturday at his home on the Upper East Side. He was 84.

title: Rape (and Silence About It) Haunts Baghdad

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORELL, , PIERRE
description: MORELL -- Pierre, 61, a professor of biochemistry and a research scientist at the Neuroscience Center of the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill, died July 15, 2003. He is survived by the adoring members of his loving family, including his wife, Bonnie Jean of Chapel Hill; two children, David Henry Morell and Sharon Maria Harbaugh; a grandchild, Katherine Harbaugh; and by his parents, Anatol and Helena Morell of Stony Brook, NY. Within the specialized field of molecular neurobiology, Dr. Morell's research interests centered upon metabolism and functions of myelin. He and his collaborators have published more than 120 papers in scientific journals as well as reviews, book chapters and textbooks. In addition to his principal duties as a teacher and research scientist in the medical school, Dr. Morell was a member of the University community and shared his knowledge and love of scuba diving with hundreds of undergraduate students. Dr. Morell was born on December 10, 1941, in Puerto Plata, the Dominican Republic, where his parents had settled briefly after fleeing from Poland at the outbreak of World War II. He graduated from Columbia College in 1963 and earned a doctorate in biochemistry in 1968 from the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx, NY. Dr. Morell joined the Biochemistry Department faculty at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill in 1973, where he continued to teach and conduct path-breaking research in the neurosciences for more than a quartercentury. Funeral arrangements are incomplete. >>AD#

description: Kurt Sanger is only a captain and so he will leave to higher-ups the question of whether Romania would make a good ally as the United States sets about a historic reordering of its military, relying less on its old friends in Western Europe and more on new ones in the east. He does, however, have some thoughts about Romania as a place where American soldiers like him may find a new home, perhaps soon.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank's Profit Surges
description: Woori Bank, South Korea's second-largest bank, reported a net income of 565.2 billion won ($480 million) for the first half of this year, more than twice the 208.6 billion won that it posted for the same period last year. Woori Bank, is the dominant unit of Woori Finance Holdings, which is 87 percent government-owned. The bank attributed its results in part to the sale early last year of its credit-card unit to Woori Finance. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS AGREES TO BUY ROSENBLUTH
description: The American Express Company, the biggest corporate travel agency, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Rosenbluth International, a private travel-management company, to add business customers and expand its line of services. Financial terms were not disclosed. The purchase of Rosenbluth, which is based in Philadelphia, will not affect the per-share earnings of American Express in 2003 and will add to profit in 2004 and 2005, the company said. American Express managed $15.5 billion in corporate travel services in 2002, while Rosenbluth managed more than $3 billion.

title: Mischievous Musical Jokes From a Cocktail Raconteur
description: Ever dapper in a dark suit and bow tie and squinting like a mischievous owl from behind dark-rimmed spectacles, the singer and pianist John Wallowitch comes as close as anyone nowadays to personifying the spirit of vintage Tin Pan Alley but with a modern uptown gloss. Mr. Wallowitch has written more than 2,000 songs on almost every newsy topic and is a storehouse of musical esoterica.

title: C.I.A. Chief to Face Panel On Dubious Iraq Arms Data
description: George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, is expected to testify before a Senate panel on Wednesday about the reliability of intelligence indicating Iraq tried to obtain uranium, as administration officials raised new concerns about information his agency gave the White House on the matter last fall.

description: For 65 years, this city, once dependent on shipping and on seafood provided by the Chesapeake Bay, has spun an identity from the first of the 20th-century miracle fibers, nylon.

title: Star Effort Just to Make Game in Time
description: When Major League Baseball invited Roger Clemens to be a part of the All-Star Game, he gathered the members of his family at his lake house in Texas on Sunday night and asked them their opinion. If Clemens attended the game, it would interrupt a rare family summer vacation. But the only person who was against his going was Kody, Clemens's 7-year-old son.

title: Welcome to (Company Name Here) High(TM)
description: ''It's easy, like selling candy to children.'' In the last month, that bromide has taken on a whole new meaning as public school officials have acted to make selling junk food to students a whole lot harder. On July 1, Kraft Foods announced that it would withdraw its advertisements for processed foods from the in-school television station Channel One. A week before, New York City's Education Department banned soda and candy from the vending machines of its public schools. The department's action came on the heels of similar measures by school districts in San Francisco and Los Angeles.

description: The emergency inspection performed on a New Jersey Transit train before it lost a wheel and derailed here Monday morning was re-enacted today as part of the accident investigation, officials said.

description: Afederal judge has refused to grant Martha Stewart's request to have the federal sentencing guidelines declared unconstitutional. The guidelines will influence the length of any prison sentence Ms. Stewart receives today.

description: The United States, France and Britain have united behind a French draft resolution that would impose an arms embargo in eastern Congo, increase the ceiling on United Nations peacekeepers in the country and strengthen their military mandate, diplomats from two of the countries involved said today.

description: The White House today projected a $455 billion budget deficit in the current fiscal year, by far the government's largest deficit ever and $150 billion higher than what the administration predicted just five months ago.

The latest technology allows for maximum rates of 54 megabits a second; it is not limited to 11 megabits a second.

description: In his first major initiative, the new chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the agency would make it easier for a company's shareholders to elect a limited number of independent directors.

title: Lottery Numbers
Lots of Lime, Chilies, Too
description: IN summer the flavors of the Yucatn -- lime, chili, tomato, cilantro -- are just as much at home in Maine as they are in Mrida. I was served this dish at a restaurant in a fishing village called Telchac Puerto, where the road ends at a lighthouse, a pier and the Gulf of Mexico. The tables, chairs, utensils, tablecloths and plates were made of plastic, but the floor was just sand. There was a roof for shade, and a mariachi played.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: New Sars Test
description: The Swiss drug maker Roche Holding A.G. announced yesterday that it had developed a test that could diagnose even a trace of SARS in roughly an hour. The test, which has not been reviewed by an independent health agency, is available for research use only. Dick Thompson, a spokesman for the World Health Organization, said a fast, accurate test was greatly needed to help doctors identify who should be quarantined in a future epidemic. He said that the Roche test could prove valuable, but that it needed to be field tested first. He noted that tests based on the P.C.R. technique of identifying DNA, as the Roche test is, often yielded false negatives. The P.C.R. technique is a method of amplifying minute genetic material. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Wednesday with an article about Wine Spectator honors for restaurants misidentified an award prominently displayed by the Tribeca Grill. It was the magazine's Grand Award, the highest, not its Award of Excellence.

title: 'Producers': To Ape or Ignore You-Know-Who?
description: In ''Betrayed,'' the 11 o'clock number in ''The Producers,'' that rapscallion showman Max Bialystock sits in a jail cell. Abandoned by his partner, the accountant and erstwhile shrinking violet Leo Bloom, an embittered Max recapitulates the entire play. In fast-forward mode, he caricatures the voices and the gestures of the characters and recounts most of the plot. It's a star turn for the actor playing Max, and the Broadway original, Nathan Lane, turned it into a dazzling tour de force, oddly poignant and exhaustingly funny.

title: Once Upon a Time in Africa, Updated; Folklore's Mythic Menagerie Finds a Wider Audience in the Americas
description: Long before children heard Mother Goose rhymes or ''Jack and the Beanstalk,'' stories were told in Africa about wise lions, wily snakes and how the world began. Storytellers passed along these tales orally, embodying ideas about ethics, human nature and the cultures from which they came. Unlike collections of European fairy tales, myths and legends, which are familiar worldwide, compilations of African folk tales have only recently received mainstream attention outside Africa.

title: Tenth of H.I.V. Cases in a Study In Europe Are Resistant to Drugs
description: The biggest study, so far, of resistance to AIDS drugs, to be released today at an international AIDS conference in Paris, finds that about 10 percent of all newly infected patients in Europe are infected with drug-resistant strains.

description: About the only place the environmental community has any real hope of victory in its continuing war with the Bush administration is in the courts. And so it proved last week when Federal District Judge Gladys Kessler ordered the Army Corps of Engineers to reduce water levels in the Missouri River to help save three endangered species: two bird species and one fish species, the pallid sturgeon.

description: The Dutch health care and technology giant Royal Philips Electronics reported today that thanks to a one-time gain, it eked out a profit of 42 million euros ($46.9 million) in the second quarter, beating market expectations. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Union: U.S. Help Sought On Spam
description: Efforts to form an international alliance to combat unsolicited e-mail, or spam, will be restricted if the United States does not ban spam outright, European Commission officials said yesterday. A European Union-wide law forbidding e-mail promotions unless the recipient has given the marketer prior consent takes effect in the fall. The United States, the source for an estimated 33 percent of all spam in the world, is in the process of drafting antispam rules, too. Instead of insisting on prior consent from recipients, the American law is likely to permit spamming unless individuals ask to be removed from the spammers mailing lists. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: A Sculptor Masters the Art Of Beautiful Vegetables
description: IT is the sort of place that sneaks up on you: past the bodega, beyond some abandoned storefronts and smack between a pawnshop and the B-Side Bar. The only clue that you are getting close is that the lazy, humid air grows heavy with the aroma of newly uprooted garlic, onions and chives.

title: Rate Hedging Lowers Fannie Mae Earnings
description: Fannie Mae, the largest source of mortgage financing in the nation, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings fell 25 percent as the value of financial contracts used to hedge against interest rate swings declined by $1.88 billion. The shares fell on investor concern that earnings growth may lag estimates.

title: Winning The Real War
description: Last Sunday was the most important day in Iraq since the start of the war, and maybe the most important day in its modern history. It was the first day that one could speak about the ''liberation'' of Iraq. It was the day that a multireligious, multiethnic Governing Council of Iraqi men and women began to assume some power and responsibility for their own country -- the most representative leadership Iraq has ever had.

title: Nuclear Doubts in the House
description: Thanks to an unexpected vote by a House appropriations subcommittee, the Bush administration's ill-considered plan to study the development of a new generation of nuclear weapons has been at least temporarily stalled. These warheads, less powerful than those built during the cold war, would be designed to penetrate hardened underground command centers or weapons sites or for possible use in regional conflicts. The plan threatens to blur the line between nuclear and conventional arms. Instead of looking for new uses for nuclear weapons, the administration should be directing its research toward creating advanced conventional bombs capable of the same missions.

title: Knicks Are Still Shopping For Players
description: On the eve of the free-agent signing period, the National Basketball Association raised the salary cap to $43.84 million a team tonight.

description: The white flag with a thin red cross in front of Currysource, 88 Bergen Street (Smith Street), in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, puzzles shoppers. ''It's the English flag, the Cross of St. George,'' explained Gary Dovey, the owner, at left with his wife, Jilly Stephens. ''What you think of as the English flag is the Union Jack,'' which represents England, Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JAROSLOW, , FRED
description: JAROSLOW -- Fred. The North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System mourns the passing of our esteemed friend and colleague, Fred Jaroslow. A quiet, dedicated, generous professional who made his mark in the business world as the chief operating officer of Weight Watchers International and chairman of Playorena, Inc., Fred provided invaluable expertise as a trustee of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System, serving on numerous committees and contributing countless hours of his time and talent. He had been a trustee of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center Board since 1985. A devoted husband, father and grandfather, he is survived by his wife, Ruth; three daughters, Karen Siris, and Amy and Elizabeth Jaroslow; and six grandchildren, Joshua, Jeremy, Benjamin, Emily, Morey and Jake. Fred will be greatly missed but never forgotten. Roy J. Zuckerberg, Chairman Michael J. Dowling President & CEO North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Inmates Denied Vegan Meals
description: A federal judge has refused to order officials at Rikers Island to provide vegan meals to three inmates who claimed in a lawsuit that the regular prison diets would violate their Jewish religious beliefs. Judge Shira A. Scheindlin said she did not question the sincerity of the inmates' belief that Judaism compels a vegan diet. But, in a ruling on Friday, she said the inmates had failed to make the legal showing that they would be irreparably harmed by the diet policy. The inmates were convicted of charges stemming from protests advocating animal rights. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: CREW OF COLUMBIA SURVIVED A MINUTE AFTER LAST SIGNAL
description: The Columbia astronauts lived for almost a minute after their final communication with mission control, well after signs that the craft was in serious trouble, investigators at NASA and the Columbia Accident Investigation Board said yesterday.

title: When More Means Less
description: In its headlong rush to provide a prescription drug benefit for the elderly and disabled, Congress risks abandoning a fundamental principle that has been a hallmark of Medicare since the program's inception in 1966. That principle -- universality -- ensures that all Medicare beneficiaries, no matter where they live or what their financial circumstances, are eligible for the same basic benefits.

title: Iraqis Plan War-Crime Court; G.I.'s to Stay Until Elections
description: Iraq's postwar government moved today to form a special war-crimes court to try members of President Saddam Hussein's government, and the top American civilian official in Iraq said American troops would leave as soon as the government ratified a new constitution and held valid national elections. He did not give a timetable for elections.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Pressure From U.S.
description: The United States House of Representatives voted to strengthen economic penalties against Myanmar, the former Burma, after a similar move a month ago by the Senate in response to a violent crackdown on political opposition and the continuing imprisonment of the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. The new penalties would ban the import of goods from Myanmar, expand a ban on visas for high-ranking officials, freeze government assets in the United States and effectively bar international loans or technical aid. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Midtown Hotel Is Sold
description: A large Midtown hotel has been sold for more than $100 million to a real estate partnership that plans a major renovation of the 42-year-old property. The partnership closed yesterday on its purchase of the Metropolitan Hotel, a 730-room hotel on Lexington Avenue between 50th and 51st Streets. The partnership -- Highgate Holdings, Oxford Lodging and the Goldman Sachs Whitehall fund -- bought the property from Loews Hotels, a division of the Loews Corporation. Opened in 1961 as the Summit, the hotel was renamed the Loews New York, and finally the Metropolitan. Jeffrey D. Stewart, a vice president at Loews, said the company now planned to focus on ''four- and five-star luxury hotels.'' Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Airline Warns On Results
description: British Airways executives warned yesterday that its first-quarter results might be weak. The report will ''reflect a continuing, difficult situation for the world air transport industry,'' the chairman, Lord Colin Marshall, told investors at the company's annual shareholder meeting. Rod Eddington, the chief executive, above, added that the outlook remained uncertain. British Airways cut 10,000 jobs last year and has announced plans to cut another 3,000 in 2003. British Airways has said first-quarter revenues will fall about 10 percent because of heavy price cutting. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: AIDS Fund Still Lagging in Financial Commitments
description: PARIS, July 16 — Representatives of countries contributing to a fund to support the global struggle against AIDS and other diseases that are debilitating the developing world met in Paris today but made little progress toward assuring money for health programs it is expected to approve later this year.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON REPORTS 27% DROP IN EARNINGS
description: Johnson & Johnson said its second-quarter earnings dropped 27 percent on costs for acquisitions and a decline in revenue from its biggest drug, Procrit for anemia. Net income fell to $1.21 billion, or 40 cents a share, from $1.65 billion, or 54 cents a share, in the same period a year ago, said the company, which is based in New Brunswick, N.J. Sales rose 14 percent to $10.3 billion, from $9.07 billion. Revenue from Procrit, also sold as Eprex, declined 7 percent to $1.02 billion as it faced competition from drugs sold by Amgen and Roche Holding.

title: 3 More Biotech Firms File Suit Against Columbia Over Patent

title: BERKSHIRE WILL NOT INCREASE OFFER FOR CLAYTON HOMES
description: Berkshire Hathaway, the investment and insurance conglomerate run by the billionaire Warren Buffett, said it would not increase its $1.7 billion offer for Clayton Homes Inc. Berkshire also said it had advanced Clayton $360 million since signing a takeover agreement on April 1. Clayton shareholders plan to meet today to vote on Berkshire's $12.50-a-share offer. Shares of Clayton fell 11 cents, to $12.98.

description: Sony Ericsson Mobile Communications today announced better-than-expected quarterly results, but said it did not expect to turn a profit for the year.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: MOTOROLA POSTS 2ND-QUARTER NET INCOME Motorola Inc., the mobile-telephone maker, yesterday reported second-quarter net income of $119 million. Sales fell 10 percent as demand slumped in Asia, and the company said sales in the current quarter might also drop. Net income in the quarter was 5 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $2.32 billion, or $1.02 a share, in the year-earlier period, when the company wrote down the value of some assets, Motorola said in a statement. Sales fell to $6.16 billion. The company exceeded the lowered earnings-per-share forecasts it gave last month of 2 cents a share. It reported a profit before some gains of 1 cent a share, above a break-even forecast. Motorola made no forecast for 2003 results. In April, the company forecast sales of as much as $28 billion and net income in a range of 35 cents to 40 cents. In 2002, Motorola had a net loss of $1.09 a share on sales of $26.7 billion. Motorola shares rose 28 cents, or 3 percent, to $9.78. They have risen 29 percent this year.   (Bloomberg News)

title: At Helm of Port Authority, Behind-the-Scenes Outsider
description: When the nomination of the developer and Democratic fund-raiser Charles Kushner to be chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey collapsed earlier this year, New Jersey Gov. James E. McGreevey turned to Plan B, a lawyer named Anthony R. Coscia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WARMBOLD, , GRACE
description: WARMBOLD--Grace, the former Grace Staub of Miami, Florida left this world to be with the Lord on July 11, 2003 after a long battle with cancer. She was sixty-five years old. Grace Warmbold was born and raised in New York City and educated in Florida. She is a graduate of the University of Miami and former President of Delta Gamma sorority. After graduating from college, Grace studied painting and textile design at New York City's world renowned ''Art Students League'' Institute. She began her professional career as a freelance artist, initially designing textiles for the home furnishings industry. In addition, she pursued interest in painting one-of-a-kind art on fabrics as well as oils, water colors and acrylic which were displayed in galleries in New York and Southampton, Long Island. In 1990, Grace and her family relocated from New York City to Florida. Grace's artwork then reflected the Florida life-style with emphasis on golf course scenes and signature holes. She leaves with loving memories her husband, Herman Warmbold of Miami, daughter Kimberly of New York City, a brother, nieces and nephews. A memorial gathering will be held on July 17, 2003 in New York City at the Essex House. Interment and a memorial service will follow at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY on July 24, 2003 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society. >>AD#

title: On 49th Street, a Cool Breeze From Mexico
description: PLCIDO DOMINGO likes to eat. He just can't decide what he wants to order. Domingo, his pet project in Manhattan, opened in 1996 as a Spanish restaurant of no particular distinction. When that failed, he abandoned Spain and hired the cookbook author Patricia Quintana to devise a Mexican menu. When that did not please, he turned to Richard Sandoval, the chef and owner of Maya, to work some magic on a restaurant that seemed to have only one thing going for it, Mr. Domingo's name.

description: Responding to expected recommendations from the Columbia space shuttle investigation, NASA said today that it would establish an agency-wide safety center that could halt shuttle launchings in the event of safety concerns.

description: Lance Armstrong faced a new peril today in his quest for his fifth Tour de France title: a street protest. The disruption cost Armstrong and his pack about 90 seconds, but his overall lead was not affected.

title: Trial of Older Sniper Suspect Is Moved to Southern Virginia
description: The trial of John Allen Muhammad, the older man charged in the sniper shootings that terrorized the Washington metropolitan region in the fall, will be moved from Manassas, Va., near Washington, to Virginia Beach, 160 miles to the south, a judge ruled today.

title: The Deficit Floats Up and Away
description: Having done its utmost to choke back the revenue flow into the Treasury, the Bush administration offered a running tab on this year's exploding budget deficit yesterday. To hear the casual patter of White House aides about the deficit, one would think it was pocket change. In fact, the shortfall has ballooned 50 percent in just five months, to $455 billion and counting. This historic high shows no sign of cresting, certainly not while the president's detaxation mania rolls forward.The White House firmly insists that the growing wad of government costs and debt being rolled across the years toward tomorrow's taxpayers is eminently ''manageable.'' Actually, what was manageable was the $127 billion surplus the fledgling administration enjoyed just two years ago.

title: Future of Terror Case Is in Judge's Hands as Government Continues to Block Testimony
description: The Justice Department's hopes of salvaging its case against Zacarias Moussaoui in civilian court rested today with a no-nonsense federal trial judge who has repeatedly questioned the government's efforts to prosecute Mr. Moussaoui with so much of the case against him kept secret from the public -- and from Mr. Moussaoui.

title: Priest is Given 18-Year Term In Sex Assaults
description: A 57-year-old Roman Catholic priest in New Jersey who was convicted in December of having sexually assaulted an 11-year-old altar boy a decade ago was sentenced yesterday to 18 years in the state's specialized prison for sex offenders.

title: Harvard Scholar Rebuilds African Studies Department
description: After a year of turmoil that saw two of its biggest stars defect to Princeton University, Harvard's celebrated Afro-American studies department will be refocused and expanded to include an African language program and a new major in African studies, the chairman of the department, Henry Louis Gates Jr., said yesterday.

title: One Name He Can Remember. It Was an Elephant's.
description: UNLESS you make an enemy of him, or front him a bushel of money for a real estate adventure, odds are that David C. Walentas, the developer who latched onto Brooklyn's derelict Dumbo neighborhood decades ago and, several hundred million dollars in equity later, sees himself as its mayor, won't remember your name. Don't await an apology.

title: Despite a Sluggish City Economy, Apartment Prices Up in Manhattan
description: After two consecutive quarters of decline, the average sales price of apartments in Manhattan rose 11 percent, to $864,860, in the second three months of the year despite a sluggish economy, according to a report released yesterday.

title: Councilman Quits Race and Backs Son
description: In the Bronx, where no election year seems to pass without the candidacy of one member of the Espada family or another, voters in the Soundview section might be somewhat puzzled by their choices in this year's contest for a City Council seat.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: EUROPEAN UNION: SUPPORT FOR BUDGET LIMITS European Union finance ministers yesterday defended a set of rules intended to ensure sound bookkeeping by governments in the euro zone, after President Jacques Chirac of France called for them to be temporarily eased. The prevailing view among European finance ministers is that the Stability and Growth Pact signed before use of the euro began in 1999 is flexible enough to manage the current economic downturn, Gerrit Zalm, the Dutch finance minister, said after yesterday's meeting. The pact calls on governments to keep their budget deficits below 3 percent of gross domestic product. The French finance minister, Francis Mer, above, however, announced that France would exceed that limit again next year, the third consecutive year. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: MORE VERIZON WORKERS TO BE REHIRED Verizon Communications is rehiring 1,100 laid-off workers in the Northeast who were not covered by last week's order by an arbitrator in New York to take back 2,300 employees in the state who had been improperly terminated in a cost-cutting effort. The reinstatement, possibly pre-empting similar rulings in labor grievances filed in other states, comes just weeks before the deadline on talks between Verizon and its unions for a new contract covering 75,000 of the telephone company's nearly 230,000 employees. On Friday, an arbitrator, Shyam Das, ruled that Verizon's justification for the December layoffs  a weak economy and toughening competition from rivals and new technology  was not permissible under the existing contract. "We disagree with that ruling, but nonetheless, Verizon was directed to rehire workers in New York," Verizon spokesman Eric Rabe said Tuesday. "Now we have voluntarily decided to no longer contest union grievances over layoffs in the other states." (AP)

description: Had Aleksei Kovalev remained a right wing with the Pittsburgh Penguins, it was a foregone conclusion that he would have filed for arbitration by yesterday's midnight deadline.

description: Kisses keep coming up in the lyrics of Bruce Springsteen's most recent album, ''The Rising,'' released in the backdraft of the Sept. 11 attacks. They are for reassurance, confirmation of one's place in the world, proof of life, a passage to understanding. Whether waking or dying, the characters need to fuse with someone before the song can end.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Investor Sentiment Improves
description: German investor confidence jumped to an 11-month high, according to a survey released yesterday by the ZWE Center for European Economic Research. The institute's index that measures expectations for economic growth rose to 41.9 in July from 21.3 in June, gaining for a seventh month. The center said that rising share prices and the German government's efforts to loosen labor markets and cut taxes contributed to the growing optimism. Victor Homola (NYT)

That was United's first clear indication of the initial size of the low-cost operation, a business the company has been trumpeting since it filed for bankruptcy protection last December.

title: Summer-School Attendance Rate Is Just 60%, Officials Say
description: Only about 60 percent of New York City's failing students who were assigned to summer school are actually attending classes, city education officials said yesterday. As a result, nearly 100,000 students may be forced to repeat a grade next year.

description: A dispute between the Narragansett Indian tribe and Rhode Island officials over a tax-free tobacco shop moved into the courts today, a day after a melee between tribal members and state troopers who raided the shop.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: House Panel Expands Inquiry On E-Rate Program
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee has expanded its investigation of the troubled $2.25 billion E-Rate program, calling on more than a dozen companies, including I.B.M., to turn over documents related to their involvement in the program. E-Rate, created in 1996 by Congress, offers subsidies of 20 percent to 90 percent for buying telecommunications services like Internet connection fees and for wiring classrooms. Under the program, paid from fees on telephone bills, the biggest subsidies go to the poorest schools. In January, the Center for Public Integrity in Washington found that the program was ''honeycombed with fraud and financial shenanigans.'' The report was in large part based on investigations by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Affirming Increase, Court Rules Fares Are M.T.A.'s Call
description: A state appeals court ruled unanimously yesterday that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was within its rights when it raised transit fares and tolls in May, meaning that millions of riders and drivers will continue to pay the higher prices.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hauppauge: 8 Accused Of Running Gambling Ring
description: Eight people described by the authorities as members of the Bonanno crime family have been arrested in a raid that shut down a gambling ring that took in $20 million a year in bets on football and other sports, the Suffolk County district attorney, Thomas J. Spota, announced yesterday. Investigators said that the ring had been operating for up to two decades, taking bets in the Bronx and Manhattan. The suspects, arrested in a Monday raid, are Patrick Nestico of Manhattan; Anthony Frascone of East Meadow; Michael Casale, John Spirito Jr., Nicholas Terrigno and Louis J. Aresu, all of the Bronx, and Vincent Falci and Patrick Marone, both of West Babylon. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

description: JERUSALEM, July 16  The Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, plans to make his first visit to President Bush in Washington on July 25, to press for Israeli concessions to advance the new Middle East peace plan, Palestinian officials said today.

description: The last time Royal St. George's played host to the British Open, Greg Norman felt like a king.

title: CHEVRONTEXACO AGREES TO RESTRUCTURE DYNEGY DEBT
description: Dynegy Inc., a utility owner and power producer based in Houston, said it would sell $1.5 billion in bonds to refinance debt. It also said ChevronTexaco, its largest shareholder, had agreed to restructure a $1.5 billion payment due in November. The proceeds from the bond sale will be used to redeem $650 million of bonds due in 2005 and 2006 and to pay down $1.66 billion in loans obtained in April. In lieu of the November payment, Dynegy will pay ChevronTexaco $225 million in cash, $225 million in bonds due in 2016, and $400 million in convertible preferred stock, the company said. Dynegy borrowed the money from ChevronTexaco in November 2001 as part of its aborted takeover of Enron.

title: World Briefing: Americas

At a meeting in Bangkok, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Jerry D. Jennings made plans with North Korean officials for an operation later this year north of the capital, Pyongyang, and in the northeast near the Chosin Reservoir. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Democratic Candidates Are Split On the Issue of Gay Marriages
description: The issue was gay marriage. The occasion was a candidates' forum, sponsored by the Human Rights Campaign, a group advocating gay rights. description: Power lines twisted in the air and billboards and other debris littered the streets of this seaside town and other communities throughout southern Texas today as Hurricane Claudette broke out of the Gulf of Mexico in a fury of rain and wind.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Ruling On Marcos Money
description: The Supreme Court announced that it had awarded to the government more than $650 million in Swiss bank deposits of the late president Ferdinand Marcos. The court said the dictator's heirs had failed to justify ownership of the money. President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo's spokesman said the money would go to the government's poverty-alleviation program. Some will compensate close to 10,000 victims of human rights violations under Marcos. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: Carol Shields, Pulitzer-Prize Winning Novelist, Dies
