title: Untethered Unit Morphs Into a Front or Surround Speaker
description: It's easy to wire up a home theater system's front speakers neatly because they are generally at the same end of the room as your TV set and other viewing electronics. But connecting surround speakers at the sides or back of the room is likely to leave cables where they can be seen or, worse, tripped over. The Pioneer HTD-630VD solves that problem with a wireless rear speaker fed by radio.

title: Tom DeLay's Down-Home Muscle
description: We're happy to note that Tom DeLay's lunge for more political power is running into trouble in his home state of Texas. The special session of the State Legislature, which he prompted in order to redraw the political map to favor more Congressional Republicans, is foundering. A lone G.O.P. state senator is holding out against the House majority leader's plan to redistrict Democratic incumbents out of their seats, thwarting Mr. DeLay's hubristic plotting.

title: SCHOLASTIC EXPECTS $2.2 BILLION IN SALES IN FISCAL 2004
description: The chief executive of the Scholastic Corporation, Richard Robinson, said that the company, which is the American publisher of the ''Harry Potter'' books, would have sales of $2.1 billion to $2.2 billion in the 2004 fiscal year, about 7 percent to 12 percent higher than a year earlier. Cash flow in the year that started June 1 will be $40 million to $50 million, Mr. Robinson said in a conference call. The low end of the sales forecast assumes that Scholastic will not see much revenue growth except for ''Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix,'' the fifth book in the series about a boy wizard's adventures, Mr. Robinson said. The latest Harry Potter installment, published on June 21, broke publishing records by selling five million copies within 24 hours of its release.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRADLEE, , FREDERIC
description: BRADLEE--Frederic. July 12, 2003. Brother of Benjamin C. Bradlee, former actor and author. Memorial service Thursday July 17th, 12:00 at Church of The Resurrection, 115 East 74th Street, between Park and Lexington, NYC. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Opera Orchestra of New York, Suite 2R, 239 W 72 St, NY, NY 10023. >>AD#

title: John Gerhart, 59, Expert On Agriculture in Africa
description: John D. Gerhart, a specialist in African agriculture and land use for the Ford Foundation and president of the American University in Cairo until his retirement last year, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 59.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Court Voids Redistricting
description: The State Supreme Court has ruled for the second time in two years that legislative redistricting maps drawn by the Democratic-controlled General Assembly are unconstitutional. The court's 4-to-1 decision upheld the ruling of a lower court that the redistricting violated the state's Constitution in several ways, including a provision against splitting counties. The justices, who are elected, divided along party lines, and the dissenter was the lone Democrat; two other Republican justices did not participate. The 2002 elections were held based on temporary districts. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Dylan's Lyrics: Something Borrowed . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrating the Life and Impact Of the Nigerian Music Legend Fela
description: Femi Osunla stood quietly before a wall of snapshots at the New Museum in SoHo one evening last week, seemingly unaware of the blaring music and swelling crowd that had gathered around him. Lost in his remembrances, he was staring at pictures of the Nigerian singer and political activist Fela Anikulapo-Kuti, who died in 1997. Some were candid; others were posed. All were taken by Mr. Osunla, a member of Fela's retinue for nearly two decades.

title: Pattani Journal; Snug Hotels for Birds, Who Pay With Their Nests
description: There is a half-built hotel on the edge of town and investors are debating what kind of guests they want to attract -- people or birds.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Tex Schramm, former general manager of the Dallas Cowboys, misidentified the year of the highlight film that helped imprint the team on the public consciousness. It covered the 1978 season, not 1968.

title: Aide to Mayor In Graft Case Is Sentenced To 14 Months
description: A former Bridgeport mayor's associate, who once wrote a book about the city's history, was sentenced today to 14 months in prison and ordered to pay a $75,000 fine in the corruption case that brought the mayor down.

title: Sports of The Times; Mastering the Nuances of a Quirky Course to Win the British Open
description: DOWN here, not far from the white cliffs of Dover, the names that have won the British Open at Royal St. George's jump out of the sandhills of history: Harry Vardon twice, Walter Hagen twice, Bobby Locke and, more recently, Bill Rogers, Sandy Lyle and Greg Norman.

title: Behold, High-Gloss Cinder Blocks
description: When architects suggest using exposed concrete blocks, some clients prefer to dress up the look. Blocks from E. Dillon & Company of Swords Creek, Va., are cast in exotic custom colors like those above. The company starts with blocks that look like ordinary concrete and shaves off a quarter-inch of surface to reveal dark dolomite gravel from its quarry. Dillon then polishes the blocks to a mirror finish as reflective as marble or granite. The blocks are 16 inches long and oversize at a generous 12 inches tall($7.50 each), but thinner than typical concrete blocks. David A. Skidmore, the company president, recommends them for foyers or around fireplaces; (800) 234-8970 or www.edillon.com.

title: A Hands-On Boss Will Try To Let an Old Friend Lead
description: They are very close. But in many ways they are contrasting personalities. Sanford I. Weill, a brash, voluble man with a robust ego, has a Brooklyn boy's love for the Manhattan high life and likes to frame magazine cover stories of himself. Charles O. Prince, whom Mr. Weill picked to succeed him as chief executive of Citigroup, is more of a backroom operator: his name hardly appears in the society pages and he is not a familiar face on magazine covers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BORAN, , SR. FRANCIS DE SALES
description: BORAN--Sr. Francis de Sales, RSHM, 88, July 15, 2003, Tarrytown, NY. Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary 67 years. Teacher at Marymount Secondary School, Tarrytown; Academy of the Sacred Heart of Mary, Manhattan, NY; Marymount College, Tarrytown, NY; Marymount College, Palos Verdes, CA; Marymount University, Arlington, VA. Visiting Thursday, 3:00-7:30PM, Mass Friday, 10:30AM, both at Marymount Convent, Tarrytown, NY. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary, 50 Wilson Park Drive, Tarrytown, NY, 10591. >>AD#

description: STEIN--Nettie. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Myron Fenster, Int. Sr. Rabbi Sidney Freedman, President >>AD#

title: World Briefing | Europe: Sicily: U.S. Military Craft Crashes
description: An American military helicopter crashed and exploded in Sicily, killing all four crew members on board, the Italian police said. The helicopter, which took off from the American Navy base at Sigonella, on Sicily's eastern coast, crashed on a roadside and caught fire. The police said the cause of the crash was unclear. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: London Looks West: Talk Show Is an Opera, a Film Is a Play
description: There is a dangerous breed of show tune that, once heard, refuses to let go of you no matter how hard you push it away. You know, one of those brassy, uplifting and desperate anthems of hope and egotism like ''Everything's Coming Up Roses'' from ''Gypsy'' or ''Once in a Lifetime'' from ''Stop the World, I Want to Get Off.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Combos For Mutt And Jeff
description: YOU know the TV ad for Apple's latest laptops? Two passengers sit side by side on a plane: Verne Troyer, the 2-foot-8 actor who plays Mini-Me in the Austin Powers movies, and Yao Ming, the 7-foot-5 center for the Houston Rockets. Each pulls out a laptop to watch a DVD on the flight. The joke, of course, is that Mr. Yao pulls out Apple's diminutive 12-inch model, and Mr. Troyer pulls out the 17-inch model, which seems roughly the size of Utah.

description: Growing Crisis in Hong Kong

description: To the Editor:

description: UNDER THE BANNER OF HEAVEN

title: Global AIDS Fund Finding Few Answers to Its Cash Shortage
description: Representatives of countries contributing to a fund to support the global struggle against AIDS and other diseases that are ravaging the developing world met in Paris today but made little progress toward easing a cash crisis expected later this year.

title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; Despite a Change of Scene, Benitez Is Still Benitez
description: Things change when a player relocates from Flushing to the Bronx. Things change when a reliever is required to secure outs in the eighth inning for the Yankees as opposed to getting outs in the ninth for the Mets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACKNIS, , NATHAN
description: JACKNIS -- Nathan. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, NY mourns the passing of our beloved member Nathan Jacknis. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas Dr. Steven Zeldis, President >>AD#

title: Despite Changes, Low Rating
description: Although the new All-Star Game format gave the American League the home-field advantage in the World Series with its 7-6 victory and produced a taut, well-played game, the Fox broadcast on Tuesday night generated a historic low rating for a second straight year.

title: Rumsfeld Deputy Begins Tour of Iraq to Assess Strategy
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 17  Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz arrived here today for a five-day tour of Iraq to assess the Bush administration's successes and shortcomings in the postwar reconstruction effort.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Killed In Hit-And-Run:
description: An 85-year-old woman was killed by a hit-and-run driver yesterday afternoon in Homecrest, the police said. The woman, whom the police identified as Helena Gliksman of Avenue Y, was crossing the street at Avenue Y and Coney Island Avenue just before 2 a.m. when a northbound green minivan hit her and fled the scene. She was pronounced dead at 3:30 p.m. at Coney Island Hospital, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CLOROX CO., Oakland, Calif., the household bleach maker, said it would raise its quarterly dividend to 27 cents from 22 cents a share, a 23 percent increase, and may repurchase $700 million of its shares to help raise the stock's price.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COLMAN, , GERALD S.
description: COLMAN--Gerald S. 10/17/46--7/17/00 We love you still. Judy, Emily, family & friends >>AD#

description: GORDON--Aaron, on July 15, 2003, at the age of 78. Loving father of Eric and his wife Andrea Gordon, and Lisa and her husband, Jon Taubes. Adoring grandfather of Jennifer, Alexandra, Harris and Seth. Dear brother of Doris Matorin and Annette Arkin. Funeral service, Thursday, July 17, 2003, 9:30AM at Westchester Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. >>AD#

title: 'Excited' Mourning Introduced by Nets
description: As soon as Alonzo Mourning landed in New Jersey today, he called Jason Kidd from his cellphone.

description: Following is a transcript of a joint news conference yesterday by President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Central Bank Is Optimistic
description: In its monthly report for July, the Bank of Japan raised its assessment of the economy for the first time in a year, citing a rebound in stock prices and capital spending. The bank repeated that the economy over all was flat, but that exports were also improving. The upgraded outlook comes a day after the central bank left monetary policy unchanged, and follows a nearly 30 percent rise in stock prices since late April. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: True Stories

title: Two Distinct Views Of Workers Rising Up
description: The double bill of documentaries that opens today at the Anthology Film Archives bridges 35 years of leftist political filmmaking and suggests that just about everything has changed in the field but the basic Marxist message.

title: AT HOME WITH: Michael Bay; A Slam-Bang Master With a House of Om
description: WHEN Michael Bay began directing music videos, he scouted a modern house in Bel Air as a possible site to use as background for the hard rock band Aerosmith. ''I was in my 20's and I remember opening the door and saying, 'Man, I'd love to own a house like this some day,' '' he said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's low intensity conflict, in our doctrinal terms, but it's war, however you describe it.''

title: Round It Goes, Up It Goes, Where It Stops, Nobody Knows
description: Cities are racing to build the world's tallest ferris wheel. George Ferris pioneered the form in Chicago a century ago with a wheel 250 foot high -- five times the height of previous wheels. Today, the London Eye, above, is at 450 feet the world's tallest. ''The public has an appetite for these more daring bravura works of engineering,'' said Joan Ockman, an architecture professor at Columbia University. The London Eye has become a landmark, partly because of its view of Big Ben. ''You have to make sure that your customer is going to see something worthwhile,'' said David Sharpe, the general manager. More than three million people a year take the 30-minute ride, giving a boost to the real estate around the wheel.

title: 3 Blinks Means You're Hot: A Wireless Network Tracker
description: You've seen them wandering through airports and conference centers, holding laptops up at strange angles and squinting at the screens. They move slowly forward, then backward. Then they often scratch their heads, stow their computers and wander off muttering.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Support For Burmese Opposition Leader
description: Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, said he met with an envoy from Myanmar and told him that he expected the government to release Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the opposition leader, ''as soon as possible.'' Mr. Annan said he considered the government responsible for the protection of Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, who was detained on May 30. In Washington, the Senate passed and sent to President Bush for his promised signature a measure that bans the import of goods from Myanmar, formerly Burma, expands a ban on visas for top officials, freezes government assets in the United States and effectively bars international loans or technical aid to Myanmar. Felicity Barringer (NYT)

title: Failed Magazine May Be Revived
description: The little Southern literary journal that tried failed today. But the editor of the journal, The Oxford American, resolved to revive the magazine only hours after announcing that it would suspend publication.

title: Conductor Draws Blame In Derailment
description: The conductor on the Manhattan-bound commuter train that lost a wheel and derailed Monday morning was accused today of incorrectly performing an emergency inspection and failing to detect dangerous overheating in the wheel's assembly about 40 minutes before it came off.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Mistaken Identity Case Resolved
description: The government released from jail a man from Northern Ireland who was arrested four days ago when he was apparently mistaken for a suspected bombmaker and accused of teaching Palestinians how to make explosives. Israeli officials described the man, John Morgan, as a bombmaker for the Real Irish Republican Army, a group that broke away from the I.R.A. Later, the officials backed off the bombmaking claim. His family described Mr. Morgan as a pro-Palestinian campaigner not connected to any I.R.A. faction. His Irish name is Sean O'Muireagain, and he was apparently mistaken for another man with that name who is with the Real I.R.A. Mr. Morgan left Israel after his release.

title: MORE SUBSCRIBERS AND HIGHER PRICES LIFT HUGHES
description: Hughes Electronics, the largest American satellite-television provider, said yesterday it earned $21.6 million in the second quarter as its DirecTV service added subscribers and raised prices. The net loss a year earlier was $177.9 million, after dividends on preferred stock, the company said in a statement. Hughes does not report per-share results because it is a tracking stock of General Motors. Revenue rose 8.1 percent to $2.37 billion from $2.19 billion. DirecTV ended the quarter with 11.6 million subscribers, 7.5 percent more than a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMILEN, , HYMAN
description: SMILEN -- Hyman. Died peacefully on July 13, 2003, 92 years young. Beloved father and sidekick of Francine, (Tod Ensign), Steven, (Ilde), and grandpa of Rachel Ensign. Died as he lived, with determination and dignity. Rest in peace. Donations to: Town and Village Synagogue, 334 East 14th St., NYC 10003. >>AD#

title: Madonna and Magic To Pitch Products
description: Two big marketers have hired celebrities to endorse their products for undisclosed terms.

title: For Guitarists on the Go, A Svelte Box Packs Boom
description: At first glance, the sturdy little black box with reinforced corners resembles an industrial-strength version of Nintendo's GameCube console (strap handle included). But on closer examination, the volume and tone control knobs and the shiny input jack give away its true purpose: portable guitar amplifier.

title: Localism's Last Stand
description: General managers of 75 stations owned and operated by the Big Four television networks swept into a meeting of the House Appropriations Committee yesterday. Big Media's lobbying purpose was to squelch the bipartisan movement in Congress to nullify the Federal Communications Commission's cave-in to the networks' lust to gobble up more independent stations.

title: Court Likely To Take Up Congo First
description: The new International Criminal Court is likely to open its first case by investigating the leaders most responsible for flagrant abuses against civilians in eastern Congo, the court's chief prosecutor announced today.

title: COTT BOARD ELECTS PRESIDENT AND OPERATING OFFICER
description: The board of the Cott Corporation, the world's largest supplier of generic soft drinks, voted yesterday to elect John K. Sheppard as its new president and chief operating officer. Mr. Sheppard was also given a spot on the company's board. Cott is expected to announce the appointments formally today. Mr. Sheppard, who joined the company in 2002, had previously served as the president of Cott's operations in the United States. He assumes the title of president from Frank E. Weise, who had served as Cott's president, chairman and chief executive. Other senior management changes include the promotion of Paul R. Richardson, an executive vice president for global procurement and Britain, to president of United States operations. Andrew Murfin was named managing director of Cott Britain. Sherri Day (NYT)

title: Bring Back 30-Year Bond? No Guide From Greenspan
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, seemed inclined yesterday toward favoring the return of the 30-year bond, whose issuance was halted by the Treasury in October 2001.

title: Tour Riders Get First Breather
description: As the Tour de France paused for its first rest day today, some riders looked ahead to the time trial stage and others tried to put the race out of their minds.

title: Pressing the Maid's Room Into Service
description: THE architect Kate Webb says her work is inspired not by Palladio, Frank Lloyd Wright or Mies van der Rohe (well, maybe a little by Mies), but by the Greenwich Village maid's room where she learned the virtues of living small. ''My brother says I design my spaces like a boat builder,'' Ms. Webb said. ''Everything functions three or four ways.'' In perhaps her most brazen exercise in condensation, Ms. Webb created what she calls a ''baby boat,'' a bateau-shaped miniroom for a newborn that incorporates a crib and changing table.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: RAISING UNIVERSITY FEES Expecting deep cuts in state financing, leaders of the state's two public university systems approved raising student fees by as much as 30 percent. A committee of University of California regents recommended raising fees by 25 percent, giving the system president the option to go 5 percent higher if needed. The full board is expected to approve the increase. Trustees of California State University raised fees 30 percent. (AP)

title: Heady Days in Hong Kong
description: Hong Kong has suddenly found its democratic voice, and China is at least listening. That's the encouraging story so far this month. The next chapter, however, will probably be written in Beijing over the coming days, and there's no predicting its direction. That will depend on the wisdom and maturity of China's new leaders, who now face their biggest political test so far.

title: White House Aide Behind Uranium Claim, Senator Says
description: ADemocratic member of the Senate Intelligence Committee said today that a White House official insisted that claims about Iraqi attempts to purchase uranium be included in President Bush's State of the Union address, despite doubts from the Central Intelligence Agency about its credibility.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: State Avoids Credit Downgrade
description: A Wall Street bond-rating agency maintained its assessment of New Jersey government bonds, praising the government's addition of revenue and restraint of spending, but warning of increased pension payments and borrowing costs. Such ratings are closely watched by investors and influence how much New Jersey must pay in interest on its bonds. The rating agency, Standard & Poor's, said Tuesday that it was maintaining its AA rating. A $24 billion budget was passed by the Legislature and signed by the governor late last month. The budget ''adds additional permanent revenues to the base and controls spending for the second consecutive year, making strides toward structural balance,'' said Richard J. Marino, an analyst for Standard & Poor's. John Holl (NYT)

title: 2 Top Officials in Hong Kong Resign in Wake of Protests
description: Two weeks of street protests here produced a government crisis tonight as two top officials announced their resignations and the territory's chief executive said he would fly to Beijing on Saturday to consult China's rulers about what to do next.

title: Player and Normalcy Still Missing
description: An academic reputation to match Vanderbilt's and an athletic program to rival, say, Texas'. That is what Robert B. Sloan Jr., the president of Baylor, has in mind for the university he leads.

title: A Fair Medicare Competition
description: The conference committee charged with fashioning a final Medicare bill convened this week amid signs that the differences between House Republicans and Senate Democrats are hardening. The main point of the bill was supposed to be providing prescription drug benefits to elderly Americans. But warring camps seem to be drawing lines in the sand around a much larger issue: a provision in the House bill that would force the traditional Medicare program to compete against private insurance plans starting in 2010.

title: House Backs $5.6 Billion Fund To Develop Bioterror Remedies
description: Nearly two years after a spate of anthrax-tainted letters killed five Americans and terrified millions more, the House voted overwhelmingly today to establish a $5.6 billion fund intended to encourage the development of drugs, vaccines and other defenses against biological, nuclear, radiological or chemical attack.

title: Bush and Blair Defend Decision to Wage War in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain today emphatically defended the war they launched against Iraq, with Mr. Blair insisting that disputed British intelligence on Iraq used to justify the war was genuine.

title: New Scrutiny Directed at Bundled Sale of Hospital Supplies
description: Federal and state investigators are looking into whether large medical-products companies are bundling products for sale to hospitals in ways that may violate antitrust laws.

title: Blair Arrives in U.S. Today, Trailing Controversy Over Iraq
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair travels to Washington Thursday on a mission to underline Britain's close and dependable relationship with the United States without reinforcing his critics' portrayal of him at home as an unquestioning follower of President Bush.

title: That Kitten May Look Harmless, but He's a Jailbird
description: Gizmo the cat is only about 6 weeks old, but his life reads like that of the most streetwise New Yorker. Days spent on subway platforms with his keeper, a street musician. A brush with the law. And now, a record of hard time -- more than 40 hours -- in the system.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the beginning of a month of guided tours through the ruins of Palace of the Republic, an East Berlin entertainment showcase, misstated the period of its construction. That occurred between 1973 and 1975; in 1950 the remains of a Hohenzollern palace at the site were removed.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Rounding Up The Usual Suspects

title: Knicks Have Van Horn On Their Radar Screen
description: While news conferences were held around the N.B.A. today on the first signing day for free agents, the Knicks' executives remained holed up here at the Reebok Pro Summer League working the telephones, trying to find a way to improve their team.

title: Landfill Cleanup Was Delayed, State Admits
description: The state acknowledged today that it failed to manage adequately the cleanup of a solid waste landfill here, a lapse environmentalists say may have allowed tons of heavy metals, benzenes and other carcinogens to seep into the groundwater and possibly the Raritan River.

title: A Climb to Riches, One Merger at a Time
description: If ever there was a case in which investors bought a boss, not a business, it came in the fall of 1986 when a sleepy lender to borrowers with not very good credit, known as Commercial Credit, went public.

title: Celia Cruz, Petite Powerhouse of Latin Music, Dies at 77
description: Celia Cruz, the Cuban singer who became the queen of Latin music, died yesterday at her home in Fort Lee, N.J. She was 77.

title: Leela Chitnis, 93, an Actress In Scores of Bombay Movies
description: Leela Chitnis, an actress whose half-century-long 40-film career in India progressed from romantic roles to the motherly ones for which she is best remembered, died on Monday at a hospital in Danbury, Conn. She was 93. She had been living in Connecticut for many years to be near her family.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Dress Code Debate
description: The Parliament reversed itself and allowed lawmakers to enter the chambers wearing African dress, but debate continued on whether to abandon a colonial-era dress code requiring a suit and tie. The speaker, Francis ole Kaparo, expelled Raila Odinga, a cabinet minister, and two members of Parliament last week for what he deemed improper dress. The three men have since been permitted to return wearing African robes. A group of Kenyan fashion designers said, ''African-inspired dress is our way of promoting national pride at a time of political and social rebirth in Kenya.'' Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Cablevision's New Venture With Satellite Stirs Skeptics
description: Cablevision Systems, the largest cable television operator in the New York City area, plans to launch a television satellite from Cape Canaveral, Fla., tonight. The company hopes the move -- one viewed with great skepticism by some industry analysts -- will enable it to expand its program offerings across the United States.

title: Developer Wants 9/11 Bonds for Times's Project in Midtown
description: The New York Times Company's development partner in building the newspaper's new headquarters on Eighth Avenue has asked city officials for $400 million in tax-exempt bonds that were designated for rebuilding New York after the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Dimpled Pads Reduce the Risk Of Losing That Slick Cellphone
description: Fred Antonini found cellphone cases unappealingly bulky. But the alternatives -- having his unprotected phone ''rocket out of my shirt pocket'' when he bent over or slide off smooth tabletops -- were equally unpleasant.

title: Civil Liberties Union Faults Inquiry Into Rap Producer
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union is questioning the state lobbying commission's decision to investigate Russell Simmons, Andrew M. Cuomo and others who have been pushing to soften the state's Rockefeller-era drug laws.

title: The Invisible Hand Opens the Checkbook
description: IT has long been possible to pay bills online, but now you can use your personal computer to receive bills, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, , STANLEY S., M.D.
description: WEISS--Stanley S., M.D., The faculty of the NYU Psychoanalytic Institute and the members of the Psychoanaltytic Association of New York mourn the passing of Dr. Stanley Weiss, our esteemed colleague. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. Robert Fischel, M.D. Charles Goodstein, M.D. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AMPEL, , NANCY H.
description: AMPEL--Nancy H. On July 15, 2003. Beloved wife of the late David B. Loving mother of Kenneth and Frederick. Dear sister of Claire Brody. Adoring grandmother of Ethan David. Service Thursday 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made to the David B. Ampel Memorial Scholarship Fund, C/O Brooklyn Law School, Brooklyn, NY 11201.

title: For Woods, Rough Start (Really Rough) at British Open
description: SANDWICH, England, July 17  Tiger Woods needed two golf balls and seven shots to finish his first hole today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday about the annual meeting of media executives in Sun Valley, Idaho, misspelled the surname of a participant. He is Jim Wiatt, not Wyatt.

title: A Cup for a Kiddush Or a Cabernet
description: ''Artists need only to please themselves, but designers address a community,'' said Marilyn Davidson, who develops products with the Jewish Museum in Manhattan. For Namb, the tableware maker based in New Mexico, Ms. Davidson has created a sleek kiddush cup, right, suitable for occasions like bar mitzvahs and Passover seders. The cup inaugurates a new line of Judaica made from Namb's signature nontarnishing metal alloy, which costs less than the traditional silver.

title: ABBAS PLANS VISIT TO BUSH IN HOPES OF PRESSING ISRAEL
description: The Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, plans to make his first visit to President Bush in Washington on July 25, to press for Israeli concessions to advance the new Middle East peace plan, Palestinian officials said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Cleric Accused Of Misusing Funds
description: A minister was accused in an indictment yesterday of misappropriating $570,000 from state and local grants for homeless shelters. The defendant, the Rev. Carrie Wilson, 59, of Amityville, pleaded not guilty in Suffolk County Court. Prosecutors say she had a hidden ownership in shelters rented by her New Life Christian Mission Ministries and she had used charity money for luxury cars and two houses and to pay relatives who had little or no work documented. The county gave her group $5 million over several years but has ended the contract. The state has sued to remove Ms. Wilson and her two daughters from the ministries' board for violating rules on nonprofit groups. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Fallon Is Chosen For Subway Account
description: Subway Restaurants in Milford, Conn., named Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis yesterday to handle creative and strategic planning duties on its account. Those duties have been handled for three years by Euro RSCG MVBMS in New York. Although billings were not disclosed, Subway spent $218.6 million to advertise in major media last year, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, part of Taylor Nelson Sofres.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Giuliani Promotes Indian Pt. Terror Drill
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York City mayor, visited Westchester County today to speak on behalf of one of his new clients, Entergy Nuclear Northeast, as it prepares for an antiterrorism drill at its Indian Point nuclear power complex.

title: No Stun Grenades Since Death in Raid, As Debate Continues
description: In the two months since a 57-year-old Harlem woman was literally scared to death after a detective rolled a concussion grenade into her apartment during a mistaken raid, the New York Police Department has not used a single one of the grenades, according to police officials. Last year, it was using about three a week.

title: France and Germany set themselves apart from rest of Europe : Schrder adds voice to Chirac's on deficits
description: BRUSSELS:  For the second time in as many weeks, the European Union is projecting an image of squabbling and dissonance over a deeply divisive internal controversy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOFF, , SAMUEL GEORGE
description: KOFF--Samuel George, on July 1, in Durham, NC. Son of the late Seymour Koff and the late Mildred Koff. Survived by friends and relatives: Marilyn Franks, Richard and Judy Koff, Marjorie and Charles Zuckerman, Stephanie Rubin, Amanda Klarsfeld, Lauren Loeb and Matthew Koff and Aunt Pearl Harris. Adored by his dogs Sophie and Max. Memorial gathering at his home in Durham, July 20. Donations to the Weimaraner Rescue. >>AD#

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: MISSING POLICE FILES Preliminary results of an outside audit of Atlanta police records show that files on about 20,000 calls to the police for 2002 are unaccounted for. As a result, the police do not know whether the calls were investigated or resolved, said Elizabeth Kelly, executive director of the Atlanta Police Foundation, which hired the auditor at the request of Chief Richard Pennington. The reports include minor incidents and serious offenses. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Equipment Maker Posts Loss
description: ASML Holding, one of the world's largest makers of semiconductor equipment, said yesterday that it would eliminate 550 jobs as it announced a second-quarter loss that was worse than expected. The company had a net loss of 64 million euros ($71.6 million), compared with a profit of 9.5 million euros in the year-ago quarter. Sales plunged in the second quarter to 329 million euros from 609 million euros in the same period in the previous year. The company said it would likely have a loss for 2003 because of the continuing slump in the semiconductor industry. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: NEXTEL'S NET INCOME MORE THAN DOUBLES Nextel Communications raised its 2003 profit forecast, after second-quarter net income more than doubled on rising demand for its walkie-talkie service. Net income was $309 million, or 27 cents a share, compared with $123 million, or 37 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said in a statement. Sales rose 19 percent to $2.56 billion. Nextel said it will have a profit of at least $1 a share this year, above an earlier forecast of at least 75 cents a share.

title: Timely Help for AmeriCorps
description: Betraying his oft-repeated promise to expand opportunities for meaningful national service, President Bush has not lifted a finger to secure the extra money needed to avoid devastating cuts to AmeriCorps, the federal government's flagship domestic volunteer program. Fortunately, however, Republicans and Democrats in the Senate have now joined together to try to fill the leadership gap.

title: U.S. COMMANDER IN IRAQ SAYS YEARLONG TOURS ARE OPTION TO COMBAT 'GUERRILLA' WAR
description: American troops in Iraq are under attack from ''a classical guerrilla-type campaign'' whose fighters, drawn from Saddam Hussein's most unyielding loyalists and foreign terrorist groups, are increasingly organized, the new commander of allied forces in Iraq said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Branson Plans U.S. Airline
description: Sir Richard Branson, founder of the Virgin Group, said he planned to introduce an airline in the United States by the first half of 2004. Speaking at a news conference at Gatwick airport in London, Sir Richard said that he would confine his voting stock to 25 percent of the company, as United States regulations dictate. Virgin has lobbied to have those regulations changed. The new airline, as of yet unnamed, would follow JetBlue's business model, offering low-cost flights, Sir Richard said. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: For Richer, for Poorer
description: Highlights from this week's forums, including viewpoints on lavish weddings and one reader's top 10 power ballads.

title: U.S. Women No. 1 In First Ranking
description: One day before today's draw for the Women's World Cup, the United States national team was ranked No. 1 in FIFA's first world ranking of women's national teams.

title: Dangerous Information
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Co-Op City Workers Authorize Strike
description: Nearly 250 apartment-building workers at Co-Op City voted unanimously last night to authorize a strike against the Riverbay Corporation, the managing agent of Co-Op City. John Hamill, a spokesman for the union, Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, said the workers did not set a specific date for a strike, although he warned that a walkout could occur in the next few weeks. Mr. Hamill said wage increases were the main issue in the dispute; the janitors, repairmen and other workers seeking to close the gap between them and apartment-building workers in other boroughs. Riverbay, whose offices were closed after the vote, could not be reached for comment. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: No Surprise: Leaders Are South Koreans
description: Yes, the South Korean national archery team still sends its men and women on night training runs, even in the winter, in below-zero temperatures. But no, the archers and team officials say, the athletes no longer take part in a navy-commando training camp and no longer have to bite live snakes.

title: Patron Saint of Sore Shoulders; In Brooklyn, Proudly Carrying 4 Tons of Tradition
description: This was a day to honor St. Paulinus. His saint's tower -- four tons, 70 feet tall -- waited. A hundred and twenty men stood poised to lift and carry it down Havemeyer Street in Brooklyn.

title: Report Clears Police In Brooklyn Death
description: The autopsy of a Brooklyn man who died 10 days after police officers stormed into his home showed that their action did not prompt his death, the medical examiner's office said yesterday. Rather, the office said, the man, Calvin Washington, 41, who had a long history of heart problems, died of complications from pacemaker surgery.

title: Judge Orders Season Shift In Westchester Girls' Soccer
description: A federal judge has ruled that two Westchester high schools violated the law by offering girls' soccer in the spring rather than during the fall, when boys play the game.

title: Pataki Seeks Changes in Decision on City Water Filtration Plant
description: Gov. George E. Pataki, who had expressed serious but vague concern in recent weeks about New York City's plan for a $1.3 billion water filtration plant in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, has finally put his objections in writing and asked that the state legislation authorizing the plant be amended.

title: Debt-Ridden Drug Maker Misses Filing
description: The Elan Corporation, the financially troubled Irish drug maker, said yesterday that it had missed a second deadline for filing its 2002 annual report with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the United States, a failure that could allow creditors to demand repayment of its $2.2 billion in debt.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Sunday about accusations of academic impropriety involving an Ohio State football player, Maurice Clarett, misstated the location of Warren G. Harding High School, which he attended. It is Warren, Ohio, not Youngstown.

title: China Intensifies Efforts on U.S.-North Korea Nuclear Talks
description: GUANGZHOU, China, July 17  China stepped up its efforts to broker negotiations between the United States and North Korea today, dispatching a senior diplomat to Washington and urging both sides to revive a discarded 1994 accord on ending North Korea's nuclear program.

title: Apple Posts Decline in Profit, but Its Sales Rise
description: Apple Computer posted a sharp decline in profit for the quarter yesterday, but said that sales rose as it expanded its reach into laptops and music players.

title: Sliding Twins Acquire Stewart From Blue Jays
description: The slumping Minnesota Twins, looking for a spark to jump-start the second half of the season, acquired Shannon Stewart yesterday from the Toronto Blue Jays for Bobby Kielty in an exchange of outfielders. The Twins will also receive a player to be named.

title: Robertson's Agent To Meet With Jets
description: With the Jets' training camp opening next Monday, Hadley Engelhard, the agent for the team's first-round draft pick, Dewayne Robertson, will arrive in New York today and expects to meet with the Jets tomorrow in an effort to start contract negotiations.

title: Big, Curved and Road-Ready? Book It
description: AS you might have noticed, mine is not a family that travels gracefully. To recap, we're the ones who get six straight days of rain on Nantucket, beautiful views of the hotel's parking garage in Los Angeles and lice in the Adirondacks.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Union: French Internet Company Fined
description: The European Commission fined Wanadoo, France's biggest Internet service provider, just over 10 million euros yesterday for having stifled competition in the market for high-speed Internet access. The commission said in a statement that Wanadoo, which is majority owned by the government-controlled phone group France Tlcom, was offering high-speed Internet subscriptions at below cost for an 18-month period ended last October. During that time, Wanadoo's market share jumped from 46 percent to 72 percent, no rival service acquired more than 10 percent of the market and one competitor, Mangoosta, went out of business, the commission said. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Inspecting Meat Imports
description: To the Editor:

title: 8 Die After Driver Plows Through Outdoor California Market
description: An elderly motorist plowed through a crowded farmer's market here this afternoon, killing eight people and injuring dozens more, witnesses and the police said.

title: Executives More Optimistic but Still Expect Weak Growth
description: Chief executives of big companies have become more optimistic about the economy, but they expect growth to remain weak enough for job cuts to continue through at least the end of the year, according to a survey released yesterday.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Poisoning Dogs In Parks
description: Somebody has been poisoning the dogs in one of Portland's major parks, officials say. At least eight dogs have died after visiting Laurelhurst Park during or after the July Fourth holiday weekend. Up to 10 more are sick or showing symptoms of poisoning, including respiratory and kidney problems, vomiting and diarrhea, after apparently ingesting poisoned pieces of sausage. The police are investigating. Judy Berck (NYT)

title: In Ohio, Iraq Questions Shake Even Some of Bush's Faithful
description: Jim Stock voted for George W. Bush in 2000 and says that if the election were held tomorrow, he'd vote for President Bush again. But he says he is troubled by indications that the White House used questionable intelligence about Iraqi efforts to buy uranium in Africa to push for war in Iraq. And he wants a fuller accounting.

title: Talking to Me? No, the Cabby's on His Cell
description: Slide into a cab in New York City, shut the door, and there's that murmur.

title: Exploding Universe Of Web Addresses
description: SINCE the early 1990's, the popularity of cellphones, pagers and other telecommunications equipment has prompted major changes to the country's area codes, and the supply of 10-digit phone numbers is expected to be exhausted by 2025.

title: Everyone Thinks It's Slate, But That Tabletop Is Concrete
description: Bradlee Kirkpatrick of Kittery, Me., restored old houses for a living and built Shaker-style furniture in his spare time. Mr. Kirkpatrick, 34, was pouring concrete for a foundation one day when inspiration struck. ''After 3,000 pounds of concrete, you kind of get to know it,'' he said. He started using the concrete for tabletops and shelves in a line he calls Ocho. Natalie van Dijk Carpenter and her husband, Curtis Carpenter, below with an Ocho coffee table ($695), sell the furniture at their store, Lekker, 1317 Washington Street in Boston. ''Everyone thinks it's slate,'' she said, ''especially in the charcoal color.'' The tables and shelves are $395 to $995 (www.ochofurniture.com) and have mahogany bases. They are also at Comina stores in Massachusetts, Connecticut and Rhode Island (information, www.comina.com) and at Nahcotta, 111 Congress Street, Portsmouth, N.H. DIANE DANIEL

title: Technology Briefing | Software: PeopleSoft Sets Final Price For J. D. Edwards
description: PeopleSoft said yesterday that the final price it would pay to acquire J. D. Edwards would be $1.8 billion rather than $1.75 billion, because of changes in the price of the stock. The company, based in Pleasanton, Calif., said J. D. Edwards shareholders would receive the equivalent of roughly $14.74 in stock or cash. Shareholders who choose stock will receive 0.8243 PeopleSoft shares for each J. D. Edwards share. The per-share value is based on the average closing price of PeopleSoft stock during the five trading days leading up to July 15.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABHYANKAR, , RAMESH
description: ABHYANKAR--Ramesh. On July 7, 2003. He was a valued employee of Delta Airlines for 34 years. He is survived by his brother Jayant Abhyankar and family, nephew Narasimha Rao, and niece Rohini Moholkar and family. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Rockville Centre: Armored Car Robbed
description: Two private security guards were subdued during the robbery of an armored car yesterday at a routine bank delivery in Rockville Centre, the police said. One guard, a 42-year-old man was punched in the face, and the other was not injured. Witnesses said a robber grabbed one bag filled with an undetermined amount of cash and that he and a second man were seen fleeing on foot eastbound on Sunrise Highway shortly after 9 a.m. Both were described as white men, about 6 feet tall and 250 pounds. The names of the guards, both employed by CDC Company of Central Islip, were not immediately released. The guards were delivering currency to the Chase Manhattan Bank on North Village Avenue. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BRONX: CO-OP CITY WORKERS AUTHORIZE STRIKE Nearly 250 apartment-building workers at Co-Op City voted unanimously last night to authorize a strike against the Riverbay Corporation, the managing agent of Co-Op City. John Hamill, a spokesman for the union, Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, said the workers did not set a specific date for a strike, although he warned that a walkout could occur in the next few weeks. Mr. Hamill said wage increases were the main issue in the dispute; the janitors, repairmen and other workers seeking to close the gap between them and apartment-building workers in other boroughs. Riverbay, whose offices were closed after the vote, could not be reached for comment. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: We're Still the One
description: A quick read of the European Union's draft Constitution provides plenty of evidence of the creation of a world power. The draft, which will be formally presented to European leaders tomorrow, calls for a bill of rights, a foreign minister and a single trade policy. It even proposes a motto, ''United in Diversity.'' But those who hope for the emergence of a Superpower Europe that can rival the United States -- and those who fear such an entity will be an anti-American menace -- will have their expectations disappointed.

title: An animated soap drop with sales experience in Latin America is being put to work in the U.S.
description: PROCTER & GAMBLE is betting that a cartoon character created to promote its dishwashing liquids in Latin America will increase sales of Joy in the United States.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Commissioner Criticizes Banks
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly criticized the banking industry yesterday for not doing enough to combat bank robberies and suggested that state legislation may be needed tp force banks to do more. Banks have done little to improve security since the department issued guidelines in May, including suggestions like posting a guard, he said. So far this year, there have been 283 bank robberies in New York, including four reported yesterday. The total number is more than triple the number at the same period last year, when 84 robberies took place. The American Bankers Association could not be reached for comment yesterday. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: Compromise To Build On
description: Larry A. Silverstein was not in the room as the two renowned architects, Daniel Libeskind and David M. Childs, worked out an agreement early yesterday morning to collaborate on the design of the 1,776-foot tower that will be the first office building to rise at the World Trade Center site.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: ECONOMY SLOWS ON SARS China's economic growth slowed to 6.7 percent in the second quarter from a year earlier as the SARS virus depressed consumption, delayed foreign investment and disrupted production, the People's Daily reported, citing the National Bureau of Statistics deputy director, Qiu Xiaohua, above. Growth in the first quarter surged 9.9 percent, the fastest in seven years. Mr. Qiu said that "SARS didn't lead to a crisis in the economy," though he noted it badly hurt the service sector. (Bloomberg News)

title: Can an MP3 Glutton Savor a Tune?
description: WHEN Marcel Proust bit into a little madeleine, it famously triggered a book's worth of delicate memories. But when it comes to being jolted back in time, foodstuffs aren't nearly as effective as music.

title: Midas Picks DDB To Replace Freeman
description: Midas Inc. in Itasca, Ill., has named the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, as creative agency of record on its account, which has been handled since October 2001 by Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York. Billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: North and South Koreans Exchange Gunfire
description: North and South Korean soldiers exchanged machine-gun fire early today from guard posts on either side of the demilitarized zone that has divided the Korean peninsula since the end of the Korean War 50 years ago this month.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Proposed Directors Back Out
description: Active Value, the largest shareholder in British advertising firm Cordiant Communications Group, said yesterday that two executives that it had nominated to be Cordiant directors as part of an attempt to take control of the company have decided not to participate. In June, Active Value said Richard Wheatly, the former chief executive of Jazz FM, should become executive chairman of Cordiant, and that Stephen Davidson, vice chairman of the bank WestLB, should become vice chairman. The fund called for an emergency general meeting of Cordiant shareholders to vote on the nominations, scheduled for Wednesday. Cordiant's board agreed two weeks later to a deal from WPP Group that values Cordiant shares at about 90 percent less than their value a year ago. Shareholders will vote on whether or not to accept WPP's deal in a meeting, also on Wednesday. Active Value has said it opposes a low-priced deal, and with more than 25 percent of Cordiant's shares, has enough clout to block it. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Minister Survives Vote
description: Japan's banking and economics minister, Heizo Takenaka, survived a parliamentary vote sought by the opposition Democratic Party of Japan, which had demanded he resign. Though Mr. Takenaka has no party affiliation, the three-party ruling coalition voted together to defeat the motion, 137 to 100. Mr. Takenaka has come under attack from lawmakers critical of his handling of the 2 trillion yen ($16.9 billion) bailout of Resona Bank, the country's fifth-largest lender. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: At Sea or on Safari, Satellite Phones Hook Users
description: FOR years, Arctic explorers, oil field workers, globe-trotting businessmen and war correspondents have used satellite phones to harness a telephone signal in places where utility poles were scarce. The phones, now with smaller handsets with better reception and lower prices, are gaining wider appeal.

title: Firm Found Guilty of Bribing Ex-State Official
description: A jury in federal court convicted a Boston investment firm and its lawyer today on racketeering, bribery and obstruction of justice charges that included offering money and other benefits to Connecticut's former state treasurer in exchange for a $200 million pension fund contract. The defendants were acquitted of other bribery charges.

title: An All-Star Game That Satisfies
description: The confusing ending was replaced by a captivating ending. The carefree attitude that has long existed was replaced by a more serious approach. The primary goal of making sure everyone played in the game was replaced by the new objective of actually winning the game. Overnight, a tedious exhibition was forced to became a keener competition, and the result was refreshing.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Corrections
description: Two picture captions on Tuesday with a Critic's Notebook article about photography exhibitions in London misstated the dates of the works shown. ''New York,'' by Philip-Lorca diCorcia, is from 1993, not 1983. ''Lutz & Alex Sitting in the Trees,'' by Wolfgang Tillmans, is from 1992, not 1952.

title: The Wildflower Mating Game
description: WHEN Dr. James Ault delivered a lecture in Ames, Iowa, last November, I swear I heard someone in the audience say ''gesundheit'' when he mentioned Echinacea.

title: Diving for Dinars
description: When the Iraq Museum put the treasures of Nimrud on display earlier this month, it was heralded by many as a sign -- one of the few -- that the coalition authority could restore order in Iraq. Maybe, but things are never that simple.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOFFMEISTER, , JOHN F.
description: HOFFMEISTER--John F. Age 57, of Coram, suddenly on July 16th, 2003. Twenty-five year pressman at The New York Times. Beloved husband of April (nee Climorick). Devoted father of Shean, Michael, Jennifer, and the late Derek. Cherished grandfather of Christie. Reposing at the Marinello Funeral Home, Inc, 493 Middle Country Road, Coram. Funeral Mass on Saturday, at 9:30 A.M., at St. Frances Cabrini RC Church. Interment in Holy Sepulchre Cemetery. Visitation on Thursday and Friday, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. >>AD#

title: Four Floors of Fabric on the Web
description: A comprehensive source in San Francisco for upholstery, curtain fabric, trims, tassels and other textiles is now available online and by mail order -- all at competitive prices. Britex Fabrics, established in 1952, has four floors of fabrics, accessories and notions. If you describe a project and include a $5 handling fee, you will get back fabric swatches. Helpful links on the Web site will take you to Fabric University, which covers subjects like fabric care. Another link, www.sewing.org, gives instructions for projects like window shades and bed canopies. Britex Fabrics can be reached at (415) 392-2910 or www.britexfabrics.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday reported the Coca-Cola Company's disclosure of an investigation by the United States attorney's office in Atlanta. The inquiry came after the filing of a lawsuit against the company by a former Coke executive, Matthew Whitley, who contends that Coke's fountain division engaged in a $2 billion accounting fraud, created slush funds and manipulated its inventories.

title: Senate Rejects Panel on Prewar Iraq Data
description: The Republican-led Senate defeated an effort tonight to establish a bipartisan panel to examine the use of intelligence in the prelude to the Iraq war. The vote came as Democrats pressed the Bush administration on the rationale for the war as well as on the long-term costs of military operations.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has confirmed the deaths of the following Americans in Iraq:

title: Puerto Ricans Angry That U.S. Overrode Death Penalty Ban
description: This island, it is safe to say, hates capital punishment. It has not had an execution since 1927. It outlawed the practice two years later and wrote this antipathy into its Constitution in 1952: ''The death penalty shall not exist.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Graffiti Cleanup Advances
description: In the year since a task force began work to rid the city of graffiti, more than 16.3 million square feet of surfaces have been cleaned at more than 6,241 sites, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. Mr. Bloomberg spoke in front of a building in Ridgewood where teenage workers were about to paint over graffiti. He said the citywide effort was the equivalent of wiping clean 280 football fields. Still, Mr. Bloomberg said much more work needed to be done to keep surfaces clean and he urged people to call 311, the city services hotline, to report vandalism. ''We are not declaring the city graffiti-free,'' he said. ''It is unfortunately a fact of life.'' Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Finger-Pointing Over the War
description: To the Editor:

title: Dylan's Lyrics: Something Borrowed . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GERHART, , JOHN D.
description: GERHART--John D., 59, President Emeritus of The American University in Cairo and former Ford Foundation executive. At home in NYC, July 15, of cancer. Survived by wife Gail, children Leslie and Nathaniel, brother Harry. Funeral in Austin, Texas on July 26. Memorial service September 12, 3PM, Church Center for the UN, 777 UN Plaza, NYC. Contributions to ''The American University in Cairo/Gerhart Fund''; send to The John and Gail Gerhart Public School Scholarship Fund, AUC, 420 Fifth Avenue, 3rd Floor, NY, NY 10018. >>AD#

title: New Budget Director Calls Deficit Manageable
description: In his first Congressional testimony since he became budget director last month, Joshua B. Bolten asserted today that the $455 billion budget deficit he projected on Tuesday was completely manageable and that President Bush's tax cuts were not the problem but ''part of the solution.''

title: Sharon Meets Norwegian Leader, but Shuns Oslo
description: Almost exactly 10 years after Israeli and Palestinian negotiators initialed what would become known as the Oslo agreement, opening a short-lived period of hope for peace in the Middle East, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon paid his respects to Norway today, but pointedly stayed away from Oslo, the capital.

title: Shuttle Investigator Faults NASA for Complacency Over Safety
description: NASA managers grew so complacent about safety that at times inspectors were prevented from performing spot checks, an independent investigator said yesterday.

title: Tracing a Disputed Claim
description: Here is a chronology of some important events in the claim made by the United States and Britain that Iraq had sought uranium in Africa to produce nuclear weapons.

title: Men With Geiger Counters, a Rabbit Under Siege
description: From sturdy bonsai little pine cones grow. Akaji Maro, a grandmaster of Butoh dance in Japan and director of the fabled Dairakudakan company, has taken to presenting new dances by emerging choreographers in his troupe.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: House Panel Adds Voice To Opponents Of Media Rule
description: The recent decision by federal regulators to loosen media ownership rules, already under fire in the Senate, took another blow in Congress yesterday. This setback was dealt by the House Appropriations Committee, which approved a budget amendment that would make it harder for big broadcasting companies to acquire more television stations.

title: 2 Democrats Seek Delay in Vote on Bush Nominee
description: Two Democratic members of the Senate Judiciary Committee questioned today whether a conservative nominee to a federal appeals court had given accurate information to the committee about his role in raising money for a Republican organization. They asked for a delay in a confirmation vote, scheduled for Thursday.

title: Sports of The Times; Proud Fathers Cheering Title IX
description: TWO former adversaries from the manly world of professional football ran into each other this week near Atlanta and decided to bond yesterday with a round of golf. Then John Elway, the quarterback, and Mick Luckhurst, the place-kicker, sat in a gymnasium watching their progeny extend the family names into the next generation via the opposite gender.

title: Finger-Pointing Over the War
description: To the Editor:

title: Orchestra Supports Merger Option
description: The New York Philharmonic board voted to proceed with a merger with Carnegie Hall on Tuesday after considering becoming a tenant instead, the orchestra said yesterday. The Philharmonic said roughly 85 percent of its 46 trustees favored pursuing a merger.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Profit Declined 95% For Network Associates
description: Network Associates Inc., a software maker whose accounting is being investigated, said yesterday that second-quarter profit slid 95 percent because of costs related to cutting jobs and closing an office. The shares fell as the company reduced forecasts. Net income declined to $1.11 million, or 1 cent a share, from $21.2 million, or 14 cents, a year earlier, the. Sales dropped 7 percent, to $216.6 million from $233 million. Network Associates, the maker of McAfee antivirus software, trimmed expectations for the next two quarters and the year. Sales of Sniffer, its network-management program, are falling as clients limit software spending to lift their own profits, the chief financial officer, Stephen Richards, said. Shares fell $2.40, or 16.4 percent, to $12.20.

title: Bad Bounces And Breaks Hold the Key
description: Ernie Els sounded like an astronaut, describing the hilly, brownish fairways at Royal St. George's.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: I.B.M. Meets Expectations But Is Cautious on Future

title: G.E. Proposes A Way to Ease Finnish Deal
description: In a bid to secure European regulatory approval of its $2.3 billion acquisition of the Finnish medical devices maker Instrumentarium, the General Electric Company has offered to sell Spacelabs, a recently acquired unit of the Finnish company, people close to the review said today.

title: Europe Seeks Firm Limits On Health Claims for Food
description: In a bid to get consumers to eat healthier foods, the European Commission today proposed strict regulations that would make it harder for companies to make health and nutritional claims for their products, especially for foods high in sugar, salt or fat.

title: Academy Cadet Chief Backs Rape Report Disclosures
description: Brig. Gen. Johnny A. Weida, the recently appointed commandant of cadets at the Air Force Academy, says he strongly supports a new policy making it mandatory for a commanding officer to be informed if a cadet seeks help on campus for a sexual assault.

title: South African Takes Lead in British Open
description: SANDWICH, England, July 17  Almost on cue, the British Open began, and the wind began to howl.

title: I.B.M. Meets Expectations for Quarter
description: I.B.M., the world's largest computer maker, met Wall Street's earnings expectations for the second quarter, continuing its steady performance of the last several quarters. But company executives did not project confidence that a resurgence in technology spending had begun.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   O'DONNELL, , JOSEPH P.
description: O'DONNELL--Joseph P. 7/17/2000 Rest in peace. JPS >>AD#

title: Several Wrinkles In New Schedule
description: A regular-season game outdoors, increased divisional play and a change in home colors highlight the National Hockey League's schedule for 2003-4, which was released yesterday.

title: Coming Soon To a Hand Near You
description: REMEMBER the first Walkman? It has been almost a quarter-century since Sony's portable cassette player changed the way people listen to music on the go. Now another form of entertainment is getting the Walkman treatment. Palm-size portable video players are beginning to change where and how people watch movies, cartoons and music videos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARANTZ, , DR. JOAN LAKIN
description: MARANTZ--Dr. Joan Lakin. On July 14th, 2003. Beloved wife of Dr. Robert Marantz. Cherished mother of Lisa Sloane and Garret Lakin. Devoted grandmother of Eliza, Will and Rhiannon Sloane. An accomplished psychotherapist, author, and a leader in Imago Relationship Therapy. Services will be held at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University on July 17th, 2003 at 2PM. Donations may be sent to Green Meadow Waldorf School, 307 Hungry Hollow Rd, Chestnut Ridge, NY 10977, Attention: Tony Cirone. On check memo write, ''Sloane Education Fund''. >>AD#

title: G.I. Killed and 6 Are Wounded in Stepped-Up Attacks
description: A flurry of attacks on the anniversary of Saddam Hussein's seizure of power in 1979 killed one American soldier and wounded at least six others around Baghdad today.

title: Ford Reports 27% Drop In 2nd-Quarter Earnings
description: The Ford Motor Company's earnings fell nearly 27 percent in the second quarter, and the company said today that it expected profits to be flat for the second half of the year.

title: Microsoft Upbeat on Prospects as Sales Rise a Strong 11%
description: Microsoft reported a solid gain of 11 percent in its quarterly revenues this afternoon, surpassing Wall Street's estimates. But the big software maker's profits slightly trailed analysts' expectations, as marketing expenses rose sharply to keep Microsoft's sales rising briskly despite lingering weakness in technology spending by corporate customers.

title: Publisher at GQ Magazine Resigns
description: Ron Galotti, the publisher of Conde Nast Publications' GQ magazine, resigned this morning and will be leaving the magazine immediately. In an announcement, the company said that Peter King Hunsigner, president of the Conde Nast Bridal Group, was named to replace him.

title: Montgomerie Chasing Elusive Major Title
description: Before the British Open started, at least, Colin Montgomerie was in a good mood. Montgomerie, who celebrated his 40th birthday last month, has yet to celebrate a victory at a major championship. If the prospect of ending his career without winning a major title haunts him, he refuses to admit it.

title: Samsung Profit Falls on Lower Chip Prices
description: The Samsung Electronics Company reported today that second-quarter profit had declined 41 percent from the period a year earlier. But the company also forecast improvement in the second half of the year, citing a recovering world economy.

title: Blair's Address to a Joint Session of Congress
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 - Following is the text of Prime Minister Tony Blair's address to a joint session of Congress as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Journalist Beaten, Official Says
description: A Canadian photojournalist, Zahra Kazemi, died of a brain hemorrhage caused by a beating while in custody, Vice President Muhammad Ali Abtahi told reporters. Ms. Kazemi, 54, who also held an Iranian passport, was arrested on June 23 while taking pictures of antigovernment protests outside a prison in Tehran where many dissidents are jailed. The Iranian authorities initially said Ms. Kazemi became ill while she was being questioned and was transferred to a hospital. She died on July 11. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: QUARTERLY EARNINGS RISE FOR COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises, the world's largest soft-drink bottler, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings increased 21 percent. Shares in the company, however, had their biggest decline in 18 months because higher prices and cool weather hurt sales in North America. The number of products sold was unchanged in the United States and Canada, which account for three-quarters of its sales, said the company, which is based in Atlanta. Analysts had forecast a gain of about 2 percent. Coca-Cola Enterprises lowered its forecast for sales volume growth to 1 percent this year from 3 percent in January. Some consumers have switched to cheaper PepsiCo soft drinks after Coca-Cola Enterprises raised prices by 2.5 percent amid a weak economy and wet, cool weather that has hurt demand in the Northeast. Net income rose to $260 million, or 56 cents a share, after the payment of preferred dividends, from $215 million, or 47 cents, in the year-earlier period. Sales rose 9 percent, to $4.6 billion. Shares fell $1.60, to $18.

title: Technology Briefing: Software

The shares fell as the company reduced forecasts. Net income declined to $1.11 million, or 1 cent a share, from $21.2 million, or 14 cents, a year earlier, the. Sales dropped 7 percent, to $216.6 million from $233 million. Network Associates, the maker of McAfee antivirus software, trimmed expectations for the next two quarters and the year. description: A former investment adviser pleaded guilty yesterday to embezzling $3.3 million from her clients, the United States attorney's office said yesterday. The adviser, Alexis Arlett, 44, admitted stealing for five years and evading $922,000 in federal income taxes, according to an assistant United States attorney, Scott S. Christie. Ms. Arlett used the money to buy jewelry, art and clothing. Ms. Arlett, the owner of Arlett and Associates Incorporated, in Montgomery Township, N.J., admitted to routinely submitting false broker-dealer claims, prosecutors said. Ms. Arlett will be sentenced Oct. 21 and faces up to 10 years in prison and $350,000 in fines. Her lawyer did not immediately return a call seeking comment. John Holl (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: STATE AVOIDS CREDIT DOWNGRADE A Wall Street bond-rating agency maintained its assessment of New Jersey government bonds, praising the government's addition of revenue and restraint of spending, but warning of increased pension payments and borrowing costs. Such ratings are closely watched by investors and influence how much New Jersey must pay in interest on its bonds. The rating agency, Standard & Poor's, said Tuesday that it was maintaining its AA rating. A $24 billion budget was passed by the Legislature and signed by the governor late last month. The budget "adds additional permanent revenues to the base and controls spending for the second consecutive year, making strides toward structural balance," said Richard J. Marino, an analyst for Standard & Poor's.

title: INSURERS ARE NOT LIABLE FOR SETTLEMENT, JUDGE SAYS
description: Insurers will not have to cover $70 million of a settlement between Credit Suisse First Boston and federal regulators, according to a New York State judge. The $70 million payment was part of a $100 million settlement resolving charges by regulators that First Boston had coerced participants in initial public offerings to share with First Boston a portion of their gains from immediately selling the shares. The $70 million represented a repayment of money improperly obtained by First Boston; the other $30 million was a civil penalty. In a decision handed down late Wednesday, the judge, Karla Moskowitz, wrote that three insurance companies, the Vigilant Insurance Company, a subsidiary of Chubb; the Continental Casualty Company; and Travelers Casualty and Surety Company of America, would not have to cover the $70 million and First Boston would have to pay that amount on its own. A spokeswoman for First Boston said that the company was reviewing its options and that it has 30 days to appeal.
