A past president of the Buttonwood Club and a founding member of the Yale School of Management, Robert Silver is survived by his beloved wife of 47 years, Sandra Kadin Silver and his two children Susan deMenil and John Silver. In addition he was the loving father-in-law and grandfather to Francois deMenil, Heather Silver, John deMenil, Sophie deMenil, Conrad deMenil, Henry Silver and Stella Silver. Services Tuesday, July 22, 9:30AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65 St. Friends may call on Monday, July 21 from 4-7PM at the Silver's home. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made to Lenox Hill Hospital, Department of Pulmonary Medicine.

title: City Ties Unemployment Services to Needs of Businesses
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is overhauling a city program aimed at helping the unemployed improve their chances of getting a new job. City officials said it was an attempt to improve a neglected city service in which millions of federal dollars have sat idle or have drained away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GELFAND, , FLORENCE
description: GELFAND -- Florence. The LeFrak family deeply mourns the passing of a dear friend with whom we have shared a long and affectionate relationship. Florence will be remembered as a source of strength, wisdom, humor and integrity. Our most profound condolences are extended to her entire family. She will be greatly missed but never forgotten.

title: New Warning Was Put Off On Weapons Syria Plans
description: The Central Intelligence Agency and other agencies blocked a Bush administration plan to deliver sharp new warnings this week about Syria's efforts to develop unconventional weapons, according to United States government officials.

title: Corrections
description: A map last Friday with the 36 Hours column, about Cape May, N.J., misstated the name of a restaurant. It is Tisha's Fine Dining, not Tricia's.

title: A Grand Finale of Group Show Fireworks
description: BACK in the day, most New York galleries coasted from Memorial Day to June 30 with a hastily flung-up group show, usually of gallery artists, sometimes lightly coated with a summery theme, and afterward closed until Labor Day. More recently, season's end has drifted ineluctably toward mid-August. Yes, there's a brief lull in mid-June while everyone troops off to Europe for the big shows and the Basel Art Fair. But then, bam, they're ba-a-a-ck! And the air is alive with the sound of gauntlets being thrown to the ground. Those gauntlets are your summer group shows.

title: Passing It Along
description: Here's another sentence in George Bush's State of the Union address that wasn't true: ''We will not deny, we will not ignore, we will not pass along our problems to other Congresses, to other presidents and other generations.''

title: For This Wedding Party, Political Ties Are Set Aside
description: Consider the wedding of former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his beloved, Judith Nathan. The details, down to the sparkle of Ms. Nathan's diamond and sapphire engagement ring, captured the attention of New York society.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Natural Gas Bidding
description: Mexico's government-owned oil monopoly, Petrleos Mexicanos, has opened bidding for contracts to drill for natural gas in the northern Burgos Basin. The government hopes to double output from Burgos by 2006, an increase of 1 billion cubic feet a day, to meet Mexico's need for natural gas, which is growing at about 9 percent a year. Burgos produces about 25 percent of Mexico's natural gas. The 10- to 20-year multiple service contracts will be awarded for seven geographical blocks in October and November.

title: Leaders Let Spaniard Take Stage
description: The sky was baby blue, a brisk wind made it seem less hot than it was, the road was lined with acre after acre of sunflowers, everybody had enjoyed a day off and an important time trial lay ahead -- why not another stage of Tour de France-lite?

title: Ideas for Making Medicare Better (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Can Democracy Take Root in the Islamic World?; Why Religion Must Play a Role in Iran
description: The student movement that has consumed Iran this summer has been interpreted by many senior American officials as a signal for the Bush administration to begin its next phase in democratizing the Middle East. But while the waves of protests and arrests -- the latest came last week outside a Tehran university -- may indicate the inevitable collapse of the Islamic Republic, what student leaders are calling for in Iran does not correspond with the administration's designs for the region.

title: WYETH WILL MOVE SOME OF ITS MANUFACTURING PLANTS
description: Wyeth plans to eliminate 330 jobs in Rouses Point, N.Y., as the company moves the manufacturing of some medicines to Virginia and Puerto Rico. The cuts will be made over 27 months, starting at the end of the year with 66 positions, a Wyeth spokeswoman, Natalie DeVane, said. Wyeth, based in Madison, N.J., is trying to lower costs as it struggles with lower demand for the Premarin and Prempro hormone treatments, once top sellers, that have been linked to breast cancer and heart disease.

title: New Court Fees Are Challenged . . . in Court
description: New court fees took effect Monday for all civil cases in the state and county courts across New York, and already those fees are being challenged in court.

title: Five Solo Shows
description: Art Resources Transfer

title: Jersey Central to Reimburse Power Failure Losses
description: Executives for Jersey Central Power and Light agreed yesterday to reimburse merchants and residents of shore communities for losses attributed to power failures over the Fourth of July weekend.

title: Daniel Libeskind's Tower
description: One central question in the future of Lower Manhattan was answered this week when Daniel Libeskind, the architect of the winning master plan for ground zero, and David Childs, a consulting partner of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, agreed to work together on the design of the 1,776-foot tower at the heart of Mr. Libeskind's plan. Mr. Childs's immediate client is Larry Silverstein, the developer who held the lease on the World Trade Center when it was destroyed and who clearly intends that whatever replaces it will be commercially practical. Still, the ultimate client for Mr. Childs, like Mr. Libeskind, is the public.

title: Casting New Spell Over Russian Tale
description: During a symphonic interlude before the final scene of Rimsky-Korsakov's enchanted opera ''The Legend of the Invisible City of Kitezh and the Maiden Fevronia,'' the central character, young Fevronia, a forest-dweller who has lived in harmony with the animals and devised powerful herbal remedies for sickness and ills, is being led to the invisible city by two prophet birds. There, one of these magical creatures promises her, Fevronia will find everlasting life among other joyful departed souls, including the dashing prince who was to marry her but fell in battle to a marauding band of Tartar-Mongols.

title: Judge Orders Change in Plan to Distribute Klamath River Water
description: A federal judge here has ruled that a Bush administration plan for distributing water from the Klamath River, where 33,000 salmon died last year in one of the country's biggest fish kills, must be revised because it is based on a biological opinion that violates the Endangered Species Act.

title: Tiny Treasures Leave Big Void In Looted Iraq
description: While there is still confusion about just how many objects were stolen from the Iraq Museum in Baghdad during the recent war, there is no doubt that one of its major collections is gone. In London last week, at an annual meeting of experts in archaeology, history and ancient languages of Mesopotamia, the museum's director, Dr. Nawala al-Mutawalli, said that 4,795 cylinder seals were missing. Col. Matthew Bogdanos of the Marines, leader of the American team investigating losses of antiquities in Iraq, confirmed the theft.

description: Directed by Samira Makhmalbaf, Claude Lelouch, Youssef Chahine, Danis Tanovic,

title: Drawn to a 1980's Camper With the Soul of an S.U.V.
description: BOUNDING and bouncing through the dusty backcountry of the Hollister Hills in central California, Ron Lussier demonstrated a rugged bravado that would do the steeliest off-roader proud. ''You know,'' he said, ''roads like this are really the only valid reason for owning a Humvee. They're completely silly in cities or even driving down the freeway. But get back here in one, and you can have some serious fun.''

title: Snapshots From the Hub of Domestic Dysfunction
description: You've definitely leafed through this photo album before: the one with the pictures of the handsome, hopeful suburban family that fragments before your eyes, its members' expressions growing more sour with every turn of the page.

title: Blair's Words: 'Our Job Is to Be There With You'
description: Following are excerpts from a speech yesterday by Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to a joint meeting of Congress, as recorded by Federal News Service, Inc. A full transcript is available online at nytimes.com/international.

title: Matsui Is Only Relief the Yankees Need
description: Hideki Matsui bowed his head, puffed his cheeks and closed his eyes. Maybe his 332 home runs in Japan were blurring together. Asked if he remembered the last time he hit a ''Sayonara Home Run,'' Matsui could not. ''Maybe three years ago,'' Matsui finally said, through an interpreter.

title: BOEING SAYS IT WILL CUT ABOUT 4,000 MORE JOBS
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it would cut an additional 4,000 to 5,000 workers before the end of the year because of continued weakness in its commercial aircraft division, based in the Seattle area. The workers will be cut through layoffs and attrition, the company said. Those cuts are in addition to 5,000 workers that the company had already been planning to cut from its commercial aviation arm, a move that was announced in November. Before this year, Boeing had already laid off 30,000 workers because of the slump in business after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. Boeing also said it would issue its next round of 60-day notices to 660 workers today.

title: Rollovers Led the Rise in Traffic Deaths Last Year
description: Federal traffic statistics released today showed that rollovers were the leading contributor to the increase in the numbers of deaths on the nation's roads last year.

title: S.E.C. Inquiry Into Amex's Procedures On Options
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun a formal investigation of the American Stock Exchange concerning the way it has regulated its options trading floor, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Via Madison Ave., a Secular Synagogue
description: Funny, it doesn't look like 63003 77th Street.

title: Deals Are Probably Done, Duquette Tells Mets
description: Jim Duquette, the Mets' interim general manager, joined the team here this afternoon after his two latest deals to clean up the Mets' last-place mess. He came bearing hope and a message: the Mets are probably done with any significant moves for the remainder of the season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REID, , REV. JAMES H., S.J.
description: REID--Rev. James H., S.J. Beloved brother of Vincent, devoted uncle of James and Thomas. Reposing at The Jesuit Community Chapel, at Murray/Weigel Hall, 515 E Fordham Road. Visitation Friday, 3-5, 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial, Murray/Weigel Hall Chapel, Saturday, 11:30 AM. For information contact Farenga Bros, Inc. >>AD#

title: Watching a Queen Make an Exit
description: There are hundreds of free shows in Manhattan: buildings going up or coming down; policemen running with their hands on their holsters; taxicab races seen from the 35th floor; young women walking in SoHo on the first warm day of spring. My favorite, after the young women, takes place on the far West Side, next to a pier, more than a dozen times a year. It's been going on for decades, but this is the last full season, because early next year, the Queen Elizabeth 2 will leave New York for good.

title: Riffs on 9/11 and City Life And Lots of Liza Minnellis
description: Here's a news flash to shake the foundations of Capitol Hill: Karen Finley is entertaining the troops.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Recall Of Millions Of Slow Cookers
description: Nearly three million slow cookers are being recalled because of broken handles that pose a burn risk on thousands of them, according to the maker, Hamilton Beach and Proctor-Silex, of Glen Allen, Va., and the Consumer Product Safety Commission. The slow cookers were sold from January 1999 to December 2002. Consumers can contact the manufacturer for replacement parts at (800) 429-6363 or at www.proctor-silex.com.

title: King of Music (and of All He Surveyed)
description: Politically speaking, contemporary Africa is a disaster area, simultaneously pulling itself together and tearing itself apart as it tries to deal with the pernicious long-term effects of colonialism. Culturally, it is one of the most vivacious and progressive places on earth, generating art, music, films and literature of matchless inventiveness and passion.

title: Ford Says New S.U.V.'s Less Fuel-Efficient Than Old Ones
description: DEARBORN, Mich., July 18  The Ford Motor Company's sport utility vehicles will be less fuel-efficient in the 2003 model year than the previous year, the company said in a new report.

title: Harsh Style Runs Course And GQ Publisher Is Ousted
description: Ron Galotti, the publisher of GQ magazine who made a much-publicized return to Cond Nast Publications after the demise of Talk magazine 18 months ago, abruptly resigned yesterday morning. The company named Peter King Hunsinger, the president of the Cond Nast Bridal Group, to succeed him.

title: Mayor Details Plan to Revise City Elections
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg wants to offer New York City voters the option in November to eliminate party labels from future municipal elections. But he says that if voters decide to make the change, it should not take place until the 2009 elections, after his campaign for a second term.

description: Daniel Reich

title: 5,200 Designs Submitted for 9/11 Memorial
description: The competition to design the World Trade Center memorial to the victims of the Sept. 11 attack has attracted 5,200 entries, organizers said yesterday, making it by far the largest open design competition of its kind.

title: Shopping List | Picnics
description: SUMMER days are here again, so take your meals out-of-doors. These highly portable picnic-gear items will make it easy to spend a lazy afternoon in the great wide open, without having to sacrifice comfort. BONNIE TSUI

title: ESTE LAUDER SETTLES A LAWSUIT FILED BY CONSUMERS
description: The Este Lauder Companies said it had settled a class-action lawsuit under an industrywide agreement with cosmetics consumers and recorded fourth-quarter costs for the case. The $13.5 million expense, 6 cents a share, covered some free products the company will give to consumers and legal costs for the plaintiffs, Este Lauder said in a filing. The company did not admit any wrongdoing and settled the lawsuit ''solely to avoid protracted and costly litigation,'' the filing stated. Este Lauder was among major cosmetics manufacturers and retailers sued in 1998 by some consumers who suspected price fixing, a spokeswoman, Sally Susman, said.

title: Democrats Wait for Ferrer To Decide on Mayoral Bid
description: From the list of people who filed campaign fund-raising reports this week expressing interest in running for governor, attorney general, New York City mayor or City Council member, one name was absent: Fernando Ferrer.

title: Can Democracy Take Root in the Islamic World?; Empty Promises Of Freedom
description: With President Bush vowing to bring democracy to Iraq and the Middle East, Arab governments have begun professing a new commitment to encouraging democracy. Kings, emirs and dictators alike suddenly appear to have discovered the value of human rights and civil society and are trumpeting initiatives to promote them.

title: Profits at Coke Climb 11% And Beat Analysts' Estimate
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its second-quarter profits increased 11 percent, largely on the strength of strong sales of its noncarbonated drinks like bottled water and Powerade.

title: Profit Falls 28% at Nokia; Slower Sales Are Forecast
description: Nokia, the world's largest mobile phone manufacturer, reported a drop in second-quarter profits today and said that revenue could fall further in the third quarter.

title: Shutting Doors in Syria May Not End Militants' Attacks
description: The cast-iron gate that guards the offices of Hamas, the militant Palestinian group that has operated for years in an apartment building here, is locked tight, in apparent compliance with a longstanding American demand.

title: Coke to Seek Ideas for Sprite's Ads
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it had asked agencies to present creative ideas for advertising its Sprite brand, which has been handled since 2001 by Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York. Billings on the account were estimated at $45 million.

title: Wolfowitz on Visit to Iraq To Assess Rebuilding Effort
description: Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz arrived here today for a five-day tour of Iraq to assess the Bush administration's successes and shortcomings in the postwar reconstruction effort.

title: Russia Says It Won't Seek Origins of Elite's Wealth
description: Prime Minister Mikhail M. Kasyanov sought to calm anxiety in his country's business community today by publicly stating that Russia would not review the origins of the fortunes made in its much-questioned privatization program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAGER, , ELLIOT M.
description: MAGER--Elliot M., 68, on July 16, 2003, at home in Newton, MA. Beloved husband for 45 years of Susan (Israel) Mager; son of the late Isidor and Minnie Mager; loving brother of Stanley Mager and wife Mynda; wonderful father of Anne Mager and husband Bayard King, Deborah Mager Rickner and husband Mark, Daniel Mager and wife Amy, and David Mager and wife Nancy. He enjoyed his six beautiful grandchildren, Hannah, Julia, Eli, Sophie, Jacob and Theodore. Elliot was a graduate of Columbia University '56 and Columbia Engineering '57, and was an executive in the oil industry. Services at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ, 1 pm, Friday, July 18, 2003, reception to follow at the Hilton Woodbridge. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in his memory to the charity of your choice. >>AD#

title: Democrats Question Fund-Raising by Judicial Nominee
description: William H. Pryor, the Alabama attorney general nominated to an appeals court judgeship by President Bush, has been opposed for several weeks by Democrats who say his opposition to legalized abortion and his calls for greater Christian influence in the law and government make him unfit for the bench.

title: Cars Clad in Plastic: The Look Lives On
description: CLADDING has peaked -- or has it? Automotive designers have been changing the look of new cars, re-emphasizing a sleek, unadorned silhouette. That seems like bad news for makers of cladding -- the plastic add-ons often attached to the fronts, sides and backs of cars and trucks, usually with the effect of making them look bulkier. But thanks to body kits available at the neighborhood auto parts store, car owners don't have to go along with manufacturers' style changes. And brisk sales of the kits, especially to young owners in search of a racecar look, suggest that many of them don't intend to.

title: Tens of Thousands Will Lose College Aid, Report Says
description: The first report to document the impact of the government's new formula for financial aid has found that it will reduce the nation's largest grant program by $270 million and bar 84,000 college students from receiving any award at all.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: PeopleSoft Set to Wrap Up J.D. Edwards Acquisition
description: Four days after receiving legal clearance from federal regulators, PeopleSoft Inc. said today that it expected to complete its acquisition of software maker J.D. Edwards for $1.8 billion in cash and stock by midnight tonight.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Jobless Rate Steady
description: New York City continued to lose jobs in June, but the overall jobless rate remained steady, according to monthly figures released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor. There were job declines in industries like securities and film production but gains in construction. The city unemployment rate remained at 8.1 percent. For the first time since February 1991, the state rate, 6.1 percent, was lower than the national rate, which is 6.4 percent. William C. Thompson, the New York City comptroller, estimated the number of jobs lost in the city in June, after seasonal adjustment, at 9,000. Stephen Kagann, chief economist to Gov. George E. Pataki, said signs of renewed activity on Wall Street offered hope for the city. The city has lost about 242,000 jobs since the number peaked in December 2000. Janny Scott (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Gay Student Settles Suit
description: A lawsuit brought by the A.C.L.U. on behalf of a gay junior high student was settled when the Pulaski County Special School District agreed to pay his family $25,000 in legal fees and to clear his disciplinary record. The student, Thomas McLaughlin, 14, said teachers at his school in suburban Little Rock had punished him for discussing his sexual orientation and compelled him to listen to biblical admonitions against homosexuality. The district said it would forbid personnel to proselytize or to punish students on the basis of sexual orientation.

description: SANDWICH, England, July 18  Like a strong swimmer in dangerous seas, Davis Love III kept treading water, while all others around him were sinking.

title: S.E.C. IS INVESTIGATING BAXTER'S PROFIT FORECASTS
description: Baxter International, a maker of blood-disease treatments, said federal regulators were seeking information on a series of reductions in its revenue and profit forecasts. Baxter is struggling with lower prices for some products and has cut its 2003 sales estimates three times in nine months. Baxter said that the Securities and Exchange Commission told the company that its request ''should not be construed as an indication by the commission or its staff that any violations of law have occurred.'' The company also reported second-quarter results and said severance costs and write-downs caused net income at the company to drop 76 percent to $49 million, or 8 cents a share, from $204 million, or 33 cents, a year earlier. Revenue climbed 11 percent to $2.16 billion from $1.95 billion.

description: RICHARDSON--Charles Tiffany of Glen Cove, formerly of Lattingtown, LI and Greenwich, CT on July 11, 2003 age 86. Class of 1935 Saint Paul's School, Concord, NH, class of 1939 Harvard graduate, Phi Beta Kappa, WWII Captain US Navy. Former partner of Auerbach, Pollack and Richardson in Panama. Beloved father of Schuyler and Amado Santos. Grandfather of Charles T. Edmonds and Amado K. Santos. Service at Dodge - Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, New York Saturday July 19th at 12Noon. description: District Attorney Mark D. Hurlbert said today that he would announce on Friday whether Kobe Bryant would be charged with sexually assaulting a 19-year-old woman.

description: This town is lonesome, neon-lighted, tough. They say there are 20 bars in Gallup, 30 churches, 30 pawnshops and 60 trading posts.

description: Three Democratic presidential candidates who were chastised by the N.A.A.C.P. for skipping the group's political forum in Miami on Monday upended their schedules today to fly south and make elaborate apologies. Earlier this week, all the candidates were summoned to a forum before gay leaders, where they were pressed to endorse gay marriage.

description: When a Navy helicopter crashed on Wednesday in Sicily, killing four crew members, it was the second time such an accident left Albert Bianchi, of Maplewood, N.J., in grief.

title: Consistency Pays Off as Kim Leads Big Apple Classic
description: Everything worked well today in the opening round of the Sybase Big Apple Classic for Mi Hyun Kim, the 26-year-old South Korean. She drove the ball with accuracy, was precise with her approach shots and putted well to shoot a five-under-par 66.

title: Carol Shields Dies at 68; Wrote 'The Stone Diaries'
description: Carol Shields, the Pulitzer Prize-winning Canadian novelist who captured and illuminated the ordinariness of life -- ''domesticity, the shaggy beast that eats up 50 percent of our lives,'' as she put it -- died on Wednesday in Victoria, British Columbia. She was 68.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Robbery Suspect Shot By Police
description: A 43-year-old man was wounded last night after attempting to rob a fast food restaurant in the Bronx, according to the police. The police received a report of a robbery at the McDonald's at 1625 Webster Avenue in the Bathgate section about 8:30 p.m. When officers arrived, the man was trying to flee by overpowering a motorist, investigators said. One shot was fired, the police said, hitting the man in the right thigh. He was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, where he was reported in stable condition. The identities of the man and the police officers involved were not available early today. Carla Baranauckas (NYT)

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: AIRPORT FINDS GUN IN TEDDY BEAR Airport security workers found a loaded .22-caliber handgun stuffed inside a brown teddy bear that a 10-year-old boy was carrying on a trip home after his family's Florida vacation, the authorities said. A Transportation Security Administration worker noticed the outline of a gun on Saturday when the bear passed through an X-ray machine at Orlando International Airport. The boy's family said the bear was a gift from a girl at their hotel. "She appeared at their hotel room door and offered them the bear," said Robert Johnson, an agency spokesman.   (AP)

title: Audiotape Purports to Carry Hussein's Recent Voice
description: An audiotape with a voice purporting to be that of Saddam Hussein was broadcast on Al Arabiya satellite television station today, a holiday under Mr. Hussein's rule commemorating the 1968 coup that brought his Baath Party to power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GERHART, , JOHN
description: GERHART--John. The Board of the Friends of the David Anderson Africa Trust were deeply saddened to learn of his passing. John's knowledge of Africa and his wise counsel will be greatly missed by his colleagues and friends at the Trust, as will his wonderful sense of humor and his indomitable spirit. Our heartfelt condolences to Gail, Leslie, and Nathaniel. Allan Lenzner, President Susan B. Fisher, Vice President >>AD#

title: Allegheny Energy Faces Cash Shortage
description: Allegheny Energy Inc., which sells electricity and natural gas service in five states, said in a regulatory filing yesterday that it might be edging closer toward a bankruptcy filing that could disrupt service and increase utility bills for about three million people.

title: Recession Is Over; Jobs Aren't Trickling Down
description: The recession that began in March 2001 ended eight months later, the National Bureau of Economic Research, an independent group that tracks the business cycle, concluded in a report released yesterday.

title: Mayor Pushes to Bar Parties From Ballot
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg wants to offer New York City voters the option in November to eliminate party labels from future municipal elections. But he says that if voters decide to make the change, it should not take place until the 2009 elections, after his re-election campaign.

title: Outcry Over Regents Physics Test, But Officials in Albany Won't Budge
description: Leonard Morochnick was so upset after 43 percent of his physics students at the New York City Lab School for Collaborative Studies failed the Regents physics exam last month that he sat down at his computer and banged out a lengthy analysis of the test, which on one question required students to ''calculate the de Broglie wavelength of a helium nucleus.''

title: New York's Bid Remains Viable
description: Jim Easton, one of the three American members of the International Olympic Committee, said yesterday that the awarding of the 2010 Winter Olympics to Vancouver, British Columbia, theoretically should not hurt New York's bid for the 2012 Olympics.

title: Shots fired across DMZ by 2 Koreas
description: SEOUL:  North and South Korean troops exchanged machine-gun fire inside the demilitarized zone on Thursday, raising tension as diplomatic efforts to persuade North Korea to engage in talks on its nuclear weapons program intensified. No casualties were reported in the incident, which was the first exchange of fire across the zone since 2001.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Better Rating Sought
description: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority said that it had hired HSBC and Goldman Sachs for advice on how to improve its credit ratings. With a large budget deficit amplified by the costs of the SARS outbreak, Hong Kong is quickly going through fiscal reserves accumulated from budget surpluses in the 1990's, and it may have to start issuing foreign-currency debt. Standard & Poor's has assigned a rating of AA- to Hong Kong's local-currency sovereign debt, which is mainly used in interbank operations. It assigned a rating of A+ for the autonomous Chinese territory's foreign-currency debt, even though such debt is not being issued. S.& P. also has a negative outlook for Hong Kong's local-currency debt and a stable outlook for foreign-currency debt. The hiring of the investment banks was first reported earlier this week by Apple Daily, a local newspaper, and confirmed on Wednesday by the monetary authority. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Subway Fare: Bottom Line On Jump to $2
description: ONCE prices go up, they don't come down. That was the opinion heard around town this week after a state appeals court gave its blessing to the higher mass-transit fares and tolls in effect since May.

title: Fischer differentiates Berlin from Paris : Germany rejects a U.S. rivalry
description: PARIS:  Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer of Germany, the leading candidate to become the European Union's first foreign minister under its new constitution, has told Bush administration officials in Washington that the Europe of the future can be strong only "together with the United States, and not as its rival."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Dismissal Of Schoolteacher Affirmed
description: A city schoolteacher who was also a member of the North American Man-Boy Love Association, or Nambla, was justifiably dismissed, despite a claim of an abridgment of his First Amendment rights, a federal appeals court panel ruled. In a decision made public yesterday, the panel ruled that Peter Melzer, a teacher at the Bronx High School of Science for more than 30 years, was justifiably dismissed by the Board of Education in 2000. Parents threatened to withdraw their children from school after Mr. Melzer's membership in Nambla -- which advocates sexual relations between men and adolescents -- was reported by a local television station, WNBC. The panel said Mr. Melzer's right to free association was constitutionally protected but the disruption of his membership was ''great enough to warrant the school's action.'' Mr. Melzer's lawyer, Eugene Nathanson, called the decision ''dangerous'' to government employees. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BEER, , MORTON D.
description: BEER--Morton D. Dad, One year has passed and we miss you more each and every day. Mindy and the kids >>AD#

description: Directed by Danny Provenzano

title: Bending to Protests, Hong Kong Leader Will Revisit Security Bill
description: Retreating further in response to street protests, Hong Kong's leader announced this evening that he would begin another round of public consultation over controversial internal-security legislation, but stopped short of saying he would accept changes to it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBERTS, , LUCILLE
description: ROBERTS--Lucille on July 17, 2003. Beloved wife of Bob. Devoted mother of Kevin and Kirk, and mother-in-law of Samantha. Loving sister of Harry Spindel. Services Friday, 10 AM at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St, NYC. For information ''The Riverside'' 212-362-6600 >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCHUGH, , JOAN
description: McHUGH--Joan. The Board and Staff of Aging in America and Morningside House Nursing Home extend their condolences to the family of Joan McHugh and her colleagues at Loeb and Troper. Her untimely and tragic passing has made our world poorer, yet we are stronger for having known her. It is our prayer that Joan will be at Peace and that God will hold her in the palm of His hand. Richard Zeitoun Vice President/Administrator William T. Smith, Ph.D President/Chief Executive Officer >>AD#

title: Justifying a War After Blood Is Shed (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bumbling British Spy, Both Shaken and Stirred
description: Rowan Atkinson, the gangly, rubber-faced British comedian who is the star and raison d'tre of ''Johnny English,'' has collected a devoted American following for his two television personas, the history-hopping scoundrel Blackadder and the hapless, spastic Mr. Bean. Blackadder, with his fluent stream of self-flattering nonsense, emphasizes Mr. Atkinson's skills as a verbal comedian; the silent Bean, in contrast, is a creature of pure slapstick, compounded out of twitches, grimaces, flailing limbs and unfortunate brushes with the laws of physics.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about troubles in the satellite business misidentified one of the banks that are financing Intelsat's purchase of six satellites from Loral Space and Communications. Along with Morgan Stanley and BNP Paribas, they include Citigroup, not J. P. Morgan Chase.

title: Coke to Seek Ideas For Sprite's Ads
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it had asked agencies to present creative ideas for advertising its Sprite brand, which has been handled since 2001 by Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York. Billings on the account were estimated at $45 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Township Mayor Accused Of Obstruction
description: The mayor of New Hanover Township has been charged with tampering with a witness in a federal investigation into the activities of the mayor and others. Patrick Malloy, 69, the mayor of the township in Burlington County since 1968, appeared before a federal magistrate here and is expected to enter a plea later. Prosecutors, citing a secretly recorded conversation, accused Mr. Malloy of trying to persuade a witness to lie to a federal grand jury. The jurors are investigating whether an $11,500 contract to build a sidewalk was illegally directed to a relative of the mayor. If convicted, Mr. Malloy would face up to 10 years in prison. Last month, a former township official, James Nash, pleaded guilty to a charge that he and Mr. Malloy agreed in 1999 to steer the contract to his relative.

title: A Band With Big Dreams And Home-Brewed Drugs
description: After ''The Crow'' and ''Dark City,'' two movies in which even the lightest moments seemed to take place under a full moon partly obscured by a cloud bank, the director Alex Proyas returns to the world of geek cinema with the spry and wiry punk comedy ''Garage Days.'' This sweet, delectable rock 'n' roll comedy from Australia follows the bumpy adventures of an aspiring band led by the ambitious, spiky-haired Freddy (Kick Gurry).

title: New Details Emerge On Uranium Claim And Bush's Speech
description: More details came to light today about how disputed language about Iraq's possible designs on African uranium appeared in President Bush's State of the Union address. The words in the January address were the subject of testimony before a Senate Committee on Wednesday.

title: Microsoft Exceeds Forecast for Sales, But Not for Profit
description: Microsoft yesterday reported an 11 percent gain in revenue for the quarter ended June 30, surpassing Wall Street's expectations.

title: Watson Misses Caddie
description: Tom Watson misses his ailing caddie and friend, but he has brought a strong golf game to the British Open.

title: Police Encircle Rio Shantytowns As Gang Warfare Leaves 9 Dead
description: Scores of police officers from across Rio de Janeiro were surrounding shantytowns on the city's northern outskirts last night in an effort to contain brutal gang warfare that has left at least nine dead in two days of battles involving the police and rival drug gangs.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Another Trip For 'David'

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: BATTLING LEGALESE The nation's largest court system has agreed to alter the way it words its instructions to civil juries, replacing legalisms with plain English. For example, jurors have long been given the instruction: "Failure of recollection is common. Innocent misrecollection is not uncommon." That will read: "People often forget things or make mistakes in what they remember." The Judicial Council of California approved the changes on Wednesday following a task force's six-year review.    (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RABKIN, , JACOB
description: RABKIN--Jacob. LexisNexis Matthew Bender mourns the death of one of its most distinguished and longstanding authors, Jacob Rabkin, on July 1, 2003. Together with his co-author Mark H. Johnson, Mr. Rabkin wrote three major legal publications for Matthew Bender, including Rabkin and Johnson, ''Current Legal Forms with Tax Analysis.'' Mr. Rabkin's passing is a great loss to Matthew Bender, LexisNexis, and the entire legal community. We extend our sincere condolences to Mrs. Dorothy Rabkin and her family. >>AD#

title: Safety and Jobs Are Top Issues For Iraq, Pentagon Advisers Say
description: A Pentagon advisory panel reported today that efforts to secure an allied victory in Iraq might fail unless public safety is extended throughout the nation within three months.

title: No Time to Lose on North Korea
description: If North Korea is not bluffing, it may have already produced enough plutonium to be within striking distance of building six new nuclear bombs. Short of a war no one wants, the only way to prevent that development is through a diplomatic agreement. That is why China's urgent efforts to revive the three-way talks that have been suspended since April are crucially important. The Bush administration should embrace Beijing's welcome intercession and be ready to explore a comprehensive deal that would end North Korea's nuclear ambitions in exchange for international aid and security guarantees.

title: Quick Escapes
description: Philo, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, , DOROTHY C.
description: MILLER--Dorothy C. The family of Dorothy C. Miller wishes to express heartfelt thanks to the many friends and colleagues of Dorothy who have sent messages of love and sympathy. In lieu of flowers, tax deductible contributions may be made in her memory to the New York Public Library, an institution she cherished, at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street, Room 73, New York, New York 10018-2788. >>AD#

title: Help, but Not Enough, for Girl Who Was Discarded Twice
description: It was only a week ago that the tiny body of Stephanie Ramos was found in a plastic bag in a garbage truck in the Bronx, discarded by a foster mother who told the police that she panicked when the severely disabled girl died.

title: Pimples Are the Least of This Girl's Worries
description: In the voice-over at the beginning of ''How to Deal,'' Halley, the 16-year-old heroine (Mandy Moore), complains about the frustrations of childhood: having to wear silly hats, not knowing what's in school cafeteria meatballs -- that kind of thing. Before long, these banal concerns will give way to much bigger ones for Halley and the people around her. These include, not quite in order: a divorce, a premature death, an unplanned pregnancy, a tumultuous engagement (of Halley's big sister, cutely played by Mary Catherine Garrison), a car accident, a bad New Year's Eve party, a first kiss and an undeserved grounding.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Market Place column in Business Day on Wednesday, about the second-quarter results of Intel, which cited strong sales of the Centrino chip for wireless notebook computers, referred incorrectly to the computer shown. The computer, an Apple iBook, does not use the Centrino chip for wireless access.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the increasing amount of money sent home by Hispanic immigrants to their families referred incorrectly to offices of the Delgado Travel Agency, a business that makes transfers to Latin America. They are in several states, but not in Connecticut.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Hong Kong government's resistance to street protests calling for a more democratic system referred incorrectly to Tony Blair, who is to visit the territory on July 22 to 24. As prime minister, he is Britain's head of government; the head of state is the queen.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Tobacco Acquisition
description: British American Tobacco's credit rating was put on watch for a downgrade by Standard & Poor's after it agreed to buy a rival, Ente Tabacchi Italiani. The company's long-term debt rating of A- is on watch for a cut, said S.& P., which plans to make a decision on a possible cut within three weeks. British American, the maker of Pall Mall and Lucky Strike cigarettes, agreed on Wednesday to buy Eti for 2.32 billion euros ($2.6 billion) from the Italian government. The purchase will make British American the No. 2 cigarette seller in Italy, Europe's second-largest tobacco market. (Bloomberg News)

title: Abbas to Meet With Sharon On Sunday
description: The Israeli and Palestinian prime ministers will meet on Sunday to start a week of focused Middle East diplomacy, the Israeli foreign minister, Silvan Shalom, said in an interview here today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDMAN, , ROSE ALION
description: GOLDMAN--Rose Alion. Beloved wife of Morris. Loving mother of Shirley (Roy) Schnackenberg and Barbara Goldman Pine. Dear grandmother of Lawrence Lee (Barbara), Mark Philip (Fran) and Lisa Warshauer. Fond great-grandmother of Matthew, Jamie, Ella and Eli Warshauer. Services Friday, 1:30 PM at The Piser Chapel, 5206 N. Broadway, Chicago. Interment Waldheim Cemetery, Gate #

title: Union Votes Would Allow Verizon Strike
description: The two main unions of Verizon Communications announced today that more than 75,000 workers had voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike if no contract is reached by Aug. 2.

title: South Africa Panel Reverses Its Ruling On 'Hate Speech'
description: The South African Human Rights Commission ruled today that a slogan chanted at the funeral of an antiapartheid leader last year, ''Kill the Boer, kill the farmer,'' is hate speech and is not constitutionally protected.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: I.B.M. CORP., Armonk, N.Y., said it acquired Presence Online, a closely held Australian company whose programs make it easier for customers to update Web sites. Terms were not disclosed.

description: ARMANDO BENITEZ made his first public appearance as a Yankee yesterday, an uneventful news conference, in Yankee pinstripes, a Yankee cap and a new role as the setup man for Mariano Rivera.

title: 'American Pie' Is Warmed Up
description: As DVD editions of a film multiply, so do permutations and tie-ins. For example, on July 29 Universal is to reissue ''American Pie'' and ''American Pie 2.'' With each disc, priced at $26.98 apiece, will come a free DVD called ''Beneath the Crust,'' with new behind-the-scenes material about each movie.

title: AOL Time Warner Expected to Announce 2 More Sales to Cut Debt
description: AOL Time Warner, seeking to reduce its debt, is expected to announce two sales of businesses within the next week.

title: Can Democracy Take Root in the Islamic World?; Seeing Iraq's Future By Looking at Its Past
description: Faisal I, who became the first king of Iraq in 1921, was a man of wisdom and foresight. He achieved what few, if any, leaders of the Muslim and Arab world of the last century could have done: he brought together all of his country's disparate communities in a spirit of genuine friendship and reconciliation despite the constraints of the largest hegemonic power of that time, Britain.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: National Division Wins All-Star Game
description: Greg Cattrano, a former East Setauket High School star who now plays for the Baltimore Bayhawks, was the winning goaltender for the third consecutive year in the Major League Lacrosse All-Star Game as the National Division defeated the American, 27-12, last night at Mitchel Field in Uniondale, N.Y.

As prime minister, he is Britain's head of government; the head of state is the queen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMON, , FRANK KIND
description: SIMON--Frank Kind, 80, of Lake Worth FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY on July 14. He is survived by his wife Faye, daughter Amy (Howard), and son David (Judy) and grandchildren, Matthew, Katherine, Molly and Henry. >>AD#

title: 36 Hours | Beverly Hills, Calif.
description: IF the thought of a visit to the Los Angeles area conjures up images of overpacked theme parks, hackneyed studio tours and traffic, leave the city for Beverly Hills. Slip on your sunglasses -- in this land of make-believe, rose-tinted lenses are most popular -- and wiggle into your low-riders. Put on your walking shoes, too. Surprisingly, much of what's fun in Beverly Hills can be done on foot. You may notice that summer in Beverly Hills does not involve heat, humidity or mosquitoes. It is dry; daytime temperatures are usually in the mid-70's. Stroll along the tree-lined streets, stargazing and enjoying the views of the Hollywood hills. Splurge at a shop or a spa. Try an expensive restaurant, but don't have your mouth full when Halle Berry slides into the banquette nearby. ANN COLIN HERBST

title: From Cuba, Music Sweeter Than Azcar
description: Celia Cruz and Compay Segundo, who died this week at the ages of 77 and 95, respectively, each transformed a love of their native Cuba and its traditional music into forces that helped to shape Latin salsa.

title: Glory Days: A Dad at Boy Scout Camp
description: THE beds are mildewed cots on wooden platforms in ancient green canvas tents. The food is a culinary whodunit prepared by 13-year-old boys whose idea of haute cuisine is having four chicken patties with their spaghetti instead of three. There are no television, no Internet, no movies, no cellphones.

title: 'The Next' Is Ready For 'Here and Now'
description: Last month the five members of Idlewild, a rock band from Scotland, were in Fargo, N.D. The official reason for their visit was to open for Pearl Jam at an indoor football stadium called the Fargo Dome, but they had another agenda also. As the 25-year-old singer Roddy Woomble put it, the band was hoping to find ''normal people.''

title: A Hero In Politics And Pop
description: ''Black President,'' at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo, explores the life of Fela Anikulapo-Kuti, Afrobeat musician and political agitator. In works like the 1978 album cover ''Sorrow, Tears and Blood,'' right, by Ghariokwu Lemi, more than 30 artists share their visions of Fela.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Drought's Effects Linger
description: Rains brought some relief to drought-stricken Eastern Europe but the dry spell has upset shipping on rivers and devastated wheat crops. In Romania, the Danube remained at its lowest point for the month of July since 1953, causing several river barges to run aground. In Hungary, officials said 20 percent of the country's wheat crop had been lost to drought. In Slovenia, the Parliament extended its session to discuss how to compensate affected farmers. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CASELLA, , FRANK
description: CASELLA--Frank. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Frank Casella, associated with The Times from November 10, 1976 until retiring on September 30, 2001. >>AD#

title: BUSH AT HIS SIDE, BLAIR IS RESOLUTE IN WAR'S DEFENSE
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain stood shoulder to shoulder with President Bush today in defending the war to depose Saddam Hussein, saying the conflict was justified even if allied forces find no banned weapons in Iraq.

title: Gene Is Linked to Susceptibility to Depression
description: Scientists have identified a gene that may help explain why some people become depressed in response to the stresses of life and others skate by relatively unscathed.

title: Nonpartisan Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: New Florida Communities, in Indiana
description: THE Indiana coastline -- yes, there is such a thing -- is a precious commodity, just 40 miles skirting the extreme southeast edge of Lake Michigan, much of it thick with industrial sites, steel mills and a nuclear power plant, along with long stretches of towering sand dunes.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: MEXICO: NATURAL GAS BIDDING Mexico's government-owned oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, has opened bidding for contracts to drill for natural gas in the northern Burgos Basin. The government hopes to double output from Burgos by 2006, an increase of 1 billion cubic feet a day, to meet Mexico's need for natural gas, which is growing at about 9 percent a year. Burgos produces about 25 percent of Mexico's natural gas. The 10- to 20-year multiple service contracts will be awarded for seven geographical blocks in October and November.

title: People
description: * Lance Smith was named to the new post of president and chief operating officer at Cossette Post, New York, part of the Cossette Communication Group. He had most recently been president at the New York headquarters office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, which was closed by its parent, the Publicis Groupe. Also at Cossette, three employees were named managing partners: Frank Sampagna, chairman; Steve Crane, creative director; and Richard Lefkowitz, director for media services.

title: Despite a Shortfall, Board In Yonkers Rejects Layoffs
description: Rejecting a plan for hundreds of layoffs, the Yonkers Board of Education decided Wednesday night to enter the coming school year fully staffed, despite a $20 million shortfall.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: When the Pen Takes Over

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: DAGESTAN BLAST KILLS 3 A bomb exploded near a police station in the Dagestan region, in the Caucasus, killing at least three people, including a pregnant woman and a child, officials said. The bomb, which also injured 38 people, was attached to a motorcycle or scooter parked near the police station in Khasavyurt, the Interior Ministry said. Dagestan's interior minister, Adilgirei Magomed-Tagirov, said he believed that the attack was carried out by militant Muslims in Dagestan and neighboring Chechnya. But officials also left open the possibility that the bombing was the result of a personnel vendetta. Dagestan, a mostly Muslim region, is plagued by violence partly related to the fighting in Chechnya. (AP)

title: Mob Turns Out As Mrs. Gotti Talks of Art And 'Rosie O'
description: So the stand-up guy's widow sounded like a stand-up comic. Listen to her one-word answer yesterday to the question about what she likes to paint.

title: That's No Museum, That's My Home
description: JONATHAN FEIST is expecting 52 houseguests next week. Although they will not actually be spending the night -- in fact, they are scheduled to come in three 20-minute shifts -- they will be giving his 11-room house a thorough going-over, checking the floorboards, noting the peg rails, marveling at the built-in cupboards.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Restaurants like A.O.C. Bedford have defined Greenwich Village for generations. It's a tiny place with heavy beams and a few tables and chairs. In warm weather the floor-to-ceiling windows open onto the sidewalk. The dining room staff consists of a manager, a waitress and a busboy.

title: Senate Approves $369 Billion Pentagon Measure
description: After two days of acrimony over White House handling of intelligence and the costs of the war with Iraq, the Senate tonight overwhelmingly passed a $369 billion Pentagon spending measure that continues the Bush administration's buildup and modernization of the military.

title: Expect the Unexpected if the Wind Keeps Blowing
description: Almost on cue, the British Open began and the wind began to howl.

title: Amid the Luxury, Immigrants in Peril
description: With ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire,'' the writer Steven Knight conjured up a television show with a rugged punch of a title. It encouraged the worst in contestants, daring them to keep their wits about them while competing in a Dutch-oven environment for the possibility of walking home with up to seven figures in newly disposable income.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Executive Buys Stake In Metromedia Fiber
description: Metromedia Fiber Network Inc. said yesterday that the telecommunications executive, Craig McCaw, bought some of the data network operator's debt and would own a significant stake in the company when it comes out of bankruptcy. Metromedia Fiber, which is controlled by the billionaire John Kluge, said Fiber L.L.C., the company run by Mr. McCaw, bought suppliers' claims against the company and agreed to back half of a $50 million stock offering. Mr. Kluge will back the remaining $25 million, Metromedia Fiber said. Metromedia Fiber, a provider of high-speed data links for AOL Time Warner and other Internet companies, filed for bankruptcy protection in May 2002 after amassing more than $5.35 billion in debt. It plans to change its name to AboveNet Inc. and will ask Judge Adlai Hardin of United States Bankruptcy Court in New York next month to approve a plan that gives creditors control of the company, according to court papers.

title: Knicks Still Looking to Get Van Horn
description: The Knicks continued discussions with the Philadelphia 76ers today, and might be closing in on a deal to obtain Keith Van Horn.

title: Yanks Welcome Benitez and Keep Past in the Past
description: Mariano Rivera was the winning pitcher June 22 at Shea Stadium, when Armando Benitez walked four Yankees in the ninth inning to blow a save for the Mets. Rivera had always thought of Benitez as an aggressive pitcher, and his failure was puzzling.

title: U.S. Considers Private Iraqi Force to Guard Sites
description: The Pentagon is considering a plan to train a private Iraqi security force and make it responsible for guarding pipelines, government buildings and hundreds of other sites in Iraq, military officials said today.

title: Bush Reconsiders Sending British Suspects to Tribunals
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 - After being pressed by Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, President Bush said today that his administration was reconsidering whether to bring any British citizens captured in the Afghanistan war before American military tribunals.

title: How Hot Is Hot? In Phoenix, There Are Lots of Answers
description: PHOENIX, July 18  When the sun shines all year long, as it does here, a heat wave is a heat wave only if things get really toasted.

title: Journey to a Strange Land That Seems Like Home
description: STOLEN FIGS

title: Cool Clubs, Hot Stars: Is This Atlantic City?
description: LAST season on ''Sex and the City,'' Carrie, Miranda, Charlotte and Samantha donned their best Balenciaga, Versace and Gucci, and hopped on a private jet to get away down south -- to Atlantic City, that is. They oohed and aahed and gushed over the scene as if it were the Cannes Film Festival. At the time, most New Yorkers, a discerning bunch, would probably have wondered just who in their right mind would have gone to Atlantic City, that faded beach town best known for the increasingly irrelevant Miss America pageant and the busloads of slot-machine-playing retirees who roll into town each day.

title: Allure of Europe Is Drawing Students
description: When Newton Campos returned home to Brazil in March with a new job, to recruit M.B.A. applicants for his alma mater, the Spanish business school Instituto de Empresa, his bosses were not expecting him to enroll any students in his first year.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article yesterday about the potential of the deficit to become a campaign issue for Democrats misidentified the participant in a House Budget Committee hearing who challenged members to sign a document in favor of repealing the tax cuts passed under President Bush. He was Representative Jim Nussle, Republican of Iowa and the committee's chairman, not Joshua B. Bolten, the White House budget director.

description: Theater

title: Sports of The Times; Tiger's Loss: One Ball, Two Strokes
description: THE lost golf ball is the bane of the duffer. As if the price were not costly enough -- the top-of-the-line ball goes for $50 a dozen -- the stroke-and-distance penalty hurts even more on the scorecard. Or in the bet.

title: White House E-Mail System Becomes Less User-Friendly
description: Do you want to send an e-mail message to the White House?

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway TV's To Double As PC Monitors
description: Gateway Inc., a personal computer maker that has had losses in 9 of the last 10 quarters, introduced a line of televisions that can serve as computer monitors as the company expands sales beyond PC's. Gateway is selling a 17-inch LCD television for $799 and an 18-inch model for $899. The TV's, which weigh about 15 pounds each, can fit into small spots in a kitchen or dormitory room or hang from a wall, the company said. Gateway is adding 50 products this year as it tries to rely less on PC's, where it has lost sales and market share. Gateway is applying to televisions the direct-sales methods that it learned from selling computers. Its shares fell 25 cents, to $3.74.

title: G.M.'s Net Income Declined 30% in Second Quarter
description: General Motors reported a 30 percent decline in second-quarter net income today, in large part because of falling vehicle sales in North America coupled with a price war that continues to escalate.

title: Editors' Note; On Stage and Off
description: The On Stage and Off column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: SECOND-QUARTER PROFIT AT SEARS ROSE 35%
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings climbed 35 percent as it spent less to prop up the credit card business being sold to Citigroup. The retailer cut its annual profit forecast amid sagging sales. Net income rose to $309 million, or $1.04 a share, from $229 million, or 71 cents a share, a year earlier, when Sears had costs for a change in how it accounts for uncollectible accounts. Revenue rose less than 1 percent to $10.2 billion, Sears said. Profit at the retail division fell 39 percent, as Sears cut prices to attract shoppers. Income from the finance unit more than tripled. Sears lowered its profit outlook for the year to a $4.80 to $5 a share from a forecast for up to $5.15 a share.

title: Franco Picks Up Right Where Benitez Left Off
description: John Franco reserved comment this afternoon on how his role might change now that Armando Benitez had been traded to the Yankees. Until he spoke to Manager Art Howe, Franco refused to stake a claim to the job of closer that Benitez took from him four years ago.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When I fly the kite, I think I'm on a different planet. I imagine myself someplace else.''

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: CONGO: A POWER-SHARING GOVERNMENT Congo's main rebel leaders were sworn in as vice presidents in a new power-sharing government, intended to end the country's civil war. The new government, led by President Joseph Kabila, left, brings together the rebels, Mr. Kabila's supporters and the unarmed opposition in an effort to reunite the country. The new government has until Aug. 4 to draft a plan for elections within about a year. The two rebel leaders  Jean-Pierre Bemba and Azarias Ruberwa  were sworn in with Abdoulaye Yerodia Nbombasi, who is allied to Mr. Kabila, and Arthur Z'Ahidi Ngoma, a member of the unarmed political opposition. Rival tribal militias continued to clash in northeastern Congo; more than 80 people have been killed in fighting this week. (AP)

title: National Briefing | Washington: August Decision Seen In Moussaoui Case
description: The judge in the case of Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person facing trial in the United States in the Sept. 11 attacks, made it clear that she would not decide whether to dismiss the case or impose other sanctions on the Justice Department for at least next month. The judge, Leonie M. Brinkema of Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., said she would delay her decision until prosecutors and defense lawyers had offered their views on what sanctions she should impose for the government's refusal to grant Mr. Moussaoui the chance to interview a captured member of Al Qaeda. Philip Shenon (NYT)

title: Isles Bring Czerkawski Back To Punch Up Their Scoring
description: The Islanders traded right wing Mariusz Czerkawski to Montreal 13 months ago because he made too much money and paid too little attention to defense. He hardly played for the Canadiens, then was banished to the American Hockey League.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: DISMISSAL OF SCHOOLTEACHER AFFIRMED A city schoolteacher who was also a member of the North American Man-Boy Love Association, or Nambla, was justifiably dismissed, despite a claim of an abridgment of his First Amendment rights, a federal appeals court panel ruled. In a decision made public yesterday, the panel ruled that Peter Melzer, a teacher at the Bronx High School of Science for more than 30 years, was justifiably dismissed by the Board of Education in 2000. Parents threatened to withdraw their children from school after Mr. Melzer's membership in Nambla — which advocates sexual relations between men and adolescents — was reported by a local television station, WNBC. The panel said Mr. Melzer's right to free association was constitutionally protected but the disruption of his membership was "great enough to warrant the school's action." Mr. Melzer's lawyer, Eugene Nathanson, called the decision "dangerous" to government employees.   Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Vehicle Output Increased
description: Bucking a gloomy trend in Brazil's auto industry, the Ford Motor Company has increased production at its plant in the state of Bahia to meet rising demand across Latin America for its new sport utility vehicle, the EcoSport. The factory at Camacari, which builds the vehicle for Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Ecuador and Mexico, increased output more than 18 percent in June. Tony Smith (NYT)

description: Now Playing'

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mine Strike Set
description: South Africa's largest mining union, the National Union of Mineworkers, said yesterday that more than 160,000 gold and coal workers would strike beginning July 27. Talks between the union and the South African Chamber of Mines broke down over pay, retirement benefits and job grading. This would be the first strike by South African mineworkers in 16 years. One gold company, AngloGold, and three coal companies, Xstrata, Kangra and AfriOre, have made new proposals through the Chamber of Mines and are exempted from the strike call while the union considers their offers. Nicole Itano (NYT)

description: Having missed the last world archery championships two years ago because of travel restrictions after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Amber Dawson and her teammates competing in the compound-bow division made up for lost time yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: In Torn Liberian Town, Hospital Itself Is a Fatality
description: Since the 1930's, the people of this prosperous border town had come to a stately stone hospital built by American missionaries to deliver their babies, have their eyes examined, and to be treated for everything from malaria to appendicitis to snakebites.

title: China Pushes North Korea And U.S. Talks
description: China stepped up its efforts to broker negotiations between the United States and North Korea today, dispatching a senior diplomat to Washington and urging both sides to revive a discarded 1994 accord on ending North Korea's nuclear program.

title: Profit Worries Force Shares Down for Third Straight Day
description: Stocks fell for a third day yesterday as I.B.M. said that companies were delaying software purchases and Nokia repeated a forecast for a slide in network equipment sales this year.

description: LONDON, July 18  The body of a man believed to be the arms expert at the center of a high-profile dispute over the validity of government weapons intelligence was found today near his home in Oxfordshire.

She was in the family car on her way to a children's arts festival in Philadelphia, when, she said, the utopian vision of a communist society in the Soviet Union leapt off the pages and inspired her to be a revolutionary.

description: The Queen Elizabeth 2 next visits New York on Tuesday. It sails at 4:45 p.m. from piers at the Passenger Ship Terminal that run from West 48th Street to West 52nd Street on 12th Avenue in Manhattan. There is a parking lot on top of the piers, which can be reached by taking the C or E train to 50th Street and Eighth Avenue and walking west. The liner passes the Chelsea Piers at 23rd Street 15 minutes to a half hour after sailing, Battery Park City 15 minutes after that and Shore Parkway in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, about 30 minutes after passing the tip of Manhattan. title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDONESIA: TROOPS BATTLE ACEH REBELS Indonesian troops waging war on separatist rebels in Aceh Province have killed at least 25 guerrillas in two of the bloodiest days of their offensive, the military said. According to military figures, 481 rebels have been killed since the start of the offensive on May 19. The authorities say that 992 rebels have been captured or surrendered and that 43 military and police officers have been killed. The Committee to Protect Journalists, based in New York, said the Indonesian government had prevented local and foreign reporters from investigating the situation in Aceh. (Agence France-Presse)

title: McGreevey Backs Rutgers on Pro-Palestine Seminar
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey declined yesterday to step in to prevent a student group from holding a pro-Palestine conference at Rutgers University in October, even though some Jewish leaders and others say the group promotes anti-Semitic views.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Former Budget Director Named To State Job
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday that he had named a former city budget director to oversee the administration of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. He said he had named the former budget director, Adam L. Barsky, 40, as deputy secretary for public authorities, finance and housing. Mr. Barsky, a financial consultant, was the city's budget director from 2000 to 2002 and first deputy and acting commissioner of the City Department of Finance from 1995 to 1998. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Iraqi Cleric Demands Replacement of Governing Council
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 18  A leading Iraqi cleric who has a wide following among poor and young Shiites called today for Iraqis to reject the country's newly formed Governing Council and replace it with a council that in his view would better represent the interests of Iraqis.

title: DRUG MAKER GALEN HOLDINGS SAYS IT IS IN TALKS ON A BID
description: Galen Holdings, Northern Ireland's biggest drug maker, said yesterday that it was in preliminary talks with a potential buyer it would not identify. A potential bid may exceed 1.16 billion ($1.85 billion), Galen's market valuation on Wednesday. A Galen spokesman, David Kelly, declined to comment on the talks. Galen has sold off its less-profitable units and spent almost $800 million to add to its line of women's health products, which includes pills for hormone therapy and birth control. Analysts have speculated that Barr Laboratories, Johnson & Johnson and Schering might show an interest in Galen.

title: Elisabeth Welch, 99, Cabaret Hitmaker
description: Elisabeth Welch, an expatriate cabaret singer who mixed elegant phrasing and emotive power to craft extraordinary interpretations of the songs of America's Jazz Age and Britain's musical stage, died on Tuesday at a nursing home outside London. She was 99.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in World Business on Wednesday about the quarterly earnings of Royal Philips Electronics paraphrased incorrectly from a quotation by Oscar Poos, an Amsterdam analyst who commented on the results. He said the company's net profit -- not its operating profit -- was ''nothing to get too excited about''; Philips reported an operating loss for the quarter.

title: A Director's Wooziness Finds Kurosawa's Softer Side
description: Because the director Kei Kumai's loving minor-key enchantment, ''The Sea Is Watching,'' has such a genteel, forlorn wooziness (the picture is about the restorative power of love) it's hard to believe that it was adapted from a script by Akira Kurosawa.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on May 11 about an airline crash in Congo referred incorrectly to the historic ranking of another disaster, the sinking of an overloaded ferry in heavy seas off Senegal last fall, which killed more than 1,800 people. It was among the worst maritime disasters in peacetime history, not over all. Civilian losses were heavier when passenger ships were fired on during World War II, and the death toll from the collision of a tanker and a Philippine ferry in 1987 has been estimated at several thousand. A reader's e-mail message last month pointed out the error; this correction was delayed for research.

title: Gathering a Flock of Quirky Grown-Ups
description: ''Site and Insight: An Assemblage of Artists,'' on view at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, has a few good things going for it: It pushes no ideological agenda. It's not based on a hit list of usual suspects. All the artists being at least 40, it's not in thrall to the cult of youth. And the show has as its curator Agnes Gund, former president of the Museum of Modern Art and a major collector and longtime supporter of the arts on many fronts; she has selected the work of 15 artists -- mainly paintings and sculptures -- whom she's followed over the years.

title: Hot Cars, Burning Rubber And Guys Good and Bad
description: Let's begin with a traffic report. This has been an unusually chaotic summer on the freeways and boulevards of South Florida and Southern California -- in the movies anyway. First there were Laurence Fishburne and Keanu Reeves somersaulting on top of a speeding semi in ''The Matrix Reloaded'' to the sound of grinding gears and complaining metal. This was followed in short order by the big chase at the end of ''Hollywood Homicide,'' the Mitsubishi mating dance in ''2 Fast 2 Furious'' and Arnold Schwarzenegger swinging from the end of a giant crane in ''Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines.''

title: A Local Star Brings Some Defense to All-Star Game
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., July 17 - For most of Greg Cattrano's Baltimore teammates, the trip to tonight's Major League Lacrosse All-Star Game at Mitchel Field consisted of planes, trains or carpools. For Cattrano, it was a drive on the Long Island Expressway.

description: TUZ--Peter. Of Seymour, CT, died Tuesday, July 15, 2003. Born August 16, 1915, he was a self-employed painting contractor, artist, and a veteran of World War II. Survived by his son Peter Tuz, a daughter Patricia Tuz Weilbaker, a brother William Chernecky, a sister Anne DeMoske, and five grandchildren. Services at the Hylwa Wakelee Memorial Funeral Home, 167 Wakelee Ave., Ansonia, CT. >>AD#

title: Minivan Magic
description: Foldaway third-row seats that disappear under the floor have become de rigueur for the newest minivans and S.U.V.'s. The new Nissan Quest is the first minivan to take this a step further by making the second row of bucket-style seats fold flat into the floor. Among other things, this disappearing act clears the entire rear of the minivan for cargo when both the second and third rows are folded flush with the floor. With both rows of seats in the lowered position, the Quest's clear floor can accommodate a 4-by-8-foot sheet of plywood.

title: F.D.A. Asks if a Genetic Test Is Sold Without Approval
description: In a move that could foreshadow a tightening of regulations on diagnostic testing, the Food and Drug Administration is questioning whether Roche began selling a novel genetic test without proper approval.

title: Gunfire Sends Liberian Civilians Fleeing to Capital
description: With United Nations officials growing increasingly frustrated over delays in sending West African soldiers to enforce a fragile cease-fire in this country, a familiar tableau of terror emerged late this afternoon: the sound of mortar fire on Monrovia's northern outskirts sent weary civilians marching swiftly toward the city, mattresses and clothes piled on their heads.

title: A $300,000 Car and a Big Mac
description: The wise-cracking host of "The Tonight Show" is also a genuine car buff. He took a spin with reporter Keith Martin in the ultra-luxurious Maybach 57.

title: Picnics
description: Summer days are here again, so take your meals out-of-doors with this highly portable picnic gear.

title: Experts Can Help Rebuild A Country
description: When the cultural anthropologist Ruth Benedict was asked to write a report on Japan in the spring of 1945 for the American Office of War Information, she was working under difficult conditions. She had never been to Japan and had no chance of going there during wartime. She did her ''field research'' among Japanese-Americans living in the United States and wrote Report 25, titled ''Japanese Behavior Patterns,'' in just three months between May and August, shortly before the United States dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima.

title: German Official Says Europe Must Be U.S. Friend, Not Rival
description: Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer of Germany, the leading candidate to become the European Union's first foreign minister under its new constitution, has said in Washington that a strong future Europe must not be developed in rivalry with the United States.

title: Chef Special Is Product Placement
description: On ''The Restaurant,'' a reality show about a celebrity chef struggling to open his own place in Manhattan, Rocco DiSpirito spends a lot more time in his car than in his kitchen.

description: SOON the 14 teenagers selected in last month's N.B.A. draft will be lectured in league seminars about temptation and traps, restraint and repercussions.

title: White House Tells How Bush Came to Talk of Iraq Uranium
description: The White House today set out its most detailed explanation yet of how disputed intelligence about Iraq's weapons program made it into President Bush's State of the Union address, contradicting a crucial element of the version of events provided by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: CONGO: TROUBLES FOR NEW GOVERNMENT Cracks appeared in a new government intended to end five years of war in Congo when ministers representing two important rebel groups  the Congolese Rally for Democracy, Goma, and the Movement for the Liberation of Congo  boycotted a swearing-in ceremony. A spokesman for one of the rebel groups said the ministers objected to taking an oath of allegiance to President Joseph Kabila, who is to stay on as head of the transitional government, which was inaugurated on Thursday. (Reuters)
