title: British Arms Expert at Center of Dispute on Iraq Data Is Found Dead, His Wife Says
description: The arms expert at the center of a dispute about whether the British government doctored its intelligence reports on Iraq's weapons programs to gain public support for going to war was found dead this morning near his home in Oxfordshire, his wife said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about the increased use of satellite phones misstated the reason small handsets cannot be used with satellites in high orbits. They do not have enough power to transmit signals to the satellites; there is no problem in receiving signals. The article also referred incorrectly to the satellites used by one service provider, Thuraya. They are in high orbits, about 22,000 miles above the earth, not in low orbits.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Drug Maker's Profit Falls
description: The Dutch pharmaceutical and chemicals company Akzo Nobel reported a second-quarter profit of 201 million euros ($225 million), 20 percent smaller than in the same period a year ago. However, its profit total topped analysts' expectations, setting off a rally in its share price. Second-quarter sales fell 6.7 percent to 3.4 billion euros. The company's results were hurt by increased generic competition in the United States to Remeron, an antidepressant. Sales of NuvaRing, a contraceptive, and Arixtra, which fights blood clots, doubled in the period. Akzo, which is based in Arnhem, reiterated its forecast of a 20 percent decline in annual net profit for 2003. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: F.D.A. Approves Predictor Of Heart Disease
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new blood test that is intended to help predict coronary heart disease. The test measures the blood concentration of an enzyme called lipoprotein-associated phospholipase A2. People with coronary heart disease have higher levels of the enzyme in their system; thus, elevated concentrations can serve as early warning signs. This is the most common form of heart disease, which causes more than 500,000 deaths annually. The test, called PLAC, is made by diaDexus of San Francisco. Jos Ramrez (NYT)

title: Talk, but Talk Tough
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell was upbeat this week about resuming direct diplomatic negotiations with North Korea. After months of wrangling, a meeting with the North Koreans and China is all but settled.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ESTE LAUDER COS., New York, maker of Clinique and Bobbi Brown cosmetics, said it had acquired the Rodan & Fields skin-care line. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Four Strokes Down, Woods Is Hardly Out
description: If Tiger Woods does not win the British Open, he will be haunted by two things -- his triple bogey on Thursday and his four-putt double bogey today.

title: Mayor Seeks Law to Increase Police Cameras At Intersections
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg called on the State Legislature yesterday to pass a law that would allow New York City to double the number of cameras the Police Department uses to detect and ticket drivers who run red lights.

title: SMITHFIELD FOODS ACQUIRES FOOD DEVELOPMENT COMPANY
description: Smithfield Foods Inc., the pork producer, said yesterday that it had acquired Global Culinary Solutions Inc., a food development company led by the chef Michael J. Brando, to develop products. Mr. Brando will become president of a new unit, Smithfield Innovations Group. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Smithfield is trying to reduce its reliance on hogs and fresh pork and focus more on prepared foods, which have higher profit margins.

title: AOL TIME WARNER TO SELL DISC UNIT TO CINRAM
description: AOL Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it would sell its compact disc and DVD manufacturing operations to Cinram International Inc. of Canada for $1.05 billion and use the cash to reduce debt. AOL Time Warner's music and home-video businesses will use Cinram to make and ship digital video discs and CD's, the companies said. Cinram, based in Toronto, makes CD's, DVD's and VHS videocassettes for movie, music and software companies. The sale is part of AOL's strategy to cut its debt, which had been as high as $29 billion, to $20 billion by the end of 2004. Cinram's stock rose 29 percent, to 22 Canadian dollars, on the Toronto Stock Exchange. AOL's stock rose 34 cents, to $16.74.

title: DYNEGY SAYS IT WILL REPORT A LOSS FOR THE 2ND QUARTER
description: Dynegy Inc., the utility owner and power producer, said yesterday that it would report a second-quarter loss and that earnings this year would be lower than expected because of higher interest costs from a planned debt refinancing. The company did not disclose the amount of the second-quarter loss. Dynegy said it planned to estimate 2003 results by mid-August, when the refinancing is completed. In late April, the company forecast profit of 10 to 18 cents a share this year, excluding energy trading and communications. Shares of Dynegy, which is based in Houston, fell 28 cents, or 7 percent, to $3.89.

title: Details on Iraqi Arms Claim
description: The White House presented a detailed account of how disputed intelligence made it into the State of the Union address, and it contradicted a C.I.A. claim in the process. Page A6.

title: Elders Beg Wolfowitz For Help
description: Inside a sweltering reed hut in this dust-choked village, Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz listened patiently today to a dozen wizened tribal elders from this area who asked him to restore a way of life that Saddam Hussein had taken away.

title: Stellar Defensive Effort Propels Semifinal Contender
description: Thousands of enthusiasts arriving here on Thursday night found two focuses of attention. One was the induction ceremonies, which brought Steve Robinson, Jacqui Mitchell and Fred Hamilton into the American Contract Bridge League's Hall of Fame, together with the late Ed Manfield. Special inductees were Henry Francis, for services to the game, and Tobias Stone, for playing achievements half a century ago. Larry Cohen received the Sidney Lazard Jr. Award for Sportsmanship.

title: Continental Divide
description: Greece had just clobbered Germany, 11-0, in the European baseball championships and Simon Ghring, the Germans' catcher, was contemplating his evening at Sportpark Ookmer.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Alstom's Sales Fall
description: The power and transportation company Alstom said sales in its most recent quarter fell 18 percent, to $4.34 billion euros, reflecting a decline in orders that were placed at the end of last year. Sales in Alstom's Power Turbo-Systems branch were down 50 percent, a sign of the company's trouble with faulty turbines. The company, which is based in Paris, also makes France's high speed TGV trains. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: The New BMW 6 Series coupe
description: The new 6 Series coupe from BMW will be unveiled in September at the Frankfurt Motor Show and will go on sale in the United States in spring 2004.

title: A Donizetti Discovery, Reinterpreted
description: During a career of less than 30 years, Donizetti composed nearly 70 operas. From that statistic, you might surmise that it was not syphilis that caused his death at 50, but sheer exhaustion.

title: Opinions on Economy Are Easy; Proof Is Tough
description: In the debate about tax cuts and federal budget deficits, both sides are making arguments that can never be proved.

title: PEREGRINE WINS APPROVAL FOR REORGANIZATION PLAN
description: Peregrine Systems Inc., a maker of business-management software, won court approval yesterday for its reorganization plan, clearing the way for the company to exit bankruptcy protection next month. Judge Judith K. Fitzgerald of United States Bankruptcy Court in Pittsburgh approved the plan. Peregrine plans to come out of bankruptcy in August with about $70 million in debt. Under the plan, holders of $270 million in Peregrine's 5 1/2 percent notes will receive 30 percent of their claims in cash and 20 percent in new notes. They also will receive about 63 percent of the reorganized company's stock. Unsecured creditors may choose to receive either immediate payment of 60 percent of their claims in cash this year plus 10 percent over four years, or full repayment over four years. Shareholders and securities claimants will receive about 33 percent of the reorganized company's stock.

title: To Break Logjam, Rowland Urges a One-Year Budget
description: After six months of closed-door negotiations, four weeks of executive orders to keep services in Connecticut running and hours of arguments over what is only a small fraction of a two-year, $13.5 billion state budget, Gov. John G. Rowland said today that the solution was obvious.

title: Wealthy Family Is Suing Lawyer Over Tax Plan
description: A wealthy real estate family that bought a high-priced insurance plan to shelter millions of dollars from gift and estate taxes is suing the prominent New York tax lawyer who devised the plan, his law firm and his associates for fraud.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Disappointing Software Profit
description: A software exporter, Wipro Ltd., reported a lower-than-expected 5 percent increase in quarterly profit as it cut prices to fend off competitors. Wipro said it earned 1.8 billion rupees ($39 million) in the period ended June 30. The company, which is based in Bangalore, said sales rose 28 percent, to 11.7 billion rupees ($253 million).

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: INDIANA: DNA EVIDENCE UNDER REVIEW The authorities are rechecking DNA evidence in 64 criminal cases from Marion County because of concerns that a laboratory technician, who resigned last August, may have cut corners at the Indianapolis-Marion County Forensic Services Agency. Any errors that are found could lead to new trials. The technician, Dr. Kuppareddi Balamurugan, is accused of failing to perform other steps to verify the tests' accuracy. No defendant in the 64 cases faces the death penalty. (AP)

title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: SURVEY ON EPILEPSY AND DRIVING A new study of drivers with epilepsy found that there was no statistical difference between the number of seizure-related accidents involving those who waited one year before driving again and those who waited three months. The study, led by researchers at the Mayo Clinic and published in the Mayo Clinic Proceedings, suggests that some states could shorten the "seizure-free interval" required of such drivers before privileges are reinstated. State waiting periods vary from 3 to 18 months. Jose Ramirez (NYT)

title: Paul Bernal, 92; Fought for Tribal Watershed
description: Paul J. Bernal, a Pueblo Indian elder who, as a liaison to the federal government, helped his people recover title to their sacred Blue Lake in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains of northern New Mexico, died on Wednesday in Taos Pueblo. He was 92.

title: Toxic Waste Sites
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Record Debt Delinquencies
description: A record 3.22 million South Koreans were delinquent in paying their credit card bills last month, according to banking industry data. The figure, which was released by the Korea Federation of Banks, showed that about 9 percent of South Koreans over age 20 were behind on paying credit card bills. The federation defines delinquency as failing to make payments on debt of 300,000 won ($250) for three consecutive months. Consumers in South Korea took on large debt last year when interest rates were low, prompting the government to tighten lending standards. In another report, the National Statistical Office said the unemployment rate rose to 3.6 percent in June, the highest level in 22 months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, , HOWARD
description: KLEIN--Howard. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Howard Klein, associated with The Times from March 1, 1949 to December 1, 1992. >>AD#

title: World Briefing | Europe: E.U. Constitution In Berlusconi's Hands
description: Italy's prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, who is the current president of the European Union, officially took over responsibility for the negotiations on the union's draft constitution. Valry Giscard d'Estaing, who led the convention that drew up the draft, presented the document to Mr. Berlusconi with the warning that too much meddling with the proposal would tear Europe apart. Mr. Berlusconi hopes to forge agreement and have the draft finalized during Italy's six-month presidency. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: 19 Arrested In Operation That Aimed At Bloods Gang
description: After a yearlong investigation, members of a police gang unit have arrested 19 members and associates of the Bloods street gang involved in drug sales, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Corporate Regulator Named
description: Graeme Samuel, a former merchant banker, was named Australia's chief corporate regulator and consumer watchdog. He was confirmed for a five-year term as chairman of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, an independent federal agency. Mr. Samuel succeeds Allan Fels, an economics professor who will return to teaching after 12 years in the position. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VICTOR, , ABE J.
description: VICTOR--Abe J. February 2, 1916-July 17, 2003. Survived by loving wife, Frieda Rose; daughter and son-in-law Carol and Barry Kobrin; grand children Daniel, Debra and Dana; sister and brother-inlaw Gertrude and Edward Brownstein and nephew Aaron Brownstein. Abe's engineering career spanned work at both Lockheed and Aerospace Corporations. Expressions of sympathy can be directed to Mrs. Frieda R. Victor, 40 Heyward St, Apt 125, Brooklyn, NY 11211

title: JUDGE ALLOWS TOP SPIEGEL EMPLOYEES TO RECEIVE BONUSES
description: Spiegel Inc., the bankrupt owner of Eddie Bauer stores, has won a judge's permission to give 225 top employees as much as $26.4 million in bonus payments, including $8.6 million for the chief executives of its main units. Eddie Bauer's chief executive, Fabian Mansson, and the chief executive of Spiegel's catalog unit, Geralynn Madonna, will also receive more than $3.1 million in severance if they are fired without cause or Spiegel is liquidated. Judge Cornelius Blackshear of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan approved the plan on Tuesday, court papers show. ''This is common practice in bankruptcy and we think it's an important step as we move forward in our reorganization,'' said Debbie Koopman, a company spokeswoman. Spiegel sought Chapter 11 protection in March.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the postponement of a vote in the House of Representatives on a bill to redesign Head Start misidentified the district of James T. Walsh, whose spokesman said he was ''leaning no.'' Mr. Walsh represents central New York State, not the Hudson River Valley.

title: BUSINESS OBJECTS AGREES TO BUY CRYSTAL DECISIONS
description: Business Objects, a maker of business software, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Crystal Decisions for about $820 million. Business Objects will issue about 26.5 million shares of common stock and pay about $300 million in cash for Crystal Decisions. Business Objects and the Canadian software maker Cognos Inc. have been vying for the top spot in the market for so-called business-intelligence software, which mines databases for information and generates reports. Crystal Decisions is based in Palo Alto, Calif., and Business Objects has dual headquarters in Paris and in San Jose, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Public Lives profile yesterday about Charlotte L. Kates, a law student at Rutgers University who is a leader of New Jersey Solidarity, a pro-Palestinian student group, gave an erroneous identification in some copies for the official who received hundreds of messages protesting the plan for a conference at Rutgers. He was Richard L. McCormick, the university president, not Gov. James E. McGreevey.

title: House Trims Bush Plan For Research On Weapons
description: In a rare break with the White House on national security policy, the House of Representatives approved a measure today that substantially reduces an administration request for money to begin research on new nuclear weapons.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the address to Congress by Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain misattributed a quotation. It was Mr. Blair, not President Bush, who said: ''To be a serious partner, Europe must take on and defeat the anti-Americanism that sometimes passes for its political discourse. And what America must do is show that this is a partnership, built on persuasion, not command.''

title: Hong Kong Protest Movement Pauses to Weigh Its Next Steps
description: The protest movement here is divided over what goals to pursue next and how, and is leaning toward not holding any more large rallies until near the end of the year unless the government takes strong actions to limit civil liberties before then, protest leaders said today.

title: More Disclosure for Drug Plans
description: The movement in Congress to add prescription drug coverage to Medicare could produce a bonanza for pharmacy benefit managers, the companies whose drug plans cover most working Americans. But the Medicare legislation also poses a powerful threat to the way many of the largest such companies do business.

title: Newest Challenge for PeopleSoft Is Integrating J.D. Edwards
description: Fending off Oracle so far may have been the easy part.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: MEXICO: DEATH AGAIN RULED A SUICIDE A special prosecutor has determined that the human rights lawyer Digna Ochoa, left, probably took her own life, the second time an official investigation has concluded her death was probably a suicide. Ms. Ochoa, 38, was found dead on Oct. 19, 2001, shot once in the left leg and again in the head. A note threatening other human rights workers was left near her body, and her friends and family have maintained that she was murdered. A former federal judge, Margarita Guerra, led the second investigation and determined that Ms. Ochoa probably shot herself and made it look like a murder, a spokesman said. (AP)

title: National Briefing: South
description: SOUTH CAROLINA: HARASSMENT AWARD RULING A female employee of a costume company in White Rock may keep $7,280 of a $400,000 jury award for sexual harassment, the full United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, Va., ruled, overturning a decision by a three-judge panel of the court. The earlier decision had held that the coarse sexual talk and behavior at the company was neither severe enough to justify the award nor directed at the plaintiff, Lisa L. Ocheltree, because of her sex. The full court disagreed and reinstated part of the award. It held that the bulk of the award, for punitive damages, was not warranted. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Choosing a Final Care Plan
description: In order that patients get the health care they want if illness prevents them from making decisions, doctors and organizations like AARP, the American Medical Association and the American Geriatrics Society recommend that people develop care plans. This means drafting legal documents specifying their preferences and telling their doctors and relatives their wishes.

title: Bush Reconsidering Tribunals for Britons
description: After being pressed by Prime Minister Tony Blair, President Bush said that his administration was reconsidering whether and under what circumstances to bring any British subjects captured in Afghanistan before American military tribunals.

title: At a Hearing on Power Failures, Crowd Gets Last Thing Expected
description: The Board of Public Utilities in New Jersey held a public hearing yesterday along with executives from a power company to discuss the hardships caused by power failures in several Ocean County shore communities over the Fourth of July weekend. But during the hearing, the power went out.

title: The City Life; The President in the Park
description: To many New Yorkers who seek relaxation in Riverside Park, the tomb of Ulysses S. Grant is a neoclassical afterthought, if they think about Grant at all. Families fleeing the stress of work and school congregate for picnics and barbecues under the park's refreshingly abundant foliage. Many were probably completely unaware that Grant and his wife are buried nearby until the singer Beyonc Knowles and a troupe of barely clad dancers used the tomb as a backdrop for a nationally televised Fourth of July special. This angered the Grant Monument Association, which tends not to the tomb but to Grant's reputation as the general who helped keep the Union together by defeating the Confederate Army. The association's president said the performance was unbecoming for a presidential monument. And so it probably was. But it at least put Grant back in the news.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm innocent. I didn't force her to do anything against her will. I'm innocent.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, , SYLVIA
description: GOLDBERG--Sylvia. Beloved wife to Nathan, sister of Faye, adored mother of Paula (Mark), Judy (Larry) and grandmother of Seth, Jonathan and Andrew. Funeral services Sunday July 20th at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, 9:15 AM. >>AD#

title: Archers Vie for Titles And Aim at Bull's-Eye
description: Think of archery and Robin Hood may come to mind, but that may be as far as it goes. The world archery championships, with the finals today and tomorrow in Central Park, offer spectators a view of a sport considerably more complex than that.

title: Extension of Stay in Iraq Takes Toll on Morale of G.I.'s
description: Specialist Eric Martin sits on his bunk staring at the floor, his face a picture of despair.

title: Liberians Grow Impatient With Waiting for Help
description: The thousands who have set up camp inside an American Embassy-owned compound here are hungry, sick, and tired of running. Today, with fresh fighting just six miles north of the city, they are also increasingly tired of waiting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAUBMAN, , SYLVIA
description: TAUBMAN--Sylvia. Beloved grandmother, mother, wife, sister and friend to all she knew, passed away at her home on Thursday, July 17. Her dedication to family, support for her friends, unflagging energy and total selflessness influenced all who were fortunate to know her. A proud sweet woman, who worked as a bookkeeper and premium buyer and was involved in charitable activities, she will be greatly missed but never forgotten. Graveside services will be held at King Solomon Memorial Park, Clifton, NJ, Sunday, July 20 at 11 AM. >>AD#

title: Bush, Blair and the Iraq Clamor
description: To the Editor:

title: Today's Pianos Have Prelude In Yesterday's; Steinway Family Legacy Pervades Factory in Queens
description: The mechanism that will make the keys on Steinway concert grand piano No. K0862 responsive to the pianist's touch was perfected by Henry Steinway Jr. in the 19th century. He is also responsible for the nearly nine-foot length of No. K0862, which is governed by the layout of the strings that will go inside -- a layout he devised.

title: Lakers' Star Bryant Is Charged With Sex Assault at Colorado Spa
description: Kobe Bryant, the basketball superstar celebrated for his athletic skills and his wholesome off-court persona, was charged today with sexually assaulting a 19-year-old woman on June 30 at the resort hotel where she worked in Edwards, Colo.

title: About New York; He Conned the Society Crowd but Died Alone
description: David Hampton's pursuit of a fabulous Manhattan life ended last month in the early-morning hush of a downtown hospital. No celebrities keened by his bedside, no theatrics unfolded in the hall; there was no last touch of the fabulous. Just the clinical cluck that follows the death of a man who dies alone at 39.

title: The Justice Dept. And the Terror Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday about a new advertising agency president and revamping of top management at Cossette Post, New York, misspelled the surname of the chairman, who was one of three executives at the firm named to the added post of managing partner. He is Frank Sampogna, not Sampagna.

title: Blair off to Seoul to help on North
description: SEOUL:  Prime Minister Tony Blair is awaited here Sunday on a tour during which he plans to add Britain's voice to calls for multilateral talks to defuse the North Korean nuclear dispute.

title: CITADEL BROADCASTING FILES FOR INITIAL STOCK OFFERING
description: The Citadel Broadcasting Company, which owns 144 FM radio stations across the nation, filed with regulators to raise as much as $418 million in an initial public offering of its stock to reduce debt. About 22 million shares will be sold for $17 to $19 each, Citadel said in a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Citadel, which is based in Las Vegas, has expanded its business since 1999 by acquiring radio stations in midsize markets.

title: Going Home, to Red Ink and Blues
description: Across the nation, state and local leaders have been forced to slash more than $100 billion in spending, laying off thousands of employees, cutting off health insurance for roughly one million people and lowering America's standard of living. Washington is not just aloof from the pain out here in real America, but is making matters worse.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Cement Maker's Sales Rise
description: The Mexican cement maker Cemex said its sales for the second quarter rose 7 percent to $1.9 billion. The company, which is based in Monterrey and has operations in more than 30 countries, said that operating income fell 3 percent to $390 million as a result of higher energy prices and sales of products with lower profit margins. However, net income tripled to $309 million because of gains in the company's foreign exchange and derivatives positions. Sales were higher in Mexico and Spain but fell in the United States, the company's leading markets. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: Patients Whose Final Wishes Go Unsaid Put Doctors in a Bind
description: ''Do you know your name?'' the doctor asked.

title: The Phenomenology of Harry, or the Critique of Pure Potter
description: You knew, of course, that Harry Potter's desire for a gold cauldron instead of a pewter one is an obvious example of commodity consumption, and that snobbish centaurs and enslaved elves are indicative of a conservative worldview in which ''social hierarchies prevail among magical people and creatures.''

title: Corrections
description: The Federal Reserve data table in Business Day on July 4, and again yesterday, mislabeled a figure for the annual growth rate in the monetary base. The rate of 4.1 percent was for the latest 12 weeks, not 4 weeks.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Boston Mayor Has Cancer
description: Mayor Thomas M. Menino of Boston has been diagnosed with a rare, treatable type of cancer and will have surgery to remove the malignant growth on Monday, doctors said. The small tissue sarcoma is slow-growing and rarely resurfaces or spreads. Mayor Menino's doctor at Brigham and Women's Hospital, where the surgery is to take place, said the mayor should be cancer-free after the one-inch lump is removed. Part of the tumor was removed in a biopsy on July 3. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: GEMSTAR LOSES RULING IN PATENT DISPUTE OVER GUIDES
description: Gemstar-TV Guide International Inc., which develops on-screen program guides for cable and satellite television, lost another court ruling yesterday in its patent dispute with makers of TV set-top boxes. Judge Willis B. Hunt of United States District Court in Atlanta ruled that Scientific-Atlanta Inc., the second-largest maker of set-top boxes, did not infringe a patent owned by Gemstar. Other patents remain in dispute, a Scientific-Atlanta spokeswoman, Peggy Ballard, said. Gemstar, also the publisher of TV Guide, has been unsuccessful so far in its battle to enforce patents for the on-screen menus that help viewers select shows. It sued Scientific-Atlanta, EchoStar Communications and other companies after they refused to sign licensing agreements. Those companies have accused Gemstar, which is based in Los Angeles, of anticompetitive behavior.

title: Police Say Man Set Himself and Girlfriend on Fire
description: A 44-year-old Korean immigrant doused his girlfriend with gasoline on a Queens sidewalk yesterday morning and set her on fire with a cigarette lighter as her 10-year-old son looked on, the police said. He then splashed more gasoline on his own clothes and embraced her in a bear hug, and they fell to the ground in flames. Both were in critical condition last night.

title: In the Dutch Dugout, It's Davey Johnson
description: Davey Johnson, known for his baseball smarts but also for his confrontations with management, says nice things about almost everybody nowadays.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Oil Stakes Bought
description: Cnooc Ltd., a Chinese oil company, bought stakes in two offshore oil fields from BP and the Kerr-McGee Corporation and wants to buy more reserves as part of China's drive to secure oil supplies. Cnooc paid BP $170 million for its stakes in a field off China's northern city of Tianjin and an area southeast of Hong Kong, Cnooc said. It paid Kerr-McGee $20 million for its stake in a field near Hong Kong.

title: House Panel Acts on Pension Calculations
description: After Democrats stalked out, a House panel approved legislation yesterday that would provide some relief for companies that offer traditional pensions.

title: S.E.C. Demands 6-Month Ban On New Ernst & Young Clients
description: Federal regulators reiterated their demand yesterday that the accounting firm Ernst & Young be banned from accepting new audit clients for six months as a penalty for violating conflict-of-interest rules in the 1990's.

title: Ford S.U.V.'s Use More Gas Than Before
description: The average fuel economy of the Ford Motor Company's sport utility vehicles will be worse for the 2003 model year than the previous year, the company said in a report issued on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, , DOROTHY C.
description: MILLER--Dorothy C. The family of Dorothy C. Miller wishes to express heartfelt thanks to the many friends and colleagues of Dorothy who have sent messages of love and sympathy. In lieu of flowers, tax deductible contributions may be made in her memory to the New York Public Library, an institution she cherished, at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street, Room 73, New York, New York 10018-2788. >>AD#

title: Longtime Armstrong Competitor Closes In
description: In a mixed performance in a long individual time trial today, a parched Lance Armstrong failed to dispel doubts about his overall strength but did retain the yellow jersey of the Tour de France's leader and even increased his lead a bit.

title: Homosexuality Issue Threatens To Break Anglicanism in Two
description: The election last month of an openly gay bishop in the Episcopal Diocese of New Hampshire is now threatening to crack open the long-existing fault line over homosexuality in the worldwide Anglican Communion, a global association of churches in 164 countries.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: University Enacts Gay Benefits
description: The University of Illinois will provide health and dental benefits to the domestic partners of its gay and lesbian employees, a policy already in place at many other universities in the state, including Northwestern. Trustees voted 6 to 2 in favor of the policy, which they said would help them attract and retain more staff members. To qualify, employees must live with their partner and share finances. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Rosalyn Tureck, Pianist Specializing in Bach, Dies at 88
description: Rosalyn Tureck, a pianist and harpsichordist who played an important part in the revival of interest in the music of Johann Sebastian Bach, and who devoted more than six decades to performing, researching, teaching and writing about his works, died on Thursday at her home in Riverdale, the Bronx. She was 88.

title: The Marketing of Political Clout
description: Senate hearings on President Bush's judicial nominees have stumbled upon another slippery rock in the fetid landscape of politicians' soliciting corporate America for big-money campaign donations. Turning the rock over, we have something called the Republican Attorneys General Association, whose ranking members in at least six states -- the people's lawyers, keep in mind -- have been personally begging for donations from corporate leaders in the very fields entrusted to the public officials. Donors from banking, insurance, liquor, computers and more have ponied up hundreds of thousands of dollars for the attorneys general's campaign fund since 1999. We are told to relax: the group is legal, and the Democrats have a parallel attorneys general group shaking the money tree for balance.

title: Writing Letters to the President, Who's Now at Easiertofind.com
description: The White House Web site began more prominently featuring the president's e-mail address yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Changes to Pension Bill Spur a Political Dispute

title: Nets Can't Have Krstic Until 2004-5
description: The Nets have learned, as expected, that they will not be able to bring Nenad Krstic, a 19-year-old center from Serbia, to the N.B.A. until the 2004-5 season.

title: South Koreans Put Stamp On the Big Apple Classic
description: South Korea has produced 18 players who are members of the L.P.G.A. Tour this year, and many of them have made their presence felt.

title: The Tribulations of Being a 'Lucky One'
description: Life can be trying for gorgeous women. Heidi Kristoffer has to wear a fake engagement ring when she goes out, she reports, just to avoid being overwhelmed by men approaching her in droves. ''Smiling seems to put a 'talk to me' sign over my head,'' she says. Sara Rae Gore misses the beauty pageant days of her extreme youth. ''Life is all about being judged,'' she says. ''At least then I knew what the criteria was.''

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Jail Visits Switching To Video
description: An electronic audio-visual system will replace face-to-face visits at the Orleans Parish jail in about two months, the sheriff's office has said. Forty cubicles, which the authorities began installing last year, will increase visiting hours for the 6,000 inmates and prevent the transfer of contraband to them, a spokeswoman for the office said. Lawyers may still meet with their clients in person. On Wednesday, a prisoner's wife smuggled a gun to him that he first used to escape, then later to kill himself. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has confirmed the death of the following American in Iraq:

title: INSIDE
description: Rosalyn Tureck Dies

title: U.S. MAY BE FORCED TO GO BACK TO U.N. FOR IRAQ MANDATE
description: The Bush administration, which spurned the United Nations in its drive to depose Saddam Hussein in Iraq, is finding itself forced back into the arms of the international body because other nations are refusing to contribute peacekeeping troops or reconstruction money without United Nations approval.

title: Bush, Blair and the Iraq Clamor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Urges Spending Ban In the Battle Of the Charter
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would refrain from spending his billions to promote the idea of nonpartisan elections if opponents of the idea would also hold their fire.

title: A Lively Immersion Course In Brazilian Sound and Soul
description: When Brazilian groups come to town, they normally play one concert without a warmup, local Brazilians immediately gobble up the tickets and North American heads are barely dented. But with the five concerts in ''Brazil: Beyond Bossa,'' part of this summer's Lincoln Center Festival, a gringo has at least a fighting chance to pick up the threads and follow them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FITZGERALD, , JACK
description: FITZGERALD--Jack, age 86, on July 16th, 2003. Preceded in death by wife Dorothy, survived by brother Thomas L. Fitzgerald, sister Ruth Fitzgerald. Served in the U.S. Army, Pacific, World War II, retired from Brooks Brothers Madison Avenue. Resided in Clearwater Beach, Florida, formerly of Brooklyn and Breezy Point, NY. Services at Moss Feaster Funeral Home, Clearwater Beach, July 20, 2003, at 3:00 PM. >>AD#

title: The Justice Dept. and the Terror Case (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Shots fired across DMZ by 2 Koreas
description: SEOUL:  North and South Korean troops exchanged machine-gun fire inside the demilitarized zone on Thursday, raising tension as diplomatic efforts to persuade North Korea to engage in talks on its nuclear weapons program intensified. No casualties were reported in the incident, which was the first exchange of fire across the zone since 2001.

title: War of Words Divides Residents of Texas Town
description: In history books, the killing of more than 300 Texan rebels by Mexican troops here has long been known as the Goliad Massacre. But to many residents of Goliad, with its 18th-century Spanish fort and towering monument to the dead, that brutal episode in its history is still open to interpretation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, , HELEN LEWIN
description: SHAPIRO--Helen Lewin, age 96, passed away peacefully July 17. Widow of Herman Shapiro. Cherished cousin of the Weinstein, Baron and Baskin families. She was an honored and esteemed teacher at Music and Art High School from its inception to her retirement. Memorial service to be announced. For further information contact Margot Baron or Stephen Weinstein. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent in her memory to the charity of your choice. >>AD#

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a formal investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into the way the American Stock Exchange has regulated its options trading floor misstated the name of a competing exchange at one point. It is the International Securities Exchange, not the International Stock Exchange.

title: Sex Arrests on a Gay Beach Provoke a Hamptons Debate
description: At Two Mile Hollow Beach, the longtime center of gay life in the Hamptons, the language of the parking lot pickup scene is very specific.

title: Seo and Mets Take Another Tumble
description: Four times during the first inning tonight, Jae Weong Seo of the Mets motioned for catcher Vance Wilson to make his way to the mound, wanting to make sure Wilson was set up on the correct side of the plate.

title: An Evening of Weird but Joyful Moments
description: A few months ago, the long-running British band Blur released one of the year's most controversial alternative rock albums. That album, ''Think Tank'' (Virgin), was the band's first without its founding guitarist, Graham Coxon, and some listeners loved the group's new direction. The disc is full of casual, melancholy songs embellished with unusual rhythms and textures. Others hated it, and wondered if it might be time for Blur to disband.

title: A World Of Buy, Buy, Buy, From A to Z
description: Cayce Packard, the heroine of William Gibson's recent novel, ''Pattern Recognition'' (Putnam), has a serious problem. Corporate symbols and logos make her ill. A glimpse of the bulbous Michelin Man is traumatic; even trademarks on the buttons of her Levis have to be sanded off.

title: Franco Says Talk of Rift Is Baseless
description: Mets reliever John Franco today denied that he tried to undermine Armando Benitez, whom the Mets traded Wednesday to the Yankees.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Casino Settles Bias Suit
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said that the Colorado Central Station Casino in Black Hawk had agreed to pay $1.5 million to settle a lawsuit accusing it of discriminating against Hispanic housekeeping employees with English-only rules. The casino, about 50 miles west of Denver, will notify all employees that it has no blanket English-only policy, which commission officials say is generally barred by law as discrimination by national origin. The company said it instituted the policy for safety reasons and because an employee who did not speak Spanish feared that other employees were talking about her. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOLOMON, , DORIS
description: SOLOMON--Doris. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Doris Solomon, beloved sister of Harry Heller. We extend our deepest condolences to Harry and his family Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President >>AD#

description: In percent
