description: To the Editor:

title: For Pornographer, 3-Letter Word Overturns Conviction
description: Al Goldstein, the blustering pornographic publisher, may be one of the most passionate defenders of free speech in the land. But he was not complaining too much yesterday after a court ruled that remarks made at his trial last year ''exceeded the bounds of propriety.''

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: NORWAY: TERRORIST CHARGES DROPPED Norway has dropped terror charges against Mullah Krekar, an Iraqi Kurdish founder of the group Ansar al-Islam, a police official said. The official, Erling Grimstad, told the national radio NRK that the inquiry had "not found grounds for the suspicion that Ansar al-Islam has been involved in terror activities in Iraq or in other places in the world, or that Mullah Krekar can be linked to such activities." Mullah Krekar, who has had refugee status in Norway since 1991, still faces charges of racism against American citizens and making public threats, his lawyer said. (Reuters)

title: Stresses of Day Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Iraqi Cleric Calls on Nation to Repudiate New Governing Council
description: A leading Iraqi cleric who has a wide following among poor and young Shiites called today for Iraqis to reject the country's newly formed Governing Council and replace it with a council that in his view better represents the interests of Iraqis.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-5

title: Benitez Hears Cheers, and His Team Wins, Too
description: Armando Benitez has walked off the Yankee Stadium mound many times, most memorably after failing. Until last night, he had always headed right, toward the visitors' dugout. Last night he made a left turn, to take a seat with his new Yankees teammates. His performance was satisfying, and the crowd told him so.

title: Mixed Grades on National Parks
description: President Bush has clearly done a better job than his predecessors in tackling the huge repair backlog in the national parks, estimated at $4.9 billion when he came to office. It is equally clear, however, that he will have to increase and accelerate new spending if he is to meet his campaign pledge of fixing the parks' deteriorating buildings, roads, bridges and even sewer systems by 2006.

title: 'I Cry Just Like Everybody Else'
description: Following is an excerpt from remarks made by Kobe Bryant at a news conference last evening:

title: From Korea, Simple Tales Elaborately Told in Song
description: If the pace of life in 21st-century New York has a polar opposite, it may lie in pansori, an ancient Korean art of storytelling. Such, at least, was the first impression supplied by ''Heungboga'' (a k a ''The Song of the Gourd''), performed at John Jay College on Wednesday evening as part of the Lincoln Center Festival.

title: Love Leads, but the Elements Are Winning
description: Like a strong swimmer in dangerous seas, Davis Love III kept treading water while all around him others sank.

title: Alberto Fujimori, Accused and Defended
description: To the Editor:

title: A Review Board In Name Only
description: Ten years ago this month, independent oversight of the New York City Police Department arrived with the creation of the Civilian Complaint Review Board. Our group, the New York Civil Liberties Union, could not have been more pleased, as we and other civil rights advocates had long fought for impartial monitoring of the nation's largest police force. We had great hope that the review board could curb police misconduct and improve police-community relations. In its first decade, however, the board has proved to be largely ineffective. It seems we all may have embraced an agency that is hopelessly flawed.

title: Ericsson Cuts Losses and Predicts Return to Profitability in '03
description: Ericsson, the world's largest maker of mobile-phone network equipment, sharply narrowed its losses in the second quarter and said today that it expected to turn a profit before the end of the year.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: IRAQI ENVOY WON'T LEAVE Iraq's ambassador to China, Mowaffaq Alani, has armed himself with pistols and locked other diplomats out of the main Iraqi Embassy building in Beijing, refusing orders to return to Baghdad, an Iraqi diplomat said. Mr. Alani was ordered on June 6 to return to Iraq as part of a general recall of ambassadors, said the diplomat, Talal H. al-Khudairi. He said Iraqi diplomats have appealed to China's Foreign Ministry to persuade Mr. Alani to leave, but a ministry spokesman, Kong Quan, said China wanted the Iraqis to handle the dispute themselves. (AP)

title: ALLIANT ENERGY SELLS HOUSING UNIT TO LOWER DEBT
description: The Alliant Energy Corporation, owner of four utilities in the Midwest, sold its housing business yesterday to several buyers and plans to reduce debt by $105 million with proceeds from the deal. Costs from the sale will be recorded in the second quarter, Alliant said. The company, which is based in Madison, Wis., has been shedding assets to improve its balance sheet and to focus on its main energy business. The properties sold are low-income apartment developments in Iowa, Minnesota and Wisconsin. The buyers were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: The Federal Reserve data table in Business Day on July 4, and again yesterday, mislabeled a figure for the annual growth rate in the monetary base. The rate of 4.1 percent was for the latest 12 weeks, not 4 weeks.

title: Bryant Now Confronts A Heavy Fall From Grace
description: Kobe Bryant worried about how people saw him, what they thought about him. He was determined to avoid becoming another cautionary tale of why teenagers should not jump straight from high school to the National Basketball Association. Instead, desiring only to be the best player in the world, he became a prodigy unscathed by emotional meltdown or any meaningful controversy.

title: Palestinians in Nablus Fed Up With Crime Posing as Jihad
description: They were not masked men battling for the Palestinian national cause, just three thugs trying to kidnap a man off the street, apparently for ransom.

title: An Exchange Says a Rival Botched Options Trading
description: The American Stock Exchange has had serious problems with the operation of a new system intended to provide customers with the best price on an options trade, a competing exchange contends.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bae In Talks For U.S. Army Contract
description: BAE Systems, the British military contractor, has been selected by the Boeing Company to negotiate a contract to build communications platforms for the United States Army's Future Combat System. The deal could bring BAE as much as $2 billion, it said. The Future Combat System, created to improve dispatching and communication of Army forces, is expected to be introduced by 2008. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article yesterday about the address to Congress by Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain misattributed a quotation. It was Mr. Blair, not President Bush, who said: "To be a serious partner, Europe must take on and defeat the anti-Americanism that sometimes passes for its political discourse. And what America must do is show that this is a partnership, built on persuasion, not command."

title: Recyclers, Take Note
description: To the Editor:

title: Bowing to Ally, Bush to Rethink Tribunals for British Subjects
description: After being pressed by Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, President Bush said today that his administration was reconsidering whether and under what circumstances to bring any British subjects captured in the Afghanistan war before American military tribunals.

title: The Founders And the Fedayeen
description: When questioned about the difficulties American forces are having in rebuilding Iraq, Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld has taken to giving a history lesson. Several times he has spoken of another country in ''chaos and confusion'' during a period characterized by ''looting, crime, mobs storming buildings, breakdown of government structures and institutions that maintained civil order, rampant inflation caused by the lack of a stable currency, supporters of the former regime roaming the streets . . .''

title: Liberty Wins Sloppy Contest Against Tired Team
description: Call it what you will: bruising, battering, certainly inelegant. Post players were elbowing and bumping and bruising each other like angry offensive and defensive tackles. There was so much contact that shots went in all directions and successful ones touched off minor celebrations.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Survey On Epilepsy And Driving
description: A new study of drivers with epilepsy found that there was no statistical difference between the number of seizure-related accidents involving those who waited one year before driving again and those who waited three months. The study, led by researchers at the Mayo Clinic and published in the Mayo Clinic Proceedings, suggests that some states could shorten the ''seizure-free interval'' required of such drivers before privileges are reinstated. State waiting periods vary from 3 to 18 months. Jos Ramrez (NYT)

title: Deputy Shoots Driver After Being Dragged
description: A narcotics officer shot and wounded a Virginia man yesterday afternoon in Englewood, N.J., after being hit and dragged by the suspect's car, federal officials said.

title: Fountain Revived for Central Park's 150th
description: It was a rare sight: plumes of water shooting 60 feet into the air yesterday from a fountain in the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Reservoir. Though the submerged fountain was built in 1917, this was only the third time it had been turned on.

title: Alberto Fujimori, Accused and Defended (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day on Thursday about the Defense Department's opposition to the acquisition of Global Crossing, the operator of telecommunications and Internet services, by Singapore Technologies Telemedia, a phone company controlled by the government of Singapore, carried an erroneous credit. It was by Bloomberg News.

title: The Allure Of an Empty Paradise
description: The subject is homicide, of an especially grisly kind. Bestial sex movies, serial decapitation, a baby eaten by a German shepherd and a body that lands splat, like a pizza, against the window of an Italian restaurant -- these elements all figure in John Guare's ''Landscape of the Body.''

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Harassment Award Ruling
description: A female employee of a costume company in White Rock may keep $7,280 of a $400,000 jury award for sexual harassment, the full United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, Va., ruled, overturning a decision by a three-judge panel of the court. The earlier decision had held that the coarse sexual talk and behavior at the company was neither severe enough to justify the award nor directed at the plaintiff, Lisa L. Ocheltree, because of her sex. The full court disagreed and reinstated part of the award. It held that the bulk of the award, for punitive damages, was not warranted. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Insurance Rules Eased
description: The upper house of Parliament approved a bill that permits Japan's life insurers to cut the guaranteed yields they pay policyholders if they are on the verge of bankruptcy. The bill had already been approved by the lower house and takes effect next month. With a sluggish stock market and interest rates near record lows, insurers are struggling to generate enough investment income to meet their obligations. According to the new law, an insurer can reduce its promised yield if fewer than 10 percent of its policyholders object.

title: Calpers Accuses AOL of Inflating Revenue
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System sued AOL Time Warner yesterday, contending that the company overstated advertising revenue after the merger that created it.

title: Sandy Weill Steps Down
description: Sanford Weill's surprise announcement this week that he plans to relinquish his Olympian perch as Citigroup's chief executive at the end of the year does not mean Mr. Weill's complete disappearance from the financial scene. This is not a man who takes easily to anonymity. Still, one senses a turning point, the ebbing of power of one of the financial world's most visible tycoons, the slow exit of a take-no-prisoners deal maker who vaulted from near-obscurity to the leadership of the world's single biggest financial empire.

title: Police Seek Man Who Killed One and Injured 3 in the Bronx
description: Four young men were shot early yesterday, one fatally, at a quiet plaza in the Bronx by a gunman who was apparently involved in a love triangle, the police said.

title: California Fray Offers G.O.P. Hope and Peril
description: Eight months after California Republicans suffered one of their most humiliating statewide elections, the party's traditionally warring wings are striving to put aside their differences and take advantage of the recall drive against Gov. Gray Davis.

title: An Appreciation; Josephine Jacobsen's Legacy: The Physical Thrill of Poetry
description: The poet Josephine Jacobsen, who died last week in Maryland at age 94, was a cultural exception. Although she never attended college, she earned the respect of her fellow writers and was named poetry consultant to the Library of Congress (the honorary job now called United States poet laureate) in 1971. She did not gain widespread recognition until her 60's, although her collected poems, ''In the Crevice of Time'' (Johns Hopkins University Press), and selected prose, ''The Instant of Knowing'' (University of Michigan Press), which appeared when she was an octogenarian, are still in print and winning new readers at a vigorous clip.

title: Artists Deserve Support
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Won't Oppose Japan Efforts to Lower Yen's Value
description: Brushing aside the concerns of many Europeans, the United States Treasury secretary, John W. Snow, said today that the Bush administration would not pressure Japan to stop intervening in the currency market to depress the value of the yen.

title: Order Against Interior Dept. Is Overturned
description: A federal appeals court panel today overturned a lower court's ruling against Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton that had found her in contempt for failing to fix the department's management of billions of dollars in royalties earned on American Indian land.

title: Overnight Low: 96 Degrees. Records Fall as Phoenix All but Redefines the Heat Wave.
description: When the sun shines all year long, as it does here, a heat wave is a heat wave only if things get really toasted.

title: Coup on Tiny African Islands Felt in Texas Oil Offices
description: A coup this week in the West African island nation of So Tom and Prncipe is reverberating in the corporate suites of the energy industry here, oil company executives said today. Officials from several companies said they were anxiously monitoring events on the potentially oil-rich archipelago, a former Portuguese colony on the Equator in the Gulf of Guinea.

title: Along With Damage, Museum Suffers Loss of History in Fire
description: A historic house that predates the Revolutionary War and now houses the municipal museum here was heavily damaged by fire on Thursday night, and a collection of documents rich in local history apparently was destroyed, officials said.

title: Sports of The Times; Once Again, an Unknown Stalks the Leaders
description: IN the sandhills of Royal St. George's, golf's newest name, S. K. Ho, was up there on the British Open leader board yesterday when Ernie Els was asked what he knew about Ho, a 29-year-old South Korean pro.

title: Sound, Fury, Pension Rules: Nasty Party Clash in House
description: As protests go, it wasn't much. There were no nightsticks or tear gas, and nobody was arrested.

title: Issue of Lawyer-Client Confidentiality
description: To lawyers, protecting clients' confidentiality is a cornerstone of the practice of law. So it is with considerable anxiety that they are watching a brewing battle between one law firm and the government over the confidentiality of the firm's client list.

title: 'Nightline' Producer Adds Sunday Role
description: ABC News announced on Thursday that Tom Bettag, the longtime producer of ''Nightline,'' would also oversee ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos.''

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: INSURANCE RULES EASED The upper house of Parliament approved a bill that permits Japan's life insurers to cut the guaranteed yields they pay policyholders if they are on the verge of bankruptcy. The bill had already been approved by the lower house and takes effect next month. With a sluggish stock market and interest rates near record lows, insurers are struggling to generate enough investment income to meet their obligations. According to the new law, an insurer can reduce its promised yield if fewer than 10 percent of its policyholders object.

title: Alberto Fujimori, Accused and Defended
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush, Blair and the Iraq Clamor
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: President Ratifies Reform
description: President Ahmet Necdet Sezer ratified a measure that offers greater freedom for Turkey's Kurdish minority to advocate a separate state. The new law is one of a series of reforms intended to help Turkey gain admission to the European Union. The law lifts a ban on separatist propaganda, which critics charged had often been used to silence writers and intellectuals. President Sezer vetoed the measure last month after it had been passed by Parliament, but under Turkish law, if a measure is passed a second time, it becomes law. Dexter Filkins (NYT)

title: Confidence Survey Shows Increasing Optimism
description: Consumer confidence rose this month as a measure of current economic conditions increased to its highest level in more than a year, a University of Michigan survey showed yesterday.

title: 'The Chevrolet of Caviar'
description: At less than $20 an ounce, the roe of the humble Mississippi paddlefish has become the toast of home-grown caviar lovers.

title: New Lives, and Many Lessons, for Somali Refugees
description: As refugees from the Bantu tribe of Somalia resettle in the United States, they must learn to adapt to a new life and culture.

title: On 150th Birthday, It's Party Central
description: New Yorkers gathered in Central Park on Saturday during a daylong celebration of the park's 150th anniversary.

title: In the Face of Death
description: Alex Kotlowitz's article on the Jeremy Gross trial was excellent, as absorbing as any drama I've seen (July 6). I would observe only that whereas the prosecution was forbidden to talk about the victim, no such prohibition applied to your writer, and I would have liked to see some of that angle in the story.

title: Rowdy Hamptons, Yes, But What About ...
description: The Hamptons do need to get tough on loud drunken rowdies out for what they think is a good time [''Enforcing a Quieter, Calmer Hamptons,'' July 13]. But equal and longer lasting threats to the East End environment are posed by affluent second-home owners. Georgica Pond property owners love chemical lawns but hate endangered bird species. Their affluent neighbors to the west want to avoid town codes and taxes by incorporating, thus showing an utter lack of any community responsibility. Wealthy status seekers are filling their large-lot mansion properties with private pools and tennis courts and putting stress on electricity supplies. Sports utility vehicle owners crowd slower drivers off back roads in their hurry to get ... where? To the local farm stand? More likely to one of the local beach clubs or furnishing stores on Main Street that have crowded out local services.

title: John Krutilla, 81, Economist Who Focused on Environment
description: John Vasil Krutilla, an economist who reckoned the dollars and cents of environmental preservation, died on June 27 at his home in McLean, Va. He was 81.

title: A Tree That Spans Years and Continents
description: ONCE upon a time, an Italian immigrant, returning from vacation, smuggled a fig-tree cutting through customs at Kennedy International Airport. His nephew rooted the cutting in Staten Island, then gave it to Rita and Henri Clermont, friends of his who live in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: 'The Great Wave'
description: Imagine the following scenario. Two fatherless boys on opposite sides of the earth take to the sea within days of each other, in search of adventure and a livelihood. Their paths cross on an archipelago in the middle of the Pacific Ocean, where they encounter some of the same helpers, and hinderers. One arrives after years of wandering at the other's port of departure. The other falls just short but writes an extraordinary book that completes the journey. One deserts a whaling ship while the other is rescued by one. One discovers the joys of savage life while the other discovers the ambiguous joys of civilization. Each dreams of "opening" the other's country, and each is changed utterly in the process; their reward is gloom and isolation. Now, let us give these lost boys and Pacific drifters names and dates.

title: In the Neighborhood, Farmers' Markets
description: OVER the last 20 years or so, a dozen farmers' markets have planted roots countywide as local consumers have started to seek fresh and sometimes organic produce -- and to try, perhaps, to replicate their green-market experiences from New York City. Now, restaurants and government agencies have teamed up to give farmers who take produce to market a boost by expanding the consumer base with new marketing strategies, including a floating market barge on the Hudson River, and the possibility of a wholesale distribution center similar to the Hunts Point market somewhere in lower Westchester.

title: There's No Tiptoeing Past Shoe Policy
description: TRAVELERS headed to the airport in recent months have faced a security procedure that left many of them grumbling. At some airports, all passengers were asked to remove their shoes before walking through metal detectors, regardless of whether they wore a menacing steel-toed boot or a thin rubber flip-flop.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Northern State; Rap Sisters From Suffolk
description: IT is a truth universally acknowledged that a rap group in possession of an expense account will take full advantage of the luxury, and in this respect the three women of Northern State are no different from their peers.

title: Stacy Ogier, Wesley Thurman
description: Stacy Lyn Ogier and Wesley Hamilton Thurman were married yesterday by Richard J. Bowles Jr., a Roman Catholic deacon, at the Broadmoor, a resort in Colorado Springs.

title: The Breeze in Your Face, The Screech of Your Brakes
description: The nice thing about bike paths is their uninterrupted flow. No sideswiping taxis. No zigzagging New Jersey plates. So why, many cyclists want to know, are there 30 stop signs along the Hudson River greenway?

title: Unbound in Ironbound
description: UTTER the phrase ''Ironbound restaurant,'' and what comes to mind? Pleasure, no doubt, but probably not subtlety or restraint. In the Ironbound section of Newark -- a vibrant city-within-a-city that throbs with the accents of Portugal, Spain and Brazil -- every street corner seems to hold a food palace with a flashing neon lobster, a long menu of modestly priced Iberian standards, a battalion of waiters hoisting platters the size of parking lots, tall sweating bottles of vinho verde and noisy crowds of determined diners, often holding down tables of 8 or 10 or 12.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: ANG LEE'S fans can only pray that after ''The Hulk'' he'll return to making less action-happy films. Like ''The Ice Storm,'' ''Sense and Sensibility'' and THE WEDDING BANQUET (1993), the comedy of cultural and sexual manners that first brought him to American moviegoers' attention. It's the story of a gay Chinese man (Winston Chao) living in Greenwich Village who decides he'll marry a woman (May Chin) -- in name only, of course -- just to shut his parents up. Unfortunately Mom and Dad decide to fly over from Taipei for the festivities. That means considerable deception for our hero, from de-gaying the apartment he shares with his lover (Mitchell Lichtenstein) to elaborate unfelt displays of physical affection for his bride, who just wants her green card -- Saturday at 5:30 p.m. on IFC.

title: Michelle Limantour, Nicholas Seaver
description: Michelle Christina Limantour and Nicholas Lloyd Seaver were married on Friday in New Canaan, Conn., at the home of Alex Seaver, the brother of the bridegroom. Jill Jakes, a Universal Life minister, officiated. Ms. Jakes also led a spiritual ceremony on June 26 at Notre-Dame d'Alidon, a medieval church in Oppde le Vieux, France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRIMBOLI, , STEVEN R.
description: TRIMBOLI--Steven R., 84, Pearl Harbor Survivor, died peacefuly on July 17, 2003. Loving husband of Erika. Beloved father of Linda and Carol, grandfather of Erica, brother of Bill and friend to countless people who will miss him dearly. Elmhurst Community Leader and member of many civic associations. Mass at St. Bartholomew RC Church, Whitney Avenue, Elmhurst, Tuesday, July 22, at 10:30 AM followed by memorial at Neufeld Funeral Home, 88-04 43 Avenue, Elmhurst. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the petition drive to recall Gov. Gray Davis of California misstated the number of declared candidates to succeed him. Representative Darrell E. Issa is not the only one. Peter Camejo of the Green Party has also declared his candidacy.

title: Want to Stop the Conversation? Just Mention Your Finances
description: THIS summer, I rented a beach house with four friends in Sag Harbor on Long Island. It's a great old place with hardwood floors, window seats and a patio overlooking the water. We all work in the publishing industry and spend many hours discussing our jobs, love lives, plastic surgery and politics -- everything except, strangely, money.

title: CAMDEN RAISES VETOED
description: Governor McGreevey vetoed a contract that would have made the Camden school superintendent one of the highest paid in the state. Annette D. Knox, who took the job in January 2001, had been awarded raises totaling $25,000 by the school board, bringing her salary to more than $214,000. She also was given a leased car, a cellphone and other benefits. Acting under a law that gave Camden substantial money for redevelopment in return for state oversight, Mr. McGreevey asked the board to renegotiate the contract and tie any raises to improvements in student test scores and attendance. Karen DeMasters

title: A 'David' for Our Time, or for All Time?
description: To the Editor:

title: Playing a Serious Game of Twister
description: SHEN WEI'S choreography for his new work, ''The Rite of Spring,'' represents an intersection of two of his passions: dance and painting. When the dance is presented at the Lincoln Center Festival this week, it will be performed on a 42-by-46-foot abstract painting created by Mr. Shen that looks like a giant game board with randomly crisscrossed brush strokes.

title: When a Family Is Too Big for a Unit
description: Q. We live in a large one-bedroom apartment and want to relocate to another part of Manhattan. I found a one-bedroom apartment in a high-rise building that was larger than many two-bedroom apartments. When I returned with my husband to sign the lease, I was told that we could not rent that apartment because we have two children, both under age 7. I was told that under the management company's policy, families with two children could rent only a ''junior four'' or an apartment with more bedrooms. What restrictions can management place on families seeking to rent non-rent-regulated apartments in a rental building? . . . P. Milligan, Manhattan

title: Page Two: July 13-19; BUZZWORDS
description: During the economy's prolonged slump, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has tried to make his pronouncements reassuring and clear. But in his Congressional testimony last week, he expressed what could be called ''ambivalent optimism'' about the economy. Daniel Altman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, , HAROLD
description: LEWIS--Harold. Outspoken advocate for social justice; scholar, teacher, devoted friend, former Dean of Hunter College School of Social Work, died at home Friday, July 18, 2003. Treasured husband of Celia, father of Amy & Beth, grandfather of Jennifer, Nikki, Daniel and Sam. He will always be in our hearts. His contributions to the field of social work are deep and far-reaching. A Memorial service to be announced.

title: More Flag, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Face of Death
description: In sparing the life of Gross, it must be seen that the jury concluded that the ultimate cause of the murder was outside the courtroom -- in the failure of the parents and social-service agencies, etc. Our focus, too, should be on mitigating these failures. The most satisfying retribution for Beers's death, and solace that he did not die in vain, ought to be preventing such future tragedies from happening in the first place.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 20, 2003
description: Weeks

title: Tara Watson, Robert Mathews
description: Tara Elizabeth Watson, the daughter of Susan C. Watson and Keith S. Watson of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Robert Logie Mathews, a son of Susan and William Mathews of Wilton, Conn. The Rev. Scott Planting performed the ceremony at Westport Point United Methodist Church in Westport, Mass.

title: Culinary Expansion: Adding a Cafe
description: ZCAFE, on the corner of South Main and Washington Streets in South Norwalk, is the fifth in a group of restaurants that began in Greenwich with Terra and Mediterraneo, expanded to Westport with Acqua and then to New Canaan with Sole. This is my way of saying that the ownership group, led by Ramze Zakka, has a proven track record.

title: FOULED BEACHES REOPEN
description: Four miles of public beaches in Lavallette and Dover Township reopened last weekend after the authorities determined that spreading medical waste was not as threatening as originally feared. A spokeswoman for the State Department of Environmental Protection said that an investigation after the beaches were closed on Friday had found syringes among plastic waste on the beaches, but that all the waste had been flushed through sewer systems after recent heavy rains. Thomas J. Lueck

title: Jones's Audience
description: To the Editor:

title: DELAWARE DREDGING SET
description: Even as objections continue, the Army Corps of Engineers said last week that it wanted to start dredging 102.5 miles of the Delaware River by the end of the year. The corps is working with Delaware and New Jersey to obtain environmental permits to deepen port areas and shipping lanes to 45 feet from the current 40 feet to accommodate larger ships. But the Delaware Riverkeeper Network and the National Wildlife Federation have objected, disputing an economic analysis in which the corps said that port business would gain 18 cents for each taxpayer dollar invested in dredging. The project will cost $211 million to $420 million, by various estimates. Karen DeMasters

title: Seat Belts on Trains
description: To the Editor:

title: Subway Fire Under Train In Brooklyn Sickens 100
description: About 100 people were treated for smoke inhalation early yesterday morning after a subway fire sent thick clouds of black smoke wafting through a station in Brooklyn, officials said.

title: SpongeBob's Briefs
description: To the Editor:

title: Ronaldinho Agrees To Join Barcelona
description: Brazil forward Ronaldinho has agreed to join Barcelona from Paris Saint-Germain for $25 million, turning down approaches from the English champion, Manchester United.

title: How to Marry a Billionaire And Other City Pursuits
description: TRADING UP

title: The Thinking Class
description: To the Editor:

title: L.P.G.A.'s New Idols Give the Tour Identity
description: For years, the L.P.G.A. veteran Jan Stephenson has conducted golf clinics for girls, ages 5 through 12, and for years the same question has elicited the same answer.

title: Over 90, and Still on the Road
description: Everyone around town knows me as the old lady with the red convertible. I don't mind. My red convertible, and before that the black one, and earlier the station wagon -- they are all part of my life. But as with other things, and people, our relationship has changed.

title: On Eve of Crucial Week of Diplomacy, Abbas Sums Up Vision for a Palestinian State
description: Less than three months on the job as the reluctant Palestinian prime minister, struggling to persuade Palestinians of the value of a new peace plan and Israelis of his ability to put it into effect, Mahmoud Abbas faces a crucial week of diplomacy.

title: Where Have All the Lisas Gone?
description: I was surprised that Orenstein did not mention the Jewish tradition of naming babies after deceased loved ones. Many of those Maxes, Roses, Sams and Sophies are probably carrying on the name of a greatly missed grandparent.

title: Crackdown on Tycoon Shakes Up Moscow
description: MOSCOW, July 19  In the quiet of the Russian summer, a noisy political brawl is rewriting the rules of Russian politics.

title: Rye Passes Rules On Building 'McMansions'
description: In an effort to rein in the construction of ''McMansions,'' large houses that leave little space for lawns, the City Council of Rye unanimously passed a set of regulations last Wednesday to redefine the way houses are measured to judge whether they are too big for the lots upon which they are built.

title: Head Master
description: Frdric Fekkai's Protein Rx Reparative Spray may turn out to be the season's all-purpose hair product. Designed to protect and detangle, this leave-in treatment, which is made from soy and milk extracts ($18.50 at www.sephora.com), also smooths frizziness out of just-washed hair, revives limp tresses and makes any hair more manageable.

title: Marie Walsh, Michael McCarty
description: Marie Walsh and Michael Justin McCarty were married yesterday at Jasna Polana, a country club, in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Rafferty, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: A Less-Is-More Lesson
description: IN the mid-1960's, when I was 17, Harvard College accepted me. Harvard was just becoming what it is today, a sort of vacuum cleaner. It went from being a place for the sons of the Northeastern elite to a meritocracy and started to suck up people from other parts of the country. Growing up near Cincinnati, I was in that wave, and this changed my life. It certainly opened up more than Brown County, Ohio, had to offer.

title: Architecture in Reno (And Not a Casino)
description: WITH its cluster of high-rise casinos backed by the Sierra Nevada to the west and the horizonless stretch of the Great Basin to the east, this city of 190,000 is well known as a junior, less glamorous Las Vegas. So when 11,000 people gathered downtown on May 24, the easy bet would have been that it had something to do with high-stakes poker, progressive slots and all-you-can-eat buffets. But that would have been wrong. The crowd had come for the Diegos and the Fridas, and for the opening of a new museum that may put Reno on the architectural map.

title: Nothing Random
description: I. I SEE DEAD PEOPLE

title: Picking Judges: Party Machines, Rubber Stamps
description: For decades in New York, the law has required that political parties nominate candidates to run for State Supreme Court at judicial conventions, not in primaries. The conventions are attended by delegates who are elected on the neighborhood level and who are supposed to evaluate candidates before offering the best ones a spot on the November ballot.

title: Judge Orders Halt on Work At Site of Proposed Casino
description: Lawyers for the Town of Southampton, arguing that the Shinnecock Indian Nation must have town approval to build what would be Long Island's only casino, have won a temporary restraining order that has halted the clearing of the tribe's 79-acre property in Hampton Bays.

title: A Lesser Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: AFTER NATURE, by W. G. Sebald. (Modern Library, $11.95.) Written early in Sebald's career but published posthumously, this book-length poem is loosely based on the lives of three disparate figures: the medieval artist Matthias Grnewald, the naturalist Georg Steller and the author himself. The result is a meditation on the sources of the catastrophic imagination, the connections between human nature and nature, and the interweaving of desire and destruction. The language ''is almost classically lucid,'' Eva Hoffman said here last year. Sebald's ''ability to enter diverse inner landscapes, and evoke, with an impartial empathy, entire geographies of experience,'' gives his writing ''its gravitas and its somber beauty.''

title: This Jets Quarterback Is One Happy Camper
description: Jets quarterback Chad Pennington was in California last week to film a commercial for a sneaker company, then he flew back home in time for a magazine photo shoot, the talismans of a rising N.F.L. star piling up like so many completions.

title: Firefighters And Residents Are Injured In Bronx Fire
description: A fast-burning blaze swept through a six-story Bronx apartment building yesterday morning, seriously injuring at least six residents, including a 5-month-old baby, and forcing dozens of panic-stricken families to flee down the fire escape.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ANDROMIDAS, , STEVEN CHRISTOPHER
description: ANDROMIDAS -- Steven Christopher. Also known as Chris Andromidas, a composer for film and television whose credits include more than 350 films, died on Friday July 11, 2003 at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, NY. He was 50. Chris was born on March 2, 1953 in Mineola, L.I. and resided in Ossining. Chris is survived by his wife, Christina Muller, formerly of Ellenville, NY and one brother, Charles (Rocky) Andromidas of San Francisco, CA. He is predeceased by his father Charles J. Andromidas, his mother Katherine (Notar), and his younger brother Thomas. A private memorial will be held at the convenience of the family. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Chris to ALCASE, Unit 78, POB 4800, Portland, OR. 97208-4800. >>AD#

title: Seeing Crimson
description: SIGNS of midsummer's lethargy are everywhere on the tree-lined Main Street in this wealthy South Jersey town -- at the greeting card store, the bakery and the coffee shop. Yet the gossip and the tumult about this year's graduating class at the high school, and the young woman who sued for, and won, the right to be the sole valedictorian is unrelenting.

title: The Jail Threat Is Real. So, Will Executives Behave?
description: LAST month, Samuel D. Waksal, the founder and former chief executive of ImClone Systems, was sentenced to 87 months in jail for securities fraud, conspiracy, perjury and obstruction of justice. The crimes related to stock trades he made in the company for himself and his family at the end of 2001. Mr. Waksal is scheduled to begin serving his sentence on Wednesday, becoming the first chief executive implicated in recent prominent corporate scandals to go to jail.

title: Page Two: July 13-19; SUPERSTAR CHARGED
description: Kobe Bryant, the Los Angeles Lakers' all-star guard, was charged with sexually assaulting a 19-year-old woman in a Colorado hotel where she worked. Bryant, 24, denied he assaulted the woman on June 30 but said he had made ''the mistake of adultery.''

title: Gently Riding Norah Jones's Coattails
description: FIVE years ago, Richard Julian and Jesse Harris, two struggling New York singer-songwriters, took a cross-country trip. They stopped in Denton, where some friends were playing at the University of North Texas. A freshman music major was assigned to chauffeur the visitors around, and that night she joined them in a jam session on a golf course. Impressed, they urged her to drop out of school and move to New York.

title: Testing Our Leadership
description: After nearly a decade of legal wrangling, New York's highest court has issued a sweeping ruling determining that the amount of money provided to New York City's public schools is inadequate and ordering changes. Now it is up to us, New York's state and local leaders, to take the next step.

title: The Story of a Second-Rate Actress and First-Rate Tyrant
description: LIVING on is the best revenge, to paraphrase an old saying. Jiang Qing, expunged from the official Chinese record, is remembered in her homeland through legend and slander. But being immortalized in two Western operas would have delighted this second-rate actress who rose to supreme power as the wife of Mao Zedong, fell into disgrace after Mao's death and stage-managed her own grand finale, hanging herself in her prison cell on May 14, 1991.

title: Where Have All the Lisas Gone?
description: Recently I have noticed a trend among my friends with new babies: choosing a name with a predetermined short version or nickname in mind. This is reinforced by clothing embroidered or monogrammed with the nickname, foiling what I experienced as a spontaneous evolution based on specific moments or relationships.

title: A 'David' for Our Time, or for All Time? (3 Letters)
description: Re "Question for `David' at 500: Is He Ready for Makeover?" (front page, July 15):

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   POTTS, , GEORGE H.
description: POTTS--George H. In the six years you're gone The memory shines bright, And our lives move on Forever inspired by your light Your Family >>AD#

title: Justine Cowen, Brian Bons
description: Dr. Justine Dana Cowen, a daughter of Lesley and Edward Cowen of New York, was married last evening to Dr. Brian Kenneth Bons, the son of Nancy and Kenneth Bons of Franklin, Wis. Rabbi David Posner officiated at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Sara Tripp, Gregory Boye
description: Sara Elizabeth Tripp, the daughter of Nancy and Fred Tripp of Barrington, R.I., was married there last evening to Gregory Andrew Boye, a son of Glenn Boye of Medford Lakes, N.J., and the late Patricia Boye. The Rev. C. Neal Goldsborough, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Letters
description: Our article on pro-death-penalty jurors drew a strong response. While it argued persuasively for sparing the defendant, readers regretted that it also gave short shrift to the victim. Joe Sacco's comics journalism drew even stronger mail. Many said it was worth 1,000 words; others called it a pro-Palestinian show-and-tell.

title: From the Small Screen To the Big Screen And, Sometimes, Back Again
description: FOR George Clooney, Kiefer Sutherland, James Gandolfini, David Caruso, Helen Hunt and Michael Chiklis, among others, series television has provided both a craft laboratory and a last chance at stardom. Ambition burns so brightly in the acting on their breakthrough shows, many newly available on DVD, that you can feel the heat. But acting in front of the television camera isn't the same as acting in front of the movie camera, and it's instructive to sit through Mr. Caruso's enthralling season of ''N.Y.P.D. Blue'' or to watch Mr. Chiklis's sociopathic gangster detective in ''The Shield'' and thrill to the spectacle of an actor finding himself.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: THE TRUTH ABOUT CELIA

title: School Start-Time Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Exploring Technology's Caring Side
description: ERIC DISHMAN sees a health care crisis looming. As the baby-boom generation ages, the number of people suffering from Alzheimer's disease is expected to increase sharply; some researchers predict 14 million cases by 2050, versus 4 million today. Each case means a person in need of diligent care and attention.

title: Armstrong's Lead In Tour de France Slips to 15 Seconds

The Devil Rays manager, Lou Piniella, is in his office, smoking a cigarette while talking on the phone to his stockbroker. He motions for me to sit down on the sofa next to his son, Derek, 24. In pantomime, Piniella offers me a cigar, then says to his broker, ''I'll buy 3,000 shares.''

title: The Education of a World Traveler
description: FINGERING the footholds, I keep my eye on Kelvin Watchmen, our Navajo guide, as he leads us step by step, in the very same footholds created by the fingers and callused feet of his ancestors, who climbed up and down this trail for their livelihood. Eventually, it was a means to escape from those who'd come to take it away, my ancestors. As we descend the geologic waves of smooth sandstone onto the floor of Canyon del Muerto, part of the Canyon de Chelly National Monument in northeastern Arizona, where his family tends one of the many tidy plots of corn and alfalfa, Kelvin tells stories, often using the very rocks we are holding on to as characters.

Neuberger, a college dropout without parents, went to Paris for an immersion course in life. He did not aspire to be a painter himself, but the artist's plight hooked his imagination.

title: The Good Old Music Days
description: I thoroughly enjoyed Paul LaRocco's recent article "As a Music Scene Fades, Teenagers Seek Alternatives" (July 13). As a young adult living in Connecticut, the article brought back a lot of great memories of ska/punk/rock shows I attended in the mid-90's as a high school student. Some of my best memories are of shows featuring bands like "Spring Heeled Jack", "Jiker", and "Sgt. Scagnetti." The ability to see these young, energetic bands in small (sometimes confining!) venues like teen centers, the Tune Inn, and elsewhere for about $5 was incredible. Bands were fan-friendly and interactive with their young energetic crowds who were able to express themselves without the stares of disapproving parents. It was a great feeling and since then I've never had a concert experience more powerful.

title: The Jungle Out There

It seemed a harmless enough way to kick off the season. We prepared vegetarian barbecue, and had spirited debates that set off political parrying among the generations. My dog had a great time, chasing deer and wandering the hillside and river banks, while I stuck to the dirt roads and well-cleared paths. That night he passed out in my bed.

title: Harvesting Poverty; The Rigged Trade Game
description: Put simply, the Philippines got taken. A charter member of the World Trade Organization in 1995, the former American colony dutifully embraced globalization's free-market gospel over the last decade, opening its economy to foreign trade and investment. Despite widespread worries about their ability to compete, Filipinos bought the theory that their farmers' lack of good transportation and high technology would be balanced out by their cheap labor. The government predicted that access to world markets would create a net gain of a half-million farming jobs a year, and improve the country's trade balance.

The decision was made in the case of a River Vale man who had custody of his two children and tried to limit his ex-wife's parents to one short visit a month. The children, now teenagers, had been used to extended weekend visits with the grandparents. The court said it agreed with experts who said the children would be harmed psychologically if such visits were restricted. Karen DeMasters

As she produces a serene melody, her concentration is barely disturbed by two students playing a game of billiards in an adjacent room, or by the aroma of a spaghetti dinner being prepared by another student in the nearby kitchen.

title: What Becomes A Champion Most?

She has become the overseer of a living treasure, the manager of an athlete so talented that her limitations have not been discovered. It is a task de Seroux takes seriously, but she understands that there are different ways of viewing her responsibilities and different ideas about the best way to proceed.

title: All the World's a Stage
description: Beneath the humming of a rusty old air-conditioner, Art, Nadeem, Hasan, Diar and Shant are rehearsing their single ''Hey Girl,'' dreaming of stardom, Western-style stardom, a stardom so great it'll match the name of their boy band: Unknown to No One. The conditions look normal -- walls covered with posters of Iron Maiden, Destiny's Child, Britney; a relic of an electric guitar, one string left, suspended on the wall; cassettes of Bon Jovi, Savatage and the Backstreet Boys; and a small Casio electric keyboard. ''I can be your hero baby,'' promises Nadeem, whose shirt is always half-unbuttoned. Then suddenly the keyboard goes mute. The air-conditioning drones to nothing. And the boys belt out, ''You can't take my breath away, but electricity can.''

The regular rates start at $340 a night, and the offer is good Sunday through Thursday nights; reservations required. Information: (805) 238-5600 or www.myvillatoscana.com.

Fitting seamlessly into the neighborhood, with its handsome blue awning and sidewalk tables covered with white cloths, Lusardi's looks and acts like it's been here forever. title: Fitting the Mold
description: Three years ago, when Anne Kearney, the chef at Peristyle in New Orleans, put a nightly charcuterie plate on the menu, I was thrilled. Since Peristyle, which she owns with her husband, Tom Sand, is around the corner from my house, I was already pretty happy -- when I'm in town, nothing gives me more pleasure than to belly up to its magnificent copper bar for a glass of Bandol ros and a pissaladire. The staff never fails to cheer me up when I am down, the fax machine does duty when mine is broken and, most important, the menu offers wonderful takes on the food I love most: poached oysters with cream, bacon, leeks and fennel; lump-crab salad with fresh horseradish and beets; gougres, hot at the table; a classic lemon tart for dessert. And now, on the charcuterie plate, fabulous terrines.

There may be a temperamental difference between the two parties, but ambition and cunning are certainly part of the temperament of all successful politicians.

title: 'The Cosby Show,' Starring . . . Heavily Accented Jews?
description: IT is sometimes said that America needs to see more positive images of minorities on television. How much more harmonious our polity would be if we made the acquaintance of the citizens behind the stereotypes -- the hard-working Middle Eastern immigrants dismayed by terrorism; the black strivers who deplore all things gangsta; the non-mini-skirted female lawyers; the unflighty gay couples. Every now and then, the television industry answers such criticism with a sitcom about members of an ethnic group or subculture who are just like you and me, though cuter and more colorful. Occasionally, the show becomes a hit. The national audience encounters new cultural styles; the minority enjoys the pleasure of mass representation; everyone glows with the feeling that prejudice has been overcome. There is only one problem, and it rarely impinges on the show's success: the characters are too busy being decent to be funny.

title: Denver
description: The grass is greener in Denver this summer, thanks to frequent downpours that have eased the drought in Colorado. The trails run through city and suburbs along whitewater sections of the South Platte River, placid Cherry Creek and the Highline Canal as they meander through wetlands, forests, wildflower meadows and eventually past a sandy beach at the Cherry Creek Reservoir 10 miles from downtown.

title: Working The Beat
description: Late Sunday nights, with the workweek looming ahead of me, I find myself lying awake, mentally buzzing through the streets of Baltimore, puzzling out motives, means and opportunities, trying to think like ''a natural police.'' What has me so wired (forgive me) is ''The Wire,'' the newest HBO original series, now in its second season. Like its better-known siblings ''Six Feet Under'' and ''The Sopranos,'' ''The Wire'' has been praised for its intelligent writing, nearly flawless ensemble acting and distinctive visual style. By now we expect as much, and the superiority of the cable channel's original programs to just about everything else on television -- and to most theatrically released movies -- is hardly news. What's great about ''The Wire,'' though, is how difficult it is. The stories are hard to follow; the cases have a nagging habit of remaining unsolved; the characters endure endless frustration, betrayal and mismanagement. The ones who are not incompetent are not very nice, and the smart ones often find themselves outfoxed by the dumb ones. I love it. It's the story of my life.

title: Music You Can See and Touch

Mr. Joneleit's main concerns are timbre, texture and space, and he uses them inventively and with an almost visual sense of placement. Structure comes into his sound pictures as well, but in a way so quirkily personal that organizational signposts are hard to discern. Other musical building blocks -- themes, for example -- hardly figure in his processes at all, although now and then a melodic fragment teases the ear. At a time when new music is chasing accessibility, Mr. Joneleit's pieces recall the avant-garde sound sculptures of the 1960's.

Early photos made it look like a ratty old cigar box, anyway. And the girls relished details of other fights: Two maiden aunts had had a brick wall built down the center of their Victorian house in Dorchester, the better to avoid each other; back in County Cork, one Crossley and his widowed sister hadn't spoken for the last twenty years of their lives, although they slept in the same cottage and sat across the kitchen table from each other three times a day. title: 'Nature via Nurture'
description: Similarity is the shadow of difference. Two things are similar by virtue of their difference from another; or different by virtue of one's similarity to a third. So it is with individuals. A short man is different from a tall man, but two men seem similar if contrasted with a woman. So it is with species. A man and a woman may be very different, but by comparison with a chimpanzee, it is their similarities that strike the eye - the hairless skin, the upright stance, the prominent nose. A chimpanzee, in turn, is similar to a human being when contrasted with a dog: the face, the hands, the 32 teeth, and so on. And a dog is like a person to the extent that both are unlike a fish. Difference is the shadow of similarity.

title: 'No Visible Horizon'
description: In the middle of the fifteenth century in Japan, a time when the kingdom was both at its most isolated and, to Japanese eyes, most perfect, a strange tradition emerged: composing haiku as you died, at the very moment of death. Perhaps it wasn't so surprising. Japanese culture had become obsessed with the relationship between life and art. There was an increasing belief that the two should never be separated, that a well-lived life was a work of art. Was it surprising that some Japanese poets wanted to try to weave the two together, to make a little tatami of life and art? What better time than at the moment of death? After a lifetime of study, could you be beautiful in three lines? Could you be perfect? Could you reduce it, all of it, your life, down to seventeen syllables?

title: How's Your Mom, Oed?
description: In her first book, a collection of short stories titled THE WINTER WITHOUT MILK (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, paper, $12), Jane Avrich skillfully and subtly manipulates such forms as the morality tale, the monologue and the spoof to show us characters grappling with tense social and psychological situations. In ''Life in Dearth,'' a girl who lives in a seaside village likes to indulge in ''borrowing'' miscellaneous things from Gypsies who live by the shore; as her borrowing continues, she becomes more indebted, ultimately finding her life inexorably changed. The persistent protagonist of ''The Census Taker'' finds his life's validity tested upon encountering a woman who refuses to cough up any information. Although Avrich can be wickedly clever -- as in ''Chez Oedipus,'' a catty tour of the house of the incestuous royal patricide, or ''Lady Macbeth, Prickly Pear Queen,'' a reimagining of the Scottish queen as a 20-century high-strung society gal -- she never loses sight of one of her signal themes, the tension between individual liberty and the forces working against it. The best news here is that Avrich's sentences are acute and piercing, giving these 15 stories both a striking delicacy and a confidence that is impossible to ignore. Max Winter

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEID, , RICHARD ALBERT
description: SEID--Richard Albert, 66, a New York lawyer and columnist, died in his home in Mexico City on Tuesday, June 24, 2003, of cancer. A graduate of Choate (1954), Brown University (1958), and Columbia Law School (1966), Richard Seid moved to Mexico in 1972 following his marriage to Maria Victoria Llamas, a Mexican writer and broadcast journalist. There, he became a wellknown English-language columnist. Over the years, his opinion pieces and columns were published in the ''Christian Science Monitor,'' ''The News of Mexico City,'' and ''The Mexico City Times.'' Later in life, he became a Mexican citizen in order to earn the right to vote and to fight for the democratization of his adopted home. Over the years he monitored presidential elections to guard against electoral fraud, worked on his wife's congressional campaign, and was active in many civic and human rights groups. In addition to his political activism, he taught such courses as Speech, Ethics, and Critical Thinking at the Mexico City campus of Massachusetts - based Endicott College, and continued to practice law at Goodrich, Riquelme y Asociados. He also was a champion table-tennis player. He is survived by his wife Maria Victoria Llamas de Seid, his children Alan and Marivi, his mother Shirley Seid and his brother John Seid. His father, a New York attorney, Herman Seid, died in 1984. >>AD#

In particular, he worried about finding singers who would project the turmoil of Onegin, Lenski and Tatiana, the teenagers at the heart of the story. ''How Pushkin's captivating picture will be vulgarized when it is transferred to the stage,'' he wrote, ''with its routine, its senseless traditions, its veterans of both sexes who, without any shame, take on . . . the roles of 16-year-old girls and beardless youths!''

title: A Bloody Peace in Iraq

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/New CD's; In the Present, Echoes of the Past
description: In rock music at the moment, the best new bands seem to be the ones with the best record collections. The Darkness is mining its collection of 70's glam-rock and heavy metal to become one of the most promising new British bands, one you can simultaneously laugh at and pump your fist in the air to, while Interpol has become one of New York's favorite exports with brooding post-punk similar to that of Joy Division. Below are three relatively new bands from overseas that, at times, ape their favorite albums from the 60's. The Sleepy Jackson quotes Bob Dylan, the Thrills quote the Monkees, and the Super Furry Animals sample the more obscure Wendy and Bonnie. Yet at the same time, all three acts have enough personality to transcend their record collections and release these consistently engaging -- at times breathtaking -- albums.

title: Bucharest Journal; On Dracula's Terrain, an Infusion of New Blood
description: This being Romania, and all that implies for foggy forests and the undead, there was perhaps no other way for the early days of foreign filmmaking here. In 1992 there was ''Subspecies 2,'' followed closely by ''Subspecies 3.'' Then came ''Leaping Leprechauns,'' parts 1 and 2, ''The Human Pets,'' ''The Planet of the Dino Knights,'' ''Frankenstein Reborn'' and something called, simply, ''Hideous.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TURECK, , ROSALYN
description: TURECK -- Rosalyn. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sadness the passing of its beloved friend Rosalyn Tureck on July 17 in Riverdale, New York at the age of 88. A native of Chicago, Mme. Tureck studied with Jan Chiapusso, Sophia Brilliant-Liven and later with Olga Samaroff at The Juilliard School. Her legendary Town Hall recitals of 1937 ignited her fame as a Bach specialist. She was a forward thinking musician who championed contemporary composers and inventive programming. A scholar of great renown, her creativity and passion for her music brought her an important public following. Mme. Tureck was a devoted member of the Steinway Artist family for more than six decades, and she was an inspiring force in the world of music. Her loss is deeply felt, but her acclaimed discography will keep her legacy alive for future generations. To her family we extend our heartfelt condolences. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities >>AD#

title: White House Remains Noncommittal on Troops for Liberia
description: WASHINGTON, July 22  The White House refused today to say when, or if, the United States would send a peacekeeping force to Liberia. But it said it "remains actively engaged" in trying to bring calm to the African nation.

title: Sleepover Camps That Redefine Notions of 'Away'

Uniforms were required. Campers are allowed to spend only 75 cents a week on candy. Worst of all, she said, calls home were expressly forbidden.

Mr. Long, a 35-year-old Vietnamese catfish farmer, sold his flapping fish -- 40 tons' worth, all painstakingly weighed and carried in bamboo buckets onto the trading company's launch -- at a loss of some $2,000, a small fortune here.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint PCS To Offer Wi-Fi Service
description: Sprint PCS will offer Internet access through 2,100 Wi-Fi wireless networking venues by late 2003, the company said yesterday. The service will begin this summer with 800 locations operated by Wayport and Airpath Wireless, primarily in hotels and airports in the United States. Sprint PCS plans to install 1,300 locations of its own; the company has built internal Wi-Fi systems for businesses, universities and hotels in the last two years. Jason Guesman, a Sprint PCS business marketing director, said the company currently offered a cellular data service called 1xRTT that operated at 50 to 70 kilobits a second. The service is available throughout the company's cellular network with unlimited access for $80 a month. Most business venues have an Internet connection of at least 1.5 megabits a second, with Wi-Fi's maximum potential peaking at more than 20 megabits a second with newer standards. Mr. Guesman said that although pricing had not yet been set for Wi-Fi service, the company would charge one standard fee for access at any location. Glenn Fleishman (NYT)

title: RIVERSTONE NETWORKS TO RESTATE RESULTS
description: Riverstone Networks, a maker of computer-networking equipment, said yesterday that it would restate results for the 2002 fiscal year and for the first three quarters of 2003 because of improperly booked sales. Some sales were recorded incorrectly because they were subject to rights of return and other contingencies, Riverstone said. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., did not quantify the extent of the restatement. Riverstone said a committee of its board was investigating the company's accounting practices, and the company was cooperating with a formal inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Trading in the company on the Nasdaq was halted.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: F.T.C. Settles Suit Against Youth In Net Fraud
description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it had settled a lawsuit against a 17-year-old California boy who used unsolicited e-mail messages and a fraudulent America Online Web page to gain access to credit card information and steal thousands of dollars from consumers. The boy, who was not identified because he is a minor, will be required to pay $3,500 in consumer repayment, officials said. Timothy J. Muris, the chairman of the F.T.C., said the case was the first focused on an Internet scheme called phishing, in which spam e-mail messages are used to lure computer users to look-alike or counterfeit Web sites, where they are then encouraged to supply personal financial data. Officials said the teenager created a fraudulent AOL Web site, which included the company's logo and links to legitimate AOL Web pages, seeking credit card numbers, billing addresses, Social Security numbers and AOL screen names and passwords. ''Phishing is a two-time scam,'' Mr. Muris said. ''Phishers first steal a company's identity and then use it to victimize consumers by stealing their credit identities.''

title: REAL ESTATE DEVELOPER SOLD FOR $990 MILLION
description: The Lennar Corporation, a big home builder, said yesterday that it was acquiring the Newhall Land and Farming Company, a real estate developer, in partnership with the LNR Property Corporation for about $990 million, plus debt. The companies will pay $40.50 a share in cash for Newhall, about 21 percent more than the stock's closing price yesterday of $33.40. The sale is expected to close by the middle of next year, the companies said. Lennar wants to buy Newhall, based in Valencia, Calif., because Newhall has the right to build more than 20,000 homes, as well as commercial properties, north of Los Angeles, a fast-growing market, said Jonathan M. Jaffe, a vice president with Lennar in Mission Viejo, Calif. Lennar and LNR Property, a real estate investment and management company, are both based in Miami. The announcement was made after the close of trading.

description: WELLMAN--Henry, died July 19th, 2003, at age 94. Beloved husband of Fromma. Dear father of Elisabeth Vazquez (Albert) and the late Zachary (Celia). Devoted grandfather of Jennifer Golden (David), Eric Wellman, Sarah Helmbrecht and Rebecca Wellman; great-grandfather of Michelle and Elena Golden. Henry was a graduate of City College 1928 and of NYU Law School 1931 where he was Editor-in-Chief of the Law Review. He was a friend and mentor to thousands of young people through his work in recreational services for youth. He served at various organizational camps, among them Welmet and NJ Federation Y Camps. In 1949 he purchased Camp Oquago at Perch Lake in Andes, NY which he operated for 28 years. During that time and afterwards, Henry was active in the American Camping Association and was President of the NY Division for several years. After retiring from camp ownership, he served as a voluntary arbitrator in the NYC Night Court for nearly a decade. title: FINANCIAL SERVICES COMPANY HAS COLLATERAL PROBLEM
description: UICI, a financial services and insurance company, said yesterday that two of the three student-loan facilities of its Academic Management Services unit had insufficient collateral and the unit's president was placed on leave. The company's shares fell 29 percent. In addition, all seven special subsidiaries of Academic Management and AMS itself may have failed to comply with their reporting obligations, the company, based in Dallas, said. AMS plans to transfer money to increase the amount of collateral, but that will not resolve the shortfall, UICI said. UICI said some reports about the collateral had been misstated, and some collateral did not comply with loan requirements. Gregory T. Mutz, the vice chairman of UICI, will oversee AMS during the investigation. Shares of UICI fell $4.85, to $12.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Lawyers File In Judge's Behalf
description: Lawyers for a Brooklyn judge accused of official misconduct filed a motion yesterday seeking to have the indictment thrown out on the ground that the judge is not accused of a crime. The motion argues that the acts that Justice Gerald P. Garson of State Supreme Court, above, is accused of -- accepting gifts and cash from a lawyer in return for favorable treatment and client referrals -- are violations of the Code of Judicial Conduct rather than crimes. Therefore, the district attorney has no authority to prosecute them, according to the motion filed by Ronald P. Fischetti and others. The Brooklyn district attorney's office had no immediate response to the motion, filed with Justice Steven W. Fisher of State Supreme Court. A law enforcement official said that prosecutors hope to raise the charges to bribery, making the motion moot because bribery is a crime. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: 3M POSTS 33% PROFIT INCREASE AND RAISES FORECAST
description: The 3M Company, the maker of Scotch tape, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings increased 33 percent because of lower costs and higher international sales and it raised its 2003 profit forecast. Net income rose to $619 million, or $1.56 a share, from $466 million, or $1.18 a share, a year earlier. Sales climbed 10 percent to $4.58 billion, the company said. Most of 3M's growth was overseas, where the company makes more than half its sales. International sales rose 17 percent, and half of that was because of the weakened dollar, the company said. 3M, based in St. Paul, increased its 2003 profit forecast to $5.75 to $5.90 a share, from $5.65 to $5.85. The company's shares rose $6.17, to $136.35.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEWMAN, , J. WILSON
description: NEWMAN--J. Wilson, former Chief Executive Officer of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation for sixteen years and Chairman of the Finance Committee for twelve years, died in Charlottesville, Virginia on Tuesday, July 8. Mr. Newman resided in Short Hills, New Jersey, Delray Beach, Florida, and Charlottesville, Virginia. He was born, November 3, 1909, in Clemson, South Carolina, attended Clemson University, graduated in 1931, and received his law degree from New York University Law School in 1937. Following a brief experience in banking, Mr. Newman joined the R.G. Dun Company in 1931 as a credit reporter shortly before that company's merger with the Bradstreet Company. After several years of reporting and a wide range of assignments, he became a Vice President in 1946, President in 1952, and Chairman and Chief Executive Officer in 1960. After retiring in 1968, he remained Chairman of the Finance Committee until 1980. Under his leadership, his company substantially expanded its revenues through growth and diversification of services, as well as modernizing systems and facilities. Mr. Newman participated in numerous governmental activities including being a member of the United States Price Commission ('71-72) and the Commission on Bankruptcy Laws ('70-73). He was a member of the Millburn, New Jersey Board of Education, associated in various capacities with the American Bar Association, the Committee for Economic Development, the Conference Board, the New York Chamber of Commerce Executive Committee, as well as the English Speaking Union in Charlottesville, Virginia. Numerous Board memberships included: The Atlantic Companies, Chemical Bank, Consolidated Edison, International Paper, AT&T, General Foods Corporation, Lockheed Corporation, and the New York Stock Exchange. Public service activities included the Clemson University Foundation, New York University and its Law School Foundation, the Miller Center of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia (Chairman), Sweet Briar College (Chairman), The Brookings Institute, Harvard University, the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, and the President's Council for the Arts, University of Virginia. Mr. Newman has been specifically honored by Clemson University, the New York University Law School, the South Carolina Business Hall of Fame, Sweet Briar College, and the Miller Center of Public Affairs. He also wrote and published an autobiography entitled ''For What Do We Labor?'' in 1996. He was past president of the University Club of New York and a trustee of the Baltusrol Golf Club and the Gulf Stream Bath and Tennis Club. Mr. Newman was preceded in death by his wife of 68 years, Clara Collier Newman in June 2002. He is survived by four children, Mrs. Robert E. Blanchard of Green Village, New Jersey, Mrs. Bradley R. Thayer of Whitefield, New Hampshire, James Wilson Newman, Jr. of Charlottesville, Virginia, and Charles Carter Newman of Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania, nine grandchildren and twelve great grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Miller Center of Public Affairs, University of Virginia, P.O. Box 40046, Charlottesville, Virginia 22902-4406. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Dies Days After Scuffle
description: A man whose eyes were gouged during a scuffle with his roommate died in the hospital of a heart attack on Sunday, four days after the argument, the police said yesterday. The man, Oscar Herrera, 53, of East Elmhurst, and his roommate, Hector Castillo, 51, were arguing over a broken television antenna in their home at 100-30 Ditmars Boulevard. Mr. Castillo gouged Mr. Herrera's eyes with his fingers and fingernails, the police said. Both were arrested, and Mr. Castillo was charged with assault. Mr. Herrera suffered a heart attack at Elmhurst Hospital Center and died on Sunday night. The medical examiner's office will determine whether the death was linked to the assault, the police said. title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: LEXMARK MISSES FORECASTS; SHARES PLUNGE Shares of Lexmark International , the computer printer maker, fell almost 20 percent yesterday after the company said it would miss profit forecasts for the third quarter because of lower printer prices and less demand for ink refills. Earnings in the third quarter will be 63 cents to 73 cents a share, Lexmark said yesterday as it issued second-quarter results. The company, which makes printers for Dell Inc., was expected to earn 80 cents in Thomson Financial's survey of analysts. Lexmark's estimate is lower because the company has decided to seek more sales of money-losing printers in order to increase demand for its ink cartridges, which yield a continuing revenue stream, the chief financial officer, Gary Morin, said in an interview. Lexmark shares fell $14.10, or about 19 percent, to $59.40. (Bloomberg News)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Amtrak Power Shortage Delays Thousands
description: Most train service from New York City to New Jersey stopped last night for 40 minutes because of insufficient power along the Amtrak line, delaying thousands of people, the authorities said. The rail system through New Jersey to the Philadelphia area needs 15,000 to 25,000 volts to run, but had only 9,000 volts at about 6:03 p.m., said Dan Stessel, a spokesman for Amtrak in Washington. Ten New Jersey Transit trains were on the tracks at the time, and 15 were held in New York, a New Jersey Transit spokeswoman said. No passenger trains ran between New York City and New Jersey, except for those on the PATH line, until full power resumed at 6:42 p.m. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Editorial Observer; The Politician, the Mobster and the Ties That Bind Them to Each Other
description: William Bulger is a classically educated Bostonian who touted Plutarch while reigning as president of the Massachusetts State Senate for 17 years -- the longest tenure in the history of the commonwealth. At the height of his power, one writer compared him to Aureliano Buenda, the colonel in the Gabriel Garca Mrquez novel ''One Hundred Years of Solitude'' whose orders were ''carried out even before they were given, even before he thought of them.''

title: City Clerk Is Single, but No Wet Blanket on Love
description: LOVE and marriage never did perform a horse-and-carriage dovetail for New York's city clerk, Victor L. Robles, whose office opposite City Hall churns out 70,000 marriage licenses each year and is host to 40,000 nuptials in its revamped chapels of love. He is divorced and shuns remarriage despite being surrounded by starry-eyed couples who haunt the hallway outside his office waiting to be hitched officially. ''I'm a bachelor now and I intend to stay that way until the day I die,'' he states, his cuff links and golden apple tie tack twinkling.

title: U.S. Commander Confirms Search for 2 Top Targets Is Over
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 22 - Acting on a tip from an Iraqi that Saddam Hussein's sons, Uday and Qusay, were holed up in a palatial residence in the northern city of Mosul, United States troops surrounded the house today and killed the two men in a ferocious shootout that gradually shredded the walls providing them cover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIGDERSON, , DOROTHY MARKS
description: WIGDERSON -- Dorothy Marks of Atlanta, Georgia, formerly of Queens and Valley Cottage, New York, on July 17 at age 91. Widow of Henry Wigderson; much loved mother of Jon, Seth, and Kate; caring mother-inlaw of Susan Eller Wigderson, Julie Guard, and Phillip King; beloved grandmother of Adam, Melissa, and Jonathan and Sueann Wigderson, Bronwyn Guard, and Patrick King; great-grandmother of Jonathan and Courtney Wigderson and Jennifer Zagami; and darling sister of Estelle Leontief. She was a unique and special woman, who helped and inspired in many ways: from her early career as a teacher, through her childrearing years, then to a new career as a marriage counselor, and after retirement continuing to read and listen and learn, she became the poet laureate of her retirement residence. Dorothy was a superb human being, accomplished, generous, and loving. She was a dear friend of all she knew and loved. >>AD#

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Lord Archer Is Freed
description: Jeffrey Archer, the millionaire novelist, member of the House of Lords and former Conservative party deputy chairman, was freed after serving half of a four-year sentence for perjury and perverting the course of justice in his 1987 libel trial against a London newspaper that reported he had paid hush money to a prostitute. Lord Archer, 63, went from Hollesby Bay open prison in Suffolk to see his wife, Mary, 58, at the couple's Cambridgeshire mansion and then to London, where he reported to his parole officer and went to his Thameside penthouse apartment. Warren Hoge (NYT)

The mayor discussed the need to replace older power plants, and possibly build new ones, with representatives of the city's power companies, environmentalists, and members of the construction, business and real estate industries.
