title: The Hope of Head Start
description: When the Head Start program began in the summer of 1965, I was in Jackson, Miss., where, along with other black doctors I examined prospective students, because local white doctors were unwilling to do it. Racial tensions made it especially daunting to establish the program, which provides educational and social services to preschool children living at or below the poverty line. Mississippi state officials staunchly opposed the program because most of the students were black and many white parents were intimidated and reluctant to enroll their children. To avoid these problems at the state level, the federal government had to give grants directly to local communities.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON SUES RIVAL OVER COMPETING STENT
description: Johnson & Johnson, the world's top maker of medical devices, has asked a judge to stop the Boston Scientific Corporation from selling a drug-coated stent used to prop open clogged arteries. Johnson & Johnson sought the court order at a pretrial hearing in Wilmington, Del. The company received federal approval in April to sell its Cypher stent in the United States. Boston Scientific is seeking similar approval for its Taxus stent. The companies are suing each other to stop the sale of the rival products.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: A Debt Deadline
description: Korean creditors of SK Global will press for court receivership for the company on Thursday if foreign creditors refuse to accept a proposal for repayment of SK Global debts at 43 percent of their value, a spokesman for the lead creditor, Hana Bank, said. SK Global's domestic creditors will not accept the pleas of foreign creditors for considerably better terms, the spokesman said. If placed under court receivership, SK Global would be freed from immediate obligation to repay debts totaling $8 billion, including almost $2 billion owed to foreign banks. SK Global is the trading division of SK Group, one of Korea's largest conglomerates. Don Kirk (NYT)

description: LEWIS--Harold. The Hunter College Community notes with sorrow the passing of our former Dean, who headed the School of Social Work from 1970 to 1990. Dean Lewis took a fledgling institution and, through his inspired leadership and creative vision, helped it grow into an outstanding urban public school of social work. His intellectual curiosity sparkled both in the classroom and in spirited exchanges with colleagues at the School & at the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences, where he was the first social work Fellow. His unique blend of wisdom, wit & common sense are well-remembered and will be missed by many. We extend our sympathy to his wife Celia, daughters Amy & Beth, and family. Jennifer J. Raab, President Bogart R. Leashore, Dean Faculty and Staff of the School of Social Work

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: NORTHERN IRELAND: GALEN ENDS TALKS Galen Holdings , a Northern Irish pharmaceutical company specializing in contraceptives and women's health care products, said yesterday that it had ended takeover talks with an unidentified suitor, widely reported to be Barr Laboratories , based in New Jersey. Neither company commented on the discussions, which lasted a week. Galen's stock fell 16 percent, to 595 pence, after rising 20 percent on the London stock exchange. During speculation about a deal on Friday, Galen's founder Allen McClay sold 700,000 shares at 7.10 a share.

title: ENRON SETTLES DISPUTE OVER WATER PARTNERSHIP NOTES
description: The Enron Corporation said yesterday that it had settled a legal dispute with noteholders of an off-the-books partnership created to finance a water-treatment unit. Holders of notes in Marlin Water Trust would get about $127.5 million, including collateral held by the Bank of New York as trustee for the noteholders. In exchange, the Bank of New York will reduce its claim against Enron to $507.5 million from $1.1 billion. Enron, which owes creditors about $67 billion, said 69 percent of the Marlin noteholders and a panel of Enron's unsecured creditors support the accord. Judge Arthur J. Gonzalez of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan is scheduled to consider approval of the settlement on Aug. 7, court papers show.

An honor, the rank more importantly meant higher pay for Mr. Wan in his job at a government printing plant.

description: In what was the first trial in almost 30 years in Westchester County in which a defendant might have faced the death penalty, a man convicted of a triple homicide was sentenced yesterday, in effect, to life in prison without the possibility of parole. The man, Dennis Alvarez Hernandez, 25, a native of Honduras, had been convicted of first-degree murder and was sentenced to at least 115 years in prison by Judge Kenneth Lange of Westchester County Court. Mr. Hernandez had admitted in his trial this spring to killing his girlfriend, Patricia Torres; her 7-year-old son, William Santiago; and her 4-year-old daughter, Ashley Dominguez, in a jealous rage on Sept. 3, 2000. Yilu Zhao (NYT)

title: Lean and Hungry Time That Feels Like Today
description: ''Julius Caesar'' is so full of aphorisms and declarations that onstage it often succumbs to pomposity. The play is so concerned with the difference between what men say and what they think as they jockey for power that it is frequently performed with two-faced hyperbole. And it is so determined to illustrate the manipulative nature of politics that in performance it can drip with irony or light up its contemporary relevance in neon. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Lexmark Misses Forecasts; Shares Plunge
description: Shares of Lexmark International, the computer printer maker, fell almost 20 percent yesterday after the company said it would miss profit forecasts for the third quarter because of lower printer prices and less demand for ink refills. Earnings in the third quarter will be 63 cents to 73 cents a share, Lexmark said yesterday as it issued second-quarter results. The company, which makes printers for Dell Inc., was expected to earn 80 cents in Thomson Financial's survey of analysts. Lexmark's estimate is lower because the company has decided to seek more sales of money-losing printers in order to increase demand for its ink cartridges, which yield a continuing revenue stream, the chief financial officer, Gary Morin, said in an interview. Lexmark shares fell $14.10, or about 19 percent, to $59.40.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Retailer's Sales Rise
description: Woolworths Ltd., Australia's largest retailer, has reported record sales for the year to June. Its supermarket and discount store sales increased 12.2 percent, on an adjusted basis, to 26.3 billion Australian dollars ($17 billion). The company will announce its income figures next month. The chief executive, Roger Corbett, said the sales increase was an excellent result, although the company share price fell initially, with analysts saying it was already fully valued. Woolworths revenues rose in all sectors, led by a 56 percent increase in sales at the company's growing network of gasoline outlets. John Shaw (NYT)

description: An article last Wednesday about Scotch whiskey misidentified a band that sang about the Mull of Kintyre, a headland on the west coast of Scotland known for its malts. It was Wings, not the Beatles.

title: Sports of The Times; Armstrong's Coach Saw Ullrich Coming
description: SIX weeks ago, they both saw it coming. The e-mail messages whisking back and forth between Lance Armstrong in Europe and Chris Carmichael in Colorado predicted Armstrong was going to have a rough ride in this year's Tour de France.

title: To Cool Off Czars (Or Comrades)
description: Retreat into a cool cellar, nibble treats from a cabinet labeled ''December'' and feel July's heat dissipate. At Pravda, 281 Lafayette Street (Prince Street), new caviar and vodka set-ups on trays lined with clippings from Russian newspapers are enough to make you reach for your babushka. The Bolshevik tray, $35, far left, offers American hackleback, salmon and golden whitefish roes, with chilled Polish, English and American vodkas. For $115, the Romanoff tray has Russian sevruga, osetra and beluga caviars and Russian vodkas. The caviars are accompanied by potato pancakes and crme frache. A tray easily serves two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, , HAROLD
description: LEWIS--Harold. The Board of the Lois and Samuel Silberman Fund is deeply saddened by the passing of Dr. Harold Lewis. We were privileged to have been the beneficiaries of his insight, creativity and wit for more than 30 years. Dr. Lewis was a dynamic force in the development of professional social work education, and though his contributions are lasting, the field has lost a true scholar and invaluable friend. We extend our condolences to his wife Celia and their two daughters, Amy and Beth. Anne P. Sidamon-Eristoff, Chairman Jayne M. Silberman, Vice Chairman Lois V. Silberman, Trustee Emerita

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRENNAN, , VALERIE CLAIRE
description: BRENNAN -- Valerie Claire. Beloved mother, wonderful grandmother, inspiring friend and devoted co - worker, passed away in her sleep on July 20, 2003. She is survived by two children, Deborah & John and three grandchildren. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10AM, St. Thomas More, 65 E 89 St. Friends may call Wednesday 2-4 & 6-8PM, Frank E. Campbell - The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. >>AD#

title: Hussein's 2 Sons Dead in Shootout, U.S. Says
description: Acting on a tip from an Iraqi that Saddam Hussein's sons, Uday and Qusay, were holed up in a palatial residence in the northern city of Mosul, United States troops surrounded the house today and killed the two men in a ferocious shootout that gradually shredded the walls providing them cover.

title: Private Lynch Comes Back Home To a Celebration Fit for a Hero
description: Pfc. Jessica D. Lynch, whose ordeal as a wounded prisoner of war in Iraq made her a symbol of American bravery -- and also stirred complaints of Pentagon media manipulation -- returned to a hero's homecoming in this tiny Appalachian town today.

title: QUEST DIAGNOSTICS CUTS PROFIT FORECAST FOR YEAR
description: Quest Diagnostics Inc., the medical laboratory company, cut 2003 profit estimates yesterday, saying that fewer people are able to afford its tests as the ranks of the uninsured and unemployed swell. Profit this year will be $4 to $4.10 a share, excluding costs related to the purchase of the Unilab Corporation, Quest said. That is down from an April estimate of as much as $4.20. The company's shares fell $4.87, or 7.6 percent, to $59.56. Quest, which is based in Teterboro, N.J., also said second-quarter net income increased to $120.4 million, or $1.12 a share, from $87.2 million, or 87 cents, in the same period a year earlier. That was in line with the estimates of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call.

title: AOL Results Marred by Subscriber Loss and Accounting Questions
description: AOL Time Warner reported better than expected results for the second quarter today, but they were marred by an unexpectedly steep decline in subscribers at its AOL division and persistent criticism of its accounting from securities regulators.

title: University Presidents Rally Against B.C.S.
description: The president of Tulane, Scott S. Cowen, said yesterday that a coalition of 44 university presidents who feel frozen out of the Bowl Championship Series was not ruling out any options in trying to get rid of it, including a lawsuit claiming antitrust violations.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Bid For Property Fund Raised
description: Investa, an Australian listed property trust, has stepped up its attempt to buy the Principal Office Fund. Investa has increased its bid to 2 billion Australian dollars ($1.3 billion) from 1.8 billion Australian dollars ($1.2 billion) and has pushed back the extended date to Aug. 4. Investa also said it had raised its stake to 21 percent of the fund, which is based in Sydney and is an associate of the Principal Group, a property and finance company based in Des Moines. The Principal Fund, which controls 12 major office buildings in Australia, has take a defensive measure against the proposed takeover by expanding its portfolio of property in the United States. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Yips, the Curse of Golfers, Are Put to the Test
description: Sixteen golfers, and good golfers at that, wandered through lush grass here today, putting and missing, putting and missing. They tapped the simplest putts well beyond the holes, left others far short and sent some golf balls whizzing off in puzzling directions.

title: A second scent is hitched to the fortunes of a Hollywood star.
description: THE image of Jennifer Lopez, nearly omnipresent in gossip and news reports this summer with talk of weddings and business breakups, will grow yet more pervasive this fall as the ad campaign begins for a second perfume under her name.

title: INSIDE
description: Debate Over Liberia

Palm Beach, FL

title: Nicolas Freeling, 76, Dies; Set Novels in Modern Europe
description: Nicolas Freeling, the British detective novelist whose popular Inspector Van der Valk and later Detective Henri Castang unmasked crime in modern Europe, died on Sunday in France, the London press reported. He was 76 and lived in Schirmeck, a village in Alsace.

description: GARSON--Milton. Dearly beloved husband and best friend of Frances M. (Frank), devoted father of the late Geoffrey. Very dear grandfather of Lisa B. Garson. Services will be held on Thursday July 24, 2003 at 1:30 P.M. at Riversville Cemetery, Glenville, CT. >>AD#

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Store Names Bidder
description: Debenhams, the British department store chain, said that private equity investors CVC Capital Partners and the Texas Pacific Group have approached it about a buyout. The company said in May that it had received an offer from Permira Advisers. On June 29, Debenhams said that a second party was interested in a deal, but did not name its suitor. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This will prove to the Iraqi people that at least these two members of the regime will not be coming back into power.''

title: Basic Skills Forcing Cuts In Art Classes
description: Under pressure to find time for the extra English and math classes required by the Education Department's new standardized curriculum, the city's junior high schools are slashing art, music and other electives, an unintended cost in the push to help students master basic skills.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Saturday about the damage to the public image of Kobe Bryant of the Los Angeles Lakers after his arrest on a sexual assault charge misidentified the team that chose him in the 1996 N.B.A. player draft. It was the Charlotte Hornets, who then traded him to the Lakers.

title: Bus Parking Garage Proposed Near Trade Center
description: Hoping to settle a dispute with the families of Sept. 11 victims, officials involved in the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan said yesterday that they had found an alternative site to park the buses that will bring tourists to the World Trade Center memorial.

title: Free-Trade Cure Isn't Working
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Lehman to Buy Neuberger Berman For $2.6 Billion
description: In a bid to join the ranks of the large Wall Street firms, Lehman Brothers said yesterday that it would acquire Neuberger Berman, a money management firm catering to wealthy individuals, for $2.6 billion in cash and stock.

title: At Age 46, Orosco Is Joining the Yanks
description: Three days after their annual Old-Timers' Day, the Yankees obtained a player last night who is older than many of those who were on hand at Yankee Stadium last Saturday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz's tour of Iraq gave an incorrect day in some copies for a protest by Shiite Muslims against American forces in Najaf. It was Sunday, not Monday.

title: These Tools Are Angling For Advantage At the Stove
description: Offset handles on knives and utensils are more than a matter of good looks. When the handle and the end of the tool are set on different planes, it is easier to keep your hand out of the way when you are slicing a loaf of bread, lifting fish out of a pan, turning pancakes or handling freshly baked cakes and cookies. A wood-handle bread knife, second from top, is $74.95 at Broadway Panhandler. The store also has cake spatulas, third from top, in several sizes ($2.25 to $7.65). The fish lifter, bottom, is $18 from www.williams-sonoma.com and will be in Williams-Sonoma stores in a few weeks. It is available for right or left hands. The small Teflon spatula, top, is $6 at Williams-Sonoma now. Professional Cutlery Direct, 242 Branford Road, North Branford, Conn., also sells a number of offset-handle knives in its store and online from www.shopping.cutlery.com.

title: At This Camp, You Tell Your Child To Break a Leg
description: So much to learn and so little time for the stage-struck youngsters, from ages 10 to 17, at Camp Broadway, a weeklong immersion in the thrills and heartbreaks of a career in musical theater. The energy of a big ensemble song comes from accentuating the final consonants, like those T's in ''They say the neon lights are bright on Broadway.'' Even a chorus member, a cowboy in ''Oklahoma'' or a peasant in ''Fiddler on the Roof'' must stay in character. Step-stomp-twist-twist-twist is a dance step that is harder than it looks. Stage makeup must be a shade darker than skin tone and fake eyelashes must be glued tight. Forget the words to an audition song? Keep singing! Go to the bathroom before the show starts and then hold it. And have a backup career plan as well as a vocal coach, an agent and a plan to move from Podunk to New York City. Down the hall, in the Chelsea Studios that is Camp Broadway's home for two weeks this summer, seasoned actresses auditioning for bit parts in ''Little Shop of Horrors'' still pay the rent by teaching aerobics.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WELLS FARGO & CO., San Francisco, said it increased its dividend from 30 cents a share to 45 cents a share, payable Sept. 1 to stockholders of record on Aug. 8.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business yesterday about an effort by Saudi Arabia to revive foreign interest in its natural gas fields included an outdated reference to a French company that had been negotiating with the country. It is Total S.A., not TotalFinaElf.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Wednesday about a study finding that 10 percent of newly infected AIDS patients in Europe have drug-resistant strains of the virus referred incorrectly to the status of a new class of drugs, fusion inhibitors, which was not part of the study. One such drug, Fuzeon, made by Roche Laboratories Inc., was approved by the Food and Drug Administration in March. It is not still in the testing stage.

title: Rock Idol's Legacy Devolves Into Family Feud
description: Elvis lives -- maybe. But Jimi Hendrix is definitely dead, and has been for 33 years. Even his most devoted fans accept that.

title: In Patagonia, Sheep Ranches Get Another Chance
description: Patagonia was first tamed a century ago by hardy pioneer families who established vast sheep ranches like this one to supply voracious markets in Europe and the United States with mutton and wool. Now, after a decade-long crisis that nearly wiped out both those industries here, Patagonia's producers are reclaiming their birthright.

title: Haute Meets Bistro With Bobby Short Nearby
description: WHEN the restaurant at the Carlyle Hotel reopened last spring, with a new chef and a new look, it was all dressed up with no place to go. It was overdecorated and fussy, with too many floral arrangements. The carpet pattern was too busy. The menu wandered hither and yon, determined to suggest luxury no matter what, like a nouveau riche flashing too many diamonds. The service was stiff and not welcoming. The Carlyle offered a study in how much a restaurant's success depends on hitting the right tone.

title: AOL Results Marred by Subscriber Loss and Accounting Questions
description: AOL Time Warner reported better than expected results for the second quarter today, but they were marred by an unexpectedly steep decline in subscribers at its AOL division and persistent criticism of its accounting from securities regulators.

title: Hotel bombings tied to Basque separatists : Two blasts wound 13 in Spain
description: MADRID:  Two bombs planted in beachfront hotels on Spain's Mediterranean coast exploded Tuesday, wounding 13 people, including foreign students, tourists and police officers.

title: Charles Myers, 92, Ex-Chairman Of Burlington Industries
description: Charles F. Myers Jr., a former chairman and chief executive of Burlington Industries, died on Sunday at Wellspring Retirement Center in Greensboro, N.C. He was 92.

title: Compromise Plan Is Offered To Widen Child Tax Credit
description: Senate Republicans offered a compromise to the House today intended to end the stalemate blocking an expansion of the child tax credit to low-income families, but Democrats said the proposal's benefits for wealthier families were too expensive to pass.

title: Bliss From the South: A Chef's Grand Legacy
description: IT was the spring of 1985. Keen young cooks in cities all across the country were reviving and rejuvenating American regional cooking.

title: Moves Planned On Leadership At CIT Group
description: Jeffrey M. Peek, who was a top contender for chief executive at Merrill Lynch in 2001 and joined Credit Suisse First Boston last year as a potential successor to its chief, is moving to the CIT Group, where he will be in the running to take over, people close to CIT said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Report On Journalist
description: The hard-line newspaper Jomhouri Eslami, close to the supreme religious leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, suggested in an editorial that Zahra Kazemi, the Iranian-Canadian journalist who died in custody, might have hit her head herself against a wall to cause trouble for prison authorities or interrogators. The new allegation came after the judiciary appointed a hard-line judge, Saeed Mortazavi, who was also involved in interrogating Ms. Kazemi, to investigate the case. A government report said that Ms. Kazemi, 54, died of a brain hemorrhage from a blow to the head. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Deflation Worsens
description: Prices in Hong Kong fell for the 56th consecutive month, as the consumer price index was 3.1 percent lower in June than it was a year earlier. Tourists and other travelers continued to shun the Chinese territory despite the disappearance of severe acute respiratory syndrome, while a one-time rebate by a power company and a continued decline in apartment rents contributed to the drop. Unemployment rose to 8.6 percent for April through June, hurting demand and prices. The price index had been 2.5 percent lower in May than a year earlier. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: 9/11 Payment Issues Are Argued in Appeal
description: A small army of lawyers took the long-running battle over insurance claims at the World Trade Center to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit yesterday as they argued over issues that will determine how much money is available for rebuilding the vast commercial complex.

title: Children's Agency Chief Eyes New Guidelines
description: The new director of New Jersey's troubled Division of Youth and Family Services, Edward E. Cotton, said today, his second day on the job, that caseworkers needed detailed guidelines in neglect and abuse cases like those he developed when he oversaw child protection programs in Illinois.

title: Roche in Advanced Negotiations to Acquire Igen
description: Roche Holding, the Swiss pharmaceutical giant, is in advanced talks to acquire Igen International, both companies said today. Neither company would give details.

title: Rigidity in Florida And the Results
description: DEREK ADAMSON is a good student at Citrus Elementary in Ocoee, Fla., but he did not pass the state reading test, the FCAT, required for promotion to fourth grade. He was not alone. This spring, 23 percent of Florida third graders, or 43,000 youngsters, failed the test and, under the state's new retention policy, were slated to be held back.

title: In Rituals Of Soloists, A Global Heartbeat
description: Ever since modern dance came into being in the early 20th century, many of its leading choreographers have been fascinated by the expressive power and immediacy of the solo.

title: Send in the Peace Corps
description: Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld's dreams of a leaner and meaner military, a smaller yet more modernized force, are in jeopardy. Faced with continued resistance in Iraq and peacekeeping duties in Afghanistan, Pentagon officials are now considering proposals to expand and restructure American forces amid fears that longer deployments will result in an overextended military.

title: Butting Heads With the Pentagon
description: There is no better friend of the Pentagon than Duncan Hunter, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. A conservative and a hawk on defense, Mr. Hunter has long been someone the military could count on to push its dream projects through Congress.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Tourism Official Resigns
description: The president of the Hawaii Visitors and Convention Bureau, Tony Vericella, has resigned weeks after a state audit that questioned the organization's accounting practices and use of state money. The visitors bureau holds a one-year $33 million contract to market the state of Hawaii, said Rex Johnson, president of the Hawaii Tourism Authority. Ten bidders, including the bureau, are competing for a four-year contract valued at $25 million annually.

title: Iraqis Wait to See U.S. Proof That Hussein Sons Are Dead
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 23 — The United States holds irrefutable proof that Saddam Hussein's sons are dead — including dental records and visual confirmation from four of the deposed dictator's aides — but a skeptical Iraqi public held out today for photographs and the occupying authority did not broadcast them.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Bellmawr: Troopers Kill Fleeing Suspect
description: After a chase, state troopers fatally shot a man Monday night whom they had suspected of stealing a car, the authorities said yesterday. The man, whose name was not released, was driving south on Route 295 when he crashed into a highway divider, said Sgt. Kevin Rehmann, a spokesman for the state police. He fled on foot into a wooded area near Bellmawr Borough, Sergeant Rehmann said. Troopers followed and shot him. It was unclear how many troopers were involved, how many shots were fired or if the man had had a weapon, Sergeant Rehmann said. An autopsy is scheduled for today. John Holl (NYT)

title: Allegations range from simple bribes to stock swindles : Music scandal rocks Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG:  A widening music industry scandal has transformed Hong Kong's top of the pops into a Ten Most Wanted list.

title: Putting Funny Business Into Reality Cop Shows
description: Television parody can be the easiest form of comedy, and sometimes also the hardest -- it requires viewers so familiar with a certain genre of show that they will know instantly what is being tweaked.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an announcement by Gov. Gary Locke of Washington that he would not seek re-election misstated the surname of a Democratic consultant who said the decision was politically surprising. He is Blair Butterworth, not Butterfield.

title: U.S. to Outline 60-Day Plan For Iraq Rebuilding Projects
description: The top American civilian administrator in Iraq is to announce on Wednesday a 60-day plan for that nation, including restoring power to prewar levels, resuming criminal courts, awarding mobile-telephone licenses, and distributing revised textbooks to newly opened schools.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Film Industry Begins Antipiracy Campaign
description: Using their own extensive communications outlets to campaign against digital piracy, the major motion picture companies are planning a blitz of television ads and movie trailers on the theme of respecting copyright law. A 30-second television advertisement will run tomorrow night on all the broadcast networks and many cable channels during their first prime-time break, shortly after 8 p.m. Starting Friday, more than 5,000 theaters across the country will show daily trailers featuring individuals who work in the motion picture industry, describing how online piracy threatens their livelihood. The Motion Picture Association of America has also developed a Web site, www.respectcopyrights.org, and a Digital Citizenship program intended for use in classrooms. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: The Brothers Grim
description: Few Iraqis will mourn the deaths of Saddam Hussein's two sons, Uday and Qusay. Like their father, they were mercurial, cruel killers who terrorized and plundered their country so they could live in imperial style. The word from American commanders in Iraq yesterday that the Hussein brothers had been killed in a firefight with American troops in the northern Iraqi city of Mosul was the most encouraging news out of Iraq in weeks. If American forces can now track down Saddam Hussein himself, Iraqis may finally begin to believe that the dictator and his clan will not someday storm back into power.

title: Buy.com Chief Starts Site To Sell Music Downloads
description: Scott Blum, the chief executive of the online retailer Buy.com, yesterday unveiled a new Web site, BuyMusic.com, which will sell music downloads to Windows users. The service, which is not affiliated with Buy.com, seeks to capitalize on the popularity of iTunes, the music service that Apple Computer introduced in April.

title: National Briefing: West
description: HAWAII: TOURISM OFFICIAL RESIGNS The president of the Hawaii Visitors and Convention Bureau, Tony Vericella, has resigned weeks after a state audit that questioned the organization's accounting practices and use of state money. The visitors bureau holds a one-year $33 million contract to market the state of Hawaii, said Rex Johnson, president of the Hawaii Tourism Authority. Ten bidders, including the bureau, are competing for a four-year contract valued at $25 million annually.

title: Report of Beating by an Officer Is Investigated
description: The Hudson County district attorney said today that he was investigating an encounter last week in which an off-duty Weehawken police officer is said to have beaten a 17-year-old who is now in critical condition and on life support at Jersey City Medical Center.

title: Some Bloomberg Money, But No Dung in Venice
description: How mayoral tastes change.

title: BOEING TO REVAMP ITS LAUNCH AND SATELLITE UNITS
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it would revamp its satellite and launching businesses to cut costs. ''The commercial space market has eroded to a point where it is no longer a driving factor in either our satellite or launch services business,'' Jim Albaugh, president and chief executive of Boeing Integrated Defense Systems, said. Boeing will fold Boeing Satellite Systems into Space and Intelligent Systems. Expendable Launch Systems, which has become primarily a supplier to the Air Force, will be aligned with Air Force Systems. Rocketdyne Power and Propulsion will become part of NASA Systems. Boeing expects the moves to have a minimal effect on employment.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Old Bottles, New Wine

title: McEwing's Home Run Is for Real
description: Memories of Wiffle ball games came back to Joe McEwing a lot in the last two days. The Mets just played two games at Veterans Stadium, and a pretend Vet was always the setting for those boyhood Wiffle ball games.

title: Knicks Are Set to Deal Sprewell and Acquire Van Horn
description: For more than a year, the Knicks have dangled Latrell Sprewell around the league, looking for a taker. For nearly as long, the Knicks have flirted with the prospect of acquiring Philadelphia's Keith Van Horn. Both goals may soon be accomplished in one bold move.

title: A Song of Love for Celia
description: Among my most treasured possessions are the Christmas cards that I have received from Celia Cruz and her husband, Pedro Knight, in the past 10 years. As the envelopes bear an elegant penmanship, I'd like to think that they had been addressed by Celia herself. That she would take the time out from her busy life to extend a holiday greeting to a writer whom she had only occasionally encountered over the years speaks volumes about the generosity of her spirit and of her giving, affectionate nature.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Deadly Raids In Kashmir
description: After a lull that had raised hopes for peace in the disputed region of Jammu and Kashmir, Islamic separatists struck twice in spectacular raids at an Indian army base and an annual Hindu pilgrimage, killing a total of 14 people. The attacks came as a leading member of the religious opposition in Pakistan, Faisal ur-Rahman, was meeting with Hindu politicians in India and had publicly suggested that the de facto border called the Line of Control become permanent, effectively putting the territory under Indian control. According to the Press Trust of India, three militants crept into the army base, in Jammu, killing eight soldiers, including a brigadier general, and wounding two other top army generals in a second attack. Earlier, Islamists struck the pilgrimage, killing six people. A group calling itself the Shuda Brigade claimed responsibility for the army attack, saying it was in response to Mr. Rahman's statements.

title: National Security Aide Says He's to Blame for Speech Error
description: President Bush's deputy national security adviser accepted blame today for allowing faulty intelligence to appear in the president's State of the Union speech. He took responsibility after revealing that the Central Intelligence Agency had sent him two memorandums warning that evidence about Iraqi efforts to obtain uranium in Africa was weak.

title: About New York; Claws Over Broadway
description: A REVOLVING 10-foot lobster now adorns Times Square, its gaudy red neon beckoning passers-by to come in, come in, you know you want to come in. Fried popcorn shrimp. Artichoke lobster dip. Come in, the theater can wait. There will be other trains. It's ''endless crab'' season; all you can eat.

title: Defending Champion To Race in Manhattan
description: Ivn Domnguez of Cuba, last year's winner, will return to compete in the BMC Software New York City Cycling Championship through the streets of Lower Manhattan on Aug. 3.

title: Schumer Strikes Deal on Filling Court Vacancies
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer said yesterday that he had reached an agreement with Gov. George E. Pataki and the White House to end a long-running partisan impasse that had stalled the approval of judges for the federal courts in New York.

title: Hearst Names New Editor in Chief for Seventeen Magazine
description: Atoosa Rubenstein, who had been editor in chief of CosmoGirl, a teenage publication started by Hearst Magazines in 1999, will become editor in chief of Seventeen magazine, the teenage magazine that Hearst purchased for $180 million from Primedia Inc. in April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAKER, , WILLIAM
description: BAKER--William, he was the owner of Chicago Maintenance Corporation, died at 87 on July 17, 2003. He is survived by his wife Dina, his daughters Ellen Baker, Mrs. Sharon Slotnick, and his four grandchildren. >>AD#

title: Amazon Cuts Its Loss as Sales Increase
description: Amazon.com, citing a sharp increase in sales, said yesterday that it cut its loss in half for the second quarter. The company, the largest general retailer on the Internet, said its strategy of discount prices and free shipping was the largest contributor to its growth.

title: For Brutality, Hussein's Sons Exceeded Even Their Father
description: Though very different from each other yet equally despised and feared by Iraqis, Uday and Qusay Hussein -- Saddam's two eldest sons -- personified the terror of their father's rule.

description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Priest Suspended After Sex Abuse Accusation
description: Cardinal Edward M. Egan has suspended a Westchester pastor who has been accused of sexually abusing a minor at least 20 years ago, the Archdiocese of New York said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISSMAN, , GENE
description: WEISSMAN--Gene. On July 19th, 2003. Beloved son of Herbert and Marianne Weissman. Cherished step-son of Martha L. Weissman. Loving brother of Ashleigh N. Weissman. Cherished nephew of Lee Marks, Gordon and Martha Gutmann. Cousin of Joe Paul Gutmann, and Mimi Murray. He was a Specialist Clerk with Frank Santangelo and Co., a member of the American Stock Exchange, and partner in Lieber & Weissman Co., LLC. Devoted supporter of Variety-The Children's Charity. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name can be made to Variety-The Children's Charity, 350 Fifth Avenue, NY NY 10018, Ste 1234. The service will take place, Wednesday, July 23rd, at 11:00AM at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St, NYC. For information, ''The Riverside'', 212-362-6600

title: Saratoga, Anticipating a Rematch, Opens Today
description: In Ireland, the bookmakers and their blackboards are on their way to Galway Race Course with plenty of punters in tow. In France, horsemen and horseplayers have migrated to Deauville for mornings by the seaside and afternoons at l'hippodrome. But for the next six weeks, the center of the thoroughbred racing universe will be this Victorian-style village in upstate New York.

title: Private Equity Deals Are Again the Talk of Europe
description: All the big names in leveraged buyouts are on the prowl for deals in Europe. But the going is not easy.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: IRAN: REPORT ON JOURNALIST The hard-line newspaper Jomhouri Eslami, close to the supreme religious leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, suggested in an editorial that Zahra Kazemi, the Iranian-Canadian journalist who died in custody, might have hit her head herself against a wall to cause trouble for prison authorities or interrogators. The new allegation came after the judiciary appointed a hard-line judge, Saeed Mortazavi, who was also involved in interrogating Ms. Kazemi, to investigate the case. A government report said that Ms. Kazemi, 54, died of a brain hemorrhage from a blow to the head. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Bush Team Faces Widespread Pressure to Act on Liberia
description: Three weeks after signaling it might send American troops to Liberia as part of an international peacekeeping operation, the Bush administration today disputed any suggestion that it was deliberately delaying a decision even as the Liberian capital of Monrovia endured another violent day.

title: Cabbies on Cellphones
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Subpoena For Kevorkian
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian, who is serving a 10- to 25-year sentence for assisting a 1998 suicide, has been subpoenaed to give a deposition next week as an expert witness on the effects of mercury and chloride exposure on humans, his lawyer said. Dr. Kevorkian's 1972 and 1974 studies on the effects of such exposure are being used in the lawsuit of a North Carolina man who says he became ill after being exposed to metallic mercury, chlorine gas and other hazardous chemicals while working at a Honeywell International plant. Caitlin Nish (NYT)

title: TENET HEALTHCARE NAMES EDWARD KANGAS CHAIRMAN
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation, which is under investigation by at least three federal agencies, said yesterday that it had named Edward A. Kangas as its chairman, succeeding Jeffrey C. Barbakow, who resigned in May. Mr. Kangas, 59, joined Tenet's board in April. He is a former chairman and chief executive of the accounting firm Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu. Tenet, based in Santa Barbara, Calif., announced last week that the government was examining the way it recruits physicians at its hospitals.

title: Media Rule Appears In Jeopardy in House
description: Big media conglomerates had hoped that the House of Representatives would kill the growing political efforts to overturn their recent deregulation. But in a surprising political development, the House now appears poised to support the reversal of a new rule that permits the nation's biggest TV networks to grow even larger.

title: Locations: 6 Great Tacos for $2 or Less
description: ALMOST every Mexican neighborhood in New York City has a few delis or groceries that conceal taquerias, like these six. Most are open all day, from breakfast until after dinner, and all are inexpensive, $2 or so for a taco. The selections are modest, but almost always expand on the weekends.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about group shows in New York City this summer misspelled the surname of an artist whose work is being shown in the ''2003 Summer Program'' at Apex Art in TriBeCa. He is Nate Lowman, not Loman.

title: Relaxed Tappers Let Their Feet Do Most of the Talking
description: Tap City 2003 got off to a perfect start last Wednesday night with a gala performance at the Duke on 42nd Street that said it all in a laid back kind of way. The dancers' individual styles, the relaxed staging and the genial patter of the tapmeister Tony Waag, who organizes this annual festival, showed that this distinctively American art form not only has a history but is alive and well in all its improvisational glory.

title: A Fire Atop the Eiffel Tower Startles Paris and Its Tourists
description: An electrical fire briefly engulfed a top corner of the Eiffel Tower today, startling tourists and alarming people across the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUNNE, , BRO. JAMES P., S.J.
description: DUNNE--Bro. James P., S.J., On July 14, 2003 in Manila, Philippines. Missionary for the past 37 years in San Pablo and Manila, Philippines. Survived by his loving brothers Richard and his wife Sarvia and Robert & his wife Cecilia. Also survived by three nephews. Mass and burial were held in Manila, Philippines. Donations in his memory may be made out to ''Days with the Lord'' C/O Robert Dunne, 545 N. 3rd St., New Hyde Park, New York 11040. >>AD#

title: Importing Inexpensive Drugs
description: The House of Representatives is expected to vote this week on a bill that would allow wholesalers, pharmacists and individuals to import inexpensive prescription drugs from Canada, Europe and other advanced nations. As American consumers have come to learn, the United States is virtually the only developed industrial country that does not impose price controls on drugs. People can find it cheaper to buy medicine across the border or overseas and transport it to the United States than to get the same drugs at a local pharmacy.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARDNER, , DORIS (NEE MARCUS, WOLFSON)
description: GARDNER--Doris (nee Marcus-Wolfson). Formerly of Rockville Ctr, NY, Ft. Lauderdale, Fl and Toronto, Canada. Devoted wife of the late Earl and the late Aaron Wolfson. Loving mother and motherin-law of Joyce Jed and Arnold Wendroff, Jane Wolfson and John Miller, Denise and Donald Wolfson, Zita and the late Allen Gardner, Terry and Bob Gardner, and Diane and Gary Shiffman. Cherished grandmother of 14 grandchildren and 10 great-grandchildren. Donations in her memory to Cancer Research and Treatment Foundations would be appreciated. >>AD#

title: California Recall Backer Feels Heat
description: Most Californians have never heard of Darrell Issa, the millionaire congressman who is bankrolling the effort to recall Gov. Gray Davis. But chances are, many know his voice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHMAN, , EDWARD M.
description: ROTHMAN--Edward M. Poppy will be missed by all of us, but most especially by his five loving grandchildren, Alissa, Meredith, Rachel, Stephanie, and Matt, who all adored him. Howard, Jeanette, and Judy Schapiro

title: Korean Traditions, Spiked With Jalapeo
description: In Korea, sushi rolls made without raw fish are called kim bop. At Kofoo, a new, cool, green shop at 334 Eighth Avenue (27th Street) that's barely an armspan wide, assorted kim bop are freshly made while you wait. There are traditional fillings like kimchi pickles, vegetables and bulgogi beef, plus less typical ones like spicy tuna, American cheese and jalapeo. Each order, $4, has a dozen slices. Young Jee, the owner, right, shows off another of the shop's specialties, bibimbap, $6. She also sells udon noodles in broth, ($5) and jap chae noodles and vegetables ($6).

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Middletown: Church Vandalized
description: Three teenage girls have been accused of painting racial slurs and anti-Semitic symbols on a recreation center and a fence near a Roman Catholic church, Police Chief John F. Pollinger said yesterday. The girls, two 15-year-olds and a 16-year-old, have not been formally charged, the chief said. Whether they will face charges for a bias crime has yet to be determined, he said. The vandalism occurred near St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church between Saturday and Monday, he said. The teenage stepbrother of one of the girls is also accused of desecrating a statue of the Virgin Mary at the same church last week. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Computer Associates Chief Declines Bonus
description: The chief executive of Computer Associates International, Sanjay Kumar, has declined a $1.02 million bonus for the fiscal year ended in March and has asked that the money be distributed among other executives of his software company. Mr. Kumar, 41, received a salary of $1 million for a second consecutive year, and stock options valued at $13.3 million, the company said in its proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Kumar, who took over as chairman from the founder Charles Wang in November, is trying to increase sales amid a decline in corporate spending on computer technology. He also did not receive bonuses he was eligible for in the 2001 and 2002 fiscal years. Mr. Kumar, Mr. Wang and the vice president, Russell Artz, agreed in 2000 to return $200 million of a $1 billion stock award after investors sued. Computer Associates, the world's fifth-largest software company, will report fiscal first-quarter earnings today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACOBSON, , DAVID ALAN
description: JACOBSON--David Alan, on July 18, 2003 in Los Angeles. Beloved son of Beverly Greenberg Jacobson and Julius H. Jacobson II. Beloved brother of Regina, Wendy, Janet and William. Funeral service Wednesday 12:45pm at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St & Amsterdam Ave. >>AD#

title: Free-Trade Cure Isn't Working (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Lewis Prepares Himself And His Jets Understudy
description: There will be a time, probably soon, when Mo Lewis will have turned over all his knowledge about playing linebacker in the National Football League to Victor Hobson, the player the Jets drafted in the second round this year to succeed him. Then Lewis will walk away.

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: PENNSYLVANIA: PHILANTHROPIST DONATES A KIDNEY A real estate investor who has given away much of his fortune donated a kidney to a stranger, saying it was "the moral thing to do." The philanthropist, Zell Kravinsky, left, had the surgery at Albert Einstein Medical Center, which selected the woman who received the kidney. The hospital declined to release details about the recipient, but Mr. Kravinsky specified that he wanted the kidney to go to someone who was poor and black. (AP)

title: Liberian Says He'll Leave in 10 Days; Fighting Eases
description: President Charles G. Taylor tonight offered the most specific timetable for his promised departure. Rebels here also said they had ordered their troops to stop attacks, after four days of shelling and gunfire that the government estimated had killed more than 600 people.

title: An Impulse Purchase, An Abiding Pleasure
description: A GOOD supper simply made is one true pleasure of the home cook. Most days, this means nothing more than rummaging around the refrigerator or store shelves for a few felicitous ingredients that can be put together quickly. But even when a little more effort is required -- a trip to a specialty store, say -- it's important to feel that the quiet choreography of the kitchen isn't turning into an all-out singing, dancing, stress-inducing show.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bill Seeks Housing Protection
description: The City Council plans to introduce legislation today that would expand protections for middle-income tenants of city-subsidized housing developments built under the Mitchell-Lama program in the 1960's and early 1970's. The proposed bill would require owners who want to remove their buildings from the program and charge higher rents to give 18 months' notice to tenants, instead of the 12 months currently required. The bill would also direct the city's Housing Preservation and Development Department to undertake a community impact study of a proposed building conversion to assess, among other things, how many tenants would be forced to move. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank's Profit Falls
description: Hana Bank, South Korea's third-largest lender, said yesterday that profit in the first six months had declined 30 percent, largely because of the credit it had extended to SK Global, the debt-ridden trading firm for the SK Group, the country's third-biggest conglomerate. Hana, SK Global's largest creditor, reported a profit of 159.1 billion won ($135 million) from January through June, down from 226.7 billion won ($193 million) in the period a year earlier. The bank has had to set aside 521.2 billion won ($444 million) to cover its loans to SK Global, whose debts total about $8 billion. The bank predicted, however, that its takeover earlier of SeoulBank would contribute to a turnaround in the second half. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the call by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg for a ban on spending in the debate on nonpartisan elections misstated the name of a polling firm hired by the state Democratic Party. It is the Global Strategy Group, not Strategies.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Stiffer Penalties For Young Killers
description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday signed into law a bill requiring stiffer sentences for teenagers convicted of murder after being tried as adults. The governor said, ''When you are 14 or 15 and commit a murder, you know what you are doing.'' Under the old law, a judge could sentence a juvenile murderer tried as an adult to a maximum of nine years to life, making him eligible for parole after nine years. The new statute raises that maximum to 15 years to life. It applies only to people 14 or 15 who a judge has decided should stand trial as adults. The minimum sentence for such defendants also went up as the governor signed the bill, to 7 1/2 years to life from 5 years to life. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: COLGATE-PALMOLIVE PROFIT RISES 10% ON STRONG SALES
description: Colgate-Palmolive said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings increased 10 percent, bolstered by higher sales in Europe and demand for new products. Net income was $359.8 million, or 62 cents a share, compared with $327 million, or 55 cents, a year earlier, Colgate said. Revenue increased 7 percent to $2.46 billion. Colgate gained sales from rivals including Procter & Gamble in the domestic toothpaste market, and introduced whitening products in countries including Spain and Hungary. Sales in North America rose 7.5 percent, buoyed by new products including Herbal White toothpaste.

title: Weapons Of Mass Redaction
description: This correspondence from the Office of the Vice President to the XXXXX XXXXXX ambassador to the U.S. was redacted by the Office of the Vice President for national and electoral security reasons:

title: Not Your Usual Osteria Serving Wild Boar
description: TOSS a handful of salt on a map of the East Village, and chances are every grain will land on the site of an Italian restaurant. Though the neighborhood has for years been saturated with trattorias, osterias and such, the last year has seen a surprising surge in new restaurants offering the old siren song of cheap pasta and Italian style.

title: Klitschko Cleared by Doctor
description: Only four weeks after receiving 60 stitches for a gash over his left eye, Vitali Klitschko was cleared to box by an independent medical expert yesterday, making a rematch against the heavyweight champion, Lennox Lewis, a strong possibility.

title: The True Flavors of Mexico, Hidden in New York
description: THE grocery Hidalgo Mexican Food Products looks as if it could as easily be in a courtyard in Cuernavaca as on a nondescript block in Astoria, Queens. The shelves are lined with avocado leaves and chilies. Small bags of dried herbs share the aisles with cans of beans, sacks of tortillas and racy comic books in Spanish. Bundles of fresh epazote leaves are stacked next to a cash register.

title: Corrections
description: A list of American military deaths yesterday identified the units of two soldiers incompletely. Sgt. Jason D. Jordan and Sgt. Justin W. Garvey were both with the First Battalion, 187th Infantry.

title: Troops in Iraq, But Not Liberia
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Attacks At Air Force Academy
description: Two accusations of weekend sexual assaults involving male cadets at the Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs are under investigation, academy officials said. They declined further comment. One case was reported to the Colorado Springs police because it involved a civilian woman; a police spokesman said there had been no arrests. Earlier this year, dozens of women came forward to say that their complaints of sexual assault at the academy had been ignored. The freshman class of 2007 is on campus for basic training; upperclassmen are on a summer rotation. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Administration Voices Concern Over Pace of Medicare Talks
description: Bush administration officials acknowledged today that negotiations on a bill adding prescription drugs to Medicare were taking longer than expected, and they urged Congress to keep striving for a compromise between the House and the Senate.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Drop For Electronics Maker
description: LG Electronics Inc., the electronics maker, said yesterday that second-quarter profit fell 24 percent after the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome slowed cellphone sales in China. The manufacturer, the biggest unit by sales of LG Group, had net income of 258 billion won ($218 million), down from 341 billion won a year ago. Operating profit dropped 38 percent, to 265 billion won from 429 billion won. Exports of LG Electronics were disrupted by the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome. As consumers stayed away from shops, LG lost sales and built up inventory, investors said. LG was forecast to report net income of 215 billion won, according to the median forecast of eight analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News. Operating profit was estimated at 338 billion won.

title: Video Artists Escape Hollywood Sensibility to Explore Their Inner Worlds
description: The New York Video Festival, presented every July by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, is an outpost of abstraction, eccentricity and avant-gardism planted in the middle of the blockbuster-dominated summer movie landscape. At the festival, which opens tonight and runs through Sunday at the Walter Reade Theater, artists use the medium as a tool of personal exploration, social critique and visual experimentation. But like the purveyors of big-money Hollywood action and sci-fi epics, they also occasionally use the rapidly evolving technologies of video animation to create strange and elaborate fantasy worlds.

title: A Media Rule By the F.C.C. Is in Jeopardy In the House
description: Until recent days, the nation's largest media conglomerates had hoped that the House of Representatives would kill the growing political efforts to overturn their recent deregulation.

title: A New Kind of Oil That's Nutty But Nice
description: Macadamia nut oil from Australia has several good things going for it. It has a high smoke point, so it is useful for frying. It offers a fairly light texture with an attractive hint of nuttiness. It is also extremely rich in monounsaturates, which scientists have linked to healthful cholesterol levels.

title: An Extremist Judicial Nominee
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee could vote as early as today on the nomination of the Alabama attorney general, William Pryor, to a federal appeals court judgeship. Mr. Pryor is among the most extreme of the Bush administration's far-right judicial nominees. If he is confirmed, his rulings on civil rights, abortion, gay rights and the separation of church and state would probably do substantial harm to the rights of all Americans. Senators from both parties should oppose his confirmation.

title: Elderly at the Wheel
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARKS, , ADELE
description: MARKS--Adele. The Officers, Board of Governors and members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed Honorary Life Member, and extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Ronald M. Stuart, Pres. Joyce Baumgarten, Secy.

title: 1986 Derby Winner Was Slaughtered, Magazine Reports
description: Victories in the 1986 Kentucky Derby and the 1987 Breeders' Cup Classic figured to have earned Ferdinand a cushy retirement when his racing days were over. Instead, his life apparently ended in a grisly manner, in a Japanese slaughterhouse in 2002, according to the racing industry trade magazine The Blood-Horse, which will report his death in its issue dated July 26. It is believed that his carcass was used to make pet food.

title: West African Group to Send Troops to Liberia
description: UNITED NATIONS, July 23  With Liberians in the besieged capital of Monrovia running out of food and water and rebel forces breaching key defensive lines in the city, a regional West African group under intense pressure from the United Nations announced today in Senegal that it would send at least 1,000 peacekeeping troops to the besieged capital of Monrovia within the next two weeks.

title: Curtis Is Out Of Tournament
description: Ben Curtis, who scored a huge upset by winning the British Open, informed officials of the Greater Hartford Open today that he was withdrawing from the tournament.

title: Nearly 800 Church Sex Abuse Victims in Boston, Report Says
description: Nearly 800 people have complained of being sexually abused by clergy members and workers in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese since 1940, the Massachusetts attorney general said today in a scathing report that followed a 16-month investigation into a scandal that has shaken the entire Catholic Church.

title: An Anglican Split?
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Money For Detentions
description: Officials of Shannon Hills, outside Little Rock, raised $1,100 in donations from residents to pay for the return of two fugitives who were caught in Idaho last week. The fugitives, Maggie and Richard Howe, are accused of disappearing with Ms. Howe's 5-year-old daughter before a custody hearing. Without the donations, the two would probably have been released, said the Saline County prosecuting attorney, Robert Herzfeld. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARTIN, , GLADYS ''AUNT GLADYS.''
description: MARTIN--Gladys ''Aunt Gladys.'' Formerly of Miami Beach, FL, and was currently residing in Roslyn Harbor, NY, passed away peacefully at the age of 97 on July 21, 2003. Beloved aunt of Barbara and Jim Lehrer of Roslyn Harbor, NY, Dr. Jack and Barbara Martin of Bryn Mawr, PA and Sari and Ken Friedman of Syosset, NY. Devoted great-aunt of Jonathan and Ross Lehrer, Seth, Todd and Emily Martin and Andrea and Deborah Friedman. Graveside services Wednesday, 10 AM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. All donations in her memory may be made to Martin/Lehrer Foundation, 1800 Northern Boulevard, Suite 101, Roslyn, New York 11576.

title: Derailment Prompts Offer Of Refunds In New Jersey
description: New Jersey Transit officials said today that they would give a 15 percent refund to riders with July monthly rail passes, to help compensate for the inconvenience of a train derailment and other troubles this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AUBURN, , DR. NORMAN
description: AUBURN--Dr. Norman, July 21st. President of the University of Akron for 20 years, during which time he came to know industrialist Herman Muehlstein. The Foundation notes with sorrow the loss of its esteemed president and offers condolences to the family. Lawrence Buttenwieser, Sanford Solender, Wilma Tisch, Trustees Lauren Katzowitz, Secretary >>AD#

title: A Rhone Grape Finds Glory in Australia
description: THEY make good chardonnay in Australia, and the cabernet can be outstanding, as well. There is excellent grenache to be found, and some attractive sauvignon blanc. But when shiraz is mentioned, all the others fade away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SUGARMAN, , MARVIN HENRY
description: SUGARMAN--Marvin Henry. Having lived here since May 20, 1916, left on July 20, 2003, and so bids a fond farewell to his friends and relatives. To those who loved: a hug and a farewell kiss. Cremation having taken place, there will be no further service. Aloha, shalom, sayonora, farewell. >>AD#

title: Director Says F.B.I. Better Prepared to Combat Terror
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  On the eve of a long-awaited report on the F.B.I.'s intelligence failures before the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the agency's director said today that the F.B.I. was far better prepared now to combat terrorist threats.

title: Shining Path Rebels Are Spreading Terror Again in Peru
description: The scene could have been from the 1980's, when civil conflict killed thousands here: two flag-covered coffins lowered into the ground as mothers wailed and soldiers in dress uniforms dabbed tears.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Minister Quits Race
description: Finance Minister John Manley withdrew from the race for leader of the Liberal Party, clearing the way for Paul Martin, a former finance minister and the odds-on favorite, to replace Prime Minister Jean Chrtien next year. Conceding that he did not have enough support to defeat Mr. Martin when the party elects a new leader at its November convention, Mr. Manley, who is also the deputy prime minister, said at a news conference, ''Paul Martin will be the next leader of the Liberal Party and the next prime minister of Canada.'' The only other remaining contender is the heritage minister, Sheila Copps, who is considered to have little chance of victory. The new party leader will replace Mr. Chrtien when he steps down as prime minister in February. General elections are likely to take place next year.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Governor Leaves Puerto Rico Early
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey cut short a six-day stay in Puerto Rico yesterday, returning to New Jersey to speak at the funeral of a friend's daughter today. Mr. McGreevey, accompanied by his wife and daughter, went to San Juan for a convention of the International Longshoremen's Association, where he gave the keynote speech yesterday. Some Republicans raised questions about the trip because the McGreeveys' travel and hotel expenses were paid by the union. But Micah Rasmussen, the governor's press secretary, said the criticism did not influence his change in plans. Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: STATEN ISLAND: MAYOR QUESTIONED ON CAPS Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would probably not set a cap on his own spending in the 2005 mayoral race even as he pushed for a spending limit on the campaign to revise the City Charter. Mr. Bloomberg spent roughly $75 million of his own money to get elected in 2001. Asked at a Staten Island appearance whether he would set a cap on spending in a future mayoral campaign, he said it was a long time off, "but probably not." His comments came as Democrats accused him of hypocrisy for calling for a spending limit on all parties in the campaign to make municipal elections nonpartisan, while rejecting a limit for himself. Mr. Bloomberg said also he had removed from an auction set for today six parcels of city-owned property on Staten Island that residents had feared would end up in the hands of developers. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: At Age 46, Orosco Is Joining The Yanks
description: Three days after their annual Old-Timers' Day, the Yankees obtained a player last night who is older than many of those who were on hand at Yankee Stadium last Saturday.

title: DANA REJECTS ARVINMERITOR'S $2.2 BILLION TAKEOVER BID
description: The Dana Corporation, the world's largest maker of axles for pickup trucks, minivans and sport utility vehicles, yesterday rejected a $2.2 billion takeover bid from a smaller auto-parts supplier, ArvinMeritor, saying it was too low and too risky. ArvinMeritor began a tender offer of $15 for each Dana share on July 9. Dana said the offer was inadequate based on an opinion it received from its financial advisers. Dana also reported its second-quarter results, which showed net income unchanged at $52 million, or 35 cents a share.

title: Off Their Rafts, Refugees Are Still at Sea
description: In August 1994 Fidel Castro invited his citizens to leave Cuba if they wished. Some 50,000 people took him up on his offer, piling onto homemade rafts and setting out for Miami.

title: Sports of The Times; Time to Induct Carter, and Save His Team
description: A MET again who is as capable of discourse on the prospects in Port St. Lucie and the potential options for Mike Piazza as on the 1986 postseason parable at Willets Point, Gary Carter will nonetheless be inducted into baseball's Hall of Fame this weekend with a plaque bearing the insignia of the Montreal Expos.

title: CALENDAR
description: Sake at the Shelburne

title: Elliot Norton, 100, a Critic In Boston Read on Broadway
description: Elliot Norton, a theater critic in Boston for nearly 50 years whose reviews of Broadway-bound shows on tryout runs were carefully read by New York producers, died on Sunday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he had lived since November. He was 100 and had been a longtime resident of Watertown, Mass.

title: A Fashion King Peddled The Chase
description: May 1971. Midnight. The Royal Court Theater, Chelsea, in the beating heart of swinging London. First comes the beanpole model Penelope Tree in a see-through chiffon blouse, with her partner, David Bailey; the restaurateur Michael Chow in a cerise satin blazer; Linda McCartney, with Paul, in blue to match her hair; and the artist David Hockney, front row. The raunchy, raucous, romantic Ossie Clark show starts at 2 a.m., the curvy models gyrating on glitter platform shoes and Patti Boyd, wife of George Harrison, twirling her cape top to reveal naked breasts.

title: Mayor's New Immigrant Policy, Intended to Help, Raises Fears
description: In May, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg issued an executive order altering the way city workers deal with immigrants. Seven weeks and much confusion later, he has conceded that he may have to change it.

title: Editor of Daily News to Retire in March
description: Edward Kosner, who was appointed the editor in chief of The Daily News in spring 2000, announced in yesterday's edition of the newspaper that he intended to retire in March, when his contract ends.

title: New York and Houston Lead Urban School Districts in Study
description: In the first national test of reading and writing to compare students in a half-dozen of the largest urban school districts, fourth graders in New York and Houston led students in the other cities, according to results released here today.

title: All Dolled Up in His Lounge and Shrine
description: The regulars at the Ernie K-Doe Mother-in-Law Lounge call it a statue, and few have the heart to correct them. It is actually a mannequin. Positioned regally in the corner, it looks eerily like Ernie K-Doe, the eccentric 60's rhythm-and-blues singer who ran this out-of-the-way bar until his death two years ago.

title: Major Change in Mental Health Care Is Urged
description: Mental health care in America is often inadequate and needs ''fundamental transformation,'' a presidential commission reported yesterday.

title: If Misery Loves Company, City Smokers Should Like State's Law
description: Tina Kurtzhalts had just finished eating in a small bar and restaurant near Ithaca, N.Y., on Monday when she opened her purse, plucked out a cigarette, fingered her lighter and flicked.

title: Sun Posts a Small Profit but Misses Forecasts
description: Sun Microsystems, the network computer maker, disappointed investors yesterday when it reported a profit of $12 million for the fourth quarter of its fiscal year. The company essentially broke even on a per-share basis for the second quarter in a row.

title: Putting Out Fires and Keeping the Peace
description: They are called, respectively, New York's bravest and finest. Both the city's Fire and Police Departments have produced a bounty crop of heroes over the years. But put them together and the superlatives can become lost in a historic rivalry that often winds up embarrassing both. Two recent examples were downright petty, with officers and firefighters clashing over how to dislodge a suspected thief from a chimney and how to search for a drowning victim.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bombs Hit Resort Hotels
description: Two bombs exploded at beachfront hotels in the Mediterranean resorts of Alicante and Benidorm, wounding 13 people in what appeared to be the start of a campaign by the Basque separatist group E.T.A. to disrupt Spain's tourism industry. Warnings were phoned into local newspapers, allowing the police to evacuate the hotels, but the explosions hurt neighbors, passers-by and police officers. The most seriously injured were two students, one Dutch and the other German, at a Spanish-language school in Alicante. In Benidorm, the vacationing mayor of Belfast, Northern Ireland, Martin Morgan, was just yards away from that explosion. He was not injured. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Death Penalty Ruled Out For Two British Detainees
description: The Bush administration has assured the British government that it will not seek the death penalty for two Britons being held as terrorist suspects at the American naval base in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, British and American officials said today.

title: For Every Child, a Stake in America
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain came to Washington last week to bolster President Bush against his critics on Iraq. Let's hope the two leaders found a moment to discuss domestic policy as well -- particularly Mr. Blair's effort to give every child a stake in Britain's economic future.

title: A Savvy Queen Marketed Chastity
description: European monarchs and princes frequently turned to the great painters -- Titian, Rubens, Van Dyck, Velzquez -- to record their features for posterity. Not so Elizabeth I of England. Like a modern politician, she was more interested in the immediate propagation of her image. The quality of the painting was less important than its message.

title: Bringing Heat in a Box of Spicy Sweets
description: Steve Sygman, below, has no plans to quit his day job as a chiropractor with a practice in East Hampton, N.Y., but for the past six years he has helped out in the kitchen of the Della Femina restaurant there. His avocation inspired him to found Hamptons Chocolate, which makes bite-size truffles and chocolates in intense flavors like French lavender or ginger-wasabi. Dr. Sygman and his partner, Marika Bodnarikova, a personal chef, use mostly organic chocolate that he tempers himself. title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Amgen Profit Surges In Second Quarter
description: Amgen, the world's biggest biotechnology company, said yesterday that second-quarter profit increased 47 percent as sales of arthritis and cancer medicines climbed. It raised its profit forecast for the year. Amgen is counting on Neulasta and Aranesp treatments for chemotherapy patients and the Enbrel arthritis medicine to build $10 billion in annual sales by 2005, twice last year's revenue. Sales of Aranesp, which treats anemia, jumped after the drug took sales from Procrit, a Johnson & Johnson product. Net income increased to $607.2 million, or 45 cents a share, from $412 million, or 38 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $2.04 billion from $1.25 billion. It expects to earn as much as $1.95 a share, excluding certain costs, this year compared with a previous estimate of as much as $1.90, the statement said. Shares of Amgen, which reported results after the close of regular trading, fell 15 cents, to $68.93.

title: National Briefing: Midwest

Dr. Kevorkian's 1972 and 1974 studies on the effects of such exposure are being used in the lawsuit of a North Carolina man who says he became ill after being exposed to metallic mercury, chlorine gas and other hazardous chemicals while working at a Honeywell International plant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TURECK, , ROSALYN
description: TURECK -- Rosalyn. The Tureck Bach Research Institute, Inc., mourns the passing on July 17th of its Founder and Artistic Director, renowned keyboard artist, teacher, and Bach scholar Rosalyn Tureck. Reconstituted from her earlier Tureck Bach Institute after her return to this country in September 2001, Dr. Tureck established the Tureck Bach Research Institute, Inc. for the purpose of furthering research and performance of the music of Johann Sebastian Bach through Fellowships and Grants and for the promoting of the study and performance of Bach's music by very young pianists through an annual competition in her name to be held in the United States and Russia, beginning in 2005. The Tureck Bach Research Institute, Inc., will also oversee the publication of Dr. Tureck's writings, including an autobiography she completed just weeks before her death, lectures, and master classes. She also completed a book on the Goldberg Variations, revised her ''Introduction to Bach,'' and prepared a book on the Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue, which will be edited under the artistic supervision of the Tureck Bach Research Institute, Inc. Dr. Tureck's books, papers, scores, manuscripts, and collection of ethnic and early instruments will be kept in perpetuity at the Special Collections of Boston University Library and are available for scholarly research. All her original recorded material of live performances, lectures, and master classes are kept in perpetuity at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts and are also available for research. Her CDs and videos will continue to be released by Video Artists International. She requested that there be no funeral but a memorial service, which will be held at the Lowenstein Auditorium of Temple Emanu-El, 10 East 66th Street, New York, NY, at 5:00pm on Tuesday, September 9, 2003. Friends, family, colleagues, and music-lovers, are invited. Donations to the Tureck Bach Research Institute, Inc., a New York not-for-profit corporation, founded and authorized by Rosalyn Tureck, will be accepted in her name at 2500 Johnson Avenue, 17A, Riverdale, NY 10463 or questions regarding donations, email bachalia14@aol.com. Website: www.tureckbach.com. Tureck Bach Research Institute, Inc. David Posner, Honorary President Kevin Kleinmann, President Ernest Gilbert, Vice President Michael Charry, Treasurer

He is survived by his wife of 67 years, Carol K. and four children: son Alan and daughters Joan, Anne G. Landis and Lynn Pollack, six grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. After receiving his law degree in 1938 from NYU (BA 1933 University of Wisconsin, MA 1935 Columbia University), he began his career as legal counsel to the Department of Labor, Bureau of Wages and Hours. He practiced law for over 60 years in NYC as a senior partner of Goldwater & Flynn, and continued a family legacy of devotion to both the law and the City of New York. He was an armchair scholar, avid organic gardener and philanthropist, whose generous spirit fed and nourished many. He will be dearly missed by his family and friends. title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Colleges Resist Record Industry Subpoenas
description: Boston College and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology said yesterday that they were barred from immediately handing over the names of students to the recording industry by the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act, which requires institutions to notify students before releasing any personal data. The Recording Industry of America has filed almost 1,000 subpoenas in Federal District Court in Washington, requesting information from educational institutions and Internet service providers on users of KaZaa, the file-sharing service. The group issued the requests as part of its effort to crack down on those using the Internet to illegally distribute copyrighted music. Both colleges said they were opposing the subpoenas on procedural grounds, rather than contesting the association's right to the information. ''In this case we have been advised by counsel that the subpoena was not in compliance with the court rules that apply to these subpoenas, and did not allow M.I.T. time to send any notice as the law requires,'' said James D. Bruce, vice president for information systems at M.I.T. As a result, the refusals could further delay -- but are unlikely to derail -- the recording industry's efforts to unmask file swappers and ultimately file suit against them.
