title: Brooklyn Woman Is Killed as Storms Batter the Region
description: A series of thunderstorms erupted over New York and New Jersey yesterday, resulting in the death of a Brooklyn woman who was hit by a falling tree limb and and knocking out power to thousands of residents in the region. The police reported that a tornado briefly touched down in Somerset County, N.J., and a volatile mix of lightning, hail and heavy rain pummeled the area from central New Jersey to the North Shore of Long Island.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: State Is Second-Highest In Caesarean Births
description: New Jersey ranked second in the nation, after Mississippi, in the proportion of babies delivered by Caesarean section, according to a new report issued by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. In 2002, 30.9 percent of New Jersey babies, or about 33,500, were delivered by Caesarean section. That was up from 28.9 percent the year earlier. Mark T. Olesnicky, the president of the Medical Society of New Jersey, attributed the rate to various factors, including doctors' concern about liability resulting from trauma during vaginal delivery. New York's rate is 27.2 percent and Connecticut's rate is 26.1 percent, while the national rate is 26.1 percent. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Water Talks Advance
description: The governors of Alabama, Florida and Georgia said they had agreed on several points in a water dispute that has raged among the states for 13 years. Some vexing issues have been left for later, like how much water Atlanta should draw from Lake Lanier on the Chattahoochee River. The states say that those matters are details and that this memorandum of understanding is the closest they have been to an agreement on use of the Apalachicola-Chattahoochee-Flint River basin since talks began in 1998. The memorandum calls for all details to be worked out by Aug. 31, though many such deadlines have been extended in the course of the negotiations. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: To Cool Off Czars (or Comrades)
description: Retreat into a cool cellar, nibble treats from a cabinet labeled "December" and feel July's heat dissipate. At Pravda, 281 Lafayette Street (Prince Street), new caviar and vodka set-ups on trays lined with clippings from Russian newspapers are enough to make you reach for your babushka. The Bolshevik tray, $35, far left, offers American hackleback, salmon and golden whitefish roes, with chilled Polish, English and American vodkas. For $115, the Romanoff tray has Russian sevruga, osetra and beluga caviars and Russian vodkas. The caviars are accompanied by potato pancakes and creme fraiche. A tray easily serves two.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: End To Privacy Suit
description: A former Miss Vermont who had persuaded a court to order her former boyfriend not to describe their relationship on his Web site has dropped her lawsuit. The order, issued by a state judge in West Palm Beach, had been criticized by First Amendment experts as an unconstitutional prior restraint. It expired after the defendant, Tucker Max, moved the case to federal court. The plaintiff, Katy Johnson, said the suit had achieved its purpose by exposing a Web site that she said degraded women. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Kerry Shareholders Reject Bid
description: Shareholders in Kerry Properties rejected a 3.54 billion Hong Kong dollar ($453 million) buyout offer from the Malaysian billionaire Robert Kuok even after he increased the price by 12 percent. Mr. Kuok's offer of 9.50 Hong Kong dollars a share ($1.22) was still 40 percent lower than the developer's adjusted net asset value. N. M. Rothschild & Sons (Hong Kong) Ltd., adviser to Kerry's independent board committee, recommended last month that shareholders reject the offer. In May, Mr. Kuok raised his offer from 8.50 Hong Kong dollars a share for the 373 million shares he does not own. At the meeting, holders of 98 million shares, or 56 percent of those represented, opposed the buyout. Mr. Kuok needed approval from at least 75 percent of minority shareholders at the meeting.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Mayor Questioned On Caps
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would probably not set a cap on his own spending in the 2005 mayoral race even as he pushed for a spending limit on the campaign to revise the City Charter. Mr. Bloomberg spent roughly $75 million of his own money to get elected in 2001. Asked at a Staten Island appearance whether he would set a cap on spending in a future mayoral campaign, he said it was a long time off, ''but probably not.'' His comments came as Democrats accused him of hypocrisy for calling for a spending limit on all parties in the campaign to make municipal elections nonpartisan, while rejecting a limit for himself. Mr. Bloomberg said also he had removed from an auction set for today six parcels of city-owned property on Staten Island that residents had feared would end up in the hands of developers. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: MIDDLETOWN: CHURCH VANDALIZED Three teenage girls have been accused of painting racial slurs and anti-Semitic symbols on a recreation center and a fence near a Roman Catholic church, Police Chief John F. Pollinger said yesterday. The girls, two 15-year-olds and a 16-year-old, have not been formally charged, the chief said. Whether they will face charges for a bias crime has yet to be determined, he said. The vandalism occurred near St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church between Saturday and Monday, he said. The teenage stepbrother of one of the girls is also accused of desecrating a statue of the Virgin Mary at the same church last week. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Profit for Boston Scientific
description: Boston Scientific, one of the largest makers of stents, said yesterday that its profit increased in the second quarter as the company's introduction of a new drug-coated version of stents in Europe helped lift sales. Net income rose to $114 million, or 27 cents a share, from $25 million, or 6 cents, a year ago, the company said. Sales increased 21 percent to $854 million from $708 million. Excluding research and development costs of $12 million, or 3 cents a share, Boston Scientific had a profit of $126 million, or 30 cents a share.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Possible Bank Stake Sale
description: Lone Star Funds, an investment company based in Dallas, may buy the South Korean government's 33 percent stake in the Korea Exchange Bank as it seeks to take control of the bank, South Korea's fifth-largest lender. The government-owned Export-Import Bank may sell part or all of its stake to the fund, the finance and economy minister, Kim Jin Pyo, above, said. Lone Star, which buys distressed banks, wants to acquire 51 percent of Korea Exchange, which would cost more than $1 billion, fund executives said.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: DEFLATION WORSENS Prices in Hong Kong fell for the 56th consecutive month, as the consumer price index was 3.1 percent lower in June than it was a year earlier. Tourists and other travelers continued to shun the Chinese territory despite the disappearance of severe acute respiratory syndrome, while a one-time rebate by a power company and a continued decline in apartment rents contributed to the drop. Unemployment rose to 8.6 percent for April through June, hurting demand and prices. The price index had been 2.5 percent lower in May than a year earlier. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: West African Group to Send Troops to Liberia
description: UNITED NATIONS, July 23  With Liberians in the besieged capital of Monrovia running out of food and water and rebel forces breaching key defensive lines in the city, a regional West African group under intense pressure from the United Nations announced today in Senegal that it would send at least 1,000 peacekeeping troops to the besieged capital of Monrovia within the next two weeks.

title: With Broken Collarbone, Hamilton Wins a Stage of Tour
description: BAYONNE, France, July 23  Tyler Hamilton, riding in pain with a double fracture of his right collarbone since July 6, added another exploit to a classic Tour de France today by going on a long solo breakaway in the Pyrenees and winning the day's stage by nearly two minutes.

title: Post Office Symbolism
description: For most Americans, the mail is still a central fact of life. You can be wired, or unwired, to the communications grid in any way you like, via beeper, pager, palmtop, cellphone and the Internet, yet there is hardly an office or a business or a home in this country where mail time goes unnoticed. But the competition is taking its toll. Last year, for the second year in a row, the Postal Service handled fewer first-class pieces of mail than it did the year before, leading to a deficit of nearly $700 million. Even though the Postal Service will show a profit this year, President Bush has named a commission to recommend changes in the way it operates. After months of comment, rebuttal and more comment, the President's Commission began preparing its final report, which will be issued at the end of this month.

title: OLYMPICS: U.S.O.C. Analysis; Coloradan Would Bar U.S.O.C. Office Move
description: He says there is no proof of a plot to snatch the United States Olympic Committee's headquarters from Colorado Springs. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suit Filed Over Deaths In France
description: Lawyers for a Connecticut family who died in a fire aboard a French train last year have filed a federal lawsuit seeking $175 million in damages. The suit was filed Monday against several German and French corporations, as well as an American company, the Stinnes Corporation of New York. The lawsuit claims that the companies failed to properly design and operate the overnight train from Paris to Munich. The Connecticut family -- Salvatore Michael Amore, above, and his wife, Jeanne, both 43; their children, Emily Jeanne, 12, and Michael Bernhardt, 8; and Mr. Amore's mother, Susanne Amore, 72 -- and seven other passengers died in November when a fire broke out in their sleeping car. The lawsuit seeks $75 million in compensatory damages and $100 million in punitive damages. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: A Victory by Thorpe Rekindles a Rivalry
description: There is only one sports rivalry that truly matters in this Mediterranean city. That is F.C. Barcelona versus Real Madrid, and although the world swimming championships are in full swing and soccer season will not begin until next month, Barca's signing of Ronaldinho, whom Real also coveted, has been the talk of the Rambla, the Passeig de Grcia and every other part of town.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Burial Box Owner Arrested
description: The police arrested on suspicion of fraud a prominent antiquities collector, Oded Golan, who last year unveiled an ancient burial box that purportedly held the bones of Jesus' brother James. Last month Israel's Antiquities Authority declared his box a forgery. The burial box, or ossuary, common in Jewish burials in the first centuries B.C. and A.D., has an inscription in the Aramaic language that reads, ''James, son of Joseph, brother of Jesus.'' The authorities concluded that the ossuary dated back some 2,000 years but that the writing was much more recent. Greg Myre (NYT)

Pataki signed legislation tonight that will allow New York City to build a $1.3 billion water filtration plant in a Bronx park, ending years of wrangling among the city, state and federal governments over how to clean up a portion of the city's water supply.

description: HELLER--Red (Rose), widow of Ernest Heller, died July 19, 2003 at the age of 105. She lived a full, rich life. She graduated from the University of Pittsburgh and was trained and worked as a social worker. She served as Director of Camp Swatonah in Damascus, PA from inception in the late 20's until 1950. She is survived by four nieces and nephews, Barnse Keller, Alison Diamond, Lynn Gilbert and David Fine. Throughout her life, she has been a major influence and patron of the arts, supporting numerous proteges. For many years, she served on the Board of Directors of the MacDowell Colony and the Poses Arts Awards Committee for Brandeis University. title: Complaints and Support for Diet Pill at Congressional Hearing
description: A nurse who used to work for Metabolife International, the country's largest seller of weight-loss pills containing the stimulant ephedra, told a House subcommittee today that he had taken 5 to 10 calls a day from customers complaining of side effects and that one-fifth of the callers had reported symptoms of cardiac problems.

title: Better Alive Than Dead
description: The killing of Saddam Hussein's sons, Uday and Qusay, is a tactical victory for the American occupation of Iraq. But it is not a strategic one. By not capturing these odious symbols of the old regime alive and putting them on display, the American occupation authority has denied itself the chance to give absolute proof of their demise to a society that rejects authority and thrives on conspiracy theory. It has also lost an opportunity to give Iraqis a chance to purge their bitterness, and satisfy a deep-seated need for revenge, by confronting their tormentors in court.

She was admired for her feminine looks: with liquid eyes and pancake makeup, she has the allure of a model.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Electronics Profit Falls
description: Samsung SDI, a unit of the Samsung Group that makes screens for computers, television sets and mobile telephones, reported net income of 113 billion won ($95.7 million) for the second quarter, down 34 percent from the same period last year. Sales dropped only slightly, to 1.58 trillion won from 1.62 trillion won. One reason for the profit decline was the transition to flat-panel screens from the cathode-ray-tube displays on which the company has relied for much of its business. The outbreak of SARS was also a factor, the company said. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Chief For Covenant House

She raised money for three schools and created close ties with the Lakota Sioux tribe, among the poorest people in the United States. She will take over as president on Sept. 1, replacing Sister Mary Rose McGeady, who is retiring. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

But it was understood that no matter how many special prayers you uttered or lucky talismans you waved, the gods might very well hand you a dud disc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KJELDSEN, , NORMAN
description: KJELDSEN--Norman, 87, of Brightwaters, NY, died July 22 after a short illness. Mr. Kjeldsen is survived by his wife of 61 years, Anne Marie Noone (Nana), and four children: Mary Lou Cohalan of Bayport, NY; Susan Roos of Brooklyn Heights, NY; Robert P. Kjeldsen of Babylon, NY and David C. Kjeldsen of West Islip, NY. His son Norman Peter Kjeldsen of Islip, NY predeceased him in 1993. He is also survived by 14 grandchildren and seven great grandchildren. Born in Brooklyn in 1916, he was the son of Sofus Kjeldsen and Louise Larsen of Norway. He grew up in the Scandinavian community of Bay Ridge and graduated from Brooklyn Poly Prep in 1934. He was commissioned as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy in 1942 and served in the Pacific Theater during World War II. Following the war, he and his family lived in Norfolk, VA before moving to Brightwaters in 1959. An entrepreneur, musician, art collector and avid traveler, he owned and operated several manufacturing companies, including Cardwell Condenser Corporation, Pax Manufacturing and Strux Corporation in Lindenhurst, NY. Within the art world, he was considered an expert on marine and boat paintings from the 18th and 19th century. He visited all seven continents during his frequent travels abroad. He supported many local organizations and charities and was active in raising funds for Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip. Reposing at the Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Hwy. (1/4 mile west of Robert Moses Cswy). Religious services will be held on Friday, July 25 at St. Peters By the Sea Episcopal Church in Bay Shore, NY at 10:30AM followed by burial at Oakwood Cemetery in Bay Shore, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Good Samaritan Hospital, 1000 Montauk Hwy, West Islip, NY 11795 and Consolation Residence, 111 Beach Drive, West Islip 11795. Visitation Thursday 2:00-4:00 and 7:009:00 PM. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: 24 Arrested In Car Theft Ring
description: The police announced yesterday that they had broken up an international car theft ring based in Newark in which dozens of luxury automobiles worth at least $2 million were stolen in New Jersey and shipped to the Dominican Republic and elsewhere for resale. Officials said they had recovered 37 stolen cars, including two at cargo containers at Port Newark and the Port of Baltimore. After an eight-month investigation, state and federal officials said, 15 suspects were arrested in New Jersey and nine more in other states, including Florida.

title: Tragedy at City Hall
description: The fatal City Hall shooting yesterday of James Davis, a member of the New York City Council from Brooklyn, appears to have been the result of personal enmity -- the gunman was a would-be political opponent who was himself shot dead by a security officer. At first, however, it was impossible for anyone to know that the violence that occurred right in the Council chambers was so contained. The building was evacuated, East River bridges closed and subway lines rerouted. The sight of flashing lights, sniffer dogs and officers in flak jackets, so near to ground zero, gave everyone the same chilling thought -- one Mayor Michael Bloomberg countered right away. This was not an act of terror, he said.

title: Kodak Reports Lower Profits And May Cut 6,000 Workers

The old man, dressed in battle fatigues with his headdress folded in the diamond shape of mandatory Palestine, a pistol attached to his hip, will arrive in a hurricane of aides and hangers-on. He will grab your hand for emphasis but ignore many of your questions.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Mediation In Air Dispute

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AUBURN, , NORMAN P.
description: AUBURN--Norman P. President Emeritus of The University of Akron, died July 21, 2003 in Akron after a short illness. He was 98. In New York, Dr. Auburn served as Acting President for the Council for Financial Aid to Education, Acting President of Brooklyn (now New York) Polytechnic Institute, Acting President of Union College (Schenectady), and President of the Herman Muehlstein Foundation, 1965 to its dissolution in 2002. Among his local survivors are a grandson, David, a stepgranddaughter, Illana Hyman Levin, and a great-granddaughter, Rebecca, all of Manhattan. >>AD#

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Posts Loss
description: South Korea's largest financial institution, the Kookmin Bank, reported a loss of 40.7 billion won ($34.5 million) for the first half of this year after having a net profit of 1.16 trillion won in the first half of last year. The loss reflected the troubles of Korea's banking sector, burdened by loans extended to companies like SK Global and Hynix Semiconductor as well as by rising delinquencies in payments of credit card loans. Kookmin's affiliate, Kookmin Credit Card, lost 487.6 billion won in the first half.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Computer Associates Posts First Profit In Two Years
description: Computer Associates International Inc., the world's fifth-largest software company, has reported its first quarterly profit in more than two years as the company cut costs and increased sales. Net income in the fiscal first quarter ended June 30 was $10 million, or 2 cents a share, in contrast to a net loss of $65 million, or 11 cents, in the period a year earlier, Computer Associates said in a statement. Revenue for the company, which is based in Islandia, N.Y., rose 6.3 percent, to $813 million. The company had its first profit since the quarter that ended Sept. 30, 2000, as the chief executive, Sanjay Kumar, increased sales of programs that manage and protect corporate networks. Revenue this quarter will increase to $825 million from $805 million and net income will be 1 cent to 3 cents a share, the company said. Excluding some costs, profit will be 13 cents to 15 cents a share. The company continues to cooperate with investigators from the Securities and Exchange Commission and Justice Department, Mr. Kumar said on a conference call. The agencies have been examining whether Computer Associates recorded sales improperly or manipulated accounting to inflate its stock price. Shares of Computer Associates fell 28 cents, to $22.24.

title: Sports of The Times; Knicks' Expert In Mediocrity
description: AFTER the Knicks' dysfunctional organization nearly consumed itself en route to the 1999 N.B.A. finals, Scott Layden was hired to be an irrelevant general manager, to be as neutral as beige, to be pleasantly vacant.

title: Phelps Earns Gold; His World Record Stays Intact
description: BARCELONA, Spain, July 23 - When Michael Phelps was swimming nearly 90,000 meters a week in training as he prepared for the world championships in Spain, it was with 200 meters like this in mind.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Porsche To Raise Output
description: Porsche said it planned to expand its car factory in Leipzig, eastern Germany, to meet strong demand for its new sport utility model, the Cayenne, which was introduced in December. The company also intends to add 70 jobs at the Leipzig plant in the second half of this year as it starts production of its Carrera GT Supercar.

title: In Pain, Hamilton Conquers The Field
description: Tyler Hamilton, riding today with his fractured right collarbone taped together, added another exploit to what has already become a classic Tour de France by using a long solo breakaway in the Pyrenees to win the day's stage by nearly two minutes.

title: New Editor of Seventeen Comes From Inside Hearst
description: When the Hearst Corporation bought Seventeen magazine from Primedia Inc. for about $180 million four months ago, some advertisers and competitors suggested that the acquisition would cannibalize Hearst's own teenage publication, the four-year-old CosmoGirl.

title: City Hall Police Officer Steps Out of Obscurity in an Instant
description: The "ID" on the uniform collar stands for "intelligence division," like something out of a spy movie, with secret agents and exploding pens.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Unionist Killed
description: A union organizer in Barranquilla, on the Caribbean, was killed by a gunman, bringing to 45 the number of unionists killed this year in Colombia, the country's largest labor confederation said. Carlos Barrera, a member of the hospital workers union, was walking home when a gunman stepped off a motorcycle and shot him to death, said Jess Tobr, a leader of the CUT confederation. Mr. Tobar said the confederation believed that right-wing paramilitaries, already blamed for hundreds of assassinations of union members in Colombia, were probably responsible. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: S.E.C. Money Is Likely to Go Unspent
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it would not spend $103 million of its record $716 million budget this fiscal year because it could not hire accountants and investigators fast enough.

title: Indiana Death Row Inmate Gets Support for DNA Test From Unlikely Source: His Prosecutor
description: Thomas Vanes prosecuted a dozen capital cases in the 13 years he spent working for Lake County, in northwest Indiana. He sent nine men to death row, including Darnell Williams, who is scheduled to be executed on Aug. 1.

It holds a long-term lease from the New 42nd Street, a nonprofit group that is revitalizing 42nd Street; it does not own the theater.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Woman Sentenced For Killing Son
description: A Long Island woman convicted of smothering her newborn son in a bedroom on Christmas Day in 2001 while relatives were eating a holiday dinner was sentenced yesterday to 18 years to life in prison. Judge Jerald S. Carter of Nassau County Court said the term symbolized the newborn's lost childhood. The woman, Kathleen E. Brown, 26, a waitress from North Massapequa, was found guilty of second-degree murder at her trial in May. She did not testify, but in court yesterday she said the baby had been born dead. The Nassau County medical examiner ruled that the baby had been born alive and had died of asphyxiation. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: House Wrangles Over Levels Of Global Spending on AIDS
description: Two weeks after President Bush toured Africa with promises of vast increases in spending on global AIDS, the House of Representatives was poised today to approve a measure that would bring total spending on the epidemic next year to roughly $2 billion -- $1 billion short of the amount set out in a bill Mr. Bush signed in May.

title: ARMY IS RELUCTANT TO FLAUNT PHOTOS OF HUSSEIN'S SONS
description: The United States holds irrefutable proof that Saddam Hussein's sons are dead, including dental records and visual confirmation from four of the deposed dictator's aides, but a skeptical Iraqi public held out today for photographs and the occupying authority did not broadcast them.

title: Chrebet Only Wants to Feel Wanted
description: It was, Wayne Chrebet said, one of the toughest seasons of his eight-year career. The losing, his drop in production, the friction with the offensive coordinator. It boiled inside him and bubbled up in frustration, the career-high nine touchdown catches and the playoff appearance the only salve for an otherwise painful 2002 season.

title: Is It About to Rain? Check the Typeface
description: UNTIL fire destroyed the Northwestern National Bank building in 1982, Minneapolis citizens could receive an instant weather forecast by glancing at an illuminated sphere on its rooftop. When the ''weatherball'' was red, warmer temperatures were ahead. When it was white, cold was on the way. Blinking indicated precipitation.

description: ''Initially it was just an absolute kind of stillness. It was probably only a second. And then all hell broke loose.''

title: Palestinians And Israelis Still Far Apart On Prisoners
description: Despite continuing discussions, Israel and the Palestinians remained far apart today on the issue of Palestinian prisoner releases. Israel says it is willing to free hundreds, while the Palestinians are demanding the release of thousands.

title: 789 Children Abused by Priests Since 1940, Massachusetts Says
description: At least 789 children and probably more than 1,000 have been sexually abused by 250 priests and other church workers in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston since 1940, according to a 16-month investigation by the Massachusetts attorney general that was made public today.

title: Loyalists Protest Death of Hussein Sons; Blast Kills One Soldier and Wounds Six
description: American soldiers guarding the home where Saddam Hussein's sons were killed on Tuesday were greeted by a small but animated demonstration from loyalists this morning and endured tense moments this evening when soldiers chasing away a crowd of onlookers wounded an Iraqi man as he tried to drive away.

title: A Cube That Lights Up As a Stool or Planter
description: ''If you have a dinner outdoors in the evening, you never have enough candlelight,'' said Max Kistner, a 31-year-old industrial designer from Lindau, Germany. So he designed the Lux-Us, a 19-inch polyethylene cube that is lighted from within by a 30-watt fluorescent bulb. It can be a stool, below left, that supports up to 300 pounds; a planter, below right; or even stacked into a bookcase. (Two sides are slightly concave, and two sides are slightly convex, for easy stacking.)

title: In the Cotswolds, A 'Snake in the Grass' And Other Aesthetics
description: Design ideas for outdoor spaces were solicited from 400 people, including architects, industrial designers and furniture makers, said Thrse Lang, who with Jan Chillery organized the second annual Westonbirt International Festival of Gardens. A panel chose 14 designers and gave each $24,000 and a 2,100-square-foot work site at Westonbirt, the national arboretum, 600 acres near Tetbury, in the English Cotswolds.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Proposal For Names On 9/11 Memorial
description: Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, yesterday endorsed a resolution that called for the future World Trade Center memorial to list the names of firefighters, police officers and rescue workers separately from those of other victims of the Sept. 11 attacks. The resolution asks Gov. George E. Pataki and the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation to honor rescue workers by listing them together, by department, including rank, badge number and unit ''in the context within which they gave their lives.'' The current guidelines for the memorial competition say there should be no hierarchy in listing the victims. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Powell Backs U.S. Role to Aid Liberia
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, who has been in daily contact with Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, showed himself to be a strong advocate of interceding in Liberia in an interview published in today's Washington Times.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: More Ganim Associates Sentenced
description: A man whom prosecutors described as part of a kickback scheme benefiting Joseph P. Ganim, the former mayor of Bridgeport, was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court here to three years of probation. Prosecutors said the man, Michael Schinella, 45, bought a chimney for Mr. Ganim's home. Mr. Schinella is one of 11 people, including Mr. Ganim, who have been convicted in the municipal corruption scandal. Mr. Schinella's half-brother, Alfred Lenoci Sr., 68, a real estate developer, was sentenced on Tuesday by Judge Janet Bond Arterton to a year in prison for bribery and mail fraud. His son, Alfred Lenoci Jr., 40, was sentenced on Monday to 18 months in prison in connection with the kickback scheme. The father and son, whose company, United Properties, developed several Bridgeport projects, offered Paul J. Pinto, an associate of Mr. Ganim, a kickback knowing it would be shared with Mr. Ganim, prosecutors said. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: HYPERION TO BUY BRIO SOFTWARE The Hyperion Solutions Corporation , a maker of business software whose shares have doubled in the last 12 months, agreed yesterday to buy Brio Software Inc. for about $142 million in cash and stock. Brio shareholders will receive 0.109 share of Hyperion and 36.3 cents for each Brio common share, Hyperion said in a statement. The agreement values Brio at $3.60 a share. Shares of Brio rose 30 cents, to $3 yesterday on Nasdaq. Hyperion makes software that helps businesses analyze their performance, and the acquisition of Brio will give the company more such products, a spokesman, Bob Schettino, said. Shares of Hyperion rose $1.50, to $29.68. The news was released after the close of regular trading. (Bloomberg News)

title: For Young German Writers, All Is Ich
description: Judith Hermann chases Coca-Cola with green tea at the Cafe Pasternak in the former East Berlin as she considers her own role in Germany's literary new wave. She has tropical blue eyes, streaked blond hair, a surprisingly languid beauty. At 32, she is the author of a prize-winning short-story collection, ''Summer House Later,'' and the novel ''Nothing but Ghosts,'' which will be published in English by Flamingo (HarperCollins) in London next year.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Monetary Meeting Minutes
description: The Bank of England's new governor, Mervyn A. King, was backed by all except one of his eight colleagues on the Monetary Policy Committee in voting for this month's reduction in interest rates, minutes of the July 9-10 meeting showed. A deputy governor, Rachel Lomax, voted to hold rates steady. The rest of the members agreed to cut the benchmark lending rate a quarter percentage point to 3.5 percent, its lowest level in 48 years.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Emissions Test Delayed
description: The state will postpone until January a requirement that the owners of about 640,000 automobiles take a new emissions test, Bradley M. Campbell, the state environmental protection commissioner, said yesterday. The state wants more time to educate drivers about the new test, he said. Previously set for Aug. 4, the test would have applied to the owners of cars in the 1996 and 1997 model years. The new test reads emission data from a computer in the automobile and will replace what is known as the tailpipe test, where actual emissions are measured. The state had planned to introduce the computer examination for automobiles dating from the 1996 model year to the present. Mr. Campbell said the postponement did not affect cars in the 1998 model year and later.

title: Orosco Fills Need As Lefty Specialist
description: It was two or three years ago when Mel Stottlemyre last saw his old left-handed closer on the Mets, the one who flung his glove in the air, fell on his knees and raised his fists to the sky after the last out of the 1986 World Series.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Monday and a chart about second-quarter advertising sales for the nation's top newspaper companies omitted some sales for Dow Jones & Company and thus overstated the figures' overall decline. Including results for the Ottaway newspaper chain (but excluding the chain's divestitures or acquisitions over the last year), Dow Jones's newspaper advertising sales in the United States were $199.5 million in the second quarter, not $147.1 million. Sales for the first six months were $374.3 million, not $277 million.

title: Pletcher and Prado Get Off to Fast Start
description: The red and white awnings, the strolling banjo players and the canopy of oak trees have long given Saratoga Race Course a timeless essence. Walk through its iron gates and the late 1800's are evoked down to the chatter of swells, the stylish haberdashery of the track's patrons and the clip-clop cadences of racehorses. But as the storied Spa kicked off its 135th summer race meeting today, a more recent era was conjured, one barely a year old, when a trainer and a jockey long described as up-and-coming actually up and came.

A sculptor, photographer and painter, she was the widow of Jacques Lipchitz and is survived by her sons Hanno D. Mott of NYC and Frank L. (Susan) Mott of Columbus, OH, her daughter, Lolya R. No flowers, please and any contributions may be made to the American Friends of the Israel Museum, 500 Fifth Avenue, NY, NY of which she was a Director and a close friend. >>AD#

title: JUDGE APPROVES SALE OF ALTERRA HEALTHCARE TO EMERITUS
description: A federal bankruptcy judge approved the Emeritus Corporation's acquisition of Alterra Healthcare, an operator of nursing homes for Alzheimer's patients. Judge Mary F. Walrath of federal bankruptcy court in Wilmington, Del., approved the sale. Emeritus's F.E.B.C.-Alt Investors unit will pay $76 million for 100 percent of the revamped company. Bondholders of Alterra and other unsecured creditors could receive as much as $23 million.

title: Compassion and the Tax Cuts
description: President Bush is planning a victory lap today for his latest round of tax cuts, visiting Philadelphia to signal the first mailings of $400 government checks to 25 million middle-class families entitled to expanded child credits. Missing from the photo opportunity, unless the president plans something truly dramatic, will be any children from poor families left out of the child-credit boon while the Republican-controlled Congress continues to wrangle over this shameful omission.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: MEDIATION IN AIR DISPUTE British Airways and union representatives planned to meet with mediators to resolve a dispute involving check-in employees and avert more strikes at Heathrow Airport in London, run by BAA, during the summer holiday. British Airways managers were set to begin talks with the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service and union leaders last night, a spokesman, Richard Goodfellow, said. The Transport and General Workers' Union, the largest trade union at British Airways, and Amicus, another union, confirmed they would be attending the talks. (Bloomberg News)

title: Find Brass Frames Too Boring? Try a Razzle-Dazzle Exhibition
description: If you think your digital photos are museum-quality, you now have the chance to prove it -- in a three-dimensional virtual gallery right on your own computer screen. The 3D-Album program from Micro Research Institute lets you insert your own digital photographs into a variety of animated slide-show settings, including the surface of a rotating cube, the side of a hot-air balloon as it floats over the mountains or stylish frames in an interactive museum gallery.

title: Nigeria Readies Peace Force for Liberia; Battles Go On
description: UNITED NATIONS, July 23  With Liberians in their besieged capital running out of food and water, and rebel forces breaching key defensive lines, a regional West African group announced today in Senegal that it could send as many as 1,300 Nigerian peacekeeping troops to Liberia within two weeks.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cincinnati Bell Chief To Step Down
description: Cincinnati Bell Inc., the local telephone company formerly known as Broadwing Inc., said its chief executive, Kevin Mooney, would leave after less than a year in the post. No replacement was named. Mr. Mooney, 45, previously the chief operating officer, was named chief executive in September, succeeding Rick Ellenberger, who led a money-losing foray into the fiber optic network business. Earlier this month, Cincinnati Bell said in a federal regulatory filing that it might replace Mr. Mooney, who sold the fiber optic unit in June.

title: When Edward Weston's Eye Feasted on His Beloved California
description: At age 20, Edward Weston, a struggling photographer, moved from Illinois to Southern California, beckoned by his sister, May Seaman. ''This is the place for you without an atom of a doubt,'' she wrote. ''Every year you spend back East is so much loss to you. This is the country you have been longing for.''

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Marketwatch.com To Buy Pinnacor For $103.2 Million
description: MarketWatch.com Inc., owner of the CBS MarketWatch.com financial news Web site, is buying Pinnacor Inc. for $103.2 million in cash and stock. MarketWatch.com will pay Pinnacor shareholders $44 million in cash and 6.5 million shares, Lawrence Kramer, chief executive of MarketWatch.com, said in a telephone interview. The stock is worth $59.2 million, based on MarketWatch.com's closing stock price yesterday, he said. The purchase will give MarketWatch.com access to several new products from Pinnacor, which provides market data and investment-analysis tools to financial services companies. MarketWatch.com shares fell 56 cents, to $8.54. Pinnacor shares rose 7 cents, to $2.29. The news was announced after the markets closed.

title: Images of Hussein's Sons Met With Joy and Skepticism
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 24  As soon as the macabre pictures of Uday and Qusay Hussein appeared on the television screen tonight, the arguments erupted in the Zein Barbershop in downtown Baghdad, with half the men exulting that their former oppressors were dead and the others believing that the pictures were forged and the dictator's sons were elsewhere. In Spain, in fact.

title: Officials Face Tough Part Of Water Deal
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's approval late Tuesday of legislation authorizing a $1.3 billion water-filtration plant in the Bronx broke a logjam that had kept New York City water system administrators, environmentalists and public health officials holding their breath for weeks.

title: INSIDE
description: Report Faults Freddie Mac

description: Toil and Trouble at Double Speed

title: Postcards From Angola, a Fast-Dimming Bright Spot on the AIDS Map of Africa
description: Toss a dart at a map of sub-Saharan Africa and wherever it lands the news is bound to be grim on the AIDS front. With an estimated 30 million people living with H.I.V., the picture is especially bleak in countries like Botswana, where 4 of 10 adults have the virus, and Zimbabwe, where the infection rate is well over 30 percent.

title: Treachery and Revenge in Ancient China
description: Adaptation is a tricky process, whether in theater or biology. A play is a kind of organism and all of its elements must adjust to a new environment. When the American playwright David Greenspan adapts a 13th-century Chinese drama he must adjust a language, a performance style and an ancient culture to modern American audiences.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Interest Policy Defended
description: The Bank of Japan's zero-interest rate policy is helping to limit a surge in bond yields and the central bank is committed to it, the bank's governor, Toshihiko Fukui, said. ''Because of the effects of our policy, Japan's interest rates at the maturity of up to several years have been stable at low levels,'' Mr. Fukui said in a speech at a meeting of Japanese business executives in Tokyo. Mr. Fukui said the bank planned to keep interest rates low until consumer prices rise.

title: A Newcomer With Big Plans And Mysterious Complaints
description: If there is one thing that everyone in Brooklyn who knew Othniel Boaz Askew could agree on, it is that he had big plans. At 31, he had tried his hand at the real estate business, rebuilding a row house in Fort Greene, and had served in the military, friends said. But he was always looking for the next big thing.

title: CELL GENESYS GETS $28.5 MILLION FROM NOVARTIS IN DEAL
description: Cell Genesys Inc., a maker of experimental cancer medicines, will receive $28.5 million as part of a research agreement with Novartis, the drug maker. Cell Genesys, based in South San Francisco, Calif., bought rights to virus therapies that kill cancer cells from Novartis, which will retain some development options. In return, Novartis will get about two million shares, or a 5 percent stake, in Cell Genesys, the companies said in a statement.

title: Report Says Freddie Mac Misled Investors
description: Freddie Mac, the big mortgage financier, has used a grab bag of accounting techniques to mislead investors about its results since 2000, according to a report released yesterday by the company. Gregory Parseghian, the new chief executive, knew of some of the tactics, which reduced reported profits, the report said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRAVEN, , CLARENCE LEO ''HONEY''
description: CRAVEN--Clarence Leo ''Honey'', 98, formerly of Curry Cross Road, Madison, CT and Boynton Beach, FL, husband of the late Eileen (Griffin) Craven, passed away on Tuesday, July 22nd at Fowler Nursing Center in Guilford. Born on September 10, 1904 in Brookline, MA, he was the son of the late Joseph and Elizabeth (O'Leary) Craven. Mr. Craven was the ringmaster, and later manager of the National (NY) and Devon (PA) Horse Shows for several decades. He served as ringmaster of many other shows, including Piping Rock on Long Island, Pin Oaks in Houston, TX and Eastern States in MA, where his coaching horn calls summoned entries into the ring. He was associated with The London Harness Co. of Boston for many years. Craven is a US Equestrian Lifetime Achievement award winner. He was also a member of Madison Square Garden (NYC) Hall of Fame, and in March of 2003 was inducted into the Show Jumping Hall of Fame. He is survived by a daughter and son-in-law, Carol and Henry O. Robinson II, of Madison; three grandchildren, Henry O. Robinson, III of Breckenridge, CO, Lawrence Preston Robinson of Guilford and Elizabeth Robinson Baldwin of Dallas, TX and two great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by six brothers, Francis, Joseph, William, Arthur, James and Gerard and two sisters, Mary G. ''Mollie'' Craven and Katherine Ryan. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10:30am Saturday, at St. Margaret's Church. Calling hours will precede the mass at the Swan Funeral Home, 825 Boston Post Road, Madison on Saturday morning from 910am. Interment will be in Holy Hood Cemetery in Brookline, MA at the convenience of the family. Contributions may be made in his memory to the US Equestrian Team Young Rider's Development Program, Gladstone, NJ. >>AD#

title: Taking Tips From Treetops
description: A BAND of American tree aficionados has fresh designs on Robin Hood's hideout in Sherwood Forest near Nottingham, England. If all goes as planned, one of them will scale a wizened white oak 11 feet in diameter -- reputed to be 1,000 years old and a Robin Hood meeting place -- and slice a tiny baby branch from its tip. The new growth, gingerly packed in dry ice, will then be rushed overnight to a cloning lab in the United States.

title: Portrait of the Artist As a Former Athlete
description: Vernon Wells used to draw sketches before and after meetings when he was trying out as a free-agent wide receiver for the Kansas City Chiefs in 1977. His teammates would compliment him on the intimate details of his portraits, but Wells would inevitably store his pencil and pad because, after all, he was in camp to make the football team. Then the Chiefs cut him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SINGER, , SELMA
description: SINGER--Selma. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Myron Fenster, Int. Sr. Rabbi Sidney Freedman, President >>AD#

title: KROGER PAYMENT OF $110 MILLION TO DYNEGY IS APPROVED
description: Energy regulators approved a $110 million payment by the Kroger Company, the largest supermarket chain in the country, to Dynegy Inc. to settle power-supply contracts agreed during California's energy crisis in early 2001. Dynegy, a Houston power producer, agreed to terminate two contracts and restructure two others on July 3. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission approved the settlement. Under the agreement, Dynegy will provide Kroger stores in California with 50 megawatts of power through 2006. Kroger, based in Cincinnati, said the settlement would reduce second-quarter earnings by about $41 million.

title: Times They Are Surreal in Bob Dylan Tale
description: In the midst of a heated discussion about something or another, Jack Fate, a gnomic folk singer, brings up the subject of cellulose. ''It's in the grass,'' he says to Nina Veronica, a blowzy concert promoter played by Jessica Lange. ''Cows can digest it. But you can't, and neither can I.''

title: Judge's Role Questioned in Bid to Sell a Home
description: From the beginning, it was an unusually high-profile case. When a Westchester County high school student died in April 2002 after being punched at an after-school drinking party in Harrison, the case drew national attention to the problem of teenage drinking.

title: American to Start For United in Goal
description: Manchester United did not disappoint Tuesday night in the first game of its four-game tour in the United States. It defeated Glasgow Celtic, 4-0, on goals by Ruud van Nistelrooy, Ryan Giggs, Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and David Bellion before a record crowd of 66,722 at Seahawks Stadium in Seattle.

title: A Rumpled Lawyer, Happy to Shed 'the Scarlet T'
description: The rumpled woman in the open-toed sandals was feeling pretty good yesterday. Even for this veteran of countless battles with what she calls an oppressive government, it's not every day that you beat the Justice Department.

title: Nigeria Readies Peace Force for Liberia; Battles Go On
description: With Liberians in their besieged capital running out of food and water, and rebel forces breaching key defensive lines, a regional West African group announced today in Senegal that it could send as many as 1,300 Nigerian peacekeeping troops to Liberia within two weeks.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Prune a Tomato?

title: Donor's Estate Sues Metropolitan Opera
description: Representatives of a Texas oil heiress regarded as the Metropolitan Opera's greatest individual donor are suing the Met to recover millions of dollars that they say the opera house used against the woman's artistic wishes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAW, , ALMA H.
description: LAW--Alma H., of Scarsdale, NY died peacefully in her sleep on July 22, 2003. She was 76 years old. She was born on April 19, 1927 in Racine, Wisconsin. She was the daughter of Alma S. Hanson and Allen C. Hanson. She married Edward G. Law in 1946 who passed away in 1986. Alma was an important writer and scholar of Soviet theatre and an authority on the work of playwright Vsevolod Meyerhold. She conducted extensive research in the Soviet archives in the 1970's long before they were generally open to scholars in the West. She wrote several books and translations of Soviet playwrights and was a valued resource to scholars of Soviet theatre. Alma received her PhD in Slavic Studies from Columbia University, was a fellow at the City University of New York in Slavic Studies and a fellow at the Woodrow Wilson Center in Washington, DC. Alma is survived by two sons, Keith Law and his wife Ann of Hartsdale, NY and Eric Law and his wife Candace of Berkley, Michigan. She is also survived by her sisters May Allyn Hanson of Racine, Wisconsin and Karen H. Poling of Bellevue, Washington. Services to be held at the funeral home Friday 12 noon. Interment Mt Pleasant Cemetery. Visiting hrs Thursday 2-4 7-9 PM at Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale NY 10583. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in her name to the Sisters of Divine Compassion, 52 North Broadway, White Plains, NY 10603 >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: An article on the front page of the Job Market section on Sunday about the use of telecommuting by disabled workers misstated the name of the disease that has caused Janet Pearce, a producer at NBC News, to split her time between home and office. It is multiple sclerosis, not muscular sclerosis.

title: ABBOTT UNIT PLEADS GUILTY TO OBSTRUCTING INVESTIGATION
description: The CG Nutritionals unit of Abbott Laboratories pleaded guilty yesterday to obstructing an investigation into accusations of defrauding government health-insurance programs, prosecutors said. The United States attorney's office for Southern Illinois said in a statement that it expected Abbott to pay $200 million in criminal penalties and $400 million in civil fines. The guilty plea was entered in federal court in East St. Louis, Ill. Abbott is based in Abbott Park, Ill. In settling the civil case, prosecutors said CG Nutritionals will be excluded permanently from participating in Medicare and Medicaid health-insurance programs. The settlement will not affect business dealings with the government by its parent, Abbott, and its Ross Products division, said Melissa Brotz, an Abbott spokeswoman. As part of the plea, a sentence of five years probation, in addition to the fines, was recommended. The agreement is subject to a judge's approval.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Effort To Free Hostages Shifts To Mali
description: Germany has begun another attempt to locate 15 missing European tourists, including 10 Germans, who were kidnapped by rebels in Algeria in February and are now reported to have been moved into the northern part of neighboring Mali. During a visit to the Mali capital, Bamako, the German state secretary, Jrgen Chrobog, met with President Amadou Toumani Tour to seek clarification on the fate of the tourists. A group of 17 European hostages was freed in Algeria by Algerian special forces in May. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Trial Ordered In Serial Killing Case
description: Robert Pickton, the 53-year-old farmer accused of being Canada's deadliest serial killer, will stand trial on charges of killing 15 women, a British Columbia court judge ordered. The victims are included in a list of 63 women, mostly prostitutes and drug addicts, who have disappeared from the streets of the Downtown Eastside section of Vancouver since 1983. The police have been combing Mr. Pickton's pig farm in Coquitlam, a Vancouver suburb, for human remains since February 2002, and this week expanded their search to swamp land near the farm. The court decision came after a lengthy hearing to determine if there was enough evidence to proceed. The trial is expected to begin next year. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Arrest In Bank Robberies
description: A Queens man who is a suspect in 11 bank holdups in 11 days was arrested yesterday, the police said. The man, Curtis Barthrop, 46, is accused of robbing banks in Queens, Manhattan and the Bronx from July 9 through July 19, stealing almost $4,000. In each robbery attempt he would pass a note to the teller and claim to have a gun, the police said. On July 11 and July 15, he tried to rob three banks within about an hour, the police said. He was arrested yesterday morning at his home on 145th Road.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 6 about the capture of a Macedonian who is accused of having enslaved dozens of young women for the sex trade reversed his given name and his surname. He is Dilaver Bojku.

title: Mets' Malaise Continues As Piazza Plans Return
description: The good news for the Mets came late this afternoon. Mike Piazza took batting practice for the first time since he recoiled from a pitch on May 16 and tore a groin muscle.

title: Carol Matthau, a Frank and Tart Memoirist, Dies at 78
description: Carol Matthau, whose outspoken memoir of her life and three marriages to two famous men brought her notoriety far beyond her own wide circle of Hollywood and literary celebrities, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 78.

title: Inquiry Into Attack Fuels the Frustration Of Some Soldiers' Kin
description: Although Pfc. Jessica D. Lynch has returned home to a huge and warm welcome, some families of those killed in the attack on her unit are frustrated with Army leaders for failing to better prepare and protect the group of maintenance and supply specialists attacked on the deadliest day of the war in Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JURIST, , ROSLYN
description: JURIST--Roslyn. Devoted wife and best friend to Harvey. Loving mother of Eric and Kenneth (Lynne and Gail). Grandmother of Elizabeth, Karen, Benjamin and Aaron. Retired NYC teacher, bridge player and good friend to many. Peacefully, after a brief illness, July 22nd, 2003. The linchpin of the family, will be dearly missed. >>AD#

title: Bush Calls for Bipartisan Bill on Medicare Prescription Benefit
description: President Bush told members of Congress today that he wanted them to work together in a bipartisan way to produce a bill adding prescription drug benefits to Medicare.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Fish Caught With Hook, Line and Sonar
description: USING sonar to help catch fish may seem unfair, but sonar evolved for hunting, at least in bats. They were pinging moths on nightly search-and-destroy missions eons before World War II destroyers hunted enemy submarines.

title: New Setback for Russia's Powerful Business Class
description: In a closed session today, the Moscow City Court denied bail to a business partner of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, Russia's richest man and one of its most powerful.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALDINGER, , PROFESSOR HERMANN V.
description: WALDINGER -- Professor Hermann V. Born Vienna, June 17, 1923. Died July 23, 2003 of complications from Parkinson's Disease. Mathematician, retired from Polytechnic University. Beloved husband of Renee. Cherished father of Roger and Ellen, father-in-law of Hilary and Francia. Devoted grandfather of Max, Miriam, Matteo, Joseph and Jeremy. Services July 25th, 9:30 AM at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87 Street, New York City.

title: Court Orders Accountant To Name Shelter Investors
description: A federal appeals court dealt a blow yesterday to accountants' ability to protect the identity of investors in tax shelters, ruling that one firm must turn over clients' names to regulators.
