title: Penalty Kick Sends Brazil to Cup Final
description: Brazil sent the United States crashing out of the Concacaf Gold Cup tonight with a 2-1 loss on a penalty kick in sudden-death overtime in their semifinal.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: TRIAL ORDERED IN SERIAL KILLING CASE Robert Pickton, the 53-year-old farmer accused of being Canada's deadliest serial killer, will stand trial on charges of killing 15 women, a British Columbia court judge ordered. The victims are included in a list of 63 women, mostly prostitutes and drug addicts, who have disappeared from the streets of the Downtown Eastside section of Vancouver since 1983. The police have been combing Mr. Pickton's pig farm in Coquitlam, a Vancouver suburb, for human remains since February 2002, and this week expanded their search to swamp land near the farm. The court decision came after a lengthy hearing to determine if there was enough evidence to proceed. The trial is expected to begin next year. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: F.C.C. MEDIA RULE BLOCKED IN HOUSE IN A 400-TO-21 VOTE
description: The House of Representatives overwhelmingly passed legislation today to block a new rule supported by the Bush administration that would permit the nation's largest television networks to grow bigger by owning more stations.

title: Messages in the Killing of Hussein's Sons
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Your Garbage. Pay for It.
description: Recycling is back in New York. The city's new policy, laid out in an eight-page booklet to be included in newspapers this weekend, may seem familiar -- and it should. The new rules, which are being phased in this month, will, by April of next year, be much the same as they were before last summer, when the city dropped plastic and glass from its recycling program in an effort to save money. It turns out that the costs of not recycling were greater than the costs of recycling after all.

title: 4 Noted Teams Eliminated In Spingold Competition
description: Four top-ranked teams in the Spingold Knockout Teams were eliminated in the first two days of play at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. The biggest surprise was the ouster of third-seeded James Cayne. With Geir Helgemo, Robert Levin, Michael Seamon and Steve Weinstein, he lost to an unheralded foursome: Leo LaSota, Alan Kleist, Fred King and Richard Wegman.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Hyperion To Buy Brio Software
description: The Hyperion Solutions Corporation, a maker of business software whose shares have doubled in the last 12 months, agreed yesterday to buy Brio Software Inc. for about $142 million in cash and stock. Brio shareholders will receive 0.109 share of Hyperion and 36.3 cents for each Brio common share, Hyperion said in a statement. The agreement values Brio at $3.60 a share. Shares of Brio rose 30 cents, to $3 yesterday on Nasdaq. Hyperion makes software that helps businesses analyze their performance, and the acquisition of Brio will give the company more such products, a spokesman, Bob Schettino, said. Shares of Hyperion rose $1.50, to $29.68. The news was released after the close of regular trading.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Danone Posts Profit
description: The world's largest yogurt maker, Groupe Danone, had a first-half profit of 402 million euros ($461 million) as demand for brands like Actimel and Light 'n Fit drove sales and the company sold slower-growing businesses. The earnings compared with a net loss of 630 million euros a year earlier, when the company, which is based in Paris, wrote down the value of some businesses.

title: California Sets Recall Vote Date and Resolves Ballot Issue
description: SACRAMENTO, July 24  California embarked today on an 11-week election campaign unlike any ever seen here, as the lieutenant governor set Oct. 7 as the date for a recall vote on Gov. Gray Davis and Republicans and Democrats, many still in disbelief, ratcheted up the political rhetoric.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TURECK, , ROSALYN
description: TURECK -- Rosalyn. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sadness the passing of its beloved friend Rosalyn Tureck on July 17 in Riverdale, New York at the age of 88. A native of Chicago, Mme. Tureck studied with Jan Chiapusso, Sophia Brilliant-Liven and later with Olga Samaroff at The Juilliard School. Her legendary Town Hall recitals of 1937 ignited her fame as a Bach specialist. She was a forward thinking musician who championed contemporary composers and inventive programming. A scholar of great renown, her creativity and passion for her music brought her an important public following. Mme. Tureck was a devoted member of the Steinway Artist family for more than six decades, and she was an inspiring force in the world of music. Her loss is deeply felt, but her acclaimed discography will keep her legacy alive for future generations. To her family we extend our heartfelt condolences. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities >>AD#

title: Dreaming Between The Grooves
description: IT looked like the midsection of a giant centipede, or a discreet little spaceship, or possibly the natural habitat of Tinky Winky and his Teletubby pals. But the thought that consumed my 6-year-old daughter, Alice, and me as we prepared to spend the night in the futuristic bubble of a house that loomed in front of us was practical rather than aesthetic. Where would we go to the bathroom?

title: They Still Dim But No Longer Are They Dull
description: Bulbs, lamps and lampshades come in a range of colors. Now even dimmer switches are available in shades other than black and white. The familiar Lutron dimmer switch is available in ''hot,'' a tomato red, and two translucent colors, sea glass and blue mist, right. The blue and green dimmers are designed to blend into glass-tiled bathrooms that evoke a watery ambience, said Steven Pancheri, manager of residential products at Lutron, in Coopersburg, Pa. The switches are available in 15 colors and sell for $25 to $30 apiece. For information, (877) 258-8766, extension 693.

title: Questions and Assumptions Surround Recall Process
description: With the impending vote on whether to recall Gov. Gray Davis, California is on a fast track to someplace it has never been. The path is fraught with uncertainties and questions without precedent.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Governor Names Security Chief
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has appointed James W. McMahon, the state police superintendent, as the new director of the State Office of Public Security. Mr. McMahon will succeed John Scanlon, who is retiring, and will be the third head of the office, which was formed in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks. Mr. McMahon, 60, has led New York's troopers for nine years and played a leading role in the investigations of the 1996 explosion of a T.W.A. jetliner off Long Island and the 2001 attack on the World Trade Center. The governor has nominated Wayne E. Bennett, first deputy superintendent of the state police, to succeed Mr. McMahon. Both nominations are subject to confirmation by the State Senate. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Rate Cut
description: Brazil's central bank cut the benchmark lending rate by 1.5 percentage points to 24.5 percent, the biggest reduction in four years, in a bid to spur economic growth after high borrowing costs stifled investment and consumer spending. The rate cut was the second in two months and followed a drop in consumer prices in June.

title: F.C.C. Chairman Endures Rebuke, Despite Putting Law Above Politics
description: The vote in the House today to derail media ownership rules was a setback for Michael K. Powell, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, who was guided by the laws, rather than the politics, constraining media conglomerates.

title: American Agriculture
description: To the Editor:

title: Armed for a Scorcher, Inside or Out
description: JULY is the hottest month of the year in most parts of the United States, and in New York, temperatures average 86 degrees from July 18 to Aug. 2, according to Fred Gadomsky, a meteorologist at Pennsylvania State University.

title: Kidd Will Sign New Deal Today
description: Jason Kidd decided two weeks ago that he wanted to remain with the Nets, and today he will sign a six-year, $103.57 million contract with the team.

title: Messages in the Killing of Hussein's Sons
description: To the Editor:

title: Chapel Royal Wins Sanford Stakes
description: The trainer Todd Pletcher visited the winners circle after an important race for the second day in a row yesterday at Saratoga Race Course. This time, his strapping 2-year-old colt Chapel Royal routed a field of seven in the Grade II, $150,000 Sanford Stakes.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Elizabeth Smart Reward
description: Eight people who helped recover Elizabeth Smart will share a $250,000 reward. Elizabeth was 14 in June 2002 when she was taken from her house in Salt Lake City. She was returned to her family in March after two couples saw her on a street in Sandy and called 911. Six recipients remain anonymous; the others were Alvin and Anita Dickerson, who were among those who saw Elizabeth in Sandy. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Here a Dot, There a Dot, Everywhere Dot Dot Dot
description: In 1995, the Garnet Hill catalog unsuccessfully introduced a red polka dot sheet and pillowcase for adults in flannel. This summer, the company introduced polka dots all over again, but this time in percale, above, and for children. In two weeks in June, Garnet Hill sold 25 percent more polka dot linens than in three whole months in 1995, said Kimberly Aylward, a spokeswoman for the company. The line, called Dot-to-Dot, comes in red, orange, blue or green dots; sheets are $28 to $40, a single pillowcase is $13 and a comforter cover costs $75 to $85. Information: www.garnethill.com.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: INTEREST POLICY DEFENDED The Bank of Japan's zero-interest rate policy is helping to limit a surge in bond yields and the central bank is committed to it, the bank's governor, Toshihiko Fukui, said. "Because of the effects of our policy, Japan's interest rates at the maturity of up to several years have been stable at low levels," Mr. Fukui said in a speech at a meeting of Japanese business executives in Tokyo. Mr. Fukui said the bank planned to keep interest rates low until consumer prices rise.

title: High Court Again Freezes Aid To 30 Poorest School Districts
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court today approved a freeze, for the second year in a row, in state aid for the 30 poorest school districts.

title: Metro Matters; How Does A Gun Get In? With a Wave
description: JEANNIE EDWARDS, from the Lower East Side by way of Alabama, stood across from City Hall yesterday taking in the scene, which was quite a scene to take in. Helicopters hovered overhead and police officers marched in and out of City Hall's plaza carrying semiautomatic weapons and shields. There were police cars and police vans, ambulances and trucks. There were enough police officers to fight a small war and enough reporters to cover it. Because what happened -- which was bad enough -- could have been so much worse.

title: Commissioner Addresses Future Of the Big East
description: Big East Commissioner Mike Tranghese said today that his conference had a shortlist of candidates to replace Miami and Virginia Tech, who will leave the conference after one more season to join the Atlantic Coast Conference.

title: For Spiriting Away Spy Files, A Watch With Hidden Depths
description: The Laks memory watch is more than just a pretty face: it incorporates a flash memory chip of up to 256 megabytes in a slim quartz timepiece with a U.S.B. connector cord nestled in the watchband. ''A lot of people who are going to buy a stick of memory think they might as well get a watch with it,'' said Scott Smith, a founder of ThinkGeek (www.thinkgeek.com), which distributes the watch in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOMBARDO, , FRANK T.
description: LOMBARDO--Frank T., 89, on July 23, 2003. President of Viking Sales Co. Beloved husband of Antoinette. Loving father of Philip (Carolyn), Bernadette (Alfred) Ilch and Joseph (Julia). Cherished grandfather of six and greatgrandfather of three. Dear brother of William and James. Reposing 2-4:30 & 79:30 P.M. Friday at Raynor & D'Andrea Funeral Home, 245 Montauk Hwy, West Sayville, L.I. Funeral Mass 9:45 A.M. Saturday at St. John Nepomucene RC Church, Bohemia. Interment in Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. >>AD#

title: 9/11 Congressional Report Faults F.B.I.-C.I.A. Lapses
description: The Sept. 11 attacks were preventable, but the plot went undetected because of communications lapses between the F.B.I. and C.I.A., which failed to share intelligence related to two hijackers, a Congressional report to be released on Thursday says.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEA, , JOAN
description: SHEA--Joan. Passed away at the age of 70 on July 21st. Beloved daughter of the late Geoffrey and Sarah Citrin Shea. Dear sister of Adrienne Strull and Stephen Shea. Adoring aunt of Brian, Eric and Valerie. Great-aunt of Sean, Brandon, Cody, Alec, Courtney, Nicole and Ryan. Services at Pinelawn Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY, Thursday at 11 AM. >>AD#

title: At Home on the New Range, the Cowboy Concierge
description: WARREN ANDERS has a belt buckle larger than many small mammals. Like most cowboys, he's sturdy, serious and polite. He has a honey gelding named Reuben and a dog named Bird. On a breezy summer morning, Mr. Anders stepped into a sparkling white Ford F-150 pickup to survey the Rocking K Ranch, which spills over the Sapphire Mountains of southwestern Montana as far as the eye can see. He drove past the 9,500-square-foot garage and dining hall, then past the pitch-and-putt golf tees, the 3-D archery range, the rifle range and the constructed trout pond and over to the swimming hole called Bikini Beach. Here, he leaned over the dock and turned on a delicate spigot sculptured like an owl's head.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 6 about the capture of a Macedonian who is accused of having enslaved dozens of young women for the sex trade reversed his given name and his surname. He is Dilaver Bojku.

title: Bush's Four Horsemen
description: On the domestic front, President Bush is backing into a buzz saw.

title: AOL Results Do Not Shake Investor Worry
description: Continuing accounting troubles and a steep decline in the number of America Online subscribers overshadowed an otherwise rosy report yesterday of second-quarter results at AOL Time Warner.

title: Strong Financial Results at Roche and Glaxo
description: The natural resistance of drug makers to the vagaries of economic ups and downs shone through today in the latest financial results from Roche of Switzerland and GlaxoSmithKline of Britain. Both reported substantial sales and earnings gains on the strength of their latest big drugs.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CANTEL MEDICAL CORP., Little Falls, N.J., a maker of products for cleaning medical devices, said it had agreed to buy Mar Cor Services Inc., Skippack, Pa., and Biolab Group, Oakville, Canada, for about $16.3 million in cash and an undisclosed amount of assumed debt to enter the water-treatment industry.

title: Councilman Is Fatally Shot in City Hall
description: A New York City councilman was killed inside City Hall yesterday afternoon by a political opponent who accompanied him to a Council meeting, pulled out a pistol and shot him in front of scores of stunned lawmakers and onlookers, officials said.

title: A Budding Tumor Unmasked by the Vessels That Feed It
description: FOR a tumor to grow, it needs a good supply of blood, which it gets by switching on the body's process of blood-vessel making, known as angiogenesis. Researchers are trying to develop drugs to inhibit angiogenesis as a way of fighting tumors, but they need ways to make sure the inhibitors, which have so far had mixed results, are effective early in therapy, long before the vessels affect the tumor itself.

title: Blair Denies He Gave Name Of Arms Aide To the Media
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair has denied that he approved making public the name of a weapons inspector, David Kelly, in the running battle between his government and the BBC. Dr. Kelly died last week, apparently a suicide.

title: U.S. Satisfies Australia on Possible Terror Trial
description: Australia's minister of justice said today that his government was satisfied with the fairness of the procedures the United States would use if it tried David Hicks, an Australian citizen, on terrorism charges before a military tribunal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARSON, , MILTON
description: GARSON--Milton. Dearly beloved husband and best friend of Frances M. (Frank), devoted father of the late Geoffrey. Very dear grandfather of Lisa B. Garson. Services will be held on Thursday July 24, 2003 at 1:30 P.M. at Riversville Cemetery, Glenville, CT.

title: Telling Children Not to Inhale Junk Food, Either
description: HECTOR BATISTA wants to stamp out obesity in the New York City schools. He is not an intimidating figure. He is rather unassuming and low key. So one wonders exactly how he will accomplish this feat: persuading schoolchildren to give up sugary drinks and high-fat treats.

title: From 156 Options, Down to 15 Ways to Go on Tappan Zee
description: Engineers and planners designing an alteration to or replacement for the Tappan Zee Bridge to ease congestion at one of the region's most notorious bottlenecks have narrowed 156 options down to 15.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: House Passes Bill to Block New Media Rule by F.C.C.

title: Some Things Old, Some New, All Connected by 'Clean Lines'
description: Last month, Ted Wolter, above, moved his home furnishings store, Lucca, from East Hampton to Manhattan's meatpacking district. The store sells antiques and new pieces, all united by what he calls ''very clean lines.''

title: Earnings at Anheuser-Busch Rose 7.9%
description: Anheuser-Busch said today that second-quarter earnings rose 7.9 percent because of higher prices and increased sales of its low-carbohydrate Michelob Ultra beer.

title: America's Role in Liberia
description: President Bush has said that he wants to help West African countries bring peace to war-ravaged Liberia. But with the fighting once again threatening Liberia's capital, his administration has hesitated about how and when to provide that assistance. Mr. Bush should dispatch 800 to 2,000 American soldiers to lead a temporary multinational intervention force capable of enforcing a cease-fire and paving the way for an African-led peacekeeping mission. Further delay may needlessly condemn thousands of Liberian civilians to death. Hundreds have already died this week.

title: Ex-President Said to Urge Complex Deals
description: David W. Glenn contributed to a corporate culture that prized steady earnings growth at Freddie Mac and authorized erroneous accounting techniques to achieve that goal, according to a report released yesterday by the company.

title: Mi Taco No Es Su Taco
description: Highlights from this week's forums, including good tacos and bad e-mail.

title: The Epitaph for Sprewell: Played Hard, Spread Blame
description: The car sped into the driveway of the Knicks' practice facility in Greenburgh, N.Y., abruptly swerving away from the security gate and the parking lot and pulling to a stop alongside a waiting group of reporters. It was Oct. 21, 2002, and Latrell Sprewell was going to have his say.

title: Croquet, Anyone? (Civility Optional)
description: WHEN I was growing up, my family took games so seriously that during a particularly heated round of four-handed solitaire my youngest brother almost lost a finger to a hard-slapped two of spades.

title: A Bartok Feat by the Borromeo Quartet
description: Since its debut in 1989 the Borromeo String Quartet has established itself as a solid ensemble with a reliably warm sound and a passion for both the standard repertory and new music. But the quartet world is a crowded place just now, and it must have occurred to the group that it was time for a grand gesture.

title: Conservative Anglican Leaders Warn of a Schism
description: Five Anglican archbishops from Africa, Asia and Australia met here today with more than 50 conservative American Episcopalians to convey a warning that if the Episcopal Church USA votes at its convention to accept a gay bishop or to bless same-sex unions, it would ''precipitate a dramatic realignment of the church.''

title: Davis Recalled as Maverick Who Rallied Against Violence
description: To many in central Brooklyn, Councilman James E. Davis was the man whose face was the centerpiece of red-and-white campaign posters on scores of bus shelters and store windows in the area.

title: Two Bishops in New York Faulted for Role in Abuse Cases
description: Two New York-area bishops, Thomas V. Daily of Brooklyn and William Murphy of Long Island, came in for a strong share of blame in a report issued yesterday by the Massachusetts attorney general on the sexual abuse of children by priests in the Boston Archdiocese.

title: 3 More U.S. Soldiers Killed in Iraq as Resistance Continues
description: QAIYARA, Iraq, July 24 - Three soldiers with the Army's 101st Airborne Division were killed in an ambush here early this morning that involved what one local resident said was an attack by insurgents armed with grenades and Kalashnikov automatic rifles.

title: Agents Search Marketing Firm
description: Advanced Marketing Services said yesterday that the federal authorities, holding a search warrant and a subpoena, arrived at its headquarters seeking records regarding its advertising services.

title: A's General Manager Does Things His Way
description: BILLY BEANE, the Oakland Athletics general manager, is often portrayed as a baseball genius. But Moneyball, MICHAEL LEWISs behind-the-scenes account of a year with Beane and the As front office, paints more of a portrait of a mad scientist.

title: 789 Children Abused by Priests Since 1940, Massachusetts Says
description: BOSTON, July 23  At least 789 children and probably more than 1,000 have been sexually abused by 250 priests and other church workers in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston since 1940, according to a 16-month investigation by the Massachusetts attorney general that was made public today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HANSEN, , HARRY A.
description: HANSEN--Harry A. Of Stewart Manor, New York. Beloved husband of Rita. Loving father of Matthew, Kathleen and Janice. Devoted grandfather of Thomas, Christopher, Eric, Jessica, Steven and James. Dear brother of Patricia Wersen, Florence Conley and George Wright. Dear uncle to nephews, nieces, great-nephews and great-nieces and a friend to all. Reposing Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Ave., Garden City, NY. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:30 AM St. Anne's Church. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUSHEE, , PHILIP
description: GUSHEE--Philip, died July 22, of cancer at home in Manhattan. Husband of Cheryl, loving father of Eric, brother of Susan O'Malley, Cynthia Scott and Anne Arsenault, and beloved acting teacher of many, he will be missed. >>AD#

title: Downtown Lighting With Hints Of Jazz
description: There are lights at the end of my tunnel. Fifty-four new street lamps, to be precise, lined up along Broadway in the financial district. That's enough wattage to give me hope that our great city may soon emerge from the spiritual depression that has gripped the design of street furniture in New York for the past two decades.

title: E-Mail Etiquette Redux
description: Im incredibly proud of you, the Circuits newsletter readership -- or maybe I should say writership. Not only were your 2,000 responses to my July 10 E-mail Etiquette column thoughtful, funny, articulate and persuasive, but not a single one was abusive and mean.

title: Messages in the Killing of Hussein's Sons (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Setting Record Straight on Ruth
description: Fixing the reputation of Harry Frazee, the owner of the Boston Red Sox who sold Babe Ruth to the Yankees in late 1919, is no easy task. You don't sell Babe Ruth, even if he wasn't Babe Ruth yet, and come away with history adoring you as if you were Branch Rickey.

title: 50 years of truce  and tension  in the DMZ
description: PANMUNJOM:  Five days before the 50th anniversary of the signing here of the truce that ended the Korean War on July 27, 1953, American and South Korean officers were busy Tuesday, planning what they call a "commemoration," not a celebration.

title: One-of-a-Kind Fabrics From Southern Pakistan
description: Two years ago, Omar Rahim, a modern dancer, founded Soof Designs, a company that imports one-of-a-kind hand-stitched patchwork quilts made by women in the Sind Province in southern Pakistan, the country where he was born. ''The women wear brilliant printed cotton fabrics, and use these same fabrics for household linens,'' Mr. Rahim, 27, said. The quilts, which can be washed in cold water and tumbled dry at low temperature, take three months to make. The Soof Designs quilts, above, are $850 to $1,100 at Bloomingdale's in Manhattan and at Bloomingdale's in the old Medinah Temple building in Chicago, 600 North Wabash Avenue.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Detroit Police Monitor Starts Work
description: The court-appointed federal monitor of the Detroit Police Department, Sheryl L. Robinson, began overseeing changes in the problem-plagued department. Ms. Robinson and her team will, at an estimated cost of $6.25 million over five years, plus expenses, help the department comply with changes set forth by the Justice Department and the city and in two consent decrees. Caitlin Nish (NYT)

title: Net Tumbles at Electronic Data
description: Electronic Data Systems said yesterday that its second-quarter profit dropped 56 percent because of asset write-downs and severance pay for former executives.

title: City Hall Was Prepared, But Not for Act of Courtesy
description: As usual, a dozen police officers guarded City Hall yesterday. Metal detectors were in place, standing prominently at each of the ornate building's side gates. Visitors were still interviewed twice about their intended business before they could gain entry.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: EFFORT TO FREE HOSTAGES SHIFTS TO MALI Germany has begun another attempt to locate 15 missing European tourists, including 10 Germans, who were kidnapped by rebels in Algeria in February and are now reported to have been moved into the northern part of neighboring Mali. During a visit to the Mali capital, Bamako, the German state secretary, Jurgen Chrobog, met with President Amadou Toumani Toure to seek clarification on the fate of the tourists. A group of 17 European hostages was freed in Algeria by Algerian special forces in May. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHELDON, , EILA
description: SHELDON--Eila, long time resident of Port Washington, NY, passed away peacefully at home on July 21, 2003. Loving mother of Don and Gail, loving grandmother of Donald Michael, loving aunt of Robert Merrill, and Charlie and Valerie Merrill. A strong and caring lady who will be missed. Services private. >>AD#

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Telecom Profit
description: Bharti Tele-Ventures, an Indian telephone company, said yesterday that it had earned 310 million rupees ($6.7 million) in its first quarter, reversing a year-earlier loss of 676 million rupees ($14.6 million). The company, India's largest cellular provider, said it doubled the number of cellular and fixed-line subscribers in the last year. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, , SIMON
description: SCHWARTZ -- Simon. The United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism mourns the passing of Simon Schwartz, International President of the United Synagogue from 1977-1981. During his many years of dedicated service to our organization, he demonstrated a firm commitment to Jewish education and to the State of Israel. A kind and compassionate man, he will long be remembered for his tireless efforts on behalf of the entire Jewish community. We extend our condolences to his wife Ruth, and to his children. Judy Yudof, Int'l. Pres. Rabbi Jerome M. Epstein, Executive V.P. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: ALBANY: GOVERNOR NAMES SECURITY CHIEF Gov. George E. Pataki has appointed James W. McMahon, the state police superintendent, as the new director of the State Office of Public Security. Mr. McMahon will succeed John Scanlon, who is retiring, and will be the third head of the office, which was formed in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks. Mr. McMahon, 60, has led New York's troopers for nine years and played a leading role in the investigations of the 1996 explosion of a T.W.A. jetliner off Long Island and the 2001 attack on the World Trade Center. The governor has nominated Wayne E. Bennett, first deputy superintendent of the state police, to succeed Mr. McMahon. Both nominations are subject to confirmation by the State Senate.   Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Residential Sales column on July 10 for a brownstone at 215 West 136th Street in Manhattan misidentified the neighborhood. It is in Harlem but not in the Strivers' Row historic district.

title: ENRON WORKERS SUE OVER BONUSES PAID TO EXECUTIVES
description: Former executives of the Enron Corporation have been sued by a group of workers seeking the return of $72 million in bonuses paid in the days surrounding the company's collapse in a record bankruptcy proceeding. Four lawsuits have been filed in federal bankruptcy court in Houston against 292 former employees, officers and executives of the energy company by the Enron Employee-Related Issues Committee, a panel named in Enron's bankruptcy case. The lawsuits come as Enron is trying to advance a reorganization plan filed this month that might allow it to emerge from bankruptcy by year's end.

title: Insular Japan Needs, but Resists, Immigration
description: With their tidy suburban home here, a late-model Toyota in the driveway and two school-age children whose Japanese is indistinguishable from any native's, Akio Nakashima and his wife, Yoshie, are the perfect immigrants.

title: U.S. to Use Mix of Regular, National Guard and Reserve Troops in Iraq
description: The Pentagon will deploy to Iraq a mix of active-duty and National Guard soldiers to relieve battle-weary forces in a new rotation plan, the Army's top general announced today. But for the rotation plan to work in the long term, the general said, allies must contribute more troops.

title: DELTA PILOTS SET CONDITIONS FOR RESUMING TALKS
description: Pilots for Delta Air Lines, who are being asked to take pay cuts, said they would resume labor talks only if the airline agreed to extend their current contract and abandoned a proposal to match the cost reductions made at competitors. The union's top council informed Delta that the current contract would need to be extended as part of any agreement, according to the union's Web site. The union also said it thought that pilot costs at Delta do not need to be in line with those at its rivals for the carrier to be profitable. In April, Delta asked its pilots to agree to reduce their hourly pay by 22 percent. No one from the union, the Air Line Pilots Association, was immediately available for further comment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OPTEKMAN, , ANNETTE
description: OPTEKMAN--Annette. With profound sadness we mourn the passing of our beloved mother on July 22nd. She enriched our lives and the lives of her grandchildren and great - children. And, of course, that of our dear father, Harold, whom we lost in 1998. This extraodinary woman, born in New York City, graduated from Hunter College and was a Teacher in the NYC school system. Among her many interests, she contributed to the community as an active leader at Anshe Sholom Jewish Center. In 1987 she and our father were honored by the UJA-Federation Campaign. Annette brought happiness to every life she touched and she will be eternally missed. Bonnie Optekman Stephanie Saft Arline Golby Services Thursday 1PM at Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 76th Rd at Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY

title: Jean R. Warnke
description: Jean R. Warnke, a volunteer in social service organizations in Washington and the widow of Paul C. Warnke, a top official in the Johnson and Carter administrations, died on Monday in a Brooklyn hospice. She was 80 and lived in Washington.

title: Here, Preservation Meets Imagination
description: IT won't be enough to say, ''Don't tear it down.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 12 about a proposed election for honorary mayor of Harlem referred incorrectly to The Amsterdam News, which is sponsoring the project. It is a weekly tabloid, not a daily broadsheet.

title: My Close Encounter With the QE2
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: CINCINNATI BELL CHIEF TO STEP DOWN Cincinnati Bell Inc., the local telephone company formerly known as Broadwing Inc. , said its chief executive, Kevin Mooney, would leave after less than a year in the post. No replacement was named. Mr. Mooney, 45, previously the chief operating officer, was named chief executive in September, succeeding Rick Ellenberger, who led a money-losing foray into the fiber optic network business. Earlier this month, Cincinnati Bell said in a federal regulatory filing that it might replace Mr. Mooney, who sold the fiber optic unit in June. (Bloomberg News)

title: Messages in the Killing of Hussein's Sons
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; The Supreme Court finds the 'mushball middle' on affirmative action.
description: ''WHEN we see a complicated, seemingly intractable problem,'' the comedian Al Franken once remarked about affirmative action, ''we have the only really genuine, authentic human reaction you can have: we're confused.''

title: Judicial Nominee Advances Amid Dispute Over Religion
description: A scheduled vote in the Senate Judiciary Committee today on one of President Bush's most conservative judicial nominees turned into an extraordinary debate over whether Democrats were blocking Catholics from being named to the federal bench or whether such an accusation was a politically motivated slur.

title: Tenet Vows Improvements in Patient Care
description: Tenet Healthcare, under investigation for possibly overbilling Medicare, making illegal payments to doctors and performing unnecessary operations, told shareholders today that it was embarking on a new thrust -- to improve its patient care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINDERMAN, , BRENDA
description: LINDERMAN--Brenda, 64, of Boynton Beach passed away July 22, 2003. Sometimes in life if you are very lucky you will find someone like Brenda. She was more than a wife, she was a confidant, my partner, my friend. She made life a joy and an adventure. She touched everyone with whom she came in contact. She was a proud, adoring and loving mother to Jeffrey and Jennifer and she considered our son-in-law David as a second son. But the love of her life, the apple of her eye and her greatest thrill was to be Dillon's Bubby. Now she's free of the pain that has consumed her these past seven months. It's up to us to now feel the loneliness without her. If after all we judge a person's life by those they touch, the good they do, the joy and love they give to others, than her short stay on this earth was a gift to everyone, especially to me. Sleep in peace, my darling. I love you and you will always be in my heart and in every fiber of my being until I'm with you again. As always, ILY, Gary. >>AD#

title: New Doubts on Taylor
description: The question of when and whether President Charles G. Taylor will leave Liberia -- an important step in ending hostilities and paving the way for peacekeepers -- grew murky again today when his spokesman, Vaanii Passewe, said the latest assault by rebels and ''obstruction'' by the international community had forced Mr. Taylor to reconsider.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: And in This Corner, A Linguistic Lightweight

title: In the Lecture Hall, A Geek Chorus
description: AT the University of Maryland, it started as an innocent question posed in an e-mail message to those attending WebShop, a three-week lecture series about the Internet.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about a new encyclopedia of advertising misstated the surname of a character in William Gibson's novel ''Pattern Recognition'' who is a cool-hunter, a connoisseur of advertising symbols and allusions. She is Cayce Pollard, not Packard.

title: Poltergeist by Design
description: ARCHITECTS build with brick and glass, interior designers use paint, paneling and paisley. Cristina Grajales does none of those things. Neither architect nor interior designer, she rearranges furniture into offbeat tableaux, or shops for the unique piece that will make a winning appearance.

title: Exhibitions in the New York Region
description: New York Times art critics provide their take on recent exhibits in museum towns such as New Haven, Poughkeepsie and Newark.

title: Strong Convictions
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about new communities on the Indiana shore of Lake Michigan misstated the industrial history of Michigan City, Ind. It once made railroad cars, not automobiles. The article also incorrectly described a power plant in the area. It uses fossil fuels, not nuclear.

title: The Country Castro Will Leave Behind
description: Fifty years of victory, 50 weeks of goodbyes: it has an appealing symmetry. It was 50 years ago tomorrow that Fidel Castro led the assault that would eventually topple the Cuban government and bring him to power. He is sure to use the anniversary over the next year to remind Cubans that while they must plan for his succession, they should not expect a new regime.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Fatally Shot
description: A Brooklyn man was shot to death last night, and his attacker rode off on a motorcycle, the police said. The victim, Stacy Vaughn, 29, of Tompkins Avenue, was involved in a dispute around 10:30 p.m. with an unidentified man in front of 419 Pulaski Street in Bedford-Stuyvesant. Mr. Vaughn was shot four times in the neck and chest and died an hour later at Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Seabiscuit Season: The Downtrodden, the Uplifting
description: Everybody knows Seabiscuit was a sad case. For a purebred horse, he was an ugly duckling, little and brown, with a funny walk and knobby knees. His trainers and owners gave up on him. (Or had he given up on them first?) Then he met a grieving millionaire, a gentle trainer and an accident-plagued jockey and became the most famous racehorse of his day.

title: A.I.G.'s Profit Rises on Higher Prices
description: The American International Group, the world's largest insurer, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 26 percent to a record after the company raised prices on property and casualty coverage.

title: Show Tunes and Laughter Are a Boy's Best Friends
description: When Seth Rudetsky was a boy he wrote a new school song to the tune of ''Send In the Clowns.'' He managed to get out of gym class by taking jazz dance. Listening to the original cast album of ''The Pajama Game,'' he worried about Janis Paige's ability to belt high. Studying piano, he found the dark side of ''John Thompson's Teaching Little Fingers to Play.''

title: PENTAGON LEADERS WARN OF DANGERS FOR U.S. IN LIBERIA
description: Two days after Secretary of State Colin L. Powell called for the speedy deployment of troops to Liberia, the top two American military officers warned today of significant dangers facing United States military involvement there and called for a clear mission and a strategy for its successful end before any troops are sent.

title: New World Ancestors Lose 12,000 Years
description: Scientists studying the genetic signatures of Siberians and American Indians have found evidence that the first human migrations to the New World from Siberia probably occurred no earlier than 18,000 years ago.

title: Wrong Battle on TV Diversity
description: Readers may have done a double-take yesterday when they saw headlines announcing that the House of Representatives had defeated -- by an astonishing margin of 400 to 21 -- a television-ownership proposal favored by President Bush, his allies at the Federal Communications Commission and the Republican leadership. It looked as if the plan was terribly wrong and the House terribly bold in rising up almost as one to set things right. As is often the case in Washington, however, appearances can be deceiving. The president wasn't as off base, or the House as courageous, as it seemed.

title: Marriott Hires McGarry Bowen
description: Marriott International is expanding its agency roster by naming McGarry Bowen in New York to handle some creative duties in its account. Although billings were not disclosed, Marriott spent $96.8 million to advertise in major media last year, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR.

title: On the Ballot, A Candidate Still Unnamed
description: The death of Councilman James E. Davis has touched off mourning in his district, but it also leaves the question of who will take his place on the ballot.

title: On Terror, Doubts Anew
description: The report today on intelligence failures may force the Bush administration to confront a troubling question that the White House thought it put to rest months ago: how best to prevent another terrorist attack.

title: AT&T Results Beat Forecast, But Analysts Are Downbeat
description: Struggling with tough competition and a weak economy, AT&T reported second-quarter earnings yesterday that surpassed Wall Street expectations and reported an increase in its annual dividend. But analysts said the outlook for the company remained far from rosy.

title: A Day of Violence at City Hall
description: To the Editor:

title: Across Connecticut, a Summer Picnic's Worth of Exhibitions on View
description: The menu is nothing if not broad at Connecticut museums this summer. Among the shows at the state's most active institutions are an art collection assembled by Sol LeWitt; a tribute to Wallace Nutting, the merchandiser of antique America who has been called an early Martha Stewart; a dazzling display of jewelry going back to the Egyptians; a cautionary look at Connecticut's environment; and a tribute to British marine power that includes a rare sketchbook by J. M. W. Turner.

title: People
description: * James F. Lyons was named president at the New York office of Rapp Collins Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group. He succeeds Robert Solomon, who returned to his consulting company, Solomon Strategic. Mr. Lyons continues as president at Optima Direct, Vienna, Va., part of Rapp Collins.

title: John Schlesinger, 77, Director of 'Midnight Cowboy,' Dies
description: John Schlesinger, the Academy Award-winning director of "Midnight Cowboy" whose other films  including "Billy Liar," "Sunday, Bloody Sunday" and "Darling"  often captured the plight of individuals grasping for life support in contemporary society, died yesterday in Palm Springs, Calif, where he lived. He was 77.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: NEW HAVEN: EX-OFFICIAL SENTENCED IN GANIM SCANDAL A former state official who admitted accepting a bribe in return for supporting a $6.5 million government application for associates of former Bridgeport Mayor Joseph P. Ganim, was sentenced yesterday to four years probation. The official, Mark Trinkley, 47, a former senior development manager for the State Department of Economic Development, was also ordered to pay a $20,000 fine. Prosecutors said Mr. Trinkley, of Fairfield, received $35,000 in home improvements from Alfred Lenoci Sr. and Alfred Lenoci Jr., real-estate developers. The Lenocis had applied for a $6.5 million grant for a city building project. Mr. Trinkley is one of 11 people, including the Lenocis and Mr. Ganim, who were convicted in the federal corruption investigation. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Marriott Hires McGarry Bowen
description: Marriott International is expanding its agency roster by naming McGarry Bowen in New York to handle some creative duties in its account. Although billings were not disclosed, Marriott spent $96.8 million to advertise in major media last year, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Arrests Of Ex-Officers Ordered
description: Responding to an extradition request by the Spanish judge Baltasar Garzn, an Argentine court has issued provisional arrest orders for 46 leading figures from the military dictatorship that ruled the country from 1976 to 1983, including former junta members Gen. Jorge Videla and Adm. Emilio Massera. President Nstor Kirchner has promised to reverse a longstanding policy of not extraditing military officers and others accused of human rights abuses but has not yet signed the official decree that would permit Argentine violators to stand trial abroad. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Excerpts From Report on Intelligence Actions and the Sept. 11 Attacks
description: Following are excerpts from the report by Congressional intelligence committees on the actions of the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. before and after the attacks of Sept. 11. The committees' deletions of classified material, or changes in wording for national security reasons, are indicated by brackets. The full report is online at nytimes.com/washington.

description: To the Editor:

description: Early Tuscan, Courtesy of Yale

title: MEXICAN WIRELESS COMPANY OBTAINS AN ARGENTINE OPTION
description: Latin America's largest wireless company, Amrica Mvil, said yesterday that it had acquired an option to buy a controlling interest in an Argentine wireless company, CTI. CTI, in which Verizon Communications holds a 47.8 percent stake, is in talks to restructure its $1.1 billion debt. Amrica Mvil said that after the debt restructuring, CTI's enterprise value would fall to less than $200 million. If exercised, the option would give Amrica Mvil a 60 percent voting interest and a 49 percent economic interest in CTI, which has 1.2 million subscribers and licenses covering all of Argentina. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: Lottery Numbers
Long Island Shows: The Gilded Age to the Swirl of the Double Helix
description: Long Island art seekers are in for some time-travel this summer. They can visit fin-de-sicle Paris at the Nassau County Museum of Art, where an exhibition about Toulouse-Lautrec and his world is on view; the American Gilded Age at the Parrish Art Museum, which has a show about the sculptor August Saint-Gaudens; the mythic heyday of Abstract Expressionism as seen through the mischievous eyes of the collage maker Ray Johnson at the Pollock-Krasner House and Study Center; and the scientific future in a show of artistic speculations about genetics and DNA at the Heckscher Museum of Art.

title: NEC Spinoff Starts Well As Its Stock Increases 29%
description: The NEC Electronics Corporation, one of the world's largest chipmakers, rose 29 percent on its first day as a publicly traded company, as investors bet that increased demand for digital cameras and DVD players would increase profits.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway Posts Wider Loss
description: Gateway, the personal-computer maker, whose stock has dropped 96 percent since its peak, reported a wider second-quarter loss. The net loss expanded to $69.8 million, or 22 cents a share, from $58.5 million, or 19 cents, a year earlier, the company said yesterday. Sales fell 20 percent, to $799.6 million from $1 billion. Shares of Gateway fell 11 cents, to $3.68. The stock traded at $84 in November 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCELROY, , JOAN
description: McELROY--Joan. On July 19th, 2003. Beloved mother of Hanna McElroy. Grandmother of Ben and Jacob Weimer. Mother-in-law of Chris Weimer. The family wish to thank all those who helped during Joan's last illness, in particular, her cousin Bryn Kelsey and, most of all, Joan's best friend Bridgette Vidunas. Donations may be made to Joan McElroy Children's Fund, The Family Center, 66 Reade St, NY NY 10007. >>AD#

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Sweet Stress of Success
description: Ben Curtis was in a Manhattan hotel overlooking Central Park yesterday, with the claret jug for winning the British Open sitting in his room.

title: Art Shows in the Great Indoors
description: IT'S midsummer, and many humidity-addled New Yorkers are ready to hit the road to somewhere -- anywhere -- else. For art lovers, somewhere isn't the beach or the mountains; it's New Haven, Poughkeepsie or Newark, or a dozen other museum towns in the metropolitan area.

title: Twain's Tale, With Music for the Ear and Eye
description: The music doesn't end when the band stops playing.

title: Microsoft Moves To Weather Time Of Slow Growth
description: Microsoft today outlined a new corporate approach designed to allow the company to weather a period of slow growth in the computer industry. At the same time, its executives disputed the idea that the information technology boom had ended for good.

title: Cheney Asserts No Responsible Leader Could Have Ignored Danger From Iraq
description: Vice President Dick Cheney offered the White House's most forceful rebuttal to a growing tide of skepticism about justifications for the Iraq war today, arguing that it would have been ''irresponsible in the extreme'' to ignore the threat from Saddam Hussein's weapons program.

title: Israeli Soldier's Gunfire Kills Palestinian Child and Wounds 2
description: JERUSALEM, July 25  An Israeli soldier fired a machine gun that killed a 4-year-old Palestinian boy today and wounded two young girls while all three were in a family truck at a military checkpoint on the edge of a West Bank village, the military and Palestinian witnesses said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit At Siemens Drops
description: Germany's largest engineering company, Siemens, said that third-quarter profit dropped 13 percent, which was less than expected, as the company increased its results with one-time gains in its power generation and medical divisions. Net income for April through June fell to 632 million euros ($725 million), from 725 million euros ($834 million) a year earlier. Sales decreased 15 percent to 17.38 billion euros ($19.99 billion) in the quarter. In an attempt to help compensate for falling demand for telecommunications and power generation equipment, Siemens has cut 32,000 jobs in two years.

title: The U.S. and Liberia
description: To the Editor:

title: Combustible Mix Behind City Hall Shooting
description: It is often when the prizes are small that the battles seem the most ferocious. Local elections for offices like City Council can attract neighborhood gadflies and the occasional oddball. But they are also frequently bruising street fights, full of threats and intrigue, promises and favors.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Club Owners' Fine Is Upheld
description: A judge has upheld a $1 million workers' compensation fine against the owners of a West Warwick nightclub where a fire killed 100 people in February. The State Department of Labor and Training fined the owners, Jeffrey and Michael Derderian, $1,000 a day for the nearly three years they owned the Station nightclub without workers' compensation insurance. The judge, Bruce Q. Morin of Workers' Compensation Court, also ruled that each man could be held personally accountable, because their business was a limited liability company and not a corporation. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Her Husband Disappears, So She Must Find Herself
description: ''Luca, Luca'' realizes that it is so lucky to have Cecilia Roth in the starring role that her character's name is repeated. Still, while recognizing its star's allure, this title isn't nearly as good as the Spanish version: ''The Cannibal's Daughter.'' The American twist suggests a lack of confidence in American audiences that the movie itself doesn't have.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   AWAD, , DEWEY JOHN
description: AWAD--Dewey John. July 3, 1899--July 25, 1979 Pop, Another year of missing you, loving you and remembering you. Jimm

title: With Election Set, Davis Tries to Shift Focus
description: Surrounding himself with law enforcement officials, Gov. Gray Davis tried today to push aside questions about the recall election, saying that balancing the state's budget remained his top priority.

title: Mideast Plan Still Up in Air Despite Truce
description: As the Palestinian and Israeli prime ministers head to the White House for separate visits, they can point to a significant drop in violence over the last month but only halting steps in carrying out the peace plan backed by the Bush administration.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Child Rapper Growing Into His Bling-Bling

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Biotech Profit
description: A European biotechnology company, Serono, said it earned $108 million in its second quarter, an increase of 8 percent from the year-earlier quarter. The company was helped by a weak dollar and a 42 percent increase in sales of Rebif, a medicine for multiple sclerosis. Serono, which is based in Geneva, said sales in the period rose 21.2 percent to $508 million. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Dropping The Bonds
description: In his July testimony to Congress on monetary policy, Alan Greenspan was cautious but -- adjusting for his usual funereal demeanor -- quite upbeat. ''Although the uncertainties of earlier this year are as yet not fully resolved,'' he declared, ''the U.S. economy appears to have withstood a set of blows. . . . Not surprisingly the depressing effects of recent events linger. . . . Nevertheless, the fundamentals are in place for a return to sustained healthy growth.''

title: Informant for F.B.I. Had Contacts With Two 9/11 Hijackers
description: The F.B.I. may have missed its best chance to prevent the Sept. 11 plot when one of its informants developed close ties to two of the hijackers living in San Diego, yet never alerted the bureau to the impending attacks, according to a Congressional report released today.

title: Scrambling To Victory
description: AT the peak of his celebrity in the late 1930's, Seabiscuit, a runty, crooked-legged racehorse rescued from obscurity by a California car dealer, was the most famous mammal in America, surpassing even Franklin D. Roosevelt in media attention and popular esteem. In her best-selling book, ''Seabiscuit: An American Legend,'' published two years ago, Laura Hillenbrand ascribed the horse's renown to several causes, including the marketing savvy of his owner, Charles Howard; the growth of a national mass culture fueled by rural electrification, photographic wire services and cheap radios; and the ardent identification of Depression-weary Americans with a scrappy, indomitable underdog.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Airline Posts Loss
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines reported a quarterly loss of 54 million euros ($61.9 million), down from a profit of 11 million euros a year ago, partly because of weak passenger demand caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome and by the war in Iraq. Revenue in the period, KLM's first quarter, fell 16 percent, to 1.42 billion euros. The result exceeded analysts' forecasts, and the company's stock rose 3 percent. KLM, which is based in Amsterdam, said it expected to break even on an operating basis in the fiscal year, but that special items would lead to a net loss. On an operating basis, the company lost 66 million euros ($76 million) in the first quarter, down from an operating profit of 41 million euros ($47 million) a year earlier. KLM is in the midst of eliminating 4,500 positions from its payroll as part of a cost-cutting program. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Inquiry Into Soccer Deal

The agency, the Financial Services Authority, said its investigation followed the ''receipt of information from a number of sources suggesting that the publicly disclosed shareholdings of some parties may be inaccurate.'' Mr. Abramovich bought a majority stake of Chelsea from its chairman, Ken Bates, this month for about $100 million. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: I.B.M. TO LET MORE CUSTOMERS DEFER PAYMENTS I.B.M., the world's largest computer maker by sales, will permit more customers to defer payments or finance purchases at lower interest rates to spur sales of hardware, software and services. title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: New Brunswick: Drivers' Eye Exams Not Enforced
description: State officials acknowledged that they had not been enforcing mandatory eye examinations every 10 years for drivers. A pedestrian, Vincent Corso, alleges in a lawsuit in Superior Court in Middlesex County that in December 2001 he was struck by the car of an 80-year-old driver whose vision should have been tested. The suit says the state routinely reissued a driver's license to the driver, Phillip Piracci. Mr. Corso remains hospitalized. A spokesman for the Motor Vehicle Commission, said the agency was underfinanced but also did not administer the tests to avoid inconveniencing drivers. He said the agency might administer tests when it begins issuing digital licenses. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe

Mr. Schroder canceled his Italian vacation this month, after an Italian tourism official publicly dismissed Germans as crude beach invaders. But news reports and Italian officials said Mr. Fischer was en route yesterday to his usual summer retreat in the Tuscan countryside near Siena, suggesting that Italy's wiles were trumping Germany's wounds. Or that Mr. Fischer, with an eye on a top European Union job in the future, was putting healing first. Frank Bruni (NYT)

Two 15-year-olds and one 16-year-old counselor were charged in Juvenile Court with 24 felony counts and 34 misdemeanor ones. Sheriff Quint Overton said that other campers were charged $1 for admission to the fights and that the counselors and children bet up to $4 a fight. Several fighters suffered black eyes, and one broke his hand. The camp is near Smith Mountain Lake, about 120 miles southwest of Richmond.   (AP)

title: 36 Hours | Saranac Lake, N.Y.
description: IF you dream of Yosemite or Yellowstone but can't spare the plane fare -- or can't stand the summer crowds -- head to northern New York State for an unspoiled back-to-nature experience. The village of Saranac Lake sits in the heart of the spectacular Adirondack Park, which, at six million acres, is bigger than Yosemite, Yellowstone and the Grand Canyon combined. Unlike neighboring Lake Placid, Saranac Lake has resisted becoming a bustling -- or gentrified -- tourist town. Residents and visitors can be found hiking, biking, fishing, canoeing, kayaking and hunting, when they are not admiring the majestic surrounding mountains, known as the High Peaks, or the crystal-clear lakes framed by dense forests. Although the village of Saranac Lake is close to the three Saranac Lakes (Upper, Middle and Lower), it actually sits on the shores of Lake Flower, a smaller lake ringed by Victorian houses. Saranac Lake became known in the early 1900's as a leading tuberculosis treatment center after Dr. Edward Livingston Trudeau established a sanitarium on a sweeping stretch of lakefront property. Some of the original ''cure'' cottages still remain, as does the Trudeau Institute, now an infectious disease research center. Saranac Lake's small-town spirit shines at events throughout the summer, including the Adirondack Festival of American Music (through July 31), the Can-Am Rugby Tournament (Aug. 2 and 3) and the Adirondack Canoe Classic (Sept. 5 to 7). NANCY M. BETTER

title: DeLay Is to Carry Dissenting Message On a Mideast Tour
description: Tom DeLay, the House majority leader, never tires of reminding people that he is just a former pest exterminator from Sugar Land, Tex. title: New Jersey Tour: Napalm, African Shields and Surreal Trees

Travelers may negotiate another sort of historical leap at the Morris Museum, from Ash Can School-style paintings by Henry Gasser to contemporary neo-Abstract Expressionist paintings by Serena Bocchino. And at the Montclair Museum of Art, the sculptor Tom Nussbaum straddles the gap between folksy innocence and ironic sophistication.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Iron Output Rises
description: The Australian mining company BHP Billiton said that fourth-quarter iron ore output rose 14 percent as it sold more to steelmakers in China and other Asian countries. Iron ore production rose to 19.4 million metric tons in the three months ended June 30, from 17.1 million tons a year earlier, Billiton said. China's iron ore imports rose 44 percent in the first five months of this year aided by auto production that rose almost a third in the first six months of 2003. Billiton, one of the world's largest iron ore exporters, and a competitor, the Rio Tinto Group, also won a 9 percent price increase from Japanese steel makers for the year that began April 1. Billiton shares rose 20 cents to 9.65 Australian dollars, the highest closing price since Jan. 17.

title: Chinatown: Eat, Drink and Speak Cantonese
description: Yummy Noodles is a cheap, no-frills diner -- what in Hong Kong would be called a chaan teng -- on the Bowery in Chinatown. I eat there a lot because it is exactly like the little joints where I used to lunch in Kowloon and the New Territories when I was studying Cantonese in Hong Kong last summer. It also has the best roast-pork noodles in the city, a judgment I make based on serious time spent roaming Chinatown in May and June, searching for the ur-bowl of Cantonese roast-pork noodles that would comfort me for having to stick around New York instead of returning for another summer semester sojourn at the Chinese University at Hong Kong.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: DAIWA'S PROFIT INCREASES 91% The Daiwa Securities Group, a brokerage firm in Japan, reported a 91 percent increase in quarterly profit yesterday, helped by active foreign bond sales and other fixed-income revenues. Daiwa was aided in the April-to-June period by a stock market recovery that helped increase equity trading incomes, but the latest results underlined the company's clear shift away from equities to bonds. The Tokyo stock market's 14 percent rise in the quarter, led by foreign buying, has inspired active trading by individuals, but online brokerage firms appear to have benefited more than Daiwa and other top traditional brokers. Daiwa booked 11.03 billion yen ($92.88 million) in group net profit in the quarter, up from 5.79 billion yen ($48.64 million) a year ago. Revenue rose 11 percent, to 112 billion yen ($941 million). (Reuters)

title: Nature's Lessons in Yosemite
description: George Radanovich does not give up easily. Mr. Radanovich is a California Republican and the chairman of the House subcommittee on national parks. His district includes Yosemite, among the most beautiful of those parks and, along with the Grand Canyon, among the most stressed in terms of overcrowding. Last year, Mr. Radanovich complained unsuccessfully to the Bush administration about core elements of a popular National Park Service plan to improve conditions for both tourists and nature. Now he is back with the same complaints, as well as a bill that would greatly weaken the plan.

title: A Portrait of the Army, but Few Heroes in Sight

A group of American soldiers stationed in Germany, woozy from the fumes of heroin cooking around them, nod out in a warehouse, where a television brings news of the fall of the Berlin Wall. ''Where is the Berlin Wall?'' one of them asks another, who answers that it's in Berlin. Yeah, but where's Berlin? Unfortunately, much work remains to be done, and it is not at all clear in some important areas, like reform of the F.B.I., that change is coming fast enough to prevent another terror strike.

description: OSPREYS, and people who admire them, love the bluffs, salt marshes and pebbled bay beaches of Shelter Island. Ospreys, hawklike birds with five-foot wingspans, were once ndangered in New York State. Now, about 30 pairs are scattered around Shelter Island, an 8,000-acre windswept island town tucked between the twin forks of eastern Long Island. Their nests, which can weigh 100 pounds and have been known to include pilfered beach toys and Hula Hoops, can be spotted on tall platforms erected for them by local conservationists.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: 5 Shot, Including 4 Youths
description: Five people, including four minors, were shot in separate incidents last night in Newark and Irvington. All were taken to University Hospital. A 9-year-old boy and a 23-year-old man were shot south of downtown Newark around 8 p.m., the police said. The boy, Brion Eley, was hit in the midsection, and the man was hit in the hand. Nadira Eley, 26, Brion's mother, said he was in intensive care. A hospital spokesman said Brion was in critical condition. The adult's condition was not known. At least two shots were fired from a car driving on Thomas Street, Detective Todd McClendon said. The car, a gold Ford Taurus, turned left on Clinton Avenue with two men inside, the police said. In Irvington, Sgt. Katheryna Iwanenko said a 15-year-old boy had been abducted near Smith Street, apparently escaped, and was shot twice in the back. He was in serious condition. In another incident, a 17-year-old girl was with her 13-month-old nephew near 20th Avenue and 22nd Street in Irvington around 8 p.m. The girl was shot in the hand and upper arm and the baby was shot in the shoulder and hand, the police said, and a hospital spokesman said the baby had been shot in the chest. The girl was in fair condition and the baby was in critical condition. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: ARCHER DANIELS MIDLAND SEES GROWING NEED FOR ETHANOL
description: Archer Daniels Midland, the largest producer of ethanol in the country, is signing supply contracts with East Coast gasoline refiners that are anticipating that a ban on methyl tertiary butyl ether, or M.T.B.E., in New York and Connecticut will come into force at the end of the year. Gasoline refiners use ethanol to stretch supplies and cut emissions by raising the fuel's oxygen levels. About 75 percent of California's gasoline is currently being blended with ethanol as refiners in the state adjust to a similar M.T.B.E. ban. The additive was found to leak from storage tanks and foul drinking water supplies.
