title: A Sleepover With the Surf
description: MY favorite part of spending the night on the beach is a mind game I call ''You Be the Foley Artist.'' In it, you pretend you are a Foley artist -- a sound-recording expert who employs unusual items to supply the sounds for on-screen action, like snapping celery to make the sound of breaking bones -- and that your task requires you to simulate the sound of the crashing surf. What would you use for the sea's roar?

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Canadian Police Accused Of Killing Iranian
description: The Foreign Ministry accused the Canadian police of killing an Iranian, a day after Canada recalled its ambassador over the burial in Iran of an Iranian-Canadian journalist who died in Iranian custody. Canada had requested the return of the remains of the journalist, Zahra Kazemi. A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry said that three young Iranians were attacked by the police in a Vancouver suburb and that one, identified as Kayvan Tabesh, was killed. The incident was said to have happened on Tuesday. But Reuters reported that Mr. Tabesh, 18, was shot by a policeman on July 14, when he attacked the officer with a machete after an early morning road-rage incident. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Typhoon Batters Southeast Asia
description: After killing at least 10 people in the Philippines, a typhoon injured nearly three dozen people while passing to the south of Hong Kong. The intensity of the storm, one the worst to sweep across the region in years, uprooted trees on the island of Hainan, above, and in other parts of southern China. The storm came ashore in China's western Guangdong Province, where elaborate preparations had been made to divert ships and planes and evacuate people. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: 4 EX-EMPLOYEES OF CHARTER CHARGED WITH FRAUD
description: Charter Communications, the cable television operator controlled by Paul Allen, a founder of Microsoft, said yesterday that two former executives and two other former employees were indicted on fraud charges by a federal grand jury in St. Louis. The two former executives, Kent Kalkwarf, who was chief financial officer, and David Barford, who was the chief operating officer, were fired in December 2002. The two other employees, James Smith and David McCall, have left the company, Charter said. Charter's accounting practices have been under review by federal prosecutors and the Securities and Exchange Commission since last year. The investigations have focused on how the company counted customers, determined whether expenses were capitalized or treated as operating costs and accounted for payments from programmers and suppliers. Charter, which said it has cooperated with the government investigation, was not charged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PARISE, , JAMES
description: PARISE--James. The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community mourns the passing of James P. Parise, Assistant Vice President for Physical Facilities. Jim worked at Downstate, the campus he loved, for over thirty years, and was among its biggest supporters. Our prayers and thoughts are with his family at this time. He will be missed by all. John C. LaRosa, M.D., President Ivan M. Lisnitzer, P.E., Senior Vice President for Administration >>AD#

title: AIR FORCE BARS DEALS WITH BOEING SPACE UNITS
description: The space units of Boeing were suspended by the Air Force yesterday from seeking military contracts after the Air Force concluded there were ''serious violations of federal law'' in Boeing's use of documents from Lockheed Martin to win a $1.5 billion rocket contract. The Air Force also stripped seven launches from Boeing's schedule, won in a 1998 competition to develop a rocket for military satellites, and gave the work to Lockheed, an official said. The additional launches may be worth as much as $1 billion to Lockheed, an analyst said. ''Our inquiry into Boeing found that they were in possession of thousands of pages of Lockheed Martin proprietary documents during the 1998 selection,'' Peter Teets, Air Force under secretary, said in a statement. Boeing's chief executive, Philip M. Condit, apologized for the company's actions and said its officials ''understand the U.S. Air Force's position that unethical behavior will not be tolerated.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SPIEGEL INC., Downers Grove, Ill., the bankrupt owner of the Eddie Bauer clothing store chain, said it would close a customer contact center in Rapid City, S.D., and a distribution center in Newport News, Va., eliminating about 640 jobs.

title: F.D.A. Officials Press Legislators to Oppose Bill on Importing Less Expensive Drugs
description: Top officials of the Food and Drug Administration, including the commissioner, Mark B. McClellan, have been waging an intense effort to defeat legislation that would allow Americans to import less expensive prescription medicines from Canada and Europe, prompting an outcry from the measure's backers.

title: Children Under Stress
description: To the Editor:

title: The Biker Question: To Roar or Not to Roar
description: SOMEBODY out there is making Wayne Doenges look bad, and he's not happy about it. Mr. Doenges has been riding motorcycles for 30 years, and with his white hair and reflective two-toned riding jacket, he cuts an impressive figure on the roads of Indiana on his chromed-out six-cylinder Honda Valkyrie. ''The bike attracts attention,'' he said, adding a significant phrase, ''in a positive way.''

title: Driving Mower, Bus or Car, 9-Year-Old Has Town Jumpy
description: When Millie Guzman heard a loud horn honk outside her house on Route 40 Tuesday night, she was a bit surprised to see a yellow school bus creeping by on a warm July evening. She was even more surprised to see who was behind the wheel: her 9-year-old neighbor, who had just stolen the bus from a service garage and driven into town to show off his prize.

title: U.S. Says It Captured Hussein's Suspected Bodyguards
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  United States troops raided a house near Saddam Hussein's hometown on Thursday, rounding up several people suspected of belonging to his personal security detail and enhancing the chances of finding the deposed dictator, an American military commander said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERG, , HELEN
description: ROSENBERG -- Helen. On July 23, 2003. Beloved wife of the late J. Mitchell Rosenberg, devoted sister-in-law and devoted aunt to many nieces and nephews. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the sale of the Gotham Book Mart building in New York City's diamond district carried a misspelled byline. The writer was Mike McIntire, not McIntyre.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Thanks to the magic of television, Rocco's on 22nd may be the most famous restaurant in Manhattan. It is the subject of the NBC series ''The Restaurant,'' and it made a strong first impression. Not many viewers will shake off the image of a fire breaking out in the kitchen, setting off sprinklers upstairs and sending clouds of smoke into the dining room.

title: Murder now seen in Italian banker's 1982 death
description: MILAN:  Rome prosecutors, looking into the death of Roberto Calvi, the Italian banker found hanging from Blackfriars Bridge in London 21 years ago, have concluded that Calvi was murdered.

title: Houses With Enough Space for the Cookie Jar Collection
description: WHO -- Ted Bodenheimer, 58, and his wife, Carol, 59, retired teachers

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENAGED, , KATE
description: MENAGED--Kate. Died on July 22, aged 94. Cared for her siblings her entire life. She will be remembered. Edward Menaged, Brother >>AD#

title: An Island That Took 203 Years to Welcome Tourists
description: It was always just out of reach.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: State Wins Round On Prison Conditions
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, temporarily halted a lower court's order that Mississippi improve its death row at the state penitentiary at Parchman. Magistrate Judge Jerry A. Davis ruled in May that conditions on death row constituted cruel and unusual punishment, and he refused to grant the state a stay during appeals. The appeals court will reconsider the stay next week when it has briefs from all the parties. The American Civil Liberties Union has argued that prisoners are constantly exposed to human waste, live in dangerously high temperatures and are deprived of basic medical care. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Lessons From City Hall Tragedy (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 G.I.'s Killed in Ambush in Iraq
description: Three soldiers with the Army's 101st Airborne Division were killed in an ambush here early this morning that involved what one local resident said was an attack by insurgents armed with rocket-propelled grenades and Kalashnikov assault rifles.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Reports $14 Million Loss
description: Reporting a smaller second-quarter loss but a 16 percent drop in revenue, the telecommunications equipment maker Nortel Networks said yesterday that market conditions remained difficult and that it was taking a cautious approach to its business. Nortel, based in Toronto, said that its net loss was $14 million in the second quarter, compared with $697 million a year earlier. The company reported a profit of $54 million in the first three months of this year. Shares rose 8 cents, to $3.05. The stock touched a low of 43 cents last October. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Abbas's Mandate: Confront Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: All Road Maps Lead to Washington
description: With Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel and the Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, each heading to the White House in the next few days, optimism is in the air. After all, we have an American president eager to prove that the war in Iraq can lead to an Israeli-Palestinian agreement, a right-wing Israeli leader who supports the establishment of a Palestinian state, and a Palestinian prime minister who is against the armed intifada. Also, the terrorists are holding their fire for the time being, and both sides have committed to Mr. Bush's ''road map'' to peace.

title: Official Urges Ban Of Ephedra By Baseball
description: The commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration told House subcommittees today that major league baseball should ban use of the herbal stimulant ephedra, which was linked to the death of a young pitcher at the Baltimore Orioles' spring training camp in February.

title: Election Panel Eases A Soft-Money Rule
description: The local committees planning the political parties' 2004 nominating conventions may continue to solicit unrestricted soft-money contributions from corporations, unions and individuals, the Federal Election Commission said today.

title: Video Revenue Is Still Rising
description: The factors that restrict the economy don't have too tight a grip on home video. While 2003 movie box-office receipts are down by more than 4 percent from last year, video revenue is up by 16 percent, according to a report by Video Business magazine. In the first half of the year consumers spent $10.2 billion buying and renting DVD's and videocassettes, a healthy performance for an industry that some analysts once wrote off as road kill on the supposed fast lane to the information superhighway.

title: Sports of The Times; Kidd-Nets Marriage Is Sensible
description: THERE were roses for Joumana, sweets for T.J. and a $103 million jackpot for Jason. Walking under an arch of balloons that served symbolically as an altar, the Kidd family tied a six-year knot with New Jersey yesterday, officially severing all romantic attachments to Tim Duncan, the San Antonio Spurs and the conference where the beautiful teams live.

title: A Breakout For the 'Rite'
description: Poetic, impudent, beautiful and strange, the dances of Shen Wei, a Chinese-born choreographer, announce the advent of a strikingly original artist who fits into no familiar category.

title: Watson and Kite Are Tied for Lead
description: Tom Watson won his rematch with Jack Nicklaus at Turnberry links, but he could not shake Tom Kite.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIEBMANN, , HERMAN
description: LIEBMANN--Herman, July 21, 2003, in NYC. WW II Army Major, textile executive, private investor, Director of the Richard Tucker Foundation, member of the Harmonie Club for over 50 years. Father of Lisa Liebmann Adams, father-in-law of John Brooks Adams, grandfather of Jane Juno Adams, former husband of Loraine Pack Liebmann, dear companion of the late Elaine Reiner. Service on July 31, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on July 1, about Justice Gustin L. Reichbach of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, who keeps a picture of the singer and actor Paul Robeson over the jury box, referred incorrectly to events that led to the derailing of Robeson's career. He was called before the House Un-American Activities Committee well before Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's heyday.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: A Pianist's View of Non-Piano Repertory
description: Piano transcriptions of works composed for other instruments and for orchestra have always been a central part of Idil Biret's repertory arsenal.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Circuits yesterday about flat-panel television sets from Gateway, the computer maker, misspelled the surname of a Gateway executive who commented on the products. He is Gui Kahl, not Kaho.

title: Chapel Royal Wins Sanford Stakes
description: The trainer Todd Pletcher visited the winner's circle after an important race for the second day in a row yesterday at Saratoga Race Course. This time, his strapping 2-year-old colt Chapel Royal routed a field of seven in the Grade II, $150,000 Sanford Stakes.

title: Making Up for Last Year, Jets Focus on Sacks
description: It looks more like a mad ballet without tutus than a football drill. But an agility routine just might help the Jets snare the quarterback this season, a priority that Coach Herman Edwards has set for the defensive line in training camp.

title: Criticism Prompts McGreevey To Pay for Puerto Rican Trip
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey said yesterday that he would pay the bill himself for a trip he took to Puerto Rico this week that was criticized by Republicans because it had been paid for by a labor union.

title: Report of 9/11 Panel Cites Lapses by C.I.A. and F.B.I.
description: A Congressional report released today provided a scathing critique of the performance of the F.B.I. and C.I.A. before the September 2001 terrorist attacks and recommended several changes, including the creation of cabinet level national intelligence chief, that go beyond what the administration has proposed.

title: SBC Communications Is Target of Antitrust Suit
description: Four California companies that sell broadband Internet service over telephone lines filed an antitrust complaint yesterday against SBC Communications, the Baby Bell that controls the lines to customers.

title: SHARES OF ELAN FALL 25% AFTER SETBACK IN DRUG TRIAL
description: Shares in Elan, the financially troubled Irish drug maker, fell 25 percent in Dublin yesterday, to 4 euros from from 5.32 euros, after the company said that its new treatment for Crohn's disease was not sufficiently effective during final trials. Its American depository receipts dropped 30 percent, to $4.47 in New York. Antegren, which is also being tested as a treatment for other autoimmune disorders like multiple sclerosis, is jointly developed by Elan and Biogen of Cambridge, Mass. The drug failed to lower the activity index that measures Crohn's disease, an inflammation of the bowel, by the necessary 70 points after 10 weeks of Phase III trials, which are usually the last stage before approval by the Food and Drug Administration. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Guards and Fans Swarming, Tyson Blames His Accusers
description: Past his prime or not, Mike Tyson, the aging Brownsville brawler and former heavyweight champion of the world, seemed no less a star yesterday in Brooklyn Criminal Court than he has been in the boxing ring over the past two decades.

title: Verizon and a big union joust with help from slick hired guns.
description: LABOR battles are often fought on the picket lines, but Verizon and its largest union are dueling to get the upper hand in an unusual battle of newspaper ads and spot broadcast messages.

title: Last Exit Before the Wilderness
description: JUST before 5 a.m., as seen from a one-man canoe on the still waters of Alice Lake in early July, the sun is nothing more than a tiny dot of auburn light on the horizon. Here in the Boundary Waters Canoe Area -- a million acres of wilderness and more than 200 lakes that stretch for 150 or so miles along the border with Canada -- night gradually gives way to day as the town of Ely fades into the distance.

title: New Jobless Claims at Lowest Since February
description: The number of Americans filing new applications for jobless benefits fell below 400,000 last week for the first time since early February, suggesting a labor market on the mend.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILONE, , VERA CHRISTINE (JOECKLE)
description: MILONE -- Vera Christine (Joeckle). Born on October 3, 1898 in New York City, passed away in Calgary, Alberta, Canada at the age of 104 on July 19, 2003. She is survived by son, Dr. Eugene (Helen) Milone; two grandchildren, Bart (Lynn) and Marie; and four great - grandchildren; with extended family in New England including Ruth Bastin and in Germany. Funeral services will be held at Foster's Garden Chapel, Calgary (403-297-0888) on Sunday, July 27, 2003 at 3PM. >>AD#

title: His Nightmare: A City Forced to Sleep
description: AT midafternoon, Lotus, the hyperactive supper club in the schizoid meatpacking district, where the cutting edge lately seems more intent on cloning hipster trends than trimming tenderloin, is sleeping off last night.

title: Film Crews, an Old Resort And a Thirsty Hotel Staff
description: Mike Figgis's ''Hotel,'' the director's newest confessional-improvisational work, rises and falls on the talents of his performers. The cast includes David Schwimmer, Salma Hayek, Burt Reynolds, Lucy Liu, Saffron Burrows, Julian Sands, John Malkovich and Rhys Ifans, who wins by a mile.

title: Indians Honor an Intrepid Spirit
description: The Yawalapiti Indians of the Brazilian Amazon invited seven neighboring tribes to take part in a funeral ceremony for Orlando Villas Bas, their friend and protector.

title: Designing Men
description: Design is finally losing its cool. At this year's Milan furniture fair, the products that broke the buzz meter were either showy or whimsical or both.

title: The Swimmers
description: Moroccan smugglers on the African coast.

title: Summer Drinks
description:
By SUZANNE HAMLIN
A major element in the seasonal fun factor, summer drinks are serious business with this very cool equipment.

title: Shelling in Liberia's Capital
description: At least 12 people were killed on Friday in the bloodiest attack on Monrovia in days.

title: Shelling in Liberia's Capital
description: Artillery shells crashed into Monrovia on Friday, killing at least 12 people and wounding more than 100.

title: User Friendly
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Cuts Forecast
description: Corporate debt and credit card delinquencies forced Shinhan Bank, Korea's fourth-largest lender, to reduce its net profit target for the year to 550 billion won from 650 billion won. The bank said its net profit for the second quarter was expected to total only 100 billion won ($84.7 million), down from 306 billion won in the second quarter of last year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Loss Narrows at Dynegy
description: Dynegy Inc., a utility owner and power producer, said yesterday that its second-quarter loss narrowed to $290 million as the company exited the money-losing energy trading and telecommunications businesses. The net loss was equal to $1 a share, compared with a loss of $561 million, or $1.76 a share, a year earlier, Dynegy said. Energy trading and communications, which Dynegy called discontinued operations, had a combined loss of $240 million.

title: Tentative Deal Set on Budget In Connecticut
description: After nearly a month in which the state has had to operate without a budget, leaders of the Connecticut House and Senate said today that they had the makings of a deal that would close the state budget gap with a mix of spending cuts and tax increases.

title: City and Party Politics
description: We should not let the prospect of filling hotel rooms and restaurants overshadow the real benefit of hosting the Republican National Convention one year from now. The true value of the convention is that it will allow the city's leaders to forge a direct relationship with the leaders of the federal government. The benefits of building such a bond over the next year could help this city for years to come, not just during the four days in August and September when the Republican Party comes to town.

title: Uday's Trove: To Remember or Forget?
description: The inventory lists 193 canes, half of which slide open to become swords or guns. There is a strobe light, a fog machine and 4,002 bottles of wine and liquor, including a rare mid-1960's Cabernet Sauvignon worth $3,500. And there are family photographs of a sensitive-looking boy smiling alongside his father, the dictator.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Carmaker Expects A Loss
description: Mitsubishi Motors forecast a first-half loss as a result of car loan defaults and slumping sales in North America. The chief financial officer, Keiichiro Hashimoto, who took his position a month ago, said Mitsubishi would take a 50 billion yen ($419 million) charge to cover anticipated loan defaults in the six months to Sept. 30, when Mitsubishi projects a net loss of 80 billion yen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POMEX, , SOLOMON
description: POMEX--Solomon. Died July 25th, 2003. Beloved father of Lilliane and Richard Rohe. Grandfather and great grandfather of Michelle, Jennifer, Rebecca, William and Nicholas. Beloved brother of Selma Kronengold. Funeral services at Riverside Chapel, 76 St. & Amsterdam Avenue, Sunday, July 27 at 1 PM. >>AD#

title: Fisherman Seeks to Harvest Ailing Baltic, Gently
description: ''THIS is home,'' said Kurt Christensen, leaning over a ship's railing and watching the purple of a midsummer night brush the water with the same warm glow.

title: House Passes Drug Bill; Battle Is Likely in Senate
description: The House voted early this morning to allow Americans to import less expensive prescription drugs from Canada and Europe, but the measure now moves to an uncertain conference with the Senate, where more than half of all senators are expressing their opposition to the provision.

title: Congress to Monitor Shuttle Program Closely, Lawmaker Says
description: Congress intends to take an unusually active role in determining when a space shuttle flies again, including giving NASA a checklist of changes it must carry out before flights are approved, the chairman of the House Committee on Science said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LERNER, , CHARLES
description: LERNER--Charles. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Charles Lerner, associated with The Times from February 1962 until retiring in April 1978 >>AD#

title: Bidding a High-Risk Game When It's the Way to Win
description: The final of the Women's Knockout Teams at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here ended on Thursday night in an exact tie, which has happened only once before.

title: Can Kraft Trim the Fat In an Oreo World?
description: Three weeks ago, Kraft Foods Inc., the nation's largest food company, said it was going to help fight a global epidemic -- obesity.

title: Stock Exchange And Specialist In a Dispute Over E-Mail
description: Regulators at the New York Stock Exchange have accused LaBranche & Company, one of the largest firms that executes investors' orders on the Big Board's trading floor, of failing to cooperate with an investigation into the practices of floor traders.

title: For Life's End, Best to Plan Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Tapping The Mood Gene
description: A depressed patient tells me about her neighbor. He is suffering the crises that arise in the course of diabetes -- first foot pain, now vision loss. He has remained upbeat throughout. ''He's legally blind,'' my patient says. ''I don't know how he can stand it.'' Amid the wonder, I sometimes hear a suggestion that the man lacks self-awareness.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about public scrutiny of Darrell Issa, who is financing the effort to recall Gov. Gray Davis of California, referred incorrectly to the unregistered gun he carried in the early 1970's, an offense for which he was sentenced to probation. The weapon was a .25-caliber semiautomatic, not .25-millimeter.

title: A Cherished Civil Rights Site Faces Its Doom
description: The graying veterans of the civil rights days are mustering in the streets for one more protest, this time to save their kitchen.

title: A Top School Administrator Is to Retire on Eve of Overhaul
description: Shelley Harwayne, the superintendent in charge of more than half the public schools in Manhattan, has announced her retirement, a little more than a month before the start of school and the implementation of the most sweeping overhaul of the city school system in a generation.

title: Collins and Toomer Haven't Lost the Connection
description: They had always been like two playmates thrown together from different neighborhoods: Amani Toomer, the quiet California-bred receiver, gifted but detached, and Kerry Collins, a quarterback from the Pennsylvania rust belt, gritty and fidgety.

title: DEUTSCHE BANK OUSTED FOR PROVIDING CONFLICTING ADVICE
description: Deutsche Bank lost the job of helping an auto-parts maker, the Dana Corporation, thwart a hostile takeover by ArvinMeritor Inc. after the German bank told its client that it had earlier tried to persuade ArvinMeritor to make the bid. Deutsche Bank's securities unit in New York had lobbied ArvinMeritor earlier this year to buy Dana, according to a regulatory filing by Dana. Deutsche Bank, Germany's largest bank, later switched sides and urged the rejection of ArvinMeritor's $2.2 billion offer. Dana's board rebuffed the bid three days ago. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Dana said Deutsche Bank withdrew as its adviser this week, because of its ''prior contacts'' with ArvinMeritor.

title: Caseworkers Acted Properly In Case of 2 Slain Children
description: The two new top officials at New Jersey's child-welfare agency said today that caseworkers had followed proper procedures in the case of two South Jersey children who were killed by their father this month.

title: Endangered Species: Slow Food
description: When McDonald's planned to build a restaurant near the Piazza di Spagna in Rome in 1986, Carlo Petrini organized a demonstration in which he and his followers brandished bowls of penne as weapons of protest. Soon after, he founded the International Slow Food Movement and issued a manifesto, a response to fast food, fast life, nonsustainable farming and the eroding of local economies. By the mid-1990's, Slow Food had grown phenomenally, becoming politically active, lobbying the European Union on trade and agricultural policy and working to save endangered foods. This month, Mr. Petrini's book ''Slow Food: The Case for Taste,'' was published by Columbia University Press. Amanda Hesser spoke with him through an interpreter.

title: Bush Selects Two for Bench, Adding Fuel to Senate Fire
description: President Bush escalated his fight with Senate Democrats over judicial nominations today by naming two new candidates for judgeships for the federal appeals court in Washington, widely regarded as second in importance only to the Supreme Court.

title: ROYAL NUMICO SELLS REXALL SUNDOWN FOR $250 MILLION
description: The Dutch baby food maker Royal Numico sold Rexall Sundown, a vitamin supplements company in Boca Raton, Fla., for $250 million in cash yesterday. The buyer NBTY Inc., a manufacturer and marketer of nutritional supplements based in Bohemia, N.Y. Royal Numico, which owns the GNC vitamin stores, is heavily in debt after a series of poor investments and needs to raise 650 million euros ($746 million) by the end of 2004 to meet some of its obligations. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Phelps Sets World Records in 2 Events
description: Michael Phelps has been in an all-conquering mood at the world swimming championships, and tonight he showed it with the most extraordinary performance of his career.

title: Judge Dismisses Lawyer's Suit Challenging New Civil Case Fees
description: A state judge here has dismissed a lawsuit challenging the legality of new fees in all civil cases in state and county courts across New York.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MICHAELS, , MELVIN
description: MICHAELS--Melvin. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member Friar Melvin Michaels on July 23, 2003. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MASON, , EVELYN
description: MASON -- Evelyn. Beloved wife of the late Casimir; mother of Peter, Marc and the late Ellen; grandmother of Kathy and Jonathan; great-grandmother of Eric and Jennifer; mother-in-law of Ruth & Paula. Dear friend of Eleanor. In memoriam. >>AD#

title: Classified Section Of Sept. 11 Report Faults Saudi Rulers
description: Senior officials of Saudi Arabia have funneled hundreds of millions of dollars to charitable groups and other organizations that may have helped finance the September 2001 attacks, a still-classified section of a Congressional report on the hijackings says, according to people who have read it.

title: REGULATORS PERMIT SALE OF BAXTER HEMOPHILIA MEDICINE
description: Baxter International said yesterday that the Food and Drug Administration had approved its Advate medicine for treating hemophilia. The medicine is the first genetically engineered treatment for hemophilia that is made without blood components from humans or animals. The drug is safer than other treatments because it eliminates the risk of transmission of viruses, like H.I.V. or hepatitis, Baxter said. The treatment replaces a missing or deficient amount of a protein that allows the blood to clot when a person is injured.

title: Protecting Female Cadets
description: Over the last year, the American public has been hearing horror stories from current and former cadets about sexual assaults at the Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs. Dozens of women have charged that they were raped or sexually harassed or humiliated, often by upperclassmen. Most kept silent until recently for fear of losing their dreams of being Air Force officers. In recent months, to their credit, Air Force Secretary James Roche, the Pentagon and several members of Congress have been urgently investigating these accusations. The superintendent and three other top officers at the academy have been replaced. Secretary Roche has come up with changes designed to make the academy's procedures more in line with those of the regular Air Force and break up a secretive culture clearly intended to make female cadets feel that they do not belong.

title: Seeking Hussein (And a Successor)
description: Three new documentaries focusing on the American war in Iraq offer an object lesson in the perils of trying to record history as it happens. The ever-shifting power dynamic in the occupied nation and the unpredictable fortunes of war tend to undermine even the best-planned attempts to be authoritative.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Revised Estimates Of Whale Populaton
description: Whale populations before the advent of commercial whaling have been vastly underestimated, a study by geneticists from Stanford and Harvard finds. The global humpback whale population, previously thought to have been 100,000, could have been as high as 1.5 million, the geneticists said in the journal Science after having examined genetic variations. The findings could hamper efforts to lift the 17-year ban on commercial whaling by the International Whaling Commission, which has suggested that it would allow the resumption of commercial hunting after the whale population had reached more than half its historic numbers. Jos Ramrez (NYT)

title: Abbas Inspires Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: 70 Complaints and One Stolen Bus Later, Boy Gets Court Date
description: The 9-year-old boy who took a school bus for a joy ride this week around his South Jersey town has a long history of bicycle thefts and other offenses, the police say. But the bus escapade will bring him his first day in court.

title: Bush, With Palestinian Prime Minister, Urges Compromise
description: President Bush received the new Palestinian prime minister at the White House today for the first time, and he used the occasion to signal to both Palestinians and Israelis that he would push them toward tough decisions for peace.

title: Rejuvenated Jockey Nudges Trademark To Baruch Victory
description: At 5 feet 4 inches, Richard Migliore is on the tall side for a jockey. At 39, he is euphemistically referred to as seasoned. Check his medical chart: Migliore definitely qualifies as a tough-luck rider. He sustained a near-fatal neck injury in a 1992 spill and broke his arm in an accident that interrupted a red-hot summer in 1999.

title: National Briefing: South
description: NORTH CAROLINA: MARINE REACHES PLEA DEAL IN SABOTAGE CASE A marine facing a court-martial on Tuesday on charges of sabotaging parachutes and injuring three other marines reached a plea agreement with prosecutors, a spokeswoman for the Marine Corps said. No details on the case of the marine, Lance Cpl. Antoine D. Boykins, were released. Corporal Boykins, 21, was charged in February with attempted premeditated murder after the three other marines' parachutes failed to open when they jumped from 1,250 feet. The reserve chutes deployed safely. A prosecutor said Corporal Boykins had cut parachute suspension lines after being disciplined. (AP)

title: Russian Colonel Guilty of Murder in Death of Chechen Woman
description: A Russian military court today convicted a decorated army colonel of the murder of an 18-year-old woman in Chechnya. The verdict came at the end of a second trial in the case that has highlighted the vagaries of criminal justice in Russia.

title: Gerald Hawkins, 75, Astronomer Who Theorized on Stonehenge
description: Gerald Stanley Hawkins, a British-born astronomer who theorized that the Stonehenge megaliths on Salisbury Plain were a Stone Age astronomical computer of sorts, died on May 26 at his farm in Rappahannock County, Va. He was 75 and also had a home in Washington.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the last sentence of an article on Thursday about Democrats' opposition to the nomination of William Pryor Jr. to the federal appeals court in Atlanta omitted several words. It should have said that with only a slim majority in the Senate, the Republicans could not get Mr. Pryor confirmed if there were any defections.

title: Freddie Mac Picked Chief It Knew Had Role in Its Troubles
description: The board of Freddie Mac decided to promote Gregory Parseghian to chief executive last month even though it had already been briefed on his role in transactions that an outside investigation called into question.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CBL & ASSOCIATES PROPERTIES INC., Chattanooga, Tenn., a real estate investment trust, said it would buy three shopping malls in Virginia and one in North Carolina from Faison Enterprises Inc., Charlotte, N.C., a real estate holding company, for $340 million in cash and assumed debt.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: DELAY IN EXTRADITION RULING Germany has delayed a decision on whether to extradite two suspected members of the terrorist network Al Qaeda to the United States until the country's highest court hears an appeal from the men. The suspects, Sheik Muhammad Ali Hassan al-Mouyad and Muhammad Moshen Yahya Zayed, both from Yemen, were arrested in January in Frankfurt. A lower court had ruled that they could be extradited, after receiving a pledge from the United States that they would not be tried before a military tribunal, where they could receive the death penalty. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Chemical Profit Falls
description: The Dutch chemicals concern DSM reported a 93 percent decline in its second-quarter net profit to 68 million euros ($78.2 million) and warned investors that its third-quarter results might disappoint as well. DSM announced the elimination of 500 positions on the heels of news that its third-quarter operating profit might come in at least 25 percent below the 85 million euros it booked in the second quarter. The company, which is struggling with weak market demand and a strong euro, said it anticipated an improved performance starting in the fourth quarter. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Imported Rugs Caught Up in Antiterror Rule
description: Business has been lively and growing at the 828 International Trading Company in the six years since John Shepherd and his partner began selling area rugs imported from a half-dozen countries around the globe. But now a large batch of colorful cotton rugs that they recently had shipped from China has been ensnared by a Bush administration measure imposed in May to punish Chinese companies accused of supplying ballistic missile technology to Iran.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO RISES. The euro rose on speculation that European bonds are poised to gain more than United States Treasuries, eroding the demand for dollars. In New York, the euro settled at $1.1508, up from $1.1464 on Thursday.

title: In Iraq, a Justice System Worth Saving
description: When I agreed to travel to Iraq in May as part of a team of judges, prosecutors and defense lawyers to assess the Iraqi judicial system, my expectations were admittedly low. Two decades of Saddam Hussein's selecting judges and undermining the courts, three wars, 12 years of international sanctions and the presence of an occupying army would put a strain on any legal system.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Misuse Of Immunity Law Alleged
description: Italy's justice minister came under attack from the country's opposition, which accused him of misusing a new immunity law to block prosecutors from investigating tax fraud allegations against Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi. The immunity law, which was passed in June, freezes any criminal trials against the country's top officials, and effectively brought Mr. Berlusconi's corruption trial to a close. Opposition leaders said the effort by Justice Minister Roberto Castelli, left, to use the legislation to also suspend investigations was another example of the prime minister's efforts to bend Italian law to his benefit. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

description: The California Supreme Court refused yesterday to halt preparations for a vote on whether to recall Gov. Gray Davis, noting that a trial court's consideration of irregularities alleged in the signature collection process that authorized the election was proceeding.

title: California Chaos
description: California is now rolling inexorably toward a rendezvous with potential political chaos that it does not need in its present fragile condition and that somebody in authority should have found a way to avoid. On Thursday, Cruz Bustamante, the lieutenant governor, set Oct. 7 as the date when Californians will vote on the recall of Gov. Gray Davis and -- at the same time, on the same ballot -- choose a new governor to replace him should he be booted from office.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Bank Bailout
description: Thailand's Finance Ministry will bail out the Thai Military Bank after the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group quit talks to buy a stake in the bank, undermining a planned $525 million share sale. ''The Finance Ministry will take over the bank by injecting more money,'' the finance minister, Suchart Jaovisidha, said. ''The ministry will overhaul management and take action to deal with the bank's bad debts.'' Thai Military Bank, owned by the nation's army and the son of Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, is being bailed out for the second time in three years after failing to clean up bad loans to small and medium-size companies.

description: Josh Reed is amazed how clear a telephone connection between Buffalo and Baghdad can be. Sometimes it sounds as if his brother, Norbert, is around the corner.

title: U.S. Approves Evacuation Plan For Indian Point Nuclear Plant
description: A campaign to close the Indian Point nuclear power plant over fears of a catastrophic terrorist attack suffered a major blow yesterday when the federal government endorsed emergency evacuation plans for it, asserting that the public would be safe.

title: How far under water is Eurostar?
description: LONDON:  The tunnel under the English Channel, opened in 1994 with the promise of revolutionizing travel and fostering European cooperation, is under water in many ways these days.

title: Iraqi Informants' Tips Grow After Brothers' Deaths
description: In the three days since American soldiers killed Saddam Hussein's sons, informants have produced a stream of new tips, some of which have led to major raids in the last 24 hours alone, military officers in Iraq said today.

title: McDONALD'S TO BUY ITS BEEF FROM CANADIAN SUPPLIERS
description: The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that its 1,300 Canadian outlets would buy all their beef in Canada after a case of mad cow disease decreased meat exports and prices. McDonald's Canada, which had sales of 2.28 billion Canadian dollars ($1.65 billion) in 2002, currently buys 70 to 80 percent of its beef from Canadian suppliers. Beef prices have fallen 65 percent amid a glut since 34 countries, including the United States, closed their markets to Canadian beef after an infected cow was discovered on a farm in Alberta in May.

title: Slain Official To Lie in State
description: The body of slain City Councilman James E. Davis is to lie in state at City Hall on Monday, punctuating a series of memorial events in Brooklyn.

title: Amazon Indians Honor an Intrepid Spirit
description: Traveling for hours by boat and on foot, the chiefs, shamans and warriors arrived from all over the southeastern Amazon. For two days they danced, sang, chanted and reminisced around a painted tree trunk, decorated with a feathered headdress, that represented the soul of a recently departed friend.

title: Palestinian Boy, 4, Is Killed at Israeli Checkpoint
description: An Israeli soldier fired a machine gun that killed a 4-year-old Palestinian boy and wounded two young girls today while all three were in a family truck at a military checkpoint on the edge of a West Bank village, the military and Palestinian witnesses said.

title: WHX Agrees to Settle Pension Lawsuit
description: The WHX Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to settle a lawsuit over pensions for workers at its Wheeling-Pittsburgh steel unit.

title: Yanks Give Red Sox Fans Another Reason to Feel Cursed
description: To get a flavor of why Red Sox fans are so frustrated, consider what their team had going for it tonight. Their ace, Pedro Martnez, was on the mound and baffling the Yankees with fastballs and changeups. The Yankees' starter, David Wells, had a back problem and walked five. Mariano Rivera blew a save after Armando Benitez faltered. All that, and the Red Sox still lost.

description: Reacting swiftly to an overseas tip, MI5, the British domestic intelligence agency, helped the police discover traces of ricin, a deadly toxin, in an apartment in north London last January, which led to arrests of several men later linked to Al Qaeda.

While Medicare is generally available to people 65 and older, it does not automatically cover all elderly people. (Certain groups of state and local government employees, for example, are not included.)

title: Tears From the Gruff Chairman
description: Congress is heading off on vacation after a hilariously dewy-eyed adieu in which vows were exchanged to work harder toward bipartisan decorum -- a goal that seems about as achievable as a balanced federal budget. In a surprise, the promises to be nicer were set off by a hand-wringing apology from Representative Bill Thomas, the widely feared California Republican who is notorious for his irascibility in wielding the gavel of the Ways and Means Committee. ''I learned a very painful lesson,'' Mr. Thomas declared, fighting back tears as he expressed remorse for imperiously summoning the Capitol police to deal with protesting Democrats. They had bolted a committee meeting for a rump quorum in the library as Mr. Thomas had tried to ram through a pension bill that the Democrats had not had a chance to read.

title: Johnson Is Hoping to Stay Healthy
description: BOSTON, July 25  Nick Johnson sat on the top step of the Yankees' dugout today, three hours before game time, finally looking ready to play. As he talked with reporters, Johnson fiddled constantly with a rubber shock-absorbing ring he wears around his right thumb. It is a reminder of the reason he is so often hurt.

title: Report Says Restaurant Jobs Unaffected by Smoking Ban
description: Employment in New York City restaurants and bars has increased slightly since the law restricting smoking went into effect on March 30, according to city health officials, defying predictions from critics that the industry would be harmed.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: TRADE CONCESSIONS FOR HONG KONG Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive, announced that China had agreed to amend last month's free-trade agreement with Hong Kong to make it much easier for tourists from Beijing and Shanghai to visit Hong Kong, a former British colony that is now an autonomous Chinese territory but still has separate immigration and trade rules. Beijing will also support ongoing efforts by mainland companies to issue stock on the Hong Kong Exchange and will consider letting Hong Kong banks take deposits, issue credit cards and conduct other retail transactions in renminbi, China's currency. Beijing further agreed to decide in September instead of December how much Hong Kong content would be required for goods to qualify for duty-free entry to China under the pact. Mr. Tung sought a widening of the trade pact as part of a strategy of allaying public concerns in Hong Kong made evident by three large street protests earlier this month.

title: Hussein Bodies Shown to Skeptical Iraqis
description: American officials displayed the corpses of Uday and Qusay Hussein for a group of journalists today, acknowledging that American morticians had reconstructed their faces with putty and cosmetically repaired wounds the men had sustained in a shootout on Tuesday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer's Lawsuit Restored
description: The London Court of Appeals has granted the insurer Equitable Life the right to pursue a 2.6 billion ($4.2 billion) negligence claim against its auditor, Ernst & Young. Equitable, which is based in London, claims its accountant failed to warn it that it would need to raise money to pay pension liabilities. The case was thrown out by a high court in February. The appeals court overturned that ruling and threw out an appeal by Ernst & Young to have the case blocked. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Unlikely Or Not, Wilson Does It All
description: With All Stars and future Hall of Famers all over both teams' rosters, Enrique Wilson seemed a little out of place tonight at Fenway Park. Surely, the notables would be Pedro Martnez and Nomar Garciaparra, or perhaps Jason Giambi and Derek Jeter. A seldom-used utility player would be an unlikely candidate to fill the bill.

description: Volkswagen, Europe's largest carmaker, said its second-quarter profit fell 49 percent because the euro appreciated while sales fell as customers waited for the new model of the Golf, the company's most popular model.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Miner Cuts Dividend
description: The Canadian copper, nickel and zinc producer Noranda said it was cutting its quarterly dividend by 40 percent as part of a drive to strengthen its balance sheet in the face of weak metal markets. Noranda, based in Toronto, reported a second-quarter loss of 15 million Canadian dollars ($10.8 million), in contrast to a profit of 47 million Canadian dollars ($34 million) a year earlier. Revenue shrank by 5.4 percent to 1.58 billion Canadian dollars ($1.14 billion). The company plans to raise 500 million Canadian dollars ($362 million) in new equity, of which up to 300 million Canadian dollars ($217 million) will be taken up by the Brascan Corporation, its biggest shareholder. Bernard Simon (NYT)

description: New Yorkers tend to get spooked on their first few trips to Los Angeles. The thing that strikes us right away is that many of the city sidewalks are nearly always vacant. Walk a few blocks along a boulevard -- say, from your hotel to a restaurant -- and you can sense that motorists are staring as if you have suddenly grown a second head or split the seat of your pants.

title: John Schlesinger, 77, Dies; Directed 'Midnight Cowboy'
description: John Schlesinger, the Academy-Award-winning director of ''Midnight Cowboy'' whose other films -- including ''Billy Liar,'' ''Sunday, Bloody Sunday'' and ''Darling'' -- often captured the plight of individuals grasping for life support in contemporary society, died yesterday in Palm Springs, Calif., where he lived. He was 77.

title: Quietly, Inkster and Jones Take Charge at Evian
description: With so much attention being focused on Annika Sorenstam's participation in a PGA tournament in May and Suzy Whaley's playing in the Greater Hartford Open this week, Rosie Jones says players like her are being forgotten.

title: New G.O.P. Chief Hammers Democrats
description: Ed Gillespie began his term as the national Republican chairman yesterday with a hard-hitting attack on the Democratic presidential candidates, saying their contest had devolved into a fight over ''who can protest the most angrily and who can take their party further back in time.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: E.T.A. Bombers Sentenced
description: A Spanish court sentenced two members of the Basque separatist group E.T.A. to several terms each of life in prison for ordering and carrying out a bombing in 1987 that killed 21 people and wounded 44. The court ruled that Santiago Arrospide ordered the attack on the Hipercor supermarket in Barcelona, the deadliest committed by E.T.A. in its 35-year fight for Basque independence, and that Caride Simn planted the bomb. The Spanish authorities, meanwhile, blamed E.T.A. for a bomb that exploded yesterday outside a courthouse in Estella, in the northern Spanish region of Navarre, lightly wounding a passer-by. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Paying top yen to hobnob in English
description: TOKYO  In a country where English is not prevalent  even among the elite  and the culture is very different from the West, an English-speaking society of friends can be an oasis. In major urban areas like Tokyo, Yokohama and Kobe, private Anglophone social clubs offer dedicated dining services, libraries and reading rooms, gyms and more to expatriates seeking a home away from home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGAL, , HELEN BIENSTOCK
description: SIEGAL -- Helen Bienstock. The families of Richard and Gail Siegal and Alice and Lester Rubenfeld mourn the passing of Helen Siegal on July 24th, 2003 at the age of 90. Loving grandmother to Michael, Bippy, Jacqui and Arlo Siegal; Jody and Dean Leavitt; Joshua, Gina and Ari Rubenfeld. Also mourned by her great-grandchildren, Gabriela and Daniela Siegal, Samantha and Nicki Leavitt and Ezra and Sophie Rubenfeld. Active in the Sisterhood of Progressive Synagogue, Helen was recording secretary for many years. She was past President of the Women's Auxiliary of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. An accomplished cook and baker, Helen had a cookbook of her original recipes published recently. A longtime supporter of Hadassah, U.J.A., the University of Virginia, the Simon Weisenthal Center, and the Dolly Madison Research Foundation, she will long be remembered for her deep charitable commitment. Having always said she lived a charmed life, Helen died peacefully at home knowing she would once again be with her beloved Manny. >>AD#

title: Baseball Analysis; Heroics Are Back, Obscuring Theatrics
description: There is always hype, endless hype, when the Yankees oppose the Boston Red Sox. Especially after Pedro Martnez's mean fastballs sent Alfonso Soriano and Derek Jeter to the hospital the last time he faced them, causing George Steinbrenner to huff and puff and even to cry. A rivalry that does not need any spicing suddenly had a principal owner and a premier pitcher barking at each other.

description: When President Bush promised to channel billions of dollars in aid -- but only to countries that were committed to ''ruling justly, investing in their people and encouraging economic freedom'' -- it was an extraordinary example of how an idea hatched by scholars could wend its way into mainstream politics.

title: Weyerhaeuser Net Doubles on Forest Sales
description: Weyerhaeuser, the world's largest lumber company, said second-quarter earnings more than doubled on gains from the sale of timberland. Profit in the third quarter is expected to be hurt by lower demand and prices.

title: ALLEGHENY ENERGY SELLS SECURITIES TO RAISE CASH
description: Allegheny Energy, an utility owner, sold $300 million of new securities to a group of investors, including Zimmer Lucas Partners and Perry Capital to help raise cash and avert bankruptcy. The convertible trust preferred securities mature on June 15, 2008, and carry a coupon of 11.875 percent. They are convertible into stock at the option of the holder at $12 a share. As many as 25 million new shares could be issued as a result of conversions, or 20 percent of the 127 million shares outstanding. Allegheny, based in Hagerstown, Md., had been working toward the securities sale since January, when officials said the financing method might be needed to avoid bankruptcy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRONSTEIN, , SOPHIA L.
description: BRONSTEIN--Sophia L. Died peacefully at her home in Chicago at the age of 101. Mrs. Bronstein, who was born in Bialystok, came to Chicago as a young child. She was the widow of Dr. I. Pat Bronstein, a Pediatric Endocrinologist and Professor of Pediatrics. Mrs. Bronstein is survived by her two daughters, Alicia Lambert Albert and Susan Bronstein, her sisters Fay Weissberg and Anita Kurti, and her sister-in-law Kate Lome. She was attended at the last by her caregiver and companion, Rose Butler. There will be a memorial service in Chicago in August. >>AD#

title: Armstrong Just a Short Ride Through Paris From 5th Victory
description: NANTES, France, July 26 -- Lance Armstrong did it.

title: Leader of Major City Union Faces a Re-election Fight
description: The president of New York's main union of social workers announced yesterday that he would challenge Lillian Roberts for the leadership of District Council 37, setting up what is likely to be the closest election battle at any large New York union since the 1980's.

title: EXIDE TECHNOLOGIES SUBMITS DETAILED RECOVERY PLAN
description: Exide Technologies, a maker of car batteries, filed a detailed version of its revised recovery plan that values the reorganized company at about $950 million. The plan, awaiting bankruptcy court and creditors' approval, would eliminate $1.3 billion in debt as the company would exchange it for new shares. Exide, based in Princeton, N.J., plans to ask a bankruptcy judge in Wilmington, Del., for permission to seek creditors' approval on Aug. 25. It sought bankruptcy protection in April 2002 after accumulating more than $2.5 billion in debt, much of it from acquisitions.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Beliefs column last Saturday, about a lawsuit accusing a priest in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Santa Fe of making abusive statements about the deceased at a funeral, misattributed a denial of the lawsuit's claims. It was archdiocesan lawyers in court papers, not Celine Baca Radigan, an archdiocesan spokeswoman, who answered the complaint with a sweeping denial that the priest's actions ''fell outside the liturgical norms'' of the church.

title: City Opera's Hopes to Move To Trade Center's Site Dim
description: The municipal corporation overseeing the redevelopment of ground zero has determined that there is no place at the site for an opera house, a decision that all but dashes the New York City Opera's hopes of moving there from Lincoln Center.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has confirmed the deaths of the following Americans in Iraq:

title: Waco Police Call Off Search
description: The Waco police have called off a search for the body of the missing Baylor University basketball player Patrick Dennehy, The Fort Worth Star-Telegram reported today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALPERN, , DAVID
description: HALPERN--David, on July 24, 2003. Beloved husband of Helen; father to Susan & Ronald, Lynn and Daniel; brother to Evelyn; loving grandfather to Lisa and Bradley Berkoff, Leah & Eric Halpern, Jakob & Joshua; great-grandfather to Jack, Rachael and Jesse. Services on Sunday, 10 AM, I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York. >>AD#

title: Bloomberg Says He has Improved Security at City Hall
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sought to quiet rumblings yesterday that his administration had allowed security to slip at City Hall, saying that he had built upon security measures inherited from his predecessor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, in a way that was not noticeable to the public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINE, , ELLEN (LEVENTHAL)
description: LEVINE--Ellen (Leventhal), on July 24th, 2003, of Englishtown, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Cherished wife of Joe, loving mother of Marcia and Debbie, devoted sister of Larry and special friend to so many who knew her. For many years a teacher and administrator in the NYC school system. Funeral is at 10 AM, Sunday, at Sherman's Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn. >>AD#

title: Author Clinton Shakes Many Hands and Sells Many Books
description: Defying the odds on blockbuster books by celebrities and public officials, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's memoir, ''Living History,'' is now certain to cover its near-record $8 million advance and begin earning her royalties, her publisher said yesterday.

title: Whaley Misses Cut, but Stays Upbeat
description: For Suzy Whaley, as with Annika Sorenstam earlier this year, things became harder on the second day of a PGA Tour event. After a five-over-par 75 on Thursday that was better than scores posted by 13 players, Whaley posted a 78 today in the second round of the Greater Hartford Open. That put her at 13-over-par 153, far above the cutoff number of even-par 140.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a hearing in Brooklyn Criminal Court at which Mike Tyson pleaded not guilty in the beating of two men in a hotel lobby last month misstated the surname of the prosecutor. He is John O'Mara, not O'Hara.

title: Volunteer Accused of Making Threat to Councilman
description: A campaign volunteer for a City Council candidate was charged yesterday with threatening to shoot the incumbent and two aides because he thought they were engaged in dirty campaign tricks, investigators said. The arrest comes just days after another councilman was gunned down at City Hall.

title: At 50, the Korean Truce Defines a Generation Gap
description: For Joo Sung Ro, a 72-year-old veteran of the Korean War, the truce that ended the conflict half a century ago heralded an age of prosperity for South Korea, and an era of a divided Korean people.

title: Sports of The Times; Still Rooting to See Maris in Hall of Fame
description: WHEN he was a boy living in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn in the late 1950's and early 60's, he and his friends would take the D train to Yankee Stadium to see their favorite team play. Young Chuck loved the Yankees. The Dodgers and the Giants had absconded to Los Angeles and to San Francisco, the Mets were barely a gleam in Bill Shea's eye, and the Yankees were the only team in town.

title: Honey Craven, 98, Longtime National Horse Show Manager
description: Honey Craven, the longtime manager and ringmaster of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden, the Devon Horse Show in Pennsylvania and almost every other major horse show in the United States, died Tuesday in a nursing home in Guilford, Conn. He was 98.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Diamond Sales Rise
description: The diamond mining company De Beers said sales in the first half of the year rose 2.7 percent to $2.92 billion and that it expected sales for the full year to exceed those of 2002. The company raised prices in January and May, the managing director, Gary M. Ralfe, said on a conference call. Further increases will depend on retail sales in the fourth quarter, which accounts for about 40 percent of diamond jewelry sales, Mr. Ralfe said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALLACE, , EDWARD (TEDDY) MACINTOSH
description: WALLACE--Edward (Teddy) MacIntosh, age two, son of Michael E. and Amity E. Wallace of Darien, CT died Wednesday, July 23, 2003, at his home in Darien, CT. He was born on December 9, 2000, in Greenwich, CT. In addition to his parents, he is survived by two sisters, Meredith G. Wallace and Eleanor A. Wallace; his paternal grandmother, Marie H. Wallace, of Darien, CT, formerly of Mantoloking, NJ, wife of the late Michael E. Wallace, II of Mantoloking, NJ; and his maternal grandparents John and Nancy B. Eills of New York, NY formerly of Princeton, NJ; two aunts and two uncles and several cousins. A memorial service will be held on Monday, July 28, 2003 at 11:00 AM at Saint Luke's Parish Church, 1848 Post Road, Darien, CT. The family will receive friends at the church immediately following the service. Interment will be private. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to Saint Luke's Parish-Edward M. Wallace Children's Fund, C/O Saint Luke's Parish, 1848 Post Road, Darien, CT. 06820. >>AD#

title: Publishing Siblings Will Compete In Bridal Suite; Parent Approves
description: Fairchild Publications is expected to announce on Monday that it will purchase Elegant Bride, a quarterly magazine owned by Pace Communications, according to an executive at Fairchild and others involved in the transaction.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Antiwar Nuns Receive Prison Terms
description: Judge Robert E. Blackburn of Federal District Court in Denver sentenced three Roman Catholic nuns to prison terms of 30 to 41 months for interfering with national defense and damaging federal property. The women, Sisters Carol Gilbert, 55; Jackie Hudson, 68; and Ardeth Platte, 66, all Dominicans, were found guilty in April of defacing a Minuteman III missile silo near Greeley, in northeastern Colorado, in October by swinging a hammer at the silo and smearing their blood on it in an antiwar protest. Officials said the women caused at least $1,000 in damage.

title: Were 9/11 Attacks Preventable?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Golden Opportunity for Vieques to Be Green
description: When the United States Navy officially stopped its bombing exercises on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques in May, the 9,000 islanders were overjoyed. After for more than 60 years of using Vieques for target practice and occupying two-thirds of the island, the Navy was going, leaving behind a priceless gift: 16,000 acres of untouched land that could make Vieques an unparalleled site for Caribbean eco-tourism. If development isn't handled wisely, however -- and recent plans for projects aren't encouraging -- Vieques may one day be nostalgic for the era of Navy occupation.

title: Head Start Overhaul Passes in House but Faces Senate Hurdle
description: The House passed a bill to overhaul Head Start by the narrowest of margins early today, and the Senate appeared increasingly unlikely to adopt the House's controversial blueprint for handing over control of the program to eight states.

title: PRESIDENT ORDERS TROOP DEPLOYMENT TO LIBERIAN COAST
description: President Bush gave orders today for a naval amphibious force that includes 2,300 marines to sail from the Mediterranean and nearby waters to a position off the coast of Liberia, but left vague what its specific mission would be.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: KIDNAPPED JUDGES KILLED IN RAID Three kidnapped judges and five prisoners were killed when the police raided a jail to free seven judges taken hostage by the inmates, a police official said. The judges had been taken hostage by armed prisoners while visiting the main jail in Sialkot, in eastern Pakistan. The police said that up to three judges were wounded in the gun battle but that all the survivors were freed. The prisoners were demanding their freedom in return for that of the judges, the police said. (Reuters)

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on July 16 about a study finding that 10 percent of newly infected H.I.V. patients in Europe have drug-resistant strains of the virus misstated the number of antiretroviral drugs approved for use against it. The figure is 19, not 17.

title: Animated Films Hit the Road to Win Love of Studios
description: Don Hertzfeldt, the young, amiable and highly praised director of a series of animated shorts featuring stick-figure protagonists, is vexed by the prospects of hand-drawn animation, especially the general studio response to the form.

title: About New York; A Crime Takes Everything But Memories
description: THAT oil painting in the second-floor hall, done by an aunt; no masterpiece, but still. The urns in the attic, containing the ashes of two siblings. The squirrel-shaped bookends in the middle bedroom. The four brandy snifters in the dining room. The typewriters, the sewing machines, the books. Gone.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER GAINS. Copper prices rose after an increase in durable-goods orders for June signaled stronger demand. In New York, copper for September delivery rose 0.45 cent, or 0.6 percent, to 79.8 cents a pound.

title: A 'Four Seasons' to Raise Vivaldi's Eyebrows
description: Jazzdance, a regular visitor from Minneapolis and St. Paul to the Joyce Theater, is a refreshing company whose director, Danny Buraczeski, steers clear of definitions.

title: Asia's club scene : Membership links expats to elite
description: HONG KONG  Expatriates in major cities across Asia have long centered their lives around a coterie of exclusive social clubs. Membership confers the prestige of mingling with a country's elite, the privilege of impressive facilities and the convenience of tapping into a ready-made social circle.

title: A Big Tax Cut For Business Is Proposed In Congress
description: The chief Republican tax writer in the House introduced a big new tax cut for businesses today, a proposal that would reduce the top rate to 32 percent from 35 percent for small companies, provide other benefits for manufacturers and add about $120 billion to the deficit over the next 10 years.

title: America Yawns at Foreign Fiction
description: When the Hungarian novelist Imre Kertesz won the Nobel Prize in Literature last year, the response from many Americans was ''Who?''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a letter to the editor in Science Times on Tuesday about corrective facial operations carried a misspelled signature. The writer was Barry A. Strader, not Srader.

title: Photographer's Dilemma: Duck, or Get the Picture
description: Until gunshots cracked through City Hall, Wednesday had been a pleasantly busy day for Dan Luhmann, the City Council's official photographer.

title: National Briefing | Washington: House Rejects Americorps Money And Adjourns
description: The House adjourned for the summer after voting against an immediate cash infusion for AmeriCorps, the national service program, which is in severe financial difficulty. The leaders of the program had said they would cut 20,000 of its 55,000 positions if Congress did not appropriate $100 million before its recess. The Senate voted to appropriate the money, but House Republicans had argued against the assistance, saying the program was mismanaged. AmeriCorps pays a small stipend or scholarship. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Mets Helped by Leiter And Aggressive Reyes
description: The rookie Jos Reyes was thrown out after overrunning second base on a single to center Thursday in Montreal. Last night, Reyes showed that his aggressiveness had not been stunted.
