title: World Briefing | United Nations: New Administrator For Kosovo
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan appointed Harri Holkeri, a former prime minister of Finland and president of the 2000 General Assembly, as the new United Nations administrator in Kosovo. The choice of Mr. Holkeri is expected to satisfy both the United States and the European Union, which had clashed over previous nominees for the post. He will replace Michael Steiner, a German diplomat who left the position on July 8. Mr. Holkeri will be the fourth head of Unmik -- the United Nations Administration in Kosovo -- since it was established in 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIS, , JAMES E.
description: DAVIS--James E. The Board and staff of the Alliance of Resident Theatres/New York offer our deepest condolences to the family and friends of Councilmember James Davis. He was a frequent visitor to South Oxford Space and his dazzling smile, magnetic personality and passionate commitment to his community will be sorely missed. Ginny Louloudes, Exec Dir Jerry Homan, Facilities Mgr >>AD#

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Slow Economic Growth
description: Britain's gross domestic product increased only slightly in the second quarter, putting a damper on hopes for a quick postwar economic rebound. The country's G.D.P. increased 0.3 percent in the second quarter, up from a rate of 0.1 percent in the first quarter, the National Statistics office said in a preliminary report. It was a 1.8 percent increase from a year ago, but still lower than most economists predicted. Manufacturing output is estimated as unchanged from a quarter before, while consumer spending, reflected in the 0.4 percent increase in the service industries from the previous quarter, continues to grow. ''There is a real gap between the consumer, who is still feeling fine and having a party in his garden, and the business sector,'' said Holger Schmieding, an economist with the Bank of America in London. Because of the lower than expected rate, the Bank of England will need to revise its growth forecasts, Mr. Schmieding predicted, and cut interest rates again this year. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: MGI PHARMA WINS F.D.A. APPROVAL FOR ANTINAUSEA DRUG
description: MGI Pharma Inc. said it won United States approval of its Aloxi drug to treat nausea and vomiting in patients on chemotherapy. United States sales of the drug might exceed $250 million by 2007, said Charles Duncan, an analyst with JMP Securities. The Food and Drug Administration cleared the drug, also known as palonosetron, which MGI licensed from a Swiss drug maker, Helsinn Healthcare. MGI, which already sells Hexalen, an ovarian cancer drug, increased its sales force this year to 80 representatives from 50 to prepare to introduce Aloxi. Shares of MGI rose $5.36, to $31.97.

title: Davis, Fighting Recall, to Stump Against 'Right Wing'
description: Gov. Gray Davis of California has 74 days to defeat the movement to recall him or face being only the second governor in American history to be removed from office by referendum. His strategy for survival, aides say, is to make the vote about anything but Gray Davis.

title: Durable-Goods Orders Soared in June, Heartening Economists
description: Factory orders for durable goods surged in June, helped by spending on new equipment, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

title: Swiss Court Rebuffs a Motorola Request
description: Motorola's wide-ranging battle to recover about $2 billion from the wealthy family that controls Turkey's second-largest cellphone company hit a snag last week, when a court in Geneva said there was not enough evidence that Motorola was defrauded to warrant seizing family-controlled assets in its jurisdiction.

title: MERRILL LYNCH APPOINTS NEW PUBLIC RELATIONS EXECUTIVE
description: Merrill Lynch named Jason H. Wright to be its senior vice president for communications and public affairs, effective Sept. 3. Mr. Wright previously worked as head of worldwide communications at Nabisco Group Holdings and its predecessor RJR Nabisco Holdings, until 2000. Since 2000, Mr. Wright, 42, has been principal of his own firm, Geer Mountain Holdings, which provides capital and advisory services. He will report to E. Stanley O'Neal, Merrill's chairman, and will serve on the firm's operating committee. Mr. Wright replaces Paul W. Critchlow, who has served as Merrill's senior communications executive for almost 15 years. Mr. Critchlow has been appointed to a new position at the firm, counselor to the chairman and vice chairman for public markets.

title: Caught in the Middle
description: For many people of mixed race, life seems to have gotten harder in South Africa since apartheid's end.

title: Pulse
A Pantheon of One
description: Lenin remains the central feature of hundreds, if not thousands, of town squares and city halls in Russia and in many post-Soviet states.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARSKY, , VITA
description: BARSKY--Vita. Age 92 and a half, died on July 23, 2003. Wife of the late Dr. Edward K. Barsky and the late John J. Abt. Really special Mom of Angela Mortarotti. Delighted mother-in-law of Lionel Mortarotti and adoring aunt of Erika Roth. She was a union organizer, co-owner of the Cookery restaurant, fundraiser and a feisty political activist. Her life was filled with wonderful friends and many adventures. She had a terrific sense of humor and was one hell of a great lady. She will be truly missed. >>AD#

title: $4 MILLION IN LEGAL FEES
description: Officials said last week that the state's legal bill would come to more than $4 million in the settlement of a 1999 lawsuit in which Children's Rights Inc. challenged the quality of the state's foster care system. Governor McGreevey announced an agreement with the Manhattan-based advocacy group last month. As part the settlement, the state agreed to create an independent panel to oversee the foster care agency and to pay both the state's legal fees and those of Children's Rights. The major parts of the bill are $1.3 million paid to the Philadelphia-based law firm of Wolf, Block, Schorr & Solis-Cohen, which assisted the state, and $1.75 million for the advocacy group's legal fees. Richard Lezin Jones

title: Eric Shimanoff, Geoffrey Patton
description: Eric Joseph Shimanoff and Geoffrey Thomas Patton affirmed their partnership yesterday with a commitment ceremony at Sun West Studios, a photography studio in Manhattan. The couple met at the State University at Binghamton, from which they both graduated, Mr. Shimanoff cum laude.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: HERMAN MELVILLE called the title character of BARTLEBY (2001) ''a scrivener the strangest I ever saw or hear of,'' and Jonathan Parker's film version of the 1853 Melville novel makes that clear. Updated, Bartleby (Crispin Glover) is an office clerk who does something odd. One day his boss (David Paymer) asks him to verify a notice of petition to administer an estate and Bartleby says, ''I would prefer not to.'' He begins saying the same thing to every request, and no one at the office (his co-workers include Maury Chaykin, whose character isn't smart enough to close the cover on the photocopier) knows what to do. When Bartleby's boss fires him, he continues to come in. The next step is to mmove the office to a new building and hope that Bartleby can't find it - Friday at 9 p.m. and Friday/Early Saturday at 5 a.m.: on Sundance.

title: North by Northeast, An Inn by the River
description: WE knew what we wanted when we were planning our vacation last summer, but we were not sure where to find it on this side of the ocean.

title: The Ways to Pay Financial Advisers
description: To the Editor:

title: California's Comeback Kid
description: In California even where politics are concerned -- appearances can be deceiving. Opponents of Gov. Gray Davis most surely scored a historic victory last week when they succeeded in securing a special recall vote. Already, many are predicting the Democratic governor's demise come the Oct. 7 special election. But even if Republicans are able to place a serious contender on the ballot, don't count the governor out just yet. Mr. Davis may find himself on the political ropes, but that's exactly where he does his best fighting.

title: New York Club Honors a Founder
description: The New York Road Runners Club honored 91-year-old Joe Kleinerman, one of its founders, last Thursday at its six-story headquarters on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. The club named the headquarters lobby, where Kleinerman holds court daily, in his honor and established annual Joe Kleinerman College Scholarships for boys and girls from New York City public high schools.

title: Rockville Centre May Face Electric Rate Increase
description: Electric rates for customers in the Village of Rockville Centre may increase by 11 percent next year if the State Public Service Commission approves the increase, the first since a 14 percent rate increase in 1994.

title: Drill Spotting
description: THE first industrial revolution -- you know, the one that began in the mid-18th century with leaping advances in textile fabrication -- changed the entire course of civilization, if not of life on earth. The latest one is perhaps not such a big deal: namely, that industrial style -- at its best, chicly bleak -- has gone Technicolor.

title: A Brookhaven Moratorium On High-Density Housing
description: The Brookhaven Town Board last week approved a six-month building moratorium on planned retirement communities and multi-family housing developments so the town can complete a study on high-density housing.

title: NEW INSURANCE MAP COMING
description: The Department of Banking and Insurance issued proposed regulations last week for redrawing the state's 60-year-old map of ratings territories for automobile insurance companies. The map uses population densities, commuting patterns, crime rates and other factors to help insurers determine a driver's risk and charge rates accordingly. But the map in use now was drawn when areas like Morris County were predominantly farmland and before the Garden State Parkway and Route 287 even existed. Karen DeMasters

title: A Neighborhood Spot That Aims High
description: RIVER CITY GRILLE has a menu studded with upscale sounding dishes: goat cheese buttons on a salad of mesclun greens, filet mignon with portobello confit, ginger and sesame-crusted tuna. But after sampling several, what I really craved was diner fare -- probably because the restaurant, despite its soft lighting and cushy booths is still, quite obviously, a simple neighborhood place.

title: Trail Memories
description: To the Editor: I was interested to read ''Rocky Peaks, Bared Souls'' (June 29) by Mindy Sink, about the logbooks left in the cabins in the Rocky Mountains in Colorado. I thought of the logbooks that are often found at the shelters along the Appalachian Trail.

title: Editors' Note; Editors' Note
description: A brief article in the Westchester section on June 8 reported the opening of a business called Scarsdale Dental Spa, at which patients can receive treatments like aromatherapy and shoulder massage as well as dental treatments. The article described the spa and an owner, Dr. David M. Greene. After the article appeared, the editors learned that Dr. Greene was arrested in May on charges of sexual abuse and stalking and is to appear in court on Aug. 6. A fuller article appears on Page 7 of the Westchester section.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: NEW AND COLLECTED POEMS: 1931-2001, by Czeslaw Milosz. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $19.95.) Throughout this collection of verse gathered from a 70-year career, Milosz argues with himself about the nature of his poetics. While he long celebrated the power of poetry to rescue mankind, his later work expresses misgivings about the ability of language to capture reality. Because he is now in his 90's, his ''focus gradually shifts from the world he has left and the world he anticipates leaving to the drama of the aging poet,'' Harvey Shapiro said here in 2001. Yet his poems remain ''capacious, hospitable and often rise to quietly ecstatic heights.''

title: Page Two: July 20-26 -- The Week Ahead; CRUCIAL CHURCH MEETING
description: Episcopalians open their general convention in Minneapolis on Wednesday faced with two momentous votes on homosexuality. They will decide whether to approve the bishop elected by the diocese of New Hampshire, who happens to be a gay man, and whether to create a new liturgy for blessing same-sex unions. If approved, Bishop-elect V. Gene Robinson would be the first openly gay bishop in the worldwide Anglican Communion, of which the Episcopal Church USA is the American wing. American conservative Episcopalians and Anglicans from abroad have threatened a schism if he wins. Laurie Goodstein

title: In the Face Of Death
description: In Alex Kotlowitz's mesmerizing article (July 6), two issues explain why a possible death sentence became life without parole for Jeremy Gross.

Loving sister of Charlotte Spector. Services Monday, 11:30 AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

description: So there we were in Princeton, hot on the college circuit tour and looking for something good to eat.

title: Elders Behind the Wheel
description: When an 86-year-old driver plowed through a farmers market at high speed in Santa Monica recently, killing 10 people and injuring dozens of others, he reignited a smoldering debate over the need for stricter regulation of elderly drivers. It is a sensitive issue, pitting the desire of older Americans to remain mobile and independent against the public's need for safety on the roads. Unfortunately, there are no easy answers to this dilemma. Experts say there is no surefire test to spot those apt to cause trouble behind the wheel and no alternative transportation in many parts of the country to serve those barred from driving.

title: The World; How North Korea Became North Korea
description: HAN SUNG JOO, South Korea's ambassador to the United States, was a teenager in the devastated city of Seoul when the armistice halting the Korean war was signed 50 years ago today. He remembers the moment vividly.

title: Elizabeth Stout, John Robinson
description: Elizabeth Foster Stout was married yesterday afternoon to John Beinecke Robinson in the Emmanuel Chapel at St. Luke's Episcopal Cathedral in Portland, Me. The Rev. Elizabeth Gilmore, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Airlines to Share Kiosks For Las Vegas Check-In
description: McCarran International Airport in Las Vegas is installing new SpeedCheck kiosks this summer that will allow passengers from multiple airlines to check in using the same set of self-service machines, with an eye toward eventually replacing the single-airline kiosks now spread throughout the airport.

title: Multitasking Drivers Put Others at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Kings Park Power Plant Gets New Backer
description: Babcock & Brown, an investment banking company based in San Francisco, is reviving a dormant proposal for a 300-megawatt electric generating plant in Kings Park.

title: But What I Really Want to Do Is Throw Tantrums
description: THE HBO reality-television series ''Project Greenlight,'' now in the midst of its second season, arises from an admirably generous premise. A few years ago, Ben Affleck and Matt Damon, surprise Oscar winners for their ''Good Will Hunting'' screenplay, decided to use an Internet contest to search out unsung and promising new filmmakers. The idea, as Mr. Affleck puts it during the show's opening credits, was to give ''amateur people who have never made a movie'' a shot. The winners -- this time out, a screenwriter named Erica Beeney and a pair of directing partners, Kyle Rankin and Efram Potelle, are rewarded with financing and distribution from Miramax Films.

title: Sascha Schmitz, Michael Storfner
description: Alexandra Ursula Schmitz and Michael Norbert Storfner were married yesterday by the Rev. Joachim von Kerssenbrock at the Transfiguration Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Corinne Strauss, Avi Timor
description: Corinne Soikin Strauss and Avi Timor are to be married today at the home of Ruth and Harvey Spear, friends of the couple, in East Hampton, N.Y. Rabbi David Gelfand will officiate.

title: POSTINGS: New York State Realtors' Report; Home Prices Continue Rise
description: Prices of existing single-family homes were solidly higher last month in all of the city's suburbs in New York State, compared with June 2002, according to the New York State Association of Realtors.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the ''Boss'' article on the Executive Life page last Sunday, featuring Jim Koch of Boston Beer, misstated his title. He is the chairman and brewer, not the chief executive.

title: Range War in the Wild East
description: FRAMED by natural boundaries favorable to herding, the East End's pastoral landscape was the domain of cattle 300 years ago. The Montauk Historical Society traces the area's ranching roots to the mid-17th century, and it once supported as many as 7,000 head of cattle. Today, only Deep Hollow Ranch in Montauk, which bills itself the nation's oldest cattle ranch, still trades in livestock and the horses trained to control them.

title: Backers of California Recall Take Celebration to Capitol
description: Supporters of the recall on Gov. Gray Davis held a spirited celebration today on the lawn outside the Capitol, congratulating themselves on the Oct. 7 recall election and extending a hand to all Californians to join their movement.

title: He's Nobody Important, Really. Just a Movie Writer.
description: THE hero and narrator of Billy Wilder's 1950 Hollywood Gothic, ''Sunset Boulevard'' -- a restored print of which will be shown at Film Forum in Manhattan from Friday through Aug. 7 -- is a screenwriter to whom neither fate nor the makers of the film are especially kind. Joe Gillis (played by William Holden), down on his luck as the movie begins, winds up as the kept man of an insanely self-delusive silent film star, Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson), who hasn't made a picture in decades and dreams of a return to glory. She pampers him, and stifles him, and then, in a fit of jealousy, kills him, leaving him to tell his sad tale posthumously as he floats face down in the swimming pool he could never afford. And that's not the worst indignity this writer suffers. The worst is that Norma Desmond gets all the best lines.

Last week, Mr. Curtis paid back Mr. Yang by winning the British Open, clad in a now-famous bright orange shirt with a Kenda logo. "Why did he wear that color?" Mr. Yang wondered in a phone interview. title: Rugged Faceoff Between Rock And Sea
description: THE land and the sea are said to be eternally at war, but in Newfoundland it's more like a grudging truce. Having no recourse but to endure each other, rock and water, those ancient antagonists, have gradually taken on each other's features. The ocean offshore is slate gray, cold and hard, adamantine, polished; the foreshore, the shingle of beach, the steep headlands, border this with a fluid kind of acceptance, the pebbles as bright as sea spray, the boulders forged into breaker shapes, the cliffs leaning seaward. Watching from a distance toward where an impossibly high wave meets an improbably sheer cliff, their gray faces blending, it's hard to tell which element is hitting which.

title: A Road Map of Her Own
description: MY visit to Tel Aviv in late May began with a bang at a sophisticated cafe when I swung off my backpack and knocked over a chair. The chair hit the stone floor with such a sharp crack it stopped conversation at nearby tables, and I do not think I imagined that there was an instant when patrons looked poised to run for cover or the door. In that same moment they must also have discerned that I was klutzy but not dangerous, and animatedly picked up the pieces of their sentences. I was so embarrassed I wanted to slink out of the country, which would have been a shame since there are not many of my kind in Israel these days.

title: Why People Still Starve

If money is the answer to hunger, try the inverse proportion. And show me a prosperous country with the high birthrate of the third-world nations. How obvious and how sad.

title: Island Clearly Shows Its Own Economic Identity
description: ''Lobbying to Keep Economic Identity'' [July 20], about the federal Office of Management and Budget's decision to downgrade Long Island's status as a metropolitan area, reminded me of the Monty Python routine about the Minister of the Silly Walk. It portrays a citizen applying for a silly walk award and the government official proceeds to demonstrate his own silly walks as far superior and more worthy. Similarly, you have the federal Office of Management and Budget denying Long Island's status as an economically independent, separate metropolitan area. In the many years I have traveled between New York City and the Hamptons, I have been struck by the continuing development of Suffolk County and the eastern parts of Nassau. We have come a long way since 1947 and the development of Levittown. The notion that Long Island is a division of New York City is illogical. The strength of the outward movement and the resulting economic activity invalidates the budget office's downgrade. Clearly the federal officials may have a better silly walk, but it shouldn't blind them to the reality that Long Island has forged a separate economic identity. Perhaps Billy Joel can produce a sequel to ''New York State of Mind'' and designate Long Island as a separate mental state. I know I feel different when I'm on the East End. If you use the traffic as a barometer, I think the notion of an economically independent Long Island is self-evident.

title: The Secret of the Black Paintings
description: Venerated as the first modern artist, Francisco Goya produced nothing more abrasively modern than the series of 14 images known as the Black Paintings, which a half-century after his death were cut from the walls of his country house on the outskirts of Madrid. Even today, when you come upon them in the sanitized confines of the Prado Museum, these nightmarish visions can unmoor you. An ancient crone grins ghoulishly over a bowl of food; a demonic figure whispers in the ear of a stooped old man; a midnight coven surrounds a goat-headed sorcerer; a dog raises its head forlornly; and, most famous of all, a raggedy-bearded man with bulging eyes devours a human form that is already reduced to red meat. Of this last iconic image -- called ''Saturn,'' after the Titan who ate his children -- the art historian Fred Licht has written that it is as ''essential to our understanding of the human condition in modern times'' as Michelangelo's Sistine Chapel ceiling is to our grasp of the 16th century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LERNER, , CHARLES
description: LERNER--Charles, a decorated World War II Army veteran and longtime Cooper City, FL. resident, died June 23. He was 91. ''He was very patriotic,'' said his wife of 68 years, Wilma Lerner. He was drafted into the service in 1943, leaving behind his wife and newborn daughter Judith. He served in the 29th Division of the 116th infantry, E. Company. ''I had no fright at all,'' Charles Lerner said in a 1998 interview with a local paper. ''We were a patriotic family. If I had to go, I had to go, and I was going to do the best job I could.'' Among the medals and badges Lerner earned for his service was the Purple Heart. While firing from the top of a tank, a shell exploded, leaving shrapnel embedded in his back. The blast took the life of a good friend positioned next to him. He was discharged just after Thanksgiving in 1945. Lerner was born in Brooklyn, NY., and attended Columbia University. He moved to Coral Gables and worked as a pressman. He returned to New York continuing his career at The New York Times from 1962-1978 and later retired to Cooper City about 20 years ago. Lerner was a member of the Veterans of foreign Wars and the Disabled American Veterans. In addition to his wife Wilma, Lerner is survived by a daughter Judith Lerner of Long Island and a grandson. A son, Tice Lerner, died in 1988. A memorial service will be held in Long Island in the future. Boyd's Family Funeral Homes, University Drive Chapel handled arrangements. Interment Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, NY. >>AD#

title: Hail the Starry Estate Sale
description: Suburbanites flock to yard sales and estate sales, especially in delightful weather. But when the estate is that of a recently deceased Hollywood star, a sale can become an event in itself. At least 100 people stood in line before dawn on July 18 at the Glen Ridge home of Eddie Bracken, a longtime stage, screen and television actor who died in November and whose credits included the Preston Sturges comedies ''The Miracle of Morgan's Creek'' and ''Hail the Conquering Hero.'' Hundreds more walked through the airy Victorian home, which had been sold separately, before the sale closed the next afternoon. They took away porch furniture, paintings and golf clubs as well as photographs, sheet music, librettos, playbills and screenplays, most of which went for $1 or $2. An autobiography of Sturges, signed to Bracken by Sturges's wife, and marked at $40, was unsold by mid-afternoon, as was a box lot of Bracken's jokes, marked at $50. Jim Mahon, a neighbor, bought some scripts of ''Murder, She Wrote.'' Another neighbor, Cherry Provost, bought a silver-plated stamp holder with the initials of Bracken and his wife. Trolling through dead people's possessions can feel macabre, but picking up a picture of Bracken frolicking in his bathing suit with Ronald Reagan inspired other thoughts. A star had lived, prospered and died. His neighbors had two days to gather what fairy dust remained, and they made a merry time of it. ''It's always sad when someone dies,'' said Mary Wood, who ran the sale. ''But this house had a good feeling.'' Debra Galant

He had sources from Afghanistan and contacts in Sri Lanka. He knew Dutch, Italian, and Portuguese. title: The Rural Life; The Home Stretch
description: I never think of wasps as particularly domestic creatures. They cause in me, and in most people, a swift revulsion -- a fear not only of getting stung but also of getting stung by an insect that looks so alien. But while I was preparing the quarters for some new pigs the other afternoon, I looked up and saw a pair of paper wasps delicately dabbing at the edges of a small nest hanging from a single stem under the pig-house eave. Something about their movements, embroidering their way around the circumference of cells, struck me as downright broody -- a word, meaning maternal, that has recently come into common use up here. The wasps and I were at work on the same task, fixing up the place, and I've come to the conclusion that they're not as alien as humans think. According to one researcher, paper wasps recognize each other not only through scent but also through visual identification of facial patterns.

A blue-eyed, thirty-one-year-old sous chef from Berlin, goat-beard wisps of blond hair beneath her arms, she drops her black bikini top and diaphanous, wine-colored sarong onto her towel, strides across the damp sand, and dives into the breakers. Sitting up straight, you gape at the slope of Greta's breasts and run the back of your wrist across your mouth. Until she disrobed, you'd been lying flat against a dry dune near the Sendero cabanas, a short Frisbee toss from Greta's towel, presumably undetected in the shadows of the deserted cove, hands clasped behind your head, your attention directed chiefly towards the cloudless blue sky and a lone schooner bobbing in the calm, gold-flecked Pacific waters a few hundred yards offshore.

title: Water Babies
description: If you want to know how to capture the rapt attention of five redheads ranging in age from 2 to 16, take them 45 minutes by boat from the high-end Solstrand Fjord Hotel just outside Bergen, Norway, across the Bjornafjord to the island of Tysnesoy. This is where Eystein Michalsen and Nina Havn have set up a deliriously rustic retreat called Kubbervik. Eystein will take all the redheads out on a boat, yank in the nets he has laid the night before and, with luck, bring in a couple of cod (one weighing more than 12 pounds and worthy of gasps from several would-be Cousteaus) together with dozens of red and clear jellyfish, about which he will claim, ''These are not good.'' He will then gut the cod to the wonder of all, describing each of the organs as he goes along, and toss the inedibles back into the fiord, where they'll be immediately divebombed by a trio of friendly seagulls and one graceful tern. Game Boys and Walkmen will be silenced and earphones pocketed as the kids (and, I might as well admit it, another 10 or so adults) will be transfixed by his surgical skill in filleting the cod, which he does in under two minutes. Who would have thought marine biology so much fun?

title: Is This Town Big Enough For Two Puppet Boulevards?

When Jeff Marx arrived, however, he headed straight for the entrance and the publicist who was guarding it. Despite his large posse and his nonchalant air, he appeared to be an unlikely candidate for V.I.P. access. For one thing, he was dressed in schlumpy clothes. And for another, most of the members of his posse were puppets.

title: Pain Gains
description: In the early mornings, when I head out to work, I often see the same middle-aged jogger go by, fussing with his stopwatch. Though his pace is rapid, it is also shuddering, like a cart with a wobbly wheel. I picture bone grinding on bone with no cartilage left to intervene. And yet it is not pain that shows on his face but pleasure. I speculate about this man even as I envy him. Exercise for him is its own reward. It is life affirming and it is his addiction.

title: The First Time Around, She Blew It. Or Did She?
description: Back before reality television, in that dark time before ''The Real World'' began raising our young, we had Roseanne Barr. With her plastic surgery, her well-publicized feuds, her confessions of abuse and addiction, this tabloid-ready performer was a glimmer of the genre before it had even begun: exhibitionistic, trashy and bold. And for a time, she was a wild success. Then her sitcom ended, and her talk show shortly thereafter, and Roseanne's fame fizzled. Next month, her mini-documentary, ''The Real Roseanne,'' makes its debut on ABC. But at this moment in history, a Roseanne reality show seems oddly redundant, an afterthought for a woman who was once a pioneer.

title: Were Sanctions Right?
description: As the war in Iraq recedes, the challenges of occupying and rebuilding the country seem to grow more daunting with every passing day. It is becoming clear, though, that Iraq's devastation is not primarily the result of American bombing during the war or of the looting that followed it, but of the economic crisis that befell the country before the first shot was fired. There is still little consensus about what happened in Iraq during the years before the war or who is to blame. But the quest for answers has reawakened a fierce and bitter controversy over Iraq policy in the 1990's.

title: Why People Still Starve
description: It is surprising that Barry Bearak (July 13) could spend as much time as he apparently did with Adilesi Faisoni's family and fail to point out the most important source of hunger in Malawi (and in much of Africa): Adilesi and her husband had 12 children! No nation can hope to feed itself when population is allowed to grow to the limit of human reproductive capacity. If people cannot or will not limit the number of their offspring, nature will do the job for them, and the most that wealthier nations can do with misdirected aid is to delay the day of reckoning.

description: SEABISCUIT'' is a movie spun from a book spun from a horse tale. Now it is also an object lesson in the classicism of black-and-white photography. A 30-second Kodak television ad that ran last week spliced color clips from the movie with black-and-white film stills from Seabiscuit's races of the 1930's. The goal is to promote Kodak's black-and-white film sales and to introduce a new black-and-white disposable, one-time-use camera.

title: Benitez Fails in Ninth, as Red Sox Turn Tables on Yanks
description: Bernie Williams drifted back toward the Green Monster, like a man jogging through an airport staring hopelessly through the windows at a departing flight. As soon as David Ortiz crunched a 97-mile-an-hour fastball from Armando Benitez into the thick summer air today, the Yankees were finished.

title: SARS Abates in Toronto, But Tourism Still Lags
description: SUMMER is the time when Americans are attracted by Toronto's lakeside beaches, a slew of music festivals, a high-scoring baseball team and many sites, like Niagara Falls, within easy driving distance. But this summer is emerging as a major disappointment for Toronto's hotels and restaurants, which depend on a seasonal wave of American tourists.

title: Old Mexico, New Faces
description: Mexican restaurants have been opening fast. Join the fiesta at these seven relative newcomers.

title: What's Good for the Geese?
description: THIS year is turning out to be the year of wildlife disputes for New Jerseyans. Officials recently approved the state's first bear hunt in 33 years after months of complaints about houses and garages being broken into and people and pets being threatened. Deer, as they do every year, have aroused communities statewide by invading gardens and lawns. But the biggest brawl of all is coming to a head this month, in the gassing of the Canada geese.

title: Who's A Hero Now?
description: June 9 was a beautiful spring day in western Pennsylvania. It had been raining much of the week, but that Monday morning the clouds parted, revealing a blue Appalachian sky. Bob Long had plans -- finish remodeling the kitchen, work in the garden, maybe even paint the flower box in the front yard that he'd promised his wife he'd get around to soon. Not that Long was lacking free time. For the past three years, Long, 37, had worked as a surveyor for CME Engineering nearby in Somerset. But several months earlier, he tore his rotator cuff while pounding a surveying stake, and the injury required surgery. He had been off work for about eight weeks, attending physical therapy sessions and catching up on odd jobs around the house. Now Long was eager to get back to work -- back to the routines of ordinary life, which he had been struggling to recapture ever since the events of last summer when, for a brief, hallucinatory moment, he was a hero.

title: 'Support Any Friend'
description: In November 1953, Eddie Jacobson, a Jewish Kansas City haberdasher who had the good fortune to pick as his business partner a scrappy young man named Harry S. Truman, was asked to introduce his old friend to an audience at the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York. Before an eager crowd at the intellectual home of America's largest Jewish denomination, nestled in Morningside Heights in Manhattan, Jacobson tried to give the former president an introduction that rose to the occasion. "This is the man," Jacobson declared, "who helped create the state of Israel."

title: Lisa Herb, Peter Zahler
description: Lisa Michelle Herb, a lawyer, and Peter Irving Zahler, a biologist, were married last evening at the Stimson-Green Mansion in Seattle by Judge James Allendoerfer of the Washington State Superior Court.

title: The World: Postwar Society; When Is It Revenge and When Is It Justice?
description: ALL that is known about how American military commanders learned last week where to find Saddam Hussein's sons, Uday and Qusay, is that an Iraqi ''walk-in'' tipped them off that the two were in a villa in Mosul.

title: Out Of Their Cages
description: The hot new toy here among agents and producers is the $5,000 clicker. The AMX ViewPoint remote commands the plasma TV, TiVo, stereo, radio, pool heater, security cameras, flattering lighting, videoconferencing and air-conditioning. It makes coffee and soon it will make popcorn.

title: Sounds of Summer Begin Fading Away
description: SUMMER isn't even half over, but already it's time for a number of fond farewells.

title: In South Korea, War Veterans Commemorate 1953 Armistice
description: PANMUNJOM, South Korea, July 27  At a commemoration today of the 50th anniversary of the Korean War armistice, here in the village where it was signed, Glen Davis, a 71-year-old veteran from Paden, Okla., had lingering thoughts of the day the conflict started and how he, an Army medic stationed in Japan, found out about it.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: What Brazil Offers to Classical Music
description: AFTER a two-year visit to Rio de Janeiro during World War I, the French composer Darius Milhaud observed that the rhythms of Brazilian popular music were a source of intrigue and fascination. But he offered a disclaimer: ''There was an imperceptible suspension in the syncopation, a nonchalant respiration, a light pause that I found very difficult to grasp.''

title: Quarterback Smith Relishes Chance to Play for Packers
description: A bicycle glides across the asphalt of the Lambeau Field parking lot, carrying a quarterback to a group of fans seeking his signature and a smile. Akili Smith, a onetime captive of the Cincinnati Bengals and of his own unmet expectations, slows to a halt and engages in one of the oldest rituals of Green Bay Packers training camp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEPLEY, , JOHN R.
description: SHEPLEY--John R. A leading translator from Italian to English and writer published in numerous scholarly and literary magazines, died on May 31, 2003. He was 78 years old. Cause of death was cancer of the bladder. Mr. Shepley was a graduate from Harvard in 1946. He lived in Florence, Italy, from 1955 to 1961. He was a member of P.E.N. American Center where he served for many years in the Translation Committee. In 1987 he was awarded the first Italo Calvino prize from Columbia University for his best Italian translation of Pierpaolo Pasolini book ''Roman Nights and Other Stories.'' Among his numerous translations are works by Oriana Fallaci, Beppe Fenoglio, Ferdinando Camon, Maria Messina and Enzo Siciliano. His own fiction appeared in such literary magazines as the Southern Review, Southern Humanities Review, Massachusetts Review, Salamagundi, Mondo Greco, Bitter Oleander and New Orleans Review. >>AD#

title: Page Two: July 20-26; IRAQ: SOME RELIEF FOR BUSH
description: President Bush has been enduring a long, hot summer, with American troops dying with distressing regularity in Iraq, his credibility being challenged and the unemployment rate going up. But the Pentagon handed him a victory of sorts last week, saying it had found and killed the two sons of Saddam Hussein, a development that Republicans said would mark a turning point in the president's political fortunes.

title: Garden Variety
description: Floral print dresses and flower-trimmed hats were out in force at a garden party given by the Monmouth County Historical Association. More than 300 guests were at the benefit at the home of Ann and Thomas Unterberg, right, in Rumson, N.J. The annual event was held on July 20 in the gardens of the estate on the Navesink River. The guests were like so many colorful but conservative flowers on the lawns and gardens, which were designed as a series of rooms. The party also marked the 225th anniversary of the Battle of Monmouth, and an impeccably dressed George Washington, portrayed by William Sommerfield of Philadelphia, strode the grounds. The party quietly continued an elegance known to Rumson, Newport and Southampton before World War II.

title: BackTalk; Rice Is Exhibit A in the Hall of Fame's Voting Paradox
description: In 1976, a young star outfielder for the Boston Red Sox named Jim Rice was scheduled to give a pregame radio interview to Clif Keane, an old-time Boston sportswriter. Rice kept Keane waiting while he shagged flies for an extended period of time, hoping perhaps that Keane would simply disappear. When Rice finally came in from the field, Keane was livid and let Rice have it.

title: Jessica Stein, Mathew Colvin
description: Jessica Beth Stein, a daughter of Susan Stein and Rabbi Jonathan Stein of New York, was married last evening in Olympic Valley, Calif., to Mathew Arthur Colvin, a son of Suzanne and Andrew Colvin of San Francisco. Rabbi Sydney Mintz, a friend of the couple, officiated at the PlumpJack Squaw Valley Inn. The bride's father, who is the senior rabbi at Temple Shaaray Tefila in New York, took part in the ceremony.

title: The High-Stakes Game of the Name
description: SOME names of buildings or residential developments are fanciful, some elegant, some descriptive and some deliberately enigmatic. Some are so successfully absorbed into the identity of the properties that the names define them -- the Dakota, say, the Beresford, River House, Lefrak City. Others serve as brand labels, useful for advertising purposes but adding little cachet.

title: Finally, Porn Does Prime Time
description: LAST Monday Jerry Bruckheimer was anointed by Variety as the first producer in Hollywood history to field the top two highest-grossing movies in a single weekend, the buddy-cop fender-bender ''Bad Boys II'' and the Disney theme-park spin-off, ''Pirates of the Caribbean.'' Mr. Bruckheimer, as many are fond of saying, has that most prized of show-biz attributes: the golden gut. He knows what the American mainstream wants and he supplies it, often with a patriotic tinge. His two-decade hit parade includes ''Top Gun,'' ''Armageddon,'' ''Pearl Harbor'' and ''Black Hawk Down.''

title: Jets Look To Team Jordan And Martin
description: It could be the most anonymous position on the Jets. To be Curtis Martin's backup is to spend a career behind one of the league's most tenacious players, someone who has not missed a start since 1998, who runs with torn ligaments and sprained ankles. When the Jets drafted LaMont Jordan in the second round of the 2001 draft, it was safe to assume that he would not be heard from again until immediately after Martin's retirement.

description: How often is a local post of the Veterans of Foreign Wars denied the right to erect a memorial to fallen soldiers? It could happen.

title: Lee and Me
description: I was so pleased to read Jonathan Reynolds's article on Lee Remick (Food, July 6). She was in many movies, always a pro, always beautiful. I didn't know why she had disappeared from the scene. I missed her.

title: Ogniana Ivanova and Rajpuram Sriram
description: THE bridegroom's mother beamed as her son was married on July 19 under a gazebo wreathed in garlands in Sakura Park on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. Rajpuram Sriram, a native of India, had done what his mother and his 44 cousins had not: he had chosen a ''love marriage'' over an arranged one.

But after you've been to the aquarium, the ballpark at Camden Yards and the shimmering school of neon-wrapped chain restaurants, you would do well to look inland to some of the city's newly gentrified residential districts like Fells Point, Federal Hill and South Baltimore.

But at a planning session this month for Savor Long Island, a new campaign promoting local wines, seafood and agricultural products, he met a number of people -- mainly farmers, he said, but also winemakers and restaurateurs -- who had just become his partners in Savor Long Island, a campaign spearheaded by the Long Island Farm Bureau to raise awareness of the region's foods and wines.

At universities across the country, interest in Wal-Mart Stores has soared in the last five years, and all sorts of courses address specific questions raised by the company's dominance. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRYCE, , MAURICE HENRY LECORNEY, FRS
description: PRYCE--Maurice Henry Lecorney, FRS. Born Croydon, England on January 24, 1913. Died peacefully in Vancouver, Canada on July 24, 2003 after a long illness bravely borne. Emeritus Professor of physics at the University of British Columbia, Canada, and Fellow of the Royal Society since 1951. He had a long distinguished career in advanced theoretical physics, and gave dedicated service to his country in World War II. He will be greatly missed by his loving daughter Sylvia Pryce O'Hickey, son-in-law Patrick & grandson John Elvis in New York, & family members in England & Canada. Donations in his memory can be made to the Botanical Garden Fund at UBC, 6253 N.W. Marine Drive, Vancouver, B.C. V6T 1Z1, Canada. A memorial service will be held at the University on Friday, September 12, 2003. >>AD#

An ongoing installation of new windows on the 11-story brick and limestone palazzo provides a good opportunity to consider whether architecture is made up of solids -- or voids.

title: 3 G.I.'S ARE KILLED GUARDING HOSPITAL NORTH OF BAGHDAD
description: Three American soldiers with the Fourth Infantry Division were killed and four were wounded here today after an assailant, who witnesses said was probably perched inside the children's hospital the troops were guarding, threw a grenade into a group of soldiers who were playing a game of cards next to the building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AGELOFF, , RUTH
description: AGELOFF--Ruth. Age 88, died July 17, 2003 in Scottsdale AZ. She breathed her last with devoted family around her: her husband of 64 years Rubin, her son Roy Ageloff, daughter Joan Davis, grandson Gregg Davis and daughter-in-law Hilda Allred Ageloff. She left three grandchildren, Gregg Davis, Michelle Bermudes and Shana Allred Ageloff and three great grandchildren, Israel and Grace Bermudes and Aidan Davis. Ruth led a productive professional life as a controller for several business organizations. As a volunteer, she gave her skills and talents to the Queens Child Guidance Center as Treasurer and Board member, as a teacher's helper in the NYC school system, and to many other charities, always giving of herself to help others. Ruth graduated from the School of Business of the City College of New York class of 1935, the first class of women graduates in the day session of that school. She went quietly and peacefully and in the end did the most courageous thing of all, she gave her body to science. Contributions in her honor may be sent to the Queens Child Guidance Center, 60-02 Queens Blvd, Lower Level, Woodside, New York 11377. >>AD#

description: FOR 53 years, the Center for Government Services at Rutgers University has been doing research and advising New Jersey leaders on thorny issues like school financing as well as showing municipal officials how to do their jobs. Today, it offers 800 programs ranging from conferences to extensive courses for 24,000 people a year at locations around the state.

title: Ezra Pound, Musical Crackpot
description: ACCORDING to an old and highly unreliable story, Pablo Picasso gave a few poems he had written to Gertrude Stein for comment. In the middle of the night, he was roused violently from sleep. It was Miss Stein, shaking him furiously and shouting: ''Pablo! Pablo! Get up and paint!''

title: Whistler's Ladies
description: James McNeill Whistler (1834-1903) understood the power of fashion. Extravagant by nature, notorious for parading around Europe with his trademark monocle, cane and fur coat accessorized by a pair of ''chrysanthemum-colored gloves,'' he cultivated dandyism in part to market himself as a painter of ''the fashionables,'' as a friend called Whistler's clientele. WHISTLER, WOMEN, & FASHION (Frick Collection/Yale University, $50) is an engrossing study of the artist's obsession with clothes, a passion that, as Margaret F. MacDonald, Susan Grace Galassi and Aileen Ribeiro reveal, was anything but superficial. Painted portraits became an increasingly popular way to immortalize status; an entertaining chapter on the history of fashion quotes a novelist who wrote in 1878, ''There is now a class who dress after pictures and when they buy a gown ask 'will it paint?' '' Whistler took these matters into his own hands, styling all his sitters. In the case of Frances Leland, with whom he was rumored to be in love, he actually designed the diaphanous tea gown in which he depicted her (she had wanted something traditional and black) to signal both his modernity and his informal rapport with his subject. Lady Meux, who did not start out a lady but married the heir to a vast brewery fortune, whom she met at a tavern or dance hall, commissioned several portraits by Whistler as part of her campaign to upgrade her position. Portraying her in an excess of white fur, diamonds and makeup, Whistler not only glorified her finery but cleverly cast her, in more ways than one, as a painted lady. Hilarie M. Sheets

title: Corrections

title: Dogfish Bar: Stripers Are Worth the Wait

title: Word for Word/Revisiting 9/11; The Warnings Were There. But Who Was Listening?
description: IN last week's congressional report on the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency came under sharp criticism for failing to respond to repeated warnings that Osama bin Laden's terror network intended to strike inside the United States. In fact, the nearly 900-page report, prepared by a joint panel of House and Senate intelligence committees, outlined the intelligence lapses at great length, emphasizing the volume, clarity and magnitude of warnings gathered over months and even years.

title: Fresh Hope for Fat Cats
description: The pathetic record of the Federal Election Commission as the designated watchdog against the ravages of big-money politics is only growing worse. Scott Thomas, the stand-out commissioner on the F.E.C. who wants to clamp down on abuses, is to be removed in a stunning decision by the leaders of his own Democratic Party. Mr. Thomas, who is avid about the new McCain-Feingold law's attempt to control the money sluiceway, is to be replaced by Robert Lenhard, a lawyer for the labor movement who was part of the effort to block that law.

title: Breezy Point Attack on Hispanic Girl, 12, Is Charged as Hate Crime
description: A 12-year-old Hispanic girl visiting the virtually all-white enclave of Breezy Point, Queens, was assaulted on Saturday by a woman who used racial slurs and who was arrested on hate crime charges, the police said. Yesterday, the girl was using crutches because of her injuries, a law enforcement official said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHER, , DR. IRWIN M.
description: SCHER--Dr. Irwin M. 69, of Upper Saddle River, NJ, and Spring Valley, NY, died peacefully on July 26, 2003, after a long illness. He is survived by his wife, Cordelia, his children Steven, Robert, Douglas, Christine and Diane, and eight grandchildren. Dr. Scher was an obstetrician and gynecologist in Rockland County for 40 years, an attending physician at Good Samaritan Hospital, and Medical Director at Gynecare. In 2002 he was honored by the National Organization for Women for outstanding service. He served as Commander in the U.S. Navy from 1967 to 1969. He will be dearly missed. Services Monday, at 10 AM, Hellman's Funeral Home in Spring Valley. >>AD#

title: Improved Defense Puts Spring in Bills' Steps
description: To get to the Buffalo Bills' dormitory, players must navigate a long flight of stairs up a hill, a good leg-burning way to finish a practice and to start a season in the unforgiving American Football Conference East.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Wayne: Brush Fire Forces Evacuations
description: A downed power line sparked a gas main fire last night, causing the evacuations of hundreds of people, a police spokesman said. There were no reported injuries from the fire that happened shortly after 9:00 p.m. but a shopping center, an assisted living home, and several private homes were evacuated while firefighters battled the blaze that spread to nearby brush, said Sergeant Mark McGrath of the Wayne Police Department. The fire, at Hamburg Turnpike and Valley Road, forced the relocation of about 25 senior citizens to the local high school John Holl (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Economic Scene column in Business Day on Thursday, about the effects of affirmative action, misstated the name of an organization with which a researcher, Stacy Berg Dale, was affiliated. It is Mathematica Policy Research, not ''Police'' Research.

title: Metro Matters; Tilting At Toilets, The Sequel
description: A CHECK of the clip file shows that the subject of public toilets has a way of stimulating the literary impulse. References to Henry Miller and George Orwell have decorated musings on the matter. So have song lyrics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FERENCZ, , MICHAEL
description: FERENCZ--Michael. Passed away peacefully in his home on Saturday, July 26. He is survived by his wife Joan, children Dr. Gerald Ferencz and Karen Ferencz, grandchildren Jesse, Nikki, Kendl and Alex; his nephew Dr. Jonathan Ferencz and wife Maxine and their children Julieann and Benjamin. Michael was a Holocaust survivor who escaped from forced labor camp, ultimately made his way to the United States, opened a fabric store on 57th St, and was a tireless supporter of Israel. Contributions can be made on Michael's behalf to the Israeli Emergency Fund, c/o Temple Shaaray Tefila, 89 Baldwin Rd, Baldwin Corners, NY 10549; 914666-3133. >>AD#

title: Study Finds 2.6% Increase In U.S. Prison Population
description: The nation's prison population grew 2.6 percent last year, the largest increase since 1999, according to a study by the Justice Department.

title: Springsteen Ticket Scalpers, Glory Days Have Passed You By
description: Michael White and Sean McNeil planted themselves in the Giants Stadium parking lot with modest goals -- they would drink beer, purloin cheese from nearby tailgaters and sell a spare ticket to the evening's Bruce Springsteen concert.

title: The Ethiopian Famine
description: Famine is again stalking Ethiopia -- this time casting a wider shadow. While a million people died in the famine of 1984 and 1985, today more than 12 million are at risk, half of those children under 15. Perhaps the most chilling aspect of today's crisis is that the famine persists despite generous outside food aid. Donations of wheat, soybeans and oil can stave off much of the starvation in the short term, but they cannot keep hunger from returning year after year.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: Sentencing In Ganim Case
description: A former stockbroker who once promised to share half of his commission with former Mayor Joseph P. Ganim and his associate was sentenced in federal court Friday to four years of probation. The stockbroker, Frank Sullivan, 41, of Fairfield, had admitted offering a kickback to Mr. Ganim and Paul J. Pinto, an associate of Mr. Ganim, for a contract to manage the city's police and fire pension plans. Mr. Sullivan was also ordered to pay a $20,000 fine and perform 300 hours of community service. Nine people have been sentenced in the case, including Mr. Ganim, who was sentenced July 1 to nine years in prison for bribery, racketeering and extortion. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page subheading yesterday about a federal investigation of MCI over assertions that it defrauded other telephone companies of long-distance access fees referred imprecisely to MCI's response. The company's official statement said that such disputes were routine and that it was cooperating with the United States attorney's office. It was individual MCI executives who said they believed that the allegations were unfounded but were conducting their own internal review.

title: The Word on Music: A Sampler
description: Following are excerpts from reviews and essays by Harold C. Schonberg, chief music critic for The New York Times from 1960 to 1980:

title: New Rules, Old Rhetoric
description: As the debate about media ownership has moved to Congress during the last two months, the tone of the rhetoric has grown increasingly shrill. One member of Congress said the Federal Communications Commission's June 2 decision to modernize media ownership rules would produce ''an orgy of mergers and acquisitions,'' while another said the new rules could create a new generation of Citizen Kanes.

title: In Harlem's Fabric, Bright Threads of Senegal
description: For the last week, Senegalese pilgrims have trekked to a normally quiet corner on the western edge of Harlem to await blessings from a holy man. Resplendent in robes of shimmering cotton, colorful turbans perched on the women's heads like exotic birds, they clustered outside a red-brick building named, grandly, the House of Islam.

title: The Nets Are Close to Re-Signing Harris
description: The Nets are expected to sign backup guard Lucious Harris to two-year contract this week, according to a member of the Nets organization.

title: Totaling Up the Bill for Spam
description: When Indiana University installed its new e-mail system in 2000, it spent $1.2 million on a network of nine computers to process mail for 115,000 students, faculty members and researchers at its main campus here and at satellite facilities throughout the state. It had expected the system to last at least through 2004, but the volume of mail is growing so fast, the university will need to buy more computers this year instead, at a cost of $300,000.

title: Bob Hope, Comedic Master and Entertainer of Troops, Dies at 100
description: Bob Hope, whose mastery of the comic monologue and the topical wisecrack carried him from vaudeville to Broadway musicals and then on to worldwide fame as a radio, film and television star of the first magnitude, died Sunday night in Toluca Lake, Calif., according to his long-time publicist, Ward Grant. Mr. Hope was 100.

description: Reprinted from yesterday's late editions.

title: Don't Wanna Grow Up Cuz Puberty Isn't Funny; Series Like 'Malcolm in the Middle' Confront the Reality of an Actor's Adolescence
description: No matter how many laughs a television show can squeeze from an impish boy, cracking wise and bugging out his eyes at various oppressors, a sudden end to the laughter looms. The comedy often stops when puberty starts.

title: After a Century of Luring Tourists, Hawaii Visitors Bureau Is Stripped of Its Worldwide Reach
description: The Hawaii Visitors and Convention Bureau, in one form or another, has been the islands' primary marketing representative to the world for the last century.

title: 3 Iraqis Killed as G.I.'s Set Up Raid in Hunt for Hussein
description: American soldiers fired on a Toyota passenger car in an upscale Baghdad neighborhood late this afternoon, killing at least three Iraqis, as an American Special Operations team prepared to raid a nearby house in what an Iraqi policeman later described as an unsuccessful attempt to capture Saddam Hussein.

title: Newman Gets Mileage Out of Late Cautions
description: Even a fast car rolls to a halt if it has no gas. Ryan Newman's crew figured he had to cover 46 laps, or 115 miles, on his last tank of fuel today. Without a yellow flag, his black Dodge would quickly inhale even the fumes.

title: Manchester United Strolls Past Amrica
description: A goal from Ruud van Nistelrooy and two goals by Diego Forlan carried Manchester United past Club Amrica of Mexico, 3-1, at the Los Angeles Coliseum today. The match, the second in the English Premier League champions' tour of the United States, was the only stop on the tour that failed to sell out; the Coliseum, which holds more than 90,000, drew fewer than 60,000 fans for the match.

title: Fire Leaves A Tiki Bar, And Patrons, Devastated
description: In the suddenly trendy world of the Tiki bar, Lee's Hawaiian Islander was a bit of a throwback: dark and full of bamboo and blowfish lights. Nevertheless, it attracted fans from all over northern New Jersey and was even considered something of a classic among Tiki aficionados.

title: International Team Wins Spingold Knockout Title
description: A cosmopolitan team captured the prestigious Spingold Knockout Team title here early this morning. The captain, Roy Welland of Manhattan, is the only member of the team who learned his bridge in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, , ETHEL (SHANKMAN)
description: BERNSTEIN--Ethel (Shankman). Passed away at 88 years of age on July 26, 2003, at home in Scarsdale, NY. Born in Trenton, NJ, on July 10, 1915, to the late Samuel and Beatrice (Elkin) Shankman. Devoted, loving and caring wife to Sidney, who predeceased her in 2002. Loving mother to sons Richard A. and Barry, and daughters-inlaw Amelia and Betsy. Adoring and proud grandmother to Andrew Bernstein, Bradley Bernstein and Jennifer and Gregg Rothkin. Devoted sister to Phyllis Safran, Leonard Shankman and the late PFC Richard A. Shankman (WWII). She will be missed by her family and friends. Services Monday, July 28, at 1 PM, at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made in Mrs. Bernstein's memory to the White Plains Medical Center or the NYC Police Athletic League.

title: A First at Bride's Magazine: A Report on Same-Sex Unions
description: After 70 years of helping brides walk down the aisle, Cond Nast's Bride's magazine has crossed a threshold of its own. Its September-October issue, on newsstands now, contains a full-page article on same-sex weddings. This is the first time that any of the five top-selling bridal magazines has published such a feature.

title: Kmart Seeks A Broadcast Agency
description: The Kmart Corporation and its broadcast agency of three years, TBWA/Chiat/Day in New York, have parted ways, and Kmart is preparing to hear new creative ideas from several unnamed agencies. Although spending on the account was not disclosed, the company, which emerged from bankruptcy protection in May, spent $267 million to advertise in major media last year, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR.

title: Corrections

Two- and three-bedroom apartments there sold in 2001 for $350,000 to $695,000, not $510,000 to $850,000. A letter from residents on June 20, questioning the figures, went astray at The Times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NELSON, , TREVOR
description: NELSON--Trevor. 34, died suddenly of complications from viral meningitis on July 24. A summa cum laude graduate of U.C. Berkeley, Trevor was a producer at ''60 Minutes,'' champion skier, runner and overall sports enthusiast. He seized every waking moment of his life with an exuberance that was lovely to behold. He is survived by his adoring and devoted wife, Maggie; young sons, Conrad and George; mother, Suzanne Colt; sisters, Andrea Abbott and Angela Colt; stepfather, Edward Colt. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM, August 4, at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th Street and 5th Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations in Trevor Nelson's name may be made to St. Bernard's School in New York City, The Central Park Conservancy, and The Trustees of the Reservation, Beverly, MA. >>AD#

title: Songs for a Summer Night Cooled by River Breezes
description: On Thursday night Ashanti took a long walk on a short pier. She gave a delightful concert at Pier 54 on the Hudson, tiptoeing back and forth across the stage while singing songs as mild and breezy as the weather. It just goes to show how much pop music has changed over the past few years. Nowadays if you want dirty dancing and suggestive lyrics, you can go see Justin Timberlake and Christina Aguilera. And if you want sweet love songs the whole family can enjoy, you turn to a label called Murder Inc.

description: The metaphors going around the smokers' crevices and talk-radio shows describing the shape of politics in the Golden State are animalistic and amusing. Among the better ones: a yard full of headless chickens, a zoo with the cages left open.

title: Orgy of Curled Lips and Dropped Consonants
description: When Chris Isaak and Lisa Marie Presley played the Beacon Theater last Monday night, there was enough sneering and slurring onstage to power a dozen Elvis impersonators. The two singers spent the night curling their lips and dropping their consonants, and while only one of them could lay a biological claim to this act, no one in the crowd seemed to mind.

title: New York's Fake Conventions
description: If you want to study how not to pick a judge, the borough of Brooklyn is available. One State Supreme Court judge has been indicted recently on bribery charges. His cousin, also a judge, is being investigated for draining the bank account of a wealthy relative. The Brooklyn district attorney's office is investigating how the indicted judge's wife earned her own judicial robes. And that's just one family in one borough of New York City's politically cozy and inbred judiciary.

title: Sports of The Times; Triumph Shared With Club Of Millions
description: LANCE ARMSTRONG has joined an exclusive club. He is now one of five cyclists to have won the Tour de France five times.

description: A few weeks ago, a customer called Continental Airlines to book four tickets from San Antonio to London. An agent in Houston dutifully looked up routings and prices, and quoted a fare of $912 a person.

description: The trainer Bobby Frankel and the jockey Jerry Bailey once more asserted their dominance on New York stakes racing as Sightseek roared to an 11 1/2-length victory in the 50th running of the Go for Wand Handicap.

title: New Economy; Enhancing education, not protecting beleaguered industries, will help the economy, experts say.
description: AS the job market gropes for a recovery from the recession, some of those looking to place blame have settled on the nation's imports and exports. Consumers are importing too many goods and services, the argument goes, while companies are exporting too many jobs. But while these activities may indeed be slowing the recovery in the short term, in the long term they are likely to be essential to raising standards of living.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: NEWARK: MAN SHOT BY POLICE OFFICER /> An off-duty city police officer shot and critically wounded a man before dawn yesterday. The officer, David Lamar, notified the Newark police at 5:20 a.m. of the shooting. Paul Godley, 30, was shot in the stomach and was taken to the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. He was listed in critical condition yesterday. Officer Lamar, 35, who has been on the force less than two years, was suspended without pay.   (AP)

title: Critic's Notebook; Classic Dramas Simmer in London's Summer Heat

title: Florida City Goes to Bat for Stadium
description: This suburb of Fort Lauderdale fades into a landscape of urban sprawl. Located in the geographic center of Broward County, Lauderhill is part of a continuum of Chili's restaurants, Amoco gas stations and Target superstores. Driving from one strip mall to another, motorists often pass through Lauderhill without even realizing it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, , HAROLD ''JULIUS.''
description: FRIEDMAN--Harold ''Julius.'' 86, of Lauderhill, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died July 26, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Shayne. Cherished father of Melanie (Marc) Melloment and the late Bonnie and the late (Jay) Slotkin. Grandfather of David (Sharon) Slotkin and Jonathan Slotkin. Great-grandfather of Jayme and Benjamin. Service in Florida. >>AD#

title: Rwanda Is Said to Seek New Prosecutor for War Crimes Court
description: With the quiet support of the United States, the Rwandan government has been campaigning to have Carla Del Ponte replaced as chief prosecutor for the tribunal dealing with the mass killing in Rwanda in 1994, Western diplomats and tribunal officials have said in recent days.

title: U.S. May Authorize $1 Billion To Speed Up Afghan Projects
description: The Bush administration is weighing a proposal to seek up to $1 billion in aid to help rebuild Afghanistan, administration officials said today.

title: California Screamin'
description: The humorist S. J. Perelman used to say his wife was ''afflicted with total recall.'' That affliction has now seized California.

title: Alternate-Week Recycling Pickup Begins in New York City
description: New York City shifts to an alternate-week pickup schedule for recyclables today. Glass recycling remains suspended until next April. New Yorkers can find out the schedules for their neighborhoods by either calling 311 or logging on to the Department of Sanitations Web site at www.nyc.gov/sanitation.

title: Phelps Breaks the Record For Breaking Records
description: It came as no surprise to anyone who had spent the last eight days here that the last race of the world swimming championships ended with a world record.

title: Diverging Estimates Of the Costs of Spam
description: Spam has become the bane of the Internet because it is so cheap and easy to send that many businesses and individuals do so. Spammers these days pay as little as 0.025 of a cent to send an e-mail message. The computing costs for the recipients, or their Internet providers, to process each message are similarly tiny.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIS, , JAMES E.
description: DAVIS--James E. The Brooklyn Arts Council mourns the passing of Councilman James E. Davis, a friend and supporter of the arts in Brooklyn. When there was singing, he always sang; when there was dancing, he danced. He will be sorely missed. The Board and Staff of Brooklyn Arts Council (BAC) Dr. Thomas F. Schutte, Board Chair Ella J. Weiss, President >>AD#

title: 52-Year Separation Ends as Iraqi Jews Arrive in Israel
description: After more than a half century of separation enforced by Middle Eastern political strife, two Jewish sisters embraced today in a hotel lobby, tears forming in the corners of their eyes.

title: The French Warm to a Warmer Lance Armstrong
description: PARIS, July 27  In a little-noticed ceremony, the many photographers who cover the Tour de France awarded their Prix Orange to Lance Armstrong, honoring him last week as the most cooperative rider. Two years ago, they gave him the Prix Citron, or Lemon Prize, as the biggest pain in the lens cap.

title: Racial Progress In New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MATTES, , JOSEPH EDWARD
description: MATTES--Joseph Edward. We deeply mourn the passing of the Paul Rapoport Foundation's Founding Board President and Director, Joseph Edward Mattes. Jed's nurturing and thoughtful leadership in our formative years was invaluable and will continue to be reflected in the Foundation's essence for many years to come. Our sympathies are extended to his family and his many friends. The Board of Directors and Staff The Paul Rapoport Foundation >>AD#
