title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILLETTE, , WILLIAM S.
description: GILLETTE--William S. Died at Hilton Head, South Carolina on July 26, 2003, at the age of 46 after a long illness. Bill is survived by his parents Richard and Marion Gillette of Southampton, NY, and West Palm Beach, Florida. Also by his brother Richard C. Gillette of Hilton Head, his sister Paige G. Louthan of McLean, VA, and five nieces and nephews. Services private. In lieu of flowers contributions in Bill's memory may be made to Hospice Care of the Low Country, 20 Palmetto Parkway, Suite 104, Hilton Head, SC, 29926, or Rogers Memorial Library, Southampton, NY 11968. >>AD#

title: U.S. Women Win Another Nordic Cup
description: Joanna Lohman, a senior at Penn State, scored both goals yesterday as the United States women's under-21 team won its fifth straight Nordic Cup title with a 2-1 victory over Sweden in Randers, Denmark.

title: Murphy, Longtime Mets Announcer, Is Retiring
description: Long before the last bobbleheads of Bob Murphy and Ralph Kiner, two of the Mets' original broadcasters, were handed out at Shea Stadium yesterday, Murphy was on WFAN making the dolls a keepsake. Murphy announced his retirement, effective at the end of the season, after 50 years in the major leagues, including 42 with the Mets.

title: Man Drowns In Attempt To Retrieve Lost Camera
description: Hundreds of people watched early yesterday as a man from Queens drowned after jumping off the wooden pier at South Street Seaport to retrieve a disposable camera that had fallen into the water, the police said.

title: Just Happy to Be a Central Park Troubadour
description: Failure hasn't spoiled David Ippolito. Success hasn't spoiled him either, and he has had his share of both, this shirtless and barefoot troubadour of Central Park who calls himself ''the most famous person no one knows.''

title: Detainees' Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: Universal rolls out 'Seabiscuit' with plans to run a marathon, not a sprint.
description: IN a season packed with action-driven movies, ''Seabiscuit,'' the Depression-era tale of three troubled men and a temperamental but record-setting racehorse, presents a distinct, grown-up alternative. In the film, which opened Friday, nothing explodes, except the temper of the jockey Red Pollard (played by Tobey Maguire). The most devastating crash happens offscreen, years earlier, on Wall Street. And instead of blaring rock music, there is much quiet, thoughtful conversation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief sports article on Friday about the victory of Mark Mielke in the MONY New York State Open golf tournament referred incorrectly to the finish. Mielke won the tournament on the final hole, not in a one-hole playoff with Frank Bensel.

title: You've Got Courriel
description: The French government recently decided to ban the use of the term ''e-mail'' in all of its ministries and official documents because it does not have a French origin. Instead, it will now use the word ''courriel,'' a hybrid of the French words for electronic mail. It's the latest chapter in the long war to keep the French language pure, but we suspect this skirmish is going to be as hard to win as the attempt last year to get the French to call the ''@'' character ''arrobe.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMENT, , FRANCES
description: HAMENT--Frances. Of Great Neck, NY. Fran, beloved wife of the late Gus Hament passed away unexpectedly on July 26, 2003. She leaves behind her children Tina, Winnie, Billy (predeceased), Daniel, Nancy and Barbara; an extended family of spouses, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, unofficial foster children and an abundance of adoring friends. Fran was a woman with an open heart who adopted a lot of people along the way. She was a woman with a style all her own. Her warmth of spirit pervaded a life full of everyday experiences. At every turn, she turned toward life, toward her family and especially toward people who needed her gentle manner and deep wisdom. There was always ''room for one more'' in Fran's world. She will be sorely missed by the many lives she shared and touched. Services will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, 2 p.m., Monday, June 28. The family will sit shiva at the home of Tina Hament and Patrick Silvestri in Glen Cove. >>AD#

title: Howard Settling in With Manchester United
description: No, TIM HOWARD does not yet speak with a British accent (like BRAD FRIEDEL, another American goalkeeper playing in England), but Howard, Manchester Uniteds first player from New Jersey and from Major League Soccer, seems to have quickly adopted his teammates reticence when dealing with the news media in his new world.

title: OPEC Unfazed by Prospects For Renewed Flow of Iraqi Oil
description: After several false starts, Iraq seems poised to resume a steady flow of oil exports starting in August. For months, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries has been puzzling over what such an infusion of oil into world markets might mean for prices and what member nations should do to hold prices in a profitable range.

title: INSIDE
description: A Civil End to Filipino Mutiny

title: Jacobsen Never Wavers And Ends His Drought
description: Nineteen years after winning the Greater Hartford Open, 49-year-old Peter Jacobsen did it again today, shooting his fourth sub-par round, a three-under-par 67, to win by two strokes and become the seventh-oldest player to capture a PGA Tour event.

title: This Time, Kim Shuts The Door On Yanks
description: What does it take to exorcize demons? For Byung Hyun Kim, the Red Sox closer, the answer may be a save against the Yankees. Tonight, Kim finally did something right against the team that seemed destined to forever torment him.

title: A Writer's Heartbeats Answer Two Calls
description: Ten years ago the novelist Isabel Allende became a United States citizen. Her passport now described her as an American from California. But at heart, she said recently, she continued to be a Latin American from Chile, where her family's roots were and where she lived on and off for a third of her 60 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIENER, , PATRICIA PLEHN
description: DIENER--Patricia Plehn. On July 24, 2003. Beloved partner of Charles Zale. Loving mother of Holly and James. Dear sister of Denis. Service Tuesday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. >>AD#

title: The Odd Couple Of the Backstretch
description: Marylou Whitney's comings and goings are chronicled in high-end magazines like W. Nick Zito's paper of record is The Daily Racing Form. Her nights are filled with waltzes and Champagne; his end early because barns full of racehorses need to see him by 5 a.m.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I came into this race very confident I'd win, but I won't be so confident before next year's Tour.''

title: This Time, a Grubman Crash Leaves an Old Jaguar Limping
description: It will not be cheap. But the good news, experts say, is not only that Allen Grubman is safe after a car accident in the Village of East Hampton on Saturday morning, but that his vintage Jaguar can most likely be repaired.

title: 50 Years Later, Veterans Revisit Still-Divided Korea
description: At a commemoration here today of the 50th anniversary of the Korean War armistice, Glen Davis, a 71-year-old veteran from Paden, Okla., had lingering thoughts of the day the conflict started and how he, an Army medic stationed in Japan, found out about it.

title: Series Victory Puts Red Sox on Yanks' Heels
description: The feeling hit home for Chris Hammond during the first two games of this riveting series with the Red Sox. Hammond, a Yankees left-hander, had not pitched since last Sunday, and as he watched the drama unfold at Fenway Park, he got the idea he was much less important in the Yankees' revamped bullpen.

title: Camp Roughing It (With Cellphones)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bond Sale Schedule For the Week Ahead
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a four-week bill tomorrow.

title: No Directions Needed on Way to First Tour Victory
description: A year ago, Sean Rosenthal left his hotel and decided to walk to the A.V.P. Belmar Open. Rosenthal, a California native, did not know as he started down the road that the event was about 10 miles away, and he wandered for nearly an hour before finally calling a local player, who picked him up and took him to the oceanfront site.

title: Chief Details Huge Scope Of Special Operations
description: Brig. Gen. Gary L. Harrell, commander of Special Operations missions for the war in Iraq, sat in an office whose interior design favors hand-tooled tomahawks and recalled the day he ordered a dozen Green Berets and a small band of Kurdish fighters to take on a division of Iraqi Army troops.

title: That Old-Time Religion; New Jersey Priest's Use of Latin in Mass Sparks Protest
description: The Rev. John A. Perricone, an erudite Roman Catholic priest who uses Latin phrases and refers to T. S. Eliot in conversation, is known nationally as leading proponent of the centuries-old Latin Mass, which was banished in favor of a more accessible service by the Second Vatican Council in the 1960's.

title: Jets' Mandate for 2003: Get Bigger, Faster and Stronger
description: In Herman Edwards's playing days, the off-season conditioning program usually consisted of a few pickup basketball games and then a two-month training camp full of flabby and nauseous players who could not finish a run.

title: RED INK IN STATES BEGINNING TO HURT ECONOMIC RECOVERY
description: Having already stripped the nation of a source of economic growth, the budget crises in California and in almost every other state are now beginning to drag down the national economy, prolonging the weak, jobless recovery, the latest budget numbers show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVERMAN, , PHYLLIS, PH.D.
description: SILVERMAN--Phyllis, Ph.D. On July 26, 2003. Survived by beloved husband Arthur Liebeskind, M.D., cherished sister Arlene, devoted mother Mary Silverman, and loving friends and colleagues. Services Tuesday, 9 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. >>AD#

description: Just when it seemed as if reality television might succumb to endless variations of the dating, talent and survival show, a batch of ambitious producers have discovered a new twist that they hope will inject freshness into the genre: the reality show as sitcom.

description: STOCKS

title: Sports of The Times; Two Different Stars Find Same Reward
description: SOME of the greatest players in baseball history baseball immortals, as the mortals say -- had gathered, as they do every year around this time, to honor the new members of the Hall of Fame.

title: CNBC Disclosure Stirs Ethics Debate In Business Media
description: Maria Bartiromo, the stock-market reporter and anchorwoman for CNBC, opened her hourlong television interview earlier this month with Sanford I. Weill, the chief executive of Citigroup, with an unusual disclosure. She told viewers that she owned 1,000 shares of Citigroup stock, then worth about $45,000.

title: Webdenda
description: Kimberly Borman was named senior vice president and group account director for the relationship marketing group, overseeing production, creative and account service duties in its direct marketing division, at Hill, Holliday Connors, Cosmopulos , Boston. She succeeds Mark Mylan, who was named to the new post of senior vice president for strategy in relationship marketing. Ms. Borman had been executive vice president and director for client services at Gearon Hoffman, Boston. Environmental Defense , New York, formerly the Environmental Defense Fund, named the Green Team , New York, to handle its first paid campaign. Billings were not disclosed. The decision came after a two-month review in which the other participants were not disclosed. Environment Defense previously advertised through public service announcements created by McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, and coordinated by the Advertising Council, New York. Fallon Worldwide , Minneapolis, hired one employee and expanded duties for another. John Matejczyk was named group creative director on the accounts of Citibank and Lee Misses, succeeding Harvey Marco, who is joining the Torrance, Calif., office of Saatchi & Saatchi. Mr. Matejczyk had been senior copywriter at Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group. And Dave Damman , group creative director on the account of the International Truck and Engine, was named to manage creative work on the additional accounts of Subway, a newly won account, and Lee Dungarees. Mr. Marco had been group account director on the Lee Dungarees account. Fallon and Saatchi & Saatchi are units of the Publicis Groupe. Tom Freydl , vice president at the Los Angeles office of Ketchum Entertainment Marketing, was named director, succeeding Mark Malinowski , a senior vice president based in New York, who was named creative director. Mr. Malinowski was also named director for entertainment marketing at the parent company, Ketchum. Mr. Freydl will relocate to New York. Ketchum is part of the Omnicom Group. Lina Gallardo was named director for account services and marketing at Go East Design , St. Paul, Minn., succeeding Vicki Giefer, who left, the agency said. Ms. Gallardo had been an account director at Penn Garritano, Minneapolis. Gregg Hano , director for sales and marketing at Popular Science magazine, was named publisher, succeeding Denise Anderman, who left, the company said. Popular Science is part of the Time4 Media division of Time Inc., a unit of AOL Time Warner. Brook Harker was named multimedia designer at Boede & Partners , Salt Lake City. He had been a motion graphics designer at ImageWise Productions, Salt Lake City. Marilynn G. Jacobs , director for marketing at Better Homes and Gardens magazine, New York, was named associate publisher for marketing. Better Homes and Gardens is published by the Meredith Corporation. Lounge Lizard Worldwide , Great River, N.Y., and Adam Friedman Associates , New York, a public relations and investor relations agency, have formed a strategic alliance to share services. Terms were not disclosed. Parade , New York, the Sunday newspaper supplement, promoted three employees. Margo Coble , director for marketing and advertising, was named to the new post director for brand development. Laura Whisnand , marketing director for newspaper relations, was named to the expanded post of director for marketing, assuming duties that had been handled by Ms. Coble. And Allison White , manager for planning and development, was named to the new post of director for business development. Parade is part of the Parade Publications division of Advance Publications. Sherry Pinkof , vice president and group account director at MPG (Media Planning Group) , New York, part of Havas, was named senior vice president. She continues to oversee the account of Reckitt Benckiser, a British maker of household products like French's mustard. Brenda Saget Darling was named publisher at Traditional Home magazine, New York, succeeding Wilkie Bushby, who left, the company said. Ms. Saget Darling had been vice president and publisher at House & Garden magazine, New York, part of the Conde Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications. Traditional Home is published by the Meredith Corporation. Greg Schumann was named publisher at Baby Talk magazine, New York, succeeding Risa Crandall, who left, the company said. Mr. Schumann had been Eastern advertising director at Teen People, New York. Baby Talk and Teen People are published by the Time Inc. division of AOL Time Warner. Cathy Shaffner , account supervisor at Empower MediaMarketing , Cincinnati, was named vice president. Smithsonian magazine, New York, named Interevco , New York, to handle ad sales and sponsorship duties on behalf of SmithsonianMag.com. Those duties had been handled internally. Smithsonian is published by the Smithsonian Business Ventures division of the Smithsonian Institution. Catherine Still , business development manager at Media Revolution , Los Angeles, was named to the new post of director for marketing and solution development. Media Revolution is part of Univessence. Michael Sugzda was named senior vice president and account director at Wunderman , New York. He had been president at the New York office of Direct Partners, part of the Omnicom Group. Wunderman is the direct marketing unit of the Young & Rubicam division of the WPP Group. Robert Verrico , senior vice president for advertising sales at TheStreet.com , New York, a financial Web site, was named to the new post of executive vice president for sales and general manager for consumer markets. Samantha Voisin was named to the new post of business development manager for the Western region at the Los Angeles office of Eyeblaster , New York, a provider of online advertising technology. Ms. Voisin had been vice president and account director for the West Coast at the Los Angeles office of FastBridge, part of Initiative Media, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. James Ward was named executive vice president and account director at Doner , Southfield, Mich. He had been senior vice president and group account director at McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: No. 80 Is Now No. 1 On Giants Fans' Backs
description: Once, the walkway from the training camp practice fields to the Giants' locker room was enveloped by a near solid line of fans wearing No. 31 Giants jerseys.

title: The Trial of Zacarias Moussaoui
description: Since the Sept. 11 attacks, the Bush administration has repeatedly tried to dodge the Constitution while prosecuting the war on terror. In the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, the so-called 20th hijacker, the Justice Department is once again attempting to trample the Bill of Rights -- in this case, by denying Mr. Moussaoui the right to see evidence critical to his defense. The judge should not allow the government to have its way.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COHEN, , ROSE
description: COHEN--Rose. My beloved grandma. I miss you and think of you every day. Frey

title: The poodle's core
description: He's charming, charismatic and eloquent. In the United States, Prime Minister Tony Blair is being celebrated as a loyal ally, but at home his star is sinking. For the first time in more than a decade, Blair's Labour Party is more popular than he is.

title: Madame Mao's Life As the Stuff of Opera
description: If opera buffs and critics keep coming here to the Santa Fe Opera each summer, it's not just because this adventurous company typically presents imaginative productions with strong casts in its one-of-a-kind auditorium: a roofed, open-air, 2,100-seat theater on an elevated site seven miles north of the city that offers mountain vistas from all sides.

title: Bush Addresses National Urban League in Pittsburgh
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 - President Bush campaigned for black votes in a politically crucial state today, traveling to Pittsburgh to sketch his visions of equality, prosperity and security in an address to the National Urban League.

title: 2 Senators Aim to Put Others On Record on Emissions Cap
description: Senators John McCain and Joseph I. Lieberman are planning to compel a vote on an effort to control global warming when the Senate takes up an energy bill this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUTTER, , ESTHER M.
description: GUTTER--Esther M. On July 25, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Robert Gutter. Dear sister of the late Hannah Hyatt. Services Monday, 1 PM, at Temple Israel, City of New York, 112 East 75th St. >>AD#

title: Israel to Free Many Militants and Lift Some Roadblocks
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's government reversed an earlier position and voted today to free Islamic militants, while the military lifted several roadblocks in the West Bank. The moves came just hours before Mr. Sharon flew to the United States, where he could face rare differences with President Bush on Middle East peacemaking.

title: J. Wilson Newman, 93, Ex-Chief Of Dun & Bradstreet Company
description: J. Wilson Newman, a former chairman and chief executive of Dun & Bradstreet, died on July 8 at the Morningside assisted-living center at University Village in Charlottesville, Va. He was 93.

title: Want to Vote? Answer This . . .
description: The effort to recall Gov. Gray Davis of California is like a runaway train, fueled by voter anger and political aspirations. But as we race toward the Oct. 7 election date, the public and the courts should take time to consider the major flaws of the process. If the recall vote goes ahead as planned, it will plow over the United States Constitution and the fundamental rights of voters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MESSINESI, , DESPINA (NEE PLAKIAS)
description: MESSINESI -- Despina (nee Plakias), of New York City and Millerton, NY, on July 22, 2003. At Vogue magazine, from 1941 until her retirement in 1993, she worked as a fashion writer and editor, as American Vogue's representative in Paris, immediately following WWII until the early 1950's, and as the magazine's travel editor for over 20 years. Survived by her nephew, Nick Plakias, cousin Dora Messare, sister-in-law Mrs. John Plakias, and loving friends. She will be deeply missed. A memorial service is planned for September. >>AD#

title: Washington Memo; Can a 'Wire Brush' Learn Civility?
description: The Capitol has always been a place of outsized egos and bare-knuckled politics. Yet even here, Representative Bill Thomas stands out.

title: After the Fact
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Gift for Gags
description: Bob Hope, the master of the one-liner who entertained troops from World War II to the Gulf War in 1990, died on Sunday less than two months after turning 100.

title: Sport Basks in Exciting Climate
description: With the temperatures here regularly in the 80's and occasionally in the 90's, it was already a fine week for swimming. Michael Phelps, Aleksandr Popov, Ian Thorpe, Hannah Stockbauer, Kosuke Kitajima and Grant Hackett took the hint, transforming the world swimming championships into one of the most extraordinary displays in the sport's history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREEFF, , EDWARD R.
description: GREEFF--Edward R., 93, of Mill Neck, NY, died peacefully at home on July 26 following a year-long heart illness. Survived by his wife of 62 years, Elizabeth D. Greeff, three stepchildren, Margaret G. Stanton of Quogue, NY, Elizabeth G. Donohue of Pittsburgh, PA and Clinton Gilbert, Jr. of Vero Beach, FL, 11 grandchildren, 18 great grandchildren, and four nieces and a nephew. A graduate in 1929 of (now) Choate Rosemary Hall. In lieu of college, he became a merchant seaman traveling the earth's oceans. In the 1930s, he joined Adams and Peck (members of NYSE) and became a partner. During WWII, he served as a naval officer in the South Pacific - commendated for skippering a sub-chaser. Before and after the war, he was a renowned international sailor and in 1950, recipient of the George W. Mixter Trophy as navigator of Argyll winner of the Bermuda Race that year. Owner of Puffin, a Sparkman and Stephens designed yawl. He raced and cruised European and Caribbean waters. For many years, he held the record for the most consecutive Bermuda Races sailed in, going back to 1926. He was a member of the NY Yacht Club, Cruising Club of America, Seawanhaka Yacht Club, Piping Rock Club, and several international yacht clubs. Donations in his memory may be made to Choate Rosemary Hall, 333 Christian St., Wallingford, CT 06492-3800 for the Edward R. Greeff '29 Fund for Economics and Private Enterprise. A celebration of his life for family and friends will be held at a later date. >>AD#

title: Lottery Numbers
Bob Hope, Master of One-Liners And Friend to G.I.'s, Dies at 100
description: Bob Hope, whose mastery of the comic monologue and the topical wisecrack carried him from vaudeville to Broadway musicals and then on to worldwide fame as a radio, film and television star of the first magnitude, died on Sunday at his home in Toluca Lake, Calif. He was 100.

title: Senators Assail Bush Aides for Lack of Data on Iraq's Future
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  Senators from both parties assailed two senior Bush administration officials today for failing to give even rough projections on the length, cost and troop levels for the postwar effort in Iraq.

title: Obesity: Who's to Blame?
description: To the Editor:

title: Moscow Journal; Young, Russian, and Rich -- for Now at Least
description: It is Saturday night and tan young people in designer clothing recline on richly upholstered couches in a chic new nightclub called Chocolate. Bentleys and Ferraris are parked outside. A French D.J. named Red is playing lounge music.

title: Pentagon Prepares A Futures Market On Terror Attacks
description: The Pentagon office that proposed spying electronically on Americans to monitor potential terrorists has a new experiment. It is an online futures trading market, disclosed today by critics, in which anonymous speculators would bet on forecasting terrorist attacks, assassinations and coups.

title: Astronomers Chart the Unseen Between the Stars
description: There is more than one way to see the universe, and some of them were featured this month in Sydney, Australia, where the world's astronomers gathered for the triennial meeting of the International Astronomical Union.

title: Janacek's Search For Art In Real Life
description: Opera is a marvelous conveyor of realistic human emotions, but it may not be the best vehicle for portraying realistic daily life. This hypothesis is certainly reinforced by Janacek's fourth opera, ''Osud'' (''Fate'').

title: Rights Group Reports Abuses by Afghans, Some Backed by U.S.
description: A human rights report has documented widespread extortion, armed robbery and kidnapping by police and intelligence officials and militias in Afghanistan. The report accuses the United States of supporting some of the worst offenders, and blames all countries for not doing enough to intervene and halt the abuses.

title: Preserving the Corbin Building
description: A new downtown district will arise at the bottom of Manhattan when the World Trade Center site is redeveloped. But that new section of New York must coexist with the very oldest part of the city. Whatever goes up at and around ground zero must fit into the broader context of Lower Manhattan. In a city that often seems to be overly enamored with the new, the redevelopment must respect the old. There is no better place to start than the Corbin Building at 11 John Street.

description: To the Editor:

title: All the World's a Stage? Let's Research That
description: IT is hard to know what to call it. It is not exactly theater and certainly not journalism. It is meant to be, in the director's words, ''an articulation of the time,'' but its subject matter is often obscure and remote from the swirl of daily events and world affairs. It is a form of expression, certainly, and it ends up on a stage, before sellout crowds, so perhaps theater will do until another word comes along.

title: Mets Lose The Battle Of Bad Records
description: The plea by the Shea Stadium scoreboard operator for fans to ''Get Loud'' was met with a murmur. The bar on the luxury suite level was empty during the seventh-inning stretch. Vendors clad in fluorescent tops stood out against the empty stands like lightning bugs.

title: More Music Yields More Words
description: If you want to improve the vocabulary of your children, sign them up for the orchestra, a study released yesterday suggests.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: $89 Million In Channel Contracts Awarded
description: About $89 million was awarded last week to dredging companies as part of a years-long project to scour New York harbor channels so that larger cargo ships, which sit lower in the water, can use them. The Army Corps of Engineers said it awarded $50 million to DonJon Inc. of Hillside, N.J., and $39 to a Massachusetts company, Jay Cashman Inc. The contracts total $1.1 billion so far out of the $3 billion projected cost of dredging the harbor channels down to 50 feet from about 35 feet. The Corps of Engineers estimates that the project can be completed as early as 2014. Tyrone Richardson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Pushed Into Moving Train
description: A subway platform argument turned violent yesterday when a man was pushed into the side of a Brooklyn-bound L train as it made its way into the Union Square station at 7:45 a.m. The police said the 28-year-old victim, whose identity was not released, fell back onto the platform after he was hit by the train, and was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center in stable condition, and later released. His assailant, a man thought to be in his late teens or early 20's, fled, and the police said there were no arrests as of last night. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Fliers Are Increasingly on Their Own for Food
description: With meal service becoming scarcer than knitting needles on flights of under three and a half hours, business travelers are being forced to take matters into their own hands. Some grab a slice of pizza or a burger and fries on their way to the gate, or just go hungry. But for discerning palates, more promising alternatives abound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAUMRITTER, , DOROTHY DOOB
description: BAUMRITTER -- Dorothy Doob. Distinguished professor of speech pathology at Hunter College, NYC, for thirty-six years, died peacefully. She was inducted into The Hall of Fame at Hunter College in 1975. She was involved in several organizations in the treatment and care of children and adults with cerebral palsy. She was a Founding Member of The Scholarship and Welfare Fund of The Alumni Association of Hunter College, where an award is presented to a student each year in the name of her loving husband of forty-five years, Louis Baumritter. After Dorothy's retirement, she continued private practice & taught poetry at West Palm Community College, FL, where she was also honored & admired by her students. >>AD#

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Democrats Nominate Chairman
description: The Democratic Party has announced its leadership team for the 2004 national convention in Boston, nominating Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, left, as its chairman. Alice A. Huffman, California State Conference of the N.A.A.C.P. president, has been appointed chairwoman of the convention committee. Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the minority leader, said that the nominations of Mr. Richardson, the convention's first Hispanic chairman, and Ms. Huffman, who is black, reflect the ''diversity of our party.'' Rod O'Connor, a former chief of staff for the Democratic National Convention, has been named chief executive of the convention, which will be held next July. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Bush Takes On Challenge of Trying to Woo Black Voters
description: President Bush sought today to address one of his greatest political challenges, his lack of support among black voters, telling the National Urban League's annual convention here that ''we will not tire until we have extended the great promise of America to every neighborhood in America.''

title: He Was Custer's Bugler. Then, the Subway Called.
description: The Cypress Hills National Cemetery in Brooklyn is the final resting place of several long-dead luminaries, among them a few Medal of Honor winners and a Fiji cannibal chief named Vendovi, who was said to have eaten up to a dozen American sailors before his capture.

title: NET INCOME AT CHESAPEAKE ENERGY MORE THAN TRIPLES
description: The Chesapeake Energy Corporation said yesterday that second-quarter net income more than tripled. Profit increased to $82.2 million, or 31 cents a share, after payment of preferred dividends, from $25 million, or 13 cents, a year earlier, Chesapeake said in a statement. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial projected a profit of 26 cents a share. Revenue more than doubled, to $429.6 million. Gas output in the quarter rose 55 percent, to 67.3 billion cubic feet. Gas and oil production will increase to the equivalent of 258 billion to 262 billion cubic feet this year from the 255 billion to 260 billion projected a month ago, the company said. Shares of Chesapeake fell 3 cents, to $9.51.

description: While drug companies are competing to be the first to market a second-generation of memory enhancer, supplement manufacturers are already promoting products they maintain can improve mental fitness, although evidence supporting such claims can be slim.

title: Residents Evacuated as Glacier Park Fire Approaches Homes
description: Residents of more than 400 homes near this gateway community to Glacier National Park were evacuated tonight as a wind-driven wildfire rounded a mountain and headed for their town.

title: A Suicide or a Lynching? Answers Sought in Florida
description: Dawn was just breaking over the sugar cane fields that surround this town when police responded to a 911 call. A young black man was dead, hanged on an umbrella tree in his grandmother's yard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRADFORD, , WILLIAM JOHN, JR.
description: BRADFORD--William John, Jr., a lifelong resident of Northport and Centerport, NY. Northport H.S. Class of 1941. Graduate of Brown University and the USMMA, Kings Point. Retired commander U.S. Navy, veteran WWII and Korea. Retired V.P. Chubb Insurance Co. Founding member of the Centerport Yacht Club. Loving husband of Jeannette (nee Frolli). Devoted father of Mary Jo Mugavin (Ronald), Judith Ann Bowlby (Roger), William John Bradford III (Debbie) and Jeannette Elizabeth Boccuzzi (Michael). Cherished Pop-Pop of Marybeth and Patrick Mugavin, Joseph and Timothy Bradford, and Erica Bowlby. Brother of Joann Brevik and the late Mary E. Bradford, MD. Reposing Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Ave., Northport, NY. Funeral Mass Thursday 10 AM at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Centerport, NY. Interment Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn. Donations to the American Cancer Society, in his memory, appreciated. Vi siting Wednesday 2-5 & 7-9 >>AD#

title: A campaign by the Sierra Club chides General Motors about the Hummer's gas mileage.
description: ROBERT LUTZ, the cigar-wielding vice chairman and product czar for General Motors, has said that G.M. needs to stir passion by making ''love them or hate them'' vehicles.

title: Photographing Celebrities, Even Those of an X-Rated World
description: In Timothy Greenfield-Sanders's studio, the ground floor in a former rectory on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, famous artists, novelists, actors and politicians come to be photographed. Toni Morrison, Brian Dennehy and James Watson each sat for a formal portrait recently, and Gore Vidal, Norman Mailer and Kurt Vonnegut were brought together for a surprisingly fraternal literary trifecta that appeared in Vanity Fair. And then there was Gina Lynn, who on a July afternoon also posed before Mr. Greenfield-Sanders's Deardorff camera.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Heir's Killer Jailed For Life
description: A court sentenced a man to life in prison for kidnapping and murdering Jakob von Metzler, the 11-year-old heir to one of Frankfurt's oldest banking families. The man, Magnus Gafgen, 28, confessed to abducting the boy on his way home from school last fall and suffocating him. He was arrested after collecting $1.15 million in ransom. The case stirred a debate in Germany after the police admitted they had threatened to beat Mr. Gafgen to learn the boy's whereabouts. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Power Shift Between Argentina and the I.M.F.
description: August promises to be an interesting month in Argentina: in a perceptible shift in the balance of power, a somewhat feisty Argentina will be meeting a less imperious International Monetary Fund to hammer out a new three-year accord.

title: France Raises $1.4 Billion in Sale of Renault Shares
description: Struggling to ease its strained finances, the French government today auctioned off a part of its stake in Renault, France's second-biggest automaker, raising 1.2 billion euros, or $1.4 billion.

description: BACK in the early 1980's, you could set your watch by the Birdman. He would show up in City Hall Plaza at 3:30 every weekday afternoon and stand on a plaque marking the spot where subway excavation began on March 24, 1900.

title: Road to Ubiquity
description: There was nothing Bob Hope loved more than an audience, and audiences responded in kind, particularly soldiers facing combat who desperately needed a laugh. He once chartered a yacht for a cruise in Canadian waters. It was one of the few formal vacations he ever took, and he found he could not stand the serenity. He cut the cruise short and returned to Hollywood with the comment, ''Fish don't applaud.''

title: 2ND-QUARTER EARNINGS INCREASED $24 MILLION AT INSURER
description: Humana Inc., the biggest operator of health plans for United States military families, said yesterday that profit rose 53 percent in the second quarter as it raised premiums and cut costs. Net income climbed to $69.3 million, or 43 cents a share, from $45.4 million, or 27 cents, a year earlier. Humana said it expected earnings to be as much as $1.42 a share for the year, better than its previous estimate of $1.31. Shares of Humana, based in Louisville, Ky., rose 85 cents, to $17.68. Excluding a one-time gain of $10.1 million from a venture capital investment, profit was $59.2 million, or 37 cents, which beat the 29-cent average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERN, , ELYSE WOLFF
description: STERN--Elyse Wolff, 82, died peacefully at her Hartsdale home on July 27, 2003. Born in Yonkers to Juliette and Joseph Wolff. She had two brothers, both deceased. She is survived by her adoring husband, whom she was married for 61 years, Henry Stern. She graduated from Robert Louis Stevenson High School and attended Hunter College. She worked as both bookkeeper and homemaker. She was a loving and beloved mother to Mary Ann Hollinger (deceased), Robert Stern and Elizabeth Guttag. She was a cherished grandmother of Lisa, Julie, Sam, Sarah, Barbara, Beverly and great grandmother to Beth and Katie. These Services celebrating her life will be held on Wednesday, July 30 at 11AM at the Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave, (Exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry. We will celebrate Elyse's wonderful life and all are welcome to share memories at that time, if so moved. In lieu of flowers, memorials in the name of Elyse Stern may be made to Seeing Eyes for the Blind or Memorial SloanKettering Hospital. Elyse's family will greet friends at a memorial gathering on Thursday from 4-7PM at the family home in Hartsdale. >>AD#

title: Vance Hartke, 84, Antiwar Senator From Indiana, Dies
description: Vance Hartke, a three-term Democratic senator from Indiana best known for his criticism of the American involvement in the wars in Southeast Asia, died on Sunday in Fairfax, Va. He was 84 and lived in Falls Church, Va.

title: Salt Water and Fresh
description: Q. What is the approximate ratio of fresh to salt water on earth? I would guess that the polar ice caps are a large reservoir of fresh water, but much smaller than the salt water in the oceans.

title: With Sun on Roof, More Yen in the Pocket
description: Yoshiko Takahashi is no environmental activist, but in the last year she has become an ardent fan of the solar panels that generate most of the electricity for her 1,100-square-foot home. Using solar power, which was included with the new house that she and her husband bought a little more than a year ago, has not only cut the family's electricity bill by 17 percent but also made her feel good about helping fight global warming.

title: Facing Facts About Saudi Arabia
description: Trying to get a clear fix on Saudi Arabia's connections to the Sept. 11 terror attacks has been a lot like navigating through a sandstorm. Nearly two years after the assaults on New York and Washington, Americans still do not know whether the heavy representation of Saudis on the four hijacking squads was an odd coincidence or a telltale sign of a deliberate effort by some circles in Saudi Arabia to support the plot. The answer may be knowable now, if both Washington and Riyadh are willing to take on the politically sensitive job of vigorously investigating the Saudi role.

title: Jury Deadlocked in California Videotaped Beating Case
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif., July 29  A mistrial was declared in the case of an Inglewood police officer who was videotaped in the beating of a 16-year-old, after a jury told Judge William Hollingsworth of Superior Court that it was deadlocked.

title: World Health Organization Seeks Eradication of Polio by 2005
description: GENEVA, July 29 — Preparing for the end of polio, the World Health Organization is focusing on learning where stocks of the virus exist and encouraging laboratories to tighten controls to prevent accidental release, officials said here today.

description: Residents of Lower Manhattan say the effort to rebuild downtown and the World Trade Center is moving in the right direction, and they are generally satisfied with the new design for the World Trade Center site, according to a poll by Pace University released yesterday.

description: Tyson Foods said yesterday that fiscal third-quarter profit fell 35 percent as declines in the chicken and prepared-foods businesses eroded improved results in beef and pork.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROGERS, HOFFMAN, , JANET
description: ROGERS - HOFFMAN -- Janet. It is with profound sadness, regret and sorrow that I, and all our relatives, acknowledge the loss of our beloved heroine on July 26. Throughout our 28 years of marriage my sweetheart was always my love, my partner, my confidant and my strength. Born and raised on Staten Island, Janet lived in Woodmere, LI, before relocating to Manhattan in 1991. Janet was a natural leader whose abilities were recognized by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, where she began her career as a clerk 35 years ago, and advanced to a senior management level, obtaining the position of Senior Vice President. A graduate of St. John's University, Janet also received an MBA from Adelphi. Janet loved and supported the arts and sports. Janet sang with the Russian Chamber Chorus of New York and served on its Board of Directors. Janet is survived by her loving husband, Oleg, cherished step-daughter Jeanette Salit, her brother Raymond Rogers, her sister Elaine Worobey and three nephews. Reposing Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave (70th St), NYC; 212-744-3084. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 10 AM, at the Church of St. Monica, 413 East 79th St, NYC. Interment Cemetery of the Russian Orthodox Convent, Spring Valley, NY. Donations may be made in her name to Citymeals-on-Wheels. >>AD#

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Gear Company Posts Loss
description: ASM International, Europe's second-largest semiconductor-equipment maker, said yesterday that its second-quarter loss narrowed to 6.2 million euros ($7.1 million) from 6.4 million euros in the year-earlier quarter. In an e-mail statement, the company, whose clients include Intel and Samsung Electronics, said its sales rose 8.7 percent to 153.1 million euros. The company, based in Bilthoven, the Netherlands, was expected to report a second-quarter loss of 3.6 million euros, according to the average forecast of 11 analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News.

title: New Details, Same Nixon
description: Richard Nixon has been faulted, fairly or unfairly, for almost everything that has gone wrong in American politics since World War II: the Red Scare, the Vietnam War, the shattering of trust in government, even wage and price controls. But on the question of whether he authorized the June 1972 break-in at Democratic Party headquarters in the Watergate complex, most historians have absolved him of blame.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: 2 Die In Bombay Bus Bomb
description: At least 2 people were killed and 31 were injured when a bomb exploded on a bus northeast of Bombay, the Press Trust of India reported. title: Israel to Continue Building Security Fence Criticized by Bush
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  Prime Minister Ariel Sharon promised today that Israel would continue to work for peace with its "Palestinian neighbors." But he again demanded an end to terrorism, and he insisted that Israel would continue to build a security fence that has become a source of irritation between the two sides.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Deportation For Terror Suspect's Family
description: Salma Al-Rushaid, the wife of Rabih Haddad, an Ann Arbor man accused of supporting terrorism, was ordered deported to Kuwait for overstaying her visa. Ms. Al-Rushaid and her four children, one of whom is an American citizen, were taken to Detroit Metropolitan Airport by federal agents, said Noel Saleh, Mr. Haddad's lawyer. Mr. Haddad, a Lebanese citizen, was deported to Lebanon two weeks ago. In 2001, Mr. Haddad was suspected of funneling money to Al Qaeda through an Islamic charity he helped found, the Global Relief Foundation. He was arrested in 2001 for violating his tourist visa. He was detained for 18 months, but he was not charged with any terrorism-related crime. Caitlin Nish (NYT)

It was flanked by a pair of police officers who stood as rigid as beefeaters in their dress uniforms and white gloves, with their shiny leather Sam Browne belts creaking diagonally across their chests. description: The Fair Isaac Corporation, whose software is used by credit card and mortgage companies to measure consumers' creditworthiness, said yesterday that it had bought Narex and that the purchase would reduce profit this quarter by 1 cent a share. Fair Isaac paid $10 million for Narex, the developer of the UniScore rating system. Narex, based in Golden, Colo., helps clients decide on the best debt collection method for its customers, Fair Isaac said. The programs of Fair Isaac, based in San Rafael, Calif., handle about a third of the country's creditcard applications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SELIS, , SARA NEUFELD
description: SELIS--Sara Neufeld, died peacefully at the age of 93 on Monday, July 28, 2003. An amazing and talented woman who, although totally blind, brought a world of light to countless others. An accomplished and devoted social worker, she was a tireless advocate for the rights of the visually impaired. With her late husband, Irving Selis, she founded the Associated Blind, an organization run by and for the blind. She worked alongside her husband to help him fulfill his life-long dream to design and build Selis Manor, a residence dedicated to allowing the blind to live selfsufficient, productive lives. Beloved sister of Ben and Thelma Neufeld; the late Philip and Margaret Neufeld; and the late Laura and Joseph Robbins. Cherished aunt of Mace Neufeld, Carol Heller, Benedict Robbins, Michael Robbins, Arlene Neufeld, Lawrence Neufeld and Elizabeth Neufeld. Services private. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: SELDEN: ONE DEAD IN HOUSE FIRE A Long Island man was discovered dead inside his burning house yesterday, the authorities said. Firefighters, responding to a report of fire at 441 Boyle Road in Selden, discovered the victim, Walter Ehrgott, 48, on the first floor. A passer-by, who noticed the smoke and flames shortly after 9 a.m., had alerted a basement tenant, who escaped unharmed. Investigators are trying to determine the cause of the fire, the police said. The Suffolk County medical examiner's office will perform an autopsy on Mr. Ehrgott to determine the cause of death.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Death Row Reprieve For DNA Testing
description: Gov. Frank L. O'Bannon stayed the execution of Darnell Williams, which had been scheduled for Aug. 1, so that DNA testing could be conducted. Federal and state courts had denied Mr. Williams's request for testing largely because there was other evidence linking him to two murders in 1986. But the trial prosecutor and former jurors say that he would not have been sentenced to death had jurors not been told that the victims' blood was on his clothes, suggesting that he participated in the robbery that led to the murders and shot the victims himself. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KHANI, , HELEN
description: KHANI--Helen, 78, of Manhattan. A beautiful, courageous fighter to the end, her family mourns her passing and celebrates her life. title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 'Do Not Call' List Challenged
description: The American Teleservices Association, a telemarketing trade group, has asked a federal court to overturn the Do Not Call registry -- a list of phone numbers that telemarketers can be fined for calling. The association filed on Friday for judicial review of the Federal Communications Commission regulations in the Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit, in Denver. The group asserts that the registry -- which is scheduled to go into effect on Oct. 1 -- unfairly creates two classes of speech; while telemarketers are not permitted to call people on the list, politicians and charities will be allowed to. In January, the association sued the Federal Trade Commission, which is working with the F.C.C. on the registry. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOPE, , BOB
description: HOPE--Bob. The Officers, Governors and Members of The New York Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their beloved member, Bob Hope. He helped us preserve the rich, theatrical roots of The Friars Club and his name belongs among the legendary and immortal Friars like Jack Benny, George Burns, Enrico Caruso, Cary Grant, Dean Martin, Ed Sullivan and Frank Sinatra, and like them he shared a legacy of commitment to the very best. We are honored and proud to have been touched by the legend that will always be Bob Hope. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Exec Dir

title: More Conservatives for the Courts
description: In a further effort to remake the federal courts in its own ideological image, last week the Bush administration proposed two more nominees for appellate judgeships whose views seem well to the right of the legal and political mainstream. One is a former assistant to Kenneth Starr, the other an African-American judge best known for a major ruling against affirmative action. With these choices, the White House is once again showing that it has no interest in selecting a judiciary whose views are broadly representative of the American public. The Senate should be prepared to reject either or both of them.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Zhone To Buy Tellium
description: The closely held communications-equipment maker Zhone Technologies agreed to buy Tellium, a maker of networking equipment, to compete in the high-speed networking industry, in a deal valued at about $180 million. Zhone shareholders will receive 60 percent of the combined company's stock, and shareholders of Tellium will receive the remaining 40 percent after the transaction closes, the companies said. The new company will be called Zhone Technologies and trade on the Nasdaq, Tellium said. Tellium laid off 130 workers, 41 percent of its work force, in January to cut costs as clients cut spending. Zhone's chairman and chief executive, Mory Ejabat, will hold those jobs in the combined company. Tellium, which is based in Oceanport, N.J., said yesterday that its second-quarter loss narrowed to $12.1 million, or 12 cents a share, from a loss of $213.8 million, or $1.98, in the period a year earlier. Zhone Technologies is based in Oakland, Calif.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Offensive Against Gay Marriage
description: Facing increasing legal recognition of gay marriage, the Vatican's orthodoxy watchdog, the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, plans to issue instructions to clergy and Catholic politicians on Thursday that it hopes will help stop the trend. The group's document, ''Considerations Regarding Proposals to Give Legal Recognition to Unions Between Homosexual Persons,'' comes after months of opposition by Pope John Paul II and high-ranking Vatican officials to legislative proposals in several countries supporting same-sex marriages. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: District Attorney To Seek Death Penalty
description: Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, left, announced yesterday that he would seek the death penalty for Larry Smith, a former paralegal who is accused of killing his pregnant fiance and her 6-year-old son in June 2002. Mr. Smith is charged with killing the woman, Melesha Francis, 26, and the boy, Michael Stultz, who, according to the prosecutors, drew Mr. Smith's fury by spilling a bottle of bubble-blowing liquid. Prosecutors charge that Mr. Smith strangled Ms. Francis with a belt and then held the boy's head under the water in a bathtub. It is the eighth time since New York's capital punishment law took effect in 1995 that Mr. Hynes has elected to seek the death penalty in a case. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hyundai Cuts Production
description: Intermittent strikes at Hyundai Motor, South Korea's dominant motor vehicle manufacturer, have resulted in production cuts in the company's overseas assembly plants. Jake Jang, a Hyundai Motor spokesman, said strikes cut production almost in half in China and reduced output in Russia, Malaysia, Pakistan and Egypt. Mr. Jang said the plant in China might have to suspend production next month after running out of engines and transmissions. Hyundai Motor's 39,000 workers have adopted a strategy of one-day and four-hour strikes while pressing for a five-day workweek rather than the current workweek of five and a half days. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: PROVIDIAN FINANCIAL REPORTS A 57% DROP IN EARNINGS
description: The Providian Financial Corporation, a credit card issuer, said yesterday that second-quarter net income dropped 57 percent and net revenue decreased 27 percent. Net income fell to $39 million, or 13 cents, from $89.9 million, or 53 cents, in the period a year earlier. The company, based in San Francisco, was expected to earn 10 cents, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Net revenue fell to $521.1 million from $718.3 million. Results include $8 million, or 3 cents a share, in costs for anticipated sales, as the company plans to sell $859 million in credit card loans in the next few weeks, Providian said. Its shares fell 14 cents, or 1.4 percent, to $9.80.

title: S.&P. RAISES LEAR'S CREDIT RATING TO INVESTMENT GRADE

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: 89 MILLION IN CHANNEL CONTRACTS AWARDED About $89 million was awarded last week to dredging companies as part of a years-long project to scour New York harbor channels so that larger cargo ships, which sit lower in the water, can use them. The Army Corps of Engineers said it awarded $50 million to DonJon Inc. of Hillside, N.J., and $39 to a Massachusetts company, Jay Cashman Inc. The contracts total $1.1 billion so far out of the $3 billion projected cost of dredging the harbor channels down to 50 feet from about 35 feet. The Corps of Engineers estimates that the project can be completed as early as 2014. Tyrone Richardson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Confidence Still Growing
description: German business confidence continued to rise in July, albeit to a lesser extent than expected. The Ifo Institute's survey, released yesterday, showed an increasingly optimistic outlook in all but the construction sector, which made the overall index rise for the third consecutive month from 88.8 points in June to 89.2, the highest level in a year. The index measuring the assessment of the current situation, however, fell by 0.7 to 78.7 points, slightly damping hopes for signals of an economic recovery. Petra Kappl (NYT)

description: Two officers of a heating and air-conditioning firm were accused yesterday of shortchanging workers' pay on $60,000 worth of projects for Nassau County. The projects included a police-helicopter hangar. The firm, Fred D. Singh & Sons of Medford, paid $10 to $15 an hour instead of legally required wages of $30 for sheet metal workers and $53 for steamfitters, said an assistant Nassau County district attorney, William Dempsey. Fred D. Singh, 69, of Medford, and Hansraj Seepersaud, 39, of Coram, pleaded not guilty in county district court to grand larceny charges. title: HOMEOWNER UNIT HELPS SAFECO INCREASE NET INCOME 6.4%
description: The Safeco Corporation, an insurer, said yesterday that second-quarter profit rose 6.4 percent as strong performances in its personal auto, homeowner and small commercial operations increased its earnings. The company, based in Seattle, reported net income of $111.9 million, or 81 cents a share, for the period, compared with $105.2 million, or 82 cents a share, a year earlier. Operating earnings, which exclude realized gains or losses, were $97.2 million, or 70 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected Safeco to earn 37 cents a share on an operating basis. Revenue rose 4 percent to $1.87 billion. Safeco shares rose 51 cents, or 1.4 percent, to $36.65.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Mentally Ill Man Sentenced To Prison
description: A man whom prosecutors describe as schizophrenic when he fatally stabbed his mother's girlfriend has been sentenced to 13 years in prison. After a two-day sentencing hearing that ended last week, Justice Robert J. Hanophy of State Supreme Court also requested that the defendant undergo psychiatric treatment. The man, Luis M. Perez, 21, of Ridgewood, suffered from the delusion that the victim, Juanita Hernandez, had sexually assaulted him, according to the Queens district attorney's office. In June, Mr. Perez pleaded guilty to manslaughter. A spokeswoman for the district attorney said that despite Mr. Perez's delusion, he was still criminally responsible because ''he did not lack substantial capacity to know that the conduct was wrong.'' Stacy Albin (NYT)

He said that disclosure of the deleted section, which centers on allegations about Saudi Arabia's role in financing the hijackings, would "would help the enemy," and compromise the administration's campaign against terror.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Poll Finds Support For Gay Marriage
description: A majority of New Jersey voters favor the legalization of same-sex marriage, according to an independent opinion poll commissioned by gay groups. A lawsuit by seven same-sex couples seeking to marry is currently awaiting decision in State Superior Court. The state is opposing the suit. The Zogby International poll of 803 likely voters in New Jersey was conducted July 15 to 19 and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3.6 percentage points. The poll, released yesterday, found that 55 percent of respondents favored gay marriage and 41 percent opposed it. Whites favor gay marriage by 56 percent to 40 percent, and Hispanics favor it 69 percent to 31 percent. But blacks oppose it 53 percent to 44 percent, as do Asian-Americans, 55 percent to 45 percent. The poll was commissioned by the New Jersey chapters of Parents, Families and Friends of Lesbians and Gays. Iver Peterson (NYT)
