Everybody's great.

title: A Top Saudi to Meet With Bush; 9/11 Report Is the Likely Topic
description: Saudi Arabia has sent its foreign minister to Washington to meet with President Bush on Tuesday, an administration official said tonight.

title: Yellow Pages Fund Rises 7.5% on First Day
description: Units of the Yellow Pages Income Fund, which invests in Canada's biggest phone-directories business, rose 7.5 percent yesterday on their first day of public trading.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: AFTERSHOCKS RATTLE NORTH Several tremors, including one measuring a strong 5.0, shook northern Miyagi Prefecture, about 190 miles north of Tokyo, the latest aftershocks from a series of more powerful earthquakes that left 500 injured over the weekend. About 2,500 people were set to spend a third night in makeshift shelters, and more people joined them after their previous shelter was damaged by the tremors. (Reuters)

title: US Airways Swings to Profit in Quarter
description: The US Airways Group, which exited bankruptcy proceedings in April, said yesterday that it had second-quarter net income of $13 million, helped by lower costs and a government payment for some security expenses.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Bees, Come Oon Down!

title: People
description: * Rob Palmer was named to the new post of executive creative director on the account of Cadillac at Chemistri, Troy, Mich., a division of the Publicis Groupe dedicated to working for the Cadillac, Pontiac and the service and parts units of General Motors. Mr. Palmer had been creative director at Wieden & Kennedy, Portland, Ore.

title: Profit Down at Vulcan
description: The Vulcan Materials Company , the largest American producer of building materials like gravel and crushed stone, said yesterday that second-quarter profit declined about 1.6 percent because of higher costs.

title: After Shooting, Happy to Be on Sideline
description: Terrence Kiel was in the wrong place at the wrong time, but he is not feeling sorry for himself.

title: A Sisterhood Channels the Inimitable Janis Joplin
description: Janis Joplin would have been 60 years old on Jan. 19, 2003, and on Sunday afternoon Central Park SummerStage celebrated this by bringing together two of her bands: Big Brother and the Holding Company and, performing for the first time in 30 years, the Kozmic Blues Band. They backed 17 widely assorted female singers in songs the bands used to perform with Joplin, along with some that she recorded with her last band, Full Tilt Boogie. The concert revealed Joplin's greatness by what was absent.

title: Priceline Plans $100 Million Note Sale
description: Priceline.com , an Internet seller of discount travel services, plans to raise as much as $100 million through the sale of seven-year convertible notes in the company's first debt issue.

title: An Eye Peril, Around the Neck
description: Go ahead, loosen that tie. You could be saving your vision.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: 2 Big Banks to Pay Fines To Settle an Enron Case

title: The Nets Are Close To Re-Signing Harris
description: The Nets are expected to sign backup guard Lucious Harris to a two-year contract this week, according to a member of the Nets organization.

title: If There's a Connection, There's a Handy Web Site
description: THANKS to the proliferation of wired and wireless Internet connections in hotels, airports and other public places, business travelers are spending more time than ever online while on the road. And more and more, they're trading tips on useful -- and mostly noncommercial -- Web sites to make traveling a bit easier.

title: MCI's Competitors Are Quick to Make Use of Federal Inquiry
description: MCI came under attack today from rival phone companies, which seized on the news that it is the focus of a criminal investigation. One competitor criticized MCI in bankruptcy court, another challenged its government business and a third made public letters suggesting that MCI's new management team had been aware for some time of the problems at the center of the inquiry.

title: Mets' Purge Continues As Royals Take Lloyd
description: Graeme Lloyd's locker was empty by the time most of the Mets had dressed and made their way onto the field at Shea Stadium yesterday afternoon. The nameplate had been switched to Cerda, the left-hander Jamie Cerda, who was up from the minor leagues earlier this season and now resumes his role as part of the Mets' youth movement.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: BG Net Income Increases
description: The oil and gas producer BG Group said yesterday that its second-quarter net income increased 191 percent, to 160 million ($260 million), as energy prices and production rose. BG said that it planned to put the increase back into additional investments and acquisitions, rather than a share buyback. These may include deals in Egypt, Iran and Bolivia. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Ex-City Official Is Mentally Ill, Defense Says
description: Lawyers for Russell A. Harding, the former president of the New York City Housing Development Corporation who has been indicted on charges of embezzlement, told a federal judge in Manhattan yesterday that he has a mental disorder that should influence the defense at his coming trial.

title: Jets' Linebackers Coach Likes What He Sees
description: In an era of quick turnovers that include athletes, coaches and owners, Bob Sutton is an anomaly on the Jets. Of the team's coaches, he is the only holdover from the Bill Parcells regime and he is in only his fourth season with the club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEUCHTWANGER, , HELEN HYMAN
description: FEUCHTWANGER -- Helen Hyman, born March 6, 1909. Died July 24, 2003 at 94 years young. Beloved wife of Sigmund Feuchtwanger, who predeceased her. Cousin, aunt, godmother and friend to a large and loving extended family. A native of New York and a graduate of Cornell University, Helen touched many lives with her independence, loyalty, zest for living and caring for those whom she loved. She will be remembered with great affection and love by her family and friends. >>AD#

title: U.S. Fights Verdict Backing Ex-P.O.W.'s
description: When 21 freed American P.O.W.'s returned home from the Persian Gulf war in March 1991, Dick Cheney, then secretary of defense, welcomed them at Andrews Air Force Base, Md.

title: Annan Is Said to Want New Prosecutor for Rwanda War Crimes
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan told the chief prosecutor for war crimes tribunals for Yugoslavia and Rwanda today that he would recommend that she be relieved of her Rwanda responsibilities when the Security Council voted on renewing her contract, a Council ambassador said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAURO, , JOSEPH MICHAEL
description: LAURO--Joseph Michael on July 27, 2003. Beloved husband of Anne P. Lauro (nee Cronin). Devoted father of Mark J. Lauro, Maryann and John SanFilippo. Dear son of Mary Lauro. Loving brother of Peter and Kathleen Lauro and Vincent Lauro. Devoted grandfather of Julia Elizabeth Lauro. Member of the New York Stock Exchange, Military Order of the Knights of Malta, Knights of the Holy Sepulchre and board Member Guiding Eye's for the Blind. Former Trustee of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Patrick-Brooklyn. Reposing Aievoli Funeral Home, 1275 65 St. (corner 13 Ave). Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10:30 A.M. Roman Catholic Church of St. Patrick (95 St. & 4 Ave Brooklyn). Interment Greenwood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Guiding Eyes for the Blind in Yorktown Heights, New York. >>AD#

title: Does Mercury Matter? Experts Debate the Big Fish Question
description: What to eat?

title: The Play's the Thing for Fassel and the Giants
description: These Giants can throw it, catch it and run it with flair, unlike past Giants teams that placed offense in the shadows and defense up front.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUR, , SAM
description: KUR--Sam. Of Springfield, NJ. Loving husband of Leone. Cherished father of Alan, Larry and Barbara Berger. Dear brother of Molly Russ. Loving grandfather of six. A treasure to all who knew him. Services Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Rd., Livingston NJ, Tuesday, noon. >>AD#

title: Theater in Review
description: A14-Year Old's Problems, But Just See Her Handle Them

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Moscow Demands Sudan Release Helicopter
description: Russia and the Sudan are embroiled in an escalating diplomatic dispute over the seizure last week of a civilian Russian helicopter in the Sudanese city of Al-Fashir. Russian officials have said the helicopter was flying to Congo under contract with the United Nations and bore its markings, but Sudan said it had ordered the helicopter to land and detained the 13 crew members and passengers on board because of suspicions it may have been aiding antigovernment rebels. Russia's Foreign Ministry summoned the chief Sudanese diplomat and in a sharply worded statement demanded the release of the helicopter, warning that the dispute would hurt relations between the countries. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: HYUNDAI CUTS PRODUCTION Intermittent strikes at Hyundai Motor, South Korea's dominant motor vehicle manufacturer, have resulted in production cuts in the company's overseas assembly plants. Jake Jang, a Hyundai Motor spokesman, said strikes cut production almost in half in China and reduced output in Russia, Malaysia, Pakistan and Egypt. Mr. Jang said the plant in China might have to suspend production next month after running out of engines and transmissions. Hyundai Motor's 39,000 workers have adopted a strategy of one-day and four-hour strikes while pressing for a five-day workweek rather than the current workweek of five and a half days. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: An Appreciation; Bob Hope's Legacy of Skill and Swagger
description: You need only watch the cable-television-staple classics of the 1980's like ''Caddyshack,'' with their damp-chinned, swampy streak of anarchy, to see the influence of Bob Hope. Maybe because Mr. Hope, too, was a golfer, and ''Caddyshack'' is set in the grubby world of a country club, one could imagine him teeing off during the middle of the Tet offensive as Joey Heatherton and Ann-Margret serpentined through rice paddies for cover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NELSON, , TREVOR
description: NELSON--Trevor. 34, died suddenly of complications from viral meningitis on July 24. A summa cum laude graduate of U.C. Berkeley, Trevor was a producer at ''60 Minutes,'' champion skier, runner and overall sports enthusiast. He seized every waking moment of his life with an exuberance that was lovely to behold. He is survived by his adoring and devoted wife, Maggie; young sons, Conrad and George; mother, Suzanne Colt; sisters, Andrea Abbott and Angela Colt; stepfather, Edward Colt. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM, August 4, at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th Street and 5th Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations in Trevor Nelson's name may be made to St. Bernard's School in New York City, The Central Park Conservancy, and The Trustees of the Reservation, Beverly, MA. >>AD#

title: 2 Banks Settle Accusations They Aided in Enron Fraud
description: After more than a year of criminal and regulatory investigations, the nation's two largest banks agreed yesterday to pay almost $300 million in fines and penalties to settle accusations that they aided Enron in misrepresenting its true financial condition for years before the company collapsed.

title: ENTERGY BLAMES COURT RULING FOR 15% DROP IN PROFIT
description: The Entergy Corporation, a utility owner, said yesterday that second-quarter net income fell 15 percent after a Texas court upheld a ruling barring the company from recovering some costs at the River Bend nuclear plant. Net income fell to $211.5 million, from $247.6 million a year earlier, the company said in a statement. Earnings fell to 89 cents a share from $1.06 after the payment of preferred dividends. Revenue rose 12 percent, to $2.35 billion, from $2.1 billion. Excluding costs related to the River Bend ruling, Entergy's earnings were unchanged from a year earlier. The court ruling on River Bend reduced earnings by $65.6 million, or 28 cents a share, Entergy said. Shares of the company, based in New Orleans, fell 31 cents, to $50.59.

title: Environmental Carnage
description: Three years ago, in a rare moment of harmony, a coalition of liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans in Congress approved what it hoped would be a guaranteed stream of revenue for a range of environmental purposes. The Conservation Trust Fund, as it was called, would increase spending in increments over six years, from $1.6 billion in 2001 to $2.4 billion in 2006, and would be used, among other things, to buy open space, protect endangered species and restore damaged coastlines and estuaries. No new taxes would be needed -- the program would rely on the same offshore oil royalties that had long underwritten federal land acquisition. President Bill Clinton eagerly signed on to what was hailed as the most important conservation bill in years.

title: To the French, 'E-Mail' Just Doesn't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: MEMO PAD
description: Starting March 1, members of the United Airlines Red Carpet Club and the Delta Air Lines Crown Room will lose access to each other's lounges.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Bank Profit Rises
description: Grupo Financiero BBVA-Bancomer, the Mexican unit of Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, said yesterday that second-quarter profit rose 26 percent as income from lending and fees increased and costs fell. Net income rose to 1.86 billion pesos ($178 million), or 20 centavos a share, from 1.48 billion, or 16 centavos, a year earlier, Bancomer, Mexico's largest bank, said. Profits from lending rose as Bancomer's portfolio of loans increased and the company paid less on demand and time deposits. Net interest income, before loan loss provisions, rose 10.2 percent, to 5.23 billion pesos.

title: INSIDE
description: Report Cites Afghan Abuses

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Selden: One Dead In House Fire
description: A Long Island man was discovered dead inside his burning house yesterday, the authorities said. Firefighters, responding to a report of fire at 441 Boyle Road in Selden, discovered the victim, Walter Ehrgott, 48, on the first floor. A passer-by, who noticed the smoke and flames shortly after 9 a.m., had alerted a basement tenant, who escaped unharmed. Investigators are trying to determine the cause of the fire, the police said. The Suffolk County medical examiner's office will perform an autopsy on Mr. Ehrgott to determine the cause of death. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Can you imagine if another country set up a betting parlor so that people could go in -- and is sponsored by the government itself -- people could go in and bet on the assassination of an American political figure?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MATTES, , JED
description: MATTES--Jed. The clients and colleagues of Jed Mattes mourn his death and extend our love and condolences to his family and many friends. We will remember him for his humor, courage, generosity and strength of character. Memorial donations in his honor will be welcomed at the Hetrick-Martin Institute for the Protection of Lesbian and Gay Youth and the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Fred Morris, Jed Mattes Inc. >>AD#

title: Partner of United Makes Plans to Start Low-Fare Service
description: Atlantic Coast Airlines Holdings, which flies commuter routes for bigger carriers, said yesterday that it planned to start a low-fare operation to make up for the expected loss of a United Airlines contract that provides most of its business.

title: Earnings at Northrop Rise 12% in Quarter
description: Northrop Grumman reported yesterday that its second-quarter net income rose more than 12 percent on sales of radar, missiles and satellites, and work on a new warship. The company raised its full-year earnings forecast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GALLAGHER, , EDWARD J.
description: GALLAGHER--Edward J., age 81, of Middletown, NJ, on July 28th, 2003. Beloved husband of Johanna Shortall Gallagher. Devoted father of Edward, Jr., Stephen, John, Matthew, Patricia Gallagher, Mary Gallagher, Elizabeth Gallagher, Kathryn Gallagher and the late Joanne Gallagher. Dear brother of Joseph Gallagher, Mary Ryder and Therese Brown. Grandfather of eight and great-grandfather of one. Funeral Friday at 8:30 AM, John F. Pfleger Funeral Home, 115 Tindall Rd., Middletown, NJ. Funeral liturgy will be offered at 9:30 AM at St. Mary's R.C. Church, New Monmouth. Interment Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Middletown. Visiting Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. >>AD#

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Pipelines To Be Developed
description: CNOOC Ltd. will spend as much as $700 million building pipelines and developing gas fields in the South China Sea to supply Macau and the southern city of Zhuhai by 2006, competing with the PetroChina Company to meet the country's gas demand. CNOOC, China's No. 3 oil and gas producer, plans to link three fields to supply Zhuhai and Macau with about 1 billion cubic meters of gas, about one-tenth of planned sales next year. The project may be linked to a 1,250-mile gas pipeline CNOOC's parent plans to build along China's southern and eastern coastal provinces, analysts said. ''This would help us develop a leading position in South China's natural gas market,'' Mark Qiu, CNOOC's chief financial officer, above, said at a news briefing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAVORI, , WILLIAM P.
description: LAVORI--William P. June 28th, 1921 to July 28th, 2003 in Yarmouthport, MA. Beloved husband of Mary E. Lavori. Father of Philip, Nora, Joseph and Angela Lavori, and Judith L. Keiser. Grandfather of Liana and Alex Sterling, William Keiser, Mary Marudas, and Daniel and Cathryn Lavori. Brother of Carmel McCarthy. Retired from the practice of dentistry on Staten Island, NY. Founding Director of the Staten Island University Hospital Dept of Dentistry. Graduate of CCNY and Columbia University School of Dental & Oral Surgery. A man of science, intelligence and principle, he was devoted to his family and took great pleasure in music and the natural world. ''Oh yes, the planet is sublime.'' (Pablo Neruda, Odes to Common Things). Donations in his memory may be made to the Yarmouth Conservation Trust, P.O. Box 376, Yarmouthport, MA. 02675. >>AD#

title: A Keeper of Secrets Now Opens Up About Iraq's Dead
description: A former Iraqi intelligence officer, Sabi al-Hamed made a career of keeping quiet. Now he wants to talk, and it is the dead he talks about.

title: All Those Beethovens Whose Facets Delight
description: LATE BEETHOVEN

title: You Say Tomato
description: Two leaders politicized intelligence to sell a war. But while one has suffered a catastrophic loss of public trust, the other hasn't, at least not yet.

title: Security Council Beefs Up Force In Congo and Broadens Mandate
description: After weeks of anxious negotiations, the Security Council adopted a resolution today extending the United Nations mission in Congo for a year while stiffening its mandate and strengthening the force to 10,800 troops from 8,700.

title: Airlines Coveting Baghdad, If Airport Can Be Made Safe
description: While airlines are severely cutting service to cities in this time of industry crisis, many are jockeying to begin flights to one of the world's more unlikely destinations: Baghdad.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Settlement Helps Adaptec Profit
description: Adaptec, which makes circuit cards that speed the connections between computers, said yesterday that fiscal first-quarter profit surged because of a one-time gain from a legal settlement. Net income in the quarter ended June 30 rose to $40.8 million, or 33 cents a share, from $2.6 million, or 2 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Sales at the company, which is based in Milpitas, Calif., fell to $107.3 million from $107.9 million. The results included an after-tax gain of $49.3 million from a May settlement with the former president of the Distributed Processing Technology Corporation, a company Adaptec acquired in 1999. Excluding the gain, profit would have been $3.6 million, or 3 cents a share, from $8.4 million, or 8 cents, a year ago, the company said.

title: I.B.M. WINS CONTRACT TO RUN ABB'S INFORMATION SYSTEMS
description: I.B.M. has won a 10-year contract worth $1.1 billion to manage the systems of ABB Ltd., Europe's largest electrical engineering company. I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., will manage 90 percent of ABB's systems and will take on more than 1,200 of its employees, ABB said in a statement yesterday. ABB, based in Zurich, will also report its earnings today. I.B.M. will operate ABB's information systems in 14 countries in Europe and North America. Shares of I.B.M. fell $1.01, to $82.54.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENNETT, , HAROLD
description: BENNETT -- Harold. The American Bible Society mourns the passing of the Rev. Dr. Harold C. Bennett, Vice Chairman of the American Bible Society Board of Trustees. He served on the Board since 1980. Dr. Bennett had a long and illustrious ministry with the Southern Baptist Convention including service as one of the Vice Presidents of the Baptist World Alliance. The Society extends its condolences to Dr. Bennett's wife, Phyllis, of Brentwood, TN, and sons, Jeffrey Clark Bennett and John Scott Bennett and daughter, Cynthia Ann (Bennett) Howard. His love and enthusiasm for the Bible cause was inspirational. He will be missed. >>AD#

title: Delicious and Nutritious
description: To the Editor:

title: Contemplating Last Things At a Musical Summer Home
description: Leave-takings from this earth leave options for composers. Gabriel Faur's Requiem chooses to die exquisitely, threatening sentimentality at every measure but drawing back to its full and upright position whenever it approaches. Hector Berlioz's ''Romeo and Juliet'' represents any dying hero's one last bid for attention: theatrical, eccentric, large in gesture and very beautiful in its public way.

title: Obesity: Who's to Blame?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sea-nic Perspective
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Angolans Come Home
description: Since the end of the civil war, more than a million refugees have returned to Angola, a country physically, politically and economically in ruins.

title: Foreign, but in English
description: To the Editor:

title: Ridgewood Pitcher Excels In the Field and at the Plate
description: Ridgewood avoided elimination again and made it to the final of the New Jersey State Little League championships tonight.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''What we are telling the returnees is, 'Look, you are not returning to the land of milk and honey. But it is your home and it is good to go back. So roll up your sleeves, get to work and help rebuild your country.'''

title: Snow Says U.S. Will Encourage China to Widen Currency Range
description: The Bush administration plans to use quiet diplomacy to encourage the Chinese government to allow its currency to strengthen by widening its trading band against the dollar, Treasury Secretary John W. Snow said yesterday.

title: Thai Vice King's Lament: Police Don't Stay Bought
description: The sheer injustice. Nobody had worked harder to pay off the police with wine, women, wristwatches and sacks full of cash. And now this.

title: Cocktails to Make You See Triple
description: Now that the Bright Food Shop at 216 Eighth Avenue (21st Street) in Chelsea has a new six-foot bar, it has expanded its beverage list to include what its owners, Dona Abramson and Stuart Tarabour, call three-course cocktails. Each offers three distinct tastes.

title: Oceans of Greens Offer a Wave Of Local Flavors
description: IN July and August, New York cooks go salad mad. Restaurant chefs treat their kitchens like tiny outposts of California (where a new $45 salad, spiked with beluga, foie gras and white asparagus, is selling briskly at Restaurant Jaan in Beverly Hills) and compose mighty salads in the keys of nioise, Caesar, panzanella and cobb.

title: Corrections
description: Aseries of annotated maps of Iraq on Sunday showing, by the month, where American troops have died since the end of the war, misstated the number of soldiers killed during July. There were 38 fatalities as of July 26, not 35.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: J.F.K.'S Boxers
description: A Dublin tailor, Louis Copeland, left, is displaying a pair of boxer shorts that belonged to John F. Kennedy in the window of his Capel Street shop. The Navy-issue boxers, with a ''Jack Kennedy'' label stitched into the waistband, were worn by Kennedy in World War II. An Irish businessman, Paul Allen, bought the underwear for $5,000 in an online auction this month, along with one of Kennedy's dress shirts, which is also on display. The clothing can be viewed for three more days before the items are shipped to the John F. Kennedy Library and Museum in Boston. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: The 'Other' Tanglewood Churns With Electricity
description: Ah, Tanglewood. It was a classic scene on a Sunday afternoon in July at this bucolic summer home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Picnic-toting families streamed onto the verdant grounds and set up their portable feasts; other listeners ambled into the open-air Koussevitzky Music Shed to take their seats as birds chirped away; and before long, the comforting strains of Weber and Mozart symphonies were emanating from the stage and out over the lawn.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Alcatel Reports Operating Profit
description: Profiting from intense cost-cutting, the big French maker of telecommunications equipment Alcatel reported an operating profit of 21 million euros, or $24.1 million, for the second quarter, and forecast it would break even at the operating level in the current quarter and for the full year. Alcatel's chief executive, Serge Tchuruk, attributed the improved results to declining costs. Alcatel posted a net loss of 675 million euros, or 0.56 euro a share, compared with a loss of 1.44 billion euros, or 1.21 euros a share, in the period last year, on a slight rise in revenue to 3.15 billion euros, from 3.14 billion euros last year. Shares of Alcatel rose more than 6 percent, to 8.29 euros. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Banking Giants Further Tangle The Enron Cases
description: After agreeing to pay nearly $300 million to settle accusations that they helped Enron defraud investors, J. P. Morgan Chase and Citigroup face new hurdles to recover money they lent to the company and to reach a favorable settlement with its shareholders.

title: A Perfect Change-Up: Bluefish, Sausage and Clams
description: WHEREVER Chris Schlesinger goes, padding barefoot around his beachfront property here, there is fire. Everywhere is the scent of burning oak and the shimmery sight of heat rising from a grill. He might be preparing food. He might simply be getting rid of some old chairs, sending them to carbon in a whoosh of burning gasoline. At his restaurant, the East Coast Grill, in Cambridge, Mass., fire is as important a part of his cooking as the ingredients themselves. It is his friend and his playmate. He likes to burn.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Sunday about the former Boston Red Sox star Jim Rice and his absence from the Baseball Hall of Fame misstated Jack Lang's status with the Baseball Writers Association of America. Lang, who is a Hall of Fame voter but has never voted for Rice, is not the current executive secretary; he retired from the job in 1994.

title: New Jersey Bars a Coroner Fired by New York City in '87
description: Dr. Elliot Gross, the medical examiner for Cumberland and Cape May Counties who was fired as New York City's chief medical examiner 16 years ago, has been banned from conducting autopsies in New Jersey after state officials found him incompetent to do so.

title: Senate Report Says Enron Used Government Funds for Payments
description: The Enron Corporation used money from the World Bank and the United States government to make at least $17 million in questionable payments to a group of Guatemalan businessmen who helped win approval for a power plant in Latin America, a Senate investigation has found.

title: Blanket of Dread
description: There is no more delightful way to pass a summer's day in Washington than going up to Capitol Hill to watch senators jump ugly on Wolfie.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Vice Chairman at Merrill Abruptly Decides to Retire

title: Pursuing Hussein, U.S. Captures 175 In Dozens of Raids
description: American soldiers conducted dozens of raids and seized more than 175 suspected loyalists of Saddam Hussein today here in his hometown in what military leaders called an accelerating drive to flush him out of hiding.

title: Prosecutors Prepare to Indict Brooklyn Judge in Bribery
description: Brooklyn prosecutors have decided to file new charges of bribe-taking against Justice Gerald P. Garson, a matrimonial judge already accused of accepting gifts from a lawyer in return for preferential treatment, lawyers and others involved in the case said yesterday.

title: President Urges Compromise on Medicare Prescription Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  President Bush marked the 38th anniversary of the Medicare program today, using the occasion to prod lawmakers to resolve their differences and enact a prescription-drug program.

title: Adding a Sexy Spring To Levitate 'Bounce'
description: The director Hal Prince is fond of saying that his first response to the new musical now known as ''Bounce'' was that there wasn't enough sex in it. Now that he's added Michele Pawk to the cast, he said, there is.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Big Profit For Net Company
description: NetEase.com, one of China's biggest Internet companies, posted a record quarterly profit of $9.2 million based on revenue growth from wireless services and online advertising. The company announced that while its core online game business was flat because of the epidemic of severe acute respiratory syndrome, which led to the closings of many Internet bars where its games are played, SARS had no significant impact on advertising and wireless services. Chris Buckley (NYT)

title: EARNINGS AT DUPONT RISE 24% ON STRONG SALES
description: DuPont said yesterday that profit rose 24 percent in the second quarter as sales of farm chemicals and seeds surged. The chief executive, Charles O. Holliday Jr., is focusing on faster-growing products as he prepares to sell or spin off DuPont's nylon, polyester and Lycra businesses later this year. Sales of agricultural products climbed 21 percent. Second-quarter net income climbed to $675 million, or 67 cents a share, from $543 million, or 54 cents, a year earlier, DuPont said. Revenue increased 12 percent, to $7.52 billion from $6.73 billion. The decline in the value of the dollar and a lower tax rate helped results as well, DuPont said. Shares of DuPont fell 42 cents, to $43.97.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Kidnapped Tourist Reported Dead
description: A German woman held hostage in the Sahara desert for almost five months with 14 other European tourists has died, German television said. According to the state-owned ARD network, the woman, who was not named, died of heatstroke and was probably buried by the kidnappers, believed to be Islamic militants from Algeria. According to the report, relatives of the woman, described as the mother of two, were notified of her death by the German Foreign Ministry. Algerian and European media recently reported that the hostages, who now include 9 Germans, 4 Swiss and one Dutchman, had been taken over the border from Algeria to Mali. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Farmed Salmon Is Said to Contain High PCB Levels
description: AMERICANS consume so much salmon these days -- most of it farmed -- that it is now the third most popular fish in the country, after canned tuna and shrimp. It is one of those foods that nutritionists say is good for you, and the Food and Drug Administration says you can eat as much of it as you like.

title: Tex McCrary Dies at 92; Public Relations Man Who Helped Create Talk-Show Format
description: Tex McCrary, a legendary New York public relations man and political strategist who with his wife, the actress and model Jinx Falkenburg, helped create and popularize the talk-show format on radio and television in the 1940's and 50's, died yesterday in Manhattan. He was 92 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Russia Finds No Corner Is Safe From Chechnya's War
description: The village of Tolstopaltsevo lies in the wooded outskirts of the capital, a humble, in places dilapidated cluster of wooden houses known as dachas, where Russians go to escape Moscow's urban jostle.

title: Please, Pile On the Problems? This Has to Be Math Camp
description: WHEN Dr. Max Warshauer puts together his high-powered math camp for top high school students each summer, he selects several campers with perfect 1600 SAT's. ''We turned away a 1570 SAT this year, because there were three stronger students at the same high school,'' Dr. Warshauer said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEYAND, , RON
description: WEYAND--Ron. A New York character actor whose professional career spanned over 45 years, died Thursday, July 17, 2003, from Lou Gehrig's Disease. He was a professor of drama at Marymount College in Tarrytown from 1958 until his retirement in 1999. He is survived by his wife of 47 years, Jacqueline, three children, Mercia, Naomi and Damian, three grandchildren, Harrison, Emily and Natalie and his brother, Paul. >>AD#

title: BEAR STEARNS SELLS 6 MILLION SHARES IN AROPOSTALE
description: Bear Stearns sold six million shares in Aropostale Inc. yesterday, lifting its merchant banking fund's profit from Aropostale to more than $300 million. Bear Stearns; Aropostale's chief executive, Julian Geiger; its president, John Mills; and others sold 7.15 million shares at $25 each, a 4 percent discount to the stock's closing price of $26.05 on Monday. Bear Stearns still holds 5.7 million shares in Aropostale, or just under 16 percent of the company, after its latest sale, said Bodil Arlander, a senior managing director at Bear Stearns. It bought a majority stake in Aropostale, which sells clothes for teenagers, in August 1998 from Federated Department Stores Inc.

title: 'Burnout' Is Started to Fight Montana Fire
description: Dropping flammable plastic balls from helicopters and using gas and diesel torches on the ground, firefighters here started a 5,000-acre burnout of thickly forested land in Glacier National Park in a last-ditch effort to keep the nearly 13,000-acre Robert Fire from burning hundreds of homes and businesses.

description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer abruptly withdrew its $11.5 billion cash offer for the entertainment businesses of Vivendi Universal yesterday, contending that the asking price was too high.

description: Senators from the tobacco-producing states and a leading opponent of smoking are negotiating on a compromise that would provide a federal bailout for tobacco growers in exchange for government regulation of tobacco products.

description: Chefs often keep a collection of squeeze bottles on hand to add a touch of chili paste or decorate a plate with another tasty and frivolous accent. Now Terrapin Ridge, which makes an assortment of mustard-like condiments, including hot wasabi and honey-lavender, has introduced five flavors in squeeze bottles for the home cook.

title: Company Says It Mapped Part of SARS Virus
description: A small biotechnology company is expected to announce today that it has determined the three-dimensional structure of a crucial enzyme in the virus that causes SARS, an accomplishment that could accelerate efforts to develop treatments for the deadly respiratory disease.

title: Poindexter's Follies
description: The time has obviously come to send John Poindexter packing and to shut down the wacky espionage operation he runs at the Pentagon. The latest idea hatched by Mr. Poindexter's shop -- an online futures trading market where speculators could bet on the probabilities of terrorist attacks, assassinations and coups -- was canceled yesterday by embarrassed Pentagon officials. The next logical step is to fire Mr. Poindexter.

title: At McDonald's, Profit Falls but Hope Rises
description: The McDonald's Corporation reported a 5 percent decline in second-quarter profit yesterday, largely because of one-time expenses like advertising, promotions and real estate expenditures that are a part of the company's turnaround strategy.

title: Bush Looking for Means to Prevent Gay Marriage in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  President Bush said today that federal government lawyers are working on legislation that would define marriage as a union between a man and woman.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Freed Inmate To Get $1.5 Million
description: Chicago has agreed to pay a $1.5 million settlement to a man who spent 15 years in prison for a rape and killing he did not commit. The man, Calvin Ollins, who was a 14-year-old special education student when he was charged in 1986, was exonerated in 2001 based on DNA evidence. He and three others convicted in the killing were pardoned in 2002 by Gov. George Ryan. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: B.Y.O.B., Hungry Restaurateurs Say
description: RESTAURANTS with big investments in wine do not normally encourage customers to carry in their own. To discourage them, they charge a fee called corkage -- as much as $75 a bottle in some places, ostensibly for just pulling the cork.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Connecticut; Signs of New Life in Industrial Leasing
description: While the market for office space in the Hartford area is showing few signs of life, demand for industrial space in greater Hartford is remaining surprisingly steady, and is even picking up speed west and north of the city, local officials and real estate executives say.

title: Slain Councilman Mourned As a Crusader Without Fear
description: City Councilman James E. Davis was remembered yesterday by a wide cast of New York's political figures as a crusader against violence who did not hesitate to fight the political establishment.

title: WILLIAMS TO SETTLE CHARGES OF INDEX MANIPULATION
description: The Williams Companies, an operator of natural gas pipelines, will pay a $20 million civil penalty to settle accusations it tried to manipulate natural gas price indexes, federal regulators said yesterday. From January 2000 through June 2002, the Williams Companies and a subsidiary, Williams Energy Marketing and Trading, reported false natural gas trading information to companies that compile price indexes, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said. The purpose was to ''skew the indexes for respondents' financial benefit,'' it said. The Williams Companies and Williams Energy did not admit any wrongdoing, the commission said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Telefnica Posts A Profit
description: Telefnica, Spain's largest telephone company, posted a profit in the second quarter as it reduced operating expenses and benefited from growth in the wireless division. Net income was 882.2 million euros ($1 billion), in contrast to a loss of 5.7 billion euros in the year-ago period, the company said in a regulatory statement. Sales at the former monopoly fell 1.6 percent, to 7.1 billion euros, the sixth consecutive quarterly decline year on year. The company's chairman, Csar Alierta, above, is increasing dividends to attract investors as growth from fixed-line phone services stalls. Telefnica is raising its 2003 dividend 60 percent. To afford the payouts, Mr. Alierta is cutting costs, by among other things, reducing the domestic unit's work force by 15,000.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Death Penalty Changes
description: Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich supports all but one of the changes the Legislature plans to make to the state's death penalty laws. He supports a ban on the execution of the mentally retarded and 11 other changes that would make it a death penalty conviction more difficult, but he objected to a provision that would have allowed police officers accused of perjury to be suspended without pay regardless of the merits of the accusation. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: DEATH PENALTY CHANGES Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich supports all but one of the changes the Legislature plans to make to the state's death penalty laws. title: Columbia, in a Growth Spurt, Is Buying a Swath of Harlem
description: Columbia University, long starved for land at its campus in Morningside Heights, is buying up a 17-acre swath in West Harlem for its first major expansion in 75 years.

title: A Fallible Prostate Cancer Test
description: It seems hard to believe, but a widely used screening test for prostate cancer in men is probably missing a vast majority of tumors. An analysis published in The New England Journal of Medicine estimates that the test -- known as the P.S.A. test -- probably misses more than 80 percent of the cancers in men younger than 60 and almost two-thirds of the cancers in older men. This must come as a shock to great numbers of Americans who have been assuming, incorrectly, that the test is highly accurate. It has been administered to some 75 percent of all American men who are 50 or older.

description: The BP Group said that second-quarter profit rose 42 percent to $3.12 billion, lifted by rising oil prices. For the first half of the year, profits were up 81 percent, to $6.84 billion. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Corrections

While the Illinois budget calls for its sale by June 30, 2004, and the revenue to be used to help balance the budget, the building has not been sold yet.

title: CERBERUS DROPS OUT OF CLAYTON HOMES BIDDING
description: Shares of Clayton Homes dropped after an investor group led by Cerberus Capital Management declined to challenge Warren E. Buffett's $1.7 billion offer for the company. Clayton said late Monday night that it had received a letter from Cerberus saying it no longer had an interest in bidding. The decision by Cerberus comes as Clayton shareholders are set to vote today on the management-backed offer of $12.50 a share from Berkshire Hathaway Inc., which Mr. Buffett controls. Shares in Clayton fell 86 cents, to $12.54. The stock has traded above the Buffett offer since May 30 on speculation the company, based near Knoxville, Tenn., may attract a higher price. The company, which has 20 plants and 86 manufactured-housing communities, is 28-percent owned by the Clayton family.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Nine Accused Of Smuggling Ecstasy
description: Nine New Jerseyans, including a police officer, were indicted in Federal District Court yesterday on charges of conspiring to smuggle hundreds of thousands of Ecstasy tablets from Europe into Newark Liberty International Airport. The authorities did not say how much of the drug reached the United States. Eight of the defendants concealed money under their clothes and flew to the Netherlands to buy the drugs, the authorities said, and returning couriers would hide the drugs under their clothes. The authorities identified the ringleader as Christopher Rea, 35, of West New York. The eight others, including Brian Cohen, now a Maplewood police officer, are accused of acting as couriers for Mr. Rea. The authorities said Officer Cohen was not a police officer at the time. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Sierra Leone Warlord Dies in Custody of War Crimes Court
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, July 30  Foday Sankoh, the warlord from Sierra Leone who made mutilations his signature weapon of war and came to symbolize the face of deranged cruelty, died Tuesday night in the custody of a United Nations-backed war crimes tribunal, officials of the court announced today.

title: World Business Briefiing: Asia
description: CHINA: BIG PROFIT FOR NET COMPANY NetEase.com, one of China's biggest Internet companies, posted a record quarterly profit of $9.2 million based on revenue growth from wireless services and online advertising. The company announced that while its core online game business was flat because of the epidemic of severe acute respiratory syndrome, which led to the closings of many Internet bars where its games are played, SARS had no significant impact on advertising and wireless services. Chris Buckley (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: More Farms Online
description: Nearly half of the two million farms in the United States are connected to the Internet, more than triple the number in 1997, according to a survey from the Agriculture Department. The survey, based on responses from more than 26,000 farmers nationwide, found that 54 percent of farmers own or rent computers. About 48 percent of the farms have Internet access, the report said, an increase from 13 percent in 1997. Agriculture officials said 43 percent of farmers were online in 2001. The department's survey is conducted every two years. The rapid growth of broadband Internet service has contributed to improved access among farmers, officials said. President Bush signed a farm bill last year that included $100 million over six years for investment in broadband service in rural areas.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Tobacco Firms Must Finance Programs

title: Proof of What They Say About Small Packages
description: IN the years since Chelsea Market opened in 1997, it has quietly become a model urban mini-mall, providing retail and office space along with more than half a dozen places to eat. Yet unlike some other attempts to create sheltered shopping environments in Manhattan, Chelsea Market does not feel parachuted in from the Land of a Thousand Chain Stores. Its vitality and sometimes bumptious energy reflect its neighborhood.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Burned Woman Dies; Man Charged
description: A Queens woman who was set on fire by her boyfriend on July 18 died yesterday at Jacobi Medical Center, officials said, and the boyfriend was charged with second-degree murder. The woman, Bae Mi Ran, 41, suffered third-degree burns over 50 percent of her body when her boyfriend, Jo Sung Chul, 44, who shared an apartment with her in Jackson Heights, doused her with gasoline on a street corner. The police say Mr. Jo set her on fire with a cigarette lighter, poured gasoline on himself, then grabbed her in a bear hug. He was also burned and remained in critical condition at New York-Cornell Medical Center. Neighbors of the couple said they had argued frequently, with Ms. Bae complaining about Mr. Jo's drinking and Mr. Jo saying Ms. Bae had another boyfriend. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Museums Defend Fudge Factor

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hauppauge: 12 Face Pornography Charges
description: Twelve people have been indicted on charges of using a popular file-sharing program to download child pornography from the Internet, the Suffolk County district attorney's office said yesterday. The suspects, who range in age from 16 to 38 and did not know one another, were using the file-sharing software KaZaA to download images from other KaZaA users, officials said. They were charged with possession of child pornography, punishable by up to four years in prison, and promoting pornography, which carries a term of two and a third to seven years. The defendants pleaded not guilty at their arraignments in Suffolk County Court. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Body In a Suitcase Identified
description: A dismembered body found in a suitcase on a Chinatown street last month was identified yesterday as that of an unemployed cook who had lived in Queens, the police said. The cook, Yang Jun Zhang, 46, had been decapitated and his legs had been cut off, the police said. His body was stuffed into a large black suitcase. Mr. Yang came from Liaoning Province in China, according to Ken Fan, 29, whose family rented a room in their home on 41st Road in Flushing, Queens, to Mr. Yang. The suitcase containing the body was discovered at 2 a.m. on June 30 by homeless men at the corner of Forsyth Street and East Broadway.

description: Two Iranians have been detained here on suspicion of security violations, an official with the Coalition Provisional Authority said today. The two were arrested in early July, and were posing as journalists, the official said.
