title: Southern Classics, Dressed for the Big City
description: THE Cajun craze that Paul Prudhomme started nearly 20 years ago had unfortunate results. It redrew the map of southern cooking, making Louisiana look twice as big as Alabama, Mississippi and the Carolinas put together. It also created the completely false impression that New Orleans is Cajun, but that's another story. The principal damage, besides nearly exterminating the redfish, was to marginalize the great, mainstream tradition of southern cooking.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 21 Nigerians Held In Murder Inquiry
description: Police officers investigating the murder of a boy whose limbless and headless body was found floating in the Thames arrested 21 people from Nigeria in raids across London and said they believed that they had smashed a ring suspected of smuggling African youths into Britain to be passed to adults posing as their parents and claiming bogus child payments. The police suspect that the boy, whose torso was recovered in September 2001 near Tower Bridge, was a victim of ritual killing after being brought to London from Nigeria. An autopsy showed he had swallowed a potion of ground bones, and among the items found by police in the raids was the skull of an animal wrapped in gauzy material with a nail driven through it. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Indonesia Ready to Free Itself of I.M.F.
description: No image has captured the troubled relationship between Indonesia and the International Monetary Fund better than a photograph taken in early 1998 of former President Suharto signing a package of austerity measures. Michel Camdessus, then the fund's managing director, stands over him, arms folded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSEN, , ALICE
description: ROSEN--Alice. The Board of Trustees and Administration of Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center express great sorrow on the passing of Alice Rosen, beloved aunt of Dorothy Schachne, wife of David I. Schachne, esteemed Board of Trustees Treasurer and Chairman of the Executive Committee. We extend our profound and heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Alvin I. Kahn, M.D., FACP, Chairman, Board of Trustees David P. Rosen President and CEO >>AD#

title: Nurturing a Fragile Mideast Peace
description: It has been eight weeks since President Bush traveled to the Middle East and breathed new life into a moribund peace effort between Israelis and Palestinians. Although no breakthroughs have yet been achieved, words and deeds on both sides have been encouraging. For progress to continue, Mr. Bush will have to remain closely engaged with Israeli and Palestinian leaders.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   STAPLETON, , RIKKI
description: STAPLETON--Rikki. We wish to thank all of Rikki's friends and family especially Ken, Diane and Bob Kerrigan who offered their help and support during this time of our great sorrow. Her mother, Eloise Edwards >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: New Charges For Ex-Official
description: Anthony Serra, a former city correction official who was charged in February with using prison guards to do work on his home in Mahopac, was named yesterday in a new and broader 144-count indictment. The new charges against Mr. Serra, a former three-star bureau chief with authority over the jails at Rikers Island, involve the remodeling of his bathroom and kitchen, the construction of a basketball court, the use of Department of Correction equipment and the falsification of employee time sheets, the authorities said. Mr. Serra resigned in May and has pleaded not guilty to grand larceny, defrauding the government and criminal possession of stolen property.

title: Caution Is Costly, Scholars Say
description: The ball shot down the left-field line, and the Yankees' speedy second baseman, who had singled in the inning, raced toward third base. With two outs in the eighth, the Yankees down by 3-2 and the ball caroming off the outfield wall, the third-base coach faced a decision on which the season would turn: should the runner try for home?

title: A Race Against a Stroke
description: To the Editor:

title: California House Breaks Stalemate on Budget Plan
description: The California Assembly approved a nearly $100 billion state budget today that cuts deeply into education and health care spending but does not raise taxes.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Component Maker To Cut 400 Jobs
description: The Andrew Corporation, a maker of wireless network components, said yesterday that it had higher net income and sales in its fiscal third-quarter and that profit might beat analysts' estimates. It also said it would cut 400 jobs as a result of its purchase of Allen Telecom. Andrew acquired Allen this month for $750 million in stock. The combination will create savings of $52 million a year, up from expectations of $40 million, the company, based in Orland Park, Ill., said. Andrew will also close at least nine manufacturing and distribution centers. Andrew said net income in the quarter, ended June 30, rose to $7.63 million, or 8 cents a share, from $2 million, or 2 cents, in the period a year earlier. Sales climbed 4.9 percent, to $213.7 million from $203.8 million. Shares of Andrew rose 70 cents, or 7 percent, to close at $10.62. The company now has about 7,300 employees.

title: Colombian Folklore In a Night of Partying
description: A whole country fitted on the small, cozy stage of the Thalia Spanish Theater in Queens when Ballet Mestizo appeared there on Friday night. Before the evening was over the performance resembled a friendly neighborhood party.

title: Minting A Pasta Dish For Summer
description: I HAVE cooked all around this dish for the last 20 years; sometimes the simplest variations are the ones that get away.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: June Production Rose 7.8%
description: Industrial production in June was 7.8 percent higher than in June of last year, according to the National Statistical Office, after having dropped 1.8 percent in May from the previous May. The increase was attributed in part to recovery from the SARS epidemic that struck Southeast Asian countries, resulting in a drop in exports in March and April. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: ABB Records Another Loss
description: Burdened by capital losses from divestments and further decreases in profits from divisions it is trying to sell, ABB, the Swiss engineering firm, posted its fourth consecutive quarterly loss. Still, respectable results from its two core divisions helped the shares rise more than 8 percent. As part of an overhaul, ABB has slashed its work force nearly in half, to 100,000, and intends to continue fine-tuning its costs, said Jrgen Dormann, the chief executive and chairman. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Lottery Numbers
Martin to Handle Nascar's Account
description: Nascar said yesterday that it had named the Martin Agency in Richmond, Va., to handle its account, which since 2000 has been run by the Chicago office of Young & Rubicam Advertising. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Unemployment Dips, Spending Grows
description: Japan's jobless rate fell for the first time in four months and consumer spending rose as the world's second-largest economy continued its mild expansion. The unemployment rate dropped one-tenth of a percentage point, to 5.3 percent, in June as the labor force added 470,000 jobs. At the same time, spending by those with jobs grew 0.4 percent compared with June a year ago. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Panel Proposes Changes for National Institutes of Health
description: A committee authorized by Congress to examine the structure of the National Institutes of Health came out today against any wholesale merging of its many branches but suggested making the agency's director more powerful and re-examining the ''special status'' of the National Cancer Institute, which now operates semiautonomously.

title: About New York; Mexican, But the Dream Is American
description: WITH the weight of a day's labor in their step, they trudged along the baked Bronx pavement, through the evening heat. They turned down a concrete alley at one of those apartment buildings that loom over the Grand Concourse like man-eating Gargantuas and followed its path to the dank coolness of the utility room, where the meeting was to be held.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-8

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCLOUGHLIN, , JOHN J.
description: McLOUGHLIN--John J. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of John J. McLoughlin a Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. John H. FitzSimons, Pres. Henry F. White, Jr., Historian >>AD#

title: The Curtain Comes Down for Herbie
description: Adis, bug.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SELIS, , SARA NEUFELD
description: SELIS--Sara Neufeld, died peacefully at the age of 93 on Monday, July 28, 2003. An amazing and talented woman who, although totally blind, brought a world of light to countless others. An accomplished and devoted social worker, she was a tireless advocate for the rights of the visually impaired. With her late husband, Irving Selis, she founded the Associated Blind, an organization run by and for the blind. She worked alongside her husband to help him fulfill his life-long dream to design and build Selis Manor, a residence dedicated to allowing the blind to live selfsufficient, productive lives. Beloved sister of Ben and Thelma Neufeld; the late Philip and Margaret Neufeld; and the late Laura and Joseph Robbins. Cherished aunt of Mace Neufeld, Carol Heller, Benedict Robbins, Michael Robbins, Arlene Neufeld, Lawrence Neufeld and Elizabeth Neufeld. Services private. >>AD#

title: Speed Demons on a Zigzag Course
description: Chefs often keep a collection of squeeze bottles on hand to add a touch of chili paste or decorate a plate with another tasty and frivolous accent. Now Terrapin Ridge, which makes an assortment of mustard-like condiments, including hot wasabi and honey-lavender, has introduced five flavors in squeeze bottles for the home cook.

title: The Jets Show Their Gratitude To a Loyal Fan
description: Early this morning, Herman Edwards checked his watch, a compulsive act of football coaches everywhere. In seven minutes Jets practice would be under way, the final tuneup before the club boarded a flight to Tokyo this morning for a preseason game with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers on Saturday.

title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: RISKY SEX RAISES AIDS CONCERN A growing number of gay and bisexual men in the United States are engaging in risky sex with partners they meet on the Internet, raising fears that the AIDS virus could be poised for a major comeback in the group hardest hit by the epidemic, according to two new studies presented at the 2003 National H.I.V. Prevention Conference. The studies found that online chat rooms and Web sites were becoming popular gay meeting points. The findings come amid growing evidence of an apparent resurgence of H.I.V.  the virus that causes AIDS  as well as syphilis in men who have sex with men. (Reuters)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MATTES, , JED
description: MATTES--Jed. The clients and colleagues of Jed Mattes mourn his death and extend our love and condolences to his family and many friends. We will remember him for his humor, courage, generosity and strength of character. Memorial donations in his honor will be welcomed at the Hetrick-Martin Institute for the Protection of Lesbian and Gay Youth and the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Fred Morris, Jed Mattes Inc. >>AD#

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Dissenter Said To Be Well
description: Officials from the Red Cross said they had been allowed to visit the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in detention for the first time and that they found her to be in good health and high spirits. Her detention by the military government since May 30 has drawn international condemnation, including tougher American penalties signed by President Bush on Monday. The detention of Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi is the symbolic center of a harsh crackdown under way to crush the pro-democracy movement. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Mitchell Scholars Delve Into Irish Culture, Too
description: When Emily Mark arrived in Dublin to study art history at Trinity College, she postponed worrying about classes until she found a traditional musician to teach her the Irish style of playing five-string claw-hammer banjo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KING, , HERBERT LEWIS
description: KING--Herbert Lewis. On July 22, 2003 at age 85. Husband of Lisbeth, father of Justin Andrew Burns King, he died peacefully at home in Wilton, Conn. A former copywriter and account executive at J. Walter Thompson, he and his wife owned King R.E. in Wilton for 38 years. He was also a writer and author. >>AD#

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Man Gets 30 Years In Fraud
description: A federal judge in Seattle gave a sentence of 30 years to a man who was the ringleader of one of the state's largest investment frauds. The man, John W. Zidar, 60, of Nevada, was convicted of money laundering and mail and wire fraud for his part in a investment fund that defrauded more than 3,200 Americans and Canadians of $74 million from 1997 to 2000, the United States attorney's office in Seattle said. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Maker's Revenue To Miss
description: The Nvidia Corporation, a top maker of chips for computer graphics, said yesterday that second-quarter revenue was $455 million to $460 million, less than the $461.9 million forecast in a Thomson First Call survey of analysts. Nvidia, whose computer graphics chips are used in Microsoft's Xbox video-game machine, said yesterday that second-quarter gross margins were slightly less than forecast because of higher-than-expected production costs. Shares of Nvidia fell $1.34, or 6.6 percent, to close at $19.07. Nvidia, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., is scheduled to release its second-quarter earnings next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLUMBERG, , EDWARD J.
description: BLUMBERG--Edward J., 95, on July 28th, 2003. Beloved husband for 69 years of Carolyn, devoted father of Nancy and Bob. Loving grandfather of Lori, Todd, Gary, Julie and Karen. President and Chairman for many years of Blumberg Law Products, established in 1887 by his father, Julius. Our lives were enriched by his loyal, affectionate nature; his generous, open mind; his conscientious integrity; his dapper good looks; his adventurous spirit; his biting wit; his love of life. Services and entombment at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Friday, 2PM. The family will receive friends at his home, Thursday and Friday, from 5:30-8:30PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to The American Civil Liberties Union. >>AD#

title: A German Media Giant Moves To Pull Back and Reduce Debt
description: A year ago last week, Gunter Thielen flew to a seaside villa in Majorca for a momentous meeting with Reinhard Mohn, the 82-year-old patriarch of Bertelsmann.

title: Brutality Trial For Officer Concludes In Hung Jury
description: A mistrial was declared today in the case of a police officer who was videotaped last year slamming a 16-year-old onto the trunk of a patrol car. The jury said it was deadlocked, with seven jurors favoring a conviction of the officer, Jeremy Morse, on charges of assaulting the teenager and five voting to acquit.

title: In a Jungle of Signs, New Jersey Seeks Way
description: Drivers approaching this city from the east on Interstate 195 are suddenly faced with two signs and a bewildering choice: ''Trenton'' to the right or ''Lambertville and Capitol Complex'' to the left. Has the State House migrated to the suburbs?

title: Verizon and Unions Meet With Mediator
description: Verizon and its labor unions met yesterday with a top federal mediator in an effort to avoid a strike this weekend that could affect local and long-distance telephone service in 13 New England and Middle Atlantic States and the District of Columbia.

title: PROVIDIAN TO CLOSE CALL CENTER AND LAY OFF 232 WORKERS
description: The Providian Financial Corporation, the seventh-largest credit card issuer in the United States, said yesterday that it planned to close its call center in El Paso and eliminate 232 jobs next month to cut costs. The move comes after the company, which is based in San Francisco, sold almost half its credit card portfolio and reduced its staff by 47 percent last year. Providian said yesterday that it earned $39 million in the second quarter, down 75 percent from the $153.9 million it earned in the period a year ago. About $64 million of the profit last year was from operations that have been discontinued.

title: SHARON TELLS BUSH ISRAEL WON'T HALT ITS FENCE PROJECT
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel today rebuffed pressure from President Bush to halt construction of a security fence on the West Bank and called on Mr. Bush to persuade Palestinian leaders to do more to dismantle terrorist organizations.

title: In TriBeCa, Foccacia With A Cheesy Lining
description: Focaccia is a specialty of Liguria, the Italian province on the Riviera, and in the town of Recco, a kind of focaccia the locals call focaccia col formaggio is made with a parchment-thin, yeastless dough and stuffed with gooey stracchino cheese. It is now served at Bread Tribeca, a new restaurant at 301 Church Street (Walker Street). The owners are Luigi Comandatore, who also owns Bread on Spring Street, and Bob Giraldi, an owner of Gigino and Patria.

title: Jane Barbe, 74, Notable Voice On Those Phone Recordings
description: Jane Barbe, who was known to millions, though not by name or appearance, as the voice of telephone-company recordings and voice-mail systems across America, died on July 18 in Roswell, Ga. She was 74.

title: The Fight for the Democrats' Soul
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEEHAN, , CORNELIUS
description: SHEEHAN--Cornelius. At age 54 on July 26, 2003. Beloved son of the late Mary (Betty) and Philip. He died after a courageous two year struggle with cancer. A New York City firefighter for 25 years, Engine #

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SPAIN: TELEFONICA POSTS A PROFIT Telefonica, Spain's largest telephone company, posted a profit in the second quarter as it reduced operating expenses and benefited from growth in the wireless division. Net income was 882.2 million euros ($1 billion), in contrast to a loss of 5.7 billion euros in the year-ago period, the company said in a regulatory statement. Sales at the former monopoly fell 1.6 percent, to 7.1 billion euros, the sixth consecutive quarterly decline year on year. The company's chairman, Cesar Alierta, above, is increasing dividends to attract investors as growth from fixed-line phone services stalls. Telefonica is raising its 2003 dividend 60 percent. To afford the payouts, Mr. Alierta is cutting costs, by among other things, reducing the domestic unit's work force by 15,000. (Bloomberg News)

title: Glavine Adds Injury To Insult
description: The pageantry led right up until game time at Shea Stadium: the Mets presented Gary Carter with a plaque and a motorcycle; they held a reunion of the key members of the 1986 championship team, who were seated neatly in front of home plate; highlights of those glory years were rotated like advertisements.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Last Call at Marty's; Broadway Awaits

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DEPINNA, , GEORGE LEO
description: DePINNA--George Leo. Daddy, Happy 84th Birthday. Wish you were here to celebrate--Always in my thoughts and heart. All my love, N. M. I. >>AD#

title: TRANSOCEAN REPORTS LOSS AMID DROP IN DEMAND FOR RIGS
description: Transocean Inc., an offshore oil driller, said yesterday that it had a second-quarter loss of $44.5 million, or 14 cents a share, because of reduced demand for its deepwater rigs. The loss was in contrast to net income of $80 million, or 25 cents a share, in the second quarter of 2002, the company said. Revenue fell to $603.9 million from $646.2 million. Transocean, which is based in Houston, said it expected ''diminishing opportunities'' for its deepwater rigs in the North Sea, Brazil and Southeast Asia for the rest of the year because of a surplus of drilling platforms. The outlook for the shallow-water drilling business remains uncertain, the company said. Shares in Transocean fell 46 cents, to $18.87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SUSSMAN, , MIRIAM
description: SUSSMAN--Miriam. Died July 28 at the age of 89. Beloved wife of her late husband Murray. Cherished mother of Alan and Leonard. Devoted sister of Marjorie Dinstman. Grandmother of Andrew, Julie and Emily. Great grandmother of Hope and Teal. Good & charitable friend to many over the years in NYC and Palm Beach, FL. All of us will remember your warm smile and miss you profoundly. >>AD#

title: Accusations Against MCI Could Drive Clients Away
description: Whether true or not, accusations that MCI used fraudulent methods to reduce the access charges it pays to other phone companies could make it harder for the company to keep some of its current customers and to sign up new ones, according to industry consultants.

title: An Aboriginal Painting, Just a Souvenir, Brings a Windfall
description: JoAnne Walker always liked the small aboriginal painting she bought 30 years ago when she and her husband were temporarily posted in central Australia. It wasn't a showy piece and cost only $30, but it reminded her of the desert country she and her family used to explore around Alice Springs.

title: Neighbors See Lesson in Oneida Casino Deal: What Not to Do
description: For all of the town and county governments hoping that a new Indian casino will solve their unemployment and tax problems, the people around here have a few words of advice: Don't do it the way we did.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Honda Profit Slips
description: The Honda Motor Company said that profits slipped 5.4 percent in the April-to-June period because of slowing sales at home and a strengthening yen. The company, Japan's second-largest automaker, earned 102 billion yen ($850 million) in the first quarter of its fiscal year. Sales grew 3.7 percent because of strong demand overseas. Sales in Japan, however, fell 28 percent. Honda raised its full-year profit target by 2.5 percent, to 451 billion yen ($3.7 billion), on the expectation that the yen will weaken before the end of the fiscal year in March 2004. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Swiftly, Plan for Terrorism Futures Market Slips Into Dustbin of Idea Without a Future
description: The Pentagon's new terrorism futures market is suddenly a thing of the past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCHUGH, , EDNA CANTOR
description: McHUGH--Edna Cantor. On July 24. Artist and writer of cookbooks. Daughter of the late Eddie Cantor. Survived by her daughter Judy, grandson Lee and sisters Marilyn and Janet. All her friends knew she turned having fun into an art form. >>AD#

title: With Tightened Belt, New York Pulls Back From Fiscal Brink
description: For the first time since the terrorist attacks in 2001, there is evidence that New York City is emerging from its fiscal crisis, a startling turnaround that is a result of a budget formula consisting of higher taxes, service cuts, extra aid and greater government efficiency.

title: DeLay Says Palestinians Bear Burden for Achieving Peace
description: JERUSALEM, July 30  Calling himself "an Israeli at heart," Tom DeLay, the House majority leader, told Israeli legislators today that the burden for achieving peace here rested with the Palestinians, who he said must eradicate terrorism.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about plans by the European Union to enforce rules that reserve the use of regional labels for products -- like Roquefort or Chianti -- referred incorrectly at one point to a representative of the European Union's trade office. The representative, Arancha Gonzalez, is a woman.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: MYANMAR: DISSENTER SAID TO BE WELL Officials from the Red Cross said they had been allowed to visit the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in detention for the first time and that they found her to be in good health and high spirits. Her detention by the military government since May 30 has drawn international condemnation, including tougher American penalties signed by President Bush on Monday. The detention of Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi is the symbolic center of a harsh crackdown under way to crush the pro-democracy movement. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Jets Cross the Line, the International Date Line
description: Jets center Kevin Mawae plans to find the Sizzler restaurant that he has heard is located in the vast Tokyo Dome Hotel. Tampa Bay Coach Jon Gruden is taking his pillow and DVD's and telling anyone who will listen, ''I'm not the best traveler.''

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Annan Asks For New Rwanda Prosecutor
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan recommended to Security Council members that each of the two major war crimes tribunals -- the one focusing on the former Yugoslavia and the other on Rwanda -- have its own prosecutor. If the Council concurs, it would relieve the current prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, of her Rwanda duties, but renew her ties with the tribunal for the former Yugoslavia. Supporters of Ms. Del Ponte have argued that she has been made a political target by the Rwandan government, which, they say, wants to short-circuit her investigations of some members of the Tutsi-dominated Rwandan Patriotic Army. Felicity Barringer (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Morristown: Bank Robber Sentenced
description: A man who used his teenage daughter, dressed in Arab clothing and threatening holy war, to rob a bank in Parsippany was sentenced on Monday by Judge Catherine Langlois of State Superior Court to up to 30 years in prison. The man, Kevin Vernon Miller, 36, of Newark, pleaded guilty this month to robbery, eluding the police and using juveniles in a crime. On April 11, 2002, while Mr. Miller and his daughter's teenage friend waited in a car, his 15-year-old daughter, concealed by a veil, entered the First Union Bank branch on Route 46 and gave a note to a teller threatening ''jihad'' and saying that a bomb might go off. The three escaped with $1,162. The two girls pleaded guilty last year for their roles in the heist and were sentenced to a reformatory.

title: Corrections
description: A series of annotated maps of Iraq on Sunday showing, by the month, where American troops have died since the end of the war, misstated the number of soldiers killed during July. There were 38 fatalities as of July 26, not 35.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Actuate Buys Nimble
description: The Actuate Corporation said yesterday that it had bought the closely held Nimble Technology for less than $10 million, the third acquisition in two weeks of a maker of software that is used to collect information from databases. It may not be the last. Actuate, which is based in South San Francisco, Calif., has received seven or eight offers from potential buyers the last five years, the chief executive, Peter I. Cittadini, said in an interview. ''They've all taken a crack at us and we've always said no,'' Mr. Cittadini said. Software companies are buying each other to avoid being acquired by bigger companies. On July 18, Business Objects agreed to buy the closely held Crystal Decisions, a competitor of Actuate, for $820 million. Five days later, the Hyperion Solutions Corporation said it was buying Brio Software for $142 million in cash and stock.

title: R.J. REYNOLDS REPORTS LOWER PROFIT AS SALES FALL
description: R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings Inc. said yesterday that second-quarter earnings tumbled 67 percent as sales declined and the company spent more to keep smokers from switching to lower-priced brands. Net income dropped to $70 million, or 83 cents a share, R.J. Reynolds said in a statement. The profit, which was 1 cent short of analysts' per-share estimates, was hurt by $34 million in costs to write down the value of equipment and end a Nascar sponsorship. Sales fell 16 percent to $1.43 billion, a fourth consecutive decline. Shares of R. J. Reynolds fell 91 cents, to $35.54.

title: Ozone Layer Is Improving, According To Monitors
description: Scientists monitoring the highest levels of the atmosphere say they have detected a slowing in the rate of destruction of Earth's protective veil of ozone, the first sign that the phasing out of chemicals that harm the ozone layer is having a restorative effect.

title: Times to Name 'Public Editor' to Be Readers' Representative
description: Seeking to mend the damage to the credibility and staff morale of The New York Times following a reporter's extensive fabrications, the newspaper's new executive editor today accepted the major recommendations of an internal committee, including the appointment of a "public editor" to serve as a representative for readers.

title: Hambletonian Favorite Gives Campbell a Shot at Record
description: John Campbell broke his right elbow and injured his right hand in a mishap in the last race on the Meadowlands card on March 23.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIEBMANN, , HERMAN
description: LIEBMANN--Herman, July 21, 2003, in NYC. WW II Army Major, textile executive, private investor, Director of the Richard Tucker Foundation, member of the Harmonie Club for over 50 years. Father of Lisa Liebmann Adams, father-in-law of John Brooks Adams, grandfather of Jane Juno Adams, former husband of Loraine Pack Liebmann, dear companion of the late Elaine Reiner. Service on July 31, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: MORE WEST NILE VIRUS DETECTED Three more birds in Connecticut have tested positive for the West Nile virus. Two infected crows and a raven were found in Andover, Ledyard and Waterford from July 3 to July 15, the State Department of Public Health announced on Monday. Eight birds have tested positive so far this year in the state. Meanwhile, in New York, two birds and a mosquito pool have tested positive for the virus in Suffolk County, the first time this year the disease has been detected on eastern Long Island, Suffolk County Health Department officials announced yesterday. The birds, an American crow and a fish crow, were found on July 14 and 15 in East Northport and St. James, health department spokeswoman Millie Dinda said in a statement. The mosquito pool was collected on July 16 in Manorville. (AP)

title: From a Brewer And a Chef, Ale Forever Amber
description: Masaharu Morimoto, right, lops off the top of his new beer with a saber, but don't feel obliged to do likewise. Mr. Morimoto, who was a star of ''The Iron Chef'' on television and is now executive chef and an owner of Morimoto in Philadelphia, has come up with two brews that have more to do with subtle grace than brute force.

title: How Green Is My Rice
description: The juice of young bamboo has been used for 800 years in southwestern China to remove the husks from short-grain rice. The result is a grain with a subtle herbaceousness that keeps its lawn-green color once cooked.

title: Emergency Plans for Indian Point
description: If federal officials hoped to reassure an anxious public about evacuation plans in the event of a radioactive release from the Indian Point nuclear reactors, some 35 miles north of Times Square, they picked a terrible way to do it. Late Friday afternoon, the Federal Emergency Management Agency released a two-page letter to Gov. George Pataki conveying its ''reasonable assurance'' that measures to protect residents within 10 miles of Indian Point would be ''adequate.'' The Nuclear Regulatory Commission promptly followed with a one-page statement asserting that the emergency planning was ''satisfactory'' and should provide ''adequate protection'' for the public. And that was that. After months of criticism by local officials and antinuclear groups, federal regulators had responded with terse judgments that were too thinly supported to evoke confidence. It felt more like a thumb in the eye of the critics than a well-documented verdict.

title: Manolo Blahniks Meet Ballet Slippers; Baryshnikov Is Cast as Heartthrob for 'Sex and the City' Finale
description: For better or worse, the tumultuous love life of Carrie Bradshaw, the signature single woman of HBO's hit comedy ''Sex and the City,'' is coming to an end this season. Sarah Jessica Parker, the star who plays Carrie, says the plan has always been to go out with a romance bigger than Big.

title: Pettitte's 8th Straight Is Breather for Yankees
description: The night was hardly a quiet one, with a player essentially fired and the Yankees missing out on a solid reliever who wound up in the hands of the enemy. And all this came after a pulsating and draining three-game series in Boston, which ultimately cost the Yankees a game in the American League East standing. The last thing they needed tonight was a loss or even a tough game. It was time to take a deep breath.

title: MILACRON PLANS JOB CUTS AND REPORTS $91 MILLION LOSS
description: Milacron Inc., a maker of plastics-molding equipment, said yesterday that it would cut about 300 jobs in North America and Europe and suspend payment of a quarterly dividend in a plan to save about $20 million annually. The job cuts and other actions will reduce earnings by about $10 million over the remainder of the year, and the company will have additional costs of $8 million spread over the next four quarters, Milacron said. The net loss in the second quarter widened to $91.3 million, or $2.72 a share, from $31.1 million, or 93 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 6.8 percent, to $181.6 million from $169.9 million.

title: Prague Is Fighting to Remain in the Picture
description: The western edge of Uhelny Trh, a small cobbled square in Prague's historic center, was a curious sight last week. A fruit and vegetable market had sprouted in an alley better known for its doorways of ill repute, under a distinctly French street sign inscribed ''rue Martin.'' A few passing tourists tried to buy fruit, but a gleaming new Japanese sedan and the movie camera gave away the game -- another TV commercial was being filmed in Prague.

title: Palestinians Deter Attacks, Official Says
description: The Palestinian Authority's security minister, Muhammad Dahlan, said tonight that his forces in the West Bank had prevented seven terror attacks against Israel in the last month, but did not arrest the would-be assailants because Israeli troops still control those areas.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Officer Charged With Murder
description: A Newark police officer has been charged with attempted murder after he shot an unarmed man in the stomach on Sunday morning while off duty, prosecutors said yesterday. After an argument with his estranged girlfriend, the officer, David Lamar used his service revolver to shoot Paul Godley, 40, a bystander who had tried to break up the fight, said Charlotte Smith, a spokeswoman for the Essex County prosecutor's office. Prosecutors said Officer Lamar, 35, ended his shift at 4 a.m. on Sunday and drove to the Stephen Crane Elderly Home complex, where his girlfriend works as a security guard. After the argument in one of the complex's buildings, Officer Lamar walked to his vehicle, retrieved his revolver and shot Mr. Godley once, prosecutors said. Mr. Godley was in critical condition last night at University Hospital, a spokesman said. John Holl (NYT)

title: Critics Say Guatemalan Ex-Dictator Is Mob Manipulator
description: In a country where the masses of rural poor survive on barely enough food, work or hope, the spectacle of peasant mobs rampaging through exclusive neighborhoods last Thursday should have come as no surprise. But what many people found unsettling -- if not altogether unexpected -- was that the mobs were well organized and rallying in support of Efran Ros Montt, a former general and dictator whose iron-fisted rule devastated many of their communities in the early 1980's and who is now seeking the presidency.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Heroic Trooper Honored
description: A 29-year-old state trooper who shot and killed a man who had opened fire during a traffic stop was named the state's police officer of the year by Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday. On May 14, 2002, the trooper, Shawn C. Dean, fatally shot a former convict who had jumped out of a stolen car in Broome County and had shot another trooper, John Spero, in the hand. The two troopers had stopped the car for a traffic violation. Three stolen guns were found in the trunk. Governor Pataki decorated Trooper Dean, a father of two, with the state's medal of valor. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: Up North: Michigan's Flavorful Vacationland
description: WHEN he was a boy, Ernest Hemingway spent his summers in this remote rural dominion, where Lake Michigan curls around to meet Lake Huron.

description: Rey Sanchez had mounted a campaign to improve his image, tainted by a teammate's report of his haircut in the Mets' clubhouse during a game on April 30. Sanchez has denied that the incident occurred, but he has also been a bit murkier, having said, ''That was not the real me.''

title: Judge Warns Against Naming The Accuser Of Kobe Bryant
description: The judge hearing sexual assault charges against the Los Angeles Lakers star Kobe Bryant issued an unorthodox order yesterday intended to protect the identity of Mr. Bryant's accuser.

description: ETHAN ALLEN INTERIORS INC., Danbury, Conn., the furniture maker and retailer, increased its quarterly dividend from 7 cents a share to 10 cents a share, payable on Oct. 27 to shareholders of record as of Oct. 10.

description: Gov. George E. Pataki is refusing to sign off on millions of dollars that legislators can dole out for projects in their backyards, a move that lawmakers say is a result of a bruising budget battle.

title: Lessons of Okinawa
description: As the American military extends its stay in postwar Iraq, the risks of political and social friction will rise. Inevitably, there will be clashes; protests erupted in May, for example, when soldiers searching for troublemakers in one town intruded on unveiled women. To keep the occupation of Iraq from ending in bitterness, American officials will have to reach out to residents both economically and politically.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Psychiatrist Faces Drug Charges
description: A psychiatrist was charged yesterday with illegally selling prescription drugs after detectives for the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, entered the doctor's East 73rd Street office and arrested 18 people, the authorities said. The psychiatrist, Aaron Friedberg, 40, a resident of Alpine, N.J., maintains an office on Park Avenue but rented space that was used for the illegal drug sales at 133 East 73rd Street, the authorities said. Most of the others arrested were suspected customers and were charged with misdemeanor offenses. But the police said two others, David Santone and Kenneth Punllinger, both 42, were charged with several counts of illegal drug sales. A law enforcement official who insisted on anonymity said that Mr. Santone operated as a middleman for Dr. Friedberg by steering customers to his office. Mr. Punllinger's role remained unclear last night. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Senators Assail 2 Officials For Lack of Postwar Details
description: Senators from both parties today assailed two senior Bush administration officials for refusing to spell out how much the postwar effort in Iraq would cost and how many American troops would be needed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, , ETHEL
description: BERNSTEIN--Ethel. The partners of Jenkens & Gilchrist Parker Chapin LLP mourn the passing of Ethel Bernstein, the beloved mother of our esteemed client, Richard A. Bernstein. We extend our deepest sympathies to Richard, Amelia and the entire Bernstein family. >>AD#

title: Fox Teams Drilled On the Fundamentals
description: Several years ago, when Jimmy Johnson left Fox's National Football League studio program to coach the Miami Dolphins, he was asked by Ed Goren, the president of Fox Sports, how to keep motivating the network's announcers, producers and directors.

title: A New 'New Mideast'
description: Back in the mid-1990's there was a lot of talk about ''a new Middle East'' that seemed to be aborning. It turned out to be, shall we say, ''premature'' -- as the newest new Middle East came crashing down with the collapse of Oslo, the breakdown in Arab-Israeli relations, 9/11 and the massive passive support for Osama bin Laden. With hindsight, it's now easy to see that there could be no ''new Middle East'' without a new kind of Middle East politics. It was like trying to build a new house on swampland. Eventually, it just sank.

title: Profits Decline 83% at British American Tobacco
description: British American Tobacco, the world's second-largest tobacco company, said today that second-quarter profits fell 83 percent from a year ago, to 48 million ($78 million).

title: A More Mellow Stewart Is Trying to Stay Positive
description: Tony Stewart, his crew chief and his car owner sat in Stewart's orange hauler last Sunday. Two of the men were distraught because the engine in Stewart's car had blown up while he was running fast in the Pennsylvania 500 at Pocono. The third man decided it was a perfect time for a pep talk.

title: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING SAYS PROFIT DROPPED 25%
description: Automatic Data Processing Inc., the world's biggest paycheck issuer and a processor of stock trades, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit fell 25 percent as sales in the brokerage-services unit slid and it spent money to cut jobs. Net income decreased to $216.7 million, or 36 cents a share, from $287.3 million, or 46 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales in the quarter ended June 30 rose 3.6 percent, to $1.91 billion from $1.85 billion. Automatic Data, which is based in Roseland, N.J., said profit this year would miss analysts' expectations. Shares of Automatic Data fell 91 cents, to $35.91.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Fireworks Blast Kills 29
description: An explosion ripped through a fireworks factory in northern China, killing 29 people and injuring 141, state news media reported. The blast happened Monday at the Guoxi factory, near the city of Tianjin, destroying the brick facility and affecting buildings nearly 350 feet away, official news outlets said. The fireworks industry remains one of China's most dangerous, despite repeated promises to tighten regulations and close down unsafe operations. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

She served as a member of the Board of Trustees (1958-1963), as did her mother, Margaret Thayer Talbott from 1947 until her death in 1962, and her husband Blancke Noyes from 1972 until his death in 1978. She was a generous supporter of many areas of the College, especially the athletic program and the visual arts program, as befitted an accomplished sportswoman and lover of the arts. We will miss her greatly and send our love and sympathy to her daughter, Audrey, also a graduate of the College, her sons Nicholas, Talbott and Robert and all her family. Margot C. description: Priceline.com, the Internet seller of discount travel services, said yesterday that its offering of as much as $125 million in senior notes would carry an annual interest rate of 1 percent and convert to common stock at $40 a share.

description: KURTZ--Irving, 94. Husband of Dora; father of Marcia and Judy; grandfather of Aaron and Elena; father-in-law of Sidney. Uncle, brother and brother-in-law of the Kurtz/ Rosenstein clan. He did publicity for the WPA and worked as an advertising executive for Metromedia and Winston Network, retiring at the age of 80. He loved music, politics and his New York Times. Dad, we loved you so much and miss your humor, wisdom, kindness and concern for your family and the family of man, your sense of fairness and almost childlike wonder of the world. >>AD#

title: New Estimates on Senate Carbon Dioxide Emissions Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  An internal analysis by Environmental Protection Agency economists has found that a Senate plan to reduce the carbon dioxide emissions linked to global warming could achieve its goal at very little cost, according to a copy of the analysis made available by a group supporting the plan.

title: Mock Attacks Test Security At Indian Pt. Nuclear Plant
description: Simulated attacks on the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Westchester have begun, as part of a test this week to look for weaknesses in the plant's security plan, officials said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BRONX: BURNED WOMAN DIES; MAN CHARGED A Queens woman who was set on fire by her boyfriend on July 18 died yesterday at Jacobi Medical Center, officials said, and the boyfriend was charged with second-degree murder. The woman, Bae Mi Ran, 41, suffered third-degree burns over 50 percent of her body when her boyfriend, Jo Sung Chul, 44, who shared an apartment with her in Jackson Heights, doused her with gasoline on a street corner. The police say Mr. Jo set her on fire with a cigarette lighter, poured gasoline on himself, then grabbed her in a bear hug. He was also burned and remained in critical condition at New York-Cornell Medical Center. Neighbors of the couple said they had argued frequently, with Ms. Bae complaining about Mr. Jo's drinking and Mr. Jo saying Ms. Bae had another boyfriend.

title: Fruit Soups in Fresh Harmonies
description: IF the unexpected is a key to seduction, then Gabriel Kreuther is a master flirt. Mr. Kreuther, the executive chef of Atelier in the Ritz-Carlton on Central Park South, has concocted jewel-toned chilled fruit soups whose colors, flavors and textures parry and fuse in artful combinations.

title: VF JEANSWEAR TO LAY OFF 1,800 AND CLOSE PLANTS
description: VF Jeanswear, the maker of Wrangler jeans, plans to lay off more than 1,800 employees, about 8 percent of its work force, as it closes plants in North Carolina and Oklahoma. The company, a unit of the VF Corporation, said yesterday that 366 workers would lose their jobs in September when the company closes a sewing plant in Windsor, N.C. Another 526 employees will lose their jobs at a plant in Wilson, N.C. Executives said they would lay off 663 workers in Seminole, Okla., and shut down a plant in Ada, Okla., that employs 246 people. VF Jeanswear now has 12 plants in the United States and 20 outside of the country.

title: Train Knocks Down Power Lines And Snarls Evening Rail Service
description: Thousands of rail passengers were delayed yesterday for 90 minutes or more, or forced to find other forms of transportation, after an Amtrak train knocked down overhead power lines on the Northeast Corridor line in New Jersey about 6:30 p.m., the authorities said.

title: Bush Refuses to Declassify Saudi Section of Report
description: President Bush refused today to declassify a 28-page chapter of a Congressional report on the Sept. 11 attacks. He said disclosure of the deleted section, which centers on accusations about Saudi Arabia's role in financing the hijackings, ''would help the enemy'' and compromise the administration's campaign against terror.

On the same day Film Forum plans to show a new print of ''Johnny Guitar,'' a cult 1954 western. Next year HBO plans to show ''Deadwood,'' a western written by David Milch, who created ''N.Y.P.D. Blue'' with Steven Bochco. Even Dick Wolf, the creator of ''Law & Order,'' says he has long dreamed of transferring his franchise to sheriff's posses and desert trails.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: End To Anti-South Broadcasts
description: After three decades of broadcasting hostile propaganda to South Korea, a North Korean radio station, Voice of National Salvation, will cease broadcasting tomorrow, a senior official promised. In making the promise, the official, Kim Ryong Song, acknowledged that the station was operated by North Korea. Since broadcasts began in 1970, North Korea has said that the station was maintained by an underground Communist cell in South Korea. South Korea's military traced the signals to Haeju, a North Korean city close to the border. James Brooke (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Mothers Lose Vaccine Appeal
description: Two mothers must permit doctors to vaccinate their daughters for measles, mumps and rubella, despite their concerns about the safety of the three-in-one vaccine, the Court of Appeal ruled. The cases were brought by the fathers of the girls, aged 5 and 10, who wanted them vaccinated. The vaccine has been controversial since a widely disputed study in 1998 suggested links between it and autism. As a result there has been a steady decrease in the number of children in Britain receiving the vaccine. The court said that ''while you can never prove a negative, there was strong scientific evidence that the risks of not immunizing children were real and in many instances serious.'' Lizette Alvarez (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Progress Against Wildfire
description: Fire officials said light winds and hot temperatures had helped a controlled burn intended to eliminate fuel for a large wildfire bearing down on West Glacier. Officials said that by Thursday, most of the residential area at the west entrance to Glacier National Park would have some protection. Still, said Len Wilcock, deputy incident commander for the blaze, ''We're still days away before there's no threat.'' More than 500 people have been evacuated. Jim Robbins (NYT)

title: What's Design Got to Do With It?
description: LAST year, a substantial wall stood between me and a bigger kitchen, on which I would ultimately spend $40,000, all of it from refinancing. There were other walls, too, boxing up the living room, dining room, entrance hall and stair in my 1911 row house. The walls went up in the 1940's, when the house unmagically became four apartments. And I had only a dim idea of how to get rid of them. One thing was clear: I would not be doing the work myself.

title: Bloomberg Repeats Opposition to Capital Punishment, Calling It Flawed
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg reiterated his opposition to capital punishment yesterday, after Staten Island prosecutors said they would seek the death penalty for a man accused of killing two police officers.

title: The City Life; Of Barbecue and Men
description: New Yorkers lack the space to barbecue a half-ton steer, as is done in Texas. The stuff we grill, often illegally, on our fire escapes and balconies is generally small. But the cult of barbecue cookery burns as vibrantly here as anywhere else. Fancy stainless steel gas grills have begun to make inroads in residential New York, but the instrument of choice for apartment dwellers who practice fire-escape grilling is the kettle-shaped Weber charcoal grill, in the standard-issue black.

title: The Right and Wrong Stuff of Thinking Outside a Box
description: The Pentagon branch responsible for developing technology and techniques for warfare stumbled badly this week by devising a plan for people to bet on future terrorist attacks. Yet in pressing an idea that senators quickly denounced as absurd, the Defense Advance Research Projects Agency, or Darpa, is doing what it is supposed to do -- think outside the box.

title: To Cut Failure Rate, Schools Shed Students
description: Growing numbers of students -- most of them struggling academically -- are being pushed out of New York City's school system and classified under bureaucratic categories that hide their failure to graduate.

title: Cordoning Off Clutter (Or Roommate)
description: When you are ready to graduate from your Rhoda Morgenstern beaded curtains, the red Lyric space divider (right) by Fold of Seattle awaits.

title: Bodies of Three People Found in Connecticut Auto Repair Shop
description: The bodies of three people were found yesterday in an auto repair shop in Windsor Locks, Conn., the state police said.

title: Judge Orders Inmate Freed Or Retried in '87 Sex Case
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn ordered state officials yesterday to release or retry a prisoner from Nassau County who was convicted in 1987 of sexually abusing a 7-year-old girl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLWES, , WILLIAM
description: COLWES -- William. Died peacefully on July 29. Beloved husband of Dorothy, loving father of Matthew (Alyne Schwartz) and Carrie (Jeffrey Hymowitz), adoring grandfather of Jacob Ethan and Ari David. A great guy who will be sorely missed. Funeral service Thursday, July 31, at 11 AM, Parkside Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd. 718-896-9000. >>AD#

title: Enron's Friends in Need
description: We can now add the names of two venerable banks, J. P. Morgan Chase and Citigroup, to the dishonor roll of accountants and lazy regulators who helped Enron perpetrate its gigantic and costly fraud on the American public. On Monday, the banks agreed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Manhattan district attorney's office to pay almost $300 million in fines and penalties to settle accusations that they helped Enron deceive investors by hiding billions of dollars in debt and inflating its cash flow.

title: U.S. Economy Grew at 2.4% Annual Rate in 2nd Quarter
description: The nation's economy showed some promising signs of reinvigoration in the second quarter, according to preliminary figures the government released today. But the improvement was somewhat skewed by Washington itself, as military spending posted its biggest three-month increase since the Korean War.

title: Annan Warns of World 'Crisis'
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan called publicly today for a rethinking of the international institutions that were largely sidelined during the Iraq war.

title: This Palmtop Knows Its Place
description: EACH year, as they pay their taxes, many Americans conduct a tiny mental debate. ''Why should I have to turn over such a huge fraction of my hard-earned money to the government?'' And then, a moment later: ''Oh, yeah: schools, roads, national security -- blah, blah, blah. Sign the check.''

title: U.S. Says China Is Stepping Up Short-Range Missile Production
description: China has accelerated production of short-range ballistic missiles, not only to hold Taiwan at peril but also ''to complicate United States intervention in a Taiwan Strait conflict,'' the Pentagon said today in its annual assessment of the Chinese military.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SELIGSON, , SELMA (NEE SHAPIRO)
description: SELIGSON--Selma (nee Shapiro). July 30, 2003. Beloved wife of Henry. Loving mother of Celia Yvonne Seligson and Jeffrey Mark Seligson. Loving grandmother of Tanya Beth Lupton and Aaron George Seligson; loving great grandmother of Alex and Jason Lupton. Relatives and friends are invited to graveside services Thursday 2pm precisely at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, N.Y. Goldensteins Rosenbergs Raphael-Sacks at 1-800-622-6410 >>AD#

title: Plan to Revive Production Of Oil in Iraq Is Announced
description: Iraqi and American officials say they have agreed on a $1.6 billion plan to rehabilitate Iraq's oil industry over eight months.

title: Jets Land In Tokyo A Bit Weary
description: After a 13-hour flight, a half-hour delay circling Narita Airport and another half-hour delay waiting for their equipment to arrive at the Chiba sports complex where they were to practice, the Jets finally made it to Tokyo today. They were greeted at the airport by about a dozen fans with a Jets banner and tiny Jets helmets, although one fan also brought along a Washington Redskins helmet for good measure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREIMAN, , MURRAY, ESQ.
description: GREIMAN--Murray, Esq. Of Jersey City, NJ. Beloved husband of Lenore. Devoted father of Miriam Hutchinson. Loving grandfather of Tracy and Todd, and three great grandchildren. Services private at ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800322-0533. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Syracuse: Pataki Signs New Assault Laws
description: At a stop in Syracuse yesterday, Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation to amend the state's Sexual Assault Reform Act of 2000. The new law defines new crimes, like persistent sexual abuse, and provides greater protection for sexually abused spouses. The law, to take effect on Nov. 1, toughens penalties for possession or sale of so-called date-rape drugs and eliminates obsolete legal terms like sodomy and deviant sexual behavior, an aide to the governor said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: BARNES & NOBLE BUYS BERTELSMANN STAKE IN DOT-COM
description: Shares of BarnesandNoble.com Inc., the No. 2 U.S. Internet bookseller after Amazon.com Inc., rose 16 percent yesterday after Barnes & Noble Inc. agreed to buy a controlling interest in the company from Bertelsmann. Barnes & Noble late Tuesday said that it would pay $2.80 a share, or about $164 million, for a 37 percent stake in BarnesandNoble.com held by Bertelsmann, the German media company. Barnes & Noble will have a 75 percent interest in the company. BarnesandNoble.com's losses have been narrowing over the last two and a half years and the company expects to have operating earnings by the end of this year. BarnesandNoble.com shares rose 32 cents, to $2.36, on the Nasdaq. Shares of Barnes & Noble fell 53 cents, or 2.1 percent, to $24.79 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: World Bank Says Constitution Must Precede Loans to Iraq
description: The president of the World Bank, James D. Wolfensohn, suggested today that the bank would lend money for the reconstruction of Iraq only after the country writes a constitution and conducts national elections. He also said that an indeterminate number of the country's state-owned industries would have to be shut down or restructured.

title: 2 U.S. Soldiers Killed in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 31  Two American soldiers were killed and five were wounded in two separate attacks late Wednesday and today, one beneath an overpass on a Baghdad highway and one at an outpost 50 miles northeast of the capital.

title: Links of Saudis to Charities Come Under Senate Review
description: A Senate hearing today exploring Saudi financing of terrorism will focus on several Muslim charities that are closely linked to members of the Saudi royal family, groups that are also cited in classified sections of a Congressional report on the September 2001 hijackings, according to law enforcement officials and others with knowledge of the document.

title: Yankees Criticize Mondesi's Early Exit
description: They were careful to say some nice things about Raul Mondesi on Tuesday night, only hours after the right fielder had been expelled from the Yankees for insubordinate behavior.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Amtrak To Make Partial Refunds
description: Amtrak joined New Jersey Transit yesterday in issuing an apology and promising cash refunds to passengers who have endured significant delays this month. Downed power lines caused service disruptions and delays of up to six hours on Tuesday for riders on Amtrak's Northeast Corridor line. Yesterday, a letter signed by David L. Gunn, the president of Amtrak, and posted aboard all trains operating between Boston and Washington said passengers could send in their tickets for a refund of their expenses for travel affected by the delay. Last week, New Jersey Transit officials offered to refund 15 percent of the cost of the July monthly pass to commuters, to make up for several delays on its system. Maria Newman (NYT)

title: Finding (or Honing) the Cutting Edge
description: IT surprised me the first time a stranger approached as I was reading magazines at a checkout counter and gushed: ''I love your haircut! Who cuts your hair?''

title: 5 Plead Not Guilty to Charges Related to Seton Hall Dorm Fire
description: NEWARK, July 30  The two men charged with arson and murder in the Seton Hall University dormitory fire three years ago were arraigned today, along with a close friend and two relatives who are charged with obstructing the investigation and witness tampering.

title: British Airways and Unions Settle Costly Labor Dispute
description: British Airways and its trade unions said today that they reached a settlement over a dispute that led to a wildcat strike.

title: Unease Rises Over Motives Behind Raids In Russia
description: At first, investors shrugged off the series of raids on the periphery of the empire of Russia's richest man, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, as just a passing unpleasantness. Now, as the wrangle drags into its fourth week, investors are starting to worry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREEN, , BERNARD
description: GREEN--Bernard. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, Bernard Green and extends sincere sympathy to his wife, Barbara and other members of his family. Michael Stein, President Stephen Fiverson, Secretary >>AD#

title: City Files Lien Against Estate After Family Sues in Death
description: Before 6 a.m. on a frigid morning in November 2001, Gloria I. Brown, a 68-year-old woman with Alzheimer's disease, wandered out of her apartment in the Bronx. Her body was discovered four days later, in Manhattan, along the banks of the East River; a coroner's report said she had died of hypothermia.

title: A Wanderer In Search Of Solace
description: At Lincoln Center these days, it might be difficult to tell when one festival ends and another begins if someone didn't helpfully change the signs. Until Sunday the center had spent July presenting the Lincoln Center Festival; on Tuesday the curtain went up on the Mostly Mozart Festival. And instead of one opening, Mostly Mozart had two: in addition to the traditional opening-night orchestral concert, at Avery Fisher Hall, the festival presented a revival of the choreographer Trisha Brown's inventive staging of Schubert's ''Winterreise,'' sung by the English baritone Simon Keenlyside, at the John Jay College Theater.

title: U.S. Offers Resolution to Approve African Force for Liberia
description: The United States introduced a Security Council resolution today that would authorize the peacekeeping force being assembled by West African countries to enforce the shaky cease-fire in Liberia.

description: PARNES--Sidmore. Dearest friend. Love never forgotten. Davi

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Gowanus Included In River Cleanup Plan
description: Federal officials have selected the Gowanus Canal in New York and the Passaic River in New Jersey to be included in a pilot project that aims to clean up polluted urban waterways. The Urban Rivers Restoration Initiative, a joint project of the Environmental Protection Agency and the Army Corps of Engineers, will determine ways to clean up decades of industrial pollution, restore wildlife habitat and promote recreational activities. The initiative includes $50,000 grants for each project. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: Political Memo; Even a New Yorker's Money Can Talk With a Texas Twang
description: Members of New York's Congressional delegation are not exactly welcome here in the nation's capital these days, routinely written off as too brash, liberal and free-spending for the conservative ethos of this place.

title: Take Vacation Snapshots With Plenty of Do-Overs
description: Digital cameras usually sell for $200 and up, a lot more than their film equivalents. But Ritz Camera has begun to sell (and in Wisconsin, Walgreens is test-marketing) a single-use digital camera that costs about as much as, and works like, a disposable film camera. The Ritz Dakota Digital and the Studio 35 Digital from Walgreens hold 25 pictures with a two-megapixel resolution, enough for enlargements of up to 8 by 10 inches. That capacity need not be wasted on bad shots; users can delete a picture if they suspect it is flawed, creating room for retakes.

title: Catholic Church Installs New Boston Archbishop
description: In a venerable ceremony, the Rev. Sean P. O'Malley, a Capuchin friar, was installed today as the new archbishop of Boston, putting him in charge of efforts to restore a Roman Catholic Church rocked by a year and a half of revelations of sexual abuse by clergymen.

description: Bumpy Ride

title: 9/11 Will Echo in Campaign, but How Loudly?
description: A summer meeting of Republican leaders in New York last week featured not one but two welcoming speeches by Rudolph W. Giuliani. Those appearances by the symbol of the city's response to the World Trade Center attack were another reminder of one big reason the White House chose New York as the place where President Bush is to be nominated for re-election next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GELLER, , MIRIAM (MIMI)
description: GELLER -- Miriam (Mimi). Passed peacefully on July 27, 2003 in Pompano Beach, FL. Beloved to her family and dear friend of many; a true ''Woman of Valor.'' >>AD#

title: Manning Keeps Heisman Hype on Field
description: University of Mississippi quarterback Eli Manning is a legitimate Heisman Trophy candidate, but do not expect a showy campaign, ''Eli for Heisman'' posters or ''The Third Time's a Charm'' T-shirts.

title: A's Give Up Pitching To Get Guillen's Bat
description: Billy Beane did not express serious interest in Cincinnati's Jose Guillen until Tuesday, the day after the Reds fired their manager and general manager. But yesterday Beane, the savvy general manager of the Oakland Athletics, secured Guillen, the slugging outfielder, to give his pitching-rich club the hitter it needs desperately to help make a postseason run.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cingular-NextWave Deal
description: Cingular Wireless agreed to buy some wireless-spectrum licenses from the bankrupt NextWave Telecom for about $1.4 billion, people close to the matter said. The sale, which is subject to approval by a federal bankruptcy court and the Federal Communications Commission, would be NextWave's first transaction since it won a Supreme Court battle in January over ownership of the licenses. Cingular, based in Atlanta, is owned by SBC Communications and the BellSouth Corporation. Michael Wack, senior vice president at NextWave, and a Cingular spokeswoman, Jennifer Bowcock, declined to comment. Nextwave, based in Greenwich, Conn., won the licenses in a 1996 auction but filed for bankruptcy protection in 1998.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Court Reform Urged
description: A coalition of civic groups is calling on county political leaders, who control the election of judges across the state, to open the selection process to public scrutiny and participation. The coalition, the Committee for Modern Courts, released its recommendations yesterday, including creating independent panels to choose judicial candidates, increasing disclosure of campaign donations, and expanding efforts to inform voters about judicial candidates. Problems in Brooklyn, where a State Supreme Court justice was recently indicted and a grand jury is looking into how judges are selected, are giving new impetus to efforts to change the system, said Fern Schair, the coalition chairwoman. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Pinnacle Shares Fall 37%
description: Shares of Pinnacle Systems, which makes video-editing software, fell 37 percent yesterday after the company said that it would invest more heavily in product development and that fourth-quarter profit was lower than analysts' forecasts. Profit rose 32 percent, to $5.90 million, or 9 cents a share, in the quarter ended June 30, excluding amortization of acquisition-related assets, Pinnacle said. On that basis, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial was 10 cents. Pinnacle will develop products to reach the 85 percent of consumers who have not switched to digital camcorders from analog models, a spokesman, Bob Wilson, said in an interview. The company also wants to meet the demands of broadcasters who are shifting to digital production. The chief executive, Kim Fennell, said these steps could hurt profits in the short term, ''but I'm confident they will pay off later.'' Pinnacle shares fell $4.67, to $7.82.

title: Slain Councilman's Brother Takes His Spot on Ballot
description: Geoffrey A. Davis, the brother of the slain City Councilman James E. Davis, made his candidacy official yesterday, substituting his name for that of the late councilman with the New York City Board of Elections.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Sales Confidence Gains
description: British retail sales and consumer confidence climbed in July, easing fears of an economy-crippling slowdown in consumer spending. The Confederation of British Industry said that the number of retailers surveyed reporting an increase in sales, minus those reporting a decline, rose to 27 percent from 10 percent a month ago.

title: Dying in Iraq
description: Those are good kids that we're sending into the shooting gallery called Iraq, and unless you have the conviction of a Bush or a Rumsfeld or a Bechtel or a Halliburton, you have to be nursing the sick feeling that each death is a tragic waste, and that this conflict is as much of a fool's errand as the war in Vietnam.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: PLANS TO TRY OFFICER AGAIN Prosecutors said they would seek a second trial for a former Inglewood police officer after a mistrial was declared when a jury deadlocked on whether he was guilty of assaulting a teenager. The officer, Jeremy Morse, was videotaped punching and slamming the handcuffed teenager onto a squad car. District Attorney Steve Cooley of Los Angeles County said he would ask the judge to schedule a trial within 60 days. The jury, which said it had deadlocked 7-5 in favor of conviction, acquitted Mr. Morse's partner, Bijan Darvish, of filing a false report. (AP)

title: Tiara Time Again After Trauma at City Hall
description: She wore her tiara again yesterday afternoon, and beamed as cameras clicked and city leaders handed out proclamations, but 12-year-old Jasmine Pineda still cannot drive the gunshots from her dreams.

title: Lottery Numbers
World Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: INTELLIGENCE CHIEF QUITS Brig. Gen. Victor Corpus, the chief of military intelligence, resigned and became the first high official to step down after a failed mutiny last weekend by 300 officers and soldiers demanding military reforms. The mutineers accused General Corpus of incompetence and involvement in a recent bombing campaign. He denied the charges but said he would resign to quell dissent. (AP)

title: U.S. Agency Scales Back Data Required On Air Travel
description: The Homeland Security Department said tonight that it was scaling back the scope of the information it planned to collect on airline passengers as part of a new security system to determine who are potential terrorists who require more thorough screening.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Minister Urges Fines
description: The European Union must fine France and Germany should they breach the bloc's deficit limit for a third year in 2004, and failure to penalize them may lead to ''serious trouble,'' the Dutch finance minister, Gerrit Zalm, said yesterday. Under rules intended to protect the euro, European Union countries may be fined up to 0.5 percent of gross domestic product for deficits higher than 3 percent of G.D.P. France and Germany, close to recession, have overstepped that limit for two years. President Jacques Chirac of France this month called for a suspension of the rule and Chancellor Gerhard Schrder of Germany said meeting it in 2004 would be difficult. The Netherlands, Austria and Finland, which are taking steps to curb their deficits, say the European Commission must apply the rules to everyone.

title: The Burden Is on the Giants' Defense
description: No Giants defensive players like hearing that the defense is only as good as its last game.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Unilever Sales Drop
description: Unilever, the British-Dutch consumer products giant, yesterday attributed a double-digit slide in its second-quarter sales and net income to a weak dollar and revamping costs, but it remained upbeat about coming quarters, forecasting at least a 10 percent jump in annual profit. Second-quarter net income dropped 18 percent to 564 million euros ($639.5 million) compared with the same period a year ago. Revenue fell 13 percent to 11.1 billion euros. Sales of leading brands, including Dove soap, are expected to grow 4 percent this year, the company said.

title: Times Editor to Select Reader Representative
description: Bill Keller, the new executive editor of The New York Times, announced yesterday that he would soon name a ''public editor'' to serve as a representative for the newspaper's readers.

title: Aetna Profits Are Up 28% As Health Insurers Prosper
description: Riding a wave of growing prosperity in health insurance, Aetna reported a 28 percent increase in profit in the second quarter, joining three other industry giants that have reported better-than-expected results in the last two weeks.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Strike Cripples Bombay
description: A strike over a terrorist bombing paralyzed Bombay yesterday, affecting businesses and paring financial market transactions. The bomb explosion in a suburban bus on Monday killed two people and wounded nearly 50. The city police attributed the attack -- the latest in a series of bombings in buses and trains since December -- to an offshoot of Lashkar-e-Toiba, the Pakistan-based militant group that is demanding freedom for Kashmir. Hundreds of advocates belonging to the right-wing political party Shiv Sena as well as the Bharatiya Janata Party of Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, above, enforced the strike in the city as they stopped public transport and shut down businesses. Saritha Rai (NYT)

description: Two batters into tonight's New Jersey State Little League championship game, Freehold Township American Manager Anthony Cirillo knew that Ridgewood National was going to have a tough time hitting against his pitcher, Chris Bresnahan.

title: Bush Backs Bid To Block Gays From Marrying
description: President Bush said today that while he believed Americans should treat gays in a welcoming and respectful manner, he remained firmly opposed to gay marriages and that administration lawyers were working to ensure that the term ''marriage'' would cover only unions between men and women.

title: Charging Into Strange Tunnels of Sound
description: I suppose you could analyze Marcus Roberts's late set at the Vanguard on Tuesday by starting with the list of standards he chose to play, but it would be a waste of time: most of the performance rumbled along on the deeper levels where improvisers, not composers, live.

title: Vatican Says Lawmakers Have Duty to Oppose Gay Marriage
description: VATICAN CITY, July 31  Worried about the spread of laws that recognize same-sex couples, the Vatican today urged Roman Catholic lawmakers and others to fight back, calling support for such legislation "gravely immoral."

description: COHN--Ruth. On July 29. Adored wife of Samy Cohn, mother of Hedy Erbsen, sister of Nina Weiner, grandmother of Allan and Michael Erbsen, mother-in-law of Claude E. Erbsen, sister-inlaw of Walter H. Weiner. Funeral services will be held in Rio de Janerio, Brazil. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society, Memorial Sloane Kettering Cancer Center or Weizman Institute of Science in Israel. >>AD#

title: Fleet Trading Unit Agrees to Pay Fine
description: The FleetBoston Financial Corporation will pay the New York Stock Exchange a fine of $150,000, and its chief trader in General Motors stock will pay $25,000 to settle accusations that the bank's market-making unit violated trading rules.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Nebraska: C.D.C. Seeks To Revoke Doctor's License
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is trying to have a Nebraska doctor's medical license revoked on the ground that his practices may have caused the spread of hepatitis C among at least 99 of his patients. One woman died from hepatitis and another disease, the centers said. The doctor, Tahir Ali Javed, formerly of Fremont, is now in Pakistan. He is accused of gross negligence, having sexual relationships with his patients, reusing syringes and improperly supervising nurses. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

description: Big Pickup Trucks Grow In Both Size and Popularity

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MARATHON OIL CORP., Houston, an oil and gas producer and refiner, raised its quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share from 23 cents a share payable on Sept. 10 to stockholders of record on Aug. 20.

title: GOODYEAR SAYS QUARTER SWUNG TO LOSS ON HIGHER COSTS
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, North America's largest tire maker, reported a second-quarter loss of $73.6 million yesterday on higher prices for raw materials like rubber and oil. Sales increased 8 percent as the company sold more higher-priced tires in its home region. The net loss of 42 cents a share is in contrast to net income of $28.9 million, or 18 cents, in the period last year. Shares in Goodyear, which is based in Akron, Ohio, rose 7.1 percent as the company said its quarterly revenue per tire rose in North America and the industry's June replacement sales in the region were up. Goodyear shares rose 37 cents, to $5.54. The stock has declined 20 percent this year.
