title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCRARY, , JOHN ''TEX''
description: McCRARY--John ''Tex''. The North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System is greatly saddened by the passing of John ''Tex'' McCrary, a renowned publicist, radio and television personality, and political activist. He was one of the founders of North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset in 1953, serving for decades as a trustee of the hospital and later as a lifetime trustee of the North Shore-LIJ Health System. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Jinx Falkenburg, a former actress who was Mr. McCrary's co-host on the popular radio show ''Hi Jinx,'' and also a longtime trustee of North Shore University Hospital and the health system. We also offer our sympathies to their sons Michael, Kevin and John. Roy J. Zuckerberg, Chairman Michael J. Dowling, President & CEO North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: Threshold; HDTV for Less Than $1,000
description: FOR the first time, consumers can buy a decent-size high-definition set for under $1,000, and as the winter holidays approach, consumers will probably be bombarded with sales and promotions aimed at getting high-definition sets under trees across the country.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Siemens To Cut Jobs
description: The German electronics group Siemens plans to cut 2,300 jobs in its information and communication mobile unit by September 2004 as part of a revamping program to reduce costs by one billion euros ($1.13 billion), the company said. Five hundred jobs would go in Germany alone. Parallel to the cost cuts, the company intends to invest in advanced mobile communication technologies like GSM, EDGE and UMTS in order to expand its market position, particularly in Eastern Europe, Asia and Latin America. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Lord & Taylor To Shut Stores And Cut Jobs
description: Lord & Taylor, trying to recapture its aura as department store for the Junior League set, is closing 32 stores, more than one-third of its total nationally, and laying off 3,700 employees. Lord & Taylor, owned by the giant May Department Stores chain, is abandoning whole states -- like Florida and Texas -- after becoming mired in a losing competition with lower-priced stores like J. C. Penney and Kohl's.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BLUMBERG, , EDWARD J.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Wireless In More McDonald's
description: Cometa Networks said yesterday that it would add 15 McDonald's restaurants to its wireless Internet networks in the New York metropolitan area. Sixty restaurants already offer access, which is free through August and will then cost $2.99 a day. Cometa, which has investments from AT&T, I.B.M. and Intel, connected the first 10 McDonald's outlets in Manhattan in March. Cometa confirmed its plan to build 20,000 wireless Internet ''hot spots'' throughout the United States within two years. The first large-scale trial of wireless Internet by McDonald's started this month in the San Francisco Bay area, where Wayport operates networks in 75 restaurants. McDonald's said that a test in Chicago would begin next month. Glenn Fleishman (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Call For Pardons In Tulia
description: The parole board recommended that the governor pardon 35 people convicted on drug charges in Tulia on the word of an undercover agent whose testimony has since been discredited. The agent, Tom Coleman, has been accused of racism and faces perjury charges. Forty-six people, most of them black, were arrested in 1999 based solely on his undercover work. Texas's highest court for criminal matters is separately considering a judge's recommendation that the convictions of the defendants, who have all either served their sentences or are free on bond, be overturned. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Corrections

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Store's Shares Seized
description: The Dutch food retailer Royal Ahold said yesterday that an Argentine court had seized the shares of its supermarket chain Disco, potentially blocking a planned sale of the unit. The seizure was made at the request of creditors and depositors at Banco Montevideo, a bank in Uruguay that was once tied to an Ahold partner in South America, the Velox Group. Ahold, which owns Stop & Shop, Giant and Tops in the United States, said that it was confident it could get a judge to reverse the ruling within days. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

description: The Cigna Corporation hired Goldman Sachs Group Inc. to arrange the sale of its pension business for as much as $2 billion, people close to the situation said yesterday. Cigna shares rose 8.5 percent on the news. Cigna is trying to raise capital after two credit-rating cuts since October. Shares of Cigna gained $3.57, to $45.37, in New York Stock Exchange trading. A Cigna spokesman, Wendell Potter, and Lucas Van Praag, a Goldman spokesman, declined to comment.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Candidate Makes Environmental Pitch
description: Howard Dean, a Democratic presidential candidate, is calling for the auto industry to build cars that get 40 miles per gallon by 2015 and for 20 percent of the nation's electricity to come from renewable sources by 2020. In an environmental speech prepared for delivery in San Francisco on Thursday, Dr. Dean, the former Vermont governor, also says that as president he would close the loophole that exempts sport utility vehicles from gas-mileage standards. He says he would make the Environmental Protection Agency cabinet level and work to re-establish the Clinton administration rules limiting roads in national forests. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

description: Those betting that Japan's economy was on the mend were dealt a setback today when two of the country's largest technology companies reported weak quarterly results and figures showed industrial production unexpectedly falling in June.

title: A Controller Grows, Making Room For a Keyboard
description: Online multiplayer games like EverQuest rely as much on communication as they do on game playing. While PC gamers always have a keyboard handy for chatting with fellow players, game console controllers are not designed to enable typed conversation. Until now, console users have had to use the game controller to peck out a message on a game's virtual keyboard or attach a standard keyboard to the console and hop from controller to keyboard.

title: Cable or Satellite? Please Stay Tuned
description: MICHAEL G. MANSOUR, a 28-year-old Manhattan financial professional, used to watch television the way most people do. For his favorite shows, like ''The Sopranos,'' he would make a point of being home when they were scheduled. If the show was something he more or less liked, he would put up with the commercials. If he felt like watching a movie, he went to the video store.

title: The President's News Conference; Playing It Safe on Gays
description: Given his treasured reputation for compassion and the strong feelings of his conservative base, President Bush took what may have been the safest route when he was asked about homosexuality at yesterday's press conference. Mr. Bush spoke about the need to be ''a welcoming country,'' then denounced gay marriages. He added that he had ''lawyers looking at the best way'' to bar same-sex unions. Instead of covering all the bases, we wish the president would show himself willing to spend more of his political capital on inclusiveness.

description: Last year, they were a group of guys with a few dollars and a dream who told the other regulars at the Carousel bar behind the clubhouse at Saratoga Race Course that they had a really nice 2-year-old who was going to get them into the winner's circle. When Funny Cide did, they promised, the drinks would be on them. They never had to pay up -- the chestnut gelding caught a cough last summer and did not make it to the track.

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC SAYS ITS NET INCOME NEARLY TRIPLED
description: The American Electric Power Company, owner of utilities from Ohio to Texas, said yesterday that profit almost tripled from a year earlier, when the company recorded losses on the sale of utilities in Britain and Australia. Net income rose to $175.3 million, or 44 cents a share, from $61.9 million, or 19 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Revenue rose 2.8 percent, to $3.7 billion from $3.6 billion. Shares of American Electric, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, rose 2 cents, to $27.78. The stock has fallen 17 percent in the last year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Kills Wife and Himself
description: An East Flatbush man strangled and bludgeoned his wife in bed yesterday morning before stabbing himself to death with a knife, the police said. There was no history of domestic violence between the couple, the police said. The bodies of the husband, Edward Alexis, 42, a Haitian immigrant, and his wife, Marie Alexis, 39, were discovered by Mrs. Alexis's cousin, who came to the apartment on East 28th Street about 8:20 a.m. The couple shared the apartment with their two sons, 15 and 11, said the apartment building's superintendent, Oret Smith. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAPP, , STEVEN M.
description: PAPP--Steven M. Steven Papp was Deputy Director for Administration at New York State Psychiatric Institute for 25 years. He was also, for a number of years, the Director of Administration of the Research Foundation for Mental Hygiene, Inc at the NYSPI and an Associate Vice President in the Faculty of Medicine of Columbia University. His extraordinary administrative talents and creative leadership were instrumental in developing & maintaining the excellence in research, education and clinical care for which NYSPI is known. In an intricate and complex environment, Steven Papp was a master in balancing the urgent and competing needs of researchers and clinicians, State and University, patients and staff. His daily virtues included fairness, tolerance, tenacity, patience with essential minutiae, impatience with humbug, and a tremendous sense of humor. He is dearly loved by all who had the opportunity to work with him. His wit, wisdom, and huge fund of institutional knowledge will be sorely missed by the entire PI communmity. The loss of Steven Papp as colleague, friend and mentor at PI is second only to the loss to his family of a wonderful husband, father, son, and brother. Our hearts go out to the Papp family along with the assurance that Steven Papp will live on in the memories of his co-workers and in the history of this Institution. B. Timothy Walsh, M.D. Interim Director NYSPI

A smaller group, like the Orchestra of St. Luke's, has a tougher time. Given its status as an orchestra-for-hire, many of its concerts are not even its own concerts -- not even the celebration of its 25th season at the Caramoor International Music Festival this summer. St. Luke's was founded at Caramoor in 1979; and it was Caramoor that presented its commemorative concert, under Caramoor's artistic director, Peter Oundjian, on Sunday afternoon.

description: Throughout his political career, George Bush has been famous for sticking to a few issues, and repeating a few well-burnished talking points over and over. Wide-ranging news conferences do not play to his considerable strengths, and as president, he has generally avoided them. But having decided to make a rare exception yesterday, Mr. Bush should have been able to come up with better responses to two big and obvious questions: why he ordered the invasion of Iraq and why he pushed for tax cuts that have left the nation sinking into a hopeless quagmire of debt.

description: GREEN--Bernard R. The partners and staff of Friedman Alpren & Green LLP are saddened by the loss of Bernard R. Green, one of our founding partners. His leadership, integrity, eternal optimism and forward thinking gave our firm a strong foundation. He was a mentor to many of us, encouraged our efforts and unselfishly shared his experiences. His long-standing relationships with clients and friends of the firm is a testimony to his ongoing personal involvement and concern for our continued success. We will sorely miss his wisdom, his vision, his humor and his love and dedication to the firm. Our sympathy to his wife Barbara and children Shirley and Bob Dembner and Andrea and Andrew Koslov and their families. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about far-reaching legislation proposed in the European Union to outlaw sexual discrimination misspelled the name of a deputy manager for the European Federation of the Insurance Industry, who said that changing the gender component of risk calculation would wreak havoc with the industry. He is William Vidonja, not Vidoja.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CASIN, , HARRIETTE M.
description: CASIN--Harriette M. On July 28, 2003. Wife of the late Irving. Most beloved and best friend of Wendy Rosenbloom and the late Joan Berlan. Loving sister of Oscar Merber. Cherished grandmother of Jeffrey and Debbie; and Daniel. Great-grandmother of Sarah and Samantha. Adored aunt. Services Friday 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. >>AD#

title: Bet on Terror? Not Now, Not Ever (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush, at Medicare Birthday, Asks Again for Drug Benefits
description: President Bush paid tribute today to Lyndon B. Johnson as the father of Medicare, saying he wanted to build on Johnson's legacy by signing a bill to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare this year.

title: Big and Fancy, More Pickups Displace Cars
description: Jason Lawson had a big pickup, but like a growing number of Americans he recently traded up to an even bigger one.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the scaled-back ambitions of Bertelsmann misattributed a quotation about the possibility that an investment concern controlled by the Belgian financier Albert Frere, which owns a 25 percent stake in the company, would exercise its right to compel Bertelsmann to do an initial offering of that stake. It was Mr. Frere, not Bertelsmann's chief executive, Gunter Thielen, who said: ''If the company is not doing well, why should I sell, because I won't get a lot of money for it? And if the company is in good shape, why should I sell?''

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BREWER UPBEAT ON RESULTS SAB Miller, the brewer, yesterday described positive results for the three months ended June 30, as warm weather in Europe prompted more beer consumption. At the annual general meeting, the chief executive, Graham Mackay, said that the company had "strong performance" in the quarter, and that South African earnings rose more than expected because of the rand's strength against the dollar. The company will report first-half profits in November.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PORIS, , THEODORE BERYL
description: PORIS--Theodore Beryl. Unexpectedly, at 5:22 AM July 28, 2003. Beloved husband of Jane, adoring father of Hope and Howard, loving brother of Norman. Dear friend, successful businessman, and Masonic brother. >>AD#

title: The Rangers Sign Leetch To a Two-Year Contract
description: After 16 years as one of the best defensemen in the National Hockey League, Brian Leetch became an unrestricted free agent a month ago, free to sign with any team.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Harvard Paper Wants Police Data
description: The Harvard Crimson and the American Civil Liberties Union have sued Harvard University, asking for police records to be released to the newspaper. The suit contends that although Harvard operates a full-service police department, the university says that because it is private it does not have to comply with public records laws. Amit R. Paley, the Crimson editor, says students have a right to the information. In a statement, the university said it believed its procedures complied with the law. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: U.S. Mailing Checks For Child Tax Credit
description: The Treasury Department has begun mailing out more than 25 million checks to families getting $400-a-child refunds as a result of an increase in the child tax credit. President Bush and Republican lawmakers are hoping that those taxpayers will be moved to spend, spend, spend.

title: Clemens Completely Controls The Angels
description: The argument can still be made that this is an imperfect team. The Yankees need a big bat, preferably attached to a man who can play right field, and the addition of a dependable setup man would be a major plus. But on nights when Roger Clemens pitches like this, the Yankees do not need anything other than his ageless right arm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OLBERT, , VICTOR
description: OLBERT--Victor. The Board of Directors of East Hampton House Owners, Ltd. expresses its deep sadness on the loss of our long time board member. Victor was a true gentleman, much admired for his wisdom, his kindness and his generous spirit. Joyce M. Pilsner, President >>AD#

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Ex-President's Extradition Sought
description: The government is formally requesting that Japan extradite former President Alberto Fujimori, who is wanted on corruption and rights abuse charges, officials said. A 700-page extradition request was to be delivered in Tokyo this morning, local time. After ruling Peru with an iron hand for a decade, Mr. Fujimori fled in 2000 to Japan, his parent's homeland, after a wide-ranging corruption scandal. Japan and Peru do not have an extradition treaty, but Peru is hoping that Tokyo will be swayed by the extradition request. Mr. Fujimori, who has started a political movement in Peru to pave the way for his return, denies the charges. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Vatican Says Lawmakers Have Duty to Oppose Gay Marriage
description: VATICAN CITY, July 31 — Worried about the spread of laws that recognize same-sex couples, the Vatican today urged Roman Catholic lawmakers and others to fight back, calling support for such legislation "gravely immoral."

title: Panel Urges Quick Pictures Of Shuttles In Launchings
description: NASA must do a better job of getting quick pictures of the space shuttle's fragile heat shields and external fuel tank during liftoff, the independent board investigating the loss of the shuttle Columbia recommended yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Irishmen Deny Training Rebels
description: Three Irishmen accused of offering explosives training to leftist rebels appeared for the first time at their trial in Bogot, nearly two years after they were arrested. The three, Niall Connolly, Martin McCauley and Jim Monaghan, told the court they had come to Colombia to study a peace process then in the works with Marxist rebels, not to teach the insurgents bomb-making techniques, as the Colombian government contends. Until now, the men had refused to appear, arguing that they could not receive a fair hearing. The government claims that they are members of the Irish Republican Army. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Not-Guilty Pleas In Dorm Fire
description: The two men charged with arson and murder in the Seton Hall University dormitory fire three years ago were arraigned yesterday, along with a close friend and two relatives who are charged with obstructing the investigation and witness tampering. All five entered not guilty pleas before Judge Harold W. Fullilove in State Superior Court. The January 2000 fire in Boland Hall on the Seton Hall campus in South Orange, N.J., killed 3 freshmen and injured 50 other students. The two men charged with arson and murder, Joseph T. Lepore and Sean Ryan, both 22, were allowed to remain free on bail of $2 million and $1.2 million, respectively, which was set after their arrests and indictment last month. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: African Held for War Crimes Dies in Custody of a Tribunal
description: Foday Sankoh, the warlord from Sierra Leone who made mutilations his signature weapon of war and came to symbolize the face of deranged cruelty, died on Tuesday night in the custody of a United Nations-backed war crimes tribunal, officials of the court announced today.

title: Power in a Siren, Mary Magdalene and Church Ladies in Training
description: Commitment and passion are key ingredients in the performing of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. Both were evident in an evening of new dances on Saturday at the Ailey studios by current and former company members to raise money for the Ailey Dancers' Resource Fund for career transitions. What was unexpected was the authority and imagination of the work by mostly fledgling choreographers.

title: Newark Man, 20, Is Shot to Death by a Police Officer at a Cookout
description: A young man was shot to death by a police officer at a parking lot cookout in Newark last night after he pulled a gun and aimed it at officers, the police said.

title: AT HOME WITH: Jeannine Oppewall; Thoroughbred Modern
description: FOR 10 years Jeannine Oppewall lived in a dark one-bedroom bungalow built here during World War II for aircraft workers at McDonnell Douglas. And, she said, for those 10 years, she never invited anyone over. Nor did she consider this behavior odd. Ms. Oppewall, who designed the sets for ''Seabiscuit,'' was raised a Calvinist and accepted a certain level of austerity in life. ''Jeannine and I both came from a background where our churches looked like courtrooms,'' said the director Paul Schrader, her former husband.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUSSIANOFF, , LILY
description: RUSSIANOFF--Lily. Beloved mother of Ira and Gene. Grandmother of Natalie and Jennie. Widow of Richard. She will be missed by friends and family. Born in New York City in 1924 to Fanny and Louis Apt. She loved New York, its politics and its people. Services Friday at 12:30 at The Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. >>AD#

title: S.E.C. Investigates Bulk Sales Of AOL Internet Subscriptions
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has asked the America Online division of AOL Time Warner to provide documents about its bulk subscription program, according to a person close to the company.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Acting Chief For Trinity College
description: A history professor at Trinity College has been named acting president of the school after Richard Hersh resigned over faculty complaints about his leadership. The professor, Borden W. Painter Jr., a Trinity alumnus and former chairman of the history department, takes office on Monday. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: A Mailbag of Thurber, From Fond to Scathing
description: THE THURBER LETTERS

title: All Bets Are Off
description: The so-called terrorism futures market sounded like a hoax: investors would have been able to make money from attacks and strife. Now that the red-faced Pentagon has closed down the project, it's appropriate to ask, ''What were they thinking?''

title: The Culture of Disease
description: There are too many positive gay role models. In fighting the AIDS crisis over the last 20 years, we have done everything possible to dispel the negative connotations that come with having H.I.V. After all, it's been our brothers and sisters, our boyfriends and girlfriends, and ourselves who have been discriminated against because of a virus.

title: INSIDE
description: Britain's Leader Under Fire

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Beach Grasses for Fire Island

title: Buffett Wins Battle to Buy Clayton Homes
description: Berkshire Hathaway won a protracted battle yesterday to take over Clayton Homes, a mobile home maker, after shareholders voted by a slim margin to accept its $1.7 billion bid.

title: A New Wardrobe for Water or Something Stronger
description: The elegantly thin Jasper glasses (left) come in colors reminiscent of 1930's Vaseline glass -- and you don't have to use a Geiger counter to check for that pesky uranium that was used to produce the originals. The glassware is part of a collection designed for Salton by Thomas O'Brien, the owner of Aero Studios in SoHo. The line also includes dishes, mixing bowls and serving bowls -- more than 90 pieces, all open stock, so you can mix and match.

title: First Study on Patients Who Fast to End Lives
description: In her 23 years of nursing, Maria LaTrace had only one such case: a dying woman who decided to hasten her death by going without food or water.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Countess of Paris on July 14 misspelled the English-language version of her name. She was Isabel of Orlans and Braganza, not Bragana.

title: Mideast Roads, And Israel's Fence
description: To the Editor:

title: Suit Says Machines Missed 60,000 Votes in 2000 Race
description: The votes of as many as 60,000 people in New York City may not have been counted in the 2000 presidential election because of an adjustment made to city voting machines back in 1964, according to a lawsuit filed yesterday by advocacy groups.

title: Youngsters Sing Along, Grown-Ups Stay Sane
description: The scene on a recent Saturday was the 3,200-seat outdoor pavilion at the Ravinia Festival here, the venerable summer home of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. But on this day it had been turned into a mosh pit. Young fans rushed toward the stage, dancing and hopping about. Several giddy ones were clinging to the side of the stage. Some were shouting ''Justin! Justin!'' to the star onstage, yelling out requests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICHTER, , SIDNEY
description: RICHTER--Sidney, 95. Esteemed New York attorney and civil engineer, involved in development of NY highway system 1950s-1970s. Beloved husband of Jenny, father of Stephen and Paul Hammer, brother of Lily and an avid obituary reader (this one's for you, Pop). Sid, though you stopped building highways long ago, the roads you built for us will remain our guiding paths forever. Thank you for coming to Earth during our lifetimes. Private services, burial at Beth Moses. Your loving family, extended family and many, many admirers. >>AD#

title: Impath Says It Is Investigating Accounting
description: Impath, which analyzes cancer tests for doctors, is investigating whether it improperly overstated money owed by customers. Two officials have left the company, which may report a net loss this year.

title: Poolside Furnishings for the Splashy Season
description: WHAT could be more pleasurable than a midsummer afternoon by the pool? Swimmers and loungers alike will be more relaxed if they are surrounded by rubber tiles to cushion the deck, clever seating and stacks of fluffy towels.

title: Noses Held, Budget Passes In Hartford
description: The Connecticut House of Representatives passed a two-year budget tonight that raises taxes and cuts spending mainly for the state's poorest, leaving lawmakers on both sides of the aisle muttering about how it was a bad deal that they supported only to end a stalemate that had dragged on for months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PHILIPS, , KAYE
description: PHILIPS--Kaye, who died at her Guilderland home July 28th, was an active participant in local and national events. She was very proud of her service from 1973-81 as assistant to the late U.S. Senator Jacob K. Javits, and head of his Albany, NY office. She also helped organize local and national campaigns for Presidential candidates. From 1981-89, she was intergovernmental liaison and director of the majority leader's New York State Senate Appointments Office. Mrs. Philips, a devoted wife and mother, cared for her attorney husband, the late Irving Philips, during his 14 years of illness. Surviving family members include daughter Janet Philips, her husband, Larry Zeides, and three-yearold grandson, Ian, along with many nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at the Levine Memorial Chapel, 649 Washington Avenue, at 4 P.M., Sunday, August 3rd. >>AD#

title: On the Nature of Hens
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A dance listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for Summer in the Square gave an incorrect date and time for Lori Belilove and Company's performance of ''The Art of Isadora'' in Union Square Park, in Manhattan. It is next Wednesday at 4 p.m.; it was not yesterday.

title: Who Owns the Media?
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Every Surface Feels the Tendrils' Touch
description: SUZY BALES cannot look at a wall or a post without seeing a flowering vine climbing over it. Honeysuckle and roses, barely tamed, clamber over the front door of the rambling 1906 stucco house that she and her husband, Carter F. Bales, have here. They found the house 25 years ago on a winding road on Centre Island, a peninsula reached by causeway from Bayville, where it crooks like an elbow around Oyster Bay Harbor. On this stretch of the North Shore, money is still quietly enjoyed behind great old shade trees and ivy-covered walls.

title: Bronx 'Nightmare': Close 6 Garages, Extract 6,700 Cars, Try to Park
description: In New York City, to park is to suffer. Of all the small indignities that haunt the city dweller, none perhaps is quite so troublesome as looking for a spot.

title: A Fed Survey Sees More Hints Of a Revival
description: The economy offered some signs of faster growth in the last six weeks, including early evidence of a pickup in manufacturing, the Federal Reserve said yesterday in a survey of regional economies.

title: Shares Decline on Technology Losses; Treasuries Advance
description: Shares of many computer-related companies fell yesterday, pulling down the broader stock market. Treasury bond prices rose sharply.

title: Fortifying the In Box as Spammers Lay Siege
description: WHILE Congress continues to struggle with just how strict to make laws that regulate unwanted e-mail, technology is evolving to curb it, or at least separate the wheat from the chaff.

title: Palestinians Must Bear Burden of Peace, DeLay Tells Israelis
description: Calling himself ''an Israeli at heart,'' Tom DeLay, the House majority leader, told Israeli legislators today that the burden for achieving peace here rested with the Palestinians, who he said must eradicate terrorism.

title: CHUBB REPORTS 20% JUMP IN SECOND-QUARTER NET INCOME
description: The Chubb Corporation, one of the biggest insurers of homes and businesses, reported a 20 percent rise in net income for the second quarter yesterday, the latest indication of continued strong pricing for property casualty insurance. The net income of $252.1 million was up from $210.2 million for the period a year earlier and set a record for quarterly earnings at the company. With the insurance business booming, John D. Finnegan, the chief executive of Chubb, noted the company raised $1.3 billion in a securities offering last month. The money, he said, would be used to back increased sales. ''The biggest contributor to this quarter was commercial insurance,'' said Mark Greenberg, a spokesman. ''We had tremendous premium growth. We're still getting rate increases, and we're writing tons of new business.'' Joseph B. Treaster (NYT)

title: Ousted Priest Wistfully Departs
description: Nearly 300 priests around the country have been removed from their duties since January as a result of the church's sexual abuse scandals. As the Rev. Thomas DeVita appeals his case to the Vatican, his parishioners remain divided on whether he should be reinstated.

title: Pets on the Go
description: For lucky four-footers who get to hit the road with their owners, being prepared is paramount.

title: At the Source
description: In Donaueschingen, Germany, a kind of unity is emerging after centuries of strife.

title: From Expressionism to the Bauhaus
description: Looking at this selection of German art at the Neue Galerie, it's hard not to think about the background of creative ferment that culminated in the rise of Nazism.
